speaker: Yes, I can’t get my stupid door open.
response: You appear to have put your car key in the door lock, are you aware of that?

speaker: Yeah!
response: Alright then. (Turns to return inside. One of the grocery bags Penny is holding falls to the floor spilling groceries.)

speaker: Dammit, dammit, dammit, dammit, dammit, dammit.
response: Would it be possible for you to do this a little more quietly?

speaker: I can’t get the damned key out.
response: Well that’s not surprising. That Baldwin lock on your door uses traditional edge mounted cylinders, whereas the key for your Volkswagon uses a centre cylinder system.

speaker: Thankyou, Sheldon.
response: You’re welcome. Point of inquiry, why did you put your car key in the door lock?

speaker: Why? I’ll tell you why. Because today I had an audition, it took me two hours to get there, I waited an hour for my turn, and before I could even start they told me I looked too Midwest for the part. Too Midwest? What the hell does that even mean?
response: Well, the American Midwest was mostly settled by Scandinavian and Germanic peoples who, well they have a characteristic facial bone structure….

speaker: I know what it means, Sheldon! God, you know, I have been in L.A. for almost two years now, and I haven’t got a single acting job, I have accomplished nothing, haven’t gotten a raise at work, haven’t even had sex in six months, and just now when I was walking up those stairs a fly flew in my mouth and I ate it.
response: Well, actually, insects are a dietary staple in many cultures, they’re almost pure protein.

speaker: Oh, sonofabitch!
response: I believe the condensation on your frozen foods weakened the structural integrity of the bag. But returning to your key conundrum, perhaps you should call a locksmith and have him open the door for you.

speaker: I did, and he said he’ll get here when he gets here.
response: And you’re frustrated because he phrased his reply in the form of a meaningless tautology?

speaker: No! I am frustrated because I am a failure at everything and my breath smells like fly. (Bursts into tears.)
response: There there. (Reluctantly) Would you prefer to wait in our apartment?

speaker: No Sheldon, I’d rather sit on this freezing cold floor sobbing like a three year-old.
response: Alright then. (Turns to go inside again.)

speaker: For God’s sake! (Stomps into apartment.)
response: Just when I think I’ve gotten the hang of sarcasm.

speaker: Sheldor?
response: The Conqueror.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: AFK. I’m playing Age of Conan, an online multiplayer game set in the universe of Robert E. Howard’s Conan the Barbarian.

speaker: Oh.
response: Sheldor, back online.

speaker: What’s AFK?
response: AFK. Away from keyboard.

speaker: OIC.
response: What does that stand for?

speaker: Oh, I see?
response: Yes, but what does it stand for?

speaker: Oh, I don’t know. Can I see them in another colour?
response: Just click on them. Congratulations, you are now a level three warrior.

speaker: Uh-huh, yeah, do I stay in the jungle or go towards the beach?
response: It doesn’t matter, right now you’re looking for treasure.

speaker: Okay. (Leonard motions for Sheldon to talk in the kitchen.) Wait, wait, where are you going?
response: You’re okay, if you run into crocodiles just kick them with your boots.

speaker: Want to catch me up?
response: Well let’s see, uh, she attempted to open her apartment with her car key, because her face is overly Midwestern, um, she hasn’t had sex in six months, and she ate a fly.

speaker: Oh my God, a treasure chest, I’m rich!
response: Level three and she thinks she’s rich! What a noob.

speaker: Hey, check it out, it’s just corn starch and water.
response: They make up a non-Newtonian fluid which is liquid, but solid under the percussive action of the speaker.

speaker: Okay, look, I bought the game, and I’ve been exploring the Island of Tordage but I can’t figure out how to get past the guard captain.
response: Do you have the enchanted sword?

speaker: No, no, I’ve a bronze dagger.
response: You can’t slay the guard captain with a bronze dagger, my Lord it’s like the car key in your apartment door all over again.

speaker: Alright, alright, how do I get the sword?
response: Well, have you been to the Temple of Mithra?

speaker: Is that the place on the hill with the weird priests in front of it?
response: No, no, no, it’s… oh for God’s sakes, gimme. (Takes laptop.)

speaker: Thank you, I really appreciate this.
response: You’re going to have to learn to do these things for yourself, Penny.

speaker: No, that’s Marcie. Peppermint Patty’s just athletic.
response: There you go, one enchanted sword.

speaker: Right, gimme, gimme, gimme, I want to k*ll the guard captain. (Leaves).
response: That girl needs to get a life.

speaker: Sheldon. (Sing-song) Shel-don.
response: Danger, danger.

speaker: No danger, look, it’s just me, Penny, look, I got to level 25 and reached Purple Lotus Swamp, right?
response: You’re in my bedroom.

speaker: Yeah. Leonard gave me an emergency key.
response: People can’t be in my bedroom.

speaker: Okay, well can we go talk in the living room?
response: I’m not wearing pyjama bottoms.

speaker: Why not?
response: I spilled grape juice.

speaker: Well, wear different pyjamas.
response: I can’t wear different pyjamas, these are my Monday pyjamas. Penny, people cannot be in my bedroom.

speaker: Okay, just tell me, is it too soon to join a quest to the Black Castle?
response: You were invited on a quest to the Black Castle?

speaker: Yeah, yeah, by some guys in Budapest, I’m just not sure it’s the right move for my character.
response: Of course it’s not, you’re only a level 25, the Hungarians are just using you for dragon fodder.

speaker: Really? Boy, you’d think you could trust a horde of Hungarian barbarians.
response: Please Penny, enough, I have to sleep.

speaker: People, I am very busy today.
response: I realise that Dr Gablehauser but it is your job, as head of the department, to mediate all inter-departmental disputes. University policy manual chapter four, subsection two, mediation of inter-departmental disputes.

speaker: Dr Cooper, Dr Winkle apologises.
response: No she doesn’t.

speaker: No I don’t.
response: Here’s the problem. I was clearly signed up to use the mainframe in Buckman 204, and Dr Winkle just wantonly ripped the sign-up sheet off the wall.

speaker: It wasn’t even an official sign-up sheet. He printed it himself and he put his name down in every slot for the next six months.
response: If it is a crime to ensure that the universities resources are not being squandered chasing sub-atomic wild geese then I plead guilty. (His phone rings.) Oh, Penny!

speaker: You need to get that Dr Cooper?
response: God, no.

speaker: Well don’t turn it off, you might miss your call from the Nobel committee letting you know you’ve been nominated as dumbass laureate of the year.
response: Oh yeah, well, you wouldn’t even be nominated. Dr Gablehauser, I have a series of important multi-bit calculations and simulations to run. All she’s doing is reducing irrelevant data and making a mock…

speaker: Excuse me. Gablehauser. (Holding phone out to Sheldon) It’s for you.
response: Hello. Penny, this is not a good time. No, I told you, you’re not prepared for the Sanctum of Burning Souls. You need to be in a group of at least five for that quest, and one should be a level 35 healer. Penny, I can’t log on and help you. We’ll talk when I get home. (Puts phone down) I’m not getting the computing time, am I?

speaker: Why should I do something, you’re the one who introduced her to online gaming.
response: Well, yes, but you’re the one who said hello to her when she moved in. If you’d simply restrained yourself none of this would be happening.

speaker: Why don’t you just tell her to leave you alone.
response: I did. I told her, I texted her, I sent out a very emphatic twitter. I even changed my facebook status to Sheldon Cooper wishes Penny would leave him alone. I don’t know what else to do.

speaker: Well, what am I supposed to do?
response: I don’t know, but if you don’t figure something out, I warn you I shall become very difficult to live with.

speaker: You mean, up until now we’ve been experiencing the happy funtime Sheldon?
response: Yes.

speaker: Sheldon, wake up.
response: Danger, danger.

speaker: Afternoon men. Sheldon.
response: Oh yeah, well your attempt at juvenilizing me by excluding me from the set of adult males…. oh, I’m too tired to do this.

speaker: Right, I heard you’ve been pulling all nighters with middle-earth Barbie.
response: She comes into my room. No-one’s supposed to be in my room.

speaker: Leslie, you are way off base here.
response: Hang on, Leonard, while I have no respect for Leslie as a scientist, or a human being for that matter, we have to concede her undeniable expertise in the interrelated fields of promiscuity and general sluttiness.

speaker: Thank you. My point is that Tinkerbell just needs to get her some.
response: Some what? Oh, yes, some sexual intercourse.

speaker: Excuse me, this whole idea is insane.
response: Yeah, yeah, enough debate, I’m going to take action. (Leans over to a good looking man on a nearby table.) Excuse me, are you currently involved in a sexual relationship?

speaker: No.
response: Would you like to be?

speaker: Sheldon…
response: Zip it pip it. Can I have your phone number?

speaker: Uh… (checks out Sheldon’s package) Yeah, yeah. (Pulls out pen and writes it on Sheldon’s hand.)
response: There, problem solved.

speaker: Okay, I’m at the gate to the Treasury of the Ancients, I’m going in.
response: Stay close to the wall. Avoid the mummies.

speaker: Got it.
response: I must say, you’re playing very well for a woman of 23?
Right. 22. (Cut to his screen, he is filling in an online dating profile.)

speaker: Oh, here come the mummies, which spell do I use? The hateful strike, or the frenzy stance?
response: What happened to the rest of your group?

speaker: I dumped them, they’re a bunch of wussies.
response: Frenzy stance.

speaker: Frenzy, frenzy, frenzy, frenzy, frenzy!
response: So listen, would you describe your ideal vacation as a wild adventure to unknown lands, or staying at home curled up with a good book?

speaker: What?
response: These are market research questions. I’m filling out the online registration for your game.

speaker: Oh, okay, wild adventure. Oh, frenzy stance isn’t working, die you undead mummy, die!
response: Drink a healing potion.

speaker: Thank you.
response: You’re welcome. Anyhow, on a scale of 1 to 5, with 1 being always initiated by him, and 5 being always initiated by you, how do you prefer your sexual encounters to begin?

speaker: That’s on the registration?
response: Oh yes, it’s quite extensive. But if we complete it, we get a free expansion pack, 75 additional quests.

speaker: Ooh, awesome, okay, I totally like to initiate I’m a big old five.
response: Good to know. Big old five.

speaker: Hi.
response: Leonard, this is Tom.

speaker: Hi Tom. Sheldon? Didn’t I explain to you about your little mistake in the cafeteria?
response: Yes, you were very clear, as was everyone else at the table. Tom, however, has been chosen by science as a suitable mate for Penny.

speaker: Chosen by science?
response: Well, what passes for science on dating sites. They claim to use heuristic algorithms, but it may well be hokum.

speaker: You got Penny to sign up for online dating?
response: No, of course not. No, I used trickery and deceit.

speaker: This is bad.
response: Tom is a paramedic with the fire department, but he’s going to med school at night, uh, he likes the outdoors, and, uh, strong women who initiate sex.

speaker: Really, really bad.
response: I’m surprised you struck out with Penny. Apparently she’s a big old five.

speaker: Sheldon, what do you want.
response: Oh, good, you got my note. Penny, I’d like you to meet Tom, uh, Penny, this is Tom, Tom, may I present Penny.

speaker: Yeah, Hi, listen, as long as I’m here, I’m on a quest with a bunch of noobs, they don’t know what they’re doing, we’ve got one assassin, three spellcasters and no t*nk.
response: Can we talk about this later.

speaker: No, no, no, no, I need you now.
response: But wouldn’t you prefer to socialise with Tom, who is a sexually passive outdoorsman.

speaker: Gentlemen, I am now about to send a signal from this laptop through our local ISP, racing down fibre-optic cable at the speed of light to San Francisco, bouncing off a satellite in geosynchronous orbit to Lisbon, Portugal, where the data packets will be handed off to submerged transatlantic cables terminating in Halifax, Nova-Scotia, and transferred across the continent via microwave relays back to our ISP and the X10 receiver attached to this (clicks mouse, lamp switches on) lamp. (The others cheer and clap).
response: Look at me, look at me, I’ve got goosebumps.

speaker: Yeah, you turned your stereo down with your laptop.
response: No, we turned our stereo down by sending a signal around the world via the internet.

speaker: No.
response: Someone in Sezchuan province, China is using his computer to turn our lights on and off.

speaker: Because we can. (There is a loud noise)
response: They found the remote controlled cars.

speaker: The monster truck is out of Austin, Texas, and the blue Viper is being operated from suburban Tel Aviv.
response: You may want to put on slacks.

speaker: I suppose you could have your android penis circumcised. But that’s something your Rabbi would have to discuss with the manufacturers.
response: Not to mention you’d have to power down on Saturdays.

speaker: Sheldon, why is this letter in the trash?
response: Well, there’s always the possibility that a trash can spontaneously formed around the letter, but Occam’s Razor would suggest that someone threw it out.

speaker: It’s from the Institute for Experimental Physics. They want us to present our paper on the properties of super solids at the topical conference on Bowes-Einstein condensates.
response: I know. I read it before I threw it out.

speaker: Okay… if I may drill down to the bedrock of my question, why did you throw it out.
response: Because I have no interest in standing in the Rose Room of the Pasadena Marriott in front of a group of judgemental strangers, who wouldn’t recognise true genius if it were standing in front of them giving a speech. Which, if I were there, it would be.

speaker: Are there any other honours I’ve gotten that I don’t know about? Did UPS drop off a Nobel Prize with my name on it?
response: Leonard, please don’t take this the wrong way, but the day you win a Nobel Prize, is the day I begin my research on the drag co-efficient of tassles on flying carpets.

speaker: Shut up, Howard. Sheldon, we have to do this.
response: No we don’t. We have to take in nourishment, expel waste, and inhale enough oxygen to keep ourselves from dying, everything else is optional.

speaker: Okay, let me put it this way, I’m doing it.
response: You can’t. I’m the lead author.

speaker: Oh, come on. The only reason you’re the lead author is because we went alphabetically.
response: I let you think we went alphabetically to spare you the humiliation of dealing with the fact that it was my idea. Not to put too fine a point on it, but I was throwing you a bone. You’re welcome.

speaker: Excuse me, I designed the experiment that proved the hypothesis.
response: It doesn’t need proving.

speaker: So the entire scientific community is just supposed to take your word?
response: They’re not supposed to, but they should.

speaker: Alright, I don’t care what you say, I’m going to the conference and I’m presenting our findings.
response: And I forbid it.

speaker: You forbid it?
response: If I’m not taking credit for our work then nobody is.

speaker: Oh, you admit that it’s our work.
response: No, once again, I’m throwing you a bone. And once again, you are welcome.

speaker: Hey Sheldon!
response: Hello Penny.

speaker: Get anything good?
response: Uh, just the latest copy of Applied Particle Physics Quarterly.

speaker: Oh, you know, that is so weird that yours came and mine didn’t. (Sheldon looks confused). It was a joke. (Sheldon gives a fake laugh.) Yup, tip your waitresses, I’m here all week.
response: Penny, just to save you from further awkwardness know that I’m perfectly comfortable with the two of us climbing the stairs in silence.

speaker: Oh yeah, me too. Zip it, lock it. (The begin to climb) Put it in your pocket. So you and Leonard…
response: Oh dear God!

speaker: Little misunderstanding, huh.
response: A little misunder…. Galileo and the Pope had a little misunderstanding.

speaker: Anyway, I was talking to Leonard this morning and I think he feels really bad about it.
response: Huh.

speaker: Well how do you feel?
response: I don’t understand the question.

speaker: Well I’m just asking if it’s difficult to be fighting with your best friend.
response: Oh. I hadn’t thought about it like that. I wonder if I’ve been experiencing physiological manifestations of some sort of unconscious emotional turmoil.

speaker: Wait… what?
response: I couldn’t poop this morning.

speaker: You should just talk to him, I’m sure you guys can work this out.
response: It’s certainly preferable to my plan.

speaker: Which was?
response: A powerful laxative.

speaker: Okay, so you absolutely should talk to him, look, I know Leonard values you as a friend, and he told me himself that without your little idea there’s no way he could have come up with this whole experiment thing.
response: Excuse me, little idea?

speaker: Yeah, I mean he tried to explain it to me, I didn’t really understand it but…
response: Of course you didn’t, he said little idea?

speaker: Uh, well no, no, not in… not in those words.
response: In what words then, exactly

speaker: Um, gee, the exact words aren’t written… it’s more the spirit in which it’s
response: What did he say?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I’ve been thinking, instead of arguing about this why don’t….
response: Don’t you ever speak to me again.

speaker: Okay, I’m leaving for the conference.
response: Have fun presenting my lucky hunch.

speaker: Sheldon I didn’t mean it like that.
response: Then why did you say it.

speaker: I don’t know, I wasn’t choosing my…
response: Were you trying to impress Penny?

speaker: No, no not at all. A little bit.
response: How’d that work out for you?

speaker: Leonard, ready to go?
response: Libido 1, truth zero.

speaker: Okay, I’m going to ask you one more time, we did the work together, lets present the paper together.
response: And I’m telling you for the last time it’s pandering, it’s undignified and bite me.

speaker: Bye Sheldon.
response: Goodbye Penny. (Places fingers to head to try to make Leonard’s brain explode. Leonard leaves.) Oooh, one of these days, Pkshhhh!

speaker: Any other questions?
response: Doctor Sheldon Cooper here, I am the lead author of this particular paper. (No reaction.) Thank you. And you, sir, you have completely skipped over the part where I was walking through the park, and I saw these children on a merry-go-round, which started me thinking about the moment of inertia in gasses like helium at temperatures approaching absolute zero.

speaker: I didn’t skip it, it’s just an anecdote. It’s not science.
response: Oh, I see, was the apple falling on Newton’s head, was that just an anecdote?

speaker: You are not Isaac Newton.
response: No, no that’s true, gravity would have been apparent to me without the apple.

speaker: You cannot possibly be that arrogant.
response: You continue to underestimate me, my good man.

speaker: Look, if you weren’t happy with my presentation then maybe you should have given it with me.
response: As I have explained repeatedly, unlike you, I don’t need validation from lesser minds. No offence.

speaker: Really, so why did you come?
response: Because I knew you’d screw this up.

speaker: I didn’t screw it up.
response: Oh, please. I admit, that spherical chicken joke, that was hilarious. But it was straight downhill from there.

speaker: I’ve had enough of your condescension. Maybe I didn’t go to college when I was eleven like you, maybe I got my doctorate at 24 instead of 16, but you are not the only person who is smarter than everyone else in this room. No offense. And I am clearly not the only person who is tormented by insecurity and has an ego in need of constant validation.
response: So you admit that you’re an egotist?

speaker: Yes. (To audience) My name is Dr Leonard Hofstadter, and I could never please my parents so I need to get all my self-esteem from strangers like you. But he’s worse.
response: Okay, that is it. (Tries to explode brain again.)

speaker: You cannot blow up my head with your mind.
response: Then I’ll settle for an aneurysm.

speaker: Stop it.
response: You hit me. You saw him, he hit me.

speaker: You were trying to blow up my head.
response: So it was working.

speaker: It wasn’t, it was not, you are a nutcase.
response: Oh we’ll see about that (tries again), heads up you people in the front row, this is a splash zone.

speaker: You’re lucky I didn’t run you over.
response: I really don’t understand what you’re so unhappy about, you begged me to come, I came, there’s just no pleasing you.

speaker: You’re right, I’m the problem, I’m the one that needs help.
response: Well that’s not much of an apology, but I’ll take it.

speaker: Excuse me. Is there anything you’d like to apologise for?
response: Yes. I’m sorry I tried to blow up your head. It was uncalled for.

speaker: What?
response: Now, who would do that?

speaker: Oh jeez. Is this suit really look that bad?
response: Forget your suit, look at my arms waving, I’m like a flamingo on Ritalin.

speaker: Dude, I’m glad you finally got a girlfriend, but do you have to do all that lovey-dovey stuff in front of those of us who don’t?
response: Actually, he might have to. There’s an economic concept known as a positional good in which an object is only valued by the possessor because it’s not possessed by others. The term was coined in 1976 by economist Fred Hirsch to replace the more colloquial, but less precise neener-neener.

speaker: Oh. I used to be like that. Then I got a girlfriend.
response: In pre-1976 terms, neener-neener.

speaker: Yeah, I am pulling out all the stops. There’s a $39.95 lover’s special at P.F. Chang’s. Egg rolls, dumplings, bottomless wok, and you get your picture taken on the big marble horse out front.
response: Given that Saint Valentine was a third century Roman priest who was stoned and beheaded, wouldn’t a more appropriate celebration of the evening be taking one’s steady gal to witness a brutal m*rder?

speaker: Guess who the university is sending to Switzerland to attend a conference and see the CERN supercollider on February 14?
response: Professor Norton, although, God knows why. He hasn’t published anything of note since he won that Nobel Prize.

speaker: In any case, they’re asking me to fill in for him.
response: In Switzerland or with the big-boobed weather girl?

speaker: No way, dude!
response: This is incredible! I’m so happy, I’m not even going to question their judgment in picking you. I’m just going to run home and start packing.

speaker: Sheldon, you got a minute?
response: Of course, my good friend. Come in. Help me out, which ski hat says après supercollider?

speaker: Sheldon, I’m not taking you to Switzerland.
response: Well, of course you are. Who else would you take?

speaker: Penny.
response: What? That’s absurd. Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.

speaker: Yes, but it’ll be Valentine’s Day. We can go sightseeing and skiing and make love in front of a roaring fire in the shadow of the snowcapped Alps.
response: But Penny has no interest in subatomic particle research.

speaker: I’m sorry, Sheldon.
response: Sorry? I’ve been dreaming about going to the Large Hadron Collider since I was nine years old.

speaker: Yeah, well, I’ve been dreaming about spending Valentine’s Day with a girl since I was six.
response: Shame on you! That’s no dream for a scientist!

speaker: Oh, my God, Leonard! That’s incredible!
response: Not so fast. You might want to hold off on lighting your rabeliechtli, Penny.

speaker: My Rabe-what-ly?
response: Rabeliechtli. It means turnip light and refers to a traditional lantern hand-carved from a root vegetable and used to celebrate certain Swiss festivals. Which you will not be celebrating because, A, these festivals occur in the fall, and B, you will not be going to Switzerland.

speaker: Sheldon, we’ve been through this. I’m taking Penny.
response: Afraid not. Do you recognize this?

speaker: Not the roommate agreement.
response: Indeed, the roommate agreement. I call your attention to the Friendship Rider in Appendix C, Future Commitments. Number 37, in the event one friend is ever invited to visit the Large Hadron Collider, now under construction in Switzerland, he shall invite the other friend to accompany him.

speaker: Yeah. We also put in what happens if one of us wins a MacArthur Grant, or if one of us gets superpowers, or if one of us is bitten by a zombie.
response: He can’t k*ll me, even if I turn.

speaker: Is there anything in there about if one of you gets a girlfriend?
response: No, that seemed a little farfetched.

speaker: Sheldon, do you really expect to enforce this?
response: I’ve lived up to all my commitments under the agreement. At least once a day I ask how you are, even though I simply don’t care. I no longer stage spontaneous biohazard drills after 10 pm And I abandoned my goal to master Tuvan throat singing.

speaker: No.
response: I’d be much further along if I’d been allowed to practice.

speaker: Look, Sheldon, I know it’s in the agreement, and if you turn into a zombie, I promise I will not k*ll you. In fact, I’ll even let you eat my brains. But I am taking Penny to Switzerland.
response: Is that your final decision?

speaker: It is.
response: Very well.

speaker: Got a bit of traffic this morning, huh? Think it’s gonna rain? Instead of underpants, I covered my crotch with potato salad this morning. Thoughts? Okay, I know what’ll cheer you up, let’s play one of your driving games.
response: All right. This game is called Traitors. I will name three historical figures, you put them in order of the heinousness of their betrayal. Benedict Arnold, Judas, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.

speaker: You really think I belong with Benedict Arnold and Judas?
response: You’re right. Judas had the decency to hang himself after what he did.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. Can’t you at least try to understand how much this means to me?
response: Round two, Leonard Hofstadter, Darth Vader, Rupert Murdoch.

speaker: Rupert Murdoch?
response: He owns Fox, and they cancelled Firefly. Hint, he and Darth Vader are tied for number 2.

speaker: What’s going on?
response: I’ve made you breakfast. Juice, coffee, and pancakes in the shape of some of your favorite fictional characters. See, here’s Frodo.

speaker: You made Frodo pancakes?
response: Yeah, I used coconut shavings to do the hair on his feet. If you need to void your bladder before eating, I can keep them warm with this beret that I thoroughly laundered and pressed into service as a pancake cosy.

speaker: Why are you doing this?
response: It’s by way of an apology for my recent behaviour. I’ve had some time to reflect and I’ve come to realize that friendship is not an aggregation of written agreements. It’s a result of two people respecting and caring for each other. Butterscotch scone?

speaker: Thanks. It’s good.
response: What you’re tasting is respect and affection. And about a pound of Crisco. After you’ve finished breakfast, I thought we could spend the day watching the final season of Babylon 5 with director commentary.

speaker: You hate Babylon 5.
response: I do. It fails as drama, science fiction, and it’s hopelessly derivative. But you like it, and you’re my friend.

speaker: Okay, great. Still not taking you to Switzerland.
response: Drat. No Frodo for you.

speaker: Hello.
response: Alright, let’s dispense with the friendly banter, I believe you know why I’m here.

speaker: Well, I always figured it was to study us, discover our weaknesses, and report back to your alien overlords.
response: Yes, amusing. Extraordinary intelligence might well appear extraterrestrial to you, but let me be more specific. I believe you know why I’m here in the laundry room.

speaker: Better acoustics for your throat singing?
response: It’s actually not bad. But my true purpose in being here will be revealed in this brief PowerPoint presentation. Lights. Why Sheldon Cooper, PhD, should go to Switzerland to see the CERN supercollider. A PowerPoint presentation by Sheldon Cooper, PhD.

speaker: Oh, for God’s sakes.
response: Here we have a highly gifted researcher in the field of particle physics whose work has brought him to the precipice of forever changing mankind’s understanding of the universe. AKA me. And here we have a waitress brushing her teeth with her finger. AKA you.

speaker: I’m sorry. Is this supposed to be buttering me up?
response: Please hold all questions to the end of the presentation. This is the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Switzerland, the product of decades of planning and construction. It is a Mecca for physicists the world over. This is Bath and Body Works on Colorado Boulevard. They sell scented soaps and lotions, some of which contain glitter. Now, let’s see if we can match the individual to the appropriate destination.

speaker: Okay, show’s over.
response: No, it’s not. I’ve got five more slides.

speaker: Sheldon, this is Leonard’s decision. He invited me to Switzerland, and I intend to go.
response: Very well. Enjoy yourself. You’re going to be in the presence of something that I’ve dreamed of seeing for decades. I just hope you’ll be able to appreciate the magnitude of where you are and what it represents.

speaker: I’ll talk to Leonard.
response: You will?

speaker: Yes. If it means that much to you, you should go.
response: Oh, Penny, thank you!

speaker: You’re welcome.
response: Since I rarely hug, I’m relying on your expertise regarding duration.

speaker: I think we’re there.
response: Oh, good. Bye-bye.

speaker: Sheldon, I need to talk to you.
response: All right, my friend. Would you like some cholermus?

speaker: Some what?
response: Cholermus. It’s a traditional Swiss breakfast dish. I’m preparing my gastrointestinal system for the exotic cuisine of Switzerland.

speaker: You’re not going to Switzerland!
response: Oh, but I am. Didn’t Penny tell you the good news?

speaker: She told me that you went behind my back to guilt her into letting you go instead of her.
response: Yes, that good news.

speaker: Well, forget it. I was the one who was invited, I get to decide who goes with me, and it’s Penny, not you!
response: Howard, could you lower the lights? I have a short PowerPoint presentation.

speaker: I don’t need to see your presentation. This discussion is over!
response: That’s a somewhat ambiguous response. Am I going or not?

speaker: Sheldon, at this point, I would go by myself before I would take you.
response: Really?

speaker: Yeah, really.
response: Well then, you leave me no alternative. From this moment forward, we can be roommates, but we will no longer be friends.

speaker: I’m sorry you feel that way.
response: I don’t think you’re fully aware of the ramifications here, Leonard.

speaker: Why don’t you enlighten me?
response: With the friendship clause of our roommate agreement nullified you are no longer entitled to accompany me to go swimming at Bill Gates’ house should I be invited.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon? Listen, Penny is pretty sick and she’s not going to be able to go to Switzerland. So if you’re still interested, you’re welcome to come. (Sound of Sheldon vomiting in the bathroom)
response: Great. I’ll start packing. In a minute. (Vomits again) Oh, look, it’s the cholermus.

speaker: Here’s your soup.
response: Chicken?

speaker: Yes.
response: With the little stars?

speaker: Yes.
response: Heated to 180 degrees?

speaker: Why don’t I pour it in your lap, and you can tell me.
response: You don’t have to be mean. I’m sick.

speaker: Yeah, well, I’m sick, too.
response: Not my problem. I just don’t understand how this happened to me. I’m scrupulous about my hygiene. I regularly disinfect my hands, and I avoid contact with other people on general principle.

speaker: I don’t know what to tell you, Sheldon.
response: It’s you! I touched you!

speaker: What do you mean?
response: Well, the instructions are very clear, don’t feed the gremlins after midnight, don’t get the gremlins wet. How hard is that?

speaker: Ooh, we’re honey now, are we?
response: Yes. Since their relationship became carnal, Penny has upgraded his designated term of endearment, thus distinguishing him from those she calls sweetie, usually in an attempt to soften a thinly-veiled insult.

speaker: You’re boring people sweetie.
response: Although, sometimes, she omits the veil entirely.

speaker: Okay. What do you watch on Thanksgiving?
response: The parade.

speaker: Oh. I’ll be there.
response: Will you be serving cranberry jelly or cranberry sauce?

speaker: I guess I could serve both.
response: You guess? You don’t seem to have much of a handle on this.

speaker: What do you mean, he’s getting deported?
response: I believe it means that the U.S. Government is going to expel him from the country. He could then either return to his native India, emigrate to another country that’s willing to accept him, or wander the high seas as a stateless pirate. Personally, I’d choose pirate.

speaker: Ugh, fine. But the man really needs to work on his girl issues.
response: Another reason to consider a life of piracy. Even today, I understand that’s an all-male profession.

speaker: You know, checking e-mail, updating my facebook status, messing up wikipedia entries. Hey, did you know Netflix lets you stream movies on your computer now?
response: And you’ve continued to take the university’s money under false pretences? Highly unethical for an astrophysicist. Although practically mandatory for a pirate.

speaker: Yeah let me start practicing for it. Do you want fries with that Maharaja Mac?”
response: Hi, Leonard. Hello, Raj.

speaker: Hello Sheldon.
response: Forgive me, as you know, I’m no adept at reading facial cues, but I’m going to take a stab here, you’re either sad or nauseated.

speaker: I’m sad.
response: I was going to say sad. I don’t know why I hedged.

speaker: What are you eating?
response: Elbow macaroni with ground hamburger and tomato sauce.

speaker: We believe cows are gods.
response: Not technically. In Hinduism, cattle are thought to be like God.

speaker: Do not tell me about my own culture, Sheldon! In the mood I’m in, I’ll take you out, I swear to cow!
response: I’m sorry.

speaker: Me, too. I’m just, I’m a little on edge.
response: Understandable. Your entire life seems to be crumbling around you, and your future appears bleak at best.

speaker: Thank you.
response: And you’re wrong about Hinduism and cows.

speaker: I’m on it.
response: That’s happy, right?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Nailed it.

speaker: Tell you what, we’ll skype.
response: Gentlemen.

speaker: Hey.
response: Raj, did you get the job with Professor Laughlin?

speaker: No.
response: I assumed as much. But never fear. Like the subordinate male protagonist in countless action movies who disappears half way through the second reel, I have returned to save the day. Odd, usually, he’s met by cheers. Anyway, I was thinking about exploring the string theory implications of gamma rays from dark matter annihilations, and it occurred to me that I could benefit…

speaker: Excuse me, Sheldon, how many reels before the subordinate male protagonist gets to his point?
response: I’m sorry, if you didn’t cheer at my entrance, it’s too late to buy into the premise. Anyway, I got some extra money from the head of the department, and raj can come work for me.

speaker: You want me to work with you?
response: For me. You’re going to have to listen more carefully when you’re on the job.

speaker: Okay, uh, please don’t take this the wrong way, but I’d rather swim buck-naked across the Ganges with a paper cut on my nipple and die a slow, agonizing death from a viral infection than work with you.
response: For me.

speaker: Sheldon, are you busy?
response: Of course I’m busy.

speaker: Shall I wait?
response: Yes, please. (After about 30 seconds) How may I help you?

speaker: I’ve reconsidered your offer to let me work with you.
response: For me.

speaker: Yes, for you. I do, however, have a few conditions. First, at all times, I am to be treated as a colleague and an equal. Second, my contributions shall be noted in all published material. And third, you are never allowed to lecture me on Hinduism or my Indian culture.
response: I’m impressed, Raj. Those are very cogent and reasonable conditions.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I reject them all.

speaker: Then you leave me no choice. I accept the job.
response: I’m sorry, I believe you’ve misunderstood. I’m not giving you the job. I’m simply affording you the opportunity to apply for it. Have a seat, we’ll get started with the interview.

speaker: Wha… You’re kidding!
response: Please.

speaker: All right.
response: So, that’s what you wear to an interview?

speaker: Come on, dude, we’ve been friends for years.
response: Oh, pulling strings, are we?

speaker: Sheldon, for God’s sakes, don’t make me beg.
response: Bazinga! You’ve fallen victim to another one of my classic practical jokes. I’m your boss now. You may want to laugh at that.

speaker: Ooh, dark matter. We better bring a flashlight. I was making a joke.
response: I’m the boss. I make the jokes.

speaker: Sorry, go ahead and make your joke.
response: This is not the time for joking. We’re doing serious research, which requires complete and utter focus.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: What?

speaker: I need an aspirin.
response: Top desk drawer.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Alright?

speaker: Yes.
response: Good.

speaker: No, no, no, no! That rate is much too low for what we’d expect from this collision. Do you understand that we’re talking about dark matter colliding in outer space?
response: Of course I understand. And who are you to tell me about outer space?

speaker: I’m the astrophysicist. Astro means space.
response: Astro means star.

speaker: Okay, well, let me just tell you, if we were having this argument in my native language, I’d be kicking your butt.
response: English is your native language.

speaker: Okay, you got me there, but you’re wrong about this!
response: There is a fine line between wrong and visionary. Unfortunately you have to be a visionary to see it.

speaker: My god, you think that every thought that comes out of your head is pure gold. Well, let me tell you something. Some of those thoughts are pure caca.
response: Caca?

speaker: It means doo-doo.
response: All right! First of all, Dr. Koothrappali, when I first proposed that you work with me…

speaker: Aha! So I am working with you.
response: In this context, with me means for me.

speaker: Ah, well, in this context… (blows raspberry)
response: Oh! If I’m wrong, prove it.

speaker: Okay. Here’s where we derive the mass of the dark matter particle.
response: No, no, no, you’ve misstated the atomic weight of the target.

speaker: Let me finish.
response: You’re defacing my work.

speaker: I’m not defacing it, I’m fixing it.
response: Give me the eraser.

speaker: No.
response: I said give it to me.

speaker: Come and get it.
response: Fine. (Uses hand as an eraser. Then realises his hand is dirty) Oh, lord. Dr. Koothrappali, as your superior, I forbid you from writing on my board!

speaker: You are not my superior.
response: I am in every way.

speaker: I’m busy.
response: Doing what? (Performs finger trick again) All right, you’ve made your point.

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: I looked over the board and it turns out you were right.

speaker: So you were wrong.
response: I didn’t say that.

speaker: That’s the only logical inference.
response: Nevertheless, I didn’t say it. Anyway, I would like you to come back and work for me.

speaker: For you or with you?
response: In this context for me could mean with me.

speaker: All right, but I have some conditions.
response: I reject them all.

speaker: I’ll take the job. See you Monday.
response: Wait, you have to drive me home.

speaker: How did you get here?
response: I walked.

speaker: So walk home.
response: I can’t. There’s a big dog outside. On the way home, we can start thinking about methods of optimizing the detector for 500 GEV particles.

speaker: Which one?
response: It doesn’t matter. You can’t possibly win.

speaker: How could he ruin the game?
response: Given the cards that have already been played, Penny can only be holding necromancer potions, which are only effective against wraiths and day-walkers, and there are no more of either left to be drawn. The cards remaining in the undrawn stack are four fire w*apon, a troll, two ogres and the jewel of Osiris.

speaker: Sheldon, that is incredible.
response: From your vantage point, it certainly must seem so.

speaker: Sheldon has kind of a photographic memory.
response: Photographic is a misnomer. I have an eidetic memory, as I’ve told you many times. Most recently last year during lunch on the afternoon of may seventh. You had turkey and complained it was dry.

speaker: Yeah, I don’t remember that.
response: June 30th, 2004. Opening day of Spider-man 2 at the AMC Pasadena. They only had red icees, no blue.

speaker: Hey, how come I wasn’t part of this deal?
response: You had left the refreshment stand in order to indulge in your customary preemptive pre-show urination.

speaker: Oh, damn it. Can I have a napkin?
response: I’m sorry, no.

speaker: But you have a whole bunch of ‘em.
response: Yes, I’ve moved to a four-napkin system. Lap, hands, face and personal emergencies. If you like, starting tomorrow, I’ll add a guest napkin, but I’m afraid there’s nothing I can do for you today. (Leonard steals a napkin) Good luck. That’s the face napkin.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, guess what I heard today?
response: I’d imagine you heard any number of things today. When you arrived at work you undoubtedly heard, hello, Raj, how are you, Raj? Given that you’re wearing a new sweater-vest, you may have heard new sweater-vest? And possibly, though far less likely, nice sweater-vest.

speaker: Why don’t I just tell you what I heard today.
response: That would probably save us some time.

speaker: Saturday night at the comic book store, they’re having a Mystic Warlords of Ka-ah tournament. First prize is five hundred dollars. If we team up, we’d be unstoppable.
response: I’m sorry, Raj, but I have no interest in playing a game in which I find no challenge.

speaker: What about the money?
response: I have money.

speaker: But this is other money.
response: How does it different from the money I have?

speaker: Half of it will be mine.
response: Do you need it to buy a less disturbing sweater-vest?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, the new Green Lantern figurine’s coming in tomorrow. Want me to set one aside for you?
response: Thank you. You just robbed me of the opportunity to stumble upon the figurine and make the oh-so-satisfying journey from discovery to desire to possession.

speaker: All right, I won’t set one aside for you.
response: But I must have it.

speaker: Okay, I’ll set one aside for you.
response: Thank you. You know, I can buy all these things online. I come here for the personal service.

speaker: Yeah, he lives around here. Big gamer.
response: Excuse me. Are you saying that Wil Wheaton aka Ensign Wesley Crusher on Star Trek

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, did I rob you of the opportunity to stumble onto that for yourself?
response: You don’t understand. Growing up, I idolized Wil Wheaton? Wesley Crusher had an eidetic memory just like me.

speaker: Oh, what a coincidence. Maybe you can discuss that with him while you’re playing in the tournament. Sign here.
response: I was such a fan that in 1995, I travelled ten hours by bus to a sci-fi convention in Jackson, Mississippi, wearing my Star Fleet Academy cadet uniform in order to meet Wil Wheaton and get him to autograph my mint in-package Wesley Crusher action figure.

speaker: Ooh, it’ll be like a reunion then. Sign here.
response: My arduous journey, however, was for naught. Although advertised to appear, he did not show up. It was at that moment, I vowed eternal hatred for Wil Wheaton.

speaker: Okay, great, you can tell him you hate him. Sign here.
response: It might also interest you to know that Wil Wheaton currently ranks sixth on my all-time enemies list, right between director Joel Schumacher, who nearly destroyed the Batman movie franchise, and Billy Sparks, who lived down the street from me and put dog poop on the handles of my bicycle.

speaker: Okay, I get it, he’s a bad guy. Sign here.
response: In the words of Khan Noonien Singh in the immortal wrath of Khan, he tasks me, he tasks me and I shall have him.

speaker: No doubt, sign here.
response: From hell’s heart, I stab at thee.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s your play. Sheldon.
response: My enchanted troll bludgeons your screaming harpy with a cursed mace. Game.

speaker: Sorry, boys. Say hi to your mother when she picks you up. Or I could just tell her later tonight! We pwned them, dude! Up top!
response: Look at him. Wil Wheaton, my old friend, I have chased you round the moons of Nibia and round the Antares maelstrom and round perdition’s flames!

speaker: You know you keep quoting Wrath of Khan, but he was in next generation. It’s a totally different set of characters.
response: Silence! How much longer must I wait for my revenge?

speaker: Well, if Wil Wheaton and Stuart win their match and we b*at lonely Larry and Captain Sweatpants in the next round, we’ll face off for the championship.
response: So, my path to satisfaction is blocked by lonely Larry and Captain Sweatpants. Very well. They must be destroyed.

speaker: Dude, you have to stop talking like that. It’s really lame.
response: Silence!

speaker: Underworld guardian.
response: Underworld guardian. We skirmish to the death.

speaker: Invisibility spell.
response: Luminescence spell.

speaker: Water nymph.
response: Fire demon.

speaker: Two-headed tiger.
response: Three-headed lion.

speaker: Sulphur.
response: Brimstone.

speaker: Hang on.
response: You’re holding two moderate spell cards, a small rock and a potion of Zancor, which will be about as much help as an air conditioner on the ice planet Hoth. Your only move is to play the potion, lose the skirmish, and two moves later, the game.

speaker: I think he’s got me.
response: The year was 1995, the place, Jackson, Mississippi. Having spent ten hours on a bus, during which I had to twice violate my personal rule against relieving myself on board a moving vehicle, I finally arrived at the fourth annual Dixie-Trek convention only to find that my idol Wil Wheaton decided he had better things to do than to show up and sign my action figure.

speaker: What?
response: You betrayed me, Wil Wheaton. Now I have my revenge.

speaker: You went to the ‘95 Dixie-Trek? Oh, dude, my grandmother had just died, and I had to go to her funeral.
response: Your mee-maw died? That’s terrible.

speaker: Yeah, it was. But I’m really sorry that I disappointed you.
response: No, no, I understand. Anything happened to my mee-maw, I’d be one inconsolable moon pie. I should clarify that statement by explaining that she calls me moon pie.

speaker: It’s special relationship, isn’t it, between a boy and his grandmother?
response: Oh, yes.

speaker: What are you waiting for? k*ll Wil Wheaton! From hell’s heart, stab at him!
response: I can’t.

speaker: Sure you can. Do it! Do it!
response: No. I came here to defeat Wil Wheaton, the man who destroyed my dreams. But I can’t defeat Wil Wheaton, the man who loved his mee-maw. Enchanted bunny.

speaker: I call my mee-maw nana. And she’s going be very happy to hear that my small rock k*ll your enchanted bunny. Game over, moon pie.
response: I… I… I don’t understand. Your grandmother’s alive?

speaker: That was fun.
response: Wheaton! Wheaton! Wheaton!

speaker: I don’t see anything at all, Sheldon.
response: Well, you’re the doctor, but I am constantly hearing this annoying sound.

speaker: Me, too.
response: Is it a high-frequency whistle?

speaker: Yup, there’s no inflammation at all, Sheldon.
response: Then it must be a tumour.

speaker: Maybe it’s a lingering bacterial infection from all those childhood toilet swirlies.
response: Is that possible? I used to get those all the time. Even in church.

speaker: Okay, I’ll be right in.
response: It’s not enough that she mocks me, but that isn’t even the correct procedure for a cootie sh*t.

speaker: Do you understand that Stephanie’s not here to treat your imaginary ailments?
response: How is it imaginary that I keep hearing an octave above Middle C? Is that imaginary? I don’t think so.

speaker: Good night.
response: Leonard, there’s one more thing. Under Article One, Section Three of our Roommate Agreement, I’m calling an emergency meeting.

speaker: No, you’re not.
response: Leonard moves the meeting not occur. Is there a second? None heard, the motion fails. I’d like to begin the meeting by congratulating you on the progress in your relationship with Dr. Stephanie.

speaker: Thank you.
response: That being said, we have to discuss the implementation of the agreed upon “cohabitation” rider which has been activated now that the two of you are living together.

speaker: We’re not living together.
response: I beg to disagree. “A girlfriend shall be deemed quote living with un-quote Leonard when she has stayed over for A, ten consecutive nights or B, more than nine nights in three week period or C

speaker: That’s absurd.
response: You initialed it. See? L.H., L.H., L.H.

speaker: Wait, I only initialed it because I never thought it would happen! I initialed another clause naming you my sidekick in case I get superpowers.
response: Hmm, yes, you did. Now, to review the following provisions are hereby activated. In the refrigerator, as opposed to us having two separate shelves and one communal shelf, the three of us now get individual shelves and the door becomes communal. Next, apartment vacuuming shall be increased from two to three times a week to accommodate the increased accumulation of dead skin cells. Third,the bathroom schedule. Now, I’m given to understand women have different needs, so, we’ll have to discuss that.

speaker: I’m going to bed.
response: At least take this with you. Look, and have Stephanie initial here, here, here, here and here. This states that she does not now nor does she intend to play a percussive or brass instrument. Sure it sounds like a tumor pressing on the auditory nerve.

speaker: No, absolutely not.
response: It’s not a big deal. We have latex gloves.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon.
response: Good morning, Dr. Stephanie. I trust Leonard satisfied you sexually last night.

speaker: Oh come on! Sheldon, we don’t ask questions like that.
response: I heard you ask it over and over. How is it inappropriate for me to ask it once?

speaker: He did very nicely.
response: See? She’s not offended. And now you finally have an answer.

speaker: She’s heard about you because we’re, you know, involved and you haven’t heard about her because… I never slept with her, I swear!
response: In Leonard’s defence, it wasn’t for lack of trying.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: You’re welcome, Leonard.

speaker: Look, I’m just saying, um, Penny is one of our many neighbours, you know, and in our building, neighbours come and go, it’s very casual, no dress code. In fact, some mornings I’ll just mosey down to the third floor in my pyjamas and have cereal with Mrs. Vartabedian.
response: Really? I have never once been invited to have cereal with Mrs. Vartabedian.

speaker: Bye.
response: What could I possibly have done to offend Mrs. Vartabedian?

speaker: You know, she seems very nice.
response: Oh, she is. She’s terrific, and she’s proving to be a valuable roommate.

speaker: Roommate? You guys are living together?
response: Like hippies.

speaker: We’re not living together.
response: Do I have to pull out the paperwork again?

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: Hang on. 130 over 80. A little high. We can attribute that to the stress of sneaking past the security desk.

speaker: Where did you get the stethoscope and the blood pressure cuff?
response: My aunt Marion gave them to me for my 12th birthday. She thought if I failed at theoretical physics that I should have a trade to fall back on. And by the way, the blood pressure cuff is called a sphygmomanometer.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Didn’t they teach you that in medical school?

speaker: I’m kinda busy here, Sheldon.
response: I understand. All I need is for you to authorize these tests.

speaker: A cardiac stress test, a full body MRI, an electromyogram, a CBC, baseline glucose, upper GI?
response: Oh, and an exploratory laparoscopy. Last time I had hiccups, it felt like my diaphragm was just going through the motions.

speaker: Go home, Sheldon.
response: Can I at least have the upper GI? I already drank the barium!

speaker: Oh, no.
response: Wha?

speaker: You were right. Your larynx is terribly inflamed. I mean, I’ve never seen anything like it.
response: I knew it! What do I do?

speaker: You’re going to need to stop talking immediately.
response: For how…

speaker: Okay, uh, I’d pick swan because, uh, the resulting hybrid would have the advanced industrial civilization of a human and the long graceful neck I’ve always dreamed of having.
response: Wrong. Leonard?

speaker: Horse, but mostly just for the height. A little bit for the genital girth.
response: Wrong, and let’s keep it clean, shall we?

speaker: Also instead of just living in your mother’s house, you could actually live inside her body.
response: Clever, but also wrong. No, the best organism for human beings to merge with is the lichen itself. That way, you’d be human, fungus, and algae. Triple threat. Like three-bean salad.

speaker: Give me one circumstance in which that would be useful.
response: All right, picture this, a beautiful outdoor concert. Now, as a human, I appreciate Beethoven. As a fungus, I have a terrific view, growing out of a towering maple tree. And no thank you, expensive concessions. Because as an algae, I’ll just snack on this sunlight.

speaker: Anyway, if it’s okay with you, we should talk about Howard’s bachelor party.
response: Well, seems like a bit of a let down after our lichen conversation, but, what do you know, you’re half swan.

speaker: Good for you, Howard. I’m proud of you. And still, you’re the first one of us to get married. We have to do something special.
response: You know Germans have an interesting pre-wedding custom.

speaker: Maybe we can go up to Napa Valley. They’ve got that wine train.
response: Boo, wine! But yay, trains. I’m in.

speaker: Hey, I got to hand it to Raj, he found a really nice spot to have a bachelor party.
response: It’s not bad. Unless you compare it to a train; then it stinks.

speaker: Are you drinking whisky?
response: Indeed. If I’m to participate in the social convention that is the stag night, then I must embrace all its components, including tobacco, swear words, and yes, alcohol. Jeepers! That’s yucky.

speaker: Well, it was either this or another hot tub party at George Takei’s house.
response: I’m confused. I thought since our reconciliation, I was your friend in this group.

speaker: Oh, I’m friends with Howard too.
response: Oh. I guess you’re just friends with anybody. (Drinks) Aagh!

speaker: Hear! Hear!
response: And, apparently, Wil Wheaton’s best friend.

speaker: Sheldon…
response: Talk to the hand.

speaker: Does anyone have any words they’d like to say about our man of the evening?
response: Yeah, I do. (All groan). As is the tradition, I have prepared a series of disrespectful jokes which generate humour at Howard’s expense. Prepare to have your ribs tickled. Howard, I always thought you’d be the last one of us to ever get married, because you are so short and unappealing. Am I right? Let’s see here. Oh, seriously though, Howard, you’re actually one of the most intelligent people I know. And that’s a zinger, because you’re not. I’ve always thought that you’d make someone a fine husband someday. Assuming you’d be able to get the parts, and develop the engineering k*ll to assemble them, which I don’t see as likely. Hacha! Okay, let me see here. Okay, kidding aside, Howard, you are a good friend. And I wish you nothing but happiness. Bazinga, I don’t!

speaker: Sheldon…
response: Doubleazinga! I do! Good luck following that.

speaker: She was my second cousin.
response: And the first woman you ever disappointed sexually. Ba-da-bazinga!

speaker: Oh, Internet, this is so going all over you.
response: Jeepers, I’m drunk.

speaker: Actually, you did do one of them together.
response: Here.

speaker: What is this?
response: You’re upset. The convention is to bring an upset person a hot beverage.

speaker: No, but what is it?
response: Chicken broth. It seemed culturally appropriate. Also, there was a single cube of chicken bouillon in the cupboard when I moved in and it’s been bothering me for the last eight years. So, as they say, two birds.

speaker: All right. More Sailor Moon for me.
response: I just threw up the bachelor party.

speaker: Hmm. Can we maybe put the phones down and have an actualhuman conversation?
response: We can, but thanks to Steve Jobs, we don’t have to.

speaker: Oh, yeah
response: Yay, Penny.

speaker: If you’re really desperate to meet women and like having food eaten out of your mouth, I could set you up with my mom.
response: Why is that funny? That’s just unhygienic.

speaker: It’s a joke.
response: I don’t think so. I believe that a joke is a brief oral narrative with a climactic humorous twist. For example, uh, Wolowitz’s mother is so fat that she decided to go on a diet, or exercise, or both. See? The twist is that people don’t usually change. Well, they don’t.

speaker: Oh, that’s so sweet of you, but I was gonna steal food from here. You know, my treat.
response: Wait, if Howard’s mother is coming, then you should also steal marbles. Because she’s obese, and hippos are obese, and in the popular board game Hungry Hungry Hippos, they eat marbles. Maybe I need to dumb these down for you.

speaker: No. Do you?
response: I think I’m hysterical.

speaker: I take it back. That was funny.
response: The philosopher Henri Bergson says it’s funny when a human being behaves like an object.

speaker: I bet that bit k*ll at The Chuckle Hut.
response: Oh, he didn’t perform stand-up comedy, he was a philosopher.

speaker: You know, I think we’re zeroing in on your problem.
response: Perhaps I’ll spend some time developing a unified theory of comedy, which will allow me to elicit laughter from anyone at any time. Unless they’re German, ’cause that’s a tough crowd.

speaker: Are you set on people laughing with you? ‘Cause if you’re cool with at you…
response: I don’t get it.

speaker: I know, but you’re going to be a TV star and you haven’t left me yet. That takes guts.
response: I don’t know about you, but I’m very uncomfortable with all this.

speaker: Why?
response: I’ve never seen this show before and now I’m starting with episode 246? It’s unnatural.

speaker: Just think of the first 245 as the prequel.
response: All right.

speaker: Well, the diner scene. Where’s my diner scene?
response: Well, don’t ask me. Until I see the prequel, I’m lost.

speaker: This doesn’t make any sense. I mean, I, I thought I did a, a really good job, I… Excuse me.
response: I’ve been studying how to make people laugh. They say that comedy is tragedy plus time. Let’s tickle some ribs.

speaker: Well, that makes sense. The prefrontal cortex is responsible for planning and anticipation, and patients with brain lesions on their…
response: BRAIN LESIONS!

speaker: Sheldon, you scared me. That wasn’t funny.
response: Or maybe you have a stick up your prefrontal cortex.

speaker: Okay, the notion that you can read a few books and come up with a definitive theory of comedy is absurd. I mean, humour is a complex neurological… (Sheldon drops his trousers) Okay, that’s pretty good.
response: Excellent.

speaker: I guess.
response: Ointment?

speaker: Sure.
response: Now, would you say ointment is more, equal to, or less funny than kumquat?

speaker: I don’t think I want to go out with you anymore.
response: Will you please stop joking around? I’m trying to figure this out.

speaker: Sheldon, how many words are you gonna go through?
response: All of them.

speaker: No, forget it. I take it back. Offer’s off the table.
response: Who’s in the mood to laugh?

speaker: Really not a good time.
response: But I used science to construct the perfect joke.

speaker: No, no, I just need to be alone.
response: So, a sandwich, a rabbi and yo mama walk into a bar. Where are you going?

speaker: To my room.
response: Should I follow you?

speaker: No.
response: Leonard, wait.

speaker: What?
response: I forgot to tell you the sandwich is promiscuous.

speaker: No.
response: Would you like to talk about it?

speaker: Penny proposed, and I didn’t say yes.
response: Why not?

speaker: That’s a good question.
response: Does that mean the relationship is over?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: Why don’t you ask her?

speaker: Because I’m afraid to know the answer.
response: Well, I’m sorry.

speaker: That’s it? You’re not gonna make some dumb joke or some inappropriate comment?
response: No. You’re my friend, and, I’m sorry.

speaker: Did you just put a kick me sign on my back?
response: No. That wouldn’t be funny at all.

speaker: Oh, I’ve got butterflies.
response: Don’t get soft on me, Hofstadter. I will slap those glasses right off your face.

speaker: They sell out incredibly fast, but as long as one of us gets in, we can buy passes…
response: Good Lord, this is not the time for flirting, keep it in your pants.

speaker: Oh, I have to go to the bathroom so bad.
response: Every year. I told you, wear a diaper.

speaker: Five, four, three, two, one.
response: It’s live. Go, go, go, go, go.

speaker: Anyone in?
response: No.

speaker: Nope.
response: Do not stop refreshing your screens.

speaker: I did it, I did it, I’m in the queue.
response: Yay! And they say firefighters are the real heroes.

speaker: Oh, Thursday’s gone. Just Sunday left.
response: Oh, Sunday’s the worst. Everybody’s leaving, most of the good panels are over, and the only T-shirts they have left are small and XXXXL.

speaker: Sunday’s gone.
response: Not Sunday, I love Sunday.

speaker: I can’t believe we’re not going.
response: It’s okay. You know, there, there’s always WonderCon in Anaheim, you know? That, that’s just as good. Excuse me.

speaker: Oh, guys, this is really sad. And in a different way than it was twenty minutes ago.
response: I can’t believe we wasted all that time on our Hulk costumes.

speaker: Sheldon, just buy scalped tickets with us.
response: I told you. Buying scalped tickets is against the rules. If you get caught, you get banned from Comic-Con for life. Life, Leonard. You’re gonna feel pretty silly when we’re 80 years old, and you have to drive me down there and then wait in the car for three days.

speaker: I already found a guy online who’s willing to sell.
response: How do you know this isn’t a sting operation set up by the Comic-Con police?

speaker: Sheldon, just come with us. You’re not gonna make your own convention.
response: You know, there was a time when Comic-Con didn’t exist at all until one lone dreamer with a unique vision made it happen. And you mark my words, I’m gonna rip that guy off.

speaker: Did you tell them that you’re holding your convention at a Marie Callender’s, and that every panellist gets a free slice of pie?
response: I didn’t even get to that part.

speaker: Look, even your friend Wil Wheaton thinks this is a waste of time.
response: Not true. Wil thinks this is a great idea. He was just concerned that he wasn’t a big enough celebrity to headline such an amazing event. Also, that’s the same day that he shampoos his beard.

speaker: Sheldon, buddy, I just don’t think this is going to come together for you.
response: You don’t know that. I still have plenty of solid leads on this list.

speaker: Good luck.
response: No, wait. I need you to call Stan Lee, Leonard Nimoy and Bill Nye the Science Guy, ’cause, legally, I’m not allowed to. Oh, and, also, Carrie Fisher, you know, ’cause I hear he can be pretty nuts.

speaker: Oh, and I thought our days of pretending to be with women who don’t exist were over.
response: Gentlemen, I am one step away from securing a huge guest for my convention.

speaker: Does that step include chloroform and a roll of duct tape?
response: I don’t think that will be necessary for Mr. James Earl Jones. You heard me. The voice of Darth Vader, the Lion King’s dad, and FYI, the guy who says, This is CNN. Which also sounds like Darth Vader.

speaker: How are you gonna get James Earl Jones?
response: Simple. Earlier today, he tweeted that he’s looking forward to going to his favourite sushi restaurant for dinner. I googled an interview from four years ago which was conducted in his favourite sushi restaurant. That’s where he’ll be, and that’s where I’m going, and…

speaker: Sheldon, I don’t care if you get scalped tickets with us or not, but please don’t be creepy and go stalking this poor guy. You’re gonna get in trouble.
response: You’re the ones who are going to get in trouble. You’re buying non-transferable tickets. And from a stranger, no less. Not only can you get banned from Comic-Con, if caught, you could be charged with petty theft. You think about that while I’m warning James Earl Jones about the danger of posting his location on Twitter. He got lucky this time. There are some weirdoes out there. (To the Imperial March theme) Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum. Bom, bom, badala, baba, badalum, bom, badala, bom, bom, forgot my keys, bom, bom, bom, bom, badum, bom, badum…

speaker: Let me guess. You like Star Wars. You know, I’ve been in other movies. But you don’t care about those, do you? I have one thing to say to people like you. I like Star Wars, too. Care to join me?
response: Thank you. My friend Leonard said if I bothered you while you were eating, you’d think I was a creepy stalker.

speaker: Well, your friend Leonard sounds like a real weenie.
response: He is, Mr. Earl Jones, he is.

speaker: You know, when I first read the script for Empire Strikes Back and Darth Vader told Luke he was his father, I thought for sure he was lying.
response: Me, too. But he wasn’t, was he?

speaker: He was not. How messed up was that?
response: So messed up.

speaker: It is true.
response: Oh. Is it true they used scuba gear to create the sound of Darth Vader breathing?

speaker: They sure did.
response: Oh. Is it true that you were pre-med in college and you almost became a doctor?

speaker: That’s right.
response: Oh, James, I could listen to your stories all night.

speaker: Ah-wimoweh, ah-wimoweh…
response: Bring it home, Mufasa. Eee, eee, eee, eee, eee, um, um-a-weh.

speaker: Outside a house.
response: I don’t understand what we’re doing.

speaker: Shh.
response: Whose house is this?

speaker: Ah, Sheldon, this is the perfect end to a perfect night.
response: Okay. But I think it could have ended with the karaoke.

speaker: What were you trying to ask me at the strip club?
response: Oh. How much does it cost to get them off my lap?

speaker: No. Something about a convention.
response: Oh, right. Well, my friends and I couldn’t get into Comic-Con this year, and I was trying to start my own convention, and I was going to ask if you would be a panelist.

speaker: Why don’t you and your friends come to Comic-Con with me?
response: Really?

speaker: Of course. And San Diego is right across the border from my favorite city on Earth, Tijuana, where I’m taking you every night.
response: Ay-yi-yi.

speaker: So, Beau Bridges is on my shoulders, and Jeff Bridges is on Marlon Brando’s shoulders, and remember, we do not have permission to be in the pool… hey, Sheldon, wake up. And Angie Dickinson is about to sic the dogs on us, and I go under the water and Marlon goes under the water, and the water raises about two feet and sloshes all over her patio, and the dogs freak out and run like hell, and then we run like hell. Oh, boy, that was a lot of fun.
response: I’m sorry, who’s Angie Dickinson?

speaker: Yes, but when they're hungry-hungry, you can stop them with marbles.
response: Yeah, the correct animal for interspecies supersolider is koala. You would wind up with an army so cute it couldn't be attacked.

speaker: But half-man, half-owl could fly…
response: The answer is cuddly soldiers with big flat noses. Moving on.

speaker: I said I'll get to it.
response: I'm sensing awkwardness, am I right?

speaker: Yes.
response: Swish.

speaker: Mm, I don't know. Who here has ever been hurt because they were the teacher's pet?
response: It was like the rest of the class wanted Ms. McDonald to forget the quiz.

speaker: Dr. Cooper.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) That's right, good job. Hello. Uh, you wanted to see me?

speaker: Yes. Uh, welcome back.
response: Thank you. I assume you'd like to reopen our dialogue about the university forcing me to continue with string theory?

speaker: You mean the dialogue that went, please, no, please, no, please, no.
response: That's the one. I believe you went last, so, uh, please?

speaker: Dr. Cooper, while you were away, we came up with a solution that would allow you to change your field of study.
response: Wow. Pouting and running away actually worked. I must say, that may not be a lesson you want to reinforce with me. So, um, what is the solution?

speaker: Currently, you're being paid under a grant to specifically research string theory. If we promote you to junior professor, you'll be able to choose whatever field of research you'd like.
response: But if I'm a professor, then I'll have to teach a class.

speaker: That is correct.
response: So your solution is to promote me and pay me more money so that I can impart my knowledge to the next generation of scientists?

speaker: Yes.
response: You people are sick.

speaker: Hey, how'd it go with human resources?
response: Awful. They're allowing me to move on from string theory, but they made me a junior professor and are requiring me to teach a class.

speaker: I don't understand. Why is it bad that you have to teach?
response: What a stupid question.

speaker: The kids are gonna love him.
response: I can't believe I have to waste my time babysitting a bunch of grad students who probably think dark matter is what's in their diapers.

speaker: This might not be that bad. Uh, you like telling people they're wrong.
response: Wrong, Just because I enjoyed that one doesn't mean I always do.

speaker: You enjoy giving people grades.
response: A valid point, but unoriginal. B-minus.

speaker: And you love the sound of your own voice.
response: Yeah, well, of course I do. Listen to it. It's like an earful of melted caramel.

speaker: Look, most importantly, this will let you move on and study dark matter.
response: It is true that many of my heroes have taken students under their wings. Feynman, Einstein, Professor X. Humorously, in the case of Professor X, some of his students actually had wings. That's rich. I'll use that one to lighten the mood after my entire class fails the midterm.

speaker: Hey. We just wanted to see how your class was going. Where is everybody?
response: There is no class.

speaker: Did you send everyone to the principal's office already?
response: No one signed up.

speaker: Well, that's not your fault.
response: I called the department secretary to see what happened. Apparently, I have a reputation for being obnoxious.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I'm sorry.
response: No, it's fine. Now I can devote all my time to dark matter.

speaker: Aw, you brought cookies for everyone?
response: Oh, yes. Fig Newtons. I was going to ask them which scientist both helped to develop calculus and had a famous cookie named after him? And then after someone said Newton, I was going to tell them they're wrong. The cookies are named after a town in Massachusetts. And then I'd throw the cookies away.

speaker: Hey, what if I took your class?
response: Why would you do that?

speaker: I'm thinking about getting my doctorate, and he wants to teach. Why not?
response: Oh, Howard. I appreciate the gesture, but this is a graduate-level physics class. I don't think you'd understand a single thing I was talking about.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm more than smart enough to take your class.
response: No.

speaker: Yes.
response: How would you determine the ground state of a quantum system with no exact solution?

speaker: I would guess a wave-function and then vary its parameters until I found the lowest energy solution.
response: Hmm. Do you know how to integrate X squared times E to the minus X, without looking it up?

speaker: I'd use Feynman's trick, differentiate under the integral sign.
response: Okay. Um, what is the correct interpretation of quantum mechanics?

speaker: Since every interpretation gives exactly the same answer to every measurement, they are all equally correct. However, I know you believe in the Many Worlds Interpretation, so I'll say that. Now do you think I'm smart enough?
response: No.

speaker: Oh, come on. You might've gone to school for a couple more years than me, but guess what, engineers are just as smart as physicists.
response: You take that back.

speaker: So, after drinks with Bernadette, I get home, and Penny calls to complain about her. And then while I'm talking to Penny, I get a text from Bernadette.
response: I am trying to prepare my lesson plan for Howard. Why are you telling me this?

speaker: Because it's taken 15 years, but high school is finally awesome. I love them both, but I'm in the centre now, and I love that even more.
response: Amy, please. I am trying to figure out a way to intellectually emasculate a dear friend of mine.

speaker: But I'm just…
response: Not now.

speaker: Hmm. You're up late.
response: Oh, I'm working on my lesson plan for Wolowitz. He is going to be so lost. Look at this section over here. Even I don't really understand it.

speaker: Sheldon, why are you doing this?
response: I'm a teacher, Leonard. It's my job.

speaker: No, I mean, why are you going to so much trouble to prove that you're smarter than Wolowitz?
response: Oh, it's no trouble, it's actually a pleasure.

speaker: You want to know what I think? I think the idea that someone could be as smart as you, or even smarter, scares the pants off you, and you can't deal with it.
response: Interesting point. You're suggesting that I have emotional issues below my consciousness which drive my behaviour, thus causing me to lash out at anything or anyone that threatens my intellectual superiority.

speaker: Might be something to think about.
response: Leonard?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Howard's allergic to peanuts. How can I use that against him?

speaker: Hey.
response: Okay, now that everyone's here, we can begin.

speaker: Before we do, I just talked to Leonard. And if you're gonna spend all your time trying to belittle me by making this class unnecessarily hard, then I'm out. But if you're interested in making a sincere effort to be a good teacher, then I'm willing to give this a sh*t.
response: I suppose that's a fair request. There's no reason we both can't benefit from this experience.

speaker: Okay.
response: Okay. Well, then, uh, first things first. Um, are you familiar with the Brachistochrone problem?

speaker: I am.
response: Good. And how it relates to the calculus of variations?

speaker: It's an inverted cycloid.
response: Wonderful. Now, what about Euler-Lagrange theorems?

speaker: That's where I'm a little fuzzy.
response: Ha! I knew it. All right. We have a lot of information to cover before your first test. Which, by the way, is in eight minutes. The good news is I'm grading on a curve, so you're pretty much guaranteed a C.

speaker: ♪ All I do is win, win, win no matter what. ♪
response: What are you doing?

speaker: ♪ Everybody hands go up, up and they stay there! ♪
response: What are you doing?

speaker: If you're gonna be a crappy teacher, then I'm gonna be a crappy student. (Singing) ♪ Uh, uh, Ludacris going in on the verse. 'cause I never been defeated and I won't stop now... ♪
response: Will you stop it. This is a classroom. This is not American Bandstand.

speaker: Okay.
response: Now, where was I? Let's see. Oh, yes. Over here. You… What are you doing now?

speaker: Making a straw.
response: Why?

speaker: So I can sh**t you with a spitball.
response: You're not going to do that, and I'll tell you why. This is an institution of higher learning, I am your professor, and you're going to treat me with the prop… You sh*t your spit in my mouth!

speaker: You mean, like, where she's nice to your face? Okay got it. Bye. Hey, boyfriend.
response: Can't talk. Spitball. Probably gonna die.

speaker: Sheldon, I promise. Your uvula does not have an STD.
response: Are you sure? It just doesn't feel as innocent as it used to.

speaker: You reported me to human resources?
response: You violated the sanctity of my mouth.

speaker: Well, I dropped your class, so I hope you're happy.
response: I told you you weren't smart enough to take it.

speaker: I'm smart enough, Sheldon. Asking me a bunch of questions about a topic I'm not familiar with doesn't prove anything. I could do the same to you.
response: Yeah, try me.

speaker: Okay. You enjoy making fun of engineering so much, how do you quantify the strength of materials?
response: Young's modulus.

speaker: Yeah. Okay, how do you prevent eddy currents in a transformer?
response: Laminate the core material.

speaker: That was a hard one. All right. How does the flow rate in a pipe depend on its diameter? You don't know, do you? What's the matter, smart guy? Don't know Poiseuille's law?
response: Thank goodness I got it. Now I can quit checking my stool.

speaker: Okay, this one is for a Cadbury Creme Egg.
response: Oh! It's not even Easter time. This is crazy.

speaker: Sheldon says impossible. Howard and I say not only possible, but as a mode of transportation, way cooler than a Batmobile.
response: You are ignoring the square-cube law. The giant ant would be crushed under the weight of its own exoskeleton. And for the record, the appropriate ranking of cool modes of transportation is jet pack, hoverboard, transporter, Batmobile, and then giant ant.

speaker: What’s with him?
response: Perhaps he’s at a sensitive point in his monthly cycle.

speaker: Are you saying he’s man-struating?
response: Not literally. But as far back as the 17th century, scientists observed a 33-day fluctuation in men’s hormone levels.

speaker: Big or small, I don’t like rabbits. They always look like they’re about to say something, but they never do.
response: Rabbits do have a respiratory system that would support great size. And on a side note, they are one of the few mammals whose scrotum is in front of the penis.

speaker: Would that be a giant rat’s ass?
