response: For the record, giant rats are possible.

speaker: Okay, how about this for a topic, why is Leonard being a giant douche? Assuming giant douches are possible.
response: Of course they are. Leonard’s being one.

speaker: I don’t want to talk about it.
response: But I sense you’re going to and I don’t want to hear about it. Excuse me.

speaker: You guys still on for bowling tonight?
response: Oh, yes. In fact, I’ve prepared some trash talk for the occasion. You bowl like your mama. Unless, of course, she bowls well. In which case, you bowl nothing like her.

speaker: Oh. Ouch.
response: That is what is referred to as a burn on you.

speaker: Oh, hey.
response: Good, Penny, reminder, bowling tonight at seven o’clock.

speaker: No, no, it’s okay. I mean, let’s face it, you guys would get creamed without me.
response: We would indeed. In this particular case, your lack of femininity works to our advantage.

speaker: It’s always nice chatting with you, Sheldon.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: Thinly veiled contempt.
response: Remember, seven o’clock.

speaker: Got it.
response: Pacific Daylight time!

speaker: Bite me!
response: Please reserve that butch spirit for the lanes.

speaker: I thought you were bringing your own bowling shoes.
response: These are my own bowling shoes.

speaker: Then what’s with the disinfectant?
response: I know where my feet have been.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon. How’s it going?
response: Well, well, well. If it isn’t Wil Wheaton, the Green Goblin to my Spider-Man, the Pope Paul the fifth to my Galileo, the Internet Explorer to my Firefox.

speaker: You’re not still carrying a grudge because I b*at you at that card tournament, are you?
response: I’m the proud owner of Wil Wheaton stinks dot com, dot net, and dot org. What does that tell you?

speaker: It tells me that I am living rent-free right here (pointing at Sheldon’s head). You ready to bowl?
response: Oh, I’m ready. I don’t know if Stuart told you what you’re up against tonight, but before you stands the co-captain of the East Texas Christian Youth Holy Roller Bowling League championship team. Seven to twelve year-old division. Also, Penny’s pretty good.

speaker: Great. Then it’s on.
response: Oh, foolish Wil Wheaton, it was never off.

speaker: Yes!
response: A common spare. The Miss Congeniality of the bowling pageant. Before you jump on Twitter to tout your modest accomplishment, watch how it’s really done. I am the ball. My thoughts are its thoughts. Its holes are my holes. (Gets a strike) Yes. Tweet that, Tweety Bird.

speaker: What?
response: This is for you.

speaker: Ice cream?
response: I’ve been familiarizing myself with female emotional crises by studying the comic strip Cathy. When she’s upset, she says Ach and eats ice cream.

speaker: Um, Ach.
response: If you were a cat, I would have brought you a lasagna.

speaker: Did Leonard send you over here?
response: No, we haven’t spoken since your abrupt departure last night caused us to forfeit to Stuart and his dastardly ringer Wil Wheaton.

speaker: Yeah, I’m sorry about that.
response: I’m not too proud to admit that I cried myself to sleep.

speaker: Again, I’m sorry.
response: And let me tell you sleep did not come easily with Leonard in the next room singing along with Alanis Morrisette.

speaker: You’re kidding.
response: No. Clearly another woman in dire need of ice cream.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, what part of this is supposed to make me feel better?
response: The part where I tell you I’ve engineered a rematch with Stuart’s team for tonight.

speaker: Oh, honey, I don’t know. Things are a little weird with Leonard right now.
response: You want me to remove him from the team? I’m the captain, I can do that.

speaker: No, no, that’s okay. Just let me talk to him, and I’ll get back to you.
response: When are you going to talk to him?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: He’s in the laundry room now. Now would be a good time.

speaker: You’re not gonna leave me alone until I do it, are you?
response: Oh, I think we both know the answer to that question.

speaker: Yes, that’s what I’m telling you. We are good. We are great.
response: All right! Fence mended, problem swept under the rug. Time to bowl! Yes, I was eavesdropping, there’s a lot at stake here.

speaker: The Wesley Crushers?
response: No, not the Wesley Crushers. The Wesley “Crushers.”

speaker: Still don’t get it.
response: It’s a blindingly clever play on words. By appropriating his character’s name and adding the S, we imply that we we’ll be the crushers of Wesley.

speaker: Okay, I’m sorry, honey, but the Wesley Crushers sounds like a bunch of people who like Wesley Crusher.
response: What? No! Again, it’s not the Wesley Crushers. It’s the Wesley “Crushers.”

speaker: You know, if you want it to mean you’re crushing Wesley, it’d be the “Wesley” Crushers.
response: Do you people even hear yourselves? It’s not the Wesley Crushers. It’s not the “Wesley” Crushers. It’s the Wesley “Crushers.”

speaker: Hey, look. They named their team after me.
response: No, it’s not the… Never mind.

speaker: So, we’re all clear on the bet and the stakes?
response: Oh, yes. The losers will be publicly humiliated in a fashion to be chosen by the victor. FYI, I plan on having you publish a scientific paper expounding the discredited Velikovsky hypothesis.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I just wanted you to know that I’m really looking forward to wiping the floor with you.
response: Oh, yes? Well, before I respond, let me ask you a question. Is your mother a good or poor bowler?

speaker: After you.
response: No, after you, as we are currently crushing you, Wesley.

speaker: It’s customary for the player on the right-hand lane to bowl first.
response: All right.

speaker: It’s a custom, not a rule.
response: I so loathe you.

speaker: That’s right, Sheldon. Embrace the dark side.
response: That’s not even from your franchise!

speaker: Mmm, mmm. People from opposite sides often have good relationships. You know, Romeo and Juliet, Tony and Maria from West Side Story, what’s-his-name and the big blue chick in Avatar. I’m gonna bowl now.
response: Be the ball, Howard.

speaker: Leave me alone, Sheldon.
response: You weren’t the ball.

speaker: Shel-don! Shel-don! Shel-don! Shel-don!
response: Excuse me. I don’t know who you’re chanting for as I am currently the ball.

speaker: The ball! The ball! The ball! The ball! The ball! The ball!
response: Thank you, Jesus! As my mother would say.

speaker: Oh, that’s me.
response: Did you let Wil Wheaton get in your head?

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: He’s evil. He plays evil mind games. Did he tell you his grandmother died?

speaker: No!
response: Well, if he does, don’t believe it. He’s not above playing the dead meemaw card.

speaker: Yes!
response: Enjoy the accolades now, Wil Wheaton, but like your time on Star Trek

speaker: Penny, you’re up.
response: All right, remember, his meemaw’s alive and be the ball.

speaker: No, this isn’t fair to you, Leonard. I’m sorry.
response: Wait! Where are you going? Penny, come back! I’ll get you ice cream!

speaker: No, let her go.
response: Are you insane? If she leaves, it’s over!

speaker: Tough luck, Sheldon.
response: You did this, didn’t you?

speaker: Do you think I would really break up a couple just to win a bowling match?
response: No, I suppose not.

speaker: Good. Keep thinking that.
response: Wheaton!

speaker: Okay, Raj, hand me the number six torque screwdriver.
response: Stop. We can’t do this, it’s not right.

speaker: Sheldon, you have two choices. Either you let him put a bigger hard drive in the TiVo, or you delete stuff before we go out of town.
response: But once you open the box, you’ve voided the warranty. The warranty is a sacred covenant we’ve entered into with the manufacturer. He offers to stand by his equipment, and we in return agree not to violate the integrity of the internal hardware. This little orange sticker is all that stands between us and anarchy.

speaker: Okay, then we won’t touch the hard drive. We’ll just erase the first season of Battlestar.
response: There. We’re outlaws.

speaker: Oh, I love San Francisco. I wish I was going with you.
response: I understand your envy. This is a can’t-miss symposium. There are going to be discussions on bioorganic cellular computer devices, the advancements in multi-threaded task completion, plus a roundtable on the nonequilibrium Green’s function approach to the photoionization process in atoms.

speaker: Of course I haven’t.
response: George Smoot is a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, one of the great minds of our time. His work in black body form and anisotropy of the cosmic microwave background radiation cemented our understanding of the origin of the universe.

speaker: It’s kind of a funny name, though, Smoot.
response: It’s like talking to a chimp.

speaker: Yeah, I wish.
response: We’re not flying, we’re taking the train.

speaker: Well, we had a vote. Three of us voted for airplane, Sheldon voted for train, so we’re taking the train.
response: Don’t say it like that, Leonard, say it like

speaker: Hey, we’re all going over to the Apple store to make fun of the guys at the Genius Bar. You want to come?
response: Oh, I always enjoy that, but I’m a little busy.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I’m simplifying the task of packing for our trip. See, by attaching RFID tags to my clothing, it will enable my laptop to read and identify the items with this wand. I will then cross-reference them against destination, anticipated activity spectrum, weather conditions, duration of trip, et cetera.

speaker: Well, that does sound much simpler. How long is this going to take?
response: Assuming I can keep up this pace, three hours, 11 minutes, and plus however long it takes to conclude this fairly pointless conversation.

speaker: Wow. Teasing the guys at the Apple store seems a little redundant now.
response: I don’t follow.

speaker: I wouldn’t expect you to. I’ll see you later.
response: Socks, one pair, cotton, argyle, blue. Socks, one pair, cotton, argyle, blue.

speaker: Whatever it is, I’m guessing we’re doing it wrong.
response: Gentlemen, this is the Coast Starlight, one of the great American trains operating on one of the classic American routes. On this side, you’ll see panoramic ocean vistas inaccessible to any other form of transportation, while on your side, you’ll be treated to 350 miles of CostCos, Jiffy Lubes, and cinderblock homes with above-ground pools.

speaker: What’s wrong with Jiffy Lubes?
response: No.

speaker: Why not?
response: That’s over the wheelbase. Are you completely unfamiliar with the suspension characteristics of a pre-1980 Pullman-built Superliner Deluxe passenger coach?

speaker: Sheldon, we’ve been on this train 90 seconds, and you’ve already said a thousand words. Just tell us where to sit and shut up.
response: Here. I’m hoping once you reap the endorphic rewards of the steady clickety-clack of steel wheels on polished rails, your sour disposition will abate.

speaker: It’s not so bad, really. At least these trains have modern plumbing. In India, you squat over a hole in the train and expose your naked buttocks to the chilly air of Rajasthan.
response: He is referring, of course, to third class on Indian Railways’ magnificent Ranakpur Express and its twelve hundred kilometer journey from Maharashtra to the Bikaner Junction.

speaker: Maybe John Connor’s aboard and she’s protecting him from an evil Terminator.
response: Unlikely. That’s a television show, Leonard.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Of course, if SkyNet actually did exist in the future, a perfect way to infiltrate and destroy mankind would be to send Terminators back posing as actors who have played Terminators in popular films and television series, lulling us into a false sense of security, i.e., that’s Summer Glau from The Sarah Connor Chronicles. No, Summer, don’t k*ll me! I’m pro-robot! Ahh!

speaker: At least he’s off the train crap.
response: Whee!

speaker: My money’s on tuck and roll.
response: I’m confused. I thought you were involved in some sort of socially intimate pairing with Leslie Winkle.

speaker: Sheldon, let me explain to you how this works.
response: All right.

speaker: That’s Summer Glau.
response: Yes.

speaker: Sheldon, is there a place on this train to get alcohol?
response: Interesting that you ask. The Coast Starlight recently added the refurbished Pacific Parlour Car. Built in 1956 and originally known as the Santa Fe Lounge Car, the lower level is a theatre…

speaker: Yeah-yeah, which way?
response: and the upper level is a bar that offers wine tastings if you’re going as far as Portland.

speaker: You’re going to need more than 11 hours.
response: Oh, no.

speaker: What’s the matter?
response: I forgot my flash drive.

speaker: So?
response: So we have to go back.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, I’m going to say why and your answer cannot be because I forgot my flash drive.
response: You don’t understand. My flash drive has my paper on astrophysical probes of M-theory effects in the early universe that I was going to give to George Smoot at the conference.

speaker: Why do you have to give your paper to George Smoot?
response: It’s brilliant. He needs to read it.

speaker: So you’ll send him an e-mail when we get back.
response: Then I won’t get to see his face light up as he reads it.

speaker: Right. Of course.
response: Oh, this is an unmitigated disaster.

speaker: Well, there’s nothing you can do about it, so relax, sit back, enjoy the clickety-clack of the steel wheels on the polished rails.
response: You forgot your flash drive, You forgot your flash drive (repeated over and over in time to the sound of the train)

speaker: It’s hot in here. Must be Summer. (Walks towards her, then walks straight past. Returns, makes to talk to her, then turns to two nuns over the other side of the corridor) So, where you gals headed?
response: Okay, I’ve found the perfect solution. We get off the train at the next stop in Oxnard. We then take the 1

speaker: I’ve got a better idea.
response: Are you going to be sarcastic?

speaker: Boy, you take all the fun out of it for me. But look, Penny’s home. Why don’t we just call her, have her go in the apartment, get your flash drive and e-mail you the paper?
response: But the flash drive is in a locked drawer in my desk.

speaker: So?
response: The key is hidden in my room.

speaker: So?
response: Penny would have to go into my room.

speaker: So?
response: People don’t go in my room!

speaker: I see. Well, it seems once again, you’re caught between a rock and a crazy place.
response: Oh, I hate when that happens.

speaker: Yeah, we’re putting the play on for one night in this little 99-seat theatre. Can you come? Oh, great. Do you know 98 other people that might want to come? Oh, hang on. (Switches to another line) Hello?
response: Listen carefully. I’m about to give you a set of instructions, which you must follow to the letter.

speaker: Just a sec. (Switches back to first line) The theatre is above a bowling alley, so it’s a little noisy, but it might be the only chance I’ll ever get to play Anne Frank. And the director is brilliant. He uses the bowling sounds as, like, n*zi a*tillery. Okay, great, I’ll see you then. (Switches line again) Hello?
response: Okay, step four. Do you see that small plastic case on my dresser?

speaker: Your dresser? Who is this?
response: It’s Sheldon.

speaker: Oh, hey, Sheldon! How is San Francisco?
response: I’m not in San Francisco. I’m on a train. Were you even listening to me?

speaker: Uh, no, I was talking to my friend, but what’s up?
response: What’s up? I’ll tell you what’s up. I’m in a crisis situation, and I need you to marshal your powers of concentration, limited as they may be…

speaker: He’s calling to ask you a favour. You might be confused because he didn’t use the words, Penny, Sheldon, please or favour.
response: Okay. Enough chitchat. Okay, step one, locate your emergency key to our apartment. Step two, enter our apartment. Step three, enter my bedroom.

speaker: Oh, hang on, Sheldon, getting another call.
response: No! Leonard, let me tell you something. Personal robots cannot get here soon enough.

speaker: You mean one of the hopeless geeks? No. Those are crazy people. Howard, be a dear and get me another one of these. Now, him, he’s one of those geeks.
response: All right, now, before you enter my bedroom unescorted, I need you to understand that this onetime grant of access does not create a permanent easement. Easement. It’s a legal right

speaker: Placebo, you say. Interesting.
response: Yes, I’m still here. Where am I going? I’m on a train. Now, what you’ll be looking for is a small wooden box located between a Hoberman’s sphere and a sample of quartz flecked with pyrite. Hoberman’s Sphere. It’s a collapsible icosidodecahedron. No, the thing with the time on it is my alarm clock.

speaker: Okay, I got a box, but there’s no key in here. Just letters.
response: That’s the wrong box. Put it back.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, are these letters from your grandmother?
response: Don’t read those letters!

speaker: Oh, look, she calls you Moon Pie. That is so cute.
response: Put down the letters!

speaker: Thank you.
response: I’m back.

speaker: What up, Moon Pie?
response: Nobody calls me Moon Pie but Meemaw!

speaker: Okay, I found the box. Now what?
response: You’re holding a Japanese puzzle box, which takes ten precise moves to open. First, locate the panel with the diamond pattern and slide the centre portion one millimetre to the left. Then, on the opposite end of the box, slide the entire panel down two millimetres. You’ll hear a slight click.

speaker: Hang on. Sheldon, do you have any emotional attachment to this box?
response: No, it’s a novelty I ordered off the Internet. Now, did you hear the click?

speaker: Okay. Great. Now, can I take one where it looks like we’re making out?
response: Okay, now you’re going to insert the flash drive into the USB port. She calls me Moon Pie because I’m nummy-nummy and she could just eat me up, now, please put the flash drive in the USB port. The one that looks like a little duck’s mouth.

speaker: With all due respect, Dr. Cooper, are you on crack?
response: Fine! Smoot-Cooper. Wow, what a diva.

speaker: Which means a spherical multidimensional superfluid shows the same negative-energy density as space-time. So what do you think? What do you think? So what do you think?
response: Hmm.

speaker: What? Is it wrong? Have you seen it somewhere else?
response: Hmm.

speaker: I know this isn't my area, and I could never do the math like you can, but could this be something?
response: Well, (sighs) (stammers) you could have set Newton's gravitational constant to one. And, ugh, the whole thing reeks of blueberry. You know I can't stand these scented markers.

speaker: No one told you to taste them. Come on, is, is this good or not?
response: It's good.

speaker: Really?
response: I like it. I think you're on to something.

speaker: You do? You're not messing with me?
response: Not at all. In fact, I have got something for just such an occasion. I was starting to think I might never get a chance to give it to you. Good job.

speaker: You're giving me a sticker?
response: Not just a sticker. That is a sticker of a kitty saying me-wow.

speaker: I'm not a preschooler.
response: (stammers) Fine, I'll take it back.

speaker: You're still awake?
response: For a man whose last observation was our universe may be the surface of a multidimensional supercooled liquid, "you're still awake" seems like quite the sophomore slump.

speaker: You worked out all the math.
response: Oh, I did more than work out all the math. I wrote a paper.

speaker: You wrote a paper on my idea?
response: I wrote a paper on our idea.

speaker: When did my idea become our idea?
response: When I mixed it with Sheldony goodness and cooked it in the Easy-Bake oven of my mind.

speaker: This is good. Our idea is really good.
response: Well, the lightbulb in this oven is ridiculously bright.

speaker: You know, if no one's thought of this, yet, this could be a big deal.
response: Only way we'll know for sure is if we post it online to the pre-print server. I have it ready to go, but I wasn't gonna do it without you.

speaker: Wow, it's all happening so fast. Should we just sleep on it?
response: We could, but we always run the risk of someone else b*at us to the punch.

speaker: You're sure it's good?
response: My name is right on there with yours. That is a surefire mark of quality. That might as well say "directed by Joss Whedon".

speaker: Okay, partner, let's do it.
response: Come on. Click the mouse with me.

speaker: Well, we did it.
response: Yes, we did, my friend.

speaker: Is your tongue blue?
response: I don't want to talk about it.

speaker: Sheldon, this is superfluid helium. Put this in your mouth, your tongue will freeze and break off.
response: Does it smell like blueberries?

speaker: No.
response: Then we're probably okay.

speaker: Let me see, let me see. One calls it insightful and innovative. We're insightful and innovative.
response: Oh, nice to meet you, Mr. Insightful.

speaker: Oh, the pleasure is mine, Mr. Innovative. Uh, another one says, "The concept shows some real out-of-the-box thinking". Do you hear that, Mr. Out-Of-The?
response: I do, indeed, Mr. Box-Thinking.

speaker: Just dandy, Mr I-Wish-I-Was-Better-At-Improv.
response: Read another one.

speaker: Okay, okay. Uh, "The analogy between space-time and a supercooled fluid is either meaningless or false. I wish this blog would devote itself to real science instead of wasting our time with crackpot wannabe theoreticians in a rush to publish."
response: Who wrote that?

speaker: It's anonymous, and user name "General Relativity".
response: Well, I'm responding to it.

speaker: Uh, don't lower yourself to their level.
response: Look, I am simply going to defend our work, scientist to scientist. And failing that, suggest that his mother enjoys a string of both human and non-human lovers.

speaker: Sheldon, my name's on that paper, too. There's no upside to doing this.
response: He just left another comment.

speaker: "Upon review, I've changed my mind about the Cooper-Hofstadter hypothesis that space-time is like a superfluid. In fact, it's inspired me to come up with my own theory. Maybe space-time is like two clowns with their heads in a bucket, much like Cooper and Hofstadter."
response: Can I respond now?

speaker: Do it.
response: You mess with the bull, you get the horns. I'm about to show this guy just how horny I can be.

speaker: Did he respond yet?
response: Hmm. No, not yet.

speaker: Read it back one more time.
response: (clears throat) "My good sir, we are neither crackpots nor wannabes. In fact, we are experts in our fields. And while you hide behind your anonymity, we stand behind our paper. And later tonight, your mother."

speaker: And you don't think that's too rough?
response: We're just standing behind her. It's not like we're gonna say boo and scare her.

speaker: You know, there was a time when I was alone and had no friends. I'm starting to miss that.
response: He still hasn't responded. What's taking him so long?

speaker: Do you really want him to write back?
response: Yeah, I do. Then no matter how he responds, I am going to destroy him with a picture of a bored cat saying, "Oh, really?"

speaker: No. You have to read it how Dr. Angus McDougal of the University of Edinburgh would. (Scottish accent) "This wee li'l bairn of a theory nearly blew me kilt off."
response: (gasps) He wrote back. "Cooper and Hofstadter resorting to juvenile attempts at humour is proof they have nothing to back up their ridiculous paper. It should come as no surprise given they work at Cal Tech, essentially a technical school, where even the physicists are basically engineers." (gasps) "Engineers"? Do you know how insulting that is?

speaker: Guys, this person's just going out of their way to get a rise out of you.
response: Yeah, but it's still so aggravating.

speaker: See? Better with the accent.
response: And send.

speaker: What did you write?
response: I'm done hiding from bullies. I'm taking this into the real world.

speaker: What does that mean?
response: I told him we'll meet him face-to-face anytime, anywhere.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon!
response: Oh, okay, okay, calm down. (electronic tones play) (gasps) It's him. He's trying to video chat. Perhaps I shouldn't have taken this into the real world.

speaker: Well, I think the anonymity makes everyone feel like they can say things they'd never say to your face.
response: Interesting. I can't think of a single thing I wouldn't say to someone's face.

speaker: You know what? At least you guys did something. You know, you, you had a theory, you wrote a paper, you made an actual contribution. All guys like this do is just stand on other people's work.
response: He's right. I say we call this person back. We've got no reason to hide.

speaker: All right, do it. Call him. Let's find out what this loser's ever accomplished.
response: Click it with me. One, two, three, click.

speaker: Well, hello there.
response: Professor Hawking?

speaker: I like your paper very much. The premise is intriguing.
response: Then why are you attacking us?

speaker: Stephen Hawking liked our paper. (chuckles softly) Said the premise is intriguing.
response: Good to see you again, Mr. Stephen-Hawking Liked-Our-Paper.

speaker: O-o-o-o-h! Again?
response: Obviously you’re not well suited for three-dimensional chess, perhaps three dimensional candyland would be more your speed.

speaker: Just reset the board.
response: It must be humbling to suck on so many different levels.

speaker: Oh, better than North Dakota! (Pause) I guess that joke’s only funny in Nebraska.
response: From the data at hand you really can’t draw that conclusion. All you can say with absolute certainty is that that joke is not funny here.

speaker: Ugh, it was the worst trip, everyone got sick over the weekend.
response: Sick?

speaker: Here we go.
response: What kind of sick?

speaker: Oh, the flu I guess.
response: I don’t need you to guess, I need you to know, now when did the symptoms first appear?

speaker: Maybe Friday.
response: Friday, was that morning or afternoon?

speaker: I… I don’t…
response: Think woman, who blew their nose and when?

speaker: Sheldon, relax, she doesn’t have any symptoms, I’m sure she’s not contagious.
response: Oh please, if influenza was only contagious after symptoms appear it would have died out thousands of years ago. Somewhere between tool using and cave painting, h*m* habilus would have figured out to k*ll the guy with the runny nose.

speaker: Oh, it’s okay, I understand.
response: Thanks for your consideration, now please leave.

speaker: No problem. Welcome home. (Sees Penny out. Turns to find Sheldon spraying the air with Lysol.)
response: What?

speaker: What the hell are you doing?
response: I’m making petrie dishes to grow throat cultures.

speaker: With lime jello?
response: I need a growth medium, and someone polished off the apricot yoghurt. Here, swab my throat.

speaker: I don’t think so.
response: Leonard! If I’m going to get ahead of this thing I need to find out what’s growing in my throat.

speaker: Sheldon, you are not sick. This is, but you are not.
response: We have no idea what pathogen Typhoid Penny has introduced into our environment. And having never been to Nebraska I’m fairly certain that I have no cornhusking antibodies.

speaker: Sheldon, don’t you think you’re overreacting?
response: When I’m lying comatose in a hospital relying on inferior minds to cure me, these jello cultures and my accompanying notes will give them a fighting chance.

speaker: I’m going back to bed.
response: Wait. (Handing him a measuring jug) Put this in the bathroom.

speaker: What for?
response: I need to measure my fluid intake and output to make sure my kidneys aren’t shutting down.

speaker: I mix pancake batter in this!
response: No, that measuring cup has always been for urine.

speaker: You had time to make a label for everything in this apartment, including the label maker, but you didn’t have ten seconds to make one that said urine cup?
response: It’s right here on the bottom.

speaker: Hey.
response: Leonard, where are you?

speaker: I’m at work.
response: At six-thirty in the morning?

speaker: Yes.
response: On Sunday?

speaker: Yes.
response: Why?

speaker: They asked me to come in.
response: Well, I didn’t hear the phone ring.

speaker: They texted me.
response: Well, as I predicted, I am sick. My fever has been tracking up exponentially since 2am, and I am producing sputum at an alarming rate.

speaker: No kidding?
response: No. Not only that, it has shifted from clear to milky green.

speaker: Alright, well, get some rest and drink plenty of fluids.
response: What else would I drink? Gasses? Solids? Ionised plasma?

speaker: Drink whatever you want.
response: I want soup.

speaker: Then make soup.
response: We don’t have soup.

speaker: I’m at work, Sheldon. (A woman enters the apartment building with a barking dog.)
response: Is that a dog?

speaker: Yes,
response: In the lab?

speaker: Hello.
response: Howard, I’m sick.

speaker: Howard’s sleeping, this is his mother. Why are you calling at this ungodly hour?
response: I need soup.

speaker: No, just crazy. Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: I’m sick, thank you very much.

speaker: How could you have gotten it from me, I’m not sick.
response: You’re a carrier. All these people here are doomed. You’re doomed!

speaker: Shhh! Sheldon, what do you want.
response: I want soup.

speaker: Why didn’t you just…. (louder throat clearance) Why didn’t you just have soup at home.
response: Penny, I have an IQ of 187, don’t you imagine that if there were a way for me to have had soup at home I would have thought of it?

speaker: You can have soup delivered.
response: I did not think of that. Clearly febrile delirium is setting in, please bring me some soup while I still understand what a spoon is for.

speaker: Okay, what kind of soup do you want.
response: Well, my mother used to make me this split pea with little frankfurter slices and these home made croutons.

speaker: We have Chicken Tortilla and Potato Leek.
response: Can I get any of those with little frankfurter slices and home made croutons?

speaker: No.
response: Then surprise me. (Blows nose into handkerchief. Shows it to next table) Would you call that moss green or forest green?

speaker: Oh, it’s okay, I didn’t really need to work today, it’s not like I have rent or car payments or anything.
response: Good. Good.

speaker: Okay, well, you feel better.
response: Wait, where are you going?

speaker: Um, home, to write some bad cheques.
response: You’re going to leave me?

speaker: Sheldon, you are a grown man, haven’t you ever been sick before?
response: Well, of course, but, not by myself.

speaker: Really, never?
response: Well, once. When I was fifteen, and spending the summer at the Heidelberg Institute in Germany.

speaker: Studying abroad?
response: No, visiting professor. Anyway, the local cuisine was a little more sausage-based than I’m used to, and the result was an internal blitzkrieg with my lower intestine playing the part of Czechoslovakia.

speaker: And there was no-one there to take care of you?
response: No. No, my mum had to fly back to Texas to help my dad because the house had slipped off the cinderblocks again.

speaker: Again?
response: It was tornado season. And it was an aluminium house. Anyway, the housekeeper in the faculty residence didn’t speak any English, when I finally managed to convince her I was sick, she said “mag das du ein anspeilung?”

speaker: What does that mean?
response: Based on what happened next, I assume it means “would you like an enema?”

speaker: Okay, sweetie, I’ll take care of you, what do you need?
response: Well, my mom used to give me sponge baths.

speaker: Okay, ground rules, no sponge baths, and definitely no enemas.
response: Agreed.

speaker: Okay, nice and cosy, okay, I’ll see you later.
response: Wait. Will you please rub this on my chest.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, can’t you do that yourself?
response: Vaporub makes my hands smell funny.

speaker: But Sheldon….
response: Please, please, please, please, please, please, please.

speaker: I can’t believe I’m doing this.
response: No, no, counter-clockwise or my chest hair mats.

speaker: Sorry.
response: Can you sing “Soft Kitty”.

speaker: What?
response: My mom used to sing it to me when I was sick.

speaker: I’m sorry, honey, I don’t know it.
response: I’ll teach you. “Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur, happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr purr purr.” Now you.

speaker: Soft kitty, warm kitty…
response: Little ball of fur. Keep rubbing.

speaker: Well, I had to, you see what he’s like.
response: Penny! Penny, I’m hungry.

speaker: W-wait!
response: Leonard, I’m hungry!

speaker: Wait! Penny! Take me with you! (Runs after her and bumps into pillar. Falls semi-conscious to the floor. Sheldon appears in his comforter.)
response: I want grilled cheese.

speaker: I don’t think Penny’s ever coming here again.
response: I’m very congested.

speaker: Yeah, so?
response: Can you go to the kitchen, and get me the turkey baster labelled mucus.

speaker: If I stand, I’ll vomit.
response: Under the sink, yellow Tupperware bowl.

speaker: Probably because we left the diagram of it in the restaurant, and none of us wanted to walk back.
response: I know the real reason you never made progress with that idea. You thought of it September 22nd, 2007. Two days later, Penny moved in, and so much blood rushed to your genitals, your brain became a ghost town.

speaker: That's not what happened.
response: I remember it distinctly because I had just composed my annual poem commemorating the anniversary of Dr. Seuss's death.

speaker: No one wants to hear it.
response: Why, die. Why did he die? Old, told. I was told he was old.

speaker: Penny is not the reason I didn't pursue that idea.
response: Oh, really? Since meeting her, what have been your greatest accomplishments?

speaker: I think someone owes me an apology.
response: Well, don't feel bad. I think we've all been distracted since the girls entered our lives.

speaker: You admit Amy's a distraction?
response: Oh, very much so. Listen to this. This is from two days ago. Hi. Hope you're having a good day. Who has time for this constant sexting?

speaker: My cousin has a cabin out in the woods.
response: I'm not going to a cabin in the woods. Did you see the movie Cabin in the Woods?

speaker: Then we'll go to a hotel.
response: A hotel? Did you see The Shining?

speaker: We could go up to Big Bear and get a house on the lake.
response: Did you see The Lake House?

speaker: Nothing bad happens in The Lake House.
response: Yeah, well, no, not to them. To me. Time traveling mailbox. The only time that traveled was an hour and half of my life down the toilet.

speaker: Fine. Then we'll just stay here and do it.
response: Well, you didn't suggest a beach house.

speaker: You would go to a beach house?
response: Well, good Lord, no, have you seen Jaws?

speaker: For your information, Emily is working tonight.
response: Yeah, one would assume, on getting out of the pit.

speaker: Okay, let's focus. The girls are gone, we have 48 hours. There are no distractions. Let's change the world.
response: Thinking caps on.

speaker: Oh. I never saw that.
response: Really?

speaker: Oh. It's wonderful, and I swear I'm not saying that because Justin Timberlake is in it.
response: Yeah, I have it on Blu-ray. We should watch it.

speaker: Guys, in 30 seconds, we went from let's change the world to let's watch TV.
response: I'm sorry. Is that a no?

speaker: I, I think I still have it.
response: I did not get a clear answer. I'm gonna set this down now.

speaker: Also mine.
response: Wait. I'm confused. Why would you need both a robot girlfriend and a robot prostitute?

speaker: You know, let's just come up with something new.
response: You know, a number of significant innovations have been inspired by science fiction. The, the geosynchronous satellite from Arthur C. Clarke. The Motorola flip phone, that came from Star Trek. And I've long suspected that the idea of an African-American president was stolen from the movie Deep Impact.

speaker: How cool would that be if we could make one of those a reality?
response: If we could figure out the scientific basis for Marty's hover board, that would have universal application.

speaker: Oh, I have an idea.
response: I think I have the same one.

speaker: This is Hot Tub Time Machine all over again. If future Biff goes back to 2015 right after he gives young Biff the almanac, he could get back to the 2015 with Marty and Doc in it. Because it wasn't until his 21st birthday that 1955 Biff placed his first bet.
response: Wait. Whoa, whoa. Is placed right?

speaker: What do you mean?
response: Is placed the right tense for something that would have happened in the future of a past that was affected by something from the future?

speaker: Had will have placed?
response: That's my boy.

speaker: Okay, so, it wasn't until his 21st birthday that Biff had will have placed his first bet and made his millions. That's when he altered the timeline.
response: Yeah, but he had will haven't placed it!

speaker: What?
response: Unlike Hot Tub Time Machine, this couldn't be more simple. When Biff gets the almanac in 1955, the alternate future he creates isn't the one in which Marty and Doc Brown ever use the time machine to travel to 2015. Therefore, in the new timeline, Marty and Doc never brought the time machine…

speaker: Wait. Is brought right?
response: Marty and Doc never had have had brought?

speaker: I don't know. You did it to me.
response: Oh, I'm going with it. Marty and Doc never had have had brought the time machine to 2015. That means 2015 Biff could also not had have had brought the almanac to 1955 Biff. Therefore, the timeline in which 1955 Biff gets the almanac is also the timeline in which 1955 Biff never gets the almanac. And not just never gets. Never have, never hasn't, never had have hasn't.

speaker: Guys.
response: Do you know that the word wiener comes from the German name of the Austrian capital Vienna, or Wien?

speaker: Guys, what are we doing? We sent the girls away so we could focus.
response: I don't think it worked.

speaker: All right.
response: Oh, this is already better. There are far fewer distractions in here.

speaker: Or if we could figure out a way to supercool the materials, we could utilize quantum coupling.
response: Well, I wonder if anyone's tried that.

speaker: I'm sure Mrs. Florida's walking funny. Can we get back to work?
response: Yeah, he's right. Oh, here's a thought. What if we use some form of operant conditioning techniques to keep us from getting off topic?

speaker: Like behavior modification?
response: Yeah, exactly. Did you know those techniques were used to actually teach pigeons to play ping-pong?

speaker: We could snap a rubber band on our wrists every time we get sidetracked.
response: Mmm, not bad. You know, in medieval times, idle chatter was punished with a device called the scold's bridle. It's an iron cage that's locked around the head and pierces the tongue.

speaker: If only we had one.
response: Oh, I'll check Amazon.

speaker: All right, now, one benefit of quantum coupling…
response: Wait, a question, who decides if someone's gone off topic?

speaker: I think it'll be pretty clear. If not, we'll take a vote. Oh, and also…
response: Ow. We didn't vote!

speaker: We didn't have to, that was clearly a tangent. Now come on. Back to work. If we're leaning towards quantum coupling… Aah! Why?
response: You said quantum coupling. That made me think of the show Quantum Leap. That's a tangent and it's your fault.

speaker: Thank you. And now I owe you one.
response: Ow. That was your fault.

speaker: Everyone stop. This was a stupid idea. Negative reinforcement isn't working.
response: I think you mean positive punishment. Negative reinforcement is the removal of a positive stimulus. It's a common mistake.

speaker: Negative reinforcement is really wrong?
response: Oh, it's used incorrectly all the time. Even Bill Murray makes that mistake in the first scene of Ghostbusters.

speaker: No.
response: Leonard's right. We can't just jump ahead. We have to watch the whole movie.

speaker: It's late. We've wasted hours. Can we please find it in ourselves to do any amount of work tonight?
response: But we didn't see them bust one ghost.

speaker: So you're, you're saying we should stand here in my lab on a Saturday night and watch the rest of Ghostbusters on a crappy laptop?
response: No.

speaker: Okay.
response: Excuse me. Is it at all possible that you're knitting a pair of pants? Oh, well, no, you're understandably terrified. But, you know, allow me to explain. 45 days ago, um, I embarked on a railroad journey of healing because my university was making me do string theory, and my favorite comic book store b*rned down, and when my room mate got engaged, my girlfriend wanted to move in with me, which was no doubt a ploy just to see my, well, excuse my language, but my bathing suit parts. Uh, sir, may I use your phone?

speaker: I don't think so.
response: Yeah, well, I understand that I'm half naked, but there is a reasonable explanation. While I slept in my sleeper car, all my possessions were stolen. Now, typically, I wear pyjamas, but I recently adopted a hobo lifestyle and pyjamas are the sleep-pants of the Man. I'll have you know, Mahatma Gandhi wore no pants and a nation rallied behind him. My good man, now, before you walk away, I know that I may appear deranged, but I am, in fact, a world-renowned physicist. Ask me the difference between a boson and a fermion. Go ahead, ask. Bosons have integer spin, fermions have half-integer spin. My legs are getting cold. Why won't anybody help me?

speaker: Um, let me just have some coffee first, and then I'll have the strength to tell you how much I won't be doing that. (Phone rings) Hello?
response: Hello, Leonard.

speaker: Hey, buddy. Good to hear your voice.
response: Uh, I'm in Kingman, Arizona, and, uh, I need you to come pick me up.

speaker: I'd love to. I'm just about to do yoga with Penny.
response: Leonard, I'm at the police station. I was robbed. They took my phone, my wallet, my iPad, everything.

speaker: Oh, my God, are you okay?
response: No, I'm not okay. Uh, I'm wearing borrowed pants, I don't have I.D., and one of the officers here won't stop calling me chicken legs.

speaker: Oh.
response: 2530 East Andy Devine Avenue,

speaker: Okay.
response: Hurry.

speaker: Sheldon, hang tight. Hey, do you want me to bring anything?
response: Oh, yes, please. A pair of pants. And my toothbrush. Yeah, and my mail. And a really good comeback for chicken legs, because "I know you are, but what am I?" was met with stony silence.

speaker: I said well past it.
response: Excuse me, Officer Hernandez? Any leads on the person who stole my belongings?

speaker: Not yet.
response: Well, perhaps I can help. Sherlock Holmes always says when you eliminate the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth. Now, have, have you tried doing that?

speaker: Nope.
response: Well, maybe you should. There's lots of books called Sherlock Holmes, and there's no books called Officer Hernandez.

speaker: It wouldn't k*ll you to pick up the phone.
response: Any word on my stolen items?

speaker: We're doing everything we can.
response: You know, Sherlock Holmes liked to use cocaine to sharpen his focus. But I'm sure those Cool Ranch Doritos are doing the trick.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Leonard. Oh, I'm so happy to see you.

speaker: Are you okay?
response: Oh, I'm fine. Why did you come?

speaker: What do you mean, why did I come? You're my boyfriend. I haven't seen you in over a month. I just drove six hours to help you out. Don't you have anything to say besides why did you come?
response: I do, but, I feel uncomfortable saying it out loud in front of these police officers.

speaker: So, Sheldon, tell us about your trip. Where'd you go?
response: Where didn't I go? I went to New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Denver, Seattle.

speaker: How were they?
response: Oh, I have no idea. I never left the train station.

speaker: Hang on. You travelled across the entire country and never left a train station?
response: Why would I? That's where all the cool trains are.

speaker: I'm sorry, so you never went outside?
response: Or had a single piece of fruit.

speaker: Oh, my God, no.
response: At the hot dog stand in the Denver train station, Heinz ketchup. At the hot dog stand in the Salt Lake City train station, Heinz ketchup. At the hot dog stand in the Indianapolis train station?

speaker: I don't care.
response: Wrong. Hunt's. Hey, Amy, what do you say? You ready to move on to the mustard round?

speaker: Have you not noticed that I've been sitting back here quietly stewing for the past two hours?
response: I just thought you were bad at the game.

speaker: I'm mad at you. How could you just go away like that without even saying good-bye, and then call Leonard for help instead of me?
response: Amy, may I please have a moment of privacy to speak with my roommate?

speaker: We're in a moving car. What do you expect me to do? Stick my fingers in my ears?
response: Well, I was thinking put your head out the window like a dog, but that'll work. Please? This'll be quick. Leonard? As soon as we get home, I want to have coitus with Amy. Okay, she can't hear. The reason I called you is because I didn't want Amy to know I couldn't make it on my own.

speaker: What's the big deal?
response: Oh, of course it's no big deal to you. You idolize me, and nothing could ever knock me off that pedestal you put me on.

speaker: Just tell her.
response: I called Leonard because I failed. And I didn't want you to think less of me.

speaker: You were worried about that?
response: Yes.

speaker: Sheldon, it's okay with me that you're not perfect.
response: Can I have one more moment with Leonard?

speaker: Sure.
response: Amy just hurt my feelings. I want to break up with her.

speaker: That's right, sucka.
response: I wish I'd never gone on that trip. I feel no better now than when I left.

speaker: Yeah. If you had told anyone that you were going away on a train by yourself across the country, do you know what they would have said?
response: That I couldn't do it?

speaker: But you did do it. So what if it didn't all go your way? That's what makes it an adventure.
response: That's a good point. You know, I'm a lot like Gandalf the Grey. He fought the Balrog and emerged stronger than ever as Gandalf the White. I was robbed of my phone and pants, and I, too, came back stronger. And whiter, too, 'cause I wasn't in direct sunlight for six weeks.

speaker: See? This trip was good for you.
response: Indeed. I was the world's smartest caterpillar. And then after pupating in our nation's railway system, I've burst forth as the world's smartest butterfly.

speaker: Butterfly could've gotten himself home from Arizona.
response: Yeah, I feel renewed. I'm ready to deal with any changes that come my way.

speaker: Hey, look who's back.
response: Your hair is different. You changed your hair. I can't take this. I'm out.

speaker: I thought your phone got stolen.
response: Yeah, it did, but luckily all my photos got backed up to the Cloud.

speaker: And you thought they all had a silver lining.
response: Here, day one, uh, this was the seat I was going to sit in but didn't because there were cracker crumbs on it. As it was first class, I suspect Ritz. This is the train bathroom. This is the Imodium I took so I would never have to use the train bathroom.

speaker: I cannot believe you travelled the entire country and never left the train station.
response: I know. You know, I almost died in a fire in Des Moines, but I stayed put. FYI, that's when the Imodium gave out.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s not a great time, what do you want?
response: Hello to you, too. I’m sorry, but this is important.

speaker: What is it?
response: Back to the Future II was in the Back to the Future III case, and Back to the Future III was, get this, in the Back to the Future II case.

speaker: So?
response: So, did you do that, or am I in the house with an intruder?

speaker: Sheldon, I got to go inside. It’s getting rough out here.
response: You’re dodging the question, I knew it was you. What was that?

speaker: What was what?
response: This isn’t a very good connection, but it sounded like someone just released a kraken.

speaker: Okay, I’m hanging up now. You know there’s no such thing as a k… (Leonard is attacked and dragged into the sea by a huge tentacle. Sheldon wakes up in bed.)
response: No!

speaker: What’s the matter?
response: Um, well, I was worried that you might be missing Leonard. And that might be causing you to have bad dreams, like the kind you’d get if you watched Clash of the Titans right before you went to bed.

speaker: Sweetie, did you have a bad dream?
response: To be honest, I did.

speaker: Aw.
response: Back to the Future II was in the Back to the Future III case. Leonard did it.

speaker: Good night.
response: No, wait. Perhaps I should sleep here so you don’t miss Leonard as much, uh, ’cause you’re being kind of a baby about it.

speaker: You know what? That would make me feel better. Thank you.
response: You’re welcome. Good night.

speaker: Well, you should be, ’cause she was looking good.
response: Dear Lord, you’re an astronomer. Although you may have earthly woes, get your mind back on the stars. Gee, even the lowly dung beetle chooses to plot its course by using the Milky Way.

speaker: Is that true?
response: Everything I say is true. Now, of course, the dung beetle also enjoys eating faeces, living in faeces and making little balls out of faeces, so, you know, pick and choose which aspects of its lifestyle you want to embrace.

speaker: Thanks. Oh, Sheldon, since Amy’s out of town, would you like to join us?
response: I want you to be happy, too, but not enough to do anything about it.

speaker: No.
response: Well, now that I’ve piqued your interest, welcome to the exciting world of 3D chess.

speaker: Why don’t you just admit you only want to play this game because you always play it with Leonard and you miss him?
response: You overestimate his significance in my life.

speaker: Mmm.
response: Do I miss how he makes a face on my toaster waffle with syrup? No. Do I miss the way he fixes the zipper on my jacket when it gets stuck? I don’t think so. Do I miss how we say good night to each other through the walls of our bedroom using Morse code? (Taps out No in morse code on the table)

speaker: Okay, I get it, I get it. You are an emotionless robot.
response: Well, I try.

speaker: All right, let’s just get this stupid game over with.
response: Great. I’ll go first.

speaker: Okay.
response: By the way, how are you with zippers?

speaker: Why?
response: Well, I really need to go to the bathroom, and this one’s gone all cattywampus.

speaker: Really? Why?
response: My queen can now take your rook from below.

speaker: So that means I lose, right? It’s over?
response: If I make this move, but I won’t because we’re having too much fun.

speaker: Okay, let’s take a break.
response: We’re all out of alcohol.

speaker: I wasn’t going to get alcohol. Gosh, I wonder what Leonard’s doing right now. I miss him so much.
response: Well, if you’d like, we could call him. I mean that you could call him. As I’ve explained, the absence of my friends does not cause me pain. As rock and roll bad boy Paul Simon once said, I am a rock, I am an i-i-i-island.

speaker: I’m calling him.
response: Oh, goodie, put him on speaker phone.

speaker: Best time of my life.
response: Isn’t it five thirty in the morning there?

speaker: Uh-oh, hang on.
response: Are you in danger?

speaker: Leonard, Leonard? I cannot believe we were missing that jerk.
response: You were.

speaker: I can’t believe it. All this time I’ve been doing nothing but sit around and miss that guy. And you know what the worst part is?
response: That you’re having to process your emotional pain without vodka?

speaker: No. Yeah. But you know what the second-worst part is? He does not miss me at all.
response: Allow me to comfort you. At least you’ve got your health.

speaker: Really? That, that’s it? That’s comforting?
response: Um, uh, in a hundred years, you’ll both be dead and it won’t matter?

speaker: No. Come on, you’re supposed to say, of course he misses you, the only reason he’s partying is to cover up his pain.
response: Oh, no, I don’t think that’s true at all.

speaker: This is ridiculous. Why am I upset just because he’s off having a good time?
response: Well, perhaps you’re obsessively picturing him engaged in drunken coitus with another woman. Is that it? Did I get it right?

speaker: Okay, that, that’s great. You can stop trying to make me feel better now.
response: Actually, I can’t. Before Leonard left, he made me promise that I’d take care of you.

speaker: He did?
response: Yes.

speaker: Oh, that’s really sweet.
response: Plus, if I do a good job, he said he’d bring me back a sailor’s cap.

speaker: Well, now I miss him even more.
response: Well, if it’s any consolation, I’m sure Leonard’s tormented every moment he’s away from your warm embrace and cherry lips.

speaker: Thanks.
response: Oh, seriously?

speaker: Come on. It’s still early. Let’s do something.
response: Well, I have been toying around with an idea for 4D chess.

speaker: How about we just talk?
response: All right. In 4D chess…

speaker: No. Come on, let’s talk about our lives. Tell me something about you I don’t know.
response: I own nine pairs of pants.

speaker: Okay, that, that’s a good start, but I was thinking maybe something a little more personal.
response: I see. I own nine pairs of underpants.

speaker: How about I go first?
response: But I don’t want to know how many underpants you own. Although, based on the floor of your bedroom, I’d say it’s a thousand.

speaker: Okay, look, here’s something people do not know about me. When I first moved out to L.A., I did a topless scene in a low-budget horror movie about a k*ll gorilla. Ugh! After I did it, I felt so ashamed. Thankfully, that thing never came out.
response: I’ve seen that. Yeah. Serial Apeist. Howard found it online the day we met you.

speaker: Oh, God.
response: And it was literally the moment you walked out the door. But I see the type of personal revelations you’re going for. Okay, here’s one I thought I’d take to the grave.

speaker: Okay.
response: Hmm. A while back, YouTube changed its user interface from a star-based rating system to a thumbs-up rating system. I tell people I’m okay with it, but I’m really not.

speaker: That’s your big revelation?
response: Yes. Whew, I feel ten pounds lighter.

speaker: Okay, you know what? I give up. I’m going to bed.
response: Here’s something else you don’t know about me. You just hurt my feelings.

speaker: What did I do?
response: I opened up and shared something deeply upsetting to me, and you treated it as if it were nothing.

speaker: I, I didn’t think it was a big deal.
response: It is to me; that’s the point.

speaker: Sheldon, you are right. I’m really sorry. I should’ve known better.
response: Your apology is accepted.

speaker: Thank you. How about a hug?
response: How about a hearty handshake?

speaker: Come on.
response: Now I know how you felt getting mauled by that sex-crazed gorilla.

speaker: Aaaaaaah!
response: Hello. I'm Doctor Sheldon Cooper, and welcome to Sheldon Cooper presents Fun with Flags, the final episode flagtacular. (gasps) I knew it was coming. Still scary. Now, I'm sure you're thinking, the final episode? Who will stand between us and flag ignorance?

speaker: I know I was thinking that. Is this a show on flags or mind reading?
response: But the truth is I can no longer balance a full-time career, a popular Internet show, and a girlfriend.

speaker: And he really does have one, you jerks on the comment board.
response: So as they say, all good things must come to an end.

speaker: After only 232 episodes.
response: 233 if we include the one somebody forgot to press record on.

speaker: You said you weren't gonna bring that up.
response: And you said you pressed record. Anyway, please sit back, relax, and join us as we take our final lap, as indicated by the waving of this racing flag. And, of course, white flags can also represent surrender, the Stewards of Gondor, and the Japanese Minamoto clan, but I'm sure you remember that from episode sixty-two, White Flags, Who's Wavin' ‘Em and Why?

speaker: That was a good one.
response: It was so good.

speaker: Oh. We were just talking about how much we love working with you. Isn't that right? Dan?
response: Over the years here at Fun With Flags, we've had an opportunity to learn, laugh, wonder.

speaker: And, yes, even shed a tear or two.
response: Like when you do a two-hour Fourth of July spectacular and it doesn't get recorded.

speaker: How many times do I have to say I'm sorry?
response: How about four thousand. One for every domino I set up to make that American flag. Please enjoy these highlights.

speaker: Australia, mate.
response: And now it's time for the speed round of Flag or Not a Flag.

speaker: Say, Betsy Ross, what you working on?
response: I have no idea. Because the story of me sewing the first American flag is unsupported poppycock.

speaker: Then who did sew it, hmm?
response: Don't ask me. I'm just a simple seamstress whose descendants are out to make a quick buck.

speaker: I do.
response: Wait, that purple flag indicates that marine pests, such as jellyfish, are present.

speaker: Wow, that flag is a lifesaver.
response: No. This is. Stop looking at my legs.

speaker: Action.
response: Welcome back. Our guest today is a returning fan favourite. He puts the reading in your rainbow, the Geordi in your La Forge, and the Kunta in your Kinte, Mr. LeVar Burton.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon. Now, remember our deal.
response: You do this, I delete your contact information.

speaker: While?
response: While you watch me do it.

speaker: Great. Happy to be back.
response: Well, since you're here, I'd like to get your opinion on something. In honour of Black History Month, I portrayed George Washington Carver in a loving tribute that my roommate called wildly r*cist. What do you think? (On recording) Hi. My name is George.

speaker: Oh, hell, no.
response: You heard him, Leonard. No, it's not r*cist.

speaker: Even though your dress is ugly.
response: Well, my little flag-keteers, it looks like the last episode of Fun with Flags is at an end. If I could, I would run each and every one of you viewers up a flagpole and salute you. And if you touched the ground, burn you. I'd like to take a moment to personally thank Dr. Amy Farrah Fowler, who you may or may not know is the first woman to co-host a flag or banner-related Internet info-tainment show.

speaker: Take that, glass ceiling.
response: And if I may get serious for a moment, hosting this show has been one crazy ride. But with all its ups and downs, I wouldn't give it up for the world. Except for now, when I'm giving it up. Before I sign off, I'd, uh, I'd like to share with you all one last use for a white flag. It's good for times like this. Good night.

speaker: Cut. Sheldon, that was beautiful.
response: If you didn't press record…

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: How come you're up so late?
response: I posted the last episode of Fun with Flags hours ago, and not a single person cared enough to comment. All that effort for nothing.

speaker: Mm. I know how you feel. I spent the day throwing out a man's entire career, and all that's left is an old bottle of champagne and a naked lady pen that Raj took when he thought no one was looking.
response: It's not the same thing. I don't think you know how I feel at all.

speaker: Sad?
response: Hmm. You do get me. Someone left a comment.

speaker: Yeah. What did they say?
response: Too bad your show is done. I kind of liked it. Leonard, did you hear that? Oh, the people are heartbroken. I can't take this away from the world. Fun with Flags is back.

speaker: Congratulations.
response: Let's celebrate.

speaker: Sheldon, that wasn't for you.
response: Oh, no, I'm not going to drink it. I just wanted to hear the pop. Yeah, I knew it was coming. Still scary.

speaker: Ugh. What are you doing here?
response: You told me not to call, and I didn't know how else to give you the good news. Fun with Flags is back, and you can be in the next episode.

speaker: Wil Wheaton said, get a gate. I don't know why I didn't get a gate.
response: You, at least listen to the premise. Since you were born in Germany, I thought we could talk about German flags. How do you feel about dressing up like a swastika?

speaker: It’s called the Born Again Boat Ride. Christian Quarterly gave it their highest rating, five thorny crowns. I do wish you’d come with me, Sheldon.
response: Well, Mom, if I did, it would be conclusive proof that your God can work miracles.

speaker: Oh, it is a hoot and a half. You write your sins on a clay pigeon, they fire ‘em up in the air, and you pulverize them with a 12-gauge g*n full of our Lord’s forgiveness.
response: Frankly, Mom, I’m encouraged to see how advanced your group has become, willing to sail out into the ocean without fear of falling off the edge.

speaker: For example, if Shelly was aboard, he’d write “smart mouth” on his pigeon, and then bam!
response: The Lord giveth and the Lord bloweth away. Well, Mom, according to my itinerary for our weekend together, the fun begins with fried chicken.

speaker: Sounds delicious.
response: Good, ’cause I got you everything you need to make it. You are in for a treat. My mother’s fried chicken is why we had to buy my dad the extra large coffin.

speaker: Sheldon, she just got off the plane. She doesn’t want to cook.
response: Of course she does. Making me food is her way of saying I love you. Making me food when she’s too tired to cook is her way of saying I really love you.

speaker: Actually, I wouldn’t mind going out for a bite, Sheldon.
response: Won’t that spoil our appetites for the chicken you’re going to make me?

speaker: I’ve never had it, but there’s no harm in trying something new.
response: There’s a lot of harm in trying something new. That’s why we test out drugs and cosmetics on bunny rabbits.

speaker: Actually, I had him tested as a child. Doctor says he’s fine.
response: Told you.

speaker: Irasshaimase!
response: Stop yelling! I’m not happy about this.

speaker: What’s the last thing you were ever happy about?
response: The prospect of fried chicken.

speaker: So, Shelly, what’s up with you and your friend Amy, if you don’t mind a mother prying a bit?
response: Well, there’s actually big news on the Amy front. She’s been studying the neurobiology of addiction in lower animals. She is this close to getting a starfish hooked on cocaine.

speaker: Oh, that’s a funny turn, isn’t it? You never think about it going the other way. Well, you can’t force things. You need to figure out if you’re in a relationship or if you’re just calling it one. It’s like they say, a cat can have kittens in the oven but that don’t make ‘em biscuits.
response: And that reminds me of another saying. You can lead a chicken to Crisco, but you can’tmake your mother fry it.

speaker: It was good. The only thing that would have made it better is if it was cooked and if it was beef. Sheldon, when is your landlord going to fix the elevator?
response: I don’t know. Lately we’ve been talking about converting it into a m*ssile silo.

speaker: Your son seems to think we need to launch a pre-emptive strike on Burbank.
response: Get them before they get us.

speaker: I couldn’t find you guys so I bought six new friends. Three, sadly, are dead.
response: Mom, you remember Rajesh? Rajesh, my mother.

speaker: I’m so lonely.
response: Oh, yes, born alone, die alone. It’s a tragic human condition. Now, Raj, if you’ll excuse my mother, she’s about to make a pecan pie that’ll be so good I’ll almost forget how she blew it with the fried chicken.

speaker: Sheldon, your friend is hurtin’. What do we do when someone’s hurtin’?
response: Offer them a hot beverage.

speaker: And when they’re drunk as a skunk, what beverage do we offer?
response: Coffee.

speaker: I didn’t get a lot of that because of your accent, but the general tone was soothing and somehow I feel better.
response: I’m not going to get my pecan pie, am I?

speaker: You want some Oreos?
response: Double Stuf?

speaker: No, regular.
response: Nice. Kick a man when he’s down.

speaker: Sure. One thing you really miss when you’re on vacation is laundry.
response: Careful, you’re using too much Downey. You know if my clothes get too soft it makes me sleepy.

speaker: Well, this takes me back. Me doing your laundry, you next to me criticizing.
response: It is nice, isn’t it?

speaker: Sheldon, you didn’t tell me your mom was coming.
response: It was in my weekly e-mail blast. Right between beet season is finally here, and uh-oh, red stool from beets leads to cancer scare.

speaker: Well, it’s super cute on. That top has paid for itself in free drinks like ten times what it cost.
response: Yes, Penny has a lot of her money tied up in promiscuity futures.

speaker: Oh, not crazy at all. And don’t b*at yourself up. When I was your age, you could have me for a car ride and a bottle of strawberry wine.
response: Now that will not be in this week’s e-mail blast.

speaker: Nope. She says if I don’t back out she’s going to go on a hunger strike. It would take years before she’d be in any kind of danger, but still.
response: I’ve got a treat for us tomorrow, Mom. I’m taking you to see Saul Perlmutter give a lecture about his Nobel Prize-winning work in cosmology. And the best part is, at the Q and A afterward, I’ve worked up a couple of Q’s that will stump his sorry A.

speaker: I don’t know, Shelly. I thought we could do a little sightseeing.
response: What sight is better than your little boy embarrassing a Nobel laureate?

speaker: What do you say?
response: What do I say? I say you people need to stop ruining my mom’s visit with your sushi, and your sadness and your slutty shirts. Stop it.

speaker: Oh, doctors are always changing their mind. One week bacon grease is bad for you. The next week we’re not getting enough of it. Good morning, Shelly.
response: Mom, I want to apologize for my behaviour last night.

speaker: Apology accepted.
response: Great. Now, you’re going to love the Perlmutter lecture. Look, he will be stating that the universe is older than 6,000 years, but I thought you could stick your fingers in your ears and hum Amazing Grace during those parts.

speaker: I am still going out with your friends.
response: But I apologized. And that was hard for me because I didn’t do anything wrong.

speaker: Shelly, I hung out with you in enough dusty lecture halls while you were growing up. I want to go sightseeing. So why don’t you have some pancakes, get dressed and come with us.
response: I’m not going, and you can’t make me.

speaker: You’re right, I can’t. Have a nice day.
response: Well, I’m going to stand here until you change your mind.

speaker: I’m just gonna take my bacon grease and slide over there.
response: I can’t believe my own mother is abandoning me.

speaker: I am not abandoning you. Sheldon, abandoning you is leaving you in a basket on a church doorstep. I am going to Hollywood and thank a wax Ronald Reagan for his service to our country.
response: We appear to be at a crossroads in our relationship, Mother.

speaker: Sorry. Syrup.
response: All right, Mom. When you’re at the Ripley’s Believe It Or Not Museum, if they have an exhibit about a mother who threw away a chance to spend the day with the world’s most wonderful son, believe it, because it’s true. (Grabs pancakes and snatches syrup from Leonard’s hand)

speaker: Are you getting sick?
response: No, I’m just allergic to people who get Nobel Prizes for no good reason.

speaker: Sheldon, is it possible that your foul mood, or, to use the clinical term, bitchiness, is because your mother isn’t making you a priority?
response: No. Or to use the clinical term, nuh-uh.

speaker: Are you sure? The infant-mother pair-bond is the building block of primate psychology.
response: Oh, there it is. It always comes back to monkeys with you. Just monkeys, monkeys, monkeys.

speaker: Sheldon, we’re all animals. And granted, there are aspects of you that are extraordinary, but when it comes to emotions and relationships, you’re just like everybody else.
response: Are you trying to suggest that my emotional problems are no different than those of a stupid person?

speaker: Actually, some research indicates that by not over-thinking, the less intelligent handle emotions better. (He sneezes again) Sure you’re not coming down with a cold?
response: Oh, yes, the common cold. Just like everyone else. You’d love that, wouldn’t you?

speaker: You take notes, darlin’. The real way to get a man is with melted cheese and cream of mushroom soup. He’ll die at 50 but his love will be true.
response: I need a tissue.This one got wet.

speaker: Here.
response: Thank you. Yeah, I’ve learned something today. You and I, in so many ways, other than intelligence and what counts, we’re the same. (Sneezes)

speaker: Sweetheart, are you sick?
response: I hope so, because if this is well, life isn’t worth living.

speaker: Oh, sugarpie, you are burning up. We’ve got to get you to bed.
response: Okay.

speaker: Don’t worry. Mama’s here to take care of her baby.
response: And just to be clear, only her baby and not these other people.

speaker: Of course.
response: Can I have tea with honey and toast with the crust cut off?

speaker: You can have whatever you want.
response: Thanks, Mom.You’re the best.

speaker: Boy, last time I put VapoRub on you, you didn’t have hair on your chest.
response: I know, it filled in last year. I didn’t get to spend a lot of time with you on this visit.

speaker: And whose fault was that?
response: Yours.

speaker: Shelly, you’re not eight years old any more. We have to have a different relationship.
response: No, we don’t. The one we have works great.

speaker: Sweetheart, you are a grown man.
response: Or maybe I’m part of a new species, that lives for hundreds of years, which means I’m still basically a toddler.

speaker: Oh, I so should have taken you to Houston.
response: Does this mean you’re not going to sing Soft Kitty?

speaker: Mrs. Cooper, were we supposed to take that pie out of the oven?
response: Get out!

speaker: Well, that was rude.
response: Well, I know, but he means well. Sing.

speaker: Happy kitty, sleepy kitty…
response: What are you trying to pull, Mom? From the top.

speaker: Oh, damn, they cancelled my Visa. Oh, yay, a new MasterCard!
response: Uh-oh.

speaker: What?
response: I was going to get my mail.

speaker: Okay. Are, are you hoping to get it telepathically?
response: I think you mean telekinetically. And no, I just wasn’t sure of the proper protocol now that you and Leonard are no longer having coitus.

speaker: God, can we please just say no longer seeing each other?
response: Well, we could if it were true. But as you live in the same building, you see each other all the time. The variable which has changed is the coitus.

speaker: Okay, here’s the protocol, you and I are still friends, and you stop saying coitus.
response: Good, good. I’m glad we’re still friends.

speaker: Really?
response: Oh, yes. It was a lot of work to accommodate you in my life. I’d hate for that effort to have been in vain.

speaker: Right.
response: Just to be clear do I have to stop saying coitus with everyone or just you?

speaker: Everyone.
response: Harsh terms. But all right, I’ll just substitute intercourse.

speaker: Great.
response: Or fornication. Yeah. But that has judgmental overtones, so I’ll hold that in reserve.

speaker: So, how you been?
response: Well, my existence is a continuum, so I’ve been what I am at each point in the implied time period.

speaker: You’re just coitusing with me, aren’t you?
response: Bazinga.

speaker: Mmm. How’s Leonard doing?
response: He seems all right. Although he does spend a disturbing amount of time looking at photographs of you and smelling the pillow you slept on. Oh, but now that I think of it, he asked me not to tell you that.

speaker: I’ll pretend I didn’t hear it.
response: I’d rather you pretend I didn’t say it. I see you bought Mama Italia marinara spaghetti sauce.

speaker: Yep.
response: That’s the sauce my mother uses. She likes cooking Italian because according to her, that’s what the Romans made Jesus eat.

speaker: Interesting. I’ll have to have you over for spaghetti some night.
response: I’m hungry now.

speaker: Oh. Um, okay. Why don’t you give me an hour and come over?
response: Will you cut up hot dogs into little chunks and mix them in with the sauce?

speaker: I don’t have hot dogs.
response: Oh, it’s all right, I do. Oh! You’re in for what my mother calls a real Eye-talian treat. (Enters apartment).

speaker: Hey, where you been?
response: I was talking with Penny.

speaker: Yeah, he’s over it, that’s why he’s been whining all day about trying to invent that memory-wiper gizmo from Men in Black.
response: Is he making any progress? Because I’d like to erase Ben Affleck as Daredevil.

speaker: So would Ben Affleck. The point is, in a situation like this you got to pick sides. You’re either on Team Leonard or Team Penny.
response: Which one picks last?

speaker: What?
response: Well, usually I’m on the team that picks last. Unless there’s a kid in a wheelchair.

speaker: Sheldon, I got you your tangerine chicken. I hope you’re hungry.
response: Well, of course I’m hungry. And as I have no plans to eat with any other team, I will consume my tangerine chicken with the appropriate gusto. Mm, mm, mm!

speaker: Okay.
response: Just out of curiosity, do we still have hot dogs?

speaker: I don’t know. Why?
response: Just making dinner conversation. Go, Team Leonard!

speaker: Do you want the last dumpling, Sheldon?
response: Certainly. It’s not like I have to moderate my food intake because I’m planning on eating again very shortly. Mm, mm, mm!

speaker: I wish you were Aquaman. Then I could send you to scoop my mom out of the old lady t*nk.
response: Excuse me, I’m thirsty, so I’m going to go to the refrigerator and get myself a refreshing beverage.

speaker: What, suddenly I’m not good enough for you?
response: Ah, I do so love beverages. Now I think I’ll take my after-dinner walk.

speaker: Yeah, since when do you take walks?
response: I read a study online that walking after a meal not only aids in digestion, but increases serotonin, and you know me, if there’s one thing I like more than a refreshing beverage, it’s serotonin. Bye-bye.

speaker: Hold on. I’ll walk down with you.
response: Oh, that’s not necessary. You can go first.

speaker: Or we could go together.
response: I can’t think of a reason why not.

speaker: Let’s go.
response: Hold on. Nope, no reason.

speaker: Okay.
response: What?

speaker: You said you were going for a walk.
response: I didn’t say outside.

speaker: So what, you’re just gonna walk up and down the stairs?
response: No, of course not. That would be odd and suspicious behavior.

speaker: Which way are you going?
response: Which way are you going?

speaker: I parked my scooter down the block.
response: I’m going the other way. Bye.

speaker: Bye. Actually, I’m this way. Do I smell hot dogs?
response: No. I mean, I have no idea what you smell.

speaker: I definitely smell raw hot dog.
response: Perhaps you’re getting a brain tumour.

speaker: All right, have a nice walk.
response: I shall. Have a nice scoot.

speaker: You might want to stand back. I’m sitting on top of 13 horses here.
response: Oh. Hello, doggie. Nice doggie. I bet you think you smell hot dogs. Look, a cat!

speaker: So, um, was Leonard okay with you coming over?
response: Oh, yes. In fact, he said, I’m fine, I don’t care. And he in no way said it in a manner which would lead one to believe that he was covering up feelings of anguish and betrayal.

speaker: Well, good.
response: I’m also pleased to report that he’s all cried out over you.

speaker: He’s been crying?
response: Oh, I believe that was something else I wasn’t supposed to mention.

speaker: Oh, God, I feel terrible.
response: Do you have a stomach ache, too?

speaker: No. Why, do you?
response: No.

speaker: Why did you ask if I had one, too?
response: Just making polite dinner conversation. Your turn.

speaker: All right. So, what’s new in your life?
response: Well, my new shoes are not made for running.

speaker: Have you been running?
response: No. It’s just a suspicion I have. Mmm, mmm, mmm.

speaker: I’m so glad you like it.
response: I do. Leonard never cooks for me.

speaker: Well, maybe that’s ’cause Leonard can’t cook.
response: You can’t cook and you made me this.

speaker: Whatever. Ooh, I’m gonna get the cheesecake out of the fridge.
response: Oh, Lord, I’m in Jewish hell.

speaker: Hey, where you been?
response: I told you, walking.

speaker: For an hour and a half?
response: I got lost.

speaker: How could you get lost? Your phone has GPS.
response: Satellites are down. Solar flares.

speaker: There are no solar flares right now.
response: Yes, there are.

speaker: Dude, I’m an astrophysicist. If there were solar flares, I’d be all up in it.
response: I’m sorry. I misspoke. What I meant to say was my battery died.

speaker: Oh, just come in!
response: Thanks for seeing me on such short notice.

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: Maybe this isn’t a good time.

speaker: Tell me why you woke me up or I swear to God I will k*ll you.
response: Do you really think death threats are an appropriate way to begin this conversation? Sometimes your lack of social k*ll astonishes me.

speaker: What do you want?
response: You may want to sit down.

speaker: I’m in bed!
response: Point taken. You may want to sit up.

speaker: Sheldon!
response: I’ve been seeing Penny behind your back.

speaker: Okay, when you say seeing Penny, what exactly does that mean?
response: We had dinner last night. She made me spaghetti with little hot dogs cut up in it. Well, little hot dog. I gave up the other five hot dogs to a real dog. A real, big dog. A hell hound. Tangential to the primary story. How about I circle back to it?

speaker: Fine. Why did you have dinner with Penny?
response: I told you, she made spaghetti with little hot dogs. I like spaghetti with little hot dogs.

speaker: Then why did you have Chinese food with us?
response: I didn’t want to upset you. Howard made it very clear that my allegiance should be to male comrades before women who sell their bodies for money.

speaker: Is it possible he said Bros before Hos?
response: Yes, but I rephrased it to avoid offending the hos.

speaker: Sheldon, I don’t care if you want to be friends with Penny.
response: Oh. Well, so the emotional turmoil that’s been keeping me from achieving REM sleep was entirely unjustified?

speaker: Yes.
response: Well then as my meemaw would say, looks like we butchered a pig, but nobody wanted bacon.

speaker: I guess not.
