response: And now, as promised, the tangent. Sheldon and the Hell Hound, or How I Lost My Hot Dogs.

speaker: It’s ten o’clock, where have you been?
response: We stayed for the California Adventure water show. It was pure Disney magic.

speaker: How was I supposed to know that?
response: It’s all right. I’ll see it again with you.

speaker: I know, I know.
response: I can still eat.

speaker: No, you already threw up once. Go put on your PJs and brush your teeth.
response: Okay, but just don’t fight

speaker: Aren’t you going to thank Penny for taking you to Disneyland?
response: Thank you, Penny.

speaker: Kidding. Just a couple of friends goofin’ around.
response: No, Goofy, no.

speaker: Woo-hoo!
response: Movies or video games? Or board game? Or trading card games? Or Lego’s? Or dress up? Or comic books? Or dramatic readings of novelizations? Yes to all!

speaker: We are going to play the online game.
response: The online game? Bully!

speaker: Gentlemen, as much as I’m sure Sheldon would enjoy playing intergalactic make-believe, he and I have other plans. We are attending my Aunt Flora’s 93rd birthday party.
response: Just tell her I can’t come.

speaker: She’ll be disappointed if we don’t show up.
response: She’s 93. She won’t be disappointed for very long.

speaker: No, hang on. I followed all the protocols set forth by you in the relationship agreement. I made a written record request 72 hours in advance. I checked the tyre pressure on the car. I even contacted the Centres For Disease Control to find out what shots they recommend for travel to Orange County. FYI, it’s none.
response: Amy, the relationship agreement was not designed for either one of us to get our way.

speaker: You use it to get your way.
response: I use it to get the right way. The fact that the right way is also my way is a happy coincidence.

speaker: We’ll miss you, Sheldon.
response: Yeah, well, who wants to spend the whole weekend, running around a bunch of pretend planets battling made up monsters. That’s for babies.

speaker: Yeah, but it’s got lightsabres.
response: Yeah, please, Amy! It’s got lightsabres!

speaker: Hey Sheldon. Help you with anything?
response: Yes. I’m attending a party this weekend, for a 93-year-old woman. Can you recommend a gift?

speaker: Uh, I don’t know. Could put a tennis ball on the end of Excalibur. Make a pretty badass cane.
response: Do you supply the the tennis ball?

speaker: No.
response: Then no. What else?

speaker: Hmm. Oh, have this collectors edition Batman utility belt. Maybe she can use it as a wearable pill caddy.
response: Well, she’d just look silly wearing that without the rest of the costume.

speaker: I’m sorry Sheldon, that’s it. That’s all I got.
response: Oh, it’s not your fault. I’ve been to the model train store. I’ve been to Radio Shack. This woman is impossible to shop for.

speaker: I’d make fun of Sheldon for having girl problems if I wasn’t in shock that Sheldon has girl problems.
response: No, Leonard, go ahead and mock. Like my daddy always said, Shelly, women aren’t anything but flippin’ pains in the bottom.

speaker: That’s what your father used to say?
response: Well, I took out the bad words and the yeehaw, but you get the gist.

speaker: I can never find the tiller. I got a book; it didn’t help.
response: Yeah, I always thought if I were ever enslaved, it would be by an advanced species from another planet, not some hotsy-totsy from Glendale.

speaker: Now, I downloaded an app that might be helpful in this situation. (Phone makes whip sound)
response: You’re right. I’m smart as a whip. I should be able to figure this out.

speaker: Uh-uh.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Penny!

speaker: Sorry, Stallion. Your weird friend Giraffe is here.
response: Hello, Penny. I just stopped by to bring you this gift.

speaker: Gummy bears? Thank you.
response: Now that you’re in my debt, please manipulate Amy into releasing me from my commitment to attend her aunt’s tedious birthday party.

speaker: Not a chance.
response: All right. I thought the candy might not be enough so let me up the ante. These are Cooper Coupons. These are for various things I can do for you. Um, oh, this one is for one free grammar check. Uh, you could use it for emails, letters, tattoos, what have you. Um, oh, this is fun one. This is an afternoon with me at the California Science Center, where I point out their mistakes.

speaker: All right, sweetie, I’m not going to get involved in your relationship.
response: Oh, come on. It’s just a simple favour. Now, when’s the last time I asked you to do something for me?

speaker: Yesterday. You made me look in your ear to see if there was a ladybug in it.
response: When is the last time I asked you to do something that wasn’t a medical emergency?

speaker: Yesterday. You made me look in your ear to see if there was a ladybug in it.
response: All right, then, I have no choice but to go on to plan B.

speaker: What’s that?
response: I’m going to run around outside with a wet head and try to catch a cold.

speaker: Good morning.
response: Hello.

speaker: I think you’re really going to enjoy yourself today. Not only do you get to meet my relatives, but since my aunt’s nursing home is catering the party, all of the food is incredibly soft. It’s like a vacation for your teeth.
response: All right.

speaker: You sure you’re okay with this?
response: Yes. I decided to find a way that I could have this experience and enjoy it.

speaker: Thank you. That means a lot to me.
response: Oh, don’t thank me. Thank wireless technology. I realized, I can go to your aunt’s awful party and still spend the whole day gaming with my friends.

speaker: Sheldon, my relatives are going to want to talk to you, and you’re going to be sitting there playing a game? Isn’t that a little rude?
response: Oh, I got that covered. Headset. I won’t hear a word the old geezers are saying.

speaker: You know, if playing that game is more important to you than honouring your commitment to me, and you don’t mind me showing up at a party all by myself after I’ve already told everybody I’ll be bringing somebody, then, fine. Go home and play your game.
response: Thanks. Ooh, listen, I wouldn’t mind a piece of birthday cake, provided the old gal’s candle blow is clean and dry.

speaker: Hey, I plan on levelling up in the game, not my swimsuit size, thank you very much.
response: Gentlemen, the game offers us a choice between playing for the Republic and the light side, or the Sith Empire and the dark side.

speaker: Well, we’re always the good guys. In D&D, we’re lawful good, in City Of Heroes, we’re the heroes, in Grand Theft Auto, we pay the prostitutes promptly and never hit them with a bat.
response: Those women are prostitutes? You said they were raising money for stem cell research.

speaker: I had no choice. Last night, she said, why don’t we go out for brunch tomorrow and then maybe the Arboretum. And I said, well, no, I promised the guys I was going to play a video game with them all weekend. And she said, that sounds like fun, can I come, too? And then I didn’t answer for a second, and then she said, well, do you not want me to come? And then I bought her a new laptop and the game, and she’s parking the car right now.
response: Is the whip sound app contextually appropriate here?

speaker: Uh, it is, but I think you might’ve waited too long for it to be funny. (Whip sound) I was wrong, it’s still funny.
response: Oh, good. Hah-hah!

speaker: Get that guy! Get that guy! Pew! Pew! Pew! Pew!
response: Dr. Rostenkowski, it may interest you to know that saying pew, pew, pew isn’t as effective as pressing your blaster key. In the same way that saying whee doesn’t make the land speeder go.

speaker: Fine, I’ll change. (Whip sound)
response: Hah-hah!

speaker: I can’t help it. My Howie Wowie has an owie.
response: That is the most sickeningly sweet thing I have ever experienced. And I am sipping Kool-Aid through a Red Vine.

speaker: And if you don’t start treating me better, I’m leaving you for a miniature horse breeder named Armin.
response: Armin who?

speaker: Oh.
response: I think I understand. You’re the one person who can say Sheldon Cooper is your boyfriend, but that rings hollow if you can’t lord him over others in the flesh. I forget what I bring to the party and what I take away when I leave. Please accept these valuable Cooper Coupons as restitution.

speaker: Ooh, Science Center. Redeeming. Let’s go.
response: Well played, Amy Farrah Fowler. Let me get my coat. (Whip sound) Oh, grow up, Leonard.

speaker: Uh, well, it’s not May the fifth, and it’s not May the third. It’s May the fourth.
response: Get it?

speaker: Hey, you got a second?
response: Yes. Actually, I’m glad you’re here. I’m working on the Star Wars Day schedule. Now, I have a window built in after Phantom Menace for complaining, but I’m worried an hour won’t be enough time.

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve got some bad news.
response: What is it?

speaker: I just read online that Arthur Jeffries passed away.
response: Professor Proton is dead?

speaker: Sorry, buddy.
response: What are you doing?

speaker: Comforting you?
response: Your heart might be in the right place, but your head, chest and arms certainly aren’t.

speaker: Anyway, the, the funeral’s on Sunday.
response: But, that’s Star Wars Day.

speaker: Yeah, um, of all the things about this that are sad, that might not be number one. You okay? I know he meant a lot to you.
response: I’m fine.

speaker: Watching your old friend?
response: Hmm. Yes. Look at him, Amy. It’s such a shame. Struck down in the prime of my life.

speaker: Do you want me to go to the funeral with you?
response: Oh, I’m not going to the funeral.

speaker: Why not?
response: All those people blowing their noses. You can’t tell the sick from the sad. Mm. I’ll be at home celebrating Star Wars Day, as planned.

speaker: Are you sure you don’t want to go say good-bye?
response: Amy, mourning the inevitable is a complete waste of time.

speaker: And watching a bunch of goofy space movies you’ve seen hundreds of times isn’t?
response: If we were in a physical relationship, you just lost sex tonight.

speaker: Hey, uh, Sheldon, you want anything?
response: Uh, no, thank you.

speaker: You’re being so quiet. Are you upset or are you just rebooting?
response: I’m fine.

speaker: Sweetie, are you sure you don’t want to come with us to the funeral?
response: Oh, I appreciate the offer, but Arthur is gone and there’s nothing I can do about it. When Darth Vader struck down Obi-Wan, did Luke cry like a baby and go to his funeral?

speaker: No, he blew up the Death Star. Why do I know this?
response: Arthur Jeffries was a scientist. I’m sure he didn’t care about silly superstitions like funerals. You know, if he were here, I think he’d say enjoy Star Wars Day.

speaker: Since we all agree Episode I isn’t our favourite, maybe we just skip it this time.
response: Howard, I think you of all people should avoid espousing the principle that if something is not our favourite we should just get rid of it.

speaker: Okay, so you’d lose most of Jar Jar, all the trade route talk and the boring senate hearings, which are like watching C-SPAN with monsters.
response: Get rid of the trade route part? Then how would Palpatine get Chancellor Valorum kicked out of office? How would he get himself elected? How? Can we get through one holiday without you saying something ridiculous?

speaker: It was just a suggestion.
response: Well, you know what else was just a suggestion? Why don’t we change the Raisin Bran box? Hmm? And you know who got hurt by that? Every single person who eats breakfast.

speaker: You never heard it that time.
response: Arthur. I thought you were dead.

speaker: I am. Oh, it, it’s fantastic. I mean this, this is the longest that I’ve gone without running into a men’s room in, in, in years.
response: Why are you here?

speaker: I don’t know. I was, I was hoping I was going to haunt my ex-wife.
response: I know why. You’ve come to me because you’re my Obi-Wan.

speaker: I’m, I’m not, I’m not familiar with that. Is, is, is that an, an Internet?
response: Wow. Uh, you’re dead, so I’m going to let that slide. Obi-Wan Kenobi is a character from Star Wars. After his physical demise, he comes to Luke Skywalker as his mentor in spirit form.

speaker: Well, that, that clears that up.
response: You must be here to give me advice.

speaker: Well, this, this is weird. Most, most of my robes open in, in the back.
response: Those are your Jedi robes.

speaker: Oh, wait. What, what, what is, what is this?
response: Be careful with that.

speaker: Where, where, where are we?
response: This is the swampland of Dagobah. It’s where Luke was trained in the ways of the Jedi.

speaker: Oh. Too bad. I thought it was Florida.
response: When Obi-Wan came to Luke on this very spot, he gave him all sorts of helpful advice. So, um, what do you got for me?

speaker: Um, always, get, get a prenup.
response: That’s it? I thought there’d be more of a reason why you’re here.

speaker: Well, why, why do you think I’m here?
response: I suppose it has something to do with your recent passing.

speaker: Is, is this the, the first time you’ve lost, you know, someone close to you?
response: Oh, no. No. I’ve already had to say good-bye to 11 Dr. Whos.

speaker: Yeah, I’ve, I’ve outlived a few of my doctors, too.
response: Of course, my grandfather died when I was five. My father died when I was 14.

speaker: I’m, I’m sorry about that.
response: And now you’re gone, too. It’s like all the men I’ve looked up to have gone away.

speaker: Well, you know, it’s, it’s okay to, to be sad about them. Just, just make sure, you know, you appreciate those who, who are still there for you.
response: But I do appreciate them.

speaker: Hey, buddy. Heard you’re having a rough day. You all right?
response: I’m okay. How was the funeral?

speaker: It was nice, you know. A lot of people showed up, told some great stories about him. Did you know that Arthur’s son is a high school sci…? (Sheldon hugs him) Hey, the guys are about to start Jedi. You want to go watch?
response: I do. After I make them go back and watch one through five first.

speaker: Sheldon, that, that’ll take us all night.
response: That’s true. Oh, it’s a good thing I had a nap.

speaker: Happy Star Wars Day.
response: Wow. A Death Star cake.

speaker: Yeah, apparently, um, I’m here whenever, when, whenever you need me.
response: That’s nice.

speaker: May, maybe for you.
response: Why do I need you now?

speaker: Well, as near as I could tell, you, you fell asleep watching Star Wars, and now you’re, you’re dreaming you’re watching Star Wars.
response: So?

speaker: I mean, don’t, don’t you see a problem there? I mean, how, how you’re spending your limited time on Earth?
response: Not at all.

speaker: Agreed, what’s your point?
response: There’s no point, I just think it’s a good idea for a tee-shirt.

speaker: If you have to ask, maybe you shouldn’t be here.
response: I think this is the place.

speaker: Oh, take your time. I’ll just finish my crossword puzzle. Oh wait.
response: Leonard, I don’t think I can do this.

speaker: What, are you kidding? You’re a semi-pro.
response: No. We are committing genetic fraud. There’s no guarantee that our sperm is going to generate high IQ offspring, think about that. I have a sister with the same basic DNA mix who hostesses at Fuddruckers.

speaker: Sheldon, this was your idea. A little extra money to get fractional T1 bandwidth in the apartment.
response: I know, and I do yearn for faster downloads, but there’s some poor woman is going to pin her hopes on my sperm, what if she winds up with a toddler who doesn’t know if he should use an integral or a differential to solve the area under a curve.

speaker: I’m sure she’ll still love him.
response: I wouldn’t.

speaker: Well, what do you want to do?
response: I want to leave.

speaker: Okay.
response: What’s the protocol for leaving?

speaker: I don’t know, I’ve never reneged on a proffer of sperm before.
response: Let’s try just walking out.

speaker: No.
response: You want to hear an interesting thing about stairs?

speaker: Not really.
response: If the height of a single step is off by as little as two millimetres, people will trip.

speaker: I don’t care. Two millimetres? That doesn’t seem right.
response: No, it’s true, I did a series of experiments when I was twelve, my father broke his clavicle.

speaker: Is that why they sent you to boarding school?
response: No, that was the result of my work with lasers.

speaker: New neighbour?
response: Evidently.

speaker: Significant improvement over the old neighbour.
response: Two hundred pound tr*nsv*stite with a skin condition, yes she is.

speaker: Hi.
response: Hi.

speaker: Hi.
response: Hi.

speaker: Hi.
response: Hi.

speaker: Great.
response: Great.

speaker: Bye.
response: Bye.

speaker: Should we have invited her for lunch?
response: No. We’re going to start Season Two of Battlestar Galactica.

speaker: We already watched the Season Two DVDs.
response: Not with commentary.

speaker: I think we should be good neighbours, invite her over, make her feel welcome.
response: We never invited Louis-slash-Louise over.

speaker: Well, then that was wrong of us. We need to widen our circle.
response: I have a very wide circle. I have 212 friends on myspace.

speaker: Yes, and you’ve never met one of them.
response: That’s the beauty of it.

speaker: I’m going to invite her over. We’ll have a nice meal and chat.
response: Chat? We don’t chat. At least not offline.

speaker: Well it’s not difficult, you just listen to what she says and then you say something appropriate in response.
response: To what end?

speaker: Hi.
response: Hi.

speaker: Anyway, um. We brought home Indian food. And, um. I know that moving can be stressful, and I find that when I’m undergoing stress, that good food and company can have a comforting effect. Also, curry is a natural laxative, and I don’t have to that, uh, a clean colon is just… one less thing to worry about.
response: Leonard, I’m not expert here but I believe in the context of a luncheon invitation, you might want to skip the reference to bowel movements.

speaker: So, what do you guys do for fun around here?
response: Well, today we tried masturbating for money.

speaker: This looks like some serious stuff, Leonard, did you do this?
response: Actually that’s my work.

speaker: Wow.
response: Yeah, well, it’s just some quantum mechanics, a little string theory doodling around the edges. That part there, that’s just a joke, it’s a spoof of the Bourne-Oppenheimer approximation.

speaker: So you’re like, one of those, beautiful mind genius guys.
response: Yeah.

speaker: Holy smokes.
response: If by holy smokes you mean a derivative restatement of the kind of stuff you can find scribbled on the wall of any men’s room at MIT, sure.

speaker: What?
response: Oh, come on. Who hasn’t seen this differential below “here I sit broken hearted?”

speaker: At least I didn’t have to invent twenty-six dimensions just to make the math come out.
response: I didn’t invent, they’re there.

speaker: In what universe?
response: In all of them, that is the point.

speaker: Uh, do you guys mind if I start?
response: Um, Penny, that’s where I sit.

speaker: So, sit next to me.
response: No, I sit there.

speaker: What’s the difference?
response: What’s the difference?

speaker: Here we go.
response: In the winter that seat is close enough to the radiator to remain warm, and yet not so close as to cause perspiration. In the summer it’s directly in the path of a cross breeze created by open windows there, and there. It faces the television at an angle that is neither direct, thus discouraging conversation, nor so far wide to create a parallax distortion, I could go on, but I think I’ve made my point.

speaker: Do you want me to move?
response: Well….

speaker: Just sit somewhere else.
response: Fine. (Wanders in circles, looking lost.)

speaker: Sheldon, sit! (he does).
response: Aaah!

speaker: Well this is nice. We don’t have a lot of company over.
response: That’s not true. Koothrapali and Wolowitz come over all the time.

speaker: Yes I now, but…
response: Tuesday night we played Klingon boggle until one in the morning.

speaker: Yes, I remember.
response: I resent you saying we don’t have company.

speaker: I’m sorry.
response: That is an antisocial implication.

speaker: Um, me, okay, I’m Sagittarius, which probably tells you way more than you need to know.
response: Yes, it tells us that you participate in the mass cultural delusion that the Sun’s apparent position relative to arbitrarily defined constellations and the time of your birth somehow effects your personality.

speaker: Oh, yeah, a lot of people think I’m a water sign. Okay, let’s see, what else, oh, I’m a vegetarian, oh, except for fish, and the occasional steak, I love steak.
response: That’s interesting. Leonard can’t process corn.

speaker: Oh, okay. I love cheesecake.
response: You’re lactose intolerant.

speaker: It was. Until I fell in love with a jerk. (Bursts into tears).
response: What’s happening.

speaker: Oh God, you know, four years I lived with him, four years, that’s like as long as High School.
response: It took you four years to get through High School?

speaker: Should I say something? I feel like I should say something.
response: You? No, you’ll only make it worse.

speaker: You want to know the most pathetic part? Even though I hate his lying, cheating guts, I still love him. Is that crazy?
response: Yes.

speaker: Really? Would it be totally weird if I used it?
response: Yes.

speaker: No.
response: No?

speaker: No.
response: No.

speaker: Thanks. You guys are really sweet. (She leaves in direction of bathroom.)
response: Well this is an interesting development.

speaker: How so?
response: It has been some time since we’ve had a woman take her clothes off in our apartment.

speaker: That’s not true, remember at Thanksgiving my grandmother with Alzheimer’s had that episode.
response: Point taken. It has been some time since we’ve had a woman take her clothes off after which we didn’t want to rip our eyes out.

speaker: The worst part was watching her carve that turkey.
response: So, what exactly are you trying to accomplish here?

speaker: Excuse me?
response: That woman in there’s not going to have sex with you.

speaker: Well I’m not trying to have sex with her.
response: Oh, good. Then you won’t be disappointed.

speaker: What makes you think she wouldn’t have sex with me, I’m a male and she’s a female?
response: Yes, but not of the same species.

speaker: I’m not going to engage in hypotheticals here, I’m just trying to be a good neighbour.
response: Oh, of course.

speaker: That’s not to say that if a carnal relationship were to develop that I wouldn’t participate. However briefly.
response: Do you think this possibility will be helped or hindered when she discovers your Luke Skywalker no-more-tears shampoo?

speaker: It’s just not a good time.
response: Leonard has a lady over.

speaker: Can we please stop saying coitus?
response: Technically that would be coitus interruptus.

speaker: Must we?
response: Event A. A beautiful woman stands naked in our shower. Event B. We drive half way across town to retrieve a television set from the aforementioned woman’s ex-boyfriend. Query, on what plane of existence is there even a semi-rational link between these events?

speaker: She asked me to do her a favour, Sheldon.
response: Ah, yes, well that may be the proximal cause of our journey, but we both know it only exists in contradistinction to the higher level distal cause.

speaker: Which is?
response: You think with your penis.

speaker: That’s a biological impossibility and you didn’t have to come.
response: Oh, right, yes, I could have stayed behind and watched Wolowitz try to hit on Penny in Russian, Arabic and Farsi. Why can’t she get her own TV.

speaker: Come on, you know how it is with break-ups.
response: No I don’t. And neither do you.

speaker: Wuh… I… I broke up with Joyce Kim.
response: You did not break up with Joyce Kim, she defected to North Korea.

speaker: To mend her broken heart. This situation is much less complicated. There’s some kind of dispute between Penny and her ex-boyfriend as to who gets custody of the TV. She just wanted to avoid having a scene with him.
response: So we get to have a scene with him?

speaker: No, Sheldon, there’s not going to be a scene. There’s two of us and one of him.
response: Leonard, the two of us can’t even carry a TV.

speaker: Hi, I’m Leonard, this is Sheldon.
response: Hello.

speaker: Get lost.
response: Okay, thanks for your time.

speaker: We’re not going to give up just like that.
response: Leonard, the TV is in the building, we’ve been denied access to the building, ergo we are done.

speaker: Excuse me, if I were to give up at the first little hitch I never would have been able to identify the fingerprints of string theory in the aftermath of the big bang.
response: My apologies. What’s your plan.

speaker: Come on, we have a combined IQ of 360, we should be able to figure out how to get into a stupid building.
response: What do you think their combined IQ is?

speaker: This is it. (Knocks.) I’ll do the talking.
response: Good thinking, I’ll just be the muscle.

speaker: I’m Leonard, this is Sheldon.
response: From the intercom.

speaker: Oh. We’re scientists.
response: Tell him about our IQ.

speaker: What?
response: My mom bought me those pants.

speaker: I’m sorry.
response: You’re going to have to call her.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m so sorry I dragged you through this.
response: It’s okay. It wasn’t my first pantsing, and it won’t be my last.

speaker: And you were right about my motives, I was hoping to establish a relationship with Penny that might have some day led to sex.
response: Well you got me out of my pants.

speaker: Anyway, I’ve learned my lesson. She’s out of my league, I’m done with her, I’ve got my work, one day I’ll win the Nobel Prize and then I’ll die alone.
response: Don’t think like that, you’re not going to die alone.

speaker: Thank you Sheldon, you’re a good friend.
response: And you’re certainly not going to win a Nobel Prize.

speaker: No, it was a valid hypothesis.
response: That was a valid hypothesis? What is happening to you?

speaker: Really? Great.
response: Thank you. (Penny leaves.) You’re not done with her, are you?

speaker: Our babies will be smart and beautiful.
response: Not to mention imaginary.

speaker: Sure.
response: We can’t have Thai food, we had Indian for lunch.

speaker: So?
response: They’re both curry based cuisines.

speaker: So?
response: They would be gastronomically redundant. I can see we’re going to have to spell out everything for this girl.

speaker: Baby, baby don’t get hooked on me. Uh, baby, baby don’t get hooked on me.
response: I don’t know what your odds are in the world as a whole, but as far as the population of this car goes, you’re a veritable Mack Daddy.

speaker: It’s gonna get crazy.
response: Dungeons & Dragons.

speaker: Ready whenever you guys are.
response: Yeah, yeah, we’ll be right there. Leonard?

speaker: Yeah?
response: I’m not sure how I feel about Howard being dungeon master instead of you.

speaker: Oh, that’s nice. But relax, sometimes change is good. Uh, you were worried about Zachary Quinto being the new Spock, but you wound up liking him.
response: Oh, please. Every time the topic of change comes up, you throw Zachary Quinto in my face. I’m upset the mailman has a new haircut, Zachary Quinto. I’m upset that daylight saving time started, Zachary Quinto. I’m upset daylight saving time ended, Zachary Quinto. I’m saying this for the last time, Zachary Quinto was a weird, wonderful, unrepeatable event. So stop using him against me.

speaker: See, Howard’s just as good a dungeon master as I am.
response: As good? You just got pantsed in the schoolyard, four-eyes.

speaker: We’ll be fine, watch. Suddenly, a spectral shape rises from Koothrappali’s bloody corpse, and says, (Raj voice) don’t worry, buddies, ghost Raj will help guide you through the forest. (Nicolas Cage voice) Well, I’m just a tree, but if I were you, I’d listen to your ghost friend.
response: Go on, give him your lunch money.

speaker: Uh, it does. (Creaking sound)
response: He does sound effects, too!

speaker: Hey, I always did sound effects. A-A swarm of bloodthirsty bats fly through the dungeon. (Clicking sounds) Uh, uh, they attack a nearby unicorn. (Strange howl)
response: Okay, well, I have a sound effect for those sound effects. (Blows raspberry)

speaker: You guys enjoy your evening. I’m gonna go before I ruin anybody else’s weekend.
response: Ah, that’s my girl.

speaker: No, no, no, Amy, wait. I know it’s not the night you had in mind, but why don’t you guys stay and play with us? It’ll be fun.
response: It would? Fun? Okay, three weeks ago you bought crunchy peanut butter, now you want the girls to play D&D? Do you have a drug problem?

speaker: What’s the big deal? Raj bailed, so we could use some extra players.
response: Well, I’ve just never played Dungeons & Dragons with girls before.

speaker: So, what do you say?
response: I’ll leave it up to the dungeon master.

speaker: Okay, who wants a drink?
response: Yeah, we, now, Penny, we don’t consume alcohol during Dungeons & Dragons. It impairs our judgment.

speaker: Okay, here we go. You find yourselves face-to-face with two hulking ogres. What are you doing in our dungeon? You shall die!
response: Okay, literal goose bumps. Look.

speaker: I draw my broadsword.
response: I ready my quarter-staff.

speaker: Fifteen’s the point, the point is fifteen. Give the little lady some room, here it is, coming out. Sixteen! Yes! Oh, please tell me we’re playing for money.
response: Oh, even better than money. You gained experience points.

speaker: Seventeen, the larger ogre is dead. The-the other ogre says, you k*ll my brother, now Ogre Thanksgiving is ruined.
response: That is amazing. He made me care about the ogre.

speaker: The dragon falls from the sky, crashing into the volcano.
response: Yay!

speaker: But wait., he’s not dead. He crawls out, spreads his wings and prepares to attack.
response: Yeah, uh, wait. Doesn’t he say something first? You know, maybe in the voice of a beloved celebrity?

speaker: Fine. (Christopher Walken voice) You’d think, after all these years, I’d know not to fly over volcanoes. I’m a freaking idiot.
response: The dragon’s Christopher Walken. That’s perfect.

speaker: It’s a hit. The dragon collapses to the ground.
response: Wait. Wait. And says?

speaker: Mother? Is that you? Your little boy is coming home.
response: Oh, I don’t know about you guys, but I have been through the emotional wringer tonight.

speaker: Oh, yeah? Well, when we get home, I’m gonna take you on a whole different adventure.
response: Another quest by Wolowitz? Count me in.

speaker: Sheldon, they’re talking about sex.
response: Oh, then I’m out.

speaker: I don’t like this.
response: You see what happens when you let girls play D&D?

speaker: What?
response: I’ve never knocked on my own door before. That was a wild ride.

speaker: You don’t have to come in here and cheer me up.
response: Thank you. Would you go tell everyone else that? Because they sure think otherwise.

speaker: I’ll tell you what they think. They think our relationship is a joke.
response: Well, I don’t think our relationship is a joke. I think “a horse goes into a bar, bartender says, why the long face?’, that’s a joke. It’s a good one, too, because a horse has a long face.

speaker: Sheldon, are we ever going to have an intimate relationship?
response: Oh, my. That’s an uncomfortable topic. Amy, before I met you, I never had any interest in being intimate with anyone.

speaker: And now?
response: And now what?

speaker: Do you have any interest now?
response: I have not ruled it out.

speaker: Wow. Talk dirty to me.
response: I know it doesn’t seem like it to you, but, for me, what we have is extremely intimate.

speaker: I guess I know that. It’s just, part of me wants more.
response: More? I mean, look at us. It’s only been three years, here we are in bed together.

speaker: Come on. Let’s go back out there.
response: Well, no. Hold on. My Elven magic-user and your half-orc warrior did have a love spell cast on them. We wouldn’t really be playing the game right if we didn’t see that through.

speaker: Okay.
response: I believe that, uh, we just k*ll a dragon. While the others pillage the corpse, I lead you to a secluded area where I attempt to remove your leather armour. (Rolls dice) It comes off.

speaker: Oh.
response: What do you do?

speaker: I kiss you on the lips.
response: I kiss you back on the (Rolls dice) lips as well. Your turn.

speaker: I remove your armour. What do you do?
response: I erotically caress your (Rolls dice) nose.

speaker: Hey, you guys have been in there for a while. You doing okay?
response: We’re fine, thank you.

speaker: The comic book store.
response: Smell that? That’s the smell of new comic books. Oh, yes!

speaker: Is that supposed to be funny?
response: I believe it is. The combination of the Star Trek reference and the play on words involving the double-meaning of the verb to go suggests that Leonard is humorously mocking your efforts in space plumbing.

speaker: He’s right. This is an important achievement, for two reasons. Number one, and, of course, number two.
response: Oh, clever! Playing on the use of cardinal numbers as euphemisms for bodily functions.

speaker: Here, Sheldon, I pulled the new Hellboy for you. It’s mind-blowing.
response: Excuse me, spoiler alert.

speaker: I didn’t spoil anything.
response: You told me it’s mind-blowing, so, my mind is going into it pre-blown. And once a mind is pre-blown, it cannot be re-blown.

speaker: I’m sorry.
response: Said the Grinch to Christmas.

speaker: ‘Cause we’re going out again tomorrow.
response: Excuse me, Stuart. Have you read the new Flash?

speaker: No.
response: Well, I have and it will knock your socks off! Good luck getting them back on.

speaker: Oh. It’s Stuart.
response: You’re not going to answer it?

speaker: He wants to talk about Penny. I don’t want to talk about Penny.
response: You’re making an assumption. Perhaps the comic book store is on fire, and he needs your assistance.

speaker: Why would he call me?
response: We don’t know. And if you don’t answer the phone, we can’t know.

speaker: I’m not answering the phone, Sheldon.
response: Answer the phone, Leonard.

speaker: No! There, it went to voice mail.
response: Aren’t you going to check your messages?

speaker: No.
response: You have to check your messages, the leaving of a message is one half of a social contract which is completed by the checking of the message. If that contract breaks down then all social contracts break down and we descend into anarchy.

speaker: It must be hell inside your head.
response: At times.

speaker: Guys, we have a code red.
response: Do you mean code red the hospital emergency alert, code red the computer worm, or code red the cherry flavoured soft drink from the makers of Mountain Dew?

speaker: It’s gonna fail after about ten flushes.
response: But the mission is for six months.

speaker: Yeah, see, that’s the code red. It’s kind of like a jack-in-the-box, no one knows exactly when, but at some point something way worse than a puppet is gonna pop out of that box.
response: Have you notified NASA?

speaker: I’m trying, but you have to admit this is pretty damn funny.
response: I agree. It’s the juxtaposition of the high-tech nature of space exploration against the banality of a malfunctioning toilet that provides the comic fodder here. Check your messages.

speaker: You mean so it doesn’t hit the fan?
response: Yeah, I have to say, I thought the toilet humour would get less funny with repetition. Apparently, there is no law of diminishing comedic returns with space poop. (There is a knock on the door)

speaker: It wasn’t bad advice. It just wasn’t particularly helpful.
response: For what it’s worth, my mother says that when we deceive for personal gain, we make Jesus cry.

speaker: Of course you feel terrible. You completely screwed up your karma, dude.
response: You don’t really believe in that superstition, do you?

speaker: Okay, look. Instead of trying to reinforce this structure here, what if we just ran another line, bypass it entirely?
response: It won’t work. The diameter of the tubing is insufficient.

speaker: What if we reposition the collection t*nk?
response: It won’t work. No way to mount it.

speaker: Okay, here’s an idea. What if I change my name and go live with my cousin and her husband Avi in Israel?
response: That could work.

speaker: Hang on, I think I’ve got this. Help me see if we can wedge this little piece of PVC behind the support rod.
response: You’re overestimating the tensile strength of the substructure you’re building.

speaker: Sheldon, I know what I’m doing.
response: If you knew what you were doing, there wouldn’t be a space toilet where my coffee table should be.

speaker: Comic book store.
response: Oh, an excellent idea! I could certainly use a break.

speaker: Hold on, you can go to the comic book store when man can once again safely poop in space.
response: Why does Leonard get to go?

speaker: Damn right it’s heavy, it’s my mother’s meat loaf, it’s been testing toilets for generations.
response: I must say, Howard, I think a detailed letter to MIT describing your current circumstances might entitle you to a refund on your master’s degree.

speaker: Okay, simulated zero-gravity human waste disposal test with meat loaf analog in three, two, one. (Switches flush. Meatloaf hits ceiling.)
response: Fascinating.

speaker: Well, they’ve deployed our solution. Let’s just all hope it works.
response: I don’t see why I have to worry. My career’s not hanging in the balance. That was a joke. It’s funny, because it’s true.

speaker: Thank you.
response: No, thank you. Delivery men are the unsung foot soldiers of our nation's commerce. It's because of people like you, people like me can limit our human contact. I'd shake your hand, but, well, you know.

speaker: I'm not a delivery man, I'm a doctor. Although I do often deliver alarming biopsy results to my patients.
response: That's humorous.

speaker: All right.
response: Yeah, I bet you leave your patients in stitches. That was also humorous.

speaker: All right.
response: Are you bringing flowers to a patient to cushion the blow of a terminal diagnosis? That wasn't a joke.

speaker: All right. These are actually for a nice woman who makes sales calls to my office.
response: Hmm. You know, they have delivery people that will do that for you.

speaker: I was hoping to impress her by tracking her down on the Internet and then showing up unannounced at her door.
response: Making the extra effort. Good for you.

speaker: Great timing, food just got here.
response: Ooh, Siam Palace?

speaker: Yes.
response: Uh, mee krob and chicken satay?

speaker: Yes.
response: Uh, extra peanut sauce?

speaker: No, but you can have mine.
response: Eh, well, very well. Oh, and on the topic of sharing things that are yours, there is a gentleman caller bringing flowers to your fiancée as we speak.

speaker: What? Why didn't you say that first?
response: Why didn't you get extra peanut sauce? We can both play this game.

speaker: Oh, uh, you probably don't want her to see this. It's unnecessarily graphic.
response: Hold on, Doctor. Leonard, where are your social k*ll? This man is clearly upset. We should invite him in for a hot beverage.

speaker: He tried to score with Penny.
response: So have these two, and they're having dinner with us.

speaker: Please don't go. Up until my vicious attack, you were the one in the wrong.
response: Here you go, Doctor. Red Zinger with one teaspoon of honey.

speaker: Ever since I was a kid, but, uh, I didn't really get serious until William Shatner's bladder infection.
response: What'd you get? What'd you get?

speaker: Oh. Well, you know, just being myself, really.
response: Oh, please, you know, I'll tell you how he did it. Implacable, relentless badgering. In urology terms, he was a drug-resistant staph infection. And she was a urethra that could not shake him.

speaker: Ah, that's a good question. Apparently someone was being awfully flirty while not wearing their engagement ring, causing another someone to show up here thinking the first someone might be available.
response: Oh, God. Don't make it so hard on her. Look, the first someone is the deceitful you. The second someone is the delightful Dr. Lorvis.

speaker: I'll be right back.
response: So what other celebrity genitalia have you handled?

speaker: Oh, my God.
response: Leonard, I was wrong. Heaven does exist. And it's in the basement of a urologist's house in Sherman Oaks.

speaker: Wow, Donkey Kong. This, this was my game when I was a kid.
response: Because it's a story of a pretty blonde girl tirelessly pursued by a small, oddly-shaped man?

speaker: No, because I liked it.
response: Well, now, don't get defensive. You're oddly-shaped, but you got the girl.

speaker: So, I've noticed Leonard gets teased a lot 0about his relationship with Penny.
response: Yes. If you'd like to join in, the premise is their love seems unlikely and doomed to failure.

speaker: So, you think she'll be single soon?
response: Oh, if you want to get in on the pool, you're too late. All the squares have been purchased.

speaker: Interesting. Excuse me, I have to take care of something.
response: Leonard, as your friend I feel I should tell you something.

speaker: What?
response: I'm still upset about that peanut sauce.

speaker: Next game, let's switch helmets.
response: No, I'd look silly in that helmet.

speaker: Uh, guys, we're locked in here.
response: Oh, this day just keeps getting better.

speaker: Just walk.
response: You can do this.

speaker: Hey, will you steam my uniform next?
response: Interesting. Do you recall this conversation? Leonard, want to go halfsies on a steamer? No, Sheldon, we don’t need a steamer. Looks like that rumpled chicken’s come home to roost.

speaker: Hey, hey, hey, hey. This is my Comic-Con makeup. I love you, but there are some things a man doesn’t share with his girlfriend.
response: That’s a wise policy. I once borrowed my sister’s makeup for a costume contest. Got a terrible case of pinkeye. But luckily, I was going as a zombie. I won second place.

speaker: Well, it’s a lot smaller. It’s more about the comic books. The way these conventions used to be before they went all Hollywood.
response: So to answer your question, no, it’s not better.

speaker: Well, then why are you going?
response: It’s a comic book convention. You know, it’s like pizza or particle accelerators, even the stinky one’s still pretty good.

speaker: It is on.
response: But the turn-by-turn voice option isn’t on. I know I’d feel more safe if you turn on the turn-by-turn voice option. I love the turn-by-turn voice option.

speaker: Leonard, bear left and continue on Interstate 210.
response: Ooh, sounds like that fellow knows what he’s talking about. I’d put on my listening ears if I were you.

speaker: What did you do?
response: I found a hack online. I was able to upload MP3 recordings of my voice to your GPS.

speaker: Really?
response: Shh, he said it’s interesting.

speaker: You know, we’re not that far from Vazquez Rocks.
response: Oh, they sh*t a lot of Star Trek episodes out there.

speaker: Yeah, that sounds fun.
response: Oh, smashing. Now, Leonard, do you know how to get there?

speaker: No.
response: Yeah, well luckily, someone in the car does.

speaker: Recalculating. While we’re waiting, do you know which president signed the Intestate Highway System Act into law? The answer, coming up in 14 miles.
response: None of you will get it. It’s Eisenhower.

speaker: And we’re blending, and we’re blending, and we’re done.
response: I know Mr. Data isn’t supposed to smile, but here it comes.

speaker: Sheldon, how is that a fight pose?
response: Mr. Data’s w*apon is his mind. I’m wielding it.

speaker: Stop!
response: Stealing is against the law!

speaker: Mine, too. Anybody got any ideas?
response: Nope. The only thing left to do now is assign blame. (To Raj) Nice going.

speaker: What kind of a person steals another person’s car in broad daylight?
response: What kind of person leaves his keys in the car?

speaker: I thought we agreed this was all Koothrappali’s fault.
response: You’re right. Nice going.

speaker: What is wrong with people? Why don’t they stop?
response: Maybe we’re better off. What if we were to get in a car with a crazy person?

speaker: Look at us, Sheldon. We’re the crazy people.
response: Well, perhaps we should hold up a sign that assures passing motorists of our mental competence.

speaker: Come on, let’s just start walking. There’s got to be a gas station or something nearby.
response: What, you think just because you’re wearing a captain’s uniform, you’re in charge?

speaker: Yes.
response: All right.

speaker: Insurance is gonna buy you a new car. It’s not gonna de-funk my junk.
response: Gentlemen, a little less bellyaching. We’re Starfleet officers and a member of the Borg Collective.

speaker: Please, Sheldon, I am so not in the mood.
response: Leonard, all our lives we have dreamed of finding ourselves inside one of the fantasy worlds we love. And look at us. At this moment, we are, in fact, a Star Trek landing party stranded in an alien and unforgiving environment, relying only on our wits, our fortitude and our moxie. As long as we have those things, nothing can stop…

speaker: Nerds!
response: I hate this planet.

speaker: Why don’t you ask Scotty to beam you up?
response: Scotty was on the original series, and we’re Next Generation. So, joke’s on you.

speaker: Fine, then I guess it’s two against two. How do we decide?
response: Actually, it’s three against one.

speaker: What? What about the mission? You said we were a real-life landing party.
response: Yeah, well, we’re not. We’re an imaginary landing party who had real-life garbage thrown at us by real-life strangers who think we’re idiots. And to tell you the truth, I’m starting to feel like one. I want to go home now.

speaker: You don’t know his life.
response: There’s only one logical explanation. Somewhere in the desert we crossed into an alternate dimension where the women in our lives can finally appreciate great literature.

speaker: If it’s an alternate dimension, sounds like a job for a landing party.
response: Captain, what are your orders?

speaker: I say we investigate.
response: Wait. They might be hostile.

speaker: Too bad. You know the rules of Secret Agent Laser Obstacle Chess. Uh, Leonard died again, Sheldon. You’re up.
response: Despite my deep love of chess, lasers and aerosol disinfectant, I must forfeit.

speaker: Why?
response: – Because it’s almost eleven o’clock.

speaker: So?
response: So, Penny has a don’t knock on my door before eleven o’clock or I punch you in the throat rule.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: It’s eleven am.

speaker: I know. You’re safe.
response: This package came while you were at work.

speaker: Oh, great, my rhinestones. Thank you.
response: Excuse me.

speaker: What?
response: You have to sign this.

speaker: What is it?
response: When I signed for the package, I was deputized by the United Parcel Service and entrusted with its final delivery. I now need you to acknowledge receipt of the package so that I’m fully indemnified and no longer liable.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s just a box of rhinestones.
response: Well, the contents are irrelevant. A legal bailment has been created. Does that mean nothing to you?

speaker: It means nothing to anybody. Come here, let me show you what I’m doing.
response: Bailment describes a relationship in common law where a physical possession of personal property, or chattels, is transferred from one person, the bailor, to another person, the bailee.

speaker: Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Look, look, look! I started a business.
response: Obviously, not a cleaning business.

speaker: No, I’m making flower barrettes. See? I call them Penny Blossoms. I made one for myself, then all the girls at work wanted one. Then I showed some to this lady who runs a shop in Old Town. She sells cards and homemade jewellery. She said she wanted to sell them. I said okay, and in one week, I made a $156.
response: Good for you. Sign here.

speaker: Sheldon, don’t you get it? If this takes off, I won’t have to be a waitress anymore.
response: But then who will bring me my cheeseburger on Tuesday nights?

speaker: Another waitress.
response: What’s her name?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: And you’re going to let her handle my food?

speaker: Nancy. Her name is Nancy.
response: I think you’re just making that up.

speaker: Fine, cheeseburger.
response: Maybe I’d be better off with Nancy.

speaker: So, what do you think? I mean, this could be a business, right?
response: How many of these can you make a day?

speaker: About twenty.
response: And how much profit do you make per Penny Blossom?

speaker: I don’t know, like, 50 cents. I’m not sure.
response: No, Of course you’re not. All right, ten dollars a day times five days a week times 52 weeks a year is two thousand six hundred dollars.

speaker: That’s all?
response: Before taxes.

speaker: Well, I don’t have to pay taxes on this stuff.
response: I believe the Internal Revenue Service would strongly disagree. But, if you took advantage of modern marketing techniques, and you optimized your manufacturing process, you might be able to make this a viable business.

speaker: And you know about that stuff?
response: Penny, I’m a physicist. I have a working knowledge of the entire universe and everything it contains.

speaker: Who’s Radiohead?
response: I have a working knowledge of the important things in the universe. Good luck.

speaker: Sheldon, hold on. Could you maybe show me how to make more money with this?
response: Of course I could.

speaker: Sheldon, wait! Will you?
response: Just to be clear here, you’re asking for my assistance.

speaker: Yes.
response: And you understand that will involve me telling you what to do?

speaker: I understand.
response: And you’re not allowed to be sarcastic or snide to me while I’m doing so.

speaker: Okay.
response: Good. Let’s begin with the premise that everything you’ve done up to this point is wrong.

speaker: Oh, imagine that.
response: Sarcasm. Good-bye.

speaker: There. Done.
response: All right. 12 minutes and 17 seconds.

speaker: Pretty good, right?
response: That’s 4.9 Penny Blossoms per hour. Based on your cost of materials and your wholesale selling price, you’ll effectively be paying yourself… $5.19 a day.

speaker: A day?
response: There are children in a sneaker factory in Indonesia who outearn you.

speaker: That just can’t be right.
response: You’re questioning my math?

speaker: No, sorry.
response: Want me to show my work?

speaker: Oh, God, no, no. Just please tell me what to do about it.
response: All right, are you familiar with the development that resulted from Honoré Blanc’s 1778 use of interchangeable parts? The assembly line, of course.

speaker: Okay, you know what, if I’m not allowed to be snide, you’re not allowed to be condescending.
response: That wasn’t a part of our original agreement, and I do not agree to it now.

speaker: All right, fine. How are we supposed to set up machines and conveyor belts in my apartment?
response: You’re thinking of the moving assembly line, an understandable but not excusable mistake. No. The moving assembly line, that was introduced by Henry Ford in 1908. That innovation is what made possible our modern consumer culture by enabling a low-unit cost for manufactured goods. I guess that isn’t one of the topics discussed on your Radiohead.

speaker: W-W-Wait, what’s going on?
response: I assume you’re referring to the sea shanty. It’s a rhythmic work song designed to increase productivity.

speaker: Terrific, but that kind of raises more questions than it answers.
response: Penny’s making hair accessories. I’m helping her optimize her manufacturing process. All right, break’s over. (They start singing again.)

speaker: Hold on. What are you using as a bonding agent?
response: Hot glue.

speaker: You’re kidding. Any of the cyanoacrylates would do a better job.
response: It won’t work, the flower’s too porous.

speaker: What if we infused the bottom layer with silicone-RTV to provide a better mounting surface?
response: Intriguing.

speaker: Well, there are the waitresses at my work, and this cute, little shop in Old Town.
response: Hush, hush, hush, hush, hush, virtually non-existent. I’m thinking that we set her up with a hosted turnkey e-commerce system to start.

speaker: She’d need some kind of industrial cooling system.
response: Of course, but before we set up a marketing and distribution infrastructure, we should finish optimizing the manufacturing process. To start with, she has a terrible problem with moisture-induced glitter clump.

speaker: Actually, I’m thinking about this one stripper named Vega. But sure, calcium sulphate could work.
response: Let’s think out of the box for a moment. How about a molecular sieve?

speaker: I’ve got a spaghetti strainer in the kitchen.
response: Wow.

speaker: Hey, we could liberate some micro-porous charcoal from the chem lab.
response: Oh, great. Raj, why don’t you and Howard go get the charcoal? Leonard, why don’t you start working on some preliminary Web site designs. I’ll make some space in our apartment so we can move the manufacturing process.

speaker: Well, what’s wrong with my apartment?
response: It’s not my apartment.

speaker: Okay, what’s wrong with it?
response: – What’s wrong with it?

speaker: Please. Dateline could use it to attract predators.
response: Penny, this is your enterprise, so it’s ultimately your decision, but based on the quality of his work, I’d strongly recommend that we let Leonard go.

speaker: You want to fire me?
response: What I want is irrelevant. This is Penny’s decision. Penny?

speaker: Thank you, Penny Blossoms. These will be perfect to cover my bald spot. Aww, that is so sweet.
response: Camouflaging bald spots. That’s primarily a male concern. Perhaps we could expand our market.

speaker: We add Bluetooth!
response: Brilliant. Men love Bluetooth.

speaker: Wait a minute, wait a minute, you want to make a hair barrette with Bluetooth?
response: Penny, everything is better with Bluetooth.

speaker: The Fifth Annual East Rutherford, New Jersey, Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Alliance Luau.
response: Oh, another market to expand into, balding gay men.

speaker: And I’ll bet lesbians love Bluetooth.
response: We should get to work.

speaker: Okay, well, I’m gonna have to call them and cancel the order.
response: Excuse me, but was this not your goal? Financial independence through entrepreneurial brilliance and innovation? My brilliance and innovation, of course, but still.

speaker: I just don’t see how see can pull this off.
response: Okay, that, right there, that equivocation and self-doubt, that is not the American spirit. Did Davy Crockett quit at the Alamo? Did Jim Bowie?

speaker: They didn’t quit. They were massacred by, like, a gazillion angry Mexicans.
response: Alright, let me put it this way. Your gross receipts on this one order will be over $3,000 for one night’s work.

speaker: Oh, God, we’re never gonna finish in time. Who made Sheldon the boss anyway?
response: I believe I’m hearing some negativity on the factory floor.

speaker: So?
response: Penny, the labour force is a living organism that must be carefully nurtured. Any counterproductive grumbling must be skilfully headed off by management. Observe. Hey! Less talk, more work!

speaker: Nicely done.
response: Thank you. You hear any union talk, you let me know.

speaker: Someone’s in the kitchen with Dinah… Sheldon? Sheldon! (nudges him)
response: ‘Cause I sold my soul to the company store.

speaker: Honey, do you want some coffee?
response: No, I don’t drink coffee.

speaker: Come on, but if you don’t stay awake we’ll never finish in time.
response: I’m sorry, coffee’s out of the question. When I moved to California, I promised my mother that I wouldn’t start doing drugs.

speaker: Sheldon, we still have 380 of these things to make.
response: I have complete faith that you will make them. Good night.

speaker: Yeah, no. But, Sheldon, without your insight and leadership this entire enterprise will surely fail.
response: You’re right, of course.

speaker: Here, this will help.
response: Very well, but if this leads to opiates or hallucinogenics, you’re going to have to answer to my mother.

speaker: Sorry. My apologies to the gay community of East Rutherford, New Jersey.
response: Zoom, zoom, zoom! Where’s the coffee?

speaker: We’re all out.
response: No problem. I’ll be back before this banana hits the ground. Zoom, zoom, zoom, zoom! Zoom, zoom, zoom, zoom!

speaker: Okay, we’ve got power to the laser.
response: I should’ve brought an umbrella.

speaker: What for? It’s not going to rain.
response: I know that, but with skin as fair as mine, moon burn is a real possibility.

speaker: That’s a bazinga, right?
response: One of my best, don’t you think?

speaker: It’s not like that, I’m watching someone’s TV. The Good Wife is on. I tell you, this is my new Grey’s Anatomy.
response: Leonard, Leonard. What is that? What is that?

speaker: Relax, it’s just a dirty sock.
response: How on earth can you say dirty sock and relax in the same sentence?

speaker: Sheldon, the world is filled with dirty discarded socks.
response: Not my world.

speaker: Hey, you know who’d really dig seeing this experiment? Penny.
response: I wasn’t aware that lunar ranging was her thing. Although, I suppose the retro-reflector left on the moon by Neil Armstrong does qualify as a shiny object.

speaker: She didn’t dump me. We were just in different places in the relationship.
response: I fail to see how a relationship can have the qualities of a geographic location.

speaker: Happy now? I’m moving the dirty sock.
response: Thank you. Raj, keep an eye out for the other one.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Whoa! Is that the laser? It’s bitchin’.
response: Yes. In 1917, when Albert Einstein established the theoretic foundation for the laser in his paper Zur Quantentheorie der Strahlung, his fondest hope was that the resultant device be bitchin’.

speaker: The moon.
response: See, now this is a man for Penny.

speaker: Uh, that’s a great question, Zack.
response: No, it’s not.

speaker: Sheldon! Play nice.
response: Well it’s not a great question. How could somebody possibly think we’re going to blow up the moon? That’s a great question.

speaker: Preparing to fire laser at the moon.
response: Make it so.

speaker: What species is that?
response: I was wrong. Penny can do better.

speaker: No, just keep walking.
response: He must be very k*ll at coitus.

speaker: Tons. I’ve had, like, eight dates in the last month. And twelve if you count the ones who showed up and left.
response: I can’t bring the nitrogen t*nk down.

speaker: Why not?
response: All right, let me restate that. It’s very heavy, and I don’t want to.

speaker: I’ll help you.
response: Thank you. Lift with your knees, not your back. Good night.

speaker: Why? I mean, okay.
response: What’s going on?

speaker: Put on your noise-cancelling headphones, ’cause it’s gonna get loud.
response: Oh! Not this again.

speaker: What, do you have eyes in the back of your head?
response: When one gets b*at up every other day in school, one of necessity develops a keen sense of hearing. Incidentally, one can get b*at up in school simply by referring to oneself as one. I’m making English muffins. Would you like an English muffin?

speaker: Oh, thanks, I’m not hungry.
response: FYI, my noise-cancelling headphones proved ineffective last night.

speaker: Yeah, sorry about that.
response: As a native Texan, I must say I’ve never heard the phrase yee-haw used in quite that context.

speaker: Oh, God.
response: Oh, God. That I’ve heard on multiple occasions. In what universe is that lightly toasted? This has to be the worst day of my life. Good morning, Leonard.

speaker: How many times have I asked you not to do that?
response: Counting this instance? 317.

speaker: Where’s Penny?
response: She returned to her apartment. I presume to shower and vomit. Not necessarily in that order.

speaker: I wonder why she didn’t say good-bye.
response: Are you expecting me to offer an explanation of human behaviour?

speaker: I know. I just thought as an outsider, you might be able to provide a fresh perspective.
response: I have no difficulty believing you’re not butter.

speaker: Really? Us gonna tell him?
response: Who’s going to tell whom about what?

speaker: Hi.
response: Your surprise confuses me. I live here.

speaker: Right. So, listen, what are you doing tomorrow afternoon?
response: Be more specific.

speaker: Four thirty.
response: That’s not afternoon. That’s preevning.

speaker: What?
response: It’s a time of day I invented. It better defines the ambiguous period between afternoon and evening. Preevning. I’m fairly certain it will catch on as it fills a desperate need.

speaker: Right, okay. What are you doing tomorrow preevning?
response: Well, tomorrow’s Saturday. Saturday night is laundry night, so I’ll be spending the preevning pre-sorting and pre-soaking.

speaker: Okay, what if I were to tell you, tomorrow, at 4
response: I would snort in derision and throw my arms in the air, exhausted by your constant tomfoolery.

speaker: But it’s true. But we-we put all your vital information into this dating site, answered all their questions just like you would, and they found a match for you. Her name is Amy Farrah Fowler.
response: Please. Even assuming you could answer any question the way I would, the algorithms used by matchmaking sites are complete hokum.

speaker: Well, come on, where’s your scientific curiosity?
response: Well, most of it is being applied to unravelling the secrets of the universe while the rest of it’s wondering why I’m having this conversation with you.

speaker: Okay, how about this. Even Spock had a date once every seven years.
response: He didn’t date. It was pon farr. His blood boiled with mating lust.

speaker: Okay, well, why don’t you start with a cup of coffee, and you can pon farr Amy Farrah Fowler later.
response: I don’t drink coffee.

speaker: All right, you can have a hot chocolate.
response: As I will not be engaging in this nonsense, my choice of beverage is moot. But for the record, I only drink hot chocolate in months with an R in them.

speaker: Why?
response: What’s life without whimsy?

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve hidden the dirty sock from the roof somewhere in your apartment. Unless you are willing to come with us to meet this girl, it will remain there forever.
response: You’re bluffing.

speaker: Are you willing to risk it?
response: Curse you.

speaker: You don’t know we’re wrong yet.
response: Haughty derision it is.

speaker: Excuse me. I’m Amy Farrah Fowler. You’re Sheldon Cooper.
response: Hello, Amy Farrah Fowler. I’m sorry to inform you that you have been taken in by unsupportable mathematics designed to prey on the gullible and the lonely. Additionally, I’m being blackmailed with a hidden dirty sock.

speaker: If that was slang, I’m unfamiliar with it. If it was literal, I share your aversion to soiled hosiery. In any case, I’m here because my mother and I have agreed that I will date at least once a year.
response: Interesting. My mother and I have the same agreement about church.

speaker: I don’t object to the concept of a deity, but I’m baffled by the notion of one that takes attendance.
response: Well, then you might want to avoid East Texas.

speaker: Noted. Now, before this goes any further, you should know that all forms of physical contact up to and including coitus are off the table.
response: May I buy you a beverage?

speaker: I got whine.
response: I got the B word.

speaker: Come on, if I was any good at convincing women to do stuff, I wouldn’t have spent so much of my twenties in the shower.
response: If you ask me, this whole thing is a waste of our time.

speaker: Helping women? Y
response: Helping anyone. People should take care of themselves.

speaker: Oh, like yesterday, when you made me drive you to the dry cleaners, the pharmacy and the post office?
response: I’m not saying people can’t use tools. Even an otter picks up a rock when he wants a clam.

speaker: You don’t think it’s worthwhile to try to get more women working in science.
response: I think that’s incredibly sexist of you. I believe in a gender-blind society like in Star Trek, where women and men of all races and creeds work side by side as equals.

speaker: Oh, I did spend a lot of my shower time with Lieutenant Uhura.
response: Howard’s disturbing recollections aside, I don’t appreciate being forced to do banal committee work.

speaker: Yes, I know, you’re too smart for this.
response: Exactly. It’s like asking the Human Torch to heat up your frozen burrito.

speaker: Got it. All right, I’m thinking one way to counter bias in the peer-review process, is for papers to be submitted under gender-neutral names. Like S. Smith instead of Samantha Smith.
response: I suppose there is a history of professional women using their initials so as not to be pre-judged. Harry Potter’s J.K. Rowling, uh, Star Trek’s D.C. Fontana.

speaker: Guys, please don’t make this a school project where I’m the smart kid doing all the work while the slackers sit back and watch.
response: We’re not. This time you’re the smart kid doing all the work while the even smarter kids sit back and watch.

speaker: So, you think I’m one of the smarter kids?
response: No, you’re a tool I was using to make my point.

speaker: Guys, our topic is encouraging women in science, can you at least play a less sexist game
response: How is it sexist? My character wields a battle axe as well as any man.

speaker: Not to mention she has mammary glands that could nurse a family of 30. And have enough milk left over to open a Baskin Robbins.
response: Mother, warrior-princess, franchise owner, I hear glass ceilings shattering all over town.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re always saying how much smarter you are than me. Spend five seconds and come up with one idea on how to get more women into science.
response: All your ideas address the issue at a university level. By then it’s too late. You need to design an outreach program that targets girls at the middle school level and sets them on an academic track towards the hard sciences.

speaker: That’s actually good. Why didn’t I think of that?
response: Some people are otters, some people are rocks.

speaker: That’s great, try to set up something for the three of us to go over there.
response: Oh, hold on. While I’m comfortable speaking about science, I’m not sure I know how to spark the interest of schoolchildren. Better Google it.

speaker: What exactly are you looking up?
response: How do I get 12-year-old girls excited.

speaker: Well, they’re actually pretty excited. I’m their most famous alum. If you don’t count the serial k*ll who ate all those prostitutes.
response: This must feel pretty good for you, coming back to your alma mater as an astronaut.

speaker: Nothing.
response: Smart. We don’t want any problems.

speaker: Okay, who’s ready for some science? Me, too. Okay, I am Dr. Leonard Hofstadter. I am here with my friends Dr. Cooper and real-life astronaut Howard Wolowitz, and we are going to show you girls how cool a job in science can be. How cool, you ask? Well, how about negative 273 degrees, ’cause that’s the temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value. Did I just learn something new and have fun doing it? What? All right. So now let’s bring out theoretical physicist Dr. Sheldon Cooper.
response: Hello, female children. Allow me to inspire you with a story about a great female scientist. Polish-born, French-educated Madame Curie. Co-discoverer of radioactivity, she was a hero of science, until her hair fell out, her vomit and stool became filled with blood, and she was poisoned to death by her own discovery. With a little hard work, I see no reason why that can’t happen to any of you. Are we done? Can we go?

speaker: Quick, pull the fire alarm. Let’s get out of here.
response: Uh, hello again. Um, yeah, I don’t know if women in general have been actively discouraged from pursuing the sciences, but it’s clear you young women here, today, have been. While I was listening to my colleagues waste your time, it occurred to me that it might be much more meaningful to hear about women in science from actual women in science, and, uh, I happen to know two brilliant examples who have agreed to speak to you on the phone right now. Uh, Dr. Rostenkowski, Dr. Fowler, are you there?

speaker: We’re here.
response: Thank you for taking time out of your very busy schedule to enlighten these young women.

speaker: Sheldon, all Snow White needs is one little kiss to wake up.
response: Heard you the first time.

speaker: I wonder how long Sheldon’s got.
response: These shrimp are all the same size. There’s no the logical order to eat them in.

speaker: Yeah.
response: Mm, indeed.

speaker: So sad.
response: Dibs.

speaker: What’s up, fewwas?
response: What are you doing here, Kripke?

speaker: Ah, measuwing my new office for dwapes.
response: This is not your office. It hasn’t been assigned yet.

speaker: Well, I called dibs at the Chwistmas party when Pwofessor Wothman twied to have intercourse with the toys for tots cowwection box.
response: Dibs? This is a university, not a playground. Offices are not assigned because someone called dibs.

speaker: You just called dibs.
response: Shut it. Offices are assigned by seniority. I arrived at the university first.

speaker: Can’t this wait?
response: I’m sorry. We just need a word.

speaker: Can’t you take this up with your department chairman?
response: We tried. His assistant said he was on sabbatical. Although we distinctly heard his office window open and shut.

speaker: Gentlemen, there’s a task I’m trying to accomplish here, and I’m having trouble doing it.
response: Oh, my. President Siebert, I don’t mean to be an alarmist, but difficulty initiating a urine stream could be a symptom of benign prostatic hyperplasia. If you’re interested, I can send you a link to a YouTube video that’ll show you how to perform your own rectal exam. Yeah, uh, helpful hint, trim your nails first.

speaker: Ignore him, Pwesident Siebert. I’m sure a young man such as yourself has a perfectwy healthy pwostate.
response: Oh, he’s just trying to butter you up. And for the record, butter is an excellent lubricant for your rectal exam.

speaker: Well, as wong as we’re here, I might as well take a weak.
response: Kripke?

speaker: Yes?
response: You’re in my spot.

speaker: Ooh, limited edition. Nice.
response: Oh, that’ll be Kripke.

speaker: What’s he doing here?
response: We’re going to work this office situation out like gentlemen. And if that doesn’t work, I’m going to poison his tea.

speaker: Cooper.
response: Kripke. Come in. I’m making tea. Would you like a cup?

speaker: Am I weawing a summer fwock? No, I don’t want tea. Wet’s get down to bwass tacks.
response: Fine. In the interest of preserving our friendship…

speaker: We’re not fwiends.
response: Well, that’s a little hard to hear, but all right. As you know, the essence of diplomacy is compromise. With that in mind, I propose the following. I will take Rothman’s office, and you will find a way to be okay with that.

speaker: How about I take Wothman’s office, and you go suck a wemon?
response: You sure I can’t get you that cup of tea?

speaker: What the fwig is that?
response: Rock-Paper-Scissors-Lizard-Spock was created by Internet pioneer Sam Kass as an improvement on the classic game Rock-Paper-Scissors. All hail Sam Kass.

speaker: How does it work?
response: Oh, it’s very simple. Scissors cuts paper, paper covers rock, rock crushes lizard, lizard poisons Spock, Spock smashes scissors, scissors decapitates lizard, lizard eats paper, paper disproves Spock, Spock vaporizes rock, and as it always has, rock crushes scissors.

speaker: I’m sowwy. Can you wepeat that?
response: Well, of course. Scissors cuts paper, paper covers rock, rock crushes lizard, lizard poisons Spock, Spock smashes scissors, scissors decapitates lizard, lizard eats paper, paper disproves Spock, Spock vaporizes rock, and as it always has, rock crushes scissors.

speaker: Almost got it. One more time.
response: Surely. Scissors cuts paper, paper covers rock, rock…

speaker: Sheldon, stop. He’s screwing with you.
response: Is he? Well, then, it seems we have reached an impasse. I see no other option than to challenge you to a duel. I’d smack you with a glove, but just last week I packed away my winter things.

speaker: H-h-h-hang on, Howard. Barry, how good of a sh*t are you?
response: Not p*stol. Minds. A trivia contest, and you may choose the field of battle. Star Trek trivia, Star Trek

speaker: All right, this is one-on-one. First person to five wins the office. Any questions? Yes, Sheldon?
response: Five what?

speaker: Balls in the basket. (Throws ball to Sheldon)
response: Ew!

speaker: I get it.
response: Hey! He did that on purpose,

speaker: No. No, I’m not.
response: Use the force, Sheldon. Use the force. (Throws ball. It goes about two feet in front of him.) I’m gonna need more force.

speaker: All right, we gave it 45 minutes. It’s no longer funny. Let’s try something else.
response: What do you propose?

speaker: Oh, you are going down, Cooper.
response: I don’t think so, Kripke. I’ve bounced many a rubber ball in my day.

speaker: Congratulations, Sheldon. You win office.
response: Who’s unsatisfactory in P.E. now?

speaker: I’m happy for you, Sheldon. But I have to admit I’m going to miss sharing an office with you.
response: Oh, of course you are. Feel free to drop by any time.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Yeah. Call first. (Pushes him out. Closes door. Rothman is standing naked behind it.)

speaker: Oh. Hello.
response: Professor Rothman. This isn’t your office any more. You’re retired.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I’m trying to raise the temperature in here before my nipples tear through my shirt.

speaker: Why don’t you just turn up the thermostat?
response: Aha! Good question. It turns out the thermostat for my new office isn’t in my new office. No. It’s next door, in Professor Davenport’s office, who is currently enjoying the hot flashes associated with menopause.

speaker: Why is there a hole here?
response: Why is there a hole in my new office? I’ve narrowed it down to two possibilities

speaker: Well, at least you finally got a window that opens. That’s nice.
response: Is it? Listen.

speaker: What, you don’t like wind chimes?
response: No, I hate them, but it gets worse. There it is.

speaker: The bird?
response: Yeah, It’s completely out of tune with the wind chimes.

speaker: So?
response: You don’t get it, do you? That’s a mockingbird. Mockingbirds can change their song, which means he’s out of tune on purpose. He’s mocking me. Oh dear. There it is again. Do you feel it?

speaker: The growing realization that you are one wacky bastard? Yep.
response: No. The vibration. We are directly underneath the geology lab, and they’re running their confounded sieve shakers again. Hey, gravel monkeys, if you need to shake rocks, try jiggling your heads around!

speaker: Sheldon, relax.
response: How can I relax? My nervous system is being stretched out like the strings of a harp and plucked by holes and birds and wind and the low-hanging scrotum of the difficult-to-evict Professor Rothman.

speaker: If you’re not happy, why don’t you just let Kripke have the office?
response: What, and let him win? Do I look crazy to you? We’re trying to think down here, you geode-loving feldspar jockeys! (To the bird) And you, the notes are C, D, E, G and A. You pick one or I am chopping down that tree!

speaker: What happened?
response: I was trying to see what was in here and my head got stuck.

speaker: Why would you do that?
response: It’s called scientific curiosity. Now go get butter.

speaker: No.
response: Answer honestly. This is not a trial. That’ll come later.

speaker: Yeah. Uh, maybe we were hacked. You know, the Chinese have been hacking everything lately.
response: Why would the Chinese make our DVR record Paul Blart

speaker: I don’t know. It’s a fat guy on a Segway. That’s funny everywhere.
response: I’m deleting it.

speaker: You know, if you’re trying to make space on the DVR, why don’t you just get rid of some of the stuff you’ve already watched? Like, um, Alphas.
response: No, that’s the season two finale. That was quite the cliffhanger. I’m going to re-watch it before season three starts.

speaker: There is no season three. They cancelled that show.
response: Well, they can’t cancel it. It ended on a cliffhanger.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon, there are two dumplings left. Do you want them?
response: Dumplings? Don’t you understand what’s going on here?

speaker: As a rule, no.
response: That show ended with all the residents of New York either dead or unconscious. Oh, now I’ll never know what happened.

speaker: Well, why don’t you make up your own ending?
response: Oh, sure, what a wonderful idea. And after that, I’ll make up my own rules of oral hygiene. You know, instead of flossing, I’ll rub pudding on my gums. I’m going to get the number of the SyFy Channel and give them what for.

speaker: Oh, please, don’t do that.
response: No. They can’t just cancel a show like Alphas. You know? They have to help the viewers let go. Firefly did a movie to wrap things up. Buffy the Vampire Slayer continued on as a comic book. Heroes gradually lowered the quality season by season till we were grateful it ended.

speaker: I’m sorry you’re upset. You know, Sheldon, sometimes people seek the comfort of physical contact in moments like this.
response: I am not flying back to Texas just so my mom can give me a hug.

speaker: Okay. Well, what I think is going on here is you have a pathological need for closure.
response: Oh, that’s nonsense. I mean, you tell me stories about your day all the time. I don’t care how they end.

speaker: You know, I might be able to help you with this. There’s a whole field of behavioural neuroscience that examines ways to retrain your neural pathways so stuff like this bothers you less.
response: Yeah, but I just told you, I don’t have a problem with closure.

speaker: You sure about that?
response: Oh, quite sure. (Amy starts a knocking sequence on the table. After staring at her a moment, Sheldon completes it.) That proves nothing.

speaker: I’ve come up with a series of exercises to help with your compulsive need for closure.
response: I take issue with the word compulsive.

speaker: All I’m saying is, we live in a world where closure isn’t always an op…
response: …tion. Okay. For the sake of argument, let’s say I have a problem. What would be your plan for addressing it?

speaker: I’m going to recondition your brain so that the need for completion isn’t so overwhelming.
response: By playing tic-tac-toe?

speaker: Yep. Your turn.
