response: Oh, Amy. And you wonder why people think neuroscience is nothing but a goofy game for diaper babies. Tic-tac-toe can only end in win, lose or draw, none of which will deny me closure. Especially since I’m about to win. (She wipes the board clean.) B-But we didn’t finish.

speaker: Exactly. How does that make you feel?
response: The same way any normal person would. I feel like I want to peel off my own face and tear it in two and then again and again until I have a handful of Sheldon-face confetti.

speaker: And that’s exactly the feeling we want to address with this course of treatment.
response: Or you could pitch in, grab a nostril and help me get this face off.

speaker: Come on, you can do this.
response: You don’t know what it’s like to feel completely frustrated. To have a desire build up within you and be denied any opportunity for release.

speaker: That’s quite an impressive layout, isn’t it?
response: Yes.

speaker: Let’s box it up.
response: Let’s box it up.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, make a wish and blow out the candles. Oops, missed one. Now your wish can’t come true.
response: Lucky for you, ’cause I wished you were dead.

speaker: I’m a little surprised to hear you feeling so positive.
response: Well, you’re an excellent neuroscientist, you’re a wonderful girlfriend, and…

speaker: And?
response: Doesn’t matter, does it?

speaker: I’m proud of you, Sheldon. (Exits.)
response: And a complete sucker.

speaker: Sheldon, you big weirdo, I want you to know that I love that you’re in my life.
response: I love you, too.

speaker: If only there were a solution to that.
response: Seriously. I feel like I’ve got a fish t*nk in my pelvis.

speaker: So go to the bathroom.
response: I can’t.

speaker: Why not?
response: Because I’m trying to decide between getting an Xbox One or a PS4. Oh, pee, why’d I say that?

speaker: Forgive me for asking a stupid question, but why are you being stupid?
response: I’m not being stupid. I’m employing the work of Dutch researcher, Mirjam Tuk, who found that people with full bladders make better decisions.

speaker: I know. Next time I get pulled over for a speeding ticket, here come the waterworks.
response: Here come the waterworks.

speaker: Can you get the butter, please?
response: You know, however, with the Xbox One, I can control my entire entertainment system using voice commands. Up until now, I’ve had to use Leonard.

speaker: Then get the other one. Pass the butter.
response: Get? Hang on. I don’t feel like you’re taking this dilemma seriously.

speaker: Fine, Sheldon. You have my undivided attention.
response: Okay, now, the PS4 is more angular and sleek-looking.

speaker: No way.
response: Yeah, well, it’s true. But the larger size of the Xbox One may keep it from overheating.

speaker: Well, you wouldn’t want your gaming system to overheat.
response: No, see? Well, you absolutely would not. And furthermore, the Xbox One now comes with a Kinect included.

speaker: Included?
response: Yes. Not sold separately. Although the PS4 uses cool new GDDR5 RAM, while the Xbox One is still using the conventional DDR3 memory.

speaker: Why would they still be using DDR3? Are they nuts?
response: See? That’s what I thought. But then they go and throw in an ESRAM buffer.

speaker: Whoa, whoa. Wait a second. Who’s they?
response: Xbox.

speaker: You’re kidding.
response: No, I am not. And this ESRAM buffer should totally bridge the 100-gigabit-per-second bandwidth gap between the two RAM types.

speaker: You’re welcome.
response: Good night.

speaker: Uh, it’s date night. Aren’t you, uh, forgetting something?
response: Oh, of course. (They kiss) Did I mention the PS4 controllers light up?

speaker: No.
response: Well, they do.

speaker: Okay, that’s enough.
response: Quick poll, PS4 or Xbox One? Raj?

speaker: Uh, Xbox One.
response: Penny?

speaker: Huh?
response: Leonard?

speaker: PS4.
response: Wolowitz?

speaker: Both great.
response: Bernadette?

speaker: I like the Wii.
response: Thanks, Grandma.

speaker: I’m proud of you, Sheldon.
response: You know, I’m proud of me, too. I’ve done all my research, I conducted an informal poll, and I’ve arrived at the rock-solid certainty I’ve made the right choice.

speaker: Well, that’s got to be a good feeling.
response: Oh, it is. Although.

speaker: Oh, crap.
response: I had the same feeling when I made my dad buy a Betamax instead of a VHS.

speaker: You were just a little kid.
response: Yeah, a little kid who picked the wrong format to record The MacNeil/Lehrer Report. Now I also was certain that HD DVD would win out over Blu-ray.

speaker: How old were you then?
response: Old enough to know better. You know, and now that I think about it, I stood in front of a case of iPods and I bought a Zune.

speaker: What’s a Zune?
response: Yeah, exactly. It’s an MP3 player brought to us by the makers of Xbox.

speaker: No, what are you doing? No, no, pick that back up. You know it’s good. You did the research.
response: But what if I’m wrong?

speaker: You know what? How about I buy it for you? How about I buy you both?
response: You know I only have one slot available in my entertainment centre.

speaker: Then I’ll buy you a new entertainment centre.
response: Well, yeah, okay, sure. But which one?

speaker: How about this? I’ve heard that if you flip a coin, it will tell you how you actually feel. Because you’ll either be disappointed or excited by the outcome.
response: Interesting.

speaker: So, heads it’s PS4, tails it’s Xbox One.
response: All right, I’ll try.

speaker: What is it?
response: A quarter.

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, guys, but the store closed five minutes ago.
response: But I haven’t decided yet.

speaker: Let’s get you some food. You, You’ll feel better after you eat.
response: Okay.

speaker: What-what do you want, like, Thai food? A burger?
response: I don’t know. Hey, look, a quarter.

speaker: You know, I could totally rock a hat like that.
response: That’s the work of noted Hollywood costume designer Deborah Nadoolman. She also designed the iconic red and black jacket in Michael Jackson’s Thriller video, which I’ve never viewed in its entirety, as I find zombies dancing in choreographed synchronicity implausible. And also, it’s really scary.

speaker: Would someone please turn off the Sheldon commentary track?
response: There’s no switch. Just listen and learn.

speaker: Well, I’m watching it now. Why would I want to see it again on Friday?
response: Because the print they’re showing on Friday has an additional 21 seconds of previously unseen footage.

speaker: Exactly. They say it finally solves the submarine controversy.
response: Did Leonard? I’m no expert, but I believe what we just heard from Penny was sarcasm. (She indicates it was) Oh, good. I’m eight for 26 this month.

speaker: Relax, it’s five o’clock. The movie doesn’t start till midnight.
response: Another way of saying that is the movie starts at midnight, and it’s already five o’clock. Let’s go.

speaker: You know, if we miss it, we’ll have the fun of listening to Sheldon whine about it for the rest of our lives.
response: See? Howard’s on my side.

speaker: Actually, I’m not. I’m using sarcasm to mock you.
response: Drat. Now I’m 8 for 27.

speaker: Don’t worry, Sheldon. We’ll be fine.
response: What happened to the Leonard Hofstadter who waited in line with me for 14 hours to see the midnight premiere of Star Trek

speaker: Oh. Well, he waited in line for 14 hours, while you napped in a lawn chair, he got in a fight with a Klingon when he stepped out of line to pee and you wouldn’t wake up to vouch for him, and worst of all, he saw Star Trek
response: But how were our seats?

speaker: Excellent.
response: I rest my case. Amy, don’t you agree we should leave now and get in line?

speaker: Actually, as the newest member of your social group, I believe I’ll gain more acceptance by arbitrarily siding with your friends from time to time.
response: Shrewd.

speaker: Hysterical!
response: Wait, now, we don’t know that yet. He isn’t finished. I have a girlfriend and you don’t who?

speaker: All right. I’ll have to go shopping.
response: Knock-knock.

speaker: Who‘s there?
response: Hugh.

speaker: Hugh who?
response: Hugh people need to listen to me. It’s time to get in line for the movie. And that’s how you tell a knock-knock joke.

speaker: Ooh. Can’t wait for that to start.
response: I informed you thusly.

speaker: Eight for 28.
response: This is where we could have been if we hadn’t stopped for dinner. This is where we could have been if Koothrappali hadn’t ordered dessert.

speaker: Well I earned it, dude, I ate all my broccoli.
response: And here’s where we are. The runts in a large litter, unlikely to ever reach the nourishing teats of Indiana Jones.

speaker: Hey, guys, bad news. I just did a quick calculation. Given the size of the theatre and the length of this line, we might not get seats.
response: What did he say?

speaker: Nice going, Raj, just got him down for his nap.
response: We might not get seats?

speaker: It’s fine, it’s fine. Go back to sleep.
response: Oh, I informed you thusly. I so informed you thusly.

speaker: Hey, look who’s here! Hey, buddies!
response: Well, if it isn’t Wil Wheaton, the Jar Jar Binks of the Star Trek universe.

speaker: Mee-sa think that very funny.
response: Well, you-sa can go think that at the back of the line. No cuts, no buts, no coconuts.

speaker: I’m a big fan.
response: Of what? Poorly executed beards?

speaker: Oh, awesome. We-sa gonna go into the movie now. Bye-bye.
response: This is Indiana Jones, not Star Trek. There should be no value to his pseudo-celebrity here. And even at Star Trek conventions, they only let him in if he helps set up.

speaker: Calm down, Sheldon.
response: I will not calm down. This affront to justice and decency cannot go unanswered. As Captain Jean-Luc Picard once said, the line must be drawn here! This far, no farther!

speaker: Oh, oh, uh, looks like they’re getting ready to let people in.
response: Listen to what Mr. Wil Wheaton is tweeting. Best seats in house for Raiders screening. Suck on that, Sheldon Cooper.

speaker: Why do you read his Twitter feed? You know it’s only going to upset you.
response: I believe in knowing my enemy, Leonard. Had Twitter existed at the time, would not General Custer have followed the tweets of Sitting Bull? Would not Lee have followed Grant? Would not Spy have followed Spy? I have more examples, but excuse me. (On phone) Hello. Well, this seems like an odd time to test my cell phone quality, but go on. Test phrases? All right. Imatote. Ulbu. Twad. All together? I’m a total buttwad. Why are you laughing? Hello?

speaker: Guys, I am sorry. We are full up.
response: No!

speaker: Sorry. Fire regulations. Should’ve gotten here earlier.
response: This is nothing but a blatant abuse of power by a petty functionary. Explain to me why Wil Wheaton and his lackeys get in and we don’t.

speaker: I guess that’s that. Let’s go home.
response: You know what? I’m going back to I told you so. I told you so.

speaker: We can still see something. Uh, the new Sandra Bullock movie is playing two blocks away. You know Sandy B always brings it.
response: Look, a side door. Come on, Short Round.

speaker: Where did he go? (Raj whistles) We’re looking for Sheldon, not Marmaduke.
response: You whistled?

speaker: What is that?
response: Raiders of the Lost Ark, with 21 additional seconds. If I can’t see it, no one else can see it.

speaker: Sheldon, this is crazy.
response: No. Crazy was leaving the projection booth unattended.

speaker: Listen to me. You are over-tired. You’re not thinking right. Put the movie back before we get into trouble.
response: Trouble is my middle name, Leonard. Actually, it’s Lee, but I prefer Trouble.

speaker: Oh, look who they let in.
response: Don’t worry, Wil Wheaton. I was just leaving. Da-da-da-da, da-da-da!

speaker: He’s got the movie! Get him!
response: Why is there never a pontoon plane when you need one?

speaker: I’m just gonna run to the store and get a few things. I’ll pick you up when you’re done.
response: Okay. I like it a little better when you stay, but all right.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Hello. I’m here for my haircut with Mr. D’Onofrio.

speaker: I’m sorry, Uncle Tony’s in the hospital. He’s pretty sick.
response: Oh, dear, Mr. D’Onofrio’s in the hospital. Why do these things always happen to me?

speaker: I can cut it for you.
response: You’re not Mr. D’Onofrio. I get my hair cut by Mr. D’Onofrio. You believe this guy?

speaker: Excuse us for a second. Sheldon, it’s okay, he can do it. He’s a barber.
response: He’s not a barber, he’s the nephew. He’s an example of the kind of nepotism that runs rampant in the barbering industry. Besides, Mr. D’Onofrio knows exactly how I like my hair done because he has all my haircut records from my barber in Texas.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: When I first moved here I was nervous about finding a new barber, so my mother had all my haircut records sent here to Mr. D’Onofrio.

speaker: There’s no such thing as haircut records.
response: Yes, there are.

speaker: Have you ever seen them?
response: No, but my mother assured me they were sent here, and I’ll bet you dollars to doughnuts that this one doesn’t have them. Uh, excuse me. Do you have access to my haircut records?

speaker: Your what?
response: To paraphrase T.S. Eliot, this is the way the world ends, not with a bang but with a nephew.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re a grown man, he’s a professional, and your haircut is number three on that poster from 1946. Just sit down and let him do it.
response: Fine, but if I come out of this looking like a dork, it’s on you. (Sits)

speaker: So my kid said the funniest thing today.
response: Nope. (Runs out)

speaker: Sure. What are you doing?
response: I’m trying to get the hair out of my eyes.

speaker: Sheldon, you are one day late for your haircut.
response: Thank you for captioning my nightmare.

speaker: So, what kind of things are they… (to Sheldon) will you stop that?
response: I can’t help it, I feel like a teen heartthrob.

speaker: You know, Sheldon, I used to cut my brother’s hair. I could do it for you.
response: Penny, I know you mean well, offering the k*ll of the hill folk, but, um, here in town we don’t churn our own butter, we don’t, uh, make dresses out of g*n sacks, and, uh, we sure as sh**t’ don’t get our hair cut by bottle-blonde…

speaker: Sheldon, be nice.
response: I’m sorry, it’s the bad boy attitude that comes with this hair.

speaker: I’m a cowboy, on a steel horse I ride. I’m wanted… I’m wanted… wanted, dead or alive. Sheldon, you’re ruining girlfriend-boyfriend sing-along night.
response: I’m sorry. I’m looking for a barber and I’m running out of time. My hair is growing at the rate of 4.6 yoctometers per femtosecond. I mean, if you’re quiet, you can hear it.

speaker: What about Supercuts?
response: I tried once. They do men’s and women’s hair in the same room at the same time. It’s like Sodom and Gomorrah with mousse.

speaker: Well, this isn’t a crisis. Why don’t you just let your hair grow out a little?
response: Why don’t I let my hair grow out? Um, why don’t I start wearing Birkenstocks and, uh, uh, seeking validation of my opinions by asking can you dig it?

speaker: Can I help you?
response: Yes. Do you have something I could use as a cape?

speaker: Oh, dear, did we spit out our pills, slip out of the ninth floor, and go on a little adventure?
response: Oh, no, no, I’m just here to get my hair cut.

speaker: I-I see. J-Jus-Just wait here one moment. Security!
response: I got to run. But not with scissors, that would be unsafe.

speaker: Did you have fun? Because if you had fun, then you are, you are a winner. Now that’s, that-that’s what chess is all about.
response: Hello.

speaker: Oh, hey. Sorry, Sheldon, I’ll move.
response: Eh, why? My spot, your spot, what difference does it make?

speaker: Uh, sweetie, are you all right?
response: No, I’m not all right. It’s been six days since I was supposed to get a haircut and nothing horrible has happened.

speaker: Okay, I’m sorry, I don’t understand.
response: Leonard, explain it to her.

speaker: Oh, uh, he’s crazy.
response: I have spent my whole life trying to bring order to the universe by carefully planning every moment of every day. But all my efforts, our dinner schedule, my pyjama rotation, my bowel movement spreadsheet, it’s clear now, I’ve been wasting my time.

speaker: You know, Sh-Sheldon, sometimes it’s nice not knowing what’s coming. I mean, look at me and Leonard. We went out, we broke up, now we’re trying again. We don’t know what’s gonna happen.
response: Oh, please, everyone knows what’s going to happen. But I see your point.

speaker: I think this could be good for you. Maybe it’s time for you to shake things up a bit.
response: You’re right. I should embrace the chaos.

speaker: Great. What are you going to do first?
response: I don’t know. I could do anything. All bets are off. The world is my oyster. I got it. I’m going to put on my Tuesday pyjamas tonight.

speaker: Don’t let this be Sheldon playing bongos. Please don’t let this be Sheldon playing bongos.
response: Hello, Leonard, do you like my bongos? Bet you didn’t know that I had bongos.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s three o’clock in the morning.
response: Three in the morning is a good time for bongos.

speaker: I was sleeping.
response: Leonard sleeps while I play bongos.

speaker: No, he doesn’t.
response: Leonard no sleep while I play bongos. Bongo solo.

speaker: Why did you get bongos?
response: Richard Feynman played the bongos. I thought I’d give that a try.

speaker: Oh, Leonard, it’s three o’clock in the morning. I don’t care if Richard Feynman was a purple leprechaun who lived in my butt.
response: Penny meant if he were a purple leprechaun. Penny forgot to use the subjunctive.

speaker: Sheldon, go to bed. You have work in the morning.
response: Maybe, maybe not. Maybe tomorrow I start a bongo band and tour the world.

speaker: W-w-wuh, no, no, hang on,uh, uh, roommate agreement. No hootenannies, sing-a-longs, or barbershop quartets after ten p.m.
response: Roommate agreement? Are you kidding? We are living in a world of chaos. Roommate agreement.

speaker: Where are you going?
response: Wherever the music takes me, kitten. I play bongos walking down the stairs. (Sound of falling) Oh! Oh! Never play bongos walking down the stairs.

speaker: No, it was called for.
response: What’s going on?

speaker: All right, Sheldon, this craziness has gone on long enough. Please come home so I can cut your hair.
response: Penny, you’re not trained. You’re not licensed. Most importantly, you don’t have access to my haircut records.

speaker: It was a long story. Anyway, Sheldon, I promise I know what I’m doing. Please let me cut your hair.
response: Amy, what do you think?

speaker: There’s not a hair on my body I wouldn’t let this woman trim.
response: Fine, let’s go. Thank you for letting me sleep on your couch.

speaker: What’s this about Sheldon seeing you naked?
response: Oh, relax. It was just her bottom and her breasts.

speaker: Almost done.
response: At the end of the haircut, Mr. D’Onofrio would tell me a dirty joke.

speaker: Well, sorry, I don’t know any dirty jokes.
response: That’s okay, I never understood them anyway.

speaker: Okay, what do you think?
response: Hmm, well, it’s a little Hollywood. But I think I can pull it off. Well done, Penny.

speaker: Ha, told you. Okay, I’m just gonna clean up your neck a little and then you are good to go.
response: Fun time. Hah. Sorry, sometimes the clippers tickle me.

speaker: Have you guys heard about this research team that's trying to transgenically manipulate chicken DNA to create some sort of chicken dinosaur?
response: Oh, I think that sounds wonderful.

speaker: What? You're afraid of both dinosaurs and chickens.
response: Yes, but tell me a dinosaur chicken salad sandwich wouldn't hit the Mesozoic spot.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Yeah. I'm excited to finally meet your girlfriend.
response: Speaking of which, according to a recent study out of Oxford University, when someone takes on a new romantic partner, that person loses one or two close friends.

speaker: Since when do you read social science?
response: I go to the bathroom like everybody else.

speaker: Hey, guys.
response: Hello.

speaker: Uh, yeah, I'm a resident at Huntington Hospital.
response: Oh, I like their emergency room. Yeah, even if it turns out you don't have Dengue fever, they still let you take a lollipop.

speaker: Yeah. I'm sure that'd be fine.
response: I have some odd freckles on my buttocks. Can I make an appointment for you to look at them?

speaker: I'd say it now, but look at those cheekbones.
response: I miss Stuart's place. All this loud music and exposed brick. What, is this a comic book store, or a rave at the third little pig's house?

speaker: You know, he might not reopen. He didn't get a lot of money from the insurance company.
response: Oh, boy, if there is one thing that gets my goat, it's those dad-gum insurance companies.

speaker: All I know is, he's got my mother buying four-ply toilet paper. I mean, four-ply. If his butt is so delicate, why doesn't he just use an angora rabbit?
response: For starters, they shed and bite.

speaker: Ooh, maybe we could come up with a business plan to compete with this place.
response: I'll give you a plan right now. Step one, open comic book store. Step two, start rumour this comic book store gives you genital warts. Step three, buy a big bag to put the money in.

speaker: No. Yeah.
response: So, what are some ways we could set our comic book store apart from the competition?

speaker: Ooh, what if we got a van and drove around and picked kids up?
response: Nice. You mean, like at parks and schools?

speaker: Hold on. So, your idea is to get a van and cruise the streets looking for kids to pick up?
response: Yes.

speaker: Great.
response: On the bright side, that Oxford study was right. One friend down. I wonder who you're going to lose next.

speaker: You, okay? It's you. You're, you're next.
response: No. You're crazy about me.

speaker: Shh. Amy's here now.
response: You know, the more I think about it, the more intrigued I am about having our own store.

speaker: We'll get to see all the new stuff before it hits the shelves.
response: And we'll get to have fun interactions with our customers. Like, this isn't a library, buy it or get out.

speaker: You say things like that all the time.
response: Yes, but as a store owner, I'll finally have a good comeback to, You don't work here, shut up.

speaker: Well, do you think when she and I had that conversation, she left people off her list?
response: I'm sure she did.

speaker: Why?
response: Because if she hadn't, she'd still be wading through the list.

speaker: Will you stay out of this?
response: If only Penny had said that once in a while.

speaker: Yeah, and I'm not sure that complete honesty is always the best thing for a relationship.
response: Yeah, he's right. Once, in a moment of candour, I told Amy that her hair reminded me of a duck caught in an oil spill. She stormed out. Which was sad, because we were playing Scrabble, and I had all the letters to spell persimmon.

speaker: Why are you even part of this conversation? You don't know anything about women.
response: I know that if I had a wife or a fiancée, I'd ask her first before I invested money in a comic book store.

speaker: He's right.
response: Yeah, well, of course I am. I was also right about her hair. It did everything but quack.

speaker: That's how much buying a comic book store means to me.
response: I'd like your honest opinion on something.

speaker: Of course.
response: Now, before I start, I need you to know that I'm very excited about this, and anything you say that isn't enthusiastically supportive will throw our entire relationship into question. So, keep an open mind.

speaker: I'm feeling a little backed into a corner, Sheldon.
response: Perfect. Now, I'm considering investing in Stuart's comic book store.

speaker: Interesting. Can you see how a grown man, an accomplished scientist, who invests in a store that sells picture books about flying men in colourful underwear might be wasting both his financial and intellectual resources?
response: No.

speaker: Then I think it's a terrific idea.
response: Great. Wait till you hear about our van.

speaker: I know. I was looking forward to it.
response: It would've been so nice to have a place that was ours, where we could just sit and read comics in peace.

speaker: And snacks.
response: Well, I guess it was too good to be true.

speaker: Sheldon help!
response: I need to go, but you keep in mind that my sharply worded comments on yelp.com recently took down a local muffin store. (At Penny’s door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..

speaker: Come in! Hurry!
response: Penny?

speaker: I’m back here.
response: (At Penny’s bedroom door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..

speaker: Oh, for god’s sakes, I’m in the bathroom!
response: Shall I come back at a better time?

speaker: Get in here! Hurry! Don’t you dare knock.
response: Hello.

speaker: I slipped in the shower, and I think I dislocated my shoulder.
response: Not surprising. You have no safety mat or adhesive stickers to allow for purchase on a surface with a low coefficient of static friction.

speaker: What?
response: Tubs are slippery.

speaker: I know. I slipped.
response: I have a series of whimsical duck stickers on the bottom of my tub.

speaker: Yeah, okay, whatever. Will you just turn the water off and help me up?
response: They’re holding umbrellas.

speaker: What?
response: The ducks in my tub.

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: They’re whimsical because ducks have neither the need for, nor the ability to use umbrellas.

speaker: Oh, my god. I got to go to the emergency room.
response: Well, assuming you’re correct that your right humerus is no longer seated in the glenoid socket, I would certainly think so.

speaker: Okay, can you drive me?
response: I don’t drive.

speaker: Well, I can’t drive!
response: Well, it seems we’ve reached an impasse.

speaker: Ow.
response: But I could call you a cab or an ambulance.

speaker: No, no, no, I can’t wait that long, you got to help me, please.
response: All right. Let it never be said that Sheldon Lee Cooper ignored the pleas of a damsel in distress.

speaker: No one’s saying that. Let’s go.
response: Well, it does seem rather ironic that for want of 99-cent adhesive ducks, we both might die in a fiery car crash.

speaker: I don’t need panties, I just need shorts and a shirt.
response: My mother always told me one should wear clean underpants in case one is in an accident.

speaker: One was already in an accident.
response: That doesn’t mean one won’t be in another, especially if I’m driving.

speaker: Clothes, Sheldon. I need clothes!
response: Okay, here.

speaker: Seriously? Those shorts with that top?
response: All right.

speaker: No… No… Oh, that’s cute.
response: We should have you checked for a concussion.

speaker: Okay, now, you got to help me put these on.
response: All right.

speaker: But don’t look.
response: Don’t look?

speaker: I don’t want you to see me naked.
response: Oh. Well, that’s understandable. You may be interested to know that a prohibition against looking is well established in heroic mythology. Uh, Lot and his wife, Perseus and Medusa, Orpheus and Eurydice.

speaker: Yeah, great.
response: They always look. It never ends well.

speaker: Ok, now you gotta help me get my arm into the sleeve.
response: Ok.

speaker: Is that my arm?
response: It doesn’t feel like an arm.

speaker: Then, maybe you should let it go.
response: All righty.

speaker: You have your learner’s permit, right?
response: Yes, and I have logged a considerable number of hours on a simulator.

speaker: Good.
response: Didn’t work out well.

speaker: All right, can we please go?
response: One moment. According to my driver’s ed book, a side mirror is properly adjusted when a portion of the is driver’s door handle is visible in the lower right corner. There’s the handle. Oh, no, too far, bringing it back. Optimized. Now, where is the switch to adjust the passenger side mirror?

speaker: It’s right there.
response: Where is the passenger side mirror?

speaker: In a parking lot in Hollywood. Now, can we please go?
response: Yes. As soon as I adjust my seat. Whee! Oh, dear. I’m going to have to start again.

speaker: Could you please drive a little faster?
response: Oh, I think we’re going sufficiently fast. What’s that?

speaker: Nothing. The engine does that sometimes.
response: That can’t be nothing, the check engine light is on. We need to find a service station.

speaker: No. The light has been on since I bought the car.
response: All the more reason to consult with a mechanic before it explodes.

speaker: It’s not going to explode, just keep driving. Warp speed ahead, Mr. Spock.
response: Mr. Spock did not pilot the Enterprise. He was the science officer, and I guarantee you that if he ever saw the Enterprise’s check engine light blinking, he would pull the ship over immediately.

speaker: Oh, god, I’m gonna lose the arm.
response: Oh, oh, red light, release accelerator and slowly apply the brake. Nailed it. While we have a moment, may I ask you a question?

speaker: What?
response: Why do you have the Chinese character for soup tattooed on your right buttock?

speaker: It’s not soup, it’s courage.
response: No, it isn’t. But I suppose it does take courage to demonstrate that kind of commitment to soup.

speaker: How did you see it? You said you wouldn’t look.
response: Sorry. As I told you, the hero always peeks.

speaker: I dislocated my shoulder.
response: All right. And how did the accident occur?

speaker: You ready know that.
response: Cause of accident, lack of adhesive ducks. Okay, medical history. Have you ever been diagnosed with diabetes?

speaker: No.
response: Kidney disease?

speaker: No.
response: Migraines?

speaker: Getting one.
response: Are you currently pregnant?

speaker: No.
response: Are you sure? You look a bit puffy.

speaker: Change migraine to yes.
response: When was your last menstrual period?

speaker: Oh, next question.
response: I’ll put, in progress. Okay, moving to psychiatric disorders, list all major behavioural diagnoses, e.g. depression, anxiety, etcetera.

speaker: Oh, my god, what the hell does this have to do with my stupid shoulder?
response: Episodes of sub psychotic rage.

speaker: Ass.
response: Possible Tourette’s. All right, moles, lesions or other skin conditions. Soup tattoo on right buttock.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, Sheldon, look, I am scared and in a lot of pain. Could you please just take a break from being you for just a minute and try being, I don’t know, comforting?
response: I’m sorry. There, there. Everything’s going to be fine. Sheldon’s here.

speaker: Wait. You have to help me get into bed. Sheldon has to get me into bed. Bet you never thought I’d say that.
response: Yes. The charm of your drug addled candour knows no bounds.

speaker: You know, people think you’re this weird robot man who’s so annoying all the time, and you totally are, but then it’s like that movie Wall-E at the end. You’re so full of love, and you can save a plant and get fat people out of the floaty chairs.
response: That’s a fairly laboured metaphor, but I appreciate the sentiment behind it.

speaker: Sing “Soft Kitty” to me.
response: “Soft Kitty” is for when you’re sick. You’re not sick.

speaker: Injured and drugged is a kind of sick.
response: Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur…

speaker: Funny. We’re always giving each other a hard time up here. It’s kind of like being in a frat. You know, joking, kidding around, hurting feelings.
response: Okay, my turn. Let me talk to him.

speaker: Go ahead.
response: 2311 North Los Robles Avenue, Pasadena, California to International Space Station. Can you read me? Over. (Makes static noise)

speaker: Yes, I read you, Sheldon.
response: Copy that. Over. (Static noise)

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I am talking to a man in space. If you don’t have the (static noise) then he might as well be at the Coffee Bean over on Lake Street.

speaker: You’re out of your mind,Sheldon.
response: That’s a negative. My mother had me tested. Over. (Static noise)

speaker: Bye.
response: Over and out. (Static noise)

speaker: Hey, Stuart, come on in.
response: What are you doing here?

speaker: Um, Raj invited me to go to the movies with you guys.
response: Excuse me. I didn’t authorize this.

speaker: Sheldon, you are not in charge.
response: That’s mighty sassy for a man with a roommate performance review around the corner.

speaker: What’s the big deal? You guys are bringing your girlfriends. I didn’t want to sit by myself.
response: The big deal is I was expecting us to be an intimate group of five. Now, we’re going to be a faceless mass of six.

speaker: It’ll be fine. Just, uh, pretend he’s Wolowitz.
response: Hmm. Do you like Raisinets?

speaker: I can take them or leave them.
response: At the movies, Wolowitz always eats Raisinets.

speaker: Would you feel more comfortable if I ate Raisinets?
response: Well, it’s hardly my business what you eat, as long as it doesn’t crunch during the film and it’s Raisinets.

speaker: Okay. Should we go?
response: Yuh-uh, one more question, if you’re going to replace Wolowitz, I need to know a little more about you.

speaker: All right.
response: Wolowitz went to MIT. What’s your educational background?

speaker: I went to art school.
response: Equally ridiculous. Let’s go.

speaker: Well, I like it.
response: Yeah, of course you do. You’re a girl. You like all kinds of hippy-dippy things.

speaker: Just watch the movie.
response: It’s not fair. Penny isn’t making Leonard hold hands.

speaker: There might be a reason for that.
response: Sweaty? Unhygienic? Looks dumb? Take your pick.

speaker: Penny said she’s not sure she wants to be Leonard’s girlfriend anymore.
response: Wrong. She just took a sip from his Diet Dr. Pepper.

speaker: So?
response: So, if she wants to end her pair-bond with Leonard, why on earth would she guzzle a witches’ brew of his soda and spit?

speaker: It’s complicated.
response: String theory is complicated. That’s just yucky. Don’t get any ideas. All right, for the sake of argument, let’s say that’s true. Why doesn’t Penny just end the relationship?

speaker: She’s not sure how she feels.
response: How can she not be sure how she feels? You know, when I have a feeling, I know it. Trains? Love them. Swordfish? I love them, too. They’re fish with a sword for a nose.

speaker: Regardless, don’t say anything to Leonard.
response: Now you’re asking me to keep a secret from my best friend, colleague, and roommate?

speaker: Yes, please, Penny will k*ll me.
response: Uh, fine. FYI, secret-keeping? Hate it. Hand-holding? Not a fan. Hammerhead shark? I love that thing. Yeah, it’s another fish with a tool on its head.

speaker: Raisinet?
response: Shh, we’re trying to watch the movie. This is not working out with him.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I think I might have tartar buildup. My tongue won’t go as far forward as it used to.

speaker: Maybe your tongue is shrinking.
response: Nope. Oh, you have no idea how annoying this is.

speaker: I’m starting to get a sense of it. Don’t worry. I’ll take you to the dentist tomorrow.
response: Thank you. I appreciate that. You’re good people, Leonard. There’s something I need to tell you.

speaker: Okay.
response: I can’t tell you.

speaker: Why?
response: I can’t tell you why I can’t tell you. So I guess there’s two things I can’t tell you.

speaker: I wish there were more.
response: Good night. I’m sorry. This is really important.

speaker: What is it?
response: I like The Transformers. Do you like The Transformers?

speaker: Where exactly did your mother have you tested?
response: Leonard, the Transformers teach us that things are not always what they appear to be. You know, like, uh, a semi truck might be an alien robot, or, uh, someone in a romantic relationship, uh, might feel differently than they appear to. Or a conversation about The Transformers might actually be about someone in this room. I’m going to pause to let that sink in.

speaker: Okay, I think I understand.
response: You do?

speaker: The guy who seems like an emotionless robot is you, but your relationship with Amy is causing you to transform into a red-blooded man with sexual desires.
response: That is literally the stupidest thing I’ve ever heard.

speaker: What?
response: Are you sleeping?

speaker: I was. Now I’m having a nightmare. What do you want?
response: Never mind. I still can’t tell you.

speaker: Oh, my God. Sheldon?
response: You frightened me.

speaker: What are you doing in my bedroom?
response: Yeah, well, I knocked on the front door, but you didn’t hear it.

speaker: How did you even get in, you weirdo?
response: Yeah, really? I’ve seen strange men traipsing in and out of here for years, but when I do it, it’s weird?

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: Oh, I was having a little trouble sleeping and I just thought, uh, seeing as you’re up, we could talk.

speaker: Talk about what?
response: Oh, I don’t know, uh, weather, uh, fish you could do carpentry with, why Leonard is such an attractive and desirable boyfriend. Yeah, pick one, your choice.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Did you know that Leonard has a perfect driving record and enjoys the insurance discounts that go along with that? Hubba-hubba.

speaker: Okay, go home, crazy man.
response: Yeah. Did you know that while Leonard is not considered a tall fellow in our country, in today’s North Korea, he’s downright average. Hey, talk about a keeper.

speaker: Okay, what did Amy tell you?
response: Oh, very well. I can’t keep up this clever charade any longer. She told me that you were thinking of ending it with Leonard.

speaker: Okay, you listen to me. I think it’s really sweet you’re trying to protect your friend, but this is none of your business. Got it?
response: Excuse me. This is not about protecting my friend. I’m a big fan of homeostasis. Do you know what that is?

speaker: Of course not.
response: Homeostasis refers to a system’s ability to regulate its internal environment and maintain a constant condition of properties like temperature or pH.

speaker: Worst bedtime story ever.
response: My point is I don’t like when things change. So, regardless of your feelings, I would like you to continue dating Leonard. And also, while we’re on the subject, you recently changed your shampoo. I’m not comfortable with the new scent. Please stop this madness and go back to green apple.

speaker: Okay, honey, I have a lot to figure out, and until I do, you are not to say a word to Leonard. Do you understand?
response: I do. You clear on the shampoo issue?

speaker: Get out.
response: Penny?

speaker: What?
response: Please don’t hurt my friend.

speaker: That is the last thing I want to do.
response: Thank you. Coconut? What were you thinking? Are you a hula girl?

speaker: Hang on, please. Hello?
response: Yeah, just a heads-up

speaker: I know. She’s yelling at me right now.
response: All right then, so we’re all on the same page. Yes.

speaker: Temple of Yip.
response: I’m sorry. Wolowitz would never play that card.

speaker: All right, Lesser Demon Turtle.
response: Fairy God Monster, I win. Your desperate need for friendship makes you weak.

speaker: In case you didn’t follow that, I’m the coffee.
response: Leonard? Maybe you’d like to go with them to meet girls.

speaker: Why would I be interested? I have Penny.
response: Yeah, for now. But that woman has a death wish, Leonard. She talks to strangers, she pets unfamiliar dogs, and it is ridiculously easy to break into her apartment. If I were you, I’d get a back-up.

speaker: No, please don’t ruin this for me.
response: Do you remember how upset I was when they replaced Edward Norton as the Hulk?

speaker: Yes, you walked around for a week saying, Sheldon unhappy with casting choice.
response: But, then Mark Ruffalo was the Hulk in The Avengers, and he was even better.

speaker: What’s your point?
response: Call me a romantic. I like to think that your Mark Ruffalo is still out there somewhere.

speaker: I like Mark Ruffalo, too.
response: Yeah, settle down there, fake Wolowitz. No one likes a kiss-up.

speaker: It was like a snowy nightmare from which there was no awakening.
response: I don’t know what Arctic expedition you guys were on, but I thought it was a hoot and a half.

speaker: I’m going to go let Penny know we’re back.
response: Mother, I have to go. Yeah, love you. Bye. (To his spot) Hello, old friend. (Sits) Daddy’s home.

speaker: Thanks.
response: Of course, I can’t mention you in my Nobel acceptance speech, but when I get round to writing my memoirs you can expect a very effusive footnote, and perhaps a signed copy.

speaker: We have to tell him.
response: Tell me what?

speaker: Damn his Vulcan hearing.
response: You fellows are planning a party for me, aren’t you?

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, sit down.
response: If there’s going to be a theme, I should let you know that I don’t care for luau, toga or under the sea.

speaker: Yeah, we’ll keep that in mind, look, we need to talk to you about something that happened at the North Pole.
response: If this is about the night the heat went out, there’s nothing to be embarrassed about.

speaker: And we agreed to never speak of it again.
response: So we slept together naked. It was only to keep our core body temperatures from plummeting.

speaker: That’s why I added the tator. And then when we found our first positive data, you were so happy.
response: Oh, yes. In the world of emoticons, I was colon, capital D.

speaker: He just went colon, capital O.
response: You tampered with my experiment?

speaker: It was the only way to keep you from being such a huge Dickensian. You see that? I added the ensian.
response: Did Leonard know about this? Leonard’s my best friend in the world. Surely Leonard didn’t know.

speaker: Actually, it was his idea.
response: Of course it was. The whole plan reeks of Leonard.

speaker: Me, neither. Except for one night when the heat went out. Long story, it’s… don’t ask.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard.

speaker: Do not make a sound.
response: Whispering do not make a sound is a sound.

speaker: Damn his Vulcan hearing. Not a good time, Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: Oh, this is ridiculous. What?
response: Hello, Penny. I realize you’re currently at the mercy of your primitive biological urges, but as you have an entire lifetime of poor decisions ahead of you, may I interrupt this one?

speaker: It’s great to see you too. Come on in.
response: Wolowitz has informed me of your grand deception. Do you have anything to say for yourself?

speaker: Okay, can someone please tell me what’s going on here?
response: What’s going on is I was led to believe I was making groundbreaking strides in science, when in fact, I was being fed false data at the hands of Wolowitz, Koothrappali and your furry little boy toy.

speaker: Because when he wasn’t happy, we wanted to k*ll him. There was even a plan. We were going to throw his Kindle outside, and when he went to get it, lock the door and let him freeze to death.
response: That seems like a bit of an overreaction.

speaker: No, the overreaction was the plan to tie your limbs to four different sled dog teams and yell mush. Look, we kept the original data. You can still publish the actual results.
response: Yes, but the actual results are unsuccessful and I’ve already sent an e-mail to everyone at the university explaining that I have confirmed string theory and forever changed man’s understanding of the universe.

speaker: Aw, see, yeah, you probably shouldn’t have done that. So write another e-mail, set the record straight, it’s no big deal.
response: You’re right, Leonard, it’s not a big deal. All you did was lie to me destroy my dream and humiliate me in front of the whole university. That, FYI, was sarcasm. I, in fact, believe it is a big deal

speaker: Hey. Do you want to talk?
response: About what? Being betrayed by my friends? Spending three months at the North Pole for nothing? And I didn’t even get to go to Comic-Con!

speaker: Oh, hon… Uh… (singing) Soft kitty, warm kitty…
response: That’s for when I’m sick. Sad is not sick.

speaker: Oh. Sorry. I don’t know your sad song.
response: I don’t have a sad song. I’m not a child.

speaker: Well, you know, I do understand what you’re going through.
response: Really? Did you just have the Nobel Prize in waitressing stolen from you?

speaker: Well, no, but when I was a senior in high school, one of my friends heard I was going to be named head cheerleader. Oh, I was so excited. My mom even made me a celebration pie. Then they named stupid Valerie Mossbacher head cheerleader. Big ol’ slutbag.
response: Are you saying that you think a celebration pie is even remotely comparable to a Nobel Prize?

speaker: Well, they’re pretty tasty.
response: And on a different, but not unrelated topic, based on your current efforts to buoy my spirits, do you truly believe that you were ever fit to be a cheer leader?

speaker: Look, Sheldon, I just don’t think that the guys and Leonard really meant to hurt you. You know? They just told an unfortunate lie to deal with a difficult situation. Okay, you know what it’s like? Remember that scene in the new Star Trek movie when Kirk has to take over the ship, so he tells Spock all that stuff he knew wasn’t true, like saying Spock didn’t care his mom died?
response: I missed Comic-Con and the new Star Trek movie!

speaker: Sheldon, why are you sitting by yourself?
response: Because I am without friends. Like the proverbial cheese, I stand alone. Even while seated.

speaker: Come on. We said we were sorry.
response: It’s going to take more than I’m sorry and a store-bought apology pie from Penny to make up for what you’ve done to me.

speaker: Hey, Cooper. Wead your wetwaction e-mail. Way to destroy your weputation.
response: You see? People have been pointing and laughing at me all morning.

speaker: That’s not twue. People have been pointing and waughing at you your whole wife.
response: All right, I’ve had enough. Attention, everyone. I’ m Dr. Sheldon Cooper. As many of you in the physics department might know, my career trajectory has taken a minor detour.

speaker: Off a cwiff.
response: My credibility may have been damaged…

speaker: Compwetely wecked.
response: But I would like to remind you that in science, there’s no such thing as failure. There once was a man who referred to his prediction of a cosmological constant as the single biggest blunder of his career. That man’s name was, surprise, surprise, Albert Einstein.

speaker: Yeah, but wesearch into Dark Energy pwoved that Einstein’s cosmowogical constant was actually wight all along, so you’re still, surpwise, surpwise, a woser.
response: Oh, you think you’re so clever. Well, let me just tell you, while I do not currently have a scathing retort, you check your e-mail periodically for a doozy.

speaker: Here you go, Shelly.
response: Thanks, Mom.

speaker: Hold your horses, young man. Here in Texas, we pray before we eat.
response: Aw, Mom.

speaker: This is not California, land of the heathen. Gimme. By His hand we are all…
response: Fed.

speaker: Give us, Lord, our daily…
response: Bread.

speaker: Please know that we are truly…
response: Grateful.

speaker: For every cup and every…
response: Plateful.

speaker: Amen. Now, that wasn’t so hard, was it?
response: My objection was based on considerations other than difficulty.

speaker: Whatever. Jesus still loves you.
response: Thank you for carving a smiley face in my grilled cheese sandwich.

speaker: Oh, I know how to take care of my baby. His eyes came out a little thin, but you can just pretend he’s Chinese. So, do you want to talk about what happened with you and your little friends?
response: They’re not my friends.

speaker: All right. If you recall, when you were little, we sat right here at this very spot and we talked about some of the problems you had getting along with the neighbour kids.
response: That was different. They were threatened by my intelligence and too stupid to know that’s why they hated me.

speaker: Oh, good. I’ve been praying for you. Oh, Sheldon.
response: What are they doing here?

speaker: You watch your mouth, Shelly. Everyone’s entitled to their opinion.
response: Evolution isn’t an opinion, it’s fact.

speaker: And that is your opinion.
response: I forgive you. Let’s go home.

speaker: My new book, The Hidden Reality, takes on a grand question. Is our universe the only universe? You see, there’s a growing belief among scientists like me that ours may only be one among many universes populating a gigantic cosmos. In The Hidden Reality, I explore this possibility without presuming any knowledge of mathematics or physics on the part of the reader.
response: Hysterical.

speaker: I’m glad you talked me into this. We work so hard, sometimes, it’s nice to goof off and do something silly.
response: Agreed. Wait till you hear how he dumbs down Werner Heisenberg for the crowd. You may actually believe you’re in a comedy club.

speaker: You can think about Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle much like the special order menu that you find in certain Chinese restaurants, where you have dishes in column A and other dishes in column B, and if you order the first dish in column A, you can’t order the corresponding dish in column B. That’s sort of like the Uncertainly Principle.
response: Ba-dum-bump.

speaker: Say, I heard an interesting tidbit about Howard and Bernadette.
response: Really, Amy? Gossip? I’m disappointed in you.

speaker: Now, now. Evolutionary biologist Robin Dunbar has identified gossip as an aid to social bonding in large groups.
response: Forgive my language, but poppycock.

speaker: What if he’s right? And by not participating in gossip, society breaks down into small feral bands of tattooed motorcycle riders fighting to the death over the last few cans of tuna fish?
response: Fine. In the parlance of the urban music scene, what’s the 4-1-1?

speaker: Bernadette is thinking about breaking up with Howard.
response: I believe our nation’s tuna cans are safe. Excuse me. Dr. Greene, question?

speaker: Yes?
response: You’ve dedicated your life’s work to educating the general populace about complex scientific ideas.

speaker: Yes, in part.
response: Have you ever considered trying to do something useful? Perhaps, reading to the elderly?

speaker: Excuse me?
response: Yeah, but not your books. Something they might enjoy. I kid, of course. Big fan.

speaker: Nice sh*t.
response: Thank you. My father taught me archery as a child. It’s odd how the activity brings back the smell of Kmart bourbon.

speaker: Perfect.
response: I know. What an elf I would have made. Whoo, what do you think you’re doing?

speaker: sh**ting at a target?
response: With what?

speaker: An arrow.
response: Really? I didn’t see you draw one from your quiver.

speaker: I’m not going to do that, Sheldon.
response: Leonard, the people at Nintendo can only go so far in helping us recreate an actual athletic experience. We have to do our part, too. (Leonard mimes drawing an arrow and stabbing Sheldon with it.) That was uncalled for, but I’ll play along. Ow! I had an unusual experience with Amy last night.

speaker: Really? How could you tell?
response: She was attempting to engage me in gossip.

speaker: You don’t say?
response: Yes. I think prolonged exposure to Penny has turned her into a bit of a Gabby Gertie.

speaker: So, what’s the gossip?
response: Oh, please, I was just pointing it out. I have no desire to engage in the activity.

speaker: Fine, don’t tell me.
response: All right, get this. Bernadette is thinking about breaking up with Howard.

speaker: Oh. That’s too bad. I wonder what happened.
response: Mm, it’s hard to say. I can only speculate based on the data I collected watching my parents’ marriage implode. In that case, the woman dives into religion, while the man dives into a bottle-blonde bartender who tries to buy my love with action figures. Oop! Out of arrows.

speaker: Oh, yeah? What about it?
response: That’s all. I’ve just been thinking about it. Now, I’m thinking about fractal equations. Now I’m thinking about the origin of the phrase train of thought. Now I’m thinking about trains.

speaker: Lucky bastard.
response: Now I’m thinking about Jell-O.

speaker: I know. It’ll be awful.
response: Why are you smiling?

speaker: Uh, a smile means something different in my country. You know, tears of joy, smile of sadness. India’s a goofy place.
response: Oh, I’m back to trains. Woo-woo.

speaker: Did I tell you our lab got a grant to study addiction?
response: No.

speaker: Fascinating work. I recently trained a capuchin monkey to smoke cigarettes.
response: Have you learned anything?

speaker: Yes. He looks much cooler than the non-smoking monkeys. Although it’s not much of a contest. The other monkeys just sit around and masturbate.
response: If you don’t mind, I’d like to stop listening to you and start talking.

speaker: By all means.
response: Howard has announced his intention to propose marriage to Bernadette.

speaker: I don’t understand. The original piece of gossip indicated an impending breakup.
response: I know. The group consensus is that his proposal will be met with an humiliating, soul-crushing rejection. Everyone was set a-twitter. Although oddly, no one tweeted.

speaker: It’s not surprising that the story has captured the attention of our little circle of friends. Are you familiar with meme theory?
response: I’m familiar with everything, but go on.

speaker: Meme theory suggests that items of gossip are like living things that seek to reproduce using humans as their host.
response: I’m no stranger to memetic epidemiology. At Johnson Elementary School, the phrase Shelly Cooper’s a smelly pooper spread like wildfire.

speaker: I should think so. That’s gold.
response: Your meme hypothesis does intrigue me. How might we examine this more closely?

speaker: Do you have any ethical qualms regarding human experimentation?
response: It’s one of the few forms of interaction with people that I don’t find repellent.

speaker: We need to fabricate a tantalizing piece of gossip.
response: And a second non-tantalizing piece to use as a control.

speaker: Then we’ll track its progress through our social group and interpret the results through the competing academic prisms of memetic theory, algebraic gossip and epidemiology.
response: Look at you, getting me to engage in the social sciences. You’re a vixen, Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hey.

speaker: Hope you’re hungry.
response: Interesting. A friendly sentiment in this country, cruel taunt in the Sudan. It’s a lesson in context.

speaker: Will Amy be joining us for dinner?
response: Yes, I believe so.

speaker: Good, good. Everything okay between you two?
response: Yes. Why do you ask?

speaker: No reason. I was just talking to Raj, and he mentioned what a lovely glow she has these days.
response: Did he mean as if she’d been out in the sun, tending an herb garden without wearing a hat or sunblock?

speaker: No. That’s not what he meant.
response: Well, we may never know. As my mother would say, the Asians are an inscrutable folk. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have work to do.

speaker: Yeah, you do. You dog, you.
response: Did you get that?

speaker: Every word. Our false gossip meme appears to have reached node lambda.
response: This is moving faster than we thought.

speaker: Agreed. It appears the rate of gossip transmission is proportional to the number of nodes squared.
response: I must say, Amy, pretending to have intercourse with you is giving me a great deal of satisfaction.

speaker: Bernadette just asked about my sexual encounter with you. The meme has reached full penetration.
response: Pun intended?

speaker: No. Happy accident.
response: This is remarkable. Took less than 24 hours.

speaker: I should let you know that she asked for details about our dalliance.
response: Interesting. So it went beyond the mere fact of coitus to a blow by blow, as it were.

speaker: Pun intended?
response: I’m sorry. What pun?

speaker: Not important. I described your lovemaking as aloof, but effective.
response: I wish you hadn’t done that. That’s going to make me a chick magnet, and I’m so busy as it is.

speaker: I wonder what changed her mind.
response: Perhaps your talk of my sexual prowess renewed her faith in love.

speaker: No, I’m not jealous. All right, I’d k*ll a hobo if it’ll get me laid. Now, can we order?
response: Oh, dear Lord, they re-did the menu.

speaker: So what? It’s the same food.
response: Oh, is it? Look at this. General Tso’s Chicken is no longer listed under specialties. It’s now under chicken.

speaker: So?
response: Yes, General Tso.

speaker: Not Tso the chicken, so the question. So?
response: So, why is it no longer a specialty? Did the chef lose confidence in the dish or himself? And look over here, shrimp in mobster sauce. What is mobster sauce?

speaker: It’s obviously a typo.
response: Perhaps. Perhaps this restaurant’s now a front for organized crime. For all we know, the mobster sauce contains actual chunks of deceased mobsters.

speaker: You know what? Let’s just get a pizza.
response: Good idea. We’ll go to Corleone’s.

speaker: And why is that?
response: It was listed under seafood.

speaker: What if they were mobsters who slept with the fishes?
response: Leonard, are we having a serious conversation or not?

speaker: What the…?
response: The TV is gone.

speaker: So are our laptops.
response: Oh God, oh God, oh, God! It’s all right. They didn’t take my comic books.

speaker: We like games.
response: Right, games. They took Halo 1, Halo 2, Halo 3, Call of Duty 1, Call of Duty 2, Call of Duty 3, Rock Band, Rock Band 2, Final Fantasy 1 thru 9, The Legend of Zelda, The Legend of Zelda

speaker: Assorted video games.
response: When does the CSI team get here?

speaker: What?
response: In anticipation of their arrival, I’ve bagged some evidence. One of the thieves had the audacity to quench his thirst while ransacking our home. You should be able to pull some good prints off this. And now, here are my prints so you can rule me out as a suspect.

speaker: What about me?
response: I’m sorry, Leonard. It’s too early to discount the possibility of this being an inside job.

speaker: I’d be happy to put him under a 72-hour psychiatric hold.
response: I’m not crazy. My mother had me tested.

speaker: We’re done here. Call this number, and we’ll fax you a copy of the report so you can submit it to your insurance company.
response: I’m sorry, that’s the end of your inquiry?

speaker: Do you have any more information that might be relevant?
response: Oh, my goodness. Where do I begin? For instance, my laptop contained four out of the five gedanken experiments necessary for a cogent restatement of the quantum measurement problem.

speaker: How is that going to help them?
response: Well, they could monitor scientific publications and see if anyone posts such a cogent restatement in the next couple of months. If so, the authors are most likely in possession of my stolen laptop.

speaker: What are we supposed to do now?
response: The only thing we can do. Watch TV on our phones until the criminals return and bludgeon us to death in our sleep.

speaker: Does that mean you’ve ruled me out as a suspect?
response: Oh, how I wish I could.

speaker: I’m not scared. I would’ve gone all Nebraska on their asses.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.

speaker: Hand me the bat.
response: We just had a major crime in the building, and you open the door without asking who it is?

speaker: It won’t happen again, what’s up?
response: Nothing. Just wanted to see if you were both okay.

speaker: We’re fine, Sheldon.
response: All right, then. Good night.

speaker: Mm-hmm.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.

speaker: Who is it?
response: Sheldon. Sheldon Cooper.

speaker: Yes?
response: May I come in?

speaker: Yeah.
response: I see you’re drinking wine.

speaker: Yes, we are. And we’re about to go to bed.
response: Uh-huh.

speaker: Sheldon, do you want to sleep here tonight?
response: Oh, as small as Leonard is, I don’t think the two of you’d be comfortable on the couch.

speaker: What do you want?
response: It’s not what I want, it’s what evolution wants. Human beings are primates. Primates have evolved to live in groups, both for protection and support.

speaker: But you don’t like other people.
response: I do tonight. It’s scary over there.

speaker: Did we win? Can we go to bed?
response: Good Lord, I could not have made this easier. Hydrogen atom, H, plus pigs minus pea, Higgs. Bow, General Zod trapped in the Phantom Zone. Bow-zone. Pear. Tickle. Pear-tickle. Higgs Boson Particle. How could you not get that?

speaker: Look, Sheldon, sweetie, I know you’re feeling insecure, but we’ve really got to go to sleep.
response: All right. I’ll take the first watch and wake you at 0400.

speaker: Just gonna take a look around outside.
response: Bad idea.

speaker: No, Jim, don’t open the door!
response: Listen to her, Jim.

speaker: Don’t worry, there’s no one out here. (Sound of woman screaming. Sheldon nods, and turns off TV. Walks down to Leonard’s room.)
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny! (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny!

speaker: All right, we’ve got a titanium dead bolt and a reinforced jamb controlled by a state-of-the-art electronic access system.
response: What if they cut the power?

speaker: There’s a 200-watt uninterruptible backup power supply.
response: What if someone steals my keys?

speaker: There are independent voice and fingerprint scanners.
response: What if someone kidnaps me, forces me to record my voice, and then cuts off my thumb?

speaker: Sorry, let me help you.
response: Wonderful security system if we’re attacked by a school of tuna.

speaker: Don’t worry, the net’s going to be electrified. Picture her on the floor, spasming uncontrollably.
response: Better.

speaker: God, Sheldon. What the hell are you doing out there?
response: I heard a noise.

speaker: It was us. We knocked over a lamp.
response: Why would you knock over a lamp?

speaker: He doesn’t need to know what we were doing, Leonard.
response: Oh! No, she’s right, I don’t need to know what you were doing. Carry on. (Starts to climb back out of window)

speaker: What are you doing? Use the door.
response: Good thinking. Perhaps I’ll check the perimeter and make some warm milk.

speaker: Great, you do that.
response: Would you like me to bring you some warm milk?

speaker: I’m lactose intolerant.
response: And you don’t wish to alarm me with any more loud noises, very thoughtful. Warm milk, Penny?

speaker: No, thanks.
response: Fine. Good night to you, sir. Miss.

speaker: Sheldon, are you okay?
response: I’m fine. Although I’m no longer the master of my own bladder.

speaker: Don’t you think looking for a new city to live in is a bit of an overreaction?
response: Our apartment was broken into, our security system tried to k*ll me, and as a result, I’m leaving Pasadena forever. Tell me how that’s overreacting.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, you can’t move. Don’t you need to stay in one place so the mother ship can find you when it returns?
response: Oh, if that were only true. Unfortunately, as I’m earthbound for the foreseeable future, I need to find a location that’s more hospitable than the mean streets of Pasadena. Like Enid, Oklahoma. Low crime rate and high-speed Internet connectivity, but no model train shops. Sorry, Enid.

speaker: Oh, no, he’s going to telecommute. Everybody’s really excited about it.
response: All right. Boone, North Carolina. Every summer since 1952, Boone has hosted an outdoor amphitheater portrayal of the life and times of its namesake, Dan’l Boone. Sounds like something that would attract the wrong crowd. Penny, you’re from Nebraska, correct?

speaker: Any place specific or just the Bozeman, Montana Loony Bin?
response: I sense you’re making a joke, but Bozeman does have a comedy club called The Loony Bin, so do not forward my mail there.

speaker: Oh, come on. So you were the victim of a crime. That’s part of life. When my great-grandfather first came to this country, he put all his hopes and dreams into this little butcher shop he ran on the Lower East Side of New York. You know what happened? Every customer who walked into that butcher shop and asked for a pound of liver, got ripped off. But, those people moved on, and so should you.
response: I am moving on. I’m going to be a Bozite.

speaker: They call themselves Bozites?
response: They should. It’s one of the first things I plan to bring up upon arrival.

speaker: Sheldon, I can’t believe I’m saying this, but I’m going to miss you.
response: Please, Penny, as you know, I’m not comfortable with prolonged good-byes and maudlin displays of emotion, so I prepared a short video.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s so… (Turns to find he has gone.)
response: You might want to lock the door behind me. This isn’t Bozeman.

speaker: Help you with your bags, sir?
response: Thank you, fellow Bozite. And may I say, you are the living embodiment of all the promises made by our lovely town’s Chamber of Commerce. (Man picks up bags and starts running.) Wait! Wait! Excuse me! (At ticket desk) One ticket to Pasadena, California, please.

speaker: Hey, look who’s back!
response: Interesting. The acquaintance is the first to greet me.

speaker: Guys, you’re being childish.
response: Yeah, she’s right. You’re grown men, the kind who are perfectly capable of growing your own moo-staches.

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry.
response: You’ll get ‘em next time.

speaker: Oh, sure, I sit on the floor for years, no one cares. The pretty white girl’s there ten seconds, and suddenly we’re all running to IKEA.
response: No one is running anywhere. We’re not getting a dining room table.

speaker: Yeah, you guys never use that space up there. Why not get a table?
response: Do you want the long answer or the short answer?

speaker: Hey, how come we never get that option?
response: Chaos theory suggests that even in a deterministic system, if the equations describing its behaviour are non-linear, a tiny change in the initial conditions can lead to a cataclysmic and unpredictable result.

speaker: Hey, Penny and I are gonna go shop for a dining room table. You want to come with us?
response: You know, I’d love to, but, um, I’m too busy falling back in love with Windows 98.

speaker: Seriously? You haven’t used this desk in years. The second I want to get rid of it, you’re up here working?
response: I can’t talk right now, I have several thousand updates to install.

speaker: Are you really gonna sit here all day?
response: Think of me as Arthur Dent in Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, lying in front of the bulldozers to protect his home.

speaker: If you’ll recall, the Vogon fleet blew up the Earth anyway.
response: It’s a made-up story, Leonard, I don’t even know why you’re talking about it.

speaker: I’m putting all this stuff in storage. We don’t need any of it.
response: You, how can you say that? You show me one thing in here we can live without.

speaker: Oh, hang on. Check your in-box.
response: Wait. Is this really worth it? We’ve lived together for years with nary an argument.

speaker: Huh?
response: But we start talking about a table, and suddenly we’re at each other’s throats.

speaker: Nary an argument? Nary?
response: Well, that means not one, or not any. Maybe instead of a table, you should buy a dictionary. Well, I don’t know if I won that, but at least he’s upset.

speaker: Hey, all set. What do you think? There’s plenty of room for everybody, a view out the window.
response: My spot on the couch has a great view of a window. Sometimes I can see space battles through it. It’s called a TV.

speaker: Give it a chance, Sheldon, you might actually like it.
response: You’re absolutely right. Nope.

speaker: Well, you can’t say he didn’t give it a fair sh*t.
response: So, when can we get rid of it?

speaker: We’re not.
response: What about the roommate agreement? It specifically states that any changes in furnishing have to be approved by the Furnishing Committee. Which only sits on alternate years. Yeah, and by the way, it sits over there.

speaker: That.
response: Okay. I think we’ve found the problem here. It’s not the table at all. It’s you.

speaker: Well, it’s always me, take one for the team.
response: I have spent years turning this lump of clay into an acceptable conduit for my will, and then you came along and reshaped him, with your newfangled ideas and your fancy genitals.

speaker: Okay, I have not tried to change Leonard. That’s just what happens in relationships. Look how much Amy’s changed you.
response: That’s not true.

speaker: Oh, please. When I first met you, you were incapable of touching another human being. Now you’re holding hands, you’re going on dates, you even made out with her on a train.
response: She told you?

speaker: You’re too close to it, but Amy has had a huge impact on you.
response: You’re right. Without realizing it, I’ve allowed that woman to alter my personality.

speaker: Mm, Sheldon, you didn’t have a personality, you just had some shows you liked.
response: No. No, I’ve changed. Like the frog who’s put in a pot of water that’s heated so gradually he doesn’t realize he’s boiling to death.

speaker: Or you’re just a tall, annoying frog.
response: Excuse me. I have to break up with my girlfriend.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, wait.
response: No. You’ve opened my eyes to the truth. Amy has made me a more affectionate, open-minded person. And that stops now.

speaker: I’m not surprised you want to end the relationship. I’m a little surprised you didn’t get AppleCare. Anyway, enjoy your life. Where do I sign?
response: At the bottom. I must say, I’m relieved you’re not making more of a scene out of this.

speaker: Oh, I’ve already moved on. Besides, this breakup has nothing to do with me.
response: It doesn’t?

speaker: Of course not. This is just Leonard trying to take the focus off that dreadful table by sowing discord in our relationship. He’s manipulating you like he always does.
response: Wait, wait, now, hang on. You think he manipulates me?

speaker: All the time. And he knew that, as your girlfriend, I wasn’t gonna stand by and let him bring a table into your apartment. I mean, a table? Come on?
response: It is hideous.

speaker: Well, thankfully, I won’t have to see it, ’cause I won’t be your girlfriend anymore. Amy Farrah Fowler. Why, yes, I would like to take a survey.
response: Wait. You were really gonna stand by me against the dining room table?

speaker: Of course I was.
response: Wait. How do I know that you’re not manipulating me right now?

speaker: I think if I were manipulating you, you’d be smart enough to see it.
response: How do I know you’re not saying that as part of the manipulation?

speaker: I think you’d be smart enough to see that, too.
response: Okay. I’m sorry I gave you such a hard time, I just had to be sure.

speaker: Oh, hey. You guys didn’t break up.
response: No. Sorry to disappoint you, but Amy pointed out that you were only trying to manipulate me.

speaker: Which you also figured out by yourself.
response: Which I also figured out by myself.

speaker: Well, I’m glad you’re still together.
response: Yeah, okay, you can stop trying to make this about our relationship.

speaker: Which is stronger than ever.
response: Which is stronger than ever. This is about you trying to change my environment, which was perfect the way it was.

speaker: But it got the way it was through change. The-the-the spot that you love to sit in, that no one else can sit in, only exists because, despite your objections. I bought this couch. Me. So explain why that change was bad and this change was good.
response: Um.

speaker: You don’t need to explain yourself to him.
response: I don’t need to explain myself to you!

speaker: You’re sick of his nonsense and ready to move in with me.
response: Keep the table. We don’t use that space.

speaker: So why are you trying to ruin it?
response: No, thanks. We’re fine. I mean, if you people want to eat at the table, then that’s what you should do. I like eating down here because this is how we’ve always done things. But if those days are gone, they’re gone. It just makes me sad.

speaker: You mean tings like moo-stache?
response: Well, isn’t this nice. Sometimes the baby wins.

speaker: See, the liquid metal Terminators were created in the future by Skynet, and Skynet was developed by Miles Dyson, but that future no longer exists, due to Dyson’s death in Terminator 2.
response: Okay, then riddle me this. Assuming all the good Terminators were originally evil Terminators created by Skynet but then reprogrammed by the future John Connor, why would Skynet, an artificial computer intelligence, bother to create a petite hot 17 year-old k*ll robot?

speaker: Skynet is kinky? I don’t know.
response: Artificial intelligences do not have teen fetishes.

speaker: Alright, oh wait, they use it to in…
response: (Buzzing noise), too late, I win.

speaker: What the hell is that?
response: I don’t know, but if cats could sing, they’d hate it too. (The continue up the stairs and disappear from view).

speaker: Oh, I give up.
response: I don’t guess. As a scientist I reach conclusions based on observation and experimentation, although as I’m saying this it occurs to me you may have been employing a rhetorical device rendering my response moot.

speaker: Alright, remember when I auditioned for that workshop production of Rent, but I didn’t get it and I couldn’t figure out why?
response: I have a conclusion based on an observation.

speaker: It’s not a big deal, just a one night showcase, but they invite a lot of casting people and agents so, you never know.
response: I think I know.

speaker: Because…. uh, Friday, we are attending a symposium on molecular positronium.
response: I think that’s a week from Tuesday at six.

speaker: See you. (Penny exits singing)
response: You just lied to Penny.

speaker: Yes, I did.
response: And you did it so casually, no rapid breathing, no increase in perspiration.

speaker: So?
response: So, lack of a physiological response while lying is characteristic of a violent sociopath.

speaker: Sheldon, are you worried about your safety.
response: No, I imagine if you were going to k*ll me you’d have done it a long time ago.

speaker: What?
response: I need to speak to you.

speaker: It’s two o’clock in the morning
response: It’s important.

speaker: I highly doubt that. Go away. (Long pause). Are you still out there?
response: Yes.

speaker: What?
response: You’re right, it can wait until morning.

speaker: What, what, what, what, what?
response: Never mind. I clearly woke you up in the middle of a REM cycle, you’re in no state to talk.

speaker: Sheldon, what is it?
response: I’m uncomfortable having been included in your lie to Penny.

speaker: What was I supposed to say.
response: You could have told her the truth.

speaker: That would have hurt her feelings.
response: Is that a relevant factor?

speaker: Yes.
response: Then I suppose you could have agreed to go.

speaker: And what would I have said afterwards?
response: I would suggest something to the effect of, singing is neither an appropriate vocation nor avocation for you, and if you disagree, I’d recommend you have a CAT scan, to look for a tumour pressing on the cognitive processing centre of your brain.

speaker: I couldn’t say that, I would have to say, you were terrific and I can’t wait to hear you sing again.
response: Why?

speaker: It’s the social protocol, it’s what you do when you have a friend who’s proud of something they really suck at.
response: I was not aware of that.

speaker: Well now you are.
response: Oh, alright. Leonard.

speaker: Yes.
response: When we played chess earlier, you were terrific and I can’t wait to play you again. Goodnight.

speaker: Oooaw. This would be so much easier if I were a violent sociopath. (Opening door) What?
response: I was analysing our lie, and I believe we’re in danger of Penny seeing through the ruse.

speaker: How?
response: Simple. If she were to log on to www.socalphysicsgroup.org/activities/other, click on upcoming events, scroll down to seminars, download the pdf schedule, and look for the seminar on molecular positronium, well then, bippidy-boppidy-boo, our pants are metaphorically on fire.

speaker: Do you have any idea what time it is?
response: Of course I do. My watch is linked to the atomic clock in Boulder, Colorado. It’s accurate to one tenth of a second. But as I’m saying this it occurs to me that once again your question may have been rhetorical.

speaker: What do you want?
response: Remember how Leonard told you we couldn’t come to your performance because we were attending a symposium on molecular positronium?

speaker: I remember symposium.
response: Yes, well, he lied.

speaker: Wait, what?
response: He lied, and I’m feeling very uncomfortable about it.

speaker: Well imagine how I’m feeling.
response: Hungry? Tired? I’m sorry this really isn’t my strong suit.

speaker: You told her I lied, why would you tell her I lied?
response: To help you.

speaker: I’m sorry, I’m not seeing the help.
response: She was going to see through your lie eventually, so I told her that you were lying to protect me.

speaker: Oh, I’m getting a bad feeling.
response: Hunger? Indigestion, I’m sorry I’m really not very good at this. Anyway, Penny now believes that on Friday night, we’re going to participate in my cousin Leopold’s drug intervention.

speaker: Your cousin Leopold?
response: Yea, who most people call Leo, but he also answers to Lee, remember that, it’s important.

speaker: What’s important?
response: Details, Leonard, the success or failure of our deceitful enterprise turns on details.

speaker: Do you have a cousin Leopold.
response: No, I made him up. I think you’d call him Lee.

speaker: I don’t get it, I already told her a lie, why replace it with a different lie?
response: Well, first of all, your lie was laughably transparent, where mine is exquisitely convoluted. While you were sleeping I was weaving an un-unravelable web.

speaker: Un-unravelable?
response: Yes, if she googles Leopold Houston she’ll find a facebook page, an online blog depicting his descent into drug use, and a desperate yet hopeful listing on e-harmony.com.

speaker: Okay, why would I go to a drug intervention for your cousing.
response: Ah, because it’s in Long Beach, and I don’t drive.

speaker: We’re going to Long Beach?
response: No, of course not, there’s no cousin Leo, there’s no intervention, focus Leonard.

speaker: Oh, come on!
