response: We just leave the house on Friday night, and we return in the wee hours emotionally wrung out from the work of convincing Leo to go back into rehab.

speaker: So he goes back into rehab?
response: Yes, but, he can relapse if Penny ever invites us to go hear her sing again.

speaker: You still told her I lied.
response: For a noble purpose, to spare me the social embarrassment of having a drug-addled first cousin, which I’m assuming is embarrassing, yes?

speaker: I don’t know. How am I supposed to remember all of this.
response: That’s the best part, you don’t have to, see I told Penny that you would be embarrassed, if you knew that she found out that you had lied, so she’s agreed to operate as if the original lie was still in force.

speaker: So she’s expecting me to lie about going to a symposium in Pasadena, when in actuality we’re pretending to go to a drug intervention in Long Beach?
response: Un-unravelable.

speaker: Okay. So what’s up?
response: Well, uh, Penny is on her way to perform in a one night showcase production of Rent, which we are unable to attend because we are going to a symposium on molecular positronium, given by Dr Emile Farminfarmian.

speaker: Howard, wait. Sheldon, I think we should tell them.
response: Okay, sure. I don’t see a problem with that.

speaker: It’s okay, I do, look, Leonard is helping Sheldon through a family crisis, he made up the whole story about the symposium with Dr Farmin..farm…ian
response: Good for you.

speaker: Yeah, uh, break a leg.
response: Break a leg. (She leaves)

speaker: Oh, too bad. I’ve always wanted to go to Long Beach.
response: It’s a very nice community. The Queen Mary is docked there, once the largest ocean liner in the world, it’s now a hotel and restaurant where they host a surprisingly gripping m*rder mystery dinner.

speaker: g*n.
response: No, no, no, Leonard gets nauseous unless he sits in front, and even then it’s iffy.

speaker: Let it go, Sheldon, the m*rder was the first mate whether it makes sense to you or not.
response: No, that’s the least of our worries. I’ve been doing some research on addiction, both the biochemical and behavioural aspects, and I think there’s a problem with the current version of our lie.

speaker: What are you talking about, it’s fine, she bought it, it’s over.
response: Sadly, it’s not. Substance abuse is a lifelong struggle, but beyond that I have realised that the Leo I described would not have agreed to go to rehab.

speaker: Why not?
response: Because Leo is a middle child.

speaker: There is no Leo, how can you say that?
response: You didn’t read the bio, did you? He’s not just a middle child, he’s the quintessential middle child, from a broken home to boot. Psychologically speaking, the attention he gets by rebelling even to the point of self-destruction is more emotionally valuable than the help he would get at rehab.

speaker: I’ve got a solution.
response: Great, what is it?

speaker: Get out.
response: Fine. (He leaves. A moment later he comes back.) I’ve hesitated to point this out, but I must now remind you that we are in our current predicament because of your initial and totally inadequate deceit. I’m just trying to clean up after your mess. (Leonard throws a glass ornament at him. He just manages to shut the door in time.) We’ll talk in the morning.

speaker: Au contraire. I’m 26 years old, I’m originally from (reads off crib notes) Denton, Texas, but I was a Navy brat so I was brought up on a variety of military bases around the world, as a result I’ve often felt like an outsider, never really fitting in, which is probably the reason for my substance abuse problem.
response: Excuse me, we just went over this. As the quintessential middle child, your addiction is rooted in your unmet need for attention.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, are we really going to go with pop psychology.
response: For your information, this is all based on solid research, stick with the character profile I wrote for you.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: I’m sorry, Leonard, this is Toby Loobenfeld, he’s a research assistant in the particle physics lab, but he also minored in theatre at MIT.

speaker: Yeah, I got it, Sheldon, why?
response: Well, you see, while Leo would not have gone into rehab, it is completely plausible that we would have talked him into leaving the motel, and coming home with us.

speaker: Sheldon, how about this as my motivation. When I was fourteen years old I was abused in the Philippines by a club footed Navy chaplain.
response: No. We’re going with middle child, and a generic predisposition to inadequate serotonin production.

speaker: Swell, how do I play genetic predisposition?
response: Subtextually, of course. (There is a knock on the door.) Just have fun with it. (Opening door.) Morning Penny.

speaker: Hi. How did the intervention go.
response: Unfortunately, we weren’t able to convince him to go to rehab.

speaker: Well, based on what you told me, I’m not surprised.
response: But we did convince him to leave the motel. Come say hello. Leo, this is Penny, our friend and neighbour.

speaker: The Philippines. 1992. The Subic Bay Naval Station. A young boy on the cusp of manhood. His only companions mongrel dogs and malarial mosquitos. Desperate and alone he reached out to a man who promised to introduce him to a merciful, loving God, but who instead introduced him to a gin pickled tongue shoved down his adolescent throat. What choice did he have but to drink, sh**t and snort his pain away.
response: Don’t forget his genetic predisposition towards addiction.

speaker: That’s never been proven.
response: There have been studies.

speaker: Not double blind studies.
response: How could there be a double blind study, who would be the control group.

speaker: And that he loved the companionship and the wisdom that his own father failed to provide.
response: Your parents made the right decision.

speaker: How long is he going to stay here.
response: He’s a homeless drug addict, Leonard, where is he going to go? Boy, you have a lot to learn about lying.

speaker: Okay, it’s done. Look, guys, for the future, I don’t mind k*ll the big spiders, but you have to at least try with the little ones.
response: Penny, please, we’re facing a far more serious problem than stray arachnids.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s not that bad.
response: Not bad? It’s horrible. I mean, you hear stories about this sort of thing, but you never think it’ll happen to you.

speaker: Shh-shh-shh!
response: What?

speaker: No!
response: The horror!

speaker: Why would you just say something like that?
response: No, no, no, no, no, no, no…

speaker: Slowly, like putting a new fish in a t*nk. You don’t just drop it in, you let the bag sit in the water a while.
response: The horror!

speaker: Sheldon, I’m sure it’s going to be fine.
response: No, it’s not going to be fine, change is never fine. They say it is, but it’s not.

speaker: Okay, honey, did you even know the people that are moving out?
response: I never met them. That’s what made them perfect, there were no awkward hellos in the halls, there was no clickety-clacking of high heel shoes on hardwood floors, they may as well have been a family of cats just jumping around from drape to drape without that annoying ammonia urine smell.

speaker: Well, I’m sure the new people will be just as quiet.
response: You can’t know that. How can you possibly know that?

speaker: I’m sorry, that really is how it works.
response: You’re tricking me. You tell me the truth, what do we get?

speaker: You get to choose between a mountain bike or a PS3.
response: I knew it! PS3, definitely PS3, who would pick a mountain bike?

speaker: Hey, Penny, it’s Leonard. Good news, you can take your head out of the oven.
response: I guess I won’t be needing this.

speaker: Stay calm, we don’t know anything about them yet. What are you doing?
response: I’m checking for musical instruments. Does that sound like castanets to you?

speaker: The box says kitchen.
response: So? Do cocaine smugglers write cocaine on the box?

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: Yeah, it is.
response: If that concludes your faltering attempt to mate, hello.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello. On a scale of one to ten how light of foot would you describe yourself with one being not cat-like at all and ten being freakishly feline?

speaker: Freakishly feline?
response: Is that your answer or do you not understand the question? We’ll come back to that one.

speaker: Sheldon…
response: Hang on. Are you now or have you ever been a salsa, Irish folk or break-dancer?

speaker: You’re making her uncomfortable.
response: Oh, I’m sorry. Well, if it helps you feel any better you’re doing very well so far. Next question, are you fertile?

speaker: What?!
response: I’m trying to determine whether crying infants above my head are a possibility.

speaker: I have no immediate plans.
response: If that changes, let me know. And finally, area rugs, pro or con?

speaker: Pro?
response: Alicia?

speaker: Yes?
response: Welcome to the building.

speaker: I can see.
response: Alicia’s non-musical, childless and pro-rug. She’s still on probation, of course, but I like her.

speaker: Oh, yeah, I don’t usually dress like this. I’m going jogging.
response: You don’t jog.

speaker: I can start.
response: True, but the more likely explanation for your attire is that you’re out of clean clothes again.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: You’re welcome, Penny.

speaker: See ya. I’m dressed like a slob today, too.
response: Oh, mimicry. I enjoy mimicry. I’ve been working on Admiral Ackbar from Return of the Jedi. “It’s a trap.” You have to imagine me with a giant squid head. “It’s a trap. It’s a trap. It’s a trap.”

speaker: Hey.
response: Congratulations, I see you did your laundry.

speaker: Well, sort of.
response: How does one sort of…

speaker: I bought new clothes, okay? Is Leonard around?
response: He’s upstairs at Alicia’s.

speaker: Oh. all right, that’s cool, no biggie. He said he’d help me set up my printer, but I guess I can wait. What exactly is he doing up there?
response: In what I can only perceive as a tactical move to destroy me, he is with Wolowitz and Koothrappali setting up her stereo.

speaker: Oh, they’re all up there, huh? Hmm, typical.
response: It’s axiomatically atypical. Up until recently, they did not know Alicia, and had no encounters with her in a previous location. They never went upstairs to visit the former tenants, so your characterization of their behaviour as typical Is demonstrably fallacious.

speaker: Okay, now I see the giant squid head. (Leaves)
response: Oh, great! now, I have to start all over again. (Rubs out imaginary workings)

speaker: Well, they’re all still up there.
response: You think I can’t hear them? Listen to that. Stomp, stomp, stomp. That’s Wolowitz in his stacked heels that fool no one.

speaker: I don’t even know why I care. I don’t care. All right, I cared enough to memorize that stupid joke, but that’s all I care.
response: You know, Penny, there’s something that occurs in beehives you might find interesting. Occasionally, a new queen will arrive while the old queen is still in power. When this happens, the old queen must either locate to a new hive or engage in a battle to the death until only one queen remains.

speaker: What are you saying, that I’m threatened by Alicia? That I’m like the old queen of the hive and it’s just time for me to go?
response: I’m just talking about bees. They’re on the discovery channel. What are you talking about?

speaker: No, no occasion, just felt like getting some Chinese chow for my peeps.
response: Did you remember to ask for the chicken with broccoli to be diced, not shredded?

speaker: Yes.
response: Even though the menu description specifies shredded?

speaker: Yes.
response: Brown rice, not white?

speaker: Yes.
response: You stop at the Korean grocery and get the good hot mustard?

speaker: Yes.
response: Did you pick up the low-sodium soy sauce from the market?

speaker: Yes
response: Good. See how it’s done, Leonard?

speaker: …chinese food right here.
response: They’re gone, Penny. They can’t hear you.

speaker: I cannot believe they’re letting her just use them like that. I mean, anything she wants, they go panting after her like trained dogs. You know that just last week, she had Howard drive all the way to her uncle’s house in Orange County to pick up her TV?
response: You once had Leonard and me get your television from your ex-boyfriend.

speaker: Apples and oranges here, Sheldon. I’m telling you, that girl is a user, iceskating through the life on her looks, taking advantage of innocent weak-willed men, getting auditions for stupid network shows. It creams my corn.
response: May I interject something here?

speaker: Please.
response: You got the wrong mustard.

speaker: I like green lantern, I’m just saying it’s pretty lame that He can be defeated by the colour yellow.
response: Only the modern green lantern is vulnerable to yellow.

speaker: You’re right, this filly’s been broken.
response: You set it on DTS, didn’t you?

speaker: Well, dead whore on TV, live one in real life.
response: Oh, great now she’s jumping up and down on the bed.

speaker: No, it’s Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon. (Makes a hand movement with every syllable.)
response: Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon. (Copies hand movements.)

speaker: What’s this? (Repeats hand movements.)
response: That’s what you did. I assumed as in a number of languages that the gesture was part of the phrase.

speaker: Well it’s not.
response: How am I supposed to know that? As the teacher it’s your obligation to separate your personal idiosyncrasies from the subject matter.

speaker: You know, I’m really glad you decided to learn Mandarin.
response: Why?

speaker: Hey!
response: Mai du lui tsa.

speaker: You just called Leonard a syphilitic donkey.
response: My apologies Leonard, I’m only as good as my teacher.

speaker: Why are you learning Chinese?
response: I believe the Szechuan Palace has been passing off orange chicken as tangerine chicken and I intend to confront them.

speaker: Oh, I’ll tell you what’s going on, that stupid self-centred bastard wrote about our sex life in his blog. (Out of window) Drop dead, you stupid self-centred bastard! (To Leonard) Thank you. (exit)
response: Okay, where were we?

speaker: Okay, feel better, bye. (Goes back to apartment) She doesn’t want to talk.
response: Not surprising. Penny’s emotional responses originate from the primitive portion of the brain known as the Amygdala, while speech is centred in the much more recently developed Neocortex. The former can easily overpower the latter giving scientific credence to the notion of being rendered speechless. (Leonard stares at him.) Or maybe she just doesn’t want to talk.

speaker: I’m not going to do that, Howard.
response: I’m not aware of any social convention that requires you to intervene at all.

speaker: What about “damsel in distress?”
response: Twelfth century code of chivalry, not exactly current. You’d also have to be knighted for that to apply.

speaker: For God’s sake, Sheldon, if you don’t like the tangerine chicken, don’t order the tangerine chicken.
response: I like tangerine chicken, I’m not getting tangerine chicken.

speaker: Boy, that story gets better every time you hear it.
response: Actually, I thought the first two renditions were far more compelling. Previously I felt sympathy for the Leonard character, now I just find him to be whiny and annoying.

speaker: Just eat your tangerine chicken.
response: I’d love to, but I don’t have tangerine chicken.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Aieee ya! Xia si wo le.

speaker: I’m sorry. Look, do you have a second.
response: A second what? Pair of underwear?

speaker: I was just wondering if I could talk to you? It’s about Leonard.
response: Why me? Why not Koothrappali or Wolowitz?

speaker: Well, Raj can’t talk to me unless he’s drunk, and Wolowitz is, you know, disgusting.
response: Yes, I suppose he is.

speaker: All I’m saying is, you know Leonard the best.
response: Not necessarily. I’m often surprised by my lack of familiarity with Leonard. Just the other day I discovered, he not only has a loofah, he hides it. Why do you suppose a man would be ashamed of having a loofah? I myself prefer to have my excess epithelial cells slough off naturally, but I don’t condemn those who seek to accelerate the process. (Time shift) And until recently I had no idea that despite his lactose intolerance, he can tolerate small amounts of non-fat ice cream without producing a noxious gas that I maintain in the right concentration could be w*apon. (Begins to unlock apartment door.)

speaker: Leonard might come home, can we talk in my apartment.
response: We’re not done?

speaker: No.
response: Ach, why not? We’re already through the looking glass anyway.

speaker: Okay, so, here’s the thing. I guess you’re aware that Leonard asked me out.
response: Well, he didn’t actually say anything, but when he came back to the apartment he was doing a dance that brought to mind the happy hippos in Fantasia.

speaker: Oh, that’s nice. Anyhow, the thing I wanted to talk to you about is, you know, since Leonard and I have become friends, I was just… want to sit down?
response: Oh, I wish it were that simple. You see, I don’t spend much time here and so I’ve never really chosen a place to sit.

speaker: Well, choose.
response: There are a number of options and, I’m really not familiar enough with the cushion densities, air flow patterns and dispersion of sunlight to make an informed choice.

speaker: Alright, why don’t you just pick one at random, and then if you don’t like it you can sit somewhere else next time.
response: No, no, that’s crazy. You go ahead and talk while I figure it out.

speaker: Okay. Um, here’s the thing. So, I’ve known for a while now that Leonard has had a little crush on me…
response: A little crush? Well I suppose so, in the same way Menelaus had a little crush on Helen of Troy.

speaker: Alright, yeah, I don’t really know who they are…
response: Well Menelaus was the brother of Agamemnon…

speaker: Yeah, I don’t care, I don’t care. The point is Leonard isn’t the kind of guy I usually go out with.
response: Leonard isn’t the kind of guy anyone usually goes out with. Would you be open to rotating the couch clockwise thirty degrees?

speaker: No. What I’m saying is, Leonard might be different in a good way. Obviously my usual choices have not worked out so well.
response: The last one worked out well for Koothrappali. He got a free iPod. Oh, glare!

speaker: But on the other hand, if things don’t go well with Leonard, I risk losing a really good friend. I mean, I guess he’s not looking for a fling, he’s the kind of guy that gets into a relationship for, I don’t know, like you would say light years.
response: I would not say that. No-one would say that, a light year is a unit of distance, not time.

speaker: Thank you for the clarification.
response: Draft. You see people hear the word year and they think duration. Foot pound has the same problem, that’s a unit of work, not of weight.

speaker: Right, thanks.
response: It’s a common mistake.

speaker: Not the first one I’ve made today.
response: Okay. I think this will be my seat.

speaker: Sheldon, do you have anything to say that has anything to do with, you know, what I’m talking about.
response: Well, let’s see. We might consider Schrodinger’s Cat.

speaker: Schrodinger? Is that the woman in 2A?
response: No. That’s Mrs Grossinger. And she doesn’t have a cat, she has a Mexican hairless, annoying little animal, yip yip yip yip…

speaker: Sheldon!
response: Sorry, you diverted me. Anyway, in 1935, Erwin Schrodinger, in an attempt to explain the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics, he proposed an experiment where a cat is placed in a box with a sealed vial of poison that will break open at a random time. Now, since no-one knows when or if the poison has been released, until the box is opened, the cat can be thought of as both alive and dead.

speaker: I’m sorry, I don’t get the point.
response: Well of course you don’t get it, I haven’t made it yet. You’d have to be psychic to get it, and there’s no such thing as psychic.

speaker: Sheldon, what’s the point?
response: Just like Schrodinger’s Cat, your potential relationship with Leonard right now can be thought of as both good and bad. It is only by opening the box that you’ll find out which it is.

speaker: Okay, so you’re saying I should go out with Leonard.
response: No, no, no, no, no, no. Let me start again. In 1935, Erwin Schrodinger…

speaker: Two seats right there.
response: Chong sho sha pwe. (Caption translates to “Long Live Concrete”.) Xie xie. (Thank you)

speaker: Sheldon, I think I’ve made a mistake.
response: I can see that. Unless you’re planning on running a marathon, choosing both stuffing and mashed potatoes is a starch filled redundancy.

speaker: No, it’s about Penny.
response: A mistake involving Penny? Okay, you’ll have to narrow it down.

speaker: I don’t think I can go out with her tonight.
response: Then don’t.

speaker: Other people would say “why not?”
response: Other people might be interested.

speaker: I’m going to talk anyway.
response: I assumed you would.

speaker: Now that I’m actually about to go out with Penny, I’m not excited, I’m nauseous.
response: Ah, then your meal choice is appropriate. Starch absorbs fluid which reduces the amount of vomit available for violent expulsion.

speaker: Right.
response: You also made a common grammatical mistake, you said nauseous when you meant nauseated. But go on.

speaker: Sheldon, this date is probably my one chance with Penny, what happens if I blow it.
response: Well, if we accept your premise, and also accept the highly improbable assumption that Penny is the only woman in the world for you then we can logically conclude that the result of blowing it would be that you end up a lonely, bitter old man with no progeny. The image of any number of evil lighthouse keepers from Scooby Doo cartoons comes to mind.

speaker: You’re not helping.
response: Alright, what response on my part would bring this conversation to a speedy conclusion?

speaker: Tell me whether or not to go through with the date.
response: Schrodinger’s Cat.

speaker: Wow, that’s brilliant.
response: You sound surprised. Mmm, hou zi shui zai li du. (Your monkey sleeps inside me.)

speaker: Blow your own nose and go away.
response: This is not a tangerine bicycle.

speaker: Crazy man. Call the police.
response: No. Don’t call the library. Show me your mucus. (Leonard and Penny are seen entering, and then leaving again quickly.) Oxen are in my bed! Many, many oxen! Oy Vey!

speaker: It is. You just kind of put a damper on things when you said, the next person I see talking with food in their mouth will be put to death.
response: Well, we could argue about who said what all night long, but to set things back on course, I will propose a new topic of conversation.

speaker: Great.
response: What is the best number? By the way, there’s only one correct answer.

speaker: Five million, three hundred eighteen thousand and eight?
response: Wrong. The best number is 73. You’re probably wondering why.

speaker: We’re good.
response: 73 is the 21st prime number. Its mirror, 37, is the 12th, and its mirror, 21, is the product of multiplying, hang on to your hats, seven and three. Eh? Eh? Did I lie?

speaker: We get it. 73 is the Chuck Norris of numbers.
response: Chuck Norris wishes. In binary, 73 is a palindrome, one-zero-zero-one-zero-zero-one which backwards is one-zero-zero-one-zero-zero-one, exactly the same. All Chuck Norris backwards gets you is Sirron Kcuhc.

speaker: It’s too thin if I were making a foot-long brain sandwich at Quiznos. For examination under a two-photon microscope, it’s fine.
response: Well, you’re the expert. If the correct way to do it is the wrong way, then I yield.

speaker: Very well. If you die and donate your body to science, I promise to slice your brain like Canadian bacon.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have to take my temperature.
response: Are you monitoring your circadian rhythms in order to identify your periods of maximum mental acuity? I did that one summer. Ah, youth.

speaker: No, I experienced some distressing symptoms last night, so I’m checking my vital signs every hour.
response: I’d be happy to create a chart and participate in a differential diagnosis.

speaker: Oh, that sounds like fun.
response: All right. What were the symptoms?

speaker: Elevated heart rate, moist palms, dry mouth and localized vascular throbbing.
response: Localized to what region?

speaker: Ears and genitalia.
response: Interesting. Not body parts that usually team up. What about environmental factors? Describe the scene for me.

speaker: I was sitting in a restaurant with Penny and Bernadette, drinking water, carbonated as it was a special occasion. Penny’s friend Zack stopped by and said hello and I said hoo.
response: Who?

speaker: Zack.
response: Then why did you ask?

speaker: Ask what?
response: Who.

speaker: Zack.
response: All right, let’s start over. What did you say when Zack walked in?

speaker: Hoo.
response: Zack.

speaker: Why do you keep saying Zack?
response: Because you keep saying who.

speaker: I’m not saying hoo now. I said hoo last night.
response: And the answer was Zack, correct?

speaker: There was no question. I simply said hoo.
response: All right, I think I have enough to go on. Possible explanations for your symptoms are, in descending order of likelihood, hyperthyroidism, premature menopause, hosting an alien parasite or, and I only include it for the sake of covering absolutely all bases, sexual arousal.

speaker: My blood work shows thyroid function normal. Cortisol levels normal.
response: How about your follicle-stimulating hormone levels?

speaker: Sheldon, I am not going through menopause.
response: Are you sure? You said that with the testy bark of an old biddy.

speaker: I think we need to face the cold, hard truth, I was sexually aroused by Penny’s friend Zack.
response: Hang on. I don’t know that we’ve given the alien parasite hypothesis a fair shake.

speaker: Let’s look at this logically. I have a stomach, I get hungry. I have genitals, I have the potential for sexual arousal.
response: A cross we all must bear. You know, in difficult moments like this, I often turn to a force greater than myself.

speaker: Religion?
response: Star Trek. Did you see Star Trek

speaker: No.
response: Don’t. It’s terrible. However, in it, we learn that when Spock finds himself drawn off the path of logic by feelings bubbling up from his human half, he suppresses them using the Vulcan mental discipline of Kolinar.

speaker: Are you suggesting we live our lives guided by the philosophies found in cheap science fiction?
response: Cheap science fiction?

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Using Kolinar to suppress my anger at that last comment.

speaker: Is it possible that your concern for me at this moment is motivated by nothing more than simple jealousy?
response: I hadn’t considered that. Give me a moment. All right, I’ve considered it.

speaker: And?
response: I reject it.

speaker: You reject it because you don’t feel jealousy, or because you are suppressing jealousy?
response: I think I’ll eat my lunch at home.

speaker: That’s not your lunch, Sheldon, those are the cadaver brain specimens.
response: Oh. As they were incorrectly sliced, you can see how I could mistake them for my sashimi.

speaker: Hey. Isn’t tomorrow your usual laundry night?
response: The supermarket was out of my regular fabric softener. If this one under or over-softens, I’ll need time to make things right.

speaker: That’s thinking ahead.
response: The alternative would be to think backwards. And that’s just remembering.

speaker: So how’s Amy?
response: Amy’s changed. I might have to let her go.

speaker: Oh, no. Why?
response: I thought she was a highly evolved creature of pure intellect, like me. But recent events indicate that she may be a slave to her baser urges. Like you.

speaker: Just going to skip over that insult.
response: What insult?

speaker: Yeah. That’s why I’m going to skip over it. Are you saying that Amy is, oh, what’s the
response: Forget science. She’s horny.

speaker: Oh! Okay. Wow.
response: It’s simple biology. There’s nothing I can do about it.

speaker: Are you sure?
response: What are you suggesting?

speaker: I’m suggesting there might be something you could do about Amy’s urges?
response: It’s illegal to spay a human being.

speaker: Yeah. That’s not what I had in mind.
response: Oh. Oh! You mean something I could do.

speaker: Exactly.
response: Well, I was hoping to avoid this. But I might as well get it over with. Thank you, Penny. I’ll let you know what happens.

speaker: I’m sure it’ll wash off.
response: Little comfort tonight. I look like a Hell’s Angel.

speaker: There’s Zack.
response: Are you sure this is what you want to do?

speaker: It’s not what I want to do, it’s what I have to do.
response: Go, Amy Farrah Fowler. Follow your endocrine system.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon. You’re a good friend.
response: Please don’t drag this out. This is never going to come off.

speaker: As am I. (Holds Sheldon’s hand)
response: What are you doing?

speaker: Okay. If you can’t get me to stop eating your food, what makes you think you can get me to stop using your Wi-Fi?
response: I believe that you’re capable of great change. Like when I finally got you to stop saying Valentimes Day.

speaker: Sure.
response: In the year 2000, Pope John Paul II was named an honorary Harlem Globetrotter.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: You asked Penny if she wanted to hear something weird.

speaker: Yeah, because I have something weird to tell her.
response: Oh. I thought it was a game.

speaker: There’s this guy, Jimmy Speckerman, who used to torment me in high school. He sent me a message through Facebook. He’s in town and wants to have drinks.
response: Okay, Penny, if it were a game, here are your choices. An e-mail from an old acquaintance, or the head of one of the largest religious institutions in the world slam dunking to Sweet Georgia Brown. Pick.

speaker: Basketball Pope.
response: And that’s how it’s done.

speaker: I don’t know.
response: Is this the fellow who peed in your Hawaiian Punch?

speaker: No, that was a different guy.
response: Was he the one who wedgied you so hard, your testicle reascended, and you spent your whole Christmas break waiting for it to come back down?

speaker: No, that was a different, different guy.
response: Was he the one who used your head to open a nut?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, oh, oh. Was he the one who made you eat your arm hair?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: You know, the holidays are just around the corner. Maybe he wants to see if he can lodge the other testicle up there.

speaker: It’s two a.m. What are you doing up?
response: Nobel Prize acceptance ceremony streaming live from Stockholm.

speaker: Sure. You want to see what all the scientists are wearing this year.
response: Look at these men. They’ve managed to win the top science prize in the world with no more understanding of the quantum underpinnings of the expansion of the early universe than God gave a goose. You should pay attention, Leonard. Someday this could be you up there.

speaker: Thanks.
response: So, what’s got you up? Did you have a bad clam?

speaker: I didn’t have clams.
response: I don’t watch you 24 hours a day. I don’t know what you do.

speaker: It’s this Jimmy Speckerman thing. I can’t decide if I should agree to see him or not. Of course that might be because the last time I ran into him, he made me floss with my own shoelaces.
response: Wear loafers. Look at Dr. Saul Perlmutter up there, clutching that Nobel Prize. What’s the matter, Saul? You afraid someone’s going to steal it? Like you stole Einstein’s cosmological constant?

speaker: You know what? I am tired of living in fear of this guy. I’m gonna go see him and finally say all the things I should have said in high school. You know, pick on someone your own size, you did not have sex with my mother, and yes, I do know why I’m hitting myself.”
response: Oh, now Perlmutter’s shaking the King’s hand. Yeah, check for your watch, Gustaf. He might have lifted it.

speaker: Hi. Fellas. Hey, can I get a beer? Wow. Look at you. Little Leonard Hofstadter. I hear you’re a big-time scientist now.
response: And there’s the first zinger. Ouch.

speaker: Yeah, congratulations.
response: Congratulations? The Newcomb medal? Oh, please. That’s the scientific equivalent of a smiley face sticker on your homework.

speaker: From what I read, it sounded like a big deal.
response: Oh, good Lord, are we going to stand here and listen to him tear Leonard apart like this?

speaker: Hey, I won a Newcomb medal, too.
response: My point.

speaker: Okay, here it is. I have this great money-making idea. I just need a gear head to get it to the finish line.
response: Technically, Howard’s the gear head. Leonard’s just a dime store laser jockey.

speaker: Aw, come on, you can figure it out. You’re like the smartest guy I’ve ever known.
response: The smartest? All right, you know, I may not have a firm grasp on sarcasm, but even I know that was a doozy. Leonard, you can’t live in fear of this man forever.

speaker: Sheldon, I got this.
response: You clearly don’t. What my spineless friend lacks the courage to say is you’re a terrible person who took advantage of his tiny size, his uncoordinated nature and his congenital lack of masculinity.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Leonard, I platonically love you, man, but face it, you’re a mess.

speaker: I think what he’s trying to say is that maybe in high school you picked on me a little bit.
response: A little bit? The man Super Glued Hershey’s Kisses to your nipples.

speaker: What is that?
response: This is a list of your heinous acts against Leonard. One of which is certainly the cause of him wetting his bed well into his teens.

speaker: Nancy. You called me Nancy for three years.
response: You really need to work on your penmanship.

speaker: It wasn’t fun for me.
response: You’re being too kind, Leonard. You ruined him.

speaker: That was pretty badass, dude.
response: I help the weak. It’s yet another way I’m exactly like Batman.

speaker: Here’s your cocoa.
response: Oh, half and half instead of whole milk?

speaker: Yes.
response: Heated to precisely 183 degrees?

speaker: Yes.
response: Seven little marshmallows, no more no less?

speaker: You got one for good luck. (Knock on door) I’ll get it.
response: One for good luck. Must be the kind of math they do at Princeton.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: Sheldon, we can’t let him drive.
response: Then take away his keys and make him wander the streets with the other drunks.

speaker: Not really, no. It’s funny, huh, Leonard? Back in school, I was the winner and you were the loser. And now we’re reversed. You’re the winner.
response: You’d think a winner could make a decent cup of cocoa.

speaker: Yeah. It kind of rekindles your faith in the basic goodness of people.
response: You know what would be nice?

speaker: What’s that?
response: As a symbolic gesture to all the bullies who’ve tormented us for years, we open our home to Jimmy and once he’s asleep we k*ll him. I said it would be nice, I didn’t say we should do it.

speaker: Yeah.
response: In case it comes up again, this right here is an imposition.

speaker: What was I supposed to do? He needed a place to sleep it off.
response: You’re soft. This world’s going to chew you up and spit you out.

speaker: Morning, Jimmy.
response: Oh, there it is, tacos.

speaker: It’s good. You really know your way around a kitchen, Nancy.
response: I’m not going to say I told you so, but we could have k*ll him.

speaker: I might k*ll him right now.
response: The Dark Knight has your back. He’s scared, but he has your back.

speaker: No, you’re done. I want you out of my apartment right now.
response: Well said, Boy Wonder.

speaker: Or what?
response: Don’t answer that. It’s a trick question. I speak from experience.

speaker: Yeah, I feel pretty good about myself. You think we can outrun him?
response: I don’t need to outrun him, I just need to outrun you.

speaker: What are you grinding about?
response: Penny’s brain teaser this morning. She and Koothrappali emerge from your bedroom. She is dishevelled, and Raj is dressed only in a sheet. The sole clue, it’s not what it looks like.

speaker: Just let it go, Sheldon.
response: If I could, I would, but I can’t, so I shan’t. Now, knowing Penny, the obvious answer is, they engaged in coitus. But, since that’s what it looked like, we can rule that out. Let’s put on our thinking cap, shall we? (Mimes doing so) Raj is from India, a tropical country. Third World hygiene. Parasitic infections are common, such as pinworms. Mm-hmm. The procedure for diagnosing pinworms is to wait until the subject is asleep, and the worms crawl out of the rectum for air. (Leonard spits out food) Yes, just like that. Penny could have been inspecting Raj’s a**l region for parasites. Oh, boy. That’s a true blue friend.

speaker: They slept together, Sherlock.
response: No, you weren’t listening. She said, it’s not what it looks like.

speaker: She lied.
response: Oh. Well don’t I look silly sitting here wearing this?

speaker: Hey.
response: Hey. Leonard, is it awkward for you knowing that one of your dear friends had sexual intercourse with a woman you used to love in the very place you lay your head?

speaker: No, I’m fine with it.
response: That sounds like sarcasm, but I’m going to disregard it, because I have an agenda. Paintball. Specifically, the interdepartmental tournament this weekend. Now, in order to function better as a fighting unit, I thought we should establish a chain of command. Now, it goes without saying that I would outrank the three of you, but the question remains, by how much? Now, I don’t see me as some four-star general, back at HQ riding a desk and playing golf with the Secretary of Defence. But I also can’t be Sergeant Cooper, because that might lead you to think of me as just a regular Joe. This might take some thought. As you were.

speaker: What?
response: Gentlemen, if I may interject, I’ve decided my rank will be captain. If it’s good enough for Kirk, Crunch and Kangaroo, it’s good enough for me.

speaker: That could have been about anyone. Besides, you have nothing to worry about, because now I’m the dusky half of Koothrapenny.
response: For the record, I do have genitals. They’re functional and aesthetically pleasing.

speaker: Somewhere where no one’s seen me naked. We may have to drive awhile. (Opens door. Sees Leonard and Sheldon. Slams it shut again.)
response: Subtlety isn’t her strong suit, is it?

speaker: Do we really have to wear this camouflage crap to play paintball?
response: Who said that? Leonard, I can hear your voice, but I can’t see you.

speaker: I’m not in the mood, Sheldon.
response: Oh, there you are. Leonard, I know you’re upset about recent events, and I have someone here to help. (Showing laptop screen)

speaker: I don’t want to talk to Amy.
response: No, it’s not Amy.

speaker: You called my mother?
response: Oh, Leonard, is it really necessary to caption the obvious?

speaker: I don’t see anything.
response: Give it a second to load. Whenever you’re ready, AT&T! Okay, here we go. This is us here. To the south is Professor Loomis and the Geology Department. According to their Twitter feed, they’re out of sunblock, which means they’ll have to hug the tree line or risk melanoma. That’s our edge. All we have to do is move quickly over this ridge, the rock-worshipping pasty-faced bastards won’t know what hit them. All right, let’s move out.

speaker: Sure, whatever.
response: You can’t quit. That’s a court-martial offence. That’s punishable by… You can’t quit.

speaker: Sorry, Sheldon, it’s just not a good time for playing games.
response: This is a game to you? Uh, was the Battle of Antietam a game? Huh? Was the sack of Rome a game?

speaker: Yes, no and no.
response: Wait. I just want you all to know that I forgive you. This mutiny isn’t your fault, it’s mine. I haven’t earned these bars. Although what I lack in leadership, apparently I more than make up for in sewing.

speaker: Let it go, Sheldon. I’ll get you a Jamba Juice on the way home.
response: No. Jamba Juice is for heroes. And that’s what we’re going to be.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Following in the footsteps of Kirk, Crunch and Kangaroo. (Walks outside) Geology isn’t a real science! (Gets hit by countless paintball pellets)

speaker: Let’s get ‘em!
response: If there’s ever a Church of Sheldon, this will be when it started. Ow!

speaker: Here, here.
response: Excuse me. It’s Major Sheldon Cooper. With my last breath, I awarded myself a battlefield promotion. It’s kind of a big deal.

speaker: Shh! It’s my agent, it’s my agent. You’re kidding. Oh, my gosh. I can’t believe it! Really? Oh, I’m so excited, thank you, thank you so much. Okay, bye. I got the haemorrhoid commercial! I start Monday.
response: What about Nebraska?

speaker: Oh, hell with Nebraska. I’m gonna be a star!
response: Have you ever thought of teaching physics?

speaker: Only if you’re this jellyfish which periodically reverts to a mass of undifferentiated protoplasm.
response: If I could keep my Gmail account, I’d be okay with that.

speaker: In wieu of fwowers, the department chair is asking that evewyone donate a bottle of Febweze.
response: If we’re going to change the topic from jellyfish, I’d be okay with brine shrimp or the history of the unicycle.

speaker: And turned into a puddew of goo. Now, we can either sit awound and cwy over spilt pwofessor, or we can wejoice in the knowwedge that a tenured position has just opened up. I choose to do the watter.
response: Excuse me, the whole tenure system is ridiculous. A guaranteed job for life only encourages the faculty to become complacent. If we really want science to advance, people should have chips implanted in their skulls that explode when they say something stupid.

speaker: Well, I believe people do their best work when they feel safe and secure.
response: Pchew!

speaker: Yeah, me neither. It should be about the work. And if I can’t get tenure, I’d like to see you or Sheldon get it.
response: Raj, don’t dangle false hope in front of Leonard like that.

speaker: Excuse me, but I think I’m just as qualified as you are.
response: Pchew! Pchew! Pchew! Pchew!

speaker: Are Rajesh and Leonard competing for it as well?
response: Mm-hmm.

speaker: Do they know they don’t stand a chance ’cause you’re so great?
response: Well put. You know, I must say I go back and forth on this boyfriend-girlfriend thing, but those moments when you worship me really keep you in the running.

speaker: Or you take advantage of your newfound economic stability and move out, buy a house, get married. start a family.
response: Or, the chainsaw.

speaker: You know, if you really want tenure, maybe you should cozy up to the people making the decision.
response: Sheldon Cooper does not do cozy.

speaker: You don’t say.
response: But I suppose it wouldn’t hurt to know who’s on the committee. Let’s see. Oh, Janine Davis. Oh, dear.

speaker: Is that a problem?
response: Well…

speaker: I’m a what?
response: I’m not sure, it could go either way.

speaker: God, they’re everywhere. Come in. Dr. Cooper, how can I help you?
response: Yes, hello. I’m fine. Um, I understand you may have a bad impression of me, so I bought you a gift.

speaker: Uh, Dr. Cooper, that’s not necessary.
response: It’s too late. Get ready to like me.

speaker: Roots?
response: The tragic history of slavery in America. Fun for the whole family.

speaker: Why would you think this is an appropriate gift?
response: Um… Well… You are black, right?

speaker: This meeting has come to an end.
response: Because you want to start watching it right now. Copy that. Let’s see. Up next on the tenure committee is Professor Wu. Well, get ready for the complete works of Jackie Chan.

speaker: Probably not.
response: Barely knew him.

speaker: Well you better have a good excuse this time, because trimming Q-tips to fit your ears right is obvious nonsense.
response: First of all, when you say things like that, people think you’re crazy. Second, the reason I’m cancelling is because I have to attend a memorial service for Professor Tupperman.

speaker: It sounds like a long and tedious evening.
response: Eh, it will be. Honestly, if I must endure a long and tedious evening, I’d rather it be with you on date night. But I have no choice. The tenure committee’s going to be there.

speaker: Oh. Well, in that case, perhaps I should come along.
response: Well, now that I think about it, that would be most helpful.

speaker: Of course it would. I’m well-versed in academic politics, and as a respected scientist, I can only raise your stock as a candidate.
response: Actually, I meant you could drive me. But if it makes you happy, that other stuff, too.

speaker: Let’s go over our emotional responses one last time.
response: Okay.

speaker: Professor Tupperman is dead, and that makes us?
response: Sad.

speaker: The fact that there are so many people here tonight doesn’t make us cranky and claustrophobic. It makes us?
response: Glad.

speaker: Giving Mrs. Davis the box set of Roots was?
response: Bad. However…

speaker: No.
response: Fine. Bad.

speaker: Unbelievable. You have some nerve showing up here just to schmooze with the tenure committee.
response: You’re here.

speaker: Excuse me. I’m here to pay my respects to Professor Tupperware, or whatever his name is.
response: So am I. His passing makes me feel bad.

speaker: I’m here to support my man, just like you.
response: What are you going to do? Take people’s drink orders and get them wrong?

speaker: Do it.
response: What? Did she do it yet?

speaker: She plans on flirting with members of the tenure committee to further Leonard’s cause.
response: Well, that’s a fine how-do-you-do. Don’t just stand there. Take your breasts out.

speaker: You two should be ashamed of yourselves. Using women to advance your cause with sexuality, and whatever Amy plans on doing.
response: Are you implying that my girlfriend has no sexuality to exploit?

speaker: Yes.
response: Okay, because that was not clear.

speaker: Sheldon!
response: What? That was ambiguous.

speaker: Well, now it’s biguous. What are you gonna do about it?
response: Um…

speaker: You could talk some smack about his mother.
response: Well, yes, of course, he wouldn’t like that at all. Last night, I was feeling in need of sexual release when I happened to come across your mother.

speaker: Okay, okay. Guys, what are we doing here?
response: I don’t know what you’re doing, but I was about to insinuate that I had coitus with Raj’s mother for a dollar.

speaker: How about it, Sheldon?
response: What do you think I should do?

speaker: Well, you’ll always be an academic success, but I seriously question whether you’ll make any more friends.
response: I don’t want any more, but let’s go.

speaker: Yeah, screw it. I’m going in.
response: Wait. Hold on. I believe screw it, I’m going in is what I said to your mother last night. Don’t worry, I didn’t really say that. I find the concept of coitus ridiculous and off-putting.

speaker: What?
response: I just found out that you recommended myself, Dr. Hofstadter and Dr. Koothrappali to be on the short list for tenure.

speaker: Well, despite your quirks, the three of you are very accomplished in your respective fields.
response: I don’t know what you mean by quirks, but, um, I do want to express my gratitude.

speaker: You didn’t bring another gift, did you?
response: No, no. No, I learned my lesson. I understand that was inappropriate.

speaker: Good.
response: Anyway, thank you.

speaker: You’re welcome. (Sheldon attempts a jive handshake) I’m gonna pretend that didn’t happen.
response: Yeah, right on, sister.

speaker: And then they finish it off by staring into each other's eyes for four minutes.
response: Oh, that's nonsense. I proclaimed my love for you. And the last time I looked into your eyes was when you thought you had conjunctivitis.

speaker: Oh, careful. You're poking at the whole foundation of The Bachelor.
response: Yeah, but we don't have to debate this. We're scientists. We can conduct our own research. I propose that we imprison two street people and...

speaker: No.
response: You didn't even let me finish.

speaker: Forget it.
response: So, you can experiment on all the apes you want. But I want to manipulate the emotions of two captive human beings, suddenly I'm the monster.

speaker: Why don't you just do the test?
response: In the interest of science, I'd be willing to.

speaker: What? You're okay with an experiment where you have to answer awkward questions about your innermost feelings?
response: Yes.

speaker: That's what I said. Before I knew it, he pontificated his way right into my heart.
response: Uh, fun fact, pontificate comes from the Latin word pontifex, which means bridge builder or Pope.

speaker: In love yet?
response: Just out of curiosity, Penny, if this experiment does make us fall in love, would you drive me to Lake Geneva, Wisconsin for Gary Con? It's the only convention celebrating the life and work of Gary Gygax, the co-creator of Dungeons and Dragons.

speaker: You know what? I can honestly say if we fall in love, not only will I drive you there, I will buy you all the dragon T-shirts you want.
response: Okay, babe, let's do this.

speaker: The world's greatest mom is in the shoe compartment.
response: You ready to begin?

speaker: Yup. Be right there. I assume you don't want wine.
response: Correct. You're not supposed to drink alcohol when operating heavy machinery.

speaker: What heavy machinery? Let's just start.
response: Well, as a Texas gentleman, I'm inclined to say ladies first. Although, I'm concerned that level of politeness and charm might make you fall in love with me before the test even begins. Perhaps we should flip a coin. Or if you're familiar with the rules of Rock, Paper, Scissors...

speaker: Question one. "Given the choice of anyone in the world, whom would you want as a dinner guest?"
response: Hmm. Living or dead?

speaker: Just says "anyone in the world". I guess that means living.
response: Ah, that's just as well. As much as I'd love to meet Euclid, inventor of the geometric proof, he probably wore sandals and I cannot look at toes during dinner. Oh, I know, the person I'd most like to have dinner with is myself.

speaker: You sure that's your choice? 'Cause I've had that dinner.
response: Well, I haven't. And while they say never meet your heroes, I just don't see how I could disappoint. Who would you choose?

speaker: Robert Downey, Jr.
response: Oh, I didn't think of Iron Man. You know, maybe after myself and I have dinner, we can meet you two for dessert.

speaker: (short laugh) Oh, so kind of like what's happening with Penny right now.
response: "What would constitute a perfect day for you?"

speaker: Uh, well, I'd probably sleep in, do a little yoga, then lie on the beach while cute cabana boys brought me drinks and probably get a massage and then cap off the night with some dancing.
response: That's it?

speaker: Yeah, why?
response: You didn't mention Leonard.

speaker: He's there.
response: I don't think so. (stammers) Leonard can't stand yoga, the beach, massages or dancing.

speaker: Yeah, well, he brought a book, okay? What's yours?
response: Uh, I wake up. Uh, I enjoy some French toast with butter and syrup. Uh, then a wormhole opens, and whisks me millions of years into the future where my towering intellect is used to save the last remnants of mankind from a predatory alien race.

speaker: Interesting, you didn't mention Amy.
response: Who do you think made the French toast with butter and syrup?

speaker: I'm sorry. W, would 500 frequent-flyer miles help? That could get you to Sacramento.
response: "If you could wake up tomorrow having gained any one quality or ability, what would it be?"

speaker: Well, not to steal from the Bible, but turning water into wine sounds pretty good.
response: I don't think you're taking this seriously.

speaker: Come on, I'm just having some fun with you.
response: I believe what you're doing is using humour to avoid vulnerability.

speaker: Fine. Honestly, if I could have one quality, I wish I could be as smart as you guys.
response: Ha. Keep dreaming.

speaker: Well, I can't read people's minds. Actually, that's not true, I can read men's minds, but only 'cause it's usually the one thing.
response: When are we going to get robot eyes?

speaker: You're all alike.
response: Well, what I meant was I often misinterpret how others are feeling. Like, I can't always tell if someone is only joking or laughing at me. You know, like, uh, if they're mad at something I've done or just in a bad mood. It, it's incredibly stressful.

speaker: Really? You always seem so confident.
response: Well, I'm not. And if I could read people's minds, life would be so much simpler.

speaker: Well, now I wish I had the ability to make that stuff easier for you.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Wow, I just felt this wave of affection for you.
response: You sure it's not too much Bible juice?

speaker: "If you were to die this evening with no opportunity to communicate with anyone, what would you most regret not having told someone?"
response: So, it would be today? Huh. Well, I suppose there's something satisfying about dying on my birthday.

speaker: Today's your birthday?
response: Yes.

speaker: Well, that's always been a secret. Not even Amy knows.
response: Well, I don't enjoy presents. And the thought of people jumping out and yelling "surprise" fills me with more dread than the words "George Lucas Director's Cut."

speaker: So, why did you finally tell me?
response: The point of the experiment is to be completely honest with each other.

speaker: Well, thank you for sharing it with me. I won't tell anyone.
response: Thank you.

speaker: That is so funny. I never would have pegged you for a Pisces.
response: You're making it difficult to love you right now.

speaker: Oh, no. That thing's gonna end up in my bedroom.
response: That's it. We're done with the questions.

speaker: All that's left to do is stare into each other's eyes for four minutes without talking.
response: Okay. Wait, hang on. Bladder check. We're good to go.

speaker: You ready?
response: Yes.

speaker: And begin. This is kind of creepy.
response: We're not supposed to talk during this part.

speaker: Sorry.
response: This is kind of creepy.

speaker: Do you want to stop? I know you have trouble with eye contact.
response: Well, you have a brown fleck in your right iris that looks like a Formula One race car. So I'm just concentrating on that. Plus, it's easier around people that I'm comfortable with.

speaker: Aw, sweetie, I'm comfortable around you, too.
response: Of course you are, I'm warm and soothing. I'm like a human bowl of tomato soup.

speaker: I meant more like a little brother.
response: Oh. Well, I suppose I do think of you as a sister. And sometimes, a mother.

speaker: It's getting creepy again.
response: What?

speaker: Just thinking about the day I met you and Leonard.
response: It was a Monday afternoon. You joined us for Indian food.

speaker: Can you believe it's been eight years?
response: Yeah, and you're still eating our food.

speaker: I can't remember a time you guys weren't in my life.
response: I remember it perfectly. But I have an eidetic memory. If you're interested, I also remember how much you owe us for the food.

speaker: That's it. That wasn't so bad.
response: No, it wasn't. Uh, now let's tabulate the results of the experiment. I think it's safe to say that you're not in love with me and I'm not in love with you. And psychology has once again proved itself the doofus of the sciences.

speaker: Well, maybe. But I'm still glad we did it. I do feel closer to you.
response: And I, you. And yes, that's how you say that. Yeah, so, given our newfound intimacy, I'd say we have some hard choices to make.

speaker: Like what?
response: Gary Con, do we fly or drive? Do we wear costumes? And if so, who gets to be Gary?

speaker: I just want to make sure you get there safe.
response: Well, this is me. It's been a very interesting evening.

speaker: Surprise!
response: Aah! And after I let you be Gary.

speaker: Another? Great.
response: Changes in jet streams can affect the speed at which the Earth rotates on its axis, so bad weather can actually make the day longer.

speaker: Well, there must be a hell of a storm somewhere.
response: Joke if you must, but you’re going to miss these moments. With Leonard home in a few days, this was your last time driving me to the grocery store.

speaker: You know, I will miss this.
response: I’ll tell you what, if my apples are mealy, we’ll hit the produce section for one last crazy blowout. Heck, you can even push the cart. Please don’t take my looking forward to Leonard’s return as criticism of the job you’ve been doing in his absence.

speaker: I won’t.
response: That criticism will come later in your report card.

speaker: Oh, I just cannot believe you’re here.
response: Penny, it’s your lucky day. Three of the eggs are clearly not jumbo. Grab your keys.

speaker: Happy to, unless it’s hope or a reason to live.
response: Oh, you make me laugh, sad clown. Anyhoo, Leonard will be back in a couple days and I need a welcome home gift for him. As he’s been at sea, perhaps something with a nautical theme might be appropriate.

speaker: Okay, well, I don’t know how much you want to spend, but I do have this pretty cool Aquaman statue.
response: Aquaman? Oh, this isn’t a gag gift, Stuart.

speaker: Yeah, just as well. It’s a pretty rare piece. I’d rather just sell it to a real collector.
response: I’m a real collector. How rare is it?

speaker: Oh, I shouldn’t even have mentioned it. How about a Batman squirt g*n?
response: Don’t try and trick me into buying something I don’t want. Now let’s talk Aquaman.

speaker: Well, we’ve all seen your mom. That Butterball turkey was bound to come home to roost.
response: Twelve hundred dollars. That’s my final offer.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, you win. I’m sure Leonard is gonna love this.
response: Oh, right, a present for Leonard. You better throw in that squirt g*n.

speaker: Ooh, yeah, I don’t know. This squirt g*n, it’s, uh, it’s pretty rare.
response: Oh.

speaker: Oh. Okay. Well, here’s, um, thirty something cents and a promise I won’t call your boss and tell him you reek of marijuana.
response: Oh, Penny, I see you’ve ordered pizza. I have Chinese food.

speaker: That’s nice.
response: Oh, that’s a rather earthy cologne. My uncle used to wear that. Perhaps we can enjoy one last meal together before Leonard returns.

speaker: Yeah, thanks, but I kind of feel like eating alone tonight, so…
response: Are you sure? With your Italian pizza and my Chinese noodles, we could play Marco Polo. I mean, of course, a re-enactment of a meal in the life of Marco Polo the Venetian explorer, not Marco Polo the terrifying water sport.

speaker: Uh, yeah, it sounds fun, but no thanks. (Toilet flushes) Have a good night!
response: What, now, do you have company?

speaker: No. No, no, no. You know what? The toilet’s been doing that. I called the building manager, so…
response: Oh, I can take a look at it.

speaker: Well…
response: I’m quite familiar with plumbing. Not to brag, but I spent most of fifth grade with my head in a toilet.

speaker: Yeah, no, no, no. You know what, Sheldon, it’s okay. You don’t have to go into the bathroom.
response: That’s curious. If there’s no one here, why are there two glasses of wine on the table?

speaker: Oh. Well, you know, I, I’ve got two hands and a bit of a drinking problem.
response: Of course. Ask a silly question.

speaker: Oh.
response: That’s odd.

speaker: Um, what?
response: There are takeout containers in the trash can.

speaker: So? That’s my dinner from last night.
response: What’s odd is they’re in the trash can.

speaker: Okay. Look, honey, I promise there’s no one’s here. I‘ve had a long day. I just want to have a quiet dinner by myself.
response: Oh, very well. I’m no stranger to enjoying the pleasures of solitude. Oh!

speaker: What?
response: Have you gotten Leonard a welcome-home gift yet?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, great. Do you want to go halfsies on a two hundred dollar squirt g*n?

speaker: Oh, and here’s a fun thing. I worked it out so that there are two different words for spoon, planko and janko. Planko is a spoon with food, janko is a spoon without food. Janko is spelled with a silent ptang. Sheldon, you’re not even listening to the rules of my made-up language.
response: Yes, I am.

speaker: Then what does tweepadock mean?
response: Uh, elephant?

speaker: Lucky guess.
response: I’m sorry. I’m just distracted by something that happened over at Penny’s.

speaker: What happened?
response: I fear Penny is being unfaithful to Leonard.

speaker: What?
response: She claimed to be alone when there was obviously someone else in her apartment. I have no choice but to assume the worst, given Leonard’s lengthy sea voyage and her famously ravenous nether regions.

speaker: I don’t think Penny would cheat on Leonard.
response: Oh, really? She and I once had a staring contest. She clapped really loud and made me blink. It’s a small leap from there to sexual infidelity.

speaker: You’re being ridiculous.
response: Amy, there were Chinese food containers in the trash can.

speaker: Do you hear anything?
response: I hear a woman’s voice.

speaker: Is it Penny?
response: No, it’s you. All right, I hear whispering and giggling. Now I think I hear kissing.

speaker: Yeah, like you know what kissing sounds like.
response: There’s kissing in Star Trek, smarty-pants.

speaker: Let me listen. Sounds like Leonard.
response: Please. Why would Leonard come home early and waste his time kissing Penny when he could be hanging out with his best buddy? Yeah, that’s it. I’m catching her in the act. (Unlocks door)

speaker: No, Sheldon, don’t.
response: Aha.

speaker: What the hell?
response: Leonard?

speaker: Sheldon, you cannot just barge in here like that.
response: Right. (Goes out.) (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock)Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. Are you going to answer the door or should I open it and say aha again?

speaker: I’m sorry, Sheldon. I should’ve told you I was back. I just wanted to have a couple days alone with Penny.
response: Oh, no, I should apologize. Uh, I never realized to what extent our friendship was a burden to you.

speaker: That is not fair. I complain about what a burden it is at least once a month.
response: Oh, no, no, let’s not sugarcoat this. You find me finicky, pedantic and annoying.

speaker: I actually have used those exact words before. In that order.
response: Well, Leonard, I think it’s high time you and I address the tweepadock in the room.

speaker: The what?
response: Amy?

speaker: Please leave me out of this.
response: Fine. Leonard, there’s no need for you to pretend to like me anymore.

speaker: Come on, I said I was sorry.
response: No, no, you save your apologies for after you’ve had disappointing coitus with Penny.

speaker: Come on, this is silly. Hey, um, I brought you back a little present from my trip, huh? It’s that sailor cap that you wanted. It’s neat, huh?
response: You honestly think you can buy back my friendship with a cheap souvenir?

speaker: Ooh, now we’re talking.
response: Excuse me. This changes nothing. Except the Halloween costume I’m wearing this year. Amy, you’re going to be Olive Oyl. Lay off the doughnuts.

speaker: Good morning.
response: Hello.

speaker: So am I driving you to work or are you still mad at me?
response: I’d like a ride. Assuming you actually do take me to work.

speaker: Where do you think I would take you?
response: Who knows? Uh, you said you’d be home yesterday, but you came home three days ago. You say you’re taking me to work, but for all I know, I’ll end up in a deserted amusement park. Or a cornfield maze. Or a back alley dog fight. You tell me.

speaker: I’m going to work. You can come if you want.
response: Okay. By the way, you have something on your shirt.

speaker: No, I don’t.
response: Hurts, doesn’t it? You know, I find myself wondering if anything you’ve ever told me is true.

speaker: I didn’t make it back. The ship sank, I’m in hell.
response: You say you’re from New Jersey, but how can I believe you?

speaker: Why would anyone claim to be from New Jersey if they weren’t?
response: All right, I’ll give you that one.

speaker: Hey, I said I was sorry. What else do you want from me?
response: I want you to admit that what you did was wrong.

speaker: Fine. What I did was wrong.
response: I wish I could believe you.

speaker: You know what? I’m not driving you to work, because you’re incredibly annoying.
response: You say one thing and do the other, so then you are driving me and you find me a delight.

speaker: Stop it.
response: Keep it up?

speaker: Bye.
response: Hello. So I guess you’re really holding up the other four fingers?

speaker: I don’t know what succubus is, but it has suck in it, so that can’t be good.
response: Thought I heard you out here.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: You don’t get a hey. You get a hmm.

speaker: Come on, don’t be like that. We had so much fun together the last couple of months.
response: You’re right. Which makes your betrayal all the more devastating.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: I let you buy feminine hygiene products with my supermarket club card. You have any idea the kind of coupons I’m going to get in the mail now?

speaker: Sheldon, your fight’s with Leonard. Penny’s got nothing to do…
response: Careful, Amy. The friend of my enemy’s girlfriend is my enemy.

speaker: Really?
response: Yes. You’re either with me or against me.

speaker: You want to take the bus to work?
response: Maybe there’s a third option.

speaker: That’s so great. If you guys prove the existence of Unruh radiation… Hey, hey, hey, hey. My eyes are up here.
response: Howard, Raj. Judas.

speaker: You know what? You’re a crazy person.
response: A crazy person with a long memory, and if all goes according to plan, a robot army.

speaker: Stop it.
response: Or a mutant army. It depends on how my Kickstarter goes.

speaker: Okay.
response: I suppose so.

speaker: I’m so glad you guys are friends again.
response: And I’m glad you and I are friends again, too.

speaker: Aw.
response: Which reminds me. This came in the mail, and I want you to have it.

speaker: Fifty cents off Vagisil.
response: Think of me when you apply it.

speaker: Uh, can I just say, I’ve missed all of us hanging out together.
response: Yeah.

speaker: This is Science Friday. I’m Ira Flatow. My guest today is responsible for the discovery of the first stable super-heavy element. Welcome, Dr. Sheldon Cooper.
response: Thank you. Uh, the university made me come here. I didn’t want to. Uh, big fan of the show.

speaker: So, I understand that you actually discovered this element by mistake.
response: Yes.

speaker: And some people in the science community are calling it The Wonder Blunder.
response: Who? Give me their names. I bet it’s Wolowitz.

speaker: It’s just such a fascinating story. Your calculations are way off, but they find the element anyway. It’s like misreading a treasure map and still finding the treasure.
response: Can we talk about something else? Do you know that I yodel?

speaker: That’s interesting, but this could be taking you down the path toward a Nobel Prize. And in chemistry, no less. And wouldn’t that be unusual? Because you’re a physicist.
response: Yes, yes, I’d be a physicist with a Nobel in chemistry. Everyone laugh at the circus freak. You know, I don’t need to sit here and take this, Flatow. It is because of bullies like you, every day more and more Americans are making the switch to television.

speaker: I know you don’t like it, but every time you do an interview, it raises the profile of the university. That translates to funding.
response: Yeah, well, I’m not just some trained monkey dancing for coins.

speaker: How can you not be happy? You’re tall, thin and famous. Oh, my God, I’m jealous of Sheldon.
response: Look, you’re gonna be doing this stuff for a while. You’re just gonna have to find a way to get used to it.

speaker: Sheldon, can I come in?
response: Do you have cookies?

speaker: No.
response: Good. I don’t deserve cookies. Come in. Wil?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon. It’s been a while.
response: Why are you here?

speaker: Amy said you were having a rough time, and I thought maybe we could talk. Is that okay?
response: Certainly. Although, right now, I’m having a rough time because there’s three people in my room, and it’s starting to feel like a discotheque.

speaker: Yeah, I know a little something about that.
response: Oh, nonsense, Wil. Your endless tweets are not that bad.

speaker: I remember why it’s been a while. Sheldon, I was actually talking about when I was a kid on Star Trek.
response: How could you not like getting attention for playing Wesley Crusher? You were wonderful. A know-it-all boy genius with an eidetic memory. Who couldn’t relate to that?

speaker: Well, not everybody felt that way. A lot of people really hated the character, and some of them hated me because of it. I would do interviews, and people would be mean to me.
response: That just happened to me. Next time you’re stuck for a tweet, feel free to say what a jerk Ira Flatow is.

speaker: I’m just saying that there was a time when I thought I would never get out of Wesley Crusher’s shadow. But now, it’s just one small part of a pretty great life, and it’s a part that I’m happy is there.
response: I do see what you’re saying. That helps.

speaker: Good.
response: Would you two like to stay and play trains with me?

speaker: Okay.
response: Oh, great, now, I work the controls, I say all aboard. You sit quietly and watch.

speaker: Can I blow the whistle?
response: You should probably go.

speaker: Hey, you’re in a good mood.
response: I’m in a great mood.

speaker: Well, you’re about to be in an even better one. I didn’t want to say anything until I knew for sure, but, I’ve been re-running the tests on your element in my lab and I disproved it. Your element does not exist.
response: Yeah, but what about the Chinese research team? They found it.

speaker: Yeah, it turns out someone added simulated signals to the data files. They faked the results.
response: Really?

speaker: Yes. Do you know what that means? That means all of this attention that you hate goes away.
response: So no more interviews?

speaker: No, it’s all over.
response: I can’t believe it.

speaker: Well, you’re welcome.
response: You robbed me of my greatest achievement.

speaker: What?
response: I’m back down to nine friends. Make it eight, I’m sick of Wolowitz, too.

speaker: I, I don’t understand. All you’ve done since you discovered this stupid element was complain. I was trying to make you happy.
response: By taking away my only claim to fame? Well, if you wanted to make me happy, you could have told me a joke. Or shown me a cute video of a koala and an otter becoming unlikely friends.

speaker: Oh, there is no winning with you. And koalas and otters don’t even live near each other.
response: That’s what makes their friendship unlikely,

speaker: Hey, what’s with all the yelling?
response: Leonard disproved my element. Now all the attention is going to go away.

speaker: Oh, that’s great. You must be thrilled,
response: That’s it, I’m down to seven friends.

speaker: He’s counting hobbits and superheroes, right?
response: When I thought the element was real, I didn’t want it. But now that Leonard made it not exist, I want it more than anything in the world.

speaker: The, the element never existed. I didn’t take it away, science took it away. Be mad at science.
response: Don’t you dare use science against me. Science is my best friend. Oh, good, I’m back up to eight.

speaker: Actually, I get what he’s saying.
response: Oh, yes, nine. Welcome back, buddy.

speaker: It’s like if you’re dating someone you’re not that into, and then they break up with you and then you want them more than ever.
response: I have no idea what she’s talking about, but we’re ganging up on you so I agree.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, what do you want me to do, hide the information? If I don’t publish it, it’s just a matter of time before someone else does.
response: No, no, of course you have to publish. That’s your responsibility as a scientist. Doing otherwise would be unethical. You have no choice.

speaker: Fine, I’ll publish.
response: Can you believe this guy?

speaker: Hey. I just wanted to let you know that I, I posted my findings.
response: I saw. And I just posted a retraction of my paper. Now the whole scientific community knows I was wrong.

speaker: These things happen all the time, Sheldon.
response: Not to me. The only other retraction I ever had to issue was when I was seven and I conceded that my brother was the greatest ninja in East Texas. But that was just a ploy to get my face out of his armpit.

speaker: Okay, Barry, that’s enough.
response: No, no, no, that’s okay. I can fight my own battles. Isn’t that right, Bawwy.

speaker: Is? Is that a wefewence to my speech impediment? That’s pwetty hurtful. I, I can’t contwol it.
response: You’re right, That was uncalled for. I take it back.

speaker: Bark once if you need me to call PETA.
response: What’s that animal doing in our apartment?

speaker: Oh, relax, she’s in her crate. She can’t get out.
response: I have two words for you, Jurassic Park. This day just keeps getting worse and worse.

speaker: You know, if it makes you feel any better…
response: It probably won’t.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s a beautiful night. Why don’t you and I go for a nice walk together?
response: Oh, everything is just sex with you isn’t it?

speaker: Thanks.
response: Thank you. Ira, if I may, I’d like to apologize for my behaviour last week.

speaker: It’s all right.
response: Now, isn’t there something you’d like to say to me?

speaker: Well…
response: I believe I can answer that.

speaker: He asked me.
response: Fine.

speaker: As I was saying…
response: You’re telling it wrong. Ira, to really understand the story here, you have to start at the very beginning. A small town in East Texas, where a young genius named…

speaker: Sheldon.
response: That’s right, Sheldon Cooper. He was bitten by his neighbour’s dog, leading to his first scientific breakthrough, the doggie death-ray. Which, sadly, he couldn’t build because Santa wouldn’t bring him enriched uranium.

speaker: You know, I’d really like to hear it from Dr. Hofstadter, if it’s okay with you.
response: What a surprise. Did you invite me back just so you could ignore me?

speaker: Sheldon, this interview is supposed to be about me.
response: Well, that seems like a snooze. Even for public radio.

speaker: A little early for alcohol, isn’t it?
response: You know, I don’t just say smart things about science. I also yodel. (Does)

speaker: I'm heckling you. It's a beloved part of baseball.
response: He's right. And given that you're probably still waiting to be picked for a game that was played in fifth grade, I'm sure you do suck.

speaker: That's so cool. Congratulations. I guess that makes you the athlete of the group.
response: Well, not just him. May I remind you that you're talking to the seeker, b*at, chaser and water boy of the third place Griffith Park Quidditch team.

speaker: Now you know why we're not outside.
response: Did you enjoy my lecture?

speaker: No, and neither did our waiter.
response: Well, if you're going to serve Cornish game hen, you should either be familiar with the history of Cornwall or be prepared to learn it.

speaker: Hey, how was dinner?
response: Good, I had Cornish game hen.

speaker: You guys are going out two nights in a row?
response: I missed a number of date nights while I was on my train trip, and I'm contractually obligated to make them up under the terms of the Relationship Agreement.

speaker: It's better than hot, it's binding.
response: If you're free tomorrow night, I'd love to have you join us on a double date.

speaker: You are aware that a double date doesn't count as two dates.
response: Oh. Well, then come or don't. I don't care.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm surprised you'd choose to go to a pub.
response: At our committee meeting, Amy made a motion for a picnic in a park, but I tacked so many amendments on that thing it sank like a lead balloon.

speaker: I then suggested a pub.
response: Yeah, which I was initially sceptical of until I saw online that they serve Yorkshire pudding.

speaker: You don't even like Yorkshire pudding.
response: No, it's yucky, but informing people about the history of Yorkshire is yummy, yum-yum.

speaker: Nice to see a busy couple keep the spark of bureaucracy alive.
response: Ignore them, Amy. They're just jealous because they'll never have a relationship as good as ours.

speaker: Isn't this when he says bazooka or something?
response: I wasn't making a joke, I was merely stating fact. Amy and I have a superior relationship to yours.

speaker: You don't honestly think that, do you?
response: Leonard, I assumed you knew. The ranking of relationships in our circle by quality is me and Amy, Howard and Bernadette, Raj and his girlfriend, Penny and Chardonnay, Penny and you.

speaker: Okay, I got to, I, I, I, I got to ask. What makes you think that your relationship is so wonderful and ours isn't?
response: For starters, we enjoy spending time together.

speaker: So do we. And I've seen you guys ignore each other for hours doing totally different things.
response: It's called parallel play.

speaker: Yeah, toddlers do that.
response: Not as well as we do.

speaker: So what? Why do you even care?
response: Oh, listen to them. Not even married and the honeymoon's over.

speaker: Whatever. You can't even go on a date without checking your relationship agreement.
response: If you've got a problem basing a relationship on a contract, I'd like to tell you about 13 plucky colonies that entered a relationship agreement called the U.S. Constitution. And it may not be cool to say so, but I think that love affair is still pretty hot today.

speaker: Uh, we're not sure. But I want to wait long enough to prove to my mother I'm not pregnant.
response: May I have one of your fries?

speaker: Of course. Can I have a bite of your burger?
response: Absolutely not.

speaker: Some perfect couple. He won't even share his food with her.
response: It has avocado on it. She's allergic to avocado. Are you so jealous of our relationship you want Amy to die?

speaker: I'm not jealous. I just think it's silly for you to compare relationships like they're something that can be quantified.
response: Everything is quantifiable. That French fry? A seven. Spider-Man? A nine. The number nine? Oddly, only a four.

speaker: Sheldon, you're just assigning random numbers to things based on your opinion.
response: No, I'm not. French fries have three variables, crispiness, saltiness and shape. Which is why a curly fry only gets a two. If I wanted curls for dinner, I'd order a clown wig.
