speaker: Well, a relationship is more complicated than a French fry.
response: Not according to the work of Berscheid, Snyder and Omoto.

speaker: They developed the Relationship Closeness Inventory, which predicts the stability of a couple based on behaviour.
response: Yeah, not to be confused with the French Fry Goodness Inventory. That's pure Cooper.

speaker: So, this is accurate?
response: It's been around for 25 years, and has been extensively corroborated by other researchers.

speaker: Well, kind of takes the romance out of relationships.
response: Kind of? It does it perfectly.

speaker: No, we're sorry. We never should have been comparing relationships in the first place.
response: Why? We won. You know, I say, next, we take on Koothrappali and his dog. Really give ourselves a challenge.

speaker: I just want to say one more thing about this. Just because Penny and I are very different people does not mean that we're a bad couple.
response: The answer is one simple test away. Hmm? You know, it's like when I thought there was a possum in my closet. Did I sit around wondering? No, I sent Leonard in with a pointy stick and a bag.

speaker: Because it doesn't matter. I don't care if we're a ten or a two.
response: Or a one. A one is possible.

speaker: It would make me so happy if you said things like that.
response: We got an eight-point-two. Trust me, you're happy.

speaker: This is fun, huh? We get to see our friend throw out the first pitch, have a hot dog, watch the game.
response: Whoa. Nobody said anything about watching the game.

speaker: Sheldon, what did you expect?
response: I expected to see Howard throw the baseball, finish my hot dog, and hightail it across the street to Disneyland just in time for Mickey's Soundsational Parade.

speaker: I'll tell you what. If we stay, I'll buy you cotton candy and a bobblehead.
response: Who's the bobblehead of?

speaker: Does it matter?
response: No, as long as it bobbles.

speaker: 'Cause I'm an idiot who didn't think this through.
response: Okay, new plan. We go to Disneyland, play hide and seek on Tom Sawyer's Island, and then come back and see the end of the pitch.

speaker: You suck, Wolowitz!
response: He makes a valid point.

speaker: Thanks. And, Sheldon, I know tonight’s the night you eat Thai food, so I went to the Asian market, got all the ingredients and made it from scratch.
response: Oh, you shouldn’t have.

speaker: Oh, it’s my pleasure.
response: No, you really shouldn’t have. I brought my own.

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve been cooking all day.
response: Well, now don’t you feel silly.

speaker: Oh, well, I’m sure they wouldn’t have tasted nearly as good if I hadn’t tried your food first.
response: Howard, did you want your clothes arranged seasonally or by colour?

speaker: Colour’s fine.
response: Wrong, they’ll be arranged seasonally.

speaker: Oh, it’s okay, I’m used to it. The other day at Whole Foods, he spent an hour optimizing the cheese aisle.
response: Yeah, and some thanks I got. The assistant manager chased me out with an artisanal salami.

speaker: Sheldon, come on. It’s getting late. Time to go.
response: Oh, five more minutes.

speaker: That’s what you said five minutes ago. Amy and Penny are already in the car. Let’s move it.
response: How come I never get to do anything I want to do?

speaker: You know, if he really wants to stay and finish, I can give him a ride home.
response: Please, Leonard, he said it’s okay.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s, wait, I can go home without you? Bye.
response: Howard, I have a few questions. I found three bowling pins. Now, do you juggle these, or are you missing seven?

speaker: Juggle.
response: You health nuts k*ll me.

speaker: Oh, my God, it’s beautiful. Look, he found the juggling pins I hid.
response: Uh, just a couple more items. Howard, I found this letter from your dad in a box. Now, based on the content, it could either be filed…

speaker: Whoa, you opened this?
response: Well, I had to find out if it was personal correspondence or memorabilia. Now, as I was saying, based on the content…

speaker: If I wanted to know, I would’ve opened it years ago. The closet looks great. Let’s get out of here.
response: Wait, can I bring this box of extra shirt buttons to sort on the ride?

speaker: Do whatever you want.
response: Thanks. Oh. Great party.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Oh, hello. What can I do for you ladies?

speaker: You have something we want.
response: Oh, dear. My mother warned me this is what happens to pretty boys in the big city.

speaker: No, we just want information.
response: Oh. Oh, I’ve got that in spades. Ravage me.

speaker: We heard you read the letter from Howard’s father.
response: I did.

speaker: What did it say?
response: I can’t tell you that. I’m bound by closet organizer/organizee confidentiality.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s not a real thing.
response: Well, neither is the rule that you have to hold your girlfriend’s hand at the movies. You know. That doesn’t stop you from pawing at me like you’re a bear and I’m a trash can full of sweets.

speaker: Why do you even care? Just tell us what it says.
response: Control over the information contained in that letter belongs to Howard. By happenstance, I came to know it. That doesn’t give me the right to disseminate it freely.

speaker: Come on. Look, the letter was found in Bernadette’s closet. Doesn’t that count for something?
response: Are you pointing out that California is a community property state, and since Howard and Bernadette are married, the intellectual property contained in that letter is jointly owned by the two spouses?

speaker: Yeah, obviously.
response: Well played. Sometimes I don’t give you enough credit, Penny.

speaker: Hey, where have you been?
response: Oh, Leonard. If I was prone to sarcasm, I’d say I was pulling off a major heist at the museum of laundry baskets.

speaker: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten. I meant, golly, Sheldon, you’ve been gone a long time.
response: Oh. Yeah, well, I was waylaid by Penny, Bernadette and Amy. They made me reveal confidential information about Howard’s father.

speaker: What information?
response: I can’t tell you that. I am bound by closet organizer/organizee confidentiality.

speaker: Well, come on, we won’t tell anyone.
response: Sorry, badgering me won’t work. What you should have said is, It’s pointless to keep this a secret because Penny will tell us.

speaker: Fine, then that.
response: All right, I’ll tell you. My goodness, everyone’s on their game today.

speaker: Aw.
response: My shirt is itchy and I wish I were dead.

speaker: Absolutely.
response: If I say yes, can we turn off that Latin orgy music?

speaker: So everybody knows what’s in that letter except for me?
response: Yes, it’s six against one. Stand down, sir.

speaker: Use me as a human shield!
response: I panicked. He looked taller than usual.

speaker: Oh, yeah, what’s that?
response: It’s simple, really. It occurred to me that knowing and not knowing can be achieved by creating a macroscopic example of quantum superposition. The, the principle that a physical system exists partially in all its possible states at once.

speaker: We were all thinking it, really. It was kind of the elephant in the room, so…
response: Anyway, um, I realized that if we each present you with an account of what your father wrote to you, only one of which is true, and then we don’t tell you which one it is, you will forever be in a state of epistemic ambivalence.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: It was a map leading to the lost treasure of famous pirate One-Eyed Willy.

speaker: Told you.
response: Don’t.

speaker: Really?
response: Or that’s complete poppycock which Amy made up. It still could be the map.

speaker: It was a letter explaining that your dad wasn’t who he said he was. Eventually, his other life caught up to him, and the only way to keep you and your mom safe was to leave.
response: I would like to change mine. The pirate’s name was Peg-Leg Antoine. Now it’s completely different from Goonies.

speaker: No, it’s not.
response: Don’t.

speaker: Okay.
response: You know, surprisingly, uh, the letter from your father wasn’t the most interesting thing I read in the closet. Bernadette’s diary has some saucy passages.

speaker: Sheldon, don’t you dare.
response: There’s nothing to worry about. Your secret’s safe with me.

speaker: That’s more like it.
response: Although copyright law would allow me to quote snippets in the context of a review.

speaker: If you’d let me pierce your brain with a hot needle in the right place, you’d be happy all the time.
response: Uh, Penny, I, I have a couple of questions about your closet. Is there any reason you’re keeping this dead goldfish?

speaker: Damn, I forgot to feed him. And that I had him.
response: Well, now, did you also have a dog? Because I found what appears to be a battery-operated chew toy.

speaker: Featuring one articulated razor-sharp k*ll saw, one polycarbonate grinding and flipping wheel, steel armour plate exoskeleton top and bottom, and enough horsepower to drive a 110 pounds of mechanized death from zero to holy crap in 4.8 seconds.
response: Is it wrong to say I love our k*ll robot?

speaker: Okay. Ooh, perhaps today is the day we finally find out what’s inside the Magic Eight Ball.
response: Did it when I was four. It’s an icosahedral dye floating in tinted blue water.

speaker: How about the toaster oven?
response: What did the toaster oven ever do to you?

speaker: Gentlemen, goggles.
response: Yeah, this is an auspicious moment. Yeah, like Robert Oppenheimer or Neil Armstrong, we need the appropriate words to mark this historic scientific event.

speaker: Yeah, well, it almost k*ll me.
response: If it wanted to k*ll you, you’d be dead.

speaker: So, who exactly does it want to k*ll?
response: I’m sorry, are you unaware of the upcoming Southern California Robot Fighting League Round Robin Invitational?

speaker: Look, normally I can just ignore you. I mean, I get it, you’re a little peculiar. You know, like Sheldon.
response: Yeah, excuse me, Penny, but in this room, you’re the one who’s peculiar.

speaker: Yes, we did, Kripke.
response: His name is Monte.

speaker: Come on, is that really necessary?
response: Leonard, I believe it is. This is trash talk, and trash talk is a traditional component in all sporting events. Kripke, your robot is inferior and it will be defeated by ours because ours exceeds yours in both design and execution. Also, I’m given to understand that your mother is overweight.

speaker: Oh, snap.
response: Now, of course, if that is the result of a glandular condition and not sloth and gluttony, I withdraw that comment.

speaker: What difference does it make? Fat is fat.
response: There are boundaries.

speaker: Tell you what, forget the S.C.aw.F.L.aw.aw.I., let’s settle this woboto a woboto.
response: What do you mean?

speaker: There’s no guawantee we’ve gotta go against each other in the Wound Wobin, so let’s thwow down. You know, unless you’re afwaid.
response: We accept your challenge. Name a time and place.

speaker: Tomowow, thwee o’clock, the kinetics wab.
response: Make it so.

speaker: Sheldon, we have to call it off.
response: We don’t have that option, we’ve accepted the challenge. We can’t run away from a fight.

speaker: Oh, please, we’ve spent our whole lives running away from fights. Personally, I can squeeze through a hole in a fence half my size.
response: Impressive as that may be, Monte is not us. Monte has no fear.

speaker: Sheldon, did we all not just watch the same video? Kripke’s robot just had angry sex with a mid-sized automobile.
response: You are overlooking the fact that we now know what we’re up against and we can modify Monte so that he’s prepared.

speaker: Not yet.
response: Have faith, gentlemen. We don’t need Wolowitz, engineering is merely the slow younger brother of physics. Watch and learn. Do either of you know how to open the toolbox?

speaker: Neat. Good work. Sheldon, we’ve got to call this off.
response: No, Leonard. For years, merciless thugs like Kripke have made my life a series of painful noogies and humiliating wedgies and the insensitively named Indian burns. That stops now.

speaker: But, Sheldon, we don’t have a chance. The only improvement you were able to make on the robot was to put fresh batteries in the remote.
response: What you fail to realize is Kripke suffers from a fatal flaw, overconfidence from his robot’s massive size and its overwhelming power.

speaker: That’s not overconfidence, that’s observation.
response: Trust me, Kripke will fall easy prey to my psychological warfare. Observe. Kripke! I would ask if your robot is prepared to meet its maker, but as you are its maker, clearly the two of you have met.

speaker: Are you cwazy? This is a stweet fight, the stweet has no rules.
response: He’s right, Leonard. The paradigm is to the death.

speaker: I will, however, give you the opportunity to concede my supewiowity now and offer me your wobot as the spoils of w*r.
response: Never. I’d rather see Monte dead than in your hands.

speaker: That could be easily awanged. Weady, set, go?
response: Do it.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, you got this.
response: Indeed. We are prepared for anything he can throw at us. (A flame begins to jet out of Kripke’s robot.) That’s new.

speaker: Go, go, go, go!
response: Don’t hurt us, don’t hurt us,

speaker: Well, so much for making up for the emotional wounds of childhood.
response: I did this. Monte was k*ll by my hubris and my pride. No matter what anybody says, this is my fault.

speaker: Yeah. They sucker punch you when your eyes are closed.
response: So what do you think, Howard? It’s not that bad, right?

speaker: Oh, no. A little electrical tape, some solder. Are you insane? I’ve seen space probes that crashed into the desert that were in better shape than this.
response: You’re right. Monte’s gone. We’ll bury him in the morning. A simple ceremony. I’ll speak. Leonard, you’ll play your cello.

speaker: Sheldon, honey, aren’t you getting a little carried away? I mean, it’s just a toy robot.
response: Just a toy robot?

speaker: Sounds like most of my dates.
response: Oh, dear Lord, get away from me, you monster!

speaker: Well, he’s smart and crazy enough, he may have actually created a monster. (They enter. Sheldon is by the window.)
response: Shoo, shoo! Be gone!

speaker: What the hell is going on?
response: There’s a bird outside the window, and he won’t go away. That is the hell that is going on. We have no worms or seeds here. Shoo, shoo.

speaker: Really? On top of everything else, you’re afraid of birds?
response: It’s called ornithophobia. And someday it will be recognized as a true disability, and the landlord will be required by law to put a giant net over the building. Which is unfortunate, because I have a fear of nets.

speaker: Great. I’ll see you later. And remember, he’s more afraid of you than you are of him.
response: That doesn’t help.

speaker: No, I was talking to the bird.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird. (Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird. (Knock, knock, knock) Go away, bird.

speaker: Sheldon, just ignore him.
response: Good idea. Attention is what birds want. (Pulls curtain) Oh, much better. All right. Now I’ll just get along with my life. (Bird squawks) Make a pot of tea, Leonard. It’s going to be a long night.

speaker: The bird’s still there?
response: Quick, what does a hawk sound like?

speaker: I don’t know. Scree-scree.
response: Please, that’s a seagull. If you’re not going to help, don’t help.

speaker: Sorry. Do you think I’m overdressed?
response: It depends on the activity. For a prostate exam, yes. If you’re playing Vegas, I’d add sequins.

speaker: I’m going to the movies with Penny. I don’t want her to think that I think it’s a date.
response: Do you think it’s a date?

speaker: No, but she might think I think it’s a date even though I don’t.
response: Or you might think she thinks you think it’s a date even though she doesn’t.

speaker: Are we overthinking this?
response: Not at all.

speaker: You’re right. I’m fine. I’m wearing this.
response: Really? A blazer? All right. (Leonard takes off blazer and heads back to his room. Sheldon dials phone) Yes, hello. This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Yeah, I’m at 2311 North Robles Avenue. Yeah, I’d like to report a dangerous wild animal. A blue jay. I’m sorry, this is Animal Control. I don’t understand the laughter. No, the bird is not in my home. If he was in my home, I obviously would have called 911. Sir, I have no doubt that there are things that you’re frightened of. Being stuck in a dead-end public service job? Or your wife stepping out on you because you’re stuck in a dead-end public service job? Or spiders? Don’t you think I tried making cat noises?

speaker: Too casual?
response: For an audience with the queen, yes. For an evening of passing a bottle of fortified wine around a flaming trash can, you look great. (Leonard leaves again. Sheldon draws a picture of a cats face and returns to making cat noises at the window.) What am I thinking? Whiskers!

speaker: I’m pushing play.
response: A minute.

speaker: If we don’t start soon, George Lucas is going to change it again.
response: This would go a lot faster if you put your trade school diploma to work and helped me set up this high frequency tone generator.

speaker: I have a Masters degree from M.I.T.
response: Yeah, but you’ve got a can-do attitude and that’s what’s important.

speaker: I really don’t get your problem with birds.
response: The question you should be asking is what is their problem with me? My first memory, a hummingbird b*mb my stroller to get at the apple juice in my sippy cup.

speaker: Hummingbirds are pretty.
response: Hummingbirds are the vampires of the flower world.

speaker: Still my first choice for an ankle tattoo. Or a dolphin, I go back and forth.
response: Age seven, a blood-thirsty chicken chases me up a tree. Age twelve, a magpie tries to steal the retainer out of my mouth. Age sixteen, a parrot in a pet store called me fat ass. Need I go on?

speaker: All right, Sheldon, your bird death ray is ready.
response: It’s not a death ray. It’s just a little ultrasonic blast to scare him off. Trust me, if I had a death ray, I wouldn’t be living here. I’d be in my lair enjoying the money the people of Earth gave me for not using my death ray. All right, and in three, two, one. (Switches on. All the windows shatter. The bird doesn’t move.)

speaker: Sheldon, what do you expect us to do?
response: You’re biologists. Biology is the study of living things. That’s a living thing, get cracking.

speaker: Yeah, neither of us minored in bird-shooing.
response: Oh, come now. Your undergraduate work must have included a varmints and critters class.

speaker: Come back in, Sheldon, he’s not going to hurt you. He looks friendly. I think he might be someone’s pet.
response: No, Bernadette, don’t be a hero!

speaker: Oh, he’s a sweetie.
response: Yes. It’s very sweet. Now, slowly and carefully, flush him down the toilet.

speaker: Sheldon, the only way to get past this fear is to interact with it. Just like you did with the mailman.
response: Every year tens of people around the world are k*ll by birds. I’m not going to be another statistic.

speaker: Look how sweet he is. Come over and say hi. Come on. You can do it. Don’t be scared. Come on. Oh, just pet the bird, you big baby!
response: I did it! I actually did it. Okay, now flush him.

speaker: Oh, it’s just like my grandma with her parrot. And after she lost her marbles with her remote control.
response: My phone’s on the desk over there. Take a picture of us together. Make it good enough to go on a mug, a mouse pad, and a calendar. If you were a dove, I’d call you Lovey-Dovey. Oh. Who am I kidding? This isn’t a moment for strict adherence to the literal. You’re just my little Lovey-Dovey, aren’t you?

speaker: I still think he looks like someone’s pet. Maybe we should put up posters.
response: Yes. It should have a big picture of him, and the words, is this your bird? Not anymore. We’re going to have so much fun together. You can carry messages to all my enemies. I can tie a string to your leg and fly you like a kite.

speaker: If you’re keeping him, I’ve got a cage you can borrow. One of the test monkeys slipped on a banana peel and broke his neck. It was both tragic and hysterical.
response: Nonsense. No. Lovey-Dovey doesn’t sleep in a cage. No. Lovey-Dovey sleeps in his very own nest, which I’m going to get off the windowsill and put in my room. Isn’t that right, LD? (Opens window. Bird flies out.) No. Where are you going? Come back, Lovey-Dovey! This is your home now! I already ordered 20 pounds of bird feed off of Amazon! He’s gone.

speaker: I’m sorry, Sheldon.
response: How could he do this to me? Get back here, you stupid bird, so I can love you!

speaker: I am such an asthmatic dumbass. I had a weird night.
response: Mine was great. I’m going to be a mommy. (Reveals nest with an egg in it.)

speaker: The Fantastic Four reunited.
response: Yeah, you had a good run, Fake Wolowitz. We’ll remember you with nostalgic fondness, the way we do the dial-up modem, the VHS tape, or, or Leonard’s gym membership.

speaker: We’re not kicking him out. Stuart and I have become good friends.
response: Okay, one vote for, one vote against. Leonard, you’re the tiebreaker.

speaker: I don’t have a problem with Stuart. Besides, he gives us a twenty percent discount at his comic book store.
response: Well, I don’t sell my friendship that cheaply.

speaker: I can go thirty.
response: Welcome aboard, old chum.

speaker: Okay, the NASA Web site says Howard’s final descent has g*n.
response: He left a boy, he returns a boy-sized hero.

speaker: Me, too. But we’ll see him tomorrow.
response: Yes, it’s just that in all the years I’ve known him, he’s never had the opportunity to receive my admiration. I was excited to see the look on his face when it finally happened.

speaker: You’re unbelievable.
response: I know.

speaker: How about boys versus girls?
response: Oh, that hardly seems fair. But I guess any team that I’m not on has a decided disadvantage.

speaker: Once again, unbelievable.
response: Yeah, once again, I know.

speaker: All right, round one. Here.
response: Got it.

speaker: Present! Yeah!
response: Oh, Leonard. Now, how can you not get that?

speaker: In what universe is that a present?
response: It’s not a present, it’s the present. Look. There’s you and me. There’s Penny and Amy. We’re playing Pictionary. In the present.

speaker: Oh, my God, we’re gonna k*ll them.
response: It’s a quark-gluon plasma.

speaker: No.
response: It’s asymptotically free partons inside a quark-gluon plasma.

speaker: Nothing with quarks.
response: It’s an observational rebuttal of the Lambda-CDM model of the universe.

speaker: How could you miss that?
response: Hey, if you want someone to guess chocolate chip cookie, you draw a glass of milk next to it.

speaker: Penny got it.
response: Yeah, only after I eliminated all the obvious answers. You’re welcome.

speaker: Relax, we got time, this is so fun.
response: There.

speaker: Soon.
response: Come on, Leonard, I am spoon-feeding this to you.

speaker: Yep!
response: Wait, no, no. No. The word is Polish. See, look. Polish sausage. And the, the model of the solar system developed by Nicolaus Copernicus, a Polish astronomer. And then, finally, if that wasn’t enough, which it should have been, this is Madame Curie k*ll herself by discovering radium, who, although she was a naturalized French citizen, was Polish by birth.

speaker: Excuse me, the word is polish. See? Small P.
response: Ah. So it is. I guess we both share blame on this one.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, you’re always full of fun little facts. Where did the expression got your ass handed to you come from?
response: Don’t know.

speaker: I wonder if it’s from, like, ancient Rome where they’d actually chop somebody’s ass off and then go, here. You know, to appease Loseroneous, the god of losers.
response: I am not a loser. Pictionary is not a true test of any real intelligence or k*ll.

speaker: Mmm, in all fairness, Pictionary has verbal k*ll, visual k*ll. It’s a pretty well-rounded game.
response: Lot of big talk from a man who can’t draw a chocolate chip cookie.

speaker: All right, fine, pick another game. Amy and I will b*at you at anything.
response: All right. Let’s play Physics Fiesta.

speaker: Oh, come on, what is that?
response: It’s a game that I just invented, in which the participants answer physics questions in remedial Spanish. Um, ¿Dónde está el boson de Higgs?

speaker: En el acelerador de particulares.
response: Bueno, mi amigo.

speaker: No, no, we’re not playing some dumb made-up game.
response: All games are made up. They’re not found in nature. You don’t just dig in the ground, come across a rich vein of Rock’em Sock’em Robots.

speaker: No good, Sheldon doesn’t float.
response: That is true. I have a higher than normal body density. If I run too deep a bath, I drown.

speaker: All right, let’s keep it simple. How about darts?
response: No, that’s not fair either.

speaker: Why not?
response: Darts is a bar game. You’ve been frequenting drinking establishments since you were of legal age.

speaker: Yeah, that’s when it started.
response: Well, regardless, she has a distinct advantage in all tavern-based competitions. Pool, beer pong, wet T-shirt contests, they’re all out.

speaker: We could go to the cadaver lab at UCLA and play real-life Operation.
response: No.

speaker: Okay, glasses off. Find Waldo.
response: Hurry up, find him, find him.

speaker: I’m trying. Don’t yell at me.
response: For goodness’ sake, he’s wearing a hat, glasses, and a red striped shirt.

speaker: Yes, we win again.
response: How could you not find him?

speaker: Remember, show your work.
response: I’m okay. I’m okay. I’m not okay.

speaker: Mwah!
response: Stop that.

speaker: Mwah!
response: Amy, do something. Amy, help. Amy, stop that. Amy, Penny, both of you, stop it.

speaker: On the count of three. One, two…
response: Wait. I’m a little concerned. Blueberries are rich in antioxidants.

speaker: So?
response: So, with all those antioxidants, what if I run out of oxidants?

speaker: Sheldon, we haven’t won a game all night. Now, you either stick your face in that pie or I’m gonna stick that pie in your face.
response: That’s rude.

speaker: Not now!
response: Oh, ow, blueberry in my nose, blueberry in my nose!

speaker: Lay it on me.
response: Assuming the device could be invented which would identify the quantum state of matter of an individual in one location, and transmit that pattern to a distant location for reassembly, you would not have actually transported the individual. You would have destroyed him in one location, and recreated him in another.

speaker: How about that.
response: Personally, I would never use a transporter. Because the original Sheldon would have to be disintegrated in order to create a new Sheldon.

speaker: Would the new Sheldon be in any way an improvement on the old Sheldon?
response: No, he would be exactly the same.

speaker: That is a problem.
response: So, you see it too.

speaker: And he’s only fifteen years old.
response: Not bad, I myself started graduate school at fourteen.

speaker: I already know you’re not. You don’t have an open science grid computer, or a free electron laser, and the string theory research being done here is nothing but a dead end.
response: Excuse me, that is my research, and it is by no means a dead end.

speaker: Yes sir.
response: You can count on us, we’re on it. What the hell do you mean, dead end.

speaker: I mean, the whole landscape of false vacuums in string theory could be as large as ten to the five-hundredth power. In addition… ooh, look, chocolate milk.
response: I sense a disturbance in the force.

speaker: That.
response: He’s not wrong. Alright, and this is my office.

speaker: Is this part of the tour?
response: Nope. Goodbye.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, we’ve hardly shown him anything.
response: Oh, alright, this is my desk, these are my books, this is my door, please close it behind you. Goodbye.

speaker: Looks like you’re doing work in quantum loop corrections.
response: Keen observation, goodbye.

speaker: You see where you went wrong, don’t you?
response: Leonard.

speaker: Huh, yeah?
response: Get him out.

speaker: It’s startling to me you haven’t considered a Lorentz invariant field theory approach.
response: You think I haven’t considered it? You really think I haven’t considered it?

speaker: Have you considered it?
response: Get him out Leonard.

speaker: Wow, you won the Stephenson award.
response: Yes, in fact I am the youngest person ever to win it.

speaker: Really, how old?
response: Fourteen and a half.

speaker: Sure. Raj, hug Howard.
response: Uh-uh-uh.

speaker: Something you’d like to share? A tale of woe perhaps.
response: Fifteen years old. Dennis Kim is fifteen years old, and he’s already correcting my work. Today I went from being Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to… you know, that other guy.

speaker: Antonio Salieri?
response: Oh, God, now even you’re smarter than me.

speaker: Just eat, Sheldon, you’ll feel better.
response: Why waste food. In Texas when a cow goes dry they don’t keep feeding it, they just take her out and sh**t her between the eyes.

speaker: You can’t let this kid get to you. You always knew that someday someone would come along who was younger and smarter.
response: Yes, but I assumed I would have been dead hundreds of years, and that there would be an asterisk by his name because he would be a cyborg.

speaker: So, you’ve got a bit of competition, I really don’t see what the big deal is.
response: Well of course you don’t, you’ve never excelled at anything.

speaker: Well, what are you going to do, Sheldon, give up?
response: Yes. That’s what a rational person does when his entire life’s work is invalidated by a post-pubescent Asian wunderkind. He ceases his fruitless efforts, he donates his body to scientific research, and he waits to die.

speaker: Hey.
response: I’ve decided you’re right. My career is not over.

speaker: Great.
response: But, since the arrival of Dennis Kim has rendered my research pointless, I just have to find something else to focus on.

speaker: Great.
response: So I’ve decided, I’m going to collaborate with you.

speaker: Great.
response: What exactly is it you do? I know you chatter on about it all the time, but I’ve never really paid attention.

speaker: Okay, well, right now I’m designing an experiment to study the soft component of cosmic radiation at sea-level, but I really don’t need any help.
response: Oh, sure you do. Now, see, what’s this here in the schematic, is that a laser array?

speaker: Yes.
response: No. Hmmm. What happens if you use argon lasers instead of helium neon?

speaker: It would blow up.
response: Are you sure?

speaker: Pretty sure.
response: Pretty sure’s not very scientific, is this how you normally work, just hunches and guesses and stuff?

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, I understand that you’re going through a bit of a career crisis, you’re searching for some other area where you can feel valuable and productive but I need to tell you something and I want you to listen carefully.
response: Alright.

speaker: Go away.
response: If you’re concerned about sharing credit with me, you’re name can go first… I’m going.

speaker: It’s a small brown paper bag, Ma, I’m looking at it right now. (Pause.) Why would I make that up, there’s no ding-dong in it. (Pause.) How are two ding-dongs tomorrow going to help me today?
response: So, this is engineering, huh?

speaker: I’ll talk to you later.
response: Engineering. Where the noble k*ll labourers execute the vision of those who think and dream. Hello, oompah-loompahs of science.

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: I just came by to say hello.

speaker: I’ve been at this lab for three years, you’ve never came by to say hello.
response: Well, up until now I’ve had better things to do. So, what are we making today?

speaker: A small payload support structure for a European science experimental package that’s going up on the next space shuttle.
response: Really, how does it work?

speaker: When this is done, it will be attached to the payload bay, and the sensor apparatus will rest on it.
response: Uh, huh. So it’s a shelf?

speaker: No, you don’t understand, during acceleration it needs to stay perfectly level and provide… yeah, okay, it’s a shelf.
response: Now, I notice you’re using titanium, did you give any consideration to carbon nanotubes, they’re lighter, cheaper and half twice the tensile strength.

speaker: Sheldon, there’s a diploma in my office that says I have a masters in engineering.
response: And you also have a note from your mother that says I love you, bubbula. But neither of those is a cogent argument for titanium over nanotubes.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Yes.

speaker: Go away.
response: Did Leonard tell you to say that?

speaker: No, I thought of it all by myself.
response: Huh. It can’t be a coincidence. There must be some causal link I’m missing.

speaker: Go away. (Sheldon exits)
response: Curiouser and curiouser.

speaker: No, I just wasted a lot of time thinking about what it would be like if she did.
response: Oh, good, you’re all here. Look, I’ve decided that if the three of you drop whatever it is you’re working on and join me, we could lick cold fusion in less than a decade, twelve years tops. (They stare at him.) Go away? (They nod) Hmm. Could it be me?

speaker: Dr Cooper? Oh, are we interrupting?
response: No, no, please, come in. Yeah, I think you’ll appreciate this, very exciting.

speaker: Oh, what are you working on?
response: Something remarkable. Since my prospects for the Nobel Prize in physics have disappeared, thank you very much, I’ve decided to refocus my efforts and use my people k*ll to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Look, I’m going to solve the Middle-East Crisis by building an exact replica of Jerusalem in the middle of the Mexican desert.

speaker: To what end?
response: You know, it’s like the baseball movie, build it and they will come.

speaker: Who will come?
response: The Jewish people.

speaker: What if they don’t come.
response: We’ll make it nice, put out a spread.

speaker: Okay, well, um, speaking of spreads, we’re having a small welcoming party this afternoon for Mr Kim, who’s agreed to join us here at the University.
response: Of course he has, the oracle told us little Neo was the one. You can see the Matrix, can’t you.

speaker: Okay, well, uh, obviously you’re very busy with your… uh, um, come Dennis. You’ll have to excuse Dr Cooper, he’s been under a lot of… um… he’s nuts.
response: Ah, la-la-la, Hava Nagila. They’ll come, they’ll settle and I’ll win the prize…

speaker: Go away.
response: We could call it Nuevo Cherusalem.

speaker: Please go away.
response: Said Pharoah to Moses.

speaker: I don’t think you mean we can’t. I think you mean we shouldn’t.
response: Hey, Howard. You’re a Jew. If there was another wailing wall, exactly like the one in Jerusalem, but close to taco stands and cheap prescription drugs, would you still be able to wail at it? Okay, it’s definitely me.

speaker: Could I have everyone’s attention please. What a wonderful occasion this is. And how fortunate that it should happen to fall on take your daughter to work day. We’re here to welcome Mr Dennis Kim to our little family.
response: Welcome Dennis Kim.

speaker: Mr Kim was not only the valedictorian at Stamford University, he is also the youngest recipient of the prestigious Stephenson Award.
response: Youngest till the cyborgs rise up!

speaker: Did anyone see how he did it?
response: Don’t worry, I’ve got this. Ladies and Gentlemen, honoured daughters. While Mr Kim, by virtue of his youth and naivety, has fallen prey to the inexplicable need for human contact, let me step in and assure you that my research will go on uninterrupted, and that social relationships will continue to baffle and repulse me. Thank you.

speaker: Yeah, we really ruined his life.
response: Screw him, he was weak.

speaker: She’s just so impossible, they keep quitting.
response: So, who’s watching her now?

speaker: Hey, buddy.
response: Hello.

speaker: You okay?
response: I just got called into President Siebert’s office. The university won’t let me switch my field of study to inflationary cosmology. They’re forcing me to continue with string theory.

speaker: Why?
response: He said it’s why they hired me, it’s, it’s what my grant was designated for, and that everybody has to do things they don’t want to do. He then gave an example of something he had to do, even though he didn’t want to, which was look at my stupid face.

speaker: That’s a rude thing to say, out loud.
response: It’s an outrage. Honestly, I’m tempted to leave the university.

speaker: Whatever you do, just don’t make any rash decisions.
response: I don’t know. I am really aggravated.

speaker: What you working on?
response: I’m writing an appeal to the Faculty Senate, so that I can move on from string theory.

speaker: Oh. How’s it going?
response: You tell me. Dear Esteemed Colleagues, as you may know, I have requested to change my field of study. My decision to do so is, I believe, in the best interest of science. At your convenience, I’d be happy to explain it to you in words you’ll understand.

speaker: It’s nice that you called them esteemed.
response: You’re right. I’ll take that out.

speaker: So, listen, there was something I was hoping to float past you.
response: Mm.

speaker: Now that Penny and I are engaged, I thought we might want to talk about our living arrangements.
response: Of course. She’s spent many nights here, and you’re worried about preserving the myth of her virginity before the wedding.

speaker: I’m not.
response: Good, because not only has that ship sailed, if it hit an iceberg, countless men would perish.

speaker: Actually, this is about where she and I are going to live.
response: What do you mean?

speaker: Well, well, we might want to live together.
response: Oh, yeah, well, I’ve already given this some thought, and I’m willing to let Penny live with us one day a week for a trial period. Now, obviously, not when she’s made cranky by the shedding of her uterine lining.

speaker: That’s very sweet. But we were thinking more of us maybe living together with… not you.
response: I don’t understand. How could we all live together if I’m not there?

speaker: Look, I, I know this is, this is change, and that sounds scary.
response: Where are you going to go?

speaker: I don’t know. We just started to think about this. Maybe I’ll move in with Penny, or maybe she and I’ll take this place, and you can move across the hall.
response: Move across the hall? Did you take a marijuana?

speaker: No, I did not.
response: Did you get hit on the head with a coconut?

speaker: No.
response: Well, then, I’m all out of guesses. What? Me move across the hall. Why would you even suggest such a thing?

speaker: Because I love Penny, and want to give her the life she deserves.
response: I see. You’re putting your future bride’s happiness above mine.

speaker: Well, yeah.
response: Wow.

speaker: They just don’t appreciate you.
response: Yeah, and on top of that, Leonard has the audacity to suggest that now that he and Penny are engaged, he may not want to live with me any more.

speaker: Here, I made you some Strawberry Quik.
response: I have real problems here, Amy. I can’t be mollified with a beverage designed for children. Mmm, yummy.

speaker: You know, this might work out for the best. I mean, you’re always complaining about what a terrible roommate Leonard is. Like how he turns up the thermostat when you’re not there.
response: Ugh, it’s like walking into the Amazon. And not the good Amazon with one-day shipping. The awful one with birds and snakes.

speaker: You hate the sound of all those keys on his key chain.
response: Four keys! Who does he think he is, a warden?

speaker: See? Maybe you’ll love living alone.
response: I don’t know. Perhaps.

speaker: And if it turns out you don’t, you and I could live together.
response: You and… oh, sure, and while we’re at it, why don’t we get engaged, too? Why don’t we get a little house, start a family? Enjoy our sunset years together? Do you hear yourself, woman?

speaker: Sheldon, it was just a thought.
response: No. Here’s a thought. You’re not moving in, Leonard’s not moving out, everything stays exactly the way it is. And by the way, I saw you make this Strawberry Quik with syrup, you’re supposed to use the powder.

speaker: It tastes the same.
response: No. The syrup tastes better and I don’t like it.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: What happened?

speaker: I was cooking in the back room last night and the hot plate caught on fire.
response: And you couldn’t put it out?

speaker: I was across the street at the do-it-yourself car wash, taking a shower.
response: So when will you reopen?

speaker: Um, I don’t know. I’m waiting to hear back from the insurance company.
response: So, tomorrow?

speaker: I don’t mean to be rude, Sheldon, but, uh, my life is kind of falling apart right now.
response: Your life? The university is making me do string theory and my girlfriend loves me so much she wants to live with me. And now, the place I need to go when I’m sad is damp and smells funny.

speaker: Well, sorry I let you down.
response: No. I do not accept this. Everything is changing and I hate it. It stops now. I’m helping you get back on your feet. I would like to purchase this comic book, please.

speaker: That’ll be $2.99.
response: Really? It’s soaking wet.

speaker: Fine, a dollar.
response: Can you break a twenty?

speaker: No, I only have hundreds.
response: You know what? I don’t always recognize sarcasm, but I do right now, and I don’t appreciate it. I’m sorry for your loss. But you’re not the only one whose day has been a disaster.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: You tracked my phone?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Boy, you chase one balloon for three miles.

speaker: We were worried about you.
response: Don’t be melodramatic. I’m just getting on a train and leaving forever.

speaker: Seriously? You don’t even have a change of clothes or a toothbrush.
response: My plan is to stop at malls and buy what I need. It’s called living off the land.

speaker: Okay, I know you’re upset and there’s a lot of stuff going on, but it’s nothing we can’t work out. Come on, let’s get you home.
response: No. I’ve reached my breaking point. I need to leave. Now.

speaker: And go where?
response: It doesn’t matter.

speaker: So a few things don’t go your way and your best decision is to ride the rails like a hobo?
response: I suppose it is. Except I have a credit card. And I refuse to carry my laptop at the end of a stick. And I’d sooner die than eat beans out of a can.

speaker: Come on, come home with us and tomorrow I’ll, I’ll take you to Legoland.
response: Legoland is not the solution to everything. And it’s too much of a scene since that movie came out.

speaker: Then what can I do?
response: Leonard, I am overwhelmed. Everything is changing and it’s simply too much. I need to get away and think.

speaker: He’ll be okay. You taught him well, Padawan.
response: Good Lord. Padawan’s the student, not the teacher.

speaker: Sheldon, if you really need to do this, I’m not gonna stand in your way.
response: I do.

speaker: Be safe and call us.
response: I will.

speaker: Bye, buddy. Sheldon?
response: Yes?

speaker: I’m gonna miss you.
response: Of course you are.

speaker: The Cheesecake Factory
response: Alright, I’m moving my infantry division, augmented by a battalion of Orcs from Lord of the Rings, we flank the Tennessee Volunteers, and the North once again wins the Battle of Gettysburg.

speaker: Alright, thank you, and Sheldon.
response: We don’t eat here, I don’t know what’s good.

speaker: Well, it’s all good.
response: Statistically unlikely.

speaker: Just get a hamburger, you like hamburgers.
response: I like the hamburgers where we usually have hamburgers, you can’t make the assumption that I’ll like the hamburgers here.

speaker: Uh, which one, the Classic Burger, the Ranch House Burger, the Barbecue Burger or the Kobe burger?
response: Can’t we just go to Big Boy? They only have one burger. The Big Boy.

speaker: The Barbecue Burger is like the Big Boy.
response: Excuse me, in a world that already includes the Big Boy, why would I settle for something like a Big Boy?

speaker: Because you are not at Big Boy!
response: Fine, I’ll have the Barbecue Burger.

speaker: Make it two.
response: Waitresses don’t yell at you at Big Boy.

speaker: I didn’t know you ate here.
response: We don’t. This is a disturbing aberration.

speaker: Lesley? No, no-oh, what are you kidding?
response: He asked her out once, it was an embarrassing failure.

speaker: Thank you Sheldon.
response: Oh, I’m sorry, was that supposed to be a secret?

speaker: What did Penny mean, you’d make a cute couple?
response: Well I assume she meant that the two of you together would constitute a couple that others might consider cute. An alternate, and somewhat less likely interpretation, is that you could manufacture one. As in, oh look, Leonard and Lesley made Mr and Mrs Goldfarb, aren’t they adorable.

speaker: If Penny didn’t know that Lesley had already turned me down then that would unambiguously mean that she, Penny, thought that I should her, Lesley, out, indicating that she, Penny, had no interest in me asking her, Penny, out. But because she did know that I had asked Lesley out and that she, Lesley, had turned me down then she, Penny, could be offering consolation. That’s too bad, you would have made a cute couple. But while thinking, good, Leonard remains available.
response: You’re a lucky man, Leonard.

speaker: How so?
response: You’re talking to one of the three men in the Western hemisphere capable of following that train of thought.

speaker: Well, what do you think.
response: I said I could follow it, I didn’t say I cared.

speaker: Oh, hey Sheldon, what’s going on?
response: I need your opinion on a matter of semiotics.

speaker: I’m sorry?
response: Semiotics. The study of signs and symbols, it’s a branch of philosophy related to linguistics.

speaker: Okay, sweetie, I know you think you’re explaining yourself, but you’re really not.
response: Just come with me.

speaker: Well what?
response: What does it mean?

speaker: Oh, come on, you went to college.
response: Yes, but I was eleven.

speaker: Alright, look, a tie on the doorknob usually means someone doesn’t want to be disturbed because they’re, you know, getting busy.
response: So you’re saying Leonard has a girl in there.

speaker: We really shouldn’t be standing here.
response: This is very awkward.

speaker: Oh, come on, you know, Leonard’s had girls over before, right?
response: Oh, yes, but there’s usually planning, courtship and advance notice. Last time I was able to book a cruise to the Arctic to see a solar eclipse.

speaker: Wait, you had to leave the state because your roommate was having sex?
response: I didn’t have to, the dates just happened to coincide.

speaker: So, do you know who’s in there?
response: Well, there’s Leonard. (Picking up violin case) And he’s either with Lesley Winkle or a 1930’s gangster.

speaker: Hmmm. Good for him. Good for Leonard. Okay, night.
response: No, no, wait, hold on.

speaker: What’s the matter?
response: I don’t know what the protocol is here. Do I stay, do I leave? Do I wait to greet them with a refreshing beverage?

speaker: Gee, Sheldon, you’re asking the wrong girl. I’m usually on the other side of the tie.
response: Hi, Leonard. It’s me, Sheldon. In the living room. I just, I wanted you to know I saw the tie. Message received. You’re welcome. You carry on. Give my best to Lesley.

speaker: Hey, what’s the matter?
response: My equations, someone’s tampered with my equations.

speaker: Are you sure?
response: Of course I’m sure. Look at the beta-function of quantum chrono-dynamics, the sign’s been changed.

speaker: Oh yeah. But doesn’t that fix the problem you’ve been having?
response: Are you insane? Are you out of your mind? Are you…. hey look, that fixes the problem I’ve been having.

speaker: You’re welcome.
response: You did this?

speaker: Yeah, I noticed it when I got up to get a glass of water, so I fixed it, now you can show that quarks are asymptotically free at high energies. Pretty cool, huh?
response: Cool?

speaker: Thank you, I’ll see you at work.
response: Uh-duh, hold on, hold on!

speaker: What?
response: Who told you you could touch my board?

speaker: No-one.
response: I don’t come into your house and touch your board.

speaker: There are no incorrect equations on my board.
response: Oh, that is so… so…

speaker: I’m sorry, I’ve got to run, if you come up with an adjective, text me. (Leaves).
response: Inconsiderate, that is the adjective, inconsiderate.

speaker: You can stare at your board all day Sheldon, she’s still going to be right.
response: I’m not staring, I’m mulling.

speaker: Sheldon!
response: I’m coming.

speaker: Wuh, I don’t…. th-th-th-that’s really two different questions, uh, I’m not…. Sheldon, we have to go!
response: Boy, you’re wound awfully tight for a man who just had sexual intercourse.

speaker: Thank you. What did she mean, she’s happy for me? Is she happy because I’m seeing someone, or is she happy because she thinks that I’m happy, because anyone who cared for someone would want them to be happy, even if the reason for their happiness made the first person unhappy. You know, because the second person, though happy, is now romantically unavailable to the first person.
response: Do you realise I may have to share a Nobel Prize with your booty call?

speaker: You know what, I’m being ridiculous. But who cares what Penny thinks, Lesley is a terrific girl, she’s attractive, we like each other, she’s extremely intelligent.
response: She’s not that intelligent.

speaker: She fixed your equation.
response: She got lucky.

speaker: You don’t believe in luck.
response: I don’t have to believe in it for her to be lucky.

speaker: Regardless, I have a chance at a real relationship with Lesley, I’m not going to pass that up for some hypothetical future happiness with a woman who may or may not want me to be happy with a woman who is currently making me happy.
response: Leonard?

speaker: Yeah.
response: I still don’t care.

speaker: No kidding.
response: I won’t go out on a limb, but I think we may be looking at my new Tuesday hamburger.

speaker: Your old Tuesday hamburger will be so broken hearted.
response: Way ahead of you. I was thinking of moving Big Boy to Thursdays, and just dropping Soup Plantation.

speaker: Really?
response: Yeah, the name always confused me anyway, Soup Plantation. You can’t grow soup.

speaker: So, how’s everything.
response: Terrific, you’ll be happy to know that I plan to come here every Tuesday night for the foreseeable future.

speaker: Really, oh yay!
response: Who do I speak to about permanently reserving this table?

speaker: Well what did she mean by that? Was that just a generic platitude or was that a subtle bid for attention?
response: You know why this hamburger surpasses the Big Boy? This is a single decker hamburger whereas the Big Boy is a double decker. This has a much more satisfying meat to bun to condiment ratio.

speaker: Are you even listening to me?
response: Of course I’m listening. Blah blah, hopeless Penny delusion, blah blah blah.

speaker: Why do I always have to carry the heavy stuff?
response: Well, it’s very simple. In our ragtag band of scientists with nothing to lose, I’m the smart one, Wolowitz is the funny one, and Koothrappali is the lovable foreigner who struggles to understand our ways and fails. That leaves you, by default, as the muscle.

speaker: Oh, no, you didn’t trade the food for magic beans, did you?
response: Of course not. And, technically, magic beans would be food, although eating them would be quite a waste, since you could plant them and overnight have a giant beanstalk, which would provide enough roughage for a small city.

speaker: Who’s Adam West?
response: Who’s Adam West? Leonard, what do the two of you talk about after the coitus?

speaker: That is so sad.
response: No, what’s sad is that you don’t know Adam West was TV’s Batman.

speaker: You see what you’re doing? Stop that.
response: Fascinating.

speaker: What?
response: It appears to be a Lord of the Rings ring.

speaker: It’s even got the Elvish engraving on it.
response: It’s not Elvish. It’s the language of Mordor written in Elvish script. One Ring to

speaker: Hold on. Sheldon, is there ketchup on that table?
response: Yes, there is. Oh, here’s a fun fact, ketchup started out as a general term for sauce, typically made of, uh, mushrooms or fish brine with herbs and spices. Some popular early main ingredients included blueberry, anchovy, oyster, kidney bean and grape.

speaker: Eddie Crispo. Anyway, he said this isn’t a replica. It’s the real deal.
response: If you’re suggesting that that is the actual ring of power forged by Sauron in Mount Doom, I look at you with an expression of exhaustion and ever so slight amusement.

speaker: No, but it’s close. Look at the markings inside. Those are production markings. Nine rings were made for use in the Lord of the Rings movies. Three were given to members of the cast. The rest were destroyed. Except one. One was stolen. Gentlemen, this is the one ring.
response: Mine!

speaker: No, it is not yours. We all went in on the box together.
response: Well, yes, but I found it in the box, and the laws of maritime salvage clearly state that the finder of a sunken treasure is the owner of the treasure.

speaker: How is this maritime salvage?
response: Other than the lack of water, how is it not?

speaker: All the wealthy and beautiful people in movies ride Jet Skis. That can’t just be a coincidence.
response: We can’t sell it. We have to keep it and love it and polish it, and only take it out occasionally when we go to the park and re-enact our favourite scenes from the movies.

speaker: We are not blackmailing Peter J… All right, where’s the ring?
response: You mean my ring?

speaker: What are you doing?
response: The ring was unguarded, it was just sitting on the table, anyone could have taken it. Proof? I did.

speaker: Look, let’s be reasonable. We all want to do different things with the ring, but your ideas are stupid, and I want a jet ski.
response: I found it. The ring is mine. I don’t understand why in this group I never get my way.

speaker: You always get your way.
response: I’ll stipulate to that if you give me the ring.

speaker: This ring.
response: Looking for something?

speaker: So, Sheldon, how’s it feel to get b*at up by a girl?
response: It’s not the first time. I have a twin sister whose as*ault began in utero. If only I’d had the presence of mind to reabsorb her, then I’d have a mole with hair in it instead of a tedious yearly Christmas letter.

speaker: You know what? I am ending this. Penny didn’t want to hold the ring anymore. She gave it to me, I have it. I’m sending it back. Where’s the ring?
response: You mean this ring? Next time be aware of your surroundings while urinating in a public men’s room.

speaker: Give me that.
response: No, it’s mine.

speaker: And it wasn’t when we were driving like this?
response: I would advise the three of you that resistance is futile. I have endless patience. I once spent two-and-a-half hours on hold with Hewlett-Packard customer service just to complain about their customer service.

speaker: If you’re offended, let go of the ring and go on home to your mother’s boobies.
response: Excellent, excellent. Tire each other out, the ring will be mine. Howard, why don’t you go after Raj’s mother?

speaker: Why don’t we go after your mother?
response: Go ahead. I have no illusions about my mother. She is a kind, loving, religiously fanatical right-wing Texan with a slightly out-of-scale head and a mild Dr. Pepper addiction. Anything you’d like to add?

speaker: You’re right. Let’s talk about your grandmother.
response: No! I call no Meemaws.

speaker: Think about this. The only way your mother was born was your Meemaw had sex.
response: I don’t want to hear this.

speaker: Then let go of the ring and walk away.
response: Never.

speaker: All right. I’ll bet your Meemaw didn’t just have sex to have your mother. I bet she had sex because she liked it.
response: Stop it!

speaker: Yeah, Meemaw did the nasty.
response: I said stop it!

speaker: We’re getting to him.
response: Waterfalls!

speaker: What?
response: Waterfalls. Crashing waves. Babbling brooks.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Subliminal messaging. I’m going to make you want to pee. Dripping faucets. Leaky gutter. Peeing.

speaker: It’s, it’s not working, dude.
response: Oh-ho-ho, it’s working all right. I have to pee.

speaker: Fine. Um, on the count of three. One, two…
response: Wait, just to clarify. When you get to three, do we stand up or do we pee?

speaker: We stand up.
response: Excellent choice.

speaker: Problem?
response: This is Thai food.

speaker: Here we go.
response: We don’t have Thai food on Thursday. We have pizza on Thursday.

speaker: Yes, but we all agreed that the third Thursday of every month would be Anything Can Happen Thursday.
response: Well apparently the news didn’t reach my digestive system, which, when startled, has its own version of Anything Can Happen Thursday.

speaker: Come on, the whole idea behind Anything Can Happen Thursday is to get out of this rut we’ve been in lately.
response: Rut? I think you mean consistency. And if we’re going to abandon that, then why even call it Thursday? Let’s call it Quonko Day and divide it into 29 hours of 17 minutes apiece, and celebrate it by sacrificing a goat to the mighty god Ra.

speaker: Sheldon, we agreed we’d do something different tonight.
response: All right. Let’s go to the comic book store.

speaker: We went to the comic book store last night.
response: Last night was Wednesday. Wednesday is comic book night. Tonight, we’ll be going on Thursday, because it’s Anything Can Happen Thursday.

speaker: Really? Are you familiar with the Drake Equation?
response: The one that estimates the odds of making contact with extraterrestrials by calculating the product of an increasingly restrictive series of fractional values such as those stars with planets, and those planets likely to develop life? N equals R times FP times NE times FL times FI times FC times L?

speaker: You heard that, Ladies’ Night ladies? We’re eventually coming for you!
response: Fascinating.

speaker: You got me. While you’re there, could pick me up a few comics for my nephew’s birthday?
response: I think you mean comic books. Comics are feeble attempts at humour featuring talking babies and anthropomorphized pets found traditionally in the optimistically named funny pages.

speaker: I don’t know, he’s 13. Just pick out anything.
response: Just pick out anything? Maybe at the same time we can pick out a new suit for him without knowing his size, or pick out his career for him without knowing his aptitude, or pick out a new breakfast cereal without knowing his fibre requirements or his feelings about little marshmallows.

speaker: Spider-Man. Get him Spider-Man.
response: Amazing Spider-Man, Ultimate Spider-Man, Spectacular Spider-Man, The Marvelous Adventures of Spider-Man, Spider-Man 2099?

speaker: Ugh, that’s what I was trying to avoid.
response: Oh, I forgot Sensational Spider-Man.

speaker: Unlikely. Here, what about this one for my nephew?
response: A superb choice.

speaker: Oh, great.
response: Yeah, provided he has already read Infinite Crisis and 52, and is familiar with the re-establishment of the DC multiverse.

speaker: What’s a multiverse?
response: Get her out of here.

speaker: Let it go, Sheldon.
response: Why should I let it go? I saw it first.

speaker: Yes, but I saw it from the front.
response: A far less impressive feat.

speaker: Oh, come on! I need this for my Batman collection.
response: I need it for my Robin collection.

speaker: Rock-Paper-Scissors-Lizard-Spock?
response: Why would I gamble? It’s mine. Let go.

speaker: You let go.
response: No, you!

speaker: Problem?
response: Yes, he won’t let go of my comic book.

speaker: It’s my comic book!
response: Leonard, we need a ruling.

speaker: I have got to learn how to draw. Hey!
response: Once again, defeated by your own prurient interests.

speaker: All right. So, um, just give me a call.
response: So, Leonard, how are you enjoying Anything Can Happen Thursday?

speaker: Apparently so.
response: Are you ill?

speaker: No.
response: All right. Then is it fair to say that you’re experiencing some sort of emotional turmoil over the events involving Penny earlier this evening?

speaker: When did you pick up on that?
response: A moment ago, when you turned off the TV in the middle of }during the classic Deep Space Nine/Star Trek The Original Series Trouble With Tribbles crossover episode. Would you like some advice?

speaker: Sure, why not?
response: Then, this is the perfect time to launch a blog with an interactive comments section.

speaker: Gee, thanks a lot.
response: Would you rather I offer my personal insight?

speaker: I don’t need any insights. I just want to know why Penny’s more interested in Stuart than me. We’re practically the same guy.
response: Oh, I disagree. Stuart is taller, artistic, self-employed and, most significantly, he gets 45 percent off comic books.

speaker: You’re right, I really should be asking strangers on the Internet.
response: My original point.

speaker: It’s Friday night, that means Chinese food and vintage video games, right?
response: Vintage doesn’t even begin to describe what we have planned. Tonight, we are playing the classic 1980 interactive text adventure, Zork. It’s the buggy beta version.

speaker: Oh, you think coffee, means coffee, that is so sweet. Come on, I think I have decaf.
response: Oh, good, Stuart, I thought I heard your voice. Do you have a moment?

speaker: Sheldon, we’re a little busy here, so…
response: What are you doing?

speaker: We’re having coffee.
response: Isn’t it a little late for coffee?

speaker: What’s up?
response: Well, I’ve spent the last three hours in an online debate in the DC Comics Batman chatroom, and I need your help.

speaker: Oh yeah. Those guys can be very stubborn. What’s the topic?
response: I am asserting, in the event that Batman’s death proves permanent, that original Robin, Dick Grayson, is the logical successor to the Bat Cowl.

speaker: Ooh, Sheldon, I’m afraid you couldn’t be more wrong.
response: More wrong? Wrong is an absolute state and not subject to gradation.

speaker: Of course it is. It’s a little wrong to say a tomato is a vegetable, it’s very wrong to say it’s a suspension bridge. But returning to the original issue, Dick Grayson became Nightwing, a superhero in his own right. Batman 2 has to be the second Robin, Jason Todd.
response: Has to be? Has to be? I hope you’re being deliberately provocative.

speaker: Oh, great!
response: Yeah, herbal tea for me, please.

speaker: I’m sorry, but you’re obviously stuck in a pre-Zero Hour DC universe.
response: Of course I am. Removing Joe Chill as the k*ll of Batman’s parents effectively deprived him of his raison d’être.

speaker: Okay, you can throw all the French around you want, it doesn’t make you right.
response: Au contraire.

speaker: Plus, you’re forgetting that the Infinite Crisis storyline restored Joe Chill to the Batman mythology.
response: I am forgetting nothing and I resent your tone.

speaker: Okay, look, Sheldon, it’s late and I’ve got to get some sleep.
response: So, I win.

speaker: No, I’m tired.
response: So, I win.

speaker: Fine. You win.
response: Darn tootin’, I win.

speaker: Penny, I really had a terrific time. Penny?
response: No, no, no, no, don’t wake her. She’ll maul you like a rabid wolverine.

speaker: This is an easy one. You love this guy.
response: Me.

speaker: Come on, he's an under-appreciated genius.
response: Still think it's me.

speaker: It's not you. Now think, there's a car named after him.
response: Of course there is. The Mini Cooper, 'cause it's me.

speaker: How about this, he's a poor man's Sheldon Cooper.
response: Oh, Tesla.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hey, how did it go?

speaker: Yeah. It's a deviated septum. The surgery to correct it is simple. He's gonna do it next week.
response: Why would you have surgery?

speaker: Yeah, back off, he's all mine.
response: But you don't have a life-threatening condition. Why would you take the risk of surgery?

speaker: Sheldon, it's a routine procedure, I've heard you complain about his snoring.
response: Yes, for the first five or six years, but I've gotten used to it. It helps me sleep. He's like my mucus-powered white noise machine.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm gonna get the surgery, it's no big deal. End of story.
response: Very well. I'm done talking about it.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I believe it was your turn in the game.

speaker: Okay.
response: Let's see. Oh, this person is most famous for never having gotten his nose mutilated with elective surgery and never living the rest of his life in the shadows as a hideous, disfigured freak.

speaker: I think you could give a better clue.
response: I don't. I'm not even sure if that's a person or a typo.

speaker: Okay, why?
response: I'm listening to you snore. I'm wondering how I'll ever sleep without it.

speaker: If it helps you sleep, then why are you sitting here staring at me like the albino boogeyman?
response: Really Leonard. Insults? After I spent two hours in your closet, waiting for you to fall asleep?

speaker: What's your problem?
response: If the surgery is successful, the snoring is gone. And if you die during surgery, the snoring is gone.

speaker: It sounds like either way, I finally get some rest.
response: I have to be honest with you Leonard, I'm truly worried.

speaker: I told you, there's nothing to worry about.
response: Well, I've been doing some research and I've learned that one in 700,000 people die from general anaesthesia.

speaker: Buddy, wh, do you realize that that also means 699,999 people don't die?
response: I suppose that's true. You're such a glass half-full kind of guy. I'm going to miss that.

speaker: Hey. What're you working on?
response: Remember when I said if you went through with your surgery, there was a one-in-700,000 chance of dying?

speaker: Yeah?
response: Well, I've been crunching the numbers, and so far, I've gotten your probability of death all the way to a sphincter-tightening one in 300.

speaker: Great timing. My check sphincter light just went on.
response: Leonard, what if you have an allergic reaction to the surgeon's latex gloves?

speaker: I'm not allergic to latex.
response: Well, then why don't you wear the rubber gloves I bought for you to do the dishes?

speaker: For the same reason I don't wear the apron or the hair net.
response: Fine. What about epilepsy?

speaker: I don't have epilepsy, either.
response: You don't, but the surgeon might, hmm? And your carotid artery is just one shaky scalpel away from becoming the dancing fountain at Disneyland.

speaker: Sheldon, do you realize that driving is riskier than surgery?
response: I do. I have the drive to the hospital right here. That is if you make it to the car without falling down the stairs. And don't expect me to carry you, I do that enough in life.

speaker: Buddy, I, I get that you're worried about me and I, I appreciate that, but I'm not going to die.
response: You don't know that.

speaker: Well, I do know that it won't be from an asteroid strike.
response: You know who else said that? Every cocky T. Rex currently swimming around in the gas t*nk of your car.

speaker: If there was an asteroid strike, wouldn't you die, too?
response: I don't know, I'm smart and scrappy, I think I'd find a way.

speaker: Tell you what, the surgery's not for a week, I'll think about it.
response: Thank you. And while you're thinking about it, if you have the surgery in Nicaragua during monsoon season, I can practically guarantee your death.

speaker: He was so busy figuring out how many parts per million of urine we'd be floating around in, he didn't even question it.
response: 18 parts per million. And he's still doing it.

speaker: Don't worry about that. I'm happy to take you to work.
response: Well, thank you. And Leonard never lets me have French toast sticks in the car. I can't have syrupy fingers, but he can do the backstroke in a toilet bowl.

speaker: It's nice they're getting exercise.
response: Although now that I think about it, Leonard would never go swimming in public without his swim shirt.

speaker: I'm sure he brought it.
response: No, but last year, at Magic Mountain, he got such a bad sunburn, we had to cut him out of it.

speaker: He probably got a new one. Finish your breakfast. Look, there's an entire section of my dashboard that doesn't have any syrup on it.
response: You're acting odd. Why?

speaker: I'm odd all the time, everyone knows that. Just last night I tried to see how many fava beans I could fit in my mouth.
response: Tell me the truth.

speaker: Twenty eight.
response: Come on.

speaker: Fifty six.
response: Amy. What's going on?

speaker: All right. Don't get upset, but, an earlier appointment opened up for Leonard and he's getting the surgery right now.
response: I see. Take me to Leonard.

speaker: Just go to work, he'll be fine.
response: Amy, he's my best friend, and if you don't take me, I'm going there anyway.

speaker: Fine. It's sweet that you care about him so much.
response: I do. And I wouldn't be able to forgive myself if something happened to him and I wasn't at his bedside to say I told you so.

speaker: We had a really nice swim.
response: Oh, stop it. I assume this medical centre's already treated the burns on your bottom from the recent pants fire.

speaker: ‘Cause I'm a liar, liar?
response: That's for the fire marshal to determine.

speaker: He wore me down. And I was distracted, he has on extra baby powder today.
response: Is he okay?

speaker: He's still in surgery.
response: Very well.

speaker: Come on, let's talk about something other than the surgery.
response: That's a good idea. Penny, did you and Leonard ever discuss funeral arrangements?

speaker: I think she meant something a little happier.
response: I suppose we could try to make it a celebration, but he died so young.

speaker: Oh, it's nice you got him that.
response: Oh, this isn't for Leonard, no. Amy bought it for me.

speaker: Stubbed his toe on the revolving door on the way in.
response: You know those confounded things make me dizzy.

speaker: Who told you to keep going around?
response: There was a large plant in the lobby. It kept looking like the outside.

speaker: Penny has a good point. This is like the man in the supermarket with the goiter on his neck. Whatever you're thinking, just keep it to yourself.
response: It was like a grapefruit.

speaker: And I'm sure he knew that before you held a grapefruit up next to it.
response: Well, I'm not making any promises. Not only did Leonard take what I feel is an unnecessary risk, he deceived me.

speaker: Okay, the reason he deceived you is you were being a pain in the ass.
response: The reason I was being a pain in the B is because I was worried about him, and no one else was.

speaker: Really? You won't even say A?
response: You bet your sweet B I won't.

speaker: Obviously, I care about Leonard. I'm gonna spend the rest of my life with him.
response: And I'm not? It's an earthquake. I knew it.

speaker: Sheldon, it was just a little tremor.
response: A little tremor that turns routine sinus surgery into a frontal lobotomy. Oh, I don't care for this at all. Oh, I need to see he's okay.

speaker: Sheldon, you can't go back there.
response: Try and stop me.

speaker: Are you okay?
response: Why didn't you stop me?

speaker: Come on, smile. This is gonna be my Christmas card.
response: You know this is all your fault.

speaker: How is it my fault?
response: I told you not to get the surgery.

speaker: Okay, first of all, the surgery was a success, and secondly, I didn't even want you there.
response: Wow. I don't know which hurts worse, my nose or my heart. Well, I'm done speaking to you.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm sorry I didn't tell you about the surgery, but you were worried about nothing.
response: Oh, you're hardly out of the woods, no. You still run the risk of infection, a blood clot, the possibility that an inattentive surgeon let a barn spider lay eggs in your nose. The minute you sneeze web, I'm moving out.

speaker: Yeah, once he figures out how to work a door.
response: I was not panicked, and I am not overly attached to Leonard.

speaker: You were so worried that you smashed your face trying to check on me. You love me.
response: Yeah. Tell me those aren't the words of a man with a spider eating its way through his brain. Amy, you're a neuroscientist. Crack his skull open, spray some Raid in there.

speaker: Oh, what'd you get?
response: Oh, I ordered it before your surgery. It's the urn I was going to put you in.

speaker: Okay, that's morbid. Send it back.
response: I can't send it back, I had it engraved. Here lie the ashes of Leonard Hofstadter. He thought he was right, but his room mate knew better.”

speaker: Hey, why did you get two? I'm with stupid.
response: Oh, that one's mine.

speaker: Yes, but when they're hungry-hungry, you can stop them with marbles.
response: Yeah, the correct animal for interspecies supersolider is koala. You would wind up with an army so cute it couldn't be attacked.

speaker: But half-man, half-owl could fly…
response: The answer is cuddly soldiers with big flat noses. Moving on.

speaker: I said I'll get to it.
response: I'm sensing awkwardness, am I right?

speaker: Yes.
response: Swish.

speaker: Mm, I don't know. Who here has ever been hurt because they were the teacher's pet?
response: It was like the rest of the class wanted Ms. McDonald to forget the quiz.

speaker: Dr. Cooper.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) That's right, good job. Hello. Uh, you wanted to see me?

speaker: Yes. Uh, welcome back.
response: Thank you. I assume you'd like to reopen our dialogue about the university forcing me to continue with string theory?

speaker: You mean the dialogue that went, please, no, please, no, please, no.
response: That's the one. I believe you went last, so, uh, please?

speaker: Dr. Cooper, while you were away, we came up with a solution that would allow you to change your field of study.
response: Wow. Pouting and running away actually worked. I must say, that may not be a lesson you want to reinforce with me. So, um, what is the solution?

speaker: Currently, you're being paid under a grant to specifically research string theory. If we promote you to junior professor, you'll be able to choose whatever field of research you'd like.
response: But if I'm a professor, then I'll have to teach a class.

speaker: That is correct.
response: So your solution is to promote me and pay me more money so that I can impart my knowledge to the next generation of scientists?

speaker: Yes.
response: You people are sick.

speaker: Hey, how'd it go with human resources?
response: Awful. They're allowing me to move on from string theory, but they made me a junior professor and are requiring me to teach a class.

speaker: I don't understand. Why is it bad that you have to teach?
response: What a stupid question.

speaker: The kids are gonna love him.
response: I can't believe I have to waste my time babysitting a bunch of grad students who probably think dark matter is what's in their diapers.

speaker: This might not be that bad. Uh, you like telling people they're wrong.
response: Wrong, Just because I enjoyed that one doesn't mean I always do.

speaker: You enjoy giving people grades.
response: A valid point, but unoriginal. B-minus.

speaker: And you love the sound of your own voice.
response: Yeah, well, of course I do. Listen to it. It's like an earful of melted caramel.

speaker: Look, most importantly, this will let you move on and study dark matter.
response: It is true that many of my heroes have taken students under their wings. Feynman, Einstein, Professor X. Humorously, in the case of Professor X, some of his students actually had wings. That's rich. I'll use that one to lighten the mood after my entire class fails the midterm.

speaker: Hey. We just wanted to see how your class was going. Where is everybody?
response: There is no class.

speaker: Did you send everyone to the principal's office already?
response: No one signed up.

speaker: Well, that's not your fault.
response: I called the department secretary to see what happened. Apparently, I have a reputation for being obnoxious.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I'm sorry.
response: No, it's fine. Now I can devote all my time to dark matter.

speaker: Aw, you brought cookies for everyone?
response: Oh, yes. Fig Newtons. I was going to ask them which scientist both helped to develop calculus and had a famous cookie named after him? And then after someone said Newton, I was going to tell them they're wrong. The cookies are named after a town in Massachusetts. And then I'd throw the cookies away.

speaker: Hey, what if I took your class?
response: Why would you do that?

speaker: I'm thinking about getting my doctorate, and he wants to teach. Why not?
response: Oh, Howard. I appreciate the gesture, but this is a graduate-level physics class. I don't think you'd understand a single thing I was talking about.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm more than smart enough to take your class.
response: No.

speaker: Yes.
response: How would you determine the ground state of a quantum system with no exact solution?

speaker: I would guess a wave-function and then vary its parameters until I found the lowest energy solution.
response: Hmm. Do you know how to integrate X squared times E to the minus X, without looking it up?

speaker: I'd use Feynman's trick, differentiate under the integral sign.
response: Okay. Um, what is the correct interpretation of quantum mechanics?

speaker: Since every interpretation gives exactly the same answer to every measurement, they are all equally correct. However, I know you believe in the Many Worlds Interpretation, so I'll say that. Now do you think I'm smart enough?
response: No.

speaker: Oh, come on. You might've gone to school for a couple more years than me, but guess what, engineers are just as smart as physicists.
response: You take that back.

speaker: So, after drinks with Bernadette, I get home, and Penny calls to complain about her. And then while I'm talking to Penny, I get a text from Bernadette.
response: I am trying to prepare my lesson plan for Howard. Why are you telling me this?

speaker: Because it's taken 15 years, but high school is finally awesome. I love them both, but I'm in the centre now, and I love that even more.
response: Amy, please. I am trying to figure out a way to intellectually emasculate a dear friend of mine.

speaker: But I'm just…
response: Not now.

speaker: Hmm. You're up late.
response: Oh, I'm working on my lesson plan for Wolowitz. He is going to be so lost. Look at this section over here. Even I don't really understand it.

speaker: Sheldon, why are you doing this?
response: I'm a teacher, Leonard. It's my job.
