speaker: No, I mean, why are you going to so much trouble to prove that you're smarter than Wolowitz?
response: Oh, it's no trouble, it's actually a pleasure.

speaker: You want to know what I think? I think the idea that someone could be as smart as you, or even smarter, scares the pants off you, and you can't deal with it.
response: Interesting point. You're suggesting that I have emotional issues below my consciousness which drive my behaviour, thus causing me to lash out at anything or anyone that threatens my intellectual superiority.

speaker: Might be something to think about.
response: Leonard?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Howard's allergic to peanuts. How can I use that against him?

speaker: Hey.
response: Okay, now that everyone's here, we can begin.

speaker: Before we do, I just talked to Leonard. And if you're gonna spend all your time trying to belittle me by making this class unnecessarily hard, then I'm out. But if you're interested in making a sincere effort to be a good teacher, then I'm willing to give this a sh*t.
response: I suppose that's a fair request. There's no reason we both can't benefit from this experience.

speaker: Okay.
response: Okay. Well, then, uh, first things first. Um, are you familiar with the Brachistochrone problem?

speaker: I am.
response: Good. And how it relates to the calculus of variations?

speaker: It's an inverted cycloid.
response: Wonderful. Now, what about Euler-Lagrange theorems?

speaker: That's where I'm a little fuzzy.
response: Ha! I knew it. All right. We have a lot of information to cover before your first test. Which, by the way, is in eight minutes. The good news is I'm grading on a curve, so you're pretty much guaranteed a C.

speaker: ♪ All I do is win, win, win no matter what. ♪
response: What are you doing?

speaker: ♪ Everybody hands go up, up and they stay there! ♪
response: What are you doing?

speaker: If you're gonna be a crappy teacher, then I'm gonna be a crappy student. (Singing) ♪ Uh, uh, Ludacris going in on the verse. 'cause I never been defeated and I won't stop now... ♪
response: Will you stop it. This is a classroom. This is not American Bandstand.

speaker: Okay.
response: Now, where was I? Let's see. Oh, yes. Over here. You… What are you doing now?

speaker: Making a straw.
response: Why?

speaker: So I can sh**t you with a spitball.
response: You're not going to do that, and I'll tell you why. This is an institution of higher learning, I am your professor, and you're going to treat me with the prop… You sh*t your spit in my mouth!

speaker: You mean, like, where she's nice to your face? Okay got it. Bye. Hey, boyfriend.
response: Can't talk. Spitball. Probably gonna die.

speaker: Sheldon, I promise. Your uvula does not have an STD.
response: Are you sure? It just doesn't feel as innocent as it used to.

speaker: You reported me to human resources?
response: You violated the sanctity of my mouth.

speaker: Well, I dropped your class, so I hope you're happy.
response: I told you you weren't smart enough to take it.

speaker: I'm smart enough, Sheldon. Asking me a bunch of questions about a topic I'm not familiar with doesn't prove anything. I could do the same to you.
response: Yeah, try me.

speaker: Okay. You enjoy making fun of engineering so much, how do you quantify the strength of materials?
response: Young's modulus.

speaker: Yeah. Okay, how do you prevent eddy currents in a transformer?
response: Laminate the core material.

speaker: That was a hard one. All right. How does the flow rate in a pipe depend on its diameter? You don't know, do you? What's the matter, smart guy? Don't know Poiseuille's law?
response: Thank goodness I got it. Now I can quit checking my stool.

speaker: Okay, this one is for a Cadbury Creme Egg.
response: Oh! It's not even Easter time. This is crazy.

speaker: What?
response: I can’t comment without violating our agreement that I don’t criticize your work.

speaker: Then what was oh, boy?
response: Great restraint on my part.

speaker: There’s nothing wrong with the science here.
response: Perhaps you mean a different thing than I do when you say science.

speaker: Okay, how’s that?
response: You actually had it right in the first place. Once again, you’ve fallen for one of my classic pranks. Bazinga! Well, now here’s a peculiar e-mail. The president of the university wants me to meet him at his office tomorrow morning at 8 a.m.

speaker: Why?
response: It doesn’t say. It must be an emergency. Everyone at the university knows I eat breakfast at eight and move my bowels at 8

speaker: Yes, how did we live before Twitter? I guess you’ll find out what it is in the morning.
response: That’s 14 hours away. For the next 840 minutes, I’m effectively one of Heisenberg’s particles, I know where I am or I know how fast I’m going, but I can’t know both. Yet how am I supposed to carry on with this huge annoying thing hovering over my head?

speaker: Sheldon, it’s two o’clock in the morning.
response: Why is everybody keep telling me what time it is?

speaker: Everybody?
response: You, the president of the university, his wife, their sullen teenage daughter. That entire family is fascinated by what time it is and whether people know it.

speaker: You went to President Seibert’s house in the middle of the night?
response: He didn’t respond to my e-mail, his phone number is unlisted. Tell me what my other option was.

speaker: You could have waited until morning. I know, look who I’m talking to.
response: Do you remember the grant proposal I submitted to the National Science Foundation to detect slow-moving monopoles at the magnetic North Pole?

speaker: Hardly a day goes by when I don’t think about it.
response: Aw, how nice. Well, a space opened up at the last minute on the NSF expedition to the Arctic Circle.

speaker: Wait a minute. He offered to send you to the North Pole?
response: Yes. In fact, he was quite enthusiastic. He said, “Frankly, if I could send you tonight, I would.”

speaker: Okay, well, do you want to go?
response: Of course not. I’m a theoretical physicist, a career I chose in no small part because it’s indoors, but if I’m able to detect slow-moving magnetic monopoles there, I will be the scientist to confirm string theory. People will write books about me. Third-graders will create macaroni-art dioramas depicting scenes from my life.

speaker: Sure, maybe a tableau of me trying to pummel you to death.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: Maybe.
response: I’m on the horns of a dilemma. Can you imagine me, Sheldon Cooper, at the North Pole?

speaker: Easy peasy, I’m doing it right now.
response: I’m not good with cold, Leonard. How often have we had to leave a movie theatre because I got a headache from drinking the Icee too fast? I can’t go.

speaker: Well, then don’t go.
response: How can you say that? The scientific opportunity of a lifetime presents itself and my best friend says don’t go.

speaker: All right, then go.
response: Listen to you. How can I possibly go?

speaker: Sheldon, what are the words I can say right now to end this conversation and let me go back to sleep?
response: Odd, President Seibert posed the exact same question.

speaker: How was it resolved?
response: It wasn’t. His wife set their dogs on me and rendered the question moot.

speaker: Our dreams are very small, aren’t they?
response: Good news, gentlemen, I have tentatively accepted…

speaker: Yeah! Woo-hoo!
response: …the invitation to join the Arctic Expedition.

speaker: Godspeed.
response: Thank you, but your sentiments may be premature.

speaker: Ooh, I don’t like where this is going.
response: I would like to propose that the three of you accompany me.

speaker: To the North Pole?
response: Yes.

speaker: Is this just so we won’t touch your stuff while you’re away?
response: I’ll admit that was a concern. But the fact is, I’ll need a support team. And the three of you are my first choice.

speaker: Really?
response: Well, there are others who might be more qualified, but the thought of interviewing them gave me a stomach ache. Now, I know I’m proposing an enormous undertaking, so why don’t you take a few moments to discuss it?

speaker: We’re not really gonna go to the North Pole with him, are we?
response: I’m still within earshot! You may want to wait for my door to close.

speaker: Well, I’m a Hindu. My religion teaches that if we suffer in this life we are rewarded in the next. Three months at the North Pole with Sheldon and I’m reborn as a well-hung billionaire with wings!
response: Well, gentlemen, have you reached a decision?

speaker: Oh, damn it. Peer pressure. Fine.
response: Excellent. And just an FYI, as I am the expedition’s team leader, protocol dictates that be phrased fine, sir. But don’t worry, there will be a briefing.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: What do you want?
response: I need access to the Cheesecake Factory’s walk-in freezer.

speaker: Now, honey, I already told you, the hamburger meat is fresh and stored at a safe temperature.
response: No. This is to train for a three-month expedition to the magnetic North Pole.

speaker: What?
response: I don’t know how that sentence could possibly confuse you, but to elaborate, I’m going to the Arctic Circle with Leonard, Wolowitz and Koothrappali.

speaker: You’re all going?
response: Yes.

speaker: For three months?
response: Yes.

speaker: Excuse me.
response: Is that a yes or a no on the freezer? The woman has the attention span of a gnat.

speaker: Oh, hey, no, you don’t have to apologize. There’s no reason you have to tell me. I was just, you know, surprised.
response: Yes, yes, you were busy, you were surprised, all very fascinating. Now where do we stand on the freezer?

speaker: Yeah.
response: I’m sorry, but at what point do you put this see what you can do plan into action?

speaker: Did she seem upset to you?
response: No. Did she seem upset to you?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, good, I got it right. Are you upset?

speaker: A little bit.
response: Two for two. I’m on fire.

speaker: I mean, I know she’s not my girlfriend or anything, but wouldn’t you think she’d feel a little bad that I’m going to be gone for the whole summer?
response: That feels like a bonus question. I’m going to stop here while I’m ahead, but I’ve had a great time.

speaker: Where are your tools?
response: Right here. All right, team, open up your practice kits. As the university did not permit me to bring the actual equipment we’ll be using to the Cheesecake Factory, because apparently I’m “ridiculous,” I’ve provided substitutes which will exercise your fine motor k*ll. Leonard, you will be doing a series of complex mathematical problems on a vintage Casio model 1175 calculator watch I received when I won the Earth Science medal in 3rd grade. Treat it with respect. Raj, you will be painting sideburns and a Van d*ke on a six-inch figurine of Legolas the elf. Now, remember, a Van d*ke is a goatee without a moustache. Wolowitz, you will be completing a series of delicate surgical procedures on the classic children’s game, Operation. To begin with, you will remove funny bone for two hundred dollars.

speaker: For this I went to MIT.
response: And begin.

speaker: I can’t press any of the buttons with my gloves. Oh, son of a bitch!
response: Adversity is to be expected. Continue.

speaker: Me either.
response: Gentlemen, use your imagination. Innovate. Did Han Solo let Luke Skywalker freeze to death on the ice planet of Hoth? No. He cut open a tauntaun and used its internal body heat to warm him up.

speaker: Hang on, I know I don’t possess the tools of leadership, but I don’t understand why we can’t assemble the equipment inside the hut and then take it outside.
response: I hadn’t thought of that. I guess we’re done here.

speaker: What is it?
response: It’s hot chocolate with a stick of butter.

speaker: Okay, why?
response: Because in the frigid temperatures in the Arctic, we need to consume at least 5,000 calories a day just to maintain our body weight.

speaker: Sheldon, you know I can’t eat butter. I’m lactose intolerant.
response: Way ahead of you, that’s an “I Can’t Believe It’s Not Butter” stick.

speaker: So, she has no problem with her son being eaten by a walrus?
response: That’s very unlikely, Mrs. Koothrappali. If Raj dies, it’ll be from frostbite, gangrene, acute sunburn or being ripped to shreds by a fifteen hundred pound polar bear.

speaker: Sheldon, Sheldon?
response: I want a cookie, Meemaw.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s me.
response: But Meemaw just made cookies.

speaker: Listen, I don’t know if I can go on the expedition.
response: What?

speaker: I don’t think I can go to the North Pole.
response: Okay, Leonard, I know you’re concerned about disappointing me but I want you to take comfort from the knowledge that my expectations of you are very low.

speaker: Yeah, that’s very comforting.
response: Comforting is a part of leadership. It’s not a part I care for, but such is my burden.

speaker: Terrific, it’s just that I don’t think Penny wants me to go.
response: Assuming that’s a valid reason not to go, which it isn’t, how do you know this? Did she say it?

speaker: Not exactly. But she said she was gonna miss me and she gave me this.
response: What is it?

speaker: It’s a blanket with sleeves.
response: Oh, that’s clever. Let me see if I understand this correctly. Her missing you is an emotional state you find desirable?

speaker: Yes, obviously.
response: All right. Well, given that missing you is predicated on you leaving, logic dictates you must leave.

speaker: Yes, okay, but I’m gonna be gone for three months. What if she doesn’t miss me that long and she meets someone else?
response: She does have a short attention span.

speaker: So, I can’t go.
response: Leonard, you may be right. It appears that Penny secretly wants you in her life in a very intimate and carnal fashion.

speaker: You really think so?
response: Of course not. Even in my sleep-deprived state, I’ve managed to pull off another one of my classic pranks. Bazinga!

speaker: We’re out of ice.
response: All right, men, we begin initial assembly and deployment of the testing equipment starting tomorrow at 0700 hours, but until then, you are all off duty. I suggest you keep the shenanigans to a minimum as medical help is 18 hours away by dogsled.

speaker: Yeah, wow.
response: It is remarkable.

speaker: Dinner’s ready!
response: What are we having?

speaker: Reconstituted Thai food.
response: Did you bring the dehydrated low-sodium soy sauce?

speaker: Check.
response: Freeze-dried spicy mustard?

speaker: Check.
response: Flash-frozen brown rice, not white?

speaker: Uh, oh, sorry.
response: Not to worry. I hid it. Bazinga! You’re in my spot.

speaker: There’s no time for a crossbow. Find me an icicle.
response: Three months. This is gonna be great!

speaker: Hey. So you guys ready to order?
response: Since we come in every Tuesday night at six o’clock and order the same exact thing, and it’s now six oh eight, I believe your question not only answers itself but also stands alongside such other nonsensical queries as who let the dogs out? and, uh, How are they hanging?

speaker: Oh, gee, Amy, I’m sorry, I’m actually pretty busy this weekend.
response: Probably serving food that was ordered today.

speaker: Boy, this is great. I haven’t had a vacation in ages.
response: In order to take a vacation, one first has to work.

speaker: That does seem to be a valid principle.
response: I trust Penny will adhere to the Official California Restaurant Workers’ Solemn Oath of Ethics and Cleanliness.”

speaker: I don’t believe there’s any such thing.
response: You lied to me?

speaker: Don’t worry. Just sit next to me during the quiz, and you can copy my answers.
response: Raj? What are you doing? I don’t think so. You’ve had your allotted six ounces. The first bathroom break isn’t until the Denny’s located near Bakersfield, which is approximately two and half hours away. Remember, people, we’re only as strong as our weakest bladder.

speaker: Nobody cares about your Kegel exercises.
response: All right. We have seven people, and two cars. In the lead car, driven by Leonard, will be myself, Amy Farrah Fowler and Penny.

speaker: Yay!
response: She made the case that if we break down in the middle of nowhere, your Nebraska backwoods k*ll and brawny hands will give us the best chance to survive in the wild.

speaker: Fine. Red Five to Red Leader. What do you want now?
response: It’s eleven fifteen. I’m requesting your quarter-hourly location update.

speaker: Still right behind you.
response: Copy that, Red Five. Radio contact is sufficient. No need to extend your middle finger.

speaker: No, we discussed it. We decided we didn’t want to jeopardize our relationship by getting to know each other too well.
response: Indeed. Nothing sours a friendship more than over-familiarity with someone’s toilet routine.

speaker: Are you an element in the actinoid series?
response: No. Amy?

speaker: Are you usually radioactive when found in nature?
response: No.

speaker: Are you in the lanthanoid series?
response: Amy, it’s Penny’s turn. Penny?

speaker: Uh, I don’t know. Are you food?
response: That’s not apropos. We’ve already established I’m found in the periodic table.

speaker: Well, it’s a table, right? I mean, why can’t there be food on it?
response: I knew she wasn’t lead car material.

speaker: Who elected you Road Trip God?
response: Leonard.

speaker: It was a late-night vote. We were all exhausted, and he was threatening to filibuster. It’s not technically Road Trip God, it’s Travel Supervisor.
response: Although Road Trip God does have a certain ring to it.

speaker: Good night.
response: Please tell me you’re not having coitus.

speaker: We are not having coitus.
response: Can you guarantee that it won’t happen at any time during the night?

speaker: Oh, my God, I’m crying already.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Raj? (Knock, knock, knock) Raj? (Knock, knock, knock) Raj? I need to sleep here tonight.

speaker: Why?
response: Howard is a complete and total ass, Bernadette is in Penny’s bed, Amy bites, and Penny may or may not have coitus with Leonard.

speaker: Are we talking about women wanting penises? Because I’d like to weigh in.
response: Dr. Koothrappali, would you care to join the conversation?

speaker: We weren’t getting back together! It was a one-time thing!
response: Excuse me. We’re not taking comments or questions from the audience just yet.

speaker: Yeah, hi.
response: All right, why don’t we see if we can bring this back to topic.

speaker: Let me ask you something, Bernie.
response: I guess not.

speaker: I’d like to weigh in here. No.
response: All right, why don’t we open it up to Q&A from the audience?

speaker: Because we’re going 120 miles per hour.
response: All right, if no one’s going to guess, I was spying the aluminium rims on the police car we passed a few miles back.

speaker: Hey, Leonard, check this out. (Throws some food in the air and catches it in her mouth)
response: Leonard, she’s doing it again.

speaker: I think it upsets Sheldon when you play with the food.
response: No. It upsets Sheldon when she willy-nilly takes it from the containers without regard for its equitable distribution. This is essentially why you have famine in India.

speaker: You want me to put it back?
response: Leonard.

speaker: What’s up, my nerdizzles? Raj, Sheldon, I want you to meet my girlfriend Bernadette.
response: Hello.

speaker: Sure. The more, the merrier.
response: Wait, no, that’s a false equivalency. More does not equal merry. If there were 2,000 people in this apartment right now, would we be celebrating? No, we’d be suffocating.

speaker: Sheldon…
response: Don’t Sheldon me. We ordered for five people, not six.

speaker: Oh, come on, it’s fine. We’ll just put it all on the table, you know, family style.
response: Oh, sure. And while we’re at it, why don’t we put our hands behind our backs, have an old-fashioned eating contest?

speaker: Oh no, no, you see, in the winter, that seat is close enough to the radiator so that he’s warm, yet not so close that he sweats. In the summer, it’s directly in the path of a cross-breeze created by opening windows there and there. It faces the television at an angle that isn’t direct, so he can still talk to everybody, yet not so wide that the picture looks distorted.
response: Perhaps there’s hope for you after all.

speaker: Oh, great selection, great prices.
response: My mother was right. Hell is real.

speaker: That’s amazing.
response: Yes. Leonard’s work is nearly as amazing as third graders growing lima beans in wet paper towels. (Raj whispers to him) While I appreciate the oh, snap, I’m uncomfortable having your moist breath in my ear.

speaker: Oh, yeah, show me. In microbiology, the most exciting thing I get to work with is yeast.
response: Howard?

speaker: Yeah?
response: Your shoes are delightful. Where did you get them?

speaker: What?
response: Bazinga. I don’t care.

speaker: Ha! Eat my dust, racially stereotypical plumber.
response: That’s not fair. I got stuck behind a tree.

speaker: And a cow and a penguin. Face it dude, whether it’s a real car or a virtual cartoon car, you can’t drive.
response: Just need a little more practice.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, can I talk to you for a second?
response: It’s not about shoes, is it? I don’t think I could go through that again.

speaker: It’s not about shoes.
response: Then speak.

speaker: Um, actually, can we do it in private?
response: All right. (To Raj) Go away. I agree, it’s rude, but she asked for privacy.

speaker: Thanks, Raj. Okay, so here’s the thing, I was wondering if you could maybe teach me a little physics?
response: A little physics? There’s no such thing. Physics encompasses the entire universe, from quantum particles to supernovas, from spinning electrons to spinning galaxies.

speaker: Yeah, okay, cool. I don’t need the PBS special, I just want to know enough so I can talk to Leonard about his job. You know, like Bernadette does.
response: Why can’t Leonard teach you?

speaker: ‘Cause I want to surprise him.
response: Can’t you surprise him in some other way? For example, I’m sure he’d be delightfully taken aback if you cleaned your apartment.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, this is important to me.
response: Penny, this would be a massive undertaking, and my time is both limited and valuable.

speaker: You’re sitting here playing video games all day.
response: Okay, point. What sort of foundation do you have? Did you take any science classes in school?

speaker: Sure. I did the one with the frogs.
response: The one with the frogs.

speaker: Yeah, actually, it was pretty cool. A lot of the girls threw up, but I gutted that thing like a deer.
response: I’m sorry, Penny, I don’t think so.

speaker: Oh, come on! A smart guy like you, it’ll be a challenge. You can make it like an experiment.
response: Interesting. I suppose if someone could teach sign language to KoKo the gorilla, I could teach you some rudimentary physics.

speaker: Great! It’s a little insulting, but great. I’ll be KoKo.
response: Not likely. KoKo learned to understand over 2,000 words, not one of which had anything to do with shoes.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Come in. Take a seat. Subject has arrived. I’ve extended a friendly casual greeting.

speaker: Ready to get started?
response: One moment. Subject appears well-rested and enthusiastic. Apparently, ignorance is bliss. All right, let us begin. Where’s your notebook?

speaker: Um, I don’t have one.
response: How are you going to take notes without a notebook?

speaker: I have to take notes?
response: How else are you gonna study for the tests?

speaker: There’s gonna be a test?
response: Tests. Here. It’s college-ruled. I hope that’s not too intimidating.

speaker: Thank you.
response: You’re welcome. Now, Introduction to Physics. What is physics? Physics comes from the ancient Greek word physika. It’s at this point that you’ll want to start taking notes. Physika means the science of natural things. And it is there, in ancient Greece, that our story begins.

speaker: Ancient Greece?
response: Hush. If you have questions, raise your hand. It’s a warm summer evening, circa 600 BC, you’ve finished your shopping at the local market, or agora, and you look up at the night sky. There you notice some of the stars seem to move, so you name them planetes, or wanderer. Yes, Penny?

speaker: Um, does this have anything to do with Leonard’s work?
response: This is the beginning of a twenty six hundred year journey we’re going to take together from the ancient Greeks through Isaac Newton to Niels Bohr to Erwin Schrodinger to the Dutch researchers that Leonard is currently ripping off.

speaker: Twenty six hundred years?
response: Yeah, give or take. As I was saying, it’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece… Yes, Penny?

speaker: I have to go to the bathroom.
response: Can’t you hold it?

speaker: Not for twenty six hundred years.
response: Project Gorilla, entry two. I am exhausted.

speaker: Uh, we know that… Newton was a really smart cookie. Oh! Is that where Fig Newtons come from?
response: No, Fig Newtons are named after a small town in Massachusetts. Don’t write that down!

speaker: Sorry.
response: Now, if MA equals MG what does that imply?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: How can you not know? I just told you. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

speaker: Hey! You don’t have to be so mean!
response: I’m sorry. (Smiling) Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

speaker: No, you just suck at teaching.
response: Really? Of those two explanations, which one seems the most likely?

speaker: Oh, God, Sheldon, look I’m trying to understand, but you’re going too fast. Can you just back up a little bit?
response: All right. It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…

speaker: Not that far back!
response: Okay! At what point did you begin to feel lost?

speaker: I don’t know. Where were we looking up at the night sky?
response: Greece.

speaker: Damn it!
response: There’s no need to get frustrated, people learn at different rates. Unlike objects falling in a vacuum, which…? MA equals MG?

speaker: Squared?
response: No.

speaker: Aristotle?
response: No.

speaker: Five?
response: Oh!

speaker: Then I don’t know.
response: Why are you crying?

speaker: Because I’m stupid!
response: That’s no reason to cry. One cries because one is sad. For example, I cry because others are stupid and it makes me sad.

speaker: Okay, look, can we just please forget about all this extra stuff and can you just tell me what Leonard does?
response: All right. Leonard is attempting to learn why sub-atomic particles move the way they do.

speaker: Really? That’s it? Well, that doesn’t sound so complicated.
response: It’s not. That’s why Leonard does it.

speaker: Okay, I just have one question. What exactly are sub-atomic particles?
response: A good question.

speaker: Thank you.
response: And to answer it, we first must ask ourselves, what is physics?

speaker: Oh, balls.
response: It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…

speaker: Not great. They hired divorce attorneys.
response: You know, speaking of attorneys, if I ever needed a lawyer, I would not hire She-Hulk.

speaker: Yeah, she works at a law firm in New York.
response: Yes, but she's the only monster at the firm. Between you, me and the wall, I think she's an affirmative action hire.

speaker: I've always wanted to do a traditional Victorian Christmas. Parlour games, goose and figgy pudding.
response: Ugh. English pudding. You get yourself all excited for pudding, and here comes a cake with raisins in it. I'm not going.

speaker: You're going.
response: Why do you hate me?

speaker: I don't hate you. I love you.
response: Well, you call it love, but it has a lot of raisins in it.

speaker: Here comes Santa Claus, here comes Santa Claus, right down Santa Claus Lane. Vixen and Blitzen and all his reindeer pulling on the reins.
response: Yeah, I appreciate the ride.

speaker: Bells are ringing, children singing, all is merry and bright. So hang your stockings and say your prayers 'cause Santa Claus is coming tonight. Why'd you turn it off?
response: Because in the last ten minutes, Santa came to town, kissed Mommy and ran Grandma over with a reindeer. I had a drunk uncle who did all those things. Nobody sings songs about him.

speaker: Maybe you'd like it more if you thought of Santa as a superhero and his power is bringing joy to children.
response: My uncle was accused of that, too. It turned out to be legal in Oklahoma.

speaker: Okay, new subject. Let's talk about presents. What did you get Amy?
response: Oh, we're not exchanging gifts.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, you have to get her something.
response: Why should I? She knows that I don't like Christmas, and yet, every year, she forces me to celebrate it. Not only am I going to this foolish dinner against my will, at the Christmas tree lot, there was mistletoe, and she kissed me under it in public. Like we were the stars of a Tijuana sex show.

speaker: She's just excited about the holidays.
response: Yes, and she's not taking my feelings into account at all. Maybe it's time I teach her a lesson.

speaker: How?
response: Hmm. It'd have to be something heinous, something that makes her as miserable as she's making me. Oh, I've got it. This is good.

speaker: What?
response: I'm going to buy her a present.

speaker: Yeah, you're gonna have to walk me through that.
response: With gift-giving, there's an implied social contract. If I show up tonight with a present, and she doesn't have one for me, she'll feel terrible.

speaker: Then you're both sad?
response: Yes. Maybe she'll feel so guilty, she'll never make me celebrate the holidays again.

speaker: So your evil plot here is to buy your girlfriend a present?
response: That's right. So stay on my good side, or I'll get you a little something, too.

speaker: What about that sweater?
response: No, it's not good enough. It has to be perfect.

speaker: I think the nicest gifts I've got from Howie show how well he knows me.
response: Hmm. Let's see, what do I know about Amy? She loves medieval literature, Chaucer's her favourite. And her eyes sparkle when she watches old French movies. I enjoy how harp music causes her fingers to dance as if she's playing along.

speaker: Wow, you really do love her.
response: I do. Now, let's find the kind of gift that makes her feel small and worthless.

speaker: All right, let me see if I've got this straight. A picture of you on my lap is a way to punish your girlfriend for making you celebrate Christmas?
response: Correct.

speaker: Santa thinks dating you may be punishment enough.
response: There's an argument for that. But I want to make sure.

speaker: Mmm. Amy, that pudding was delicious.
response: If you like raisins.

speaker: Thank you. And it's figs.
response: Oh. Oh, in that case, it was pretty good.

speaker: Oh, you Heimliched a ball of wool out of me; you're good.
response: Uh, what do you say we exchange gifts?

speaker: I thought you hate giving gifts.
response: Yeah, I do. Which is why I got Amy this.

speaker: You got me something?
response: Oh, not just something, no. It's from the heart, it's holiday-themed, and I swallowed the gift receipt so you cannot return it.

speaker: Look at you on Santa's lap. That's so sweet.
response: Of course it is. It's the perfect gift. How are you feeling right now? Guilty? Sad? Wishing you were Jewish?

speaker: No, I love it.
response: Oh, really? Well, how about now? (On recording) Happy holidays to my dear Amy. I hope you treasure this as much as I treasure you. (Not on recording) And you got me nothing. Christmas is ruined. Let's never speak of it again. Well, this was fun.

speaker: Actually, I did get you something.
response: But what about our agreement?

speaker: Well, you got me something. Here.
response: Cookies?

speaker: They're your Meemaw's Christmas cookies. I called and got the recipe.
response: They're perfect. It tastes like her hugs.

speaker: Merry Christmas, Sheldon.
response: I can't believe this. You're happy, I'm happy. Well, maybe a holiday that's all about giving isn't so… Get your hand out of that box.

speaker: If you people think this is better than Tom Hanks-giving, you're all crazy.
response: Two one six four two zero one nine eight nine. And that, little lady, is pi to a thousand places.

speaker: I'd say I'm sorry I asked, except I didn't.
response: Oh, look, it's the Scientific American that covered the paper Leonard and I wrote.

speaker: Oh, let me see.
response: I have mixed feelings about doing interviews. I like the part where I talk. I do not like the part where the other man talks.

speaker: Sheldon, this article doesn't mention Leonard at all.
response: Well, that can't be right.

speaker: It only refers to "Dr. Cooper and his team." Did you even talk about him?
response: All I did was answer a few questions about the theory. And then expressed my gratitude that Scientific American doesn't include any of those smelly perfume cards.

speaker: Poor Leonard.
response: Why? The theory he came up with just got mentioned in Scientific American. He ought to be thrilled.

speaker: He might not be.
response: Oh, maybe you're right. He is kind of a lump.

speaker: Think about it. How would you feel if you were referred to as part of Leonard's team?
response: Oh, I'd be incensed.

speaker: So you see what I'm getting at?
response: Squeaky wheel gets the grease?

speaker: No.
response: Grass is always greener?

speaker: Try again.
response: Well, I don't know, we're all Groot? Just tell me.

speaker: Leonard is as much a part of this paper as you are, and he was overlooked. He's going to feel bad.
response: But it wasn't my fault. I didn't exclude him. And I didn't write the article.

speaker: Remember that time you didn't get picked to pull the sword out of the stone at Disneyland and they let that other kid do it?
response: Oh, that kid. Poor Leonard.

speaker: Exactly.
response: For the record, that kid was a terrible choice. If you cry when you drop your churro, you do not have what it takes to rule England.

speaker: Yes. It reminds me of us eating out and her saying quick, nobody's looking, fill your pockets with ketchup.
response: Leonard? Have you ever noticed that only my name is on the cable bill?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Good, good. And your name is on the electric bill and mine isn't. And I'm okay with that.

speaker: Actually, your name is on the electric bill.
response: Oh, right. This is a disaster.

speaker: I don't even know what you're talking about and I agree.
response: Okay, I have to tell you something, but you're not going to like it.

speaker: What's going on?
response: An article was just published in Scientific American about our theory.

speaker: Did they hate it?
response: No. No, they loved it. They, uh, couldn't say enough nice things about it.

speaker: So what's the problem?
response: You know how the PennySaver only has my name...

speaker: Sheldon.
response: They didn't mention you in the article. Only me.

speaker: Really?
response: I know. It's not fair. Let the anger go, buddy. You just, you relax all your muscles. Except for your pubococcygeus and a**l sphincter. Let's keep those tight.

speaker: Uh, that, that's not necessary.
response: It is. They're what hold back the urine and the faeces. Look, maybe, maybe you shouldn't read it. It'll only make you feel worse.

speaker: "Cooper and his team"?
response: You should know I had nothing to do with that.

speaker: Uh, at least they're talking about the theory. I mean, that's what's important.
response: You know, you're right. Yeah. You know, it's like when Stan Lee and Steve Ditko created Spider-Man. Stan Lee may get all the credit, but Steve Ditko knows he was just as important. Even though Stan Lee gets to be in all the Marvel movies. And. and he's far richer. And he's a household name, you know? Whereas, you know, you say Ditko, and that sounds like a company that makes Dits.

speaker: That's not helping.
response: Well, I'd give more examples, but, well, everyone in your position's so forgettable.

speaker: Baby's listening.
response: (Knocks) Leonard? (Knocks) Leonard? (Knocks) Leonard?

speaker: What?
response: I spoke to the reporter at the magazine.

speaker: What happened? Did you tell him it was my idea?
response: I did.

speaker: Thank you. What did he say?
response: He said they made the editorial decision to only cite the lead scientist.

speaker: You know, for an extra four bucks, I can have this thing here tomorrow.
response: Well, I know it was your idea, but the reporter said he's been following my work for a while, and the only reason they even mentioned it in the magazine is 'cause my name is on it.

speaker: If you're trying to make me feel better, it's not working.
response: Well then what if I told you that I added your name to the cable bill?

speaker: No.
response: Oh. That's just as well. They had me on hold for 20 minutes and I hung up. (Knocks) Leonard? (Knocks) Leonard? (Knocks) Leonard? Also, Wolowitz invited us all to dinner, so I'm ready whenever you are.

speaker: Well, that is an important part.
response: Oh, please. I have ideas all day long. Reverse SeaWorld where dolphins are allowed to pet people. A new clothing size between medium and large called Marge. Snow White retold from the point of view of Sneezy. Why won't Doc prescribe him something? We finally find out.

speaker: But Leonard's idea was good.
response: Fine. Then Grumpy, what's he so grumpy about? Maybe his girlfriend won't take his side.

speaker: And that's why you get an iPad helicopter.
response: Is it my fault I have a much bigger reputation than he does?

speaker: It's not your fault.
response: Is it my fault that my name came first on the paper alphabetically?

speaker: Not your fault.
response: Is it my fault that when the reporter cited me as the lead scientist I didn't correct him?

speaker: And there goes the mood.
response: Hi. Hello. Oh, and a special hello to Leonard, who needs to be mentioned by name.

speaker: Subtle.
response: But you got it, right?

speaker: Fine.
response: Of course.

speaker: All these bright people sitting around a table by candlelight. Feels like we could be an 18th century French salon.
response: Indeed. Penny, a salon is a gathering where intellectuals entertained each other with sparkling conversations about issues of the day.

speaker: Sheldon, The View is a daytime talk show hosted by women.
response: Oh, I'm aware. It features Whoopi Goldberg. She played Guinan on Star Trek

speaker: Okay, new salon topic. Salons, dumb thing from a long time ago or interesting thing made dumb by talking about superheroes? Discuss.
response: I don't believe it matters what the topic is. What's crucial for a salon is that we conduct the discussion in an elevated and insightful way. It's all about the execution.

speaker: Oh, that's fine.
response: Yeah, good for you, Leonard. That's a lovely little notion. Kind of like, "I wish I could talk to my uncle in Chicago." Yeah, now stand back while I invent the telephone. "Hello? Oh, hold on." Leonard, it's your uncle. He says you just got b*rned.

speaker: Well, I guess, as an engineer, I lean towards execution. I spend my days trying to take ideas and make them real.
response: Well said, old chap. I thought eloquence had died, here it stands before us. Starting today, it'll go Gettysburg Address, "I have a dream," and what he just said.

speaker: Oh, now he's a genius? All you ever do is make fun of him and engineering.
response: Leonard, please. His mother just died.

speaker: You're being ridiculous.
response: Yeah, so are you.

speaker: Guys, if I wanted to hear people be bitchy, I'd go to my real salon.
response: Leonard, lots of people could've had that idea, but very few people could've worked out the math the way I did.

speaker: Lots of people also didn't have that idea, like everyone in the entire world except for me.
response: Oh, well, apparently Leonard thinks he's better than everyone in the whole world, including those fighting for our freedom. Yeah, well, I don't know about you, but I support our boys overseas.

speaker: And girls.
response: Hey, you already ruined Thor; give it a rest.

speaker: So I'm just supposed to be okay with you hogging all the credit?
response: I didn't hog anything. Unlike you and that weird lasagna with raisins in it.

speaker: Hey. Sheldon, Leonard, living room, right now!
response: She said my name first, that must k*ll you.

speaker: It's why my people wandered the desert for 40 years. Took that long to walk it off.
response: You see, Penny, the Israelites were in the desert...

speaker: Right now, I'm just trying to burp without throwing up.
response: Hang on. Physics Today mentioned the paper.

speaker: Who cares? Did they mention Leonard?
response: They did.

speaker: Hi.
response: Oh, good. You're back.

speaker: Okay.
response: As you know, Amy and I have been together a long time, and a lot of things I never thought possible now seem possible.

speaker: Okay.
response: Do you want to say it?

speaker: This is why I've been saying we should keep champagne on ice.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: Yes.
response: Okay. That was tricky, 'cause when it comes to alcohol, she generally means business.

speaker: Thank you. Acquiring a joint pet is a big step for us.
response: No. It's true. It means that we care so much about each other, there's enough left over for an eight-ounce reptile.

speaker: Why a turtle?
response: After much deliberation, we've determined that a turtle is the ideal pet. They don't shed fur, they don't make noise.

speaker: For Halloween, we can dress him as a cobblestone.
response: Yeah. And if he ever goes berserk, I know I can outrun him. Coincidentally, that's also why I chose you as a roommate.

speaker: Well, her torso is. Just kidding. I put her in a wood chipper.
response: Oh, dear Lord. Oh, dear Lord.

speaker: It's okay. You made it. We're fine.
response: That was a lot of puppies.

speaker: Let's forget about them, and pick ourselves out a nice turtle. Oh, how about this one up on the log?
response: Oh, I don't know. He kind of looks like a jerk. How about this one?

speaker: Well, he's barely moving. He looks half dead.
response: I know. I like him, too. Hi, little guy. How'd you like to come home with us? You'll be living with me because we don't live in the same house.

speaker: But that's not your fault. Like you, we're taking it ridiculously slow. You'll stay with me when he's at Comic-Con or away for work.
response: Or if they accept Daddy's application to live on Mars.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: Oh, there's this company that's attempting to establish a colony on Mars, and I applied to be among the first to go. What should we name him? You know, I came in thinking "Seth", but he kind of looks Italian.

speaker: You applied for a mission to be a colonist on another planet, and couldn't be bothered to tell me?
response: Would you have approved?

speaker: Of course not.
response: Well, based on your reaction, it looks like I made the right choice. Isn't that right, Giuseppe?

speaker: Yeah. You get the paint, I'll rest for 30 to 40 minutes, and then we do this.
response: I can't believe you almost had me bring a wild animal into my home.

speaker: No one told you to poke the turtle's face.
response: I was playing Got Your Nose. That's how you get children to like you.

speaker: I'm surprised you even care if he likes you, since you're planning on leaving the planet the first chance you get.
response: Ugh, this again. Amy, I've already had one new hole torn in my body today. I don't need another one.

speaker: Sheldon, I know the odds of you even going to Mars are incredibly small, but it still hurts that you would volunteer for something that would take you away from me forever.
response: So you're saying you wouldn't leave me for the chance to be one of the first humans to colonize another planet?

speaker: I would at least mention it before filling out the application.
response: Huh, that's exactly what Leonard, Wolowitz, Koothrappali, Bernadette and Penny said.

speaker: And who says you could even survive an interplanetary mission, anyway? You could barely survive a tiny turtle bite.
response: First of all, this has only made me stronger. But beyond that, all I did was fill out an application.

speaker: You know what? Go to Mars, Sheldon.
response: Is there anything I can do to cheer you up?

speaker: No. Forget it.
response: What if I play the Star Trek theme on my nose?

speaker: Please don't.
response: Yep, you're mad.

speaker: Did that feel good? You feel like a big man now?
response: I was going to make you red zinger, but since Mars is the red planet, I went with peppermint.

speaker: Why do you even want to do this?
response: Actually, as part of the application, I was required to make a short video answering that very question. You want to see it?

speaker: Can't you just tell me?
response: But I made a video.

speaker: You mean this weirdly suspicious one?
response: Yes. Open it and check.

speaker: I don't get it. There's actually peanut brittle in... Please go to Mars.
response: But on a more serious note, the most important reason I want to go to Mars is that I believe, as a scientist, it's my duty to push the boundaries of human knowledge forward. Now, I know that life on Mars will be difficult. But life here on Earth is no picnic. Also, picnics are no picnic. Where should we go for lunch? Oh, I know, the ground. In conclusion, thank you for considering me for this journey of a lifetime. (echoing) To Mars.

speaker: I think I'm gonna go home.
response: Why? I really don't understand what's happening here.

speaker: You know, Sheldon, at any other time, learning that you had plans to go live on Mars would be a slow news day. But a couple of hours ago, we were getting a turtle. And silly as it sounds, I thought that meant something.
response: Amy. Oh, why didn't I give her Sleepy Time tea? Amy, wait. Getting a turtle meant a great deal to me, too.

speaker: Sure. Unless something better comes along.
response: Do you want me to withdraw my application?

speaker: What I want is for us to be planning our future together.
response: And in that future, are we on the same planet? Because I've seen people make the long-distance thing work.

speaker: We're on the same planet.
response: Okay. Does that planet have to be Earth?

speaker: Are you asking me to go to Mars with you?
response: I am. Yeah, if I'm going to a barren, lifeless environment where the chances of survival are slim to none, I want you there with me. Why don't we go back to the apartment, and fill out your application?

speaker: Okay. I suppose being the first people on a new planet would be incredibly exciting.
response: Oh, I know. We could be the first to plant a flag on Mars. We could be the first to watch Mars Attacks! on Mars. We could be the first to say "good lord, what on Mars are you talking about"?

speaker: You know, we could also be the first people to procreate on Mars.
response: You just can't keep it in your space pants, can you?

speaker: Think about it. If we had a family there, our kids would be Martians.
response: They would, wouldn't they? We could give them cool Martian names. And we could teach them about Martian history. Like, who planted those flags? And, uh, where did that copy of Mars Attacks! come from?

speaker: I guess we'll have to make a new video together, as a couple.
response: (gasps) Good idea. And since you've had such a rough day, I'm gonna let you throw the pie in Leonard's face.

speaker: Cut.
response: What’s wrong?

speaker: Don’t worry, it wasn’t terrible. Just, this time, try to say it the way people sound. And action.
response: My friend, Wil Wheaton.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon. Thanks for having me. I’m excited to be here.
response: So, Wil, what do you have for us first?

speaker: Um, no offence, but I’ve been acting since I was a kid. I think I can handle a Web show without a lot of direction.
response: It’s true. In 1982, Wil played the voice of Martin the mouse in The Secret of NIMH. You moved me.

speaker: Yes. And so far, we’re still not getting our money’s worth. Let’s try it again. Everybody’s having fun. And action.
response: So, Wil, what do you have for us first?

speaker: Problem, first-time director?
response: Oh, none that I could see. I saw a man who loved flags almost as much as I do. I got goose bumps.

speaker: He was overacting on purpose.
response: Really? He reminded me of a young William Shatner.

speaker: You gonna let him speak to me like that?
response: Well, you’re my girlfriend and I don’t want you to be upset. Then again, Wil Wheaton’s my friend and I don’t want him to be upset. Hmm, this is a sticky wicket. (To Wil) What do you think?

speaker: Can I speak to you for a second?
response: I’ll be right back. Feel free to play with yourself.

speaker: I don’t care for your friend, he’s being rude to me. You need to ask him to leave.
response: Amy, I can’t just ask Wil Wheaton to leave. He’s a minor celebrity. Once you explain who he is, many people recognize him.

speaker: Fine. Then maybe I should go.
response: Could you? That would solve everything. You are the best. I’ll see you at dinner tonight?

speaker: You sure you wouldn’t rather have dinner with your friend Wil Wheaton?
response: Come to think of it, I would! You, little lady, are on fire.

speaker: Hey, look who’s out after dark, like a big boy.
response: I was out raising heck with Mr. Wil Wheaton. Four hours more and we would have closed down the HomeTown Buffet.

speaker: I thought you had plans with Amy.
response: Yeah, I did, but then Wil called Amy a pain in the A-S-S. She got huffy and left, then Wil and I headed out to dinner. That place really did remind me of my hometown. Because there we also have a HomeTown Buffet.

speaker: Hold on. Wil and Amy had an argument?
response: Yes, quite the kerfuffle.

speaker: Then Amy got mad and left?
response: Walked right out the door.

speaker: And you?
response: Enjoyed a delightful dinner at a reasonable price. The manager recognized Wil and let us sit right next to the frozen yoghurt machine. Right next to it. I was closer to it than I am to you right now.

speaker: Buddy, I think Amy might be upset.
response: Why’s that?

speaker: Because your friend was rude to her, and then you went to dinner with him.
response: You’re just repeating what I said. It’s like living with a lactose-intolerant parrot.

speaker: Trust me, call her.
response: Fine. It’s a shame you didn’t go to dinner with us, because the buffet you’re about to enjoy only serves humble pie, a dessert much less tasty than frozen yoghurt. I was this close.

speaker: What?
response: You’ll appreciate this. Leonard has some ridiculous notion that you’re mad at me. Tell him you’re not mad at me. Go ahead, set him straight.

speaker: I’m mad at you, Sheldon.
response: Hmm. Eat one of your Luna bars. Very often when women think they’re angry, they’re really just hungry.

speaker: I’m not hungry. Your friend insulted me, and you didn’t do anything.
response: Precisely, I didn’t do anything. Now does someone feel like checking her emotional math?

speaker: Sheldon, I’m your girlfriend, and you should have taken my side. That’s it. End of story. Good night.
response: Wow, Amy’s mad and Leonard was right. What a weird day.

speaker: What?
response: I’ve been thinking about what happened, and I hope this gift will make things better.

speaker: Star Trek DVDs? Why would I want this?
response: First of all, you’re welcome. And furthermore, not being familiar with Wil Wheaton’s body of work, there was no way for you to know you were being rude to a national treasure. Get ready for 130 hours of I told you so. (She hands him back the DVDs and slams the door) Fine. I’ll just tell you what happens. Episode one, Encounter at Farpoint. Fade in. The new Enterprise heads out on its maiden voyage to contact the Bandi people of Deneb IV. Enter Wesley Crusher, played by my buddy… (Amy opens door, grabs DVDs, slams door again) She’s hooked.

speaker: Hey. What brings you in?
response: Penny, if you wouldn’t mind, I’d like to have a conversation about girls.

speaker: I had a feeling we’d have a talk like this sooner or later. Are you finally getting fuzz in weird places?
response: Penny, please, I’m on the horns of a relationship dilemma. And for the record, I had a full pubis of hair by the time I was 19.

speaker: And for the record, bleugh. So what are you drinking?
response: Well, it’s been a rough day. I usually go chamomile tea, but I don’t think that’s going to cut it.

speaker: You could have a Long Island Iced Tea.
response: Will that calm my nerves?

speaker: It’s calmed the pants off me a couple of times.
response: Sold.

speaker: Oh. So, the heart you got from the wizard giving you trouble?
response: The trouble isn’t with me, Penny, it’s with your gender. Someday, scientists will discover that second X chromosome contains nothing but nonsense and twaddle.

speaker: Yeah, Amy told me what happened. Look, just apologize. It’ll warm her twaddle.
response: It’s a Band-Aid at best. See, the core problem is that Amy and Wil do not like each other. Which is baffling because they’re both crazy about me. And I like them, which indicates they’re bright and interesting and/or were on Star Trek.

speaker: Honey, you can’t make people like each other.
response: Not true. Leonard made me like you. And let me tell you, that was a hard row to hoe. Cheers, pal. Ooh. Boy, that is a treat that’s hard to b*at. Get the Mad Hatter on the horn, I’m having a tea party.

speaker: You might want to pace yourself.
response: I drink tea all the time. I think I know what I’m doing.

speaker: Far be it from me to criticize a man with a full pubis. Look, Sheldon, your problem is not Wil Wheaton, okay? Your problem is the way you treated Amy.
response: My problem is I’m out of tea.

speaker: Come on, someone insulted your girlfriend and you just let him do it. I thought you Texas guys stood up for your womenfolk.
response: Penny, please, I think I’ve evolved beyond my simple rustic upbringing.

speaker: Sorry.
response: On the other hand, that low-down polecat done wronged my woman.

speaker: Welcome to Long Island, Tex.
response: Amy deserves better. You know, when we buy the Planter’s deluxe mix, she eats all the Brazil nuts so I don’t have to look at them. She’s a unique blend of saint and squirrel.

speaker: Yeah, that she is. Here you go.
response: I’m a callous egomaniac. She’s gonna leave me.

speaker: No, she won’t.
response: No, she won’t. I’m great.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, what’s up?
response: Wouldn’t you like to know?

speaker: Have you been drinking?
response: Just tea. S’the best tea I’ve ever had.

speaker: Why are you here?
response: I’ll tell you. I’m from Texas. Need I say more?

speaker: Yeah, actually, a little more would be helpful.
response: You insulted my woman. I’m here to defend her honour. Two! It was two. (Knock, knock, knock) Wil Wheaton! Now prepare yourself for what may come.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, do you really think we’re gonna fight?
response: My fists are not up here because I’m milking a giant invisible cow. They’re up to b*at an apology out of you.

speaker: Okay, I’m sorry.
response: Well, that was a long bus ride for not very much.

speaker: Are you okay?
response: You’re asking a lot of questions, Wil Wheaton. As a matter of idle curiosity, which of your shrubberies do you feel would benefit from a thorough vomiting? Never mind, I’ll choose. (Vomits) You were so good in Stand by Me.

speaker: Cut. Yikes, this guy is worse than Wil Wheaton.
response: I don’t know what she’s talking about, but I’m obligated to agree with her. She’s my girlfriend.

speaker: Ah, I hear you, brother. I still get lunch, right?
response: What color would you like to be?

speaker: Well, I'd like to be green, but you know you always take it.
response: That's not true. Any color's fine with me. Yeah, I could be a-a combination of blue and yellow.

speaker: Blue and yellow make green.
response: Well, then it's settled.

speaker: Hi. Ready to go?
response: Oh, good news, we ordered lunch, so we can all stay here and play Lord of the Rings Risk.

speaker: Sheldon, we said that we would play games with you tonight.
response: Oh, no, we'll still be playing it tonight, this game can easily take eight hours.

speaker: I don't want to spend the whole day playing a board game.
response: Yeah, well, you may change your mind when you hear that this is the new expanded edition which contains a more complete map of Middle Earth, now including the Haradwaith Territories.

speaker: No. We're always doing what you guys want. Just once, it'd be nice if you did something we wanted.
response: You want to be green?

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Fine. Now that we're not playing, you can be green.

speaker: Thank you.
response: And since you're green this time, I can be it next time.

speaker: You were, but somehow I held myself back.
response: You know what you could make us do? Ice-skating. The cold air will trigger Leonard's asthma and it plays right into my well-known fear of getting flattened by a Zamboni.

speaker: Now you're helping them find ways to make us miserable?
response: Well, I'm sorry, Leonard, I'm a problem-solver, it's what I do.

speaker: Ooh, the philharmonic is playing Beethoven downtown.
response: Before you say yes, it's not the movie about the big dog.

speaker: Ah, interesting, we're being accused of making you do things you don't like, and here you are, doing the same thing to poor Amy.
response: You should point out the hypocrisy of that.

speaker: That's what I was doing.
response: Oh, that wasn't clear. Try it again, but this time drive it home with how do you like them apples, Missy?

speaker: All right, keep thinking.
response: You're making it too complicated. Why not stick to the basics? Go shopping for clothes while Leonard and I sit in those uncomfortable chairs and hold your purses, hmm? I know I'd hate that. Leonard?

speaker: Well, yeah.
response: Well, then, it's settled?

speaker: It does, somehow he managed to take all the fun out of it.
response: Well, once again, it's what I do.

speaker: This isn't so bad.
response: That's easy for you to say. Your chair's not facing the lingerie section. Boy, that's a lot of panties.

speaker: You guys comfy? This might take a while.
response: I don't understand why women insist on making a big production out of buying clothes.

speaker: No, you're right, we should do what you do. Have our mom send us pants from the Walmart in Houston.
response: They have a man there who understands my personal style.

speaker: Uh, I've got some bad news. There's no cell service in here.
response: Oh. Well, that's all right. There were plenty of ways to pass the time before smart phones were invented.

speaker: That's true.
response: I'll look them up. Son of a biscuit.

speaker: Sheldon, it's fine.
response: No, it's not fine. What kind of store in the 21st century doesn't at least have Wi-Fi? I'm going to call their corporate office. Son of a biscuit.

speaker: Okay. And to defend, I roll two sixes. I win.
response: Boy, double-sixes again. You know, if I hadn't seen it with my own eyes, I wouldn't believe it. I wonder how long we're gonna be stuck here.

speaker: I don't know, but the girls do a lot for us. It's the least we can do.
response: Oh, that's true. I suppose it's only fair we make compromises.

speaker: Look at you, being all mature.
response: I don't know why you're so surprised. If there's one thing I know about after living with you for so many years, it's how to compromise.

speaker: I, I'm sorry? You make compromises for me?
response: All the time.

speaker: On Earth? In our lives? That, that, that we're living?
response: Oh, yes. I, just yesterday, you had a, a big piece of lettuce stuck in your teeth at lunch. Did I say anything? No. I compromised and kept my mouth shut. Like you should've, because everyone was laughing at you.

speaker: That is not a compromise. A compromise is me driving you everywhere because you refuse to learn how.
response: Oh, I learned how. Amy taught me.

speaker: What? Then. then why don't you do it?
response: Uh, well, it's scary. And sometimes I get the pedals mixed up. But, more importantly, driving me to work is one of the things that gives your life purpose. I can't take that away from you, so what do I do? Oh, come on, I'm practically feeding you the answer. I compromise.

speaker: Well, you named it.
response: Oh, here's another one. I wish that the apple pancake mix was on the top shelf because it starts with an A, but I don't put it there because I don't want you breaking one of your little legs when you're supposed to be making my breakfast.

speaker: Is it my turn to talk about the compromises I make?
response: I wasn't done, but go ahead. He said, compromising.

speaker: Because of you, I'm not allowed to adjust the temperature in my own home. I'm not allowed to whistle. I don't wear shoes that might squeak.
response: Well, you're a physicist, not a circus clown.

speaker: Sheldon, do you realize I don't live with the woman I love because of you? No other reason. Just you.
response: Is that true?

speaker: Yes, it's true. The last time I brought it up, you had an emotional breakdown and got on a train and ran away.
response: Well, given my history on the subject, t seems a little reckless to bring it up now.

speaker: You have no idea how much you inconvenience the lives of everyone around you. It's exhausting.
response: You know what? You think you're so tolerant, but the truth is you're mean to me a lot. Yeah, you think that I don't notice all those sarcastic comments and those eye rolls, but I do. Hmm? I have excellent peripheral vision. On a good day, I can see my ears.

speaker: Sheldon, I, I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings. I've been holding a lot of this in for a while.
response: Well, I'm sorry, too. And if you want to live with Penny, then I think you should.

speaker: Do you mean that?
response: Yes. Yeah, just put on your squeaky shoes and eee-eee-eee your way out of my life.

speaker: Come on, don't get upset.
response: I'm not upset. I'm just imagining a world without my best friend in it.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: It's okay.

speaker: I'm not leaving your world. I'm just talking about living across the hall.
response: I understand. Either way, I want you to know that I'm aware of how difficult I can be. So I just want to say thank you for putting up with me.

speaker: Are you crazy? You know he's a flight risk.
response: That's exactly what I told him.

speaker: Sheldon, we know this is a sensitive subject, and Leonard's not gonna move out until you're ready.
response: Well, what if you did it gradually?

speaker: All right. How about we start with two nights a week I live with Penny?
response: How about one night and I let you whistle?

speaker: Okay.
response: When I'm not home.

speaker: You got it.
response: There we go, compromising again. We really are the best.

speaker: Sheldon, that really is an excellent basket.
response: It's not a basket. It's a soldier's helmet from 16th century China.

speaker: Yeah, it looks great.
response: I saw that.

speaker: Yeah, I'm proud of him, too.
response: Can you keep it down? Some of us are trying to sleep out here.

speaker: Five.
response: Uh-huh. And an irrational constant.

speaker: E.
response: And a funny Greek letter.

speaker: Gamma.
response: I said funny.

speaker: Upsilon?
response: Good one. And an electrical charge.

speaker: Positive.
response: Ha. Perfect. Okay. Get this. Professor Jones told the symposium he had a new method for calculating the mass of a muon. Five times the limit of E to the upsilon as in a (laughs uncontrollably). Okay. No, no. I’ll start over. Professor (laughs again)

speaker: I haven’t seen him laugh that hard since the day Leonard made that multiplication error.
response: Oh, Oh, Lord, that multiplication error! He thought he carried the one. But he didn’t.

speaker: It’s not funny. That mistake got published.
response: Stop! I’m going to wet myself!

speaker: Told ya.
response: Oh, President Siebert, I assume you’d like to respond to one of the suggestions I put in the box by your office.

speaker: No, and stop installing suggestion boxes everywhere.
response: You don’t like written suggestions. You don’t like when I give them to you while we’re urinating in the men’s room. If I didn’t know any better, I’d say that you’re one of those stubborn people who are not open to suggestions.

speaker: Dr. Cooper, the physics department chair tells me you’re refusing to take your vacation.
response: I don’t need a vacation.

speaker: You’re obligated to take one. And I’d also like you to know the most-often received suggestion in my suggestion box you installed without asking me is can Dr. Cooper take a vacation? Okay, settled, then. I’ll see you all on Monday, except for you.
response: But if I don’t come into work, what am I supposed to do with myself?

speaker: Read, rest, travel. I hear Afghanistan is nice this time of year.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: That tonight’s gonna be a good night, and tonight’s gonna be a good night, and tonight’s gonna be a good, good night! Tonight’s the night, uh, uh, let’s live it up, uh, I got my money, let’s spend it up…
response: Good Lord! Would you stop that caterwauling!

speaker: What the hell are you doing?
response: Bleeding from my ears.

speaker: What are you doing hiding back there?
response: I’m sneaking into work. Now, if the guard at the university asks what’s under the blanket, you tell him it’s some lobster traps.

speaker: Lobster traps?
response: Yes. That’s how Velma and Scooby smuggled Shaggy into the old lighthouse.

speaker: What are you going to do when you get to the university? People are going to recognize you.
response: Will they, Leonard? (Puts on cap and long-hair wig)

speaker: Fine. Just get back under your blanket, and I’ll drive you there.
response: And no more singing.

speaker: Fine.
response: I have GPS on my phone. I know you turned around.

speaker: Sheldon, there are a million great vacations you could take. What about Hawaii?
response: Hawaii is a former leper colony on top of an active volcano where the disappointing ending to Lost was filmed. Mahalo for nothing, Hawaii.

speaker: How about Florida? They’ve got Cape Canaveral, they’ve got Disney, they’ve got my Aunt Ida and the world’s largest collection of diabetic candy. Plus, if you get sweaty enough, her plastic-covered furniture is like a flume ride.
response: My family took a trip to Florida when I was a child. A seagull stole a hot dog from me on the beach. I got the message.

speaker: Really? What was I doing to your neck last night while you were playing X-Box?
response: It’s like I’m living in a dictatorship. You must take a vacation, you must have fun, you must enjoy life.

speaker: Sheldon, everybody takes vacations.
response: One time they tried to make Richard Feynman take a vacation, but he chose instead to expand his mind and learn something new. He went to work in his friend’s biology lab. Richard Feynman was a famous American physicist, part of the Manhattan Project.

speaker: Everyone in the world of science knows who Richard Feynman was.
response: Now you do, too. Oh! I have a brilliant idea. Amy’s a biologist. I’ll go work in her lab.

speaker: Isn’t that just Feynman’s idea?
response: Ten seconds ago, you never heard of him. Now you’re an expert.

speaker: I’m excited to work with my boyfriend. It’s gonna be romantic.
response: Way to k*ll the mood.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. We can be like Marie Curie and her husband, Pierre, who spent their days working side by side, bathed in the glow of their love and the radium that ultimately k*ll her. Screw Beauty and the Beast, that’s the love story Disney should tell.
response: Okay, what do we start with? Maybe splicing some genes, clone a sheep, perhaps grow a human ear on a mouse’s back? Ha-ha, I’m a freak!

speaker: Oh, I’m gonna be doing some brain stem histology while you put yourself on the business end of a sponge and wash those beakers.
response: Wash those bea… Oh, I get it, a little hazing for the new fella. Yeah, I’d better keep and eye out for, what, shoe polish on the microscope, or mad cow disease in my grilled cheese sandwich?

speaker: No, I just need those beakers washed. Hippity-hop, quick like a bunny.
response: What? Excuse me, you have Dr. Sheldon Cooper in your lab. You’re gonna make him do the dishes? That’s like asking the Incredible Hulk to open a pickle jar.

speaker: Sheldon, you’ve never worked in a lab like this before. You have no experience in the field of biology.
response: I have plenty of experience in biology. I bought a Tamagotchi in 1998. And it’s still alive. Let’s do this.

speaker: Soap spots. Wash ‘em again.
response: Y-you’re being ridiculous. Those are perfectly clean.

speaker: Sheldon, this beaker used to contain cerebral spinal fluid from an elephant that died of syphilis. If it’s, in fact, perfectly clean, drink from it.
response: Biologists are mean.

speaker: All right, perhaps this task will be a little bit more up your alley. I need you to count the bacteria spores on these petri dishes.
response: There was something wrong with that detergent. That was way too bubbly.

speaker: I’m sure it was.
response: I intend to write that soap company a strongly worded letter.

speaker: Yeah, good for you. Now, start counting.
response: You know what this place needs? A suggestion box.

speaker: How’s it going?
response: How’s counting going? When I was in kindergarten, I recited pi to a thousand places for the school talent show. I think I got this.

speaker: Great.
response: Aw, nuts! One…

speaker: Really? Is that what you think?
response: Yes, that’s what I think. And I’m super smart, so it’s probably true.

speaker: Hey, I’ve been training in the field of neurobiology for 12 years. You’ve been here for three hours, and you’ve spent one of them in the bathroom.
response: I’m sorry. It takes me a while to get things going on an unfamiliar toilet.

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve given you the simplest things to do, and you haven’t done one of them right.
response: Maybe that’s because I’m not being challenged. It’s the same reason Einstein failed math.

speaker: Maybe the math was too bubbly for him.
response: You think you’re doing science by cutting up that brain? They could do the same thing at any Quiznos. And they’d offer to toast it for me, too.

speaker: Okay, smart guy. I’m about to remove the locus coeruleus, which is incredibly delicate work. Have at it.
response: All right. I’m no stranger to a little gray matter. Locus coeruleus. Locus coeruleus.

speaker: You’re getting warmer, it is, indeed, in the brain. Hope your hands are steady. It’s the width of a single hair. But this is just biology, so I’m sure it’s no problem for a genius like you.
response: It’s not. I’ll have you know, in the field of physics, we work with particles so small, they make fat jokes about the locus coeruleus, i.e., when your locus coeruleus sits around the house, it sits around the house.

speaker: Oh, are we nervous, Dr. Cooper?
response: No. What you see is a man trembling with confidence. Does a locus coeruleus normally bleed that much?

speaker: No. But your thumb does.
response: Oh, dear. (Faints)

speaker: What are you doing here?
response: I’m on vacation. Social convention dictates that I let my hair down at a local watering hole. Social convention is stupid.

speaker: What happened to your thumb?
response: You know, I have ten fingers and ten toes. If I tell you a story about each one of them, we’ll be here all day, let’s just move on.

speaker: What can I get you?
response: Ah, seeing as I’m on vacation, a pina colada seems appropriate. Extra pineapple slices, extra whipped cream, extra cherries, extra umbrellas, and, uh, hold the rum. Don’t let me have too many of those.

speaker: You and Amy? Good?
response: Oh, better than good.

speaker: All right, Howard Wolowitz, listen up. You sign anything she puts in front of you, because you are the luckiest man alive. If you let her go, there is no way you can find anyone else. Speaking on behalf of all women, it is not gonna happen, we had a meeting. And you, a grown man fainting at the sight of a little blood.
response: Excuse me, this is a fairly substantial wound. (Removes plaster. Faints again)

speaker: What do you want?
response: I was kind of hoping I could continue vacationing in your laboratory. After all, I did book the whole week.

speaker: Do you honestly think you can just waltz back in here after the way you behaved yesterday?
response: I was not myself. I had lost a lot of thumb blood.

speaker: That’s not an apology.
response: That is your opinion.

speaker: I want a real apology.
response: I’m sorry that you weren’t able to…

speaker: No.
response: That my genius…

speaker: No.
response: That the soap was…

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Fine. Sorry.

speaker: You’re forgiven. Now, if you want to stay, get started on those beakers. They’re still dirty from yesterday.
response: Next year I’m going to Epcot.

speaker: Uh, I’m not sure, everyone keep an eye on Howard in case he starts to swell up.
response: Since it’s not bee season, you can have my epinephrine.

speaker: Are there any chopsticks?
response: You don’t need chopsticks, this is Thai food.

speaker: Here we go.
response: Thailand has had the fork since the latter half of the nineteenth century. Interestingly they don’t actually put the fork in their mouth, they use it to put the food on a spoon which then goes into their mouth.

speaker: No.
response: You’re not swelling, Howard.

speaker: Yeah, I probably won’t, but… Hey Sheldon.
response: Hi.

speaker: Hey Raj! (Raj looks uncomfortable) Still not talking to me, huh?
response: Don’t take it personally, it’s his pathology, he can’t talk to women.

speaker: A marathon? Wow, how many Superman movies are there?
response: You’re kidding, right?

speaker: One. (Raj raises one finger).
response: You realise that scene was rife with scientific inaccuracy.

speaker: Yes, I know, men can’t fly.
response: Oh no, let’s assume that they can. Lois Lane is falling, accelerating at an initial rate of 32 feet per second per second. Superman swoops down to save her by reaching out two arms of steel. Miss Lane, who is now travelling at approximately 120 miles per hour, hits them, and is immediately sliced into three equal pieces.

speaker: Unless, Superman matches her speed and decelerates.
response: In what space, sir, in what space? She’s two feet above the ground. Frankly, if he really loved her, he’d let her hit the pavement. It would be a more merciful death.

speaker: Excuse me, your entire argument is predicated on the assumption that Superman’s flight is a feat of strength.
response: Are you listening to yourself, it is well established that Superman’s flight is a feat of strength, it is an extension of his ability to leap tall buildings, an ability he derives from Earth’s yellow Sun.

speaker: Yeah, and you don’t have a problem with that, how does he fly at night.
response: Uh, a combination of the moon’s solar reflection and the energy storage capacity of Kryptonian skin cells.

speaker: I have 26 hundred comic books in there, I challenge you to find a single reference to Kryptonian skin cells.
response: Challenge accepted. (Tries door.) We’re locked out.

speaker: Okay, her apartment’s on the fourth floor but the elevator’s broken so you’re going to have to (delivery man leaves) oh, you’re just going to be done, okay, cool, thanks. I guess we’ll just bring it up ourselves.
response: I hardly think so.

speaker: Why not?
response: Well, we don’t have a dolly, or lifting belts, or any measurable upper body strength.

speaker: We don’t need strength, we’re physicists. We are the intellectual descendents of Archimedes. Give me a fulcrum and a lever and I can move the Earth, it’s just a matter… (starts to move package) I don’t have this… I don’t have this I don’t have this.
response: Archimedes would be so proud.

speaker: Do you have any ideas?
response: Yes, but they all involve a green lantern and a power ring.

speaker: Easy, easy (package falls) Okay! Now we’ve got an inclined plane. The force required to lift is reduced by the sine of the angle of the stairs, call it thirty degrees, so about half.
response: Exactly half.

speaker: Exactly half. Let’s push. Okay, see, it’s moving, this is easy, all in the math.
response: What’s your formula for the corner.

speaker: What? Oh, okay, uh, okay, yeah, no problem, just come up here and help me pull and turn.
response: Ah, gravity, thou art a heartless bitch.

speaker: Men do things for women without expecting sex.
response: Yeah, those are men who just had sex.

speaker: Almost there, almost there, almost there. (Lets go of package, it starts to slip down)
response: No we’re not, no we’re not, no we’re not.

speaker: You okay?
response: No, it hurt… (looking around) Great Caesar’s Ghost, look at this place?

speaker: So Penny’s a little messy.
response: A little messy? The Mandelbrot set of complex numbers is a little messy, this is chaos. Excuse me, explain to me an organisational system where a tray of flatware on a couch is valid. I’m just inferring that this is a couch, because the evidence suggests the coffee table’s having a tiny garage sale.

speaker: Did it ever occur to you that not everyone has the compulsive need to sort, organise and label the entire world around them?
response: No.

speaker: Well they don’t. Hard as it may be for you to believe, most people don’t sort their breakfast cereal numerically by fibre content.
response: Excuse me, but I think we’ve both found that helpful at times.

speaker: Come on, we should go.
response: Hang on.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Straightening up.

speaker: Sheldon, this is not your home.
response: This is not anyone’s home, this is a swirling vortex of entropy.

speaker: When the tr*nsv*stite lived here, you didn’t care how he kept the place.
response: Because it was immaculate, I mean, you open that man’s closet, it was left to right, evening gowns, cocktail dresses, then his police uniforms.

speaker: What were you doing in his closet?
response: I helped run some cable for a webcam.

speaker: Great. Was it hard getting it up the stairs?
response: (sucks in breath)

speaker: No.
response: No?

speaker: No.
response: No.

speaker: Oh, great, thank you again (she throws her jacket over the back of the sofa).
response: Penny, I just want you to know that, you don’t have to live like this. I’m here for you.

speaker: Sheldon!
response: Sssshhhh! Penny’s sleeping.

speaker: Are you insane, you can’t just break into a woman’s apartment in the middle of the night and clean.
