response: I had no choice. I couldn’t sleep knowing that just outside my bedroom was our living room, and just outside our living room was that hallway, and immediately adjacent to that hallway was… this.

speaker: Do you realise that if Penny wakes up, there is no reasonable explanation as to why we’re here?
response: I just gave you a reasonable explanation.

speaker: No, no. You gave me an explanation, it’s reasonableness will be determined by a jury of your peers.
response: Don’t be ridiculous. I have no peers.

speaker: Sheldon, we have to get out of here.
response: You might want to speak in a lower register.

speaker: What?
response: Evolution has made women sensitive to high pitched noises while they sleep, so that they’ll be roused by a crying baby. If you want to avoid waking her, speak in a lower register.

speaker: That’s ridiculous. (Penny snores again.)
response: No, (lowering his voice dramatically,) that’s ridiculous.

speaker: Fine. I accept your premise, now please let’s go.
response: I am not leaving until I’m done.

speaker: O-o-o-oh! (Collapses against wall).
response: If you have time to lean, you have time to clean.

speaker: Morning.
response: I have to say, I slept splendidly. Granted, not long, but just deeply and well.

speaker: I’m not surprised. A well known folk cure for insomnia is to break into your neighbour’s apartment and clean.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: You think?
response: Granted, my methods may have been somewhat unorthodox, but I think the end result will be a measurable enhancement of Penny’s quality of life.

speaker: You know what, you’ve convinced me, maybe tonight we should sneak in and shampoo her carpet.
response: You don’t think that crosses a line?

speaker: Yes! For God’s sake, Sheldon, do I have to hold up a sarcasm sign every time I open my mouth.
response: You have a sarcasm sign?

speaker: No, I do not have a sarcasm sign.
response: Do you want some cereal. I’m feeling so good today I’m going to choose from the low fibre end of the shelf. Hello, Honey Puffs.

speaker: How did she know it was us?
response: I may have left a suggested organisational schematic for her bedroom closet.

speaker: God, this is going to be bad.
response: Goodbye, Honey Puffs, hello Big Bran.

speaker: Yes, but, only to clean.
response: Really more to organise, you’re not actually dirty, per se.

speaker: In my apartment, while I was sleeping.
response: And snoring. And that’s probably just a sinus infection, but it could be sleep apnoea, you might want to see an otolaryngologist. It’s a throat doctor.

speaker: And what kind of doctor removes shoes from asses?
response: Depending on the depth, that’s either a proctologist or a general surgeon. (Leonard holds up a sign reading “Sarcasm”) Oh!

speaker: Sure, that’s another way to go.
response: Penny, Penny, just to clarify because there will be a discussion when you leave, is your objection solely to our presence in the apartment while you were sleeping, or do you also object to the imposition of a new organisational paradigm. (Penny stares in disbelief, then leaves.) Well that was a little non-responsive.

speaker: You are going to march yourself over there right now and apologise. (Sheldon laughs.) What’s funny?
response: That wasn’t sarcasm?

speaker: No.
response: Wooh, boy, you are all over the place this morning. (Knocks on Penny’s door.) I have a masters and two PhD’s, I should not have to do this.

speaker: What?
response: I am truly sorry for what happened last night, I take full responsibility. And I hope that it won’t colour your opinion of Leonard, who is not only a wonderful guy, but also, I hear, a gentle and thorough lover. (Penny closes door in his face.) I did what I could.

speaker: What’s his problem?
response: His imaginary girlfriend broke up with him.

speaker: Six two inch dowels.
response: Check.

speaker: One package, Phillips head screws.
response: Check.

speaker: No, please, we insist, it’s the least we can do considering.
response: Considering what? How great this place looks?

speaker: It is an inefficient design, for example Penny has a flat screen TV, which means all the space behind it is wasted.
response: We could put her stereo back there.

speaker: And control it how?
response: Run an infra-red repeater, photocell here, emitter here, easy peasy.

speaker: Hey guys, I got this.
response: Hang on Penny. How about fans, here and here?

speaker: Oh, really, show me where we put a drip tray, a sluice and an overflow reservoir?
response: And if water is involved we’re going to have to ground the crap out of the thing.

speaker: Oh, I’ve got it. How about if we replace panels A, B and F and crossbar H with aircraft grade aluminium.
response: Right, then the entire thing’s one big heat sink.

speaker: That one over there.
response: Leonard, where are the Skee-Ball tickets?

speaker: Skee-Ball tickets?
response: Yeah, from when we went to the arcade three years ago? I finally decided what prize I want. Hurry up.

speaker: Ooh, what are you gonna get?
response: None of your business. But when you see me wearing a flower in my lapel later, you are most welcome to sniff it.

speaker: Yup, oh, here you go.
response: Oh, thank you. Here, get yourself an eraser for your troubles.

speaker: Why? Because I got an ugly, itchy sweater, and my brother got a car? No, I was her favorite.
response: I seem to be a few tickets short. Are there more in the box?

speaker: Hmm, I think I got them all. Nope, they’re not in there.
response: Well, you barely looked. Let me see.

speaker: No, no, no, I, I looked, and there’s, there’s, there’s no more tickets.
response: Leonard, let me look in the box.

speaker: Okay, okay. I’m gonna show you what’s in the box. But just promise not to flip out.
response: Why would I flip out? Is it a spider? It’s a spider.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, I know I was supposed to return this DVD a long time ago, and I know we rented it on your card. But it’s been, like, seven years and clearly nothing bad has happened. So in-in-in-instead of being a giant pain in the ass like you always are, what if this one time you just tried staying calm?
response: That seems like a reasonable request. Although so did, hey, Leonard, would you mind returning that DVD?

speaker: I’m sorry. I’ll, I’ll take care of it.
response: Okay.

speaker: I mean it, I’m going to.
response: I believe you.

speaker: And you’re going to stay calm?
response: I said I would.

speaker: So, when you say you’re not going to freak out about the DVD, here’s what that means. Don’t fixate on it. Don’t wake me up in the middle of the night. Or nag me through the door while I’m on the toilet.
response: Okay, first, talking to you while you’re on the toilet isn’t exactly a picnic for me either, okay? Remember, when you can hear me, I can hear you. And second, you completely disregard how uncomfortable unresolved issues are for me. It’s, it’s like, a, an itch in my brain I can’t scratch.

speaker: When I broke my arm I used to stick a coat hanger down there. You ever try that? Maybe go in through the ear?
response: You wouldn’t make jokes if you could feel the way I feel.

speaker: Well, I don’t know how to do that.
response: How about this? I promise I won’t pester you about the DVD. You can defecate in peace. That’s a win for both of us. But, until this matter is resolved, I would like you to wear this sweater. With nothing underneath it.

speaker: That’s stupid. Why?
response: You say it’s itchy and uncomfortable. I say situations like this make me feel the same way.

speaker: I’m telling you, try the hanger.
response: Put it on. Let’s share the experience.

speaker: You got it. If this sweater shuts you up, I’m gonna make a fortune selling them to everyone we know. Now all I need to do is head down to the video store and return the DVD.
response: Oh, did I forget to tell you? That store went out of business years ago.

speaker: Really?
response: How those nipples feeling, chief?

speaker: Is the point that you’re an idiot?
response: Gentlemen, please. Leonard is trying to walk a mile in my metaphorical shoes. He can’t walk in my actual shoes. He has the feet of a toddler.

speaker: Hey, what’re you working on?
response: I’m thinking about how one could use the fact that a rapidly rotating mirror turns virtual photons into real ones as a method of observing dark energy.

speaker: That’s a pretty cool idea.
response: Yeah. It’s great you’re here. I’d love to get an engineer’s opinion.

speaker: Sure.
response: This chair is squeaky. Now, do I fix it or get a new one?

speaker: Or it’s resolved.
response: Hey, that next of kin thing sounds pretty good.

speaker: I must say, Sheldon, you’re handling this DVD business with an impressive amount of maturity.
response: I don’t know why that surprises you. I’m a grown man. As should be evident by this sport coat and very real flower in my lapel.

speaker: Is there some kind of new coping mechanism you’re employing?
response: The more interesting question you should be asking is, what does this flower smell like?

speaker: I’m gonna go with sad. So what’s the story with you and this DVD?
response: There’s nothing to tell. Maybe I purchased a book entitled Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff and I followed its wise suggestions, one of which was stop and smell the flowers.

speaker: Seriously?
response: Please. Ha-ha, Oh.

speaker: I think the real question is, why do you waste your time with cheap, childish pranks?
response: There’s probably a deep reason. Which I’d be happy to discuss with you over some peanut brittle in a can.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, I am out of options. Video store owner, Nursis Manookian, has no next of kin.
response: Well, you seem hot under the collar, or is that the sweater?

speaker: Oh, oh, no, no. It’s because I spent all afternoon at the Armenian church where his funeral mass was held. According to Father Solakian, no one attended. Luckily, my trip wasn’t a complete waste. I lit a candle and prayed for your death but I’m not Armenian, so it probably won’t work. This is over, right?
response: Oh, not necessarily. I suggest you look for long-lost relatives either in Armenia or Lebanon.

speaker: Listen to me, Sheldon. I am not going to Lebanon to return Super Mario Brothers the movie.
response: You know, it might be fun. You love hummus.

speaker: Why isn’t this bothering you? Isn’t your brain getting itchy? This is on your card. This could be ruining your credit score. Why isn’t this making you crazy?
response: Leonard, I have something to tell you, but I want you to promise not to flip out.

speaker: What?
response: Seven years ago, I found out the DVD was late and I paid for it.

speaker: What?
response: I was going to mention it at the time, but then I thought, some day, this might be a teachable moment.

speaker: Sheldon, that was diabolical.
response: I know. And it wasn’t easy. Do you have any idea what it’s like to wait for years and never know if you’re going to finally get satisfaction?

speaker: I don’t know why I avoided the Harry Potter books for so long. These are great. I just started number six.
response: That’s a good one. Dumbledore dies in that one. Yeah, I know, I didn’t see it coming, either.

speaker: Why would you say that?
response: You brought up the subject. I contributed an interesting fact on that subject. It’s called the art of conversation. Okay, your turn.

speaker: That was a huge spoiler.
response: Good.

speaker: What is wrong with you? If I did that, you’d bitch about it for weeks.
response: Oh, really, Leonard? Are you going to have another one of your hissy fits?

speaker: Hissy fits? I have hissy fits?
response: Yes, and I have a theory why. Because of your lactose intolerance, you switched over to soy milk. Soy contains estrogen-mimicking compounds. I think your morning Cocoa Puffs are turning you into a hysterical woman.

speaker: You are unbelievable. I don’t know why I put up with you. You’re controlling, you’re irritating.
response: There you go again, nag, nag, nag. You’re only proving my point, little lady.

speaker: You know what? Screw you, Sheldon. You are the most annoying person I have ever met.
response: What? I’m annoying? You criticize my behaviour all the time. Sheldon, don’t talk about your bowel movements over breakfast. Sheldon, when the president of the university is giving a eulogy at a funeral, don’t yawn and point at your watch. Sheldon, don’t throw away my shirts ’cause you think they’re ugly. You’re impossible.

speaker: That’s it. I don’t, I don’t have to put up with this.
response: Actually, I have your signature on a roommate agreement that says you do.

speaker: Aw. Here’s what I think of your roommate agreement.
response: You pick that up right now.

speaker: No.
response: Roommate agreement, section 27, paragraph 5, the roommate agreement, like the American flag, cannot touch the ground.

speaker: I don’t care. I don’t have to do anything you say because I don’t think I want to live here anymore.
response: Where are you going?

speaker: To live with Penny and not you, you crazy bastard.
response: Crazy bastard?

speaker: Yes.
response: Leonard, wait.

speaker: What?
response: Dobby the elf dies in book seven.

speaker: Children’s toy.
response: One Star Trek

speaker: Children’s toy.
response: One Game of Thrones collector’s edition Longclaw sword. Oh, Leonard and I bought that together. That’s a bit of an ethical conundrum. Eh, I’ll keep it.

speaker: So, uh, what’s your plan moving forward?
response: Uh, suppose I’ll have to find and cultivate a new roommate. What a task that will be. Do you know how uncivilized Leonard was when I took him in?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, it took me forever to get him on a bathroom schedule. He would just go whenever the mood struck him.

speaker: Like a dog-boy.
response: Exactly.

speaker: What if you could find a roommate who was a scientist and already familiar and comfortable with your ways?
response: That would be ideal. If a person like that existed, I would sign on, no further questions asked.

speaker: Great. Here I am!
response: Wait. Here who is where?

speaker: Me. Aren’t I your perfect roommate?
response: Um…

speaker: Think about it, Sheldon. I’m not a stranger, we’re intellectually compatible, I’m willing to chauffeur you around town, and your personality quirks, which others find abhorrent or rage-inducing, I find cute as a button. What do you think?
response: Um…

speaker: Tell me one reason why this isn’t a fantastic idea.
response: Um…

speaker: See? You can’t. I’m gonna go see if Leonard’s room is big enough for my water bed.
response: Um…

speaker: What do you want?
response: Hey, good buddy. So, uh, I was just talking to Amy, and she made me realize that this little dust-up between you and me is much ado about nothing.

speaker: Is that so?
response: Yes. All is forgiven, so come back home. I’ll make you some soy hot chocolate, and then I’ll you tell you about our exciting new devil-may-care bathroom policy.

speaker: Cut to the chase, Sheldon.
response: Okay. Amy’s decided she wants to move in with me, so I need you to come back home, you lovable scamp. That’s a lot of product.

speaker: It’s like the happiness won’t ever leave the apartment.
response: Leonard, please. You know Amy moving in marks a level of intimacy our relationship isn’t ready for.

speaker: Well, maybe he doesn’t know how to say it without hurting her feelings.
response: Feelings? What am I, a hippie at a love-in? No. The problem is, she laid out a series of logical arguments that I couldn’t refute.

speaker: That is the worst, isn’t it?
response: Yes.

speaker: Oh, there you are. When do I get a key to our apartment?
response: Um…

speaker: What did I do?
response: You gave Leonard somewhere to go. Thanks to you, Amy’s out buying his and hers bath towels. Like I’d ever dry myself with something that has a possessive pronoun on it.

speaker: Okay. Listen, the truth is I don’t want him living with me.
response: Great. Kick him out. Break his heart. Everybody wins.

speaker: No, I don’t want to break his heart. I love him. This is just happening too fast.
response: You think this is fast? It’s just a matter of time before I see Amy’s leg stubble in my shower.

speaker: Yeah, and I’ve seen those legs. You might want to get some Drano.
response: Hold on. If you don’t want to live with Leonard, why don’t you just tell him?

speaker: Well, you know how he is. He’s sensitive and emotional.
response: That’s because he drinks too much soy milk.

speaker: Well, I don’t know what else we can do but tell them the truth.
response: I suppose there’s no choice but to face the crying, angry accusations and the high-pitched wails of despair.

speaker: Here you go. I picked up the Chinese food just the way Leonard used to.
response: Is it kung pao chicken?

speaker: Yes.
response: Brown rice, not white rice?

speaker: Yes.
response: Spicy mustard from the Korean deli?

speaker: Yes. I did good, right?
response: Yes. Amy, are you worried that us living together will take the mystery out of our relationship?

speaker: No.
response: Yeah, why would you?

speaker: Oh, and, uh, check this out. I took the liberty of scripting a new outgoing voice mail message for both of us.
response: Hello. This is Sheldon.

speaker: And this is Amy.
response: We’re not home right now.

speaker: Beep.
response: You can’t live here.

speaker: What? Why? Is it the message? I only used urban slang to sound tough so people wouldn’t break in.
response: No. It’s not the message.

speaker: Well, what is it, then? I did everything just the way you like it.
response: You did.

speaker: Then what the hell, Sheldon? We have been going out for over two years, and I have been nothing but patient with you. I watch your dopey space movies. I signed your ridiculous contract. I even stopped wearing lip gloss ’cause you said it made my mouth look too slippery. I am the best girlfriend you’re ever gonna have. You give me one good reason why I can’t live here.
response: It’s Penny’s fault.

speaker: What?
response: She doesn’t want to live with Leonard, so he has to come live here again. She’s the snake in our garden. She’s the reason we can’t be happy.

speaker: Sheldon, what did you say?
response: I said the truth. You don’t want to live with Leonard, and you know it.

speaker: Oh, don’t get all huffy. You’re the one who decided to move in without even asking me if I was ready.
response: Yeah, I think we should talk about that.

speaker: And since you love the truth so much, why don’t you tell Amy you don’t want to live with her instead of blaming it on me?
response: I thought we were talking about the other thing.

speaker: You’re a coward.
response: Well, the evidence does support that.

speaker: Um…
response: Do you want to catch up on some Walking Dead?

speaker: ‘Kay.
response: Have you seen the one where Lori dies?

speaker: No.
response: Or maybe she doesn’t. Let’s find out.

speaker: Mmm, gentlemen, I put it to you, the worst tapioca pudding is better than the best pudding of any other flavour.
response: First off, that is axiomatically wrong, because the best pudding is chocolate. Secondly, the organic structure of tapioca makes it a jiggling bowl of potential death. It is extracted from the plant…

speaker: Ah, no kidding! A Fu Man Chu? A handlebar pencil?
response: It is extracted from the plant…

speaker: Alright Sheldon, why is tapioca…
response: Tapioca is extracted from the root of the plant Manihot Esculenta. Due to a high concentration of cyanide it is poisonous in its raw form and lethal if prepared improperly.

speaker: Feel better now?
response: It is also indigenous to Brazil, as is the Cocoa Bean, from which we get chocolate, the best pudding. And you promised you wouldn’t do that anymore!

speaker: Fo’ shizzle.
response: Hey it’s true, Kripke lacks the basic social k*ll that we take for granted, but he also controls the new open science grid computer that I need to use to run some simulations of structure formation in the early universe.

speaker: Good luck getting time on it. The only people he lets use it are his friends.
response: Well then, the solution is simple. I shall befriend him. Kripke!

speaker: Yeah?
response: What’d you say of the idea of you and I becoming friends?

speaker: I would say, I have no intewest in becoming your fwiend.
response: Really? That seems rather short sighted, coming from someone who is generally considered altogether unlikable. Why don’t you take some time to reconsider?

speaker: Yeah, I’ll do that.
response: Well I think we’re off to a terrific start.

speaker: Yeah, I got the same one. And that’s not a bathing suit, it’s a tan line.
response: Hello. This is Sheldon Cooper. I’m leaving a message for Barry Kripke. Barry, It was pleasant seeing you today in the cafeteria. I saw that you purchased the chef’s salad. pparently, you did not know that the chef’s salad is kitchen trickery, to utilize scrap meat. Nevertheless, I hope you enjoyed it. I’m following up on our pending friendship, and I look forward to hearing from you regarding its status. Sheldon Cooper.

speaker: Oh come on, really? (Leonard whistles)
response: First warning.

speaker: Hello Sheldon.
response: Hi.

speaker: What is this?
response: It’s a questionnaire I devised. I’m having some difficulty bonding with a colleague at work, so I’m doing a little research to better understand why my current friends like me.

speaker: Yes. Well, that is a good question. But is this really the best way to figure it out?
response: Yeah, I agree, the social sciences are largely hokum. But, short of putting electrodes in your brain and monitoring your response to my companionship, this is the best I can do.

speaker: Okay, question 1. Rank the following aspects of Sheldon Cooper in order of appeal. Intelligence. Ruthless attention to hygiene. Playfulness. Java applet writing?
response: I know, I may have started off with a fairly obvious one. You did an aspect of my most appealing trait, playfulness. Why don’t you just go ahead and write that number 1. I’m afraid you’re on your own for the rest. It should take you no more than 3 hours.

speaker: Wait! How many questions are on this thing?
response: Only 211. Don’t worry, in deference to you, I’ve kept them on a high school graduate reading level.

speaker: Thanks pal.
response: You got it, buddy.

speaker: Sheldon honey, did you ever consider making friends by being, I don’t know, pleasant?
response: Well that’s certainly a thought-provoking hypothesis. May I suggest it as the topic for your essay.

speaker: I answered every question Sheldon.
response: You answered the multiple choice questions in a pattern. A B B A C. A B B A C.

speaker: Aw, you picked up on that huh?
response: How could I not?

speaker: Come on! There’s over 200 questions. And look at some of these things. Sheldon is to camaraderie, as the space shuttle is to blank?
response: There are a number of acceptable answers, for example, C

speaker: Hold on. I put some real work into that!
response: Yes, well it’s better than what Wolowitz did. He drew a raccoon with what appears to be, a distended scrotum.

speaker: It’s kinda cute, until you get to the scrotum.
response: What hope do I have for establishing new relationships given that my current friends apparently cannot take a few hours out of their lives to help me?

speaker: Sheldon, I’m not going to defend a big bald raccoon.
response: I don’t see how you could.

speaker: What I’m trying to say is that, maybe you can’t approach this as a purely intellectual exercise.
response: What do you mean!?

speaker: Well, remember when you tried to learn how to swim using the internet?
response: I did learn how to swim.

speaker: On the floor.
response: The k*ll are transferrable. I just have no interest in going in the water.

speaker: Then why learn how to swim?
response: The ice caps are melting Leonard. In the future, swimming isn’t going to be optional. But you do bring up an interesting point. I don’t have to break new ground here, I’m sure much of the research already exists.

speaker: No! no, my point is, if you want to learn how to make friends, then just go out to a coffee shop or a museum. Meet people. Talk to them. Take an interest in their lives.
response: That’s insane on the face of it. Come on.

speaker: Where are we going?
response: You’re driving me to the mall. I’m going to acquire a book that summarizes the current theories in the field of friendmaking.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Family or friend?

speaker: Family.
response: Too bad. If it’d been a friend, I’m available to fill the void. (Woman moves away) It’s just as well, she smelled like moth balls.

speaker: Okay, if you’re gonna start sniffing people, I’m gonna go get a hot pretzel.
response: Excuse me. Do you have any books about making friends?

speaker: Um, yeah but they’re all for little kids.
response: I assume the k*ll can be extrapolated and transferred.

speaker: Uh, I guess. They’re right over there by the wooden train set.
response: Oh! I love trains!

speaker: I bet you do.
response: Oh my! That’s awfully sticky. Alright, let’s see. Bernie Bunny has Two Daddies Now. It’s probably about homosexual rabbits. Jerry the Gerbil and the Bullies on the Bus. Read it, not helpful. Oh! Here we go. Stu the Cockatoo is New at the Zoo. Author Sarah Carpenter lives in Fort Wayne, Indiana, with her husband and best friend Mark, and their cockatoos too. Hardly makes her an expert in making friends, wouldn’t you agree?

speaker: I don’t like birds, they scare me.
response: Me too! Most people don’t see it. What are you reading?

speaker: Curious George.
response: Oh I do like monkeys!

speaker: Curious George is a monkey.
response: Somewhat anthropomorphized but yes. Say, maybe sometime you and I can go see monkeys together. Would you like that?

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing?
response: I’m making friends with this little girl. What’s your name?

speaker: Rebecca.
response: Hi Rebecca, I’m your new friend, Sheldon.

speaker: No you’re not, let’s go.
response: We were really hitting it off.

speaker: Damn it. I had Lysine and changed it.
response: Oh good! You’re just in time. I believe I’ve isolated the algorithm for making friends.

speaker: Hear him out. If he’s really on to something, we can open a booth at Comic-Con, make a fortune.
response: See, my initial approach to Kripke, had the same deficiencies as those that plagued Stu the Cockatoo, when he was new at the zoo.

speaker: Yes, he’s new at the zoo.
response: It’s a terrific book. I’ve distilled its essence into a simple flowchart that would guide me through the process.

speaker: Have you thought about putting him in a crate while you’re out of the apartment?
response: Hello, Kripke. Yes, Sheldon Cooper here. It occurred to me you hadn’t returned any of my calls because I hadn’t offered any concrete suggestions for pursuing our friendship. Perhaps the two of us might share a meal together… I see. Well then perhaps you’d have time for a hot beverage. Popular choices include tea, coffee, cocoa… I see. No, no, no, wait. Don’t hang up yet. What about a recreational activity? I bet we share some common interests. Tell me an interest of yours. Really? On actual horses? Tell me another interest of yours. Oh no, I’m sorry, I have no desire to get in the water until I absolutely have to. Tell me another interest of yours.

speaker: I can fix it.
response: Mmhmm. Mmhmm. It’s interesting. But isn’t ventriloquism, by definition, a solo activity? Yeah? Tell me another interest of yours. Hmmm. Is there any chance you like monkeys? What is wrong with you? Everybody likes monkeys. Hang on, Kripke. (Checking changes Howard has made to his flowchart) A loop counter? And an escape to the least objectionable activity! Howard, that’s brilliant! I’m surprised you saw that.

speaker: Gee. Why can’t Sheldon make friends?
response: Alright Kripke, that last interest strikes me as the least objectionable and I would like to propose that we do that together. Tomorrow. Yes, I’ll pay. Alright, goodbye. Alright! Time to learn rock climbing.

speaker: Nope, I wanna climb some wocks.
response: This appears significantly more monolithic than it did on my laptop. No, one expects to see Hominids learning to use bones as weapeons.

speaker: You afwaid of heights, Cooper?
response: Hardly. Fear of heights is illogical. Fear of falling, on the other hand, is prudent and evolutionary. What would you say is the minimum altitude I need to achieve to cement our new-found friendship?

speaker: Come on, they have birthday parties here. Wittle kids climb this.
response: Little kid Hominids, perhaps. (To man who attaches him to ropes) Is this your entire job? Your parents must be so proud.

speaker: Let’s go, Cooper.
response: Coming, Kripke. Okay. Harness seems to be secure. Small amount of incontinence just now, but the website said that’s to be expected. Hey, this isn’t so bad. A bit like vertical swimming.

speaker: Hey, look at you, Cooper. You’re almost halfway to the top.
response: I am? I was wrong. It IS a fear of heights.

speaker: You alwight there, Cooper?
response: Not really. I feel somewhat like an inverse tangent function that’s approaching an asymptote.

speaker: Are you saying you’re stuck?
response: What part of an inverse tangent function approaching an asymptote did you not understand?

speaker: Understood all that. I’m not a mowon. Just keep going.
response: Yeah, I don’t think I can.

speaker: Well, then. Cwimb back down.
response: No, that doesn’t seem any more likely.

speaker: So what’s the pwan, Cooper?
response: Well, it’s not exactly a plan but I think I’m going to pass out.

speaker: It’s a little thing but you really do miss it.
response: Hello, everyone. I brought my new friend, Barry Kripke, home for dinner.

speaker: He passed out. Just hung there like a big sawami.
response: D-d-d! That’s where I sit.

speaker: Sheldon, are you okay?
response: Oh yes, I pass out all the time. But, it was worth it. I’ve made substantial progress in bonding with Kripke, which brings me to an awkward moment.

speaker: What’s that?
response: Maintaining five friendships promises to be a Herculean task. So, I’m going to have to let one of you go.

speaker: Me, me. Let it be me.
response: Leonard, you are my roommate, my source of transportation and you help me fold my sheets when they come out of the dryer. You are safe.

speaker: Can I whistle?
response: Don’t be silly. Howard, you do not have a PhD, your cologne is an as*ault on the senses and you’re not available for video games during the Jewish high holidays.

speaker: Guilty as charged. I’m out.
response: No. You, too, are safe.

speaker: Okay. You know what? I see where this is going. I’m not one of you guys. I’m not a scientist. So just…
response: Penny, Penny, Penny. Everything you’re saying is true, but please allow me to continue. Raj, you’re out. The good question, while you do provide a certain cultural diversity to an otherwise homogenous group, your responses to the questionnaire were truly disturbing. How could you, for a moment, think that my favourite amino acid is Glutamine?

speaker: He had Lysine but changed it.
response: Yeah. Shoulda, woulda coulda, Raj.

speaker: Suddenly I’m looking pretty good, huh?
response: So uh, Kripke, I was wondering if there’s any chance you could get me some time on the open science grid computer.

speaker: No.
response: No? But we’re friends!

speaker: I’m sowy. No, my fwiend?
response: I’m confused. I was given an understanding that you allow your friends time on the machine?

speaker: No, that’s wong. There’s an official schedule. I have no contwol over it.
response: Oh. This entire endeavour seems to have been an exercise in futility. Raj, you’re back in. He likes monkeys.

speaker: Should we do something for her?
response: I know. Let’s go see the new Spider-Man movie.

speaker: Sheldon, we’re talking about your friend’s mother. She got hurt.
response: I thought that subject had run its course, so I changed it. It’s called reading the room, Amy.

speaker: I don’t know. The bisexual gorilla go-go dancer in Schindler’s List is tough to b*at.
response: Ah, very good. Because a gorilla go-go dancer of any sexual preference would be out of place in a film about the Holocaust.

speaker: It only gets funnier when you explain it, Sheldon.
response: I know.

speaker: Thanks for inviting me after everyone else said no. Aren’t you gonna get 3-D glasses?
response: I brought my own. No sense in risking bridge-of-nose herpes.

speaker: Is that a real thing?
response: Well, until they invent nose condoms, I’m not finding out.

speaker: Uh, this is my friend, Sheldon. Sheldon, this is Emily.
response: Oh, yes, you’re the dermatologist. I went for a walk yesterday without sunscreen. Do you see anything on my forehead that I should be concerned about?

speaker: Yeah, okay.
response: That was awkward, right?

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Is it because she’s dating you but was out with that other fellow?

speaker: Yes.
response: Good. I thought she saw something on my forehead.

speaker: Thanks for skipping the movie. I couldn’t sit in that theatre for two hours wondering about Emily and that guy.
response: Oh, quite all right. After my forehead melanoma scare I’ve learned not to sweat the small stuff. Well, sorry, I don’t have all the ingredients to make chai tea.

speaker: You don’t have to make me anything.
response: No, I do. You’re upset about Emily and you’re Indian. I need to make you chai tea. Now, I have all the ingredients except cardamom seeds. Do you happen to have any on you?

speaker: Sorry, I left them in my turban.
response: Oh, I’ll make English breakfast tea. They destroyed your culture. That’s close enough. You know, I’m curious, why are you so upset about seeing Emily with another man?

speaker: Wouldn’t you be upset if you saw Amy out with someone else?
response: Can’t happen. We have an ironclad relationship agreement which precludes her from physical contact with anyone other than me.

speaker: But you don’t have sex with her, either.
response: Slick, huh?

speaker: To be truthful, Emily and I haven’t dated that long, and we never agreed to be exclusive to each other.
response: Have you had intercourse?

speaker: No.
response: Well, stick to your g*n. There will be a lot of pressure.

speaker: I don’t understand it. I’m a nice guy, I have a great job, I’m well-educated, come from a good family. Why don’t women want to be with me?
response: An interesting question. Well, good night.

speaker: What? Don’t send me home. I can’t be alone right now.
response: That’s your problem. You can’t be alone.

speaker: What do you mean?
response: How many women have you had dates with?

speaker: Eleven.
response: How many of those women did you think would become your perfect companion?

speaker: Eleven. Wait. Do I count the 200-pound Sailor Moon girl that Howard and I had a threesome with at Comic Con?
response: Sure.

speaker: I’ll stick with eleven. She liked Howard better.
response: Well, now do you see the problem?

speaker: Maybe. I, I don’t know.It’s late, I should, I should go. Look, I do get what you’re saying. Instead of desperately clinging to any woman who will go out with me, I need to work on my fear of being alone.
response: I was trying to suggest chemical castration, but it’s my bedtime, so whatever gets you out the door. Good night.

speaker: I’d love that, but she’s not really comfortable around people.
response: Yeah, I used to be uncomfortable around people, but then I learned a trick. I pretend everyone I meet is a beloved character from Star Trek.

speaker: How’s that been working for you?
response: Oh, like a charm, unnamed crewman in a red shirt.

speaker: I have a job.
response: Yes, he does. He caters to my every whim.

speaker: He knows, wow.
response: Well, now, but do you think that’s a good idea? Uh, you know Star Trek. Should a guy with no name and a red shirt really go on an expedition?

speaker: Hey, don’t discourage him. This is a fantastic opportunity.
response: No one asked you, Uhura.

speaker: What do you think?
response: Great. I’ve been doing some reading about vehicular safety. Did you know that the highest number of drowning accidents happen on or around boats?

speaker: Interesting that you would bring that up when I might go work on a boat.
response: Well, that’s the thing about factoids, they’re interesting.

speaker: I know what you’re doing. You don’t want me going on this research trip because you’re afraid to be alone.
response: I’m not afraid to be alone. On land. On the sea, it would be terrifying. Because of all the drowning.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Fine, no more drowning talk. I’ll change the subject. Oh. Who do you think would win in a fight, you or a shark?

speaker: Look, I appreciate your signature blend of concern for me and incredible selfishness. If I get the chance to do this, there is nothing you can say that’s going to stop me.
response: Very well. Things between you and Penny have never been better. I hope four months apart doesn’t change anything. I should have opened with that, huh?

speaker: There’s beer in the fridge. Anyway, you guys really don’t need to make a big deal.
response: Leonard, you’re being selfish. We need to give you a proper send-off so we’ll have closure when you die at sea and crabs eat your face.

speaker: The only person allowed inside this head is Dr. Phil. Anyway, I, I spoke to my new lady friend about meeting you all, and she thought it would be easier for her to start with just one.
response: Oh, gee, I don’t know. My schedule’s a little busy.

speaker: A, that was not a joke, that was a sincere request. And B, more importantly, I was the outsider to this group, and I know how frightening that can be. But you guys took me in and made me feel loved, like I was family.
response: Fine, I’ll do it.

speaker: Yeah, it does, and here we are.
response: You know, I have to say, Penny, I don’t understand why you of all people are encouraging Leonard to do this.

speaker: Well, I’m his girlfriend, of course I’m gonna support him.
response: Yeah, well, you’re his girlfriend for now. You know, maybe you’re not aware of this, but there is a rich tradition of men at sea finding comfort in each other’s arms and britches.

speaker: Honey, this is a big deal for Leonard, okay? He gets to work with Stephen Hawking. Who, by the way, will not be on the boat. I checked it out.
response: It’s not that big of an opportunity. And even if Hawking’s theories are correct, all they prove is where the universe came from, why everything exists and what its ultimate end will be. I mean, me? I’m interested in the big questions.

speaker: Oh, my God, Sheldon the genius is jealous of Leonard.
response: I’m not jealous. I’m just very unhappy that good things are happening for him and not happening for me.

speaker: Look, sweetie, this is a natural thing to feel, okay? But just because good things are happening to Leonard doesn’t take anything away from you. You know what? Let me tell you a little story. Once there was a girl who worked at the Cheesecake Factory, and she wasn’t very good at her job.
response: It was you.

speaker: It wasn’t me. But she was also an actress, and we were both up for the same part in a toothpaste commercial. She got it. Look, I was so jealous. But instead of ripping out her fake blonde hair…
response: You ripped out your own fake blonde hair.

speaker: I, looked her in the eye, smiled and said, I’m happy for you. Because that’s what friends do.
response: They lie so they don’t look petty.

speaker: Yeah.
response: How?

speaker: Like this. I am so happy for you.
response: Wow. No wonder you didn’t get that toothpaste commercial.

speaker: She is. She’s just running a little late. You know how it is, girls always fussing about their hair, their makeup. She’ll be here. Just give it a rest, okay?
response: Um, can I have your attention, everyone? (Clinks glass) That’s, uh, B-flat, for those who don’t have perfect pitch. I would like to propose a toast to my best friend, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter. He has been presented with a wonderful opportunity, and I couldn’t be happier for him.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon. That must’ve been very hard for you to say.
response: Well, I mean it. I’m really happy for you. And that’s how you get a toothpaste commercial. Cheers.

speaker: It was really nice of you to try to be happy for Leonard.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Me, too.
response: It did not k*ll me when you went to space. Monkeys went to space.

speaker: I’m gonna miss you, too.
response: Penny, we’re in the red zone. The white zone is for loading and unloading. We’re breaking the law.

speaker: Anyway, we can e-mail, and I think the phone connections are pretty good.
response: All right, you have to get out of the car right now. I’m not going to jail for you.

speaker: Would you just relax?
response: Oh, I see a space in the white zone. Quick, circle the airport.

speaker: Okay.
response: Oh, dear Lord, a police officer’s glancing in our direction. We’ve been made.

speaker: Oh, Leonard.
response: It’s just a heart-shaped locket with a picture of Leonard’s face in it. He got it at the mall on clearance. Now move, move, move.

speaker: I love you, too.
response: Don’t worry, Officer. They just love each other. We’re not smuggling drugs.

speaker: What did they give you?
response: Turkey and roast beef with swiss and lettuce on wholewheat. It’s the right ingredients but in the wrong order. In a proper sandwich the cheese is adjacent to the bread to create a moisture barrier against the lettuce. They might as well have dragged this thing through a car wash.

speaker: I don’t believe it.
response: I know, it’s basic culinary science.

speaker: Yeah. And that’s my bid.
response: You bid $800.

speaker: It was a spur of the moment thing, I figured it would go for thousands and I just wanted to be a part of it.
response: There’s only 30 seconds left in the auction.

speaker: You lucky duck.
response: I wonder why no-one else bid, this is a classic piece of sci-fi movie memorabilia.

speaker: A time share time machine? I’m in. Sheldon?
response: Need you ask? But I still don’t understand why no-one else bid.

speaker: I just assumed. Who sells a full sized time machine for $800?
response: In a venn diagram, that would be an individual located within the intersection of the sets “no longer want my time machine” and “need $800”.

speaker: Yes but the elevator’s been broken for two years.
response: I’ve been meaning to ask you, do you think we should make a call about that?

speaker: I can’t feel my fingers, hurry up.
response: It’s the same amount of work no matter how fast you go, basic physics.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Yeah.

speaker: I don’t have a few minutes, I’m running really late.
response: Then I have a simple solution, go up to the roof, hop over to the next building, there’s a small gap, don’t look down if you’re subject to vertigo, and use their stairwell.

speaker: You’re joking, right?
response: Oh, I never joke when it comes to vertigo.

speaker: Hey, if you wait for us to set up the time machine, I can drop you off at work yesterday. Time travel joke, it’s not… never mind.
response: For what it’s worth, I thought it was humorous.

speaker: Yeah. It is by far the coolest thing I have ever owned.
response: The exact time machine that carried actor Rod Taylor from Victorian England into the post-apocalyptic future, which society had splintered into two factions, the sub-terranean Morlocks, who survived by feasting on the flesh of the gentle surface dwelling Eloy.

speaker: Oh yeah. The guy who lives next to me is always like, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony, I have a Jacuzzi on my balcony. But wait until I tell him, I’ve got a time machine on my balcony. Stuff that in your speedos, Jacuzzi Bob!
response: Gentlemen, I know we said we’d take turns, but I think you’d agree that practicality dictates it remain here.

speaker: He’s got a point.
response: Alright, I think we’re going to need some ground rules, in addition to the expected no shoes in the time machine and no eating in the time machine, I propose that we add pants must be worn at all times in the time machine.

speaker: That sounds fair.
response: Hold on. Bi-monthly is an ambiguous term, do you mean move it every other month, or twice a month?

speaker: Twice a month.
response: Then no.

speaker: Okay, every other month.
response: No.

speaker: Good choice, Alexander Graham Bell invents the telephone and calls out for Dr Watson.
response: Wait a minute, I’d want to see that too.

speaker: So, when it’s your turn you can.
response: But if we all go back to the same point in time, Bell’s lab is going to get very crowded, he’ll know something’s up.

speaker: Mrs Bell was deaf, she’s not even going to hear you knock.
response: Oh, I have a solution, first go into the future and obtain a cloaking device.

speaker: Ooh, how far into the future?
response: If I remember correctly, Captain Kirk will steal a cloaking device from the Romulans on Stardate 5027.3, which will be January 10th 2328 by pre-federation reckoning.

speaker: Not done. By the time I finally got to work, they’d given my shift away. Yeah, that’s right, I’ve lost an entire day’s pay thanks to this… this…
response: Time machine.

speaker: No! I don’t want to try it, my God, you are grown men, how could you waste your lives with these stupid toys and costumes and comic books and… and now that… that…
response: Again, time machine.

speaker: Oh please, it’s not a time machine, if anything it looks like something Elton John would drive through the Everglades.
response: It only moves in time. It would be worse than useless in a swamp.

speaker: So?
response: So it’s my turn. Why did you set it for the day before yesterday?

speaker: Because I want to go back and keep myself from getting a time machine.
response: You can’t. If you were to prevent yourself from buying it in the past, you would not have it available in the present to travel back and stop yourself from buying it, ergo you would still have it. This is a classic rookie time travel mistake.

speaker: Can I go back and prevent you from explaining that to me?
response: Same paradox. If you were to travel back in time and, say, knock me unconscious, you would not then have the conversation that irritated you, motivating you to go back and knock me unconscious.

speaker: What if I knocked you unconscious right now?
response: It won’t change the past.

speaker: But it would make the present so much nicer.
response: Are you upset about something?

speaker: What was your first clue?
response: Well, it was a number of things. First the late hour, then your demeanour seems very low energy, plus your irritability…

speaker: Yes I’m upset.
response: Oh! I don’t usually pick up on those things. Good for me.

speaker: Yeah, good for you.
response: Oh, wait. Did you want to talk about what’s bothering you?

speaker: I don’t know. Maybe.
response: Wow, I’m on fire tonight.

speaker: Uh, here’s the thing. Girls like Penny never end up with guys who own time machines.
response: I disagree. Your inability to successfully woo Penny long predates your acquisition of the time machine. That failure clearly stands on its own.

speaker: Thanks for pointing it out.
response: In addition, your premise is flawed. In the original film, Rod Taylor got Yvette Mimeaux with that very time machine. In Back to the Future, Marty McFly got the opportunity to hook up with his extremely attractive young mother.

speaker: Those are movies.
response: Well of course they’re movies. Were you expecting me to come up with an example involving a real life time machine? That’s absurd.

speaker: Oh, Leonard. (Kisses him as they descend from view. Leonard wakes up still sitting in the time machine.)
response: It’s still my turn.

speaker: I’m packing up all my collectibles and taking them down to the comic book store to sell.
response: Well is that really necessary. If you need money you can always sell blood. And semen.

speaker: Just… personal reasons.
response: My spidey-sense tells me this has something to do with Penny.

speaker: Dude, everyone knows a time machine loses half its value the minute you drive it off the lot.
response: I’ll go for two hundred, that time machine stays right where it is.

speaker: I can and I did, look up dibs on Wikipedia.
response: Dibs doesn’t apply in a bidding w*r.

speaker: He offered me a fair price for the whole collection.
response: What’s the number, I’ll match it.

speaker: I’ll match it, plus a thousand rupees.
response: What’s the exchange rate.

speaker: Forget it guys, if I sell to one of you, the other two are going to be really mad at me.
response: Who cares, as long as you pick me.

speaker: Sorry Raj, my mind is made up.
response: No. I can’t let you do this.

speaker: Sheldon, get out of my way.
response: None shall pass.

speaker: What the hell’s going on?
response: You hypocrite!

speaker: What?
response: Little Miss “grown ups don’t play with toys”. If I were to go into that apartment right now, would I find Beanie Babies? Are you not an accumulator of Care Bears and My Little Ponies? And who is that Japanese feline I see frolicking on your shorts? Hello,Hello Kitty!

speaker: Sheldon, are you okay?
response: We have to get rid of the time machine.

speaker: It is a little big for the living room, isn’t it?
response: Yeah, that’s the problem, it’s too big.

speaker: I’m glad you agree. I hired some guys to help us move it, come on in fellas. (A pair of Morlocks come through the door.)
response: Oh no, Morlocks? Eat him, eat him. Aaaaargh. (Sheldon wakes up in his own bed.) Leonard!

speaker: Right now, Howard’s staring down at our planet like a tiny Jewish Greek god. Zeusowitz.
response: I must admit, I can’t help but feel a twinge of envy. He can look out the window and see the majesty of the universe unfolding before his eyes. His dim, uncomprehending eyes. It’s like a cat in an airport carrying case.

speaker: Peering through his telescope at the birth of the cosmos.
response: Whatever it is, we know his life will never be the same.

speaker: Interesting question. On the one hand, I always thought…
response: You don’t even know what it is, do you? The anthropic principle states that if we wish to explain why our universe exists the way it does, the answer is that it must have qualities that allow intelligent creatures to arise who are capable of asking the question. As I am doing so eloquently right now.

speaker: I know what the anthropic principle is.
response: Of course. I just explained it to you. Now, where do you stand on it?

speaker: Where do you stand on it?
response: Strongly pro.

speaker: Hey.
response: Yeah, wait, Raj, where do you stand on the anthropic principle?

speaker: I’m all for it.
response: Attaboy!

speaker: Well, hang on. Why do you believe that he knows what it is and I don’t?
response: Oh, Leonard. Let’s not take a saw to the branch we’re sitting on, shall we?

speaker: Oh, okay. Sounds like it’s me and you, Sheldon. How about we sic some guppies on those puppies?
response: As I’ve stated before on numerous occasions, the only sea creature I would even consider being eaten by is the Kraken, because the last words I would hear are “Release the Kraken.” That never gets old. “Release the Kraken!” Oh, chills. Besides, I’m having dinner with Amy.

speaker: Oh, okay. I’ll just go home and be alone. Which is cool. I eat alone, I sleep alone, I cry alone, so, cool.
response: Darn. If you weren’t busy, I’d ask you to join us.

speaker: Sheldon, are you sure you want to be bringing Raj on your date night with Amy?
response: Oh, absolutely. I have a contractual obligation to provide Amy with conversation and casual physical contact, but nowhere is it specified that I can’t outsource that to an Indian.

speaker: Sheldon, this place is so romantic.
response: Oh, I’m glad you like it. Raj picked it out.

speaker: Well, when you see him, tell him I say thank you.
response: Tell him yourself.

speaker: I don’t understand. What’s he doing here?
response: I invited him.

speaker: On our date? Sheldon, that’s not okay.
response: Yes, it is. There’s a loophole in the Relationship Agreement.

speaker: My pleasure. Waiter? A bottle of champagne and three glasses. Oh, boy, isn’t this romantic?
response: Oh, I hope that’s a rhetorical question, because I have no clue.

speaker: Have I ever told you you’re like a sexy praying mantis?
response: Every time you drink alcohol.

speaker: You know what’s wonderful about the praying mantis? They devour their mate.
response: Your point being?

speaker: Dessert is served.
response: I just had cobbler.

speaker: You know what? I’m done with this.
response: W-Where are you going?

speaker: I’m leaving.
response: You can’t leave. I need you.

speaker: You do?
response: Yes. You’re my ride.

speaker: Sheldon, you either say something meaningful and from the heart, or you and I are done.
response: All right. Please. Amy, when I look in your eyes and you’re looking back in mine, everything feels not quite normal, because I feel stronger and weaker at the same time. I feel excited and, at the same time, terrified. The truth is, I don’t know what I feel, except I know what kind of man I want to be.

speaker: Sheldon, that was beautiful.
response: I should hope so. That’s from the first Spider-Man movie.

speaker: I’ll take it.
response: Good. Now, I assume we’re splitting the cheque?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, you want to play next?
response: Oh, I would, but I’m on my way out.

speaker: Where?
response: Texas.

speaker: Is someone sick?
response: Yes. My sister’s uterus came down with a baby.

speaker: Oh, she’s pregnant? That’s great. You’re gone an uncle. Uncle Sheldon.
response: No, I will be Uncle Dr. Cooper.

speaker: How come you never said she was pregnant?
response: Well, I never told you about my brother’s kidney stone. You want to hear about everything that comes out of my family’s genitals?

speaker: Well, congrats, and it’s nice you’re gonna be there for your sister.
response: Yes. I’m filling in for her husband who’s recovering from a horrible motorcycle accident. Lucky duck.

speaker: Wow, so, how long will you be gone?
response: Well, she’s due tomorrow. Although it did take her six years to finish high school, so who knows?

speaker: Can I give you a ride to the airport?
response: Oh, no, thank you, I don’t want to be an inconvenience. Chop-chop, Leonard. We leave in ten minutes.

speaker: Hello.
response: The second I go out of town you throw a Christmas party without me?

speaker: Yeah, kinda.
response: That’s so thoughtful. You guys are the best.

speaker: Hey, how’s your sister?
response: <i>She went into labor an hour ago.

speaker: That’s wonderful. So you’re at the hospital?
response: No, she chose to have a home birth because she wants to live in the Stone Age and a cave wasn’t available.

speaker: You know, many people believe that home births are better because the mother is in a warm, comfortable environment where she can be nurtured by loved ones.
response: And turn the bedroom floor into an amniotic Slip ‘n Slide.

speaker: Shelly, come on. Your sister’s fully dilated and she wants a nice family picture before there’s blood everywhere.
response: Oh, boy. I picked the wrong day to wear my good robot T-shirt.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon. Everything okay?
response: No, it’s not. I’ve seen things. Lady things.

speaker: Listen to me. That is not the way they usually look.
response: Doesn’t matter. This is no way to make new humans. People coming out of people. It’s some kind of dirty magic show.

speaker: Sheldon Lee Cooper. You get back in this room right now. And bring a mop.
response: Did you hear that? A mop. I have two PhDs yet somehow I’m the janitor of my sister’s birth canal.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Hello.

speaker: Doing laundry?
response: Of course I’m doing laundry. Saturday night is laundry night, and I’m in a laundry room, so, I believe your inference is justified.

speaker: So, what do you think?
response: A tad asymmetrical, but nothing to be concerned about.

speaker: Please, Sheldon. I need you.
response: To what?

speaker: To take me.
response: I’m not taking you anywhere till you put on a shirt.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. You and me right here.
response: Penny, for the thousandth time, I’m saving myself for someone special. Perhaps a cute bespectacled neuroscientist with hair the color of mud.

speaker: How’s it going, Sheldon?
response: Actually, much better.

speaker: Oh, good. Is the baby born yet?
response: I don’t know. I just got back.

speaker: Where’d you go?
response: My mother asked me to get some towels. I took advantage of the vague request and went to Bed, Bath & Beyond. (Scream from other room) Excuse me, I’m on the phone. So rude.

speaker: How’s it going, Sheldon?
response: That’s it. The baby’s here. It’s a boy.

speaker: Congrats.
response: Oh, thank you. I wasn’t sure I was gonna to make it. But my mother gave me some ice chips, my sister told me to breathe, and I just thought to myself, Sheldon, if you can make it through the Green Lantern movie, you can make it through this.

speaker: Well, good for you, buddy. We’ll let you get back in there.
response: Oh no, no, I’m not going back in there. That baby is so irritating. He has literally been crying his entire life.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, you should go.
response: Why?

speaker: Well, you always complain that you never had an intelligent role model growing up, and now you can be one for your nephew.
response: Ugh, all right, I’ll go. But from what I’ve seen, his attention span is as limited as his bladder control.

speaker: Just really glad you’re back.
response: Me, too. I got a lot of TV to catch up on.

speaker: I missed you.
response: To quote Han Solo, I know.

speaker: Did you miss me?
response: I would’ve preferred to have you there with me.

speaker: Oh.
response: Or instead of me.

speaker: Did you hold the baby?
response: I did.

speaker: And? How did it make you feel?
response: Looking into the blank, innocent eyes of a creature that couldn’t begin to comprehend anything I was saying? Basically just another day at the office.

speaker: Problem?
response: The online description was completely misleading, they said eight slots plus removable ID, to any rational person that would mean room for nine cards, but they don’t tell you the removable ID takes up one slot, it’s a nightmare.

speaker: Okay, now, do you really need the honorary Justice League of America membership card?
response: It’s been in every wallet I’ve owned since I was five.

speaker: Why?
response: It says keep this on your person at all times. (Knock on door) It’s right here under Batman’s signature.

speaker: And over here is Sheldon.
response: Hi.

speaker: If you don’t want to meddle, then why are you meddling.
response: If I may, your parents probably don’t consider this meddling, while arranged marriages are no longer the norm, Indian parents continue to have a greater than average involvement in their children’s lives.

speaker: Why are you telling me about my own culture?
response: You seemed confused.

speaker: Actually, I read somewhere that it’s one of the most popular programmes in India.
response: It might speak to a cultural aspiration to have one’s children enter the medical profession.

speaker: I bet they love Scrubs.
response: What’s not to love?

speaker: Excuse me, hello? My parents are trying to marry me off to a total stranger, what am I going to do?
response: I suggest you go through with it.

speaker: What?
response: Romantic love as the basis for marriage has only existed since the nineteenth century. Up until then, arranged marriages were the norm, and it served society quite well.

speaker: Me too. Of course, it speaks to me culturally.
response: Understandable, but there’s a universality to that story which transcends ethnicity.

speaker: So who wants to rent Fiddler?
response: No need, we have the special edition.

speaker: I need some guinea pigs.
response: Okay, there’s a lab animal supply company in Reseda you could try, but if your research is going to have human applications may I suggest white mice instead, their brain chemistry is far closer to ours.

speaker: Oh, great, well the key to acquiring proficiency in any task is repetition.
response: With certain obvious exceptions. su1c1de, for example.

speaker: Uh, how about a grasshopper. I make a mean grasshopper. Okay? Good. Coming up. Sheldon, what are you going to have?
response: I’ll have a diet coke.

speaker: Okay, can you please order a cocktail, I need to practice mixing drinks.
response: Fine. I’ll have a virgin cuba libre.

speaker: That’s, um, rum and coke without the rum.
response: Yes,

speaker: So coke.
response: Yes. And would you make it diet?

speaker: There’s a can in the fridge.
response: A cuba libre traditionally comes in a tall glass with a lime wedge.

speaker: Then swim to Cuba.
response: Bartenders are supposed to have people k*ll.

speaker: Um, Raj, honey, you say you can’t talk to women but… you’ve been talking to me.
response: And now we’ll never know.

speaker: I’d say he was doing fine, look at her, last girl my mom set me up with had a moustache and a vestigial tail.
response: Sorry I’m late.

speaker: What happened?
response: Nothing, I just really didn’t want to come. Virgin diet cuba libre please.

speaker: Okay.
response: In a tall glass, with a lime wedge.

speaker: Oh, I’ll wedge it right in there.
response: So, how’s Koothrappali d…. oh my Lord.

speaker: What?
response: That’s Princess Punchali.

speaker: I’m pretty sure her name’s Lalita.
response: No, no, Princess Punchali from The Monkey and the Princess.

speaker: Oh, yeah, I tried to watch that online, but they wanted a credit card.
response: It’s a children’s story.

speaker: Oh, no it isn’t.
response: When I was a little boy and got sick, which was most of the time, my mother would read it to me. It’s about an Indian princess who befriends a monkey, who was mocked by all the other monkeys because he was different. For some reason I related to it quite strongly.

speaker: We all know the reason. Sheldon, what are you getting at?
response: That woman looks exactly like the pictures of Princess Punchali in the book. How often does one see a beloved fictional character come to life?

speaker: Hey guys. This is Lalita Gupta, Lalita this is Leonard and Sheldon and Howard and Penny. Isn’t it great, she isn’t fat any more!
response: Forgive me your highness, for I am but a monkey, and it is in my nature to climb. I did not mean to gaze upon you as you comb your hair.

speaker: I’m sorry?
response: You are the living embodiment of the beautiful Princess Punchali.

speaker: Oh, no kidding? Oh, who is that?
response: A beloved character from an Indian folk tale.

speaker: Oh. Us Indian, or “come to our casino” Indian?
response: You Indian.

speaker: Oh.
response: The resemblance is remarkable. I can practically smell the lotus blossoms woven into your ebony hair.

speaker: Thanks. I imagine you smell very nice too.
response: I shower twice a day and wash my hands as often as I can.

speaker: Don’t be insulting Rajesh. So, Sheldon, tell me more about this princess you say I look like.
response: It was said that the Gods fashioned her eyes out of the stars, and that roses were ashamed to bloom in the presence of her ruby lips.

speaker: Back off Sheldon.
response: What?

speaker: If you do not stop hitting on my lady you will feel the full extent of my wrath.
response: I’m not hitting on her.

speaker: Okay, let’s get something straight here. The only reason I came tonight was to get my parents off my case, I certainly don’t need to be getting this old world crap from you.
response: Exactly the kind of spirit with which Princess Punchali led the monkeys to freedom.

speaker: But you’re not Princess Punchali.
response: Luckily for you, she could have you beheaded.

speaker: Sheldon, are you hungry?
response: I could eat.

speaker: Go ahead, tell my parents why they won’t have any grandchildren.
response: How would I know, do you have a low sperm count?

speaker: Can we please stop talking about my testicles? Sheldon, tell them what you did.
response: What did I do?

speaker: You left with his date. Friends don’t do that to each other.
response: Oh. Alright, noted. Sorry.

speaker: Take it, Raj. It’s more than I’ve ever gotten.
response: And may I point out she wouldn’t have asked me to go with her if you hadn’t been drunk and boring.

speaker: Drunk?
response: And boring, her words.

speaker: Please wait until I get into the hall.
response: Okay, well, good night.

speaker: Hold on. What happened with you and Lalita?
response: We ate. She lectured me on the link between gum disease and heart attacks, nothing I didn’t already know, and I came home.

speaker: So you’re not going to see her again?
response: Why would I see her again? I already have a dentist. (Exits)

speaker: I concur, but you changed the subject. What are we doing for Valentine’s Day?
response: Oh, you caught that, did you?

speaker: Oh, Dr. Cooper, thank you. I’ve been waiting for an opportunity to contribute to your scientific work.
response: Oh, no, no. That’s not going to happen, no. What I need you to do is find a Valentine’s gift for my girlfriend.

speaker: You realize I passed up an opportunity to work at Fermilab to take this job with you.
response: Well, I guess those chaps will have to have someone else buy their girlfriends presents. Now, here is, let’s see, this is, this is about two thousand dollars, um, I think she likes monkeys and the colour grey. Contribute to my work. Ah, kids say the darnedest things.

speaker: Okay, I think I have some really great choices. I went on Amy’s Facebook page and read up on her interests.
response: Now, see, I never would have thought to do that. Clearly, I made a good choice farming this out to you. But I am telling you, Amy hit the boyfriend jackpot. Anyway, my socks are on. Let’s knock them off.

speaker: Well, um, I know she loves playing the harp, so I found this beautiful music box that plays one of her favourite songs.
response: Now, Amy already has a real harp. And it can play any song. What are you trying to pull here?

speaker: No, I just thought it would be…
response: Next.

speaker: Okay. Um, I know she’s a fan of The Canterbury Tales.
response: Mmm.

speaker: So I found this cool map that illustrates the character’s journey through England. I thought we could put it in a really nice frame.
response: But she’s got Google Maps on her phone.

speaker: I don’t know how to respond to that.
response: Well, I hope it’s with a third good option, because these first two, buh.

speaker: Okay. Well, uh, luckily, I saved the best for last. Since Amy’s a neuroscientist, I did some research and found out that Santiago Ramon y Cajal, the father of modern neuroscience, did lots of hand drawings of brain cells. And I managed to find this signed print.
response: Wow. Oh, this is truly remarkable.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I think I’ll keep it for myself.

speaker: What about your girlfriend?
response: It’s too late. I call dibs.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: Happy Valentine’s Day.
response: Okay. Shall we go to dinner?

speaker: Hang on. As you know, I had planned a traditional evening of romance and gifts.
response: Yes, and as you know, I planned to pretend to enjoy it. I’ve been working on this facial expression all day.

speaker: And I appreciate your effort, but upon contemplation, I decided I was being selfish. So, I cancelled our dinner reservations and came up with an even better way to celebrate Valentine’s Day.
response: What is that?

speaker: By doing none of it. No dinner, no romance, no gifts. We stay here, order a pizza and watch one of your beloved Star w*r Trek things.
response: Really?

speaker: Well, that’s what you’d love, isn’t it?
response: More than anything.

speaker: Well, then, that’s what we’re going to do.
response: Well, I don’t know what to say. This is the most thoughtful gift that anyone’s ever given me. And that’s including an amazing gift that I gave myself earlier today.

speaker: I’m your girlfriend. That’s my job. And I know gift-giving puts a lot of pressure on you, so whatever you got me, you can return.
response: No. No, after everything you didn’t do for me tonight, I want you to have it.

speaker: What’s this?
response: Read it.

speaker: Sheldon Cooper, Caltech University employee information?
response: At the bottom.

speaker: In case of emergency, please contact… Amy Farrah Fowler. And there’s my phone number. This is the most beautiful gift you could’ve ever given me.
response: Well, I thought, if I have a stroke or a kidney stone, who would I want to share that with?

speaker: And you picked me.
response: It’s like you said, you’re my girlfriend.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon.
response: Yeah. Okay. Stop ruining Valentine’s Day and order my pizza.

speaker: Alright, just a few more feet, and…. here we are gentlemen, the Gates of Elzebub.
response: Good lord!

speaker: Warriors, unsheathe your w*apon, magic wielders raise your wands.
response: Lock and load.

speaker: Sheldon, he’s got Raj, use your sleath spell. Sheldon! Sheldon!
response: I’ve got the Sword of Azeroth!

speaker: Forget the sword, Sheldon, help Raj.
response: There is no more Sheldon, I am the Swordmaster!

speaker: Dammit man, we’re dying here.
response: Goodbye, peasants.

speaker: You betrayed us for money, who are you?
response: I’m a rogue knight elf, don’t you people read character descriptions? Wait, wait, wait, somebody just clicked “buy it now.”

speaker: Excuse me.
response: Don’t forget the mail you took accidentally on purpose so you’d have an excuse to talk to her.

speaker: No problem. Bye. Oh, and, bye, bro! (Returns to apartment).
response: Penny for your thoughts.

speaker: I’m a romantic.
response: Please don’t tell me that your hopeless infatuation is devolving into pointless jealousy.

speaker: Yeah. He was kinda dreamy.
response: Well, at least now you can retrieve the black box from the twisted smouldering wreckage that was once your fantasy of dating her, and analyse the data so that you don’t crash into geek mountain again.

speaker: I don’t know. Olivia Geiger?
response: The dietician at the cafeteria with the limp and the lazy eye?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Well, I don’t think you have a sh*t there. I have noticed that Lesley Winkle recently started shaving her legs. Now, given that winter is coming one can only assume that she is signalling sexual availability.

speaker: Sheldon, if you were a robot, and I knew and you didn’t, would you want me to tell you?
response: That depends. When I learn that I’m a robot, will I be able to handle it?

speaker: Maybe, although the history of science-fiction is not on your side.
response: Uh, let me ask you this. When I learn that I’m a robot, would I be bound by Asimov’s three laws of robotics?

speaker: That’s true. Have you ever harmed a human being, or through inaction allowed a human being to come to harm?
response: Of course not.

speaker: Have you ever harmed yourself, or allowed yourself to be harmed except in cases where a human being would have been endangered?
response: Well, no.

speaker: Hey, what’s going on.
response: The internet’s been down for half an hour.

speaker: Oh, we tried kissing, but the earth didn’t move. I mean any more than the 383 miles that it was going to move anyway.
response: Oh, I’ve seen that look before. This is just going to be two weeks of moping and tedious emo songs, and calling me to come down to pet stores to look at cats. I don’t know if I can take it.

speaker: You don’t know me, you don’t wear my chains… God, that’s a good song.
response: If you’re compiling a mix CD for a double su1c1de. (Leonard is taking supplies out of a bag) Oh, I hope that scratching post is for you.

speaker: I know what you’re thinking, I’ve taken your asthma into account. There’s a feline geneticist in San Diego who has developed the cutest little hypo-allergenic calicos.
response: Leonard, listen to me…

speaker: I’ve been thinking about names, I’m kind of torn between Einstein, Newton and Sergeant Fuzzyboots.
response: Leonard, do you really think you can satisfy your need for a relationship with a genetically altered cat?

speaker: Maybe, if it’s a cute little cuddly cat.
response: Oh, come on, Leonard! This is obviously about Penny.

speaker: It doesn’t matter. The woman’s not interested in me, the woman rejected me.
response: Okay, look, I think that you have as much of a chance of having a sexual relationship with Penny as the Hubble Telescope does of discovering at the centre of every black hole is a little man with a flashlight searching for a circuit breaker. Nevertheless, I do feel obligated to point out to you that she did no reject you. You did not ask her out.

speaker: You’re right. I didn’t ask her out, I should ask her out.
response: No. No, now that was not my point. My point was, don’t buy a cat.

speaker: No, but you’re right. I should march over there and ask her out.
response: Oh, goody, we’re getting a cat.

speaker: How do I look?
response: Could you be more specific?

speaker: Can you tell I’m perspiring a little?
response: No. The dark crescent-shaped patterns under your arms conceal it nicely. What time is your date?

speaker: Six thirty.
response: Perfect, that gives you two hours and fifteen minutes for that dense molecular cloud of Aramis to dissipate.

speaker: Is it too much?
response: Not if you’re a rugby team.

speaker: By the way, if it should ever come up, you didn’t join us because you stuffed yourself with a chicken carbonara sub at Quizznos.
response: Why would I join you?

speaker: No reason. Oh, you know what, maybe this isn’t such a good idea.
response: Oh, no, no, no, well now, there’s always the possibility that alcohol and poor judgement on her part might lead to a nice romantic evening.

speaker: You’re right, alcohol, poor judgement, it could go well.
response: Of course, there’s the other possibility that this date kicks off a rather unpleasant six months of the two of you passing awkwardly in the hall until one of you breaks down and moves to another zip code.

speaker: You could have stopped at “it could go well.”
response: If I could of, I would of.

speaker: I mean, I’m a perfectly nice guy. There’s no reason we couldn’t go to the restaurant and have a lovely dinner. Maybe take a walk afterwards, talk about things we have in common, “you love pottery? I love pottery!” You know, there’s a pause, we both know what’s happening, I lean in, we kiss, it’s a little tentative at first but then I realise, she’s kissing me back, and she’s biting my lower lip, you know, she wants me, this thing is going the distance, we’re going to have sex! Oh God! Oh, my God!
response: Is the sex starting now?

speaker: I’m having a panic attack.
response: Oh, okay, well then, calm down.

speaker: If I could calm down I wouldn’t be having a panic attack, that’s why they call it a panic attack.
response: Alright, alright, well, just, sit down, yes, sit down, now close your eyes.

speaker: Why?
response: Just do it.

speaker: Okay.
response: Now try to increase your alpha-wave activity.

speaker: What?
response: It’s a bio-feedback technique, it’s relaxation through brain-wave manipulation, I read a paper about it in the Journal of American Neuroscience, it was a little sparsely sourced but I think the basic science is valid, I probably have it here somewhere.

speaker: Oh, who am I kidding, I can’t go through with this, you need to call her and cancel.
response: Me?

speaker: Yes.
response: What should I tell her.

speaker: I don’t know. Tell her I’m sick.
response: Okay.

speaker: Not the kind of illness that will make her want to come over and take care of me, but nothing so critical that she’ll feel uncomfortable going out with me in the future if I want to try this again.
response: Got it. So I’m assuming nothing venereal. I’ll just tell her that you had a routine colonoscopy and haven’t quite bounced back.

speaker: Give me the phone.
response: But I thought you wanted to cancel?

speaker: I can’t because if I don’t show up she’ll still be expecting you.
response: Why would she be expecting me?

speaker: Awesome!
response: Score one for liquor and poor judgement.

speaker: You’re welcome, ladies.
response: Paradigm-shifting news, gentlemen. (Switches game off)

speaker: Dude! I was about to Bollywood this bitch.
response: Earlier today, I invited Professor Stephen Hawking to join me in the popular online game Words with Friends. Moments ago, he accepted my request. Do you understand what that means?

speaker: That somewhere right now Stephen Hawking is saying, damn it, I meant to click no.”
response: I’ll walk you through it. The game is not called Words with Strangers. No, it’s not even called Words with Acquaintances. It is called Words with…

speaker: I’m not finishing your sentence. You pulled the plug on my funk.
response: Friends! It’s Words with Friends! Which Stephen Hawking and I officially are. Now all I need is a bunk bed with a slide, I’ll have everything I’ve ever wanted since I was six years old.

speaker: That’s really nice, Sheldon, I’m happy for you.
response: And I’m happy for you, too. You are now friends with someone who is officially friends with Stephen Hawking. Enjoy it, boys. You may have peaked.

speaker: Sheldon, I know Stephen Hawking. I worked with him.
response: And if they ever come out with a game called Words with People You Once Worked With, you’ll be off to the races.

speaker: Sheldon, I don’t think this actually means…
response: Hold that thought! Professor Hawking has made a move. Boy, oh, boy. Oh, it’s only a matter of time before we’re coming up with fun nicknames for each other. I’ll be Coop. He’ll be Wheels. If he’s okay with that. (Leaves)

speaker: Wow, my boyfriend is friends with Stephen Hawking and my new dandruff shampoo doesn’t smell like tar. Everything really is coming up Amy.
response: It is glorious. One of the greatest intellects of our time has agreed to engage with me in a gentlemanly battle of wits. And I’m spanking him so hard his grad students won’t be able to sit down.

speaker: You know, when one male dominates another, his testosterone level rises.
response: What’s your point?

speaker: It’s exciting to think you might be getting a testosterone level.
response: Ooh, my friend Stephen just played the word act for 18 points. That’s right, I call him Stephen now, because I checked, and he was not okay with Wheels.

speaker: Oh, you could turn his act into extract (pronounced with emphasis on act), and it would be for double points.
response: Amy. Why would you give me a word? Now, if I play extract it would be cheating.

speaker: Sorry.
response: Although, I could play the completely unrelated and better word extract (pronounced with emphasis on ex). Ethical conundrum avoided. Thanks, brain.

speaker: Sheldon, you okay?
response: It’s been three days. Why hasn’t Stephen Hawking played a word?

speaker: The guy’s a genius. Maybe you weren’t challenging enough for him.
response: Not challenging? I was humiliating the man. I was thinking of writing a book called A Brief History of the Time I Made Stephen Hawking Cry Like a Little Girl.

speaker: There’s the problem. You can’t b*at Hawking like that. He hates to lose. Everyone knows the guy’s a big baby. I mean, forget the wheelchair, he should be in a stroller.
response: Really?
