speaker: One time when I was working with him, he said that Johnny Depp was in The Matrix. I told him he was wrong, but he kept insisting. So I looked it up online and showed him. Well, the next day, he had a pizza party, and everyone got invited but me. And then he was all, your invitation must have gotten lost in the matrix.
response: Good Lord, what have I done?

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Trying to use a Jedi mind trick to control Stephen Hawking. Play. Play. Ugh! He must be wearing a tinfoil hat or something.

speaker: I did a bad thing.
response: Does it affect me?

speaker: No.
response: Then suffer in silence. Play. Play. Play. (Knock knock knock) Stephen Hawking. (Knock knock knock) Stephen Hawking. (Knock knock knock) Stephen Hawking.

speaker: Penny started taking a class. She wrote a paper, she didn’t want me to read it, I went behind her back and I read it anyway.
response: Stephen Hawking hates me.

speaker: I don’t know what to do. I mean, the paper’s terrible. But if I tell her, she’ll know that I read it and she’ll get really mad.
response: I was b*at him so bad, he doesn’t want to be friends anymore. Why does everyone love me except Stephen Hawking?

speaker: Is it possible we’re having two different conversations?
response: How would I know? I’m not listening to you.

speaker: Hang on. Okay, here’s what we’re gonna do. Chess clock. We each get five minutes to talk about our problems. We’ll take turns. Each turn will consist of a statement and a helpful response from the friend. Begin.
response: I humiliated Stephen Hawking in a game of Words with Friends. He stopped playing, and now we’re not friends anymore.

speaker: He’s probably busy. You’re worried about nothing. Give it a couple more days. I’m sure he’ll play, and you’ll see that everything’s fine. My turn. I can’t let Penny hand in a bad paper, but how do I tell her it’s bad without letting her know that I read it?
response: Hmm. b*at me. Now, I know Hawking’s not busy because I can see he’s playing other people right now.

speaker: Maybe since you’re so good, he’s taking his time to meet the challenge. I want Penny to enjoy school…
response: Wolowitz told me he’s a big baby. But I didn’t know that, and I played extract for 82 points. It’s all Amy’s fault. She told me to play it. I have got to cut her loose.

speaker: Sheldon, I wasn’t done talking. She hands in the paper tomorrow. I know I could help her. And she’s my girlfriend. I, I should be allowed to help her. Why aren’t I allowed to help her?
response: Yeah, I hear you, brother.

speaker: No. You need to give me some advice.
response: Fine. Women, huh?

speaker: No, specific to my situation.
response: Blonde women, huh?

speaker: Empathetic.
response: It sucks to be you.

speaker: I quit.
response: Leonard, wait. No. I listened to your dumb thing. Leonard, come back. Leonard, come back. Leonard, come back.

speaker: What?
response: Oh, of course, it only works on the weak-minded.

speaker: You ever hear back from Hawking?
response: No. It would appear as if I’ve lost him. Stupid brain.

speaker: It’ll be okay.
response: How can it be okay? Stephen Hawking’s a genius and he talks like a robot. It’s everything I’ve ever wanted in a friend.

speaker: Yeah, but if he’s a sore loser, maybe you’re better off without him.
response: You’re right. I guess I just have to make lemonade out of the two of you. He played! He played! Coop and Rolling Thunder are together again. He was okay with that nickname.

speaker: So, now all you have to do is let him win.
response: Yeah, way ahead of you. I will play the word at for two measly points, throwing the game and thus securing my friendship with the smartest man in the world.

speaker: What are you waiting for? Hit send.
response: I can’t. Losing on purpose is intellectually dishonest.

speaker: So don’t do it.
response: Oh, but I want to be Hawking’s friend.

speaker: So do it.
response: Oh, but if I do, I’ll be a phony, a sellout, a Hollywood poser.

speaker: Then don’t do it.
response: I won’t. This feels right. My mother always said, to thine own self be true.

speaker: Good for you.
response: ‘Course she also told me that every animal in the world got on one boat, so what does she know? And send.

speaker: Hmm, how about, gee, Penny, you’re smarter than I thought. You may be the one in school, but I’m the one who learned a lesson. I’m so stupid, Penny. Duh.
response: She sounds exactly like you.

speaker: Well answer it. I want to hear.
response: Professor Hawking, how nice of you to call.

speaker: Hello. I really enjoyed our game, Dr. Cooper.
response: Oh, me, too.

speaker: Or should I say Dr. Loser? Ha, ha, ha.
response: Yes, congratulations. You won fair and square. Uh, very impressive, sir.

speaker: Do you like brain teasers?
response: Oh, I love brain teasers.

speaker: You got it.
response: That’s preposterous. I do not resemble C3PO. Don’t get me wrong, I’m flattered, I just don’t see it.

speaker: Leslie Winkle. You’ve reached friends with benefits. For a booty call, press one now.
response: What exactly does that expression mean, friends with benefits? Does he provide her with health insurance?

speaker: No. Look, imagine you maintained a friendship with someone you had sex with, but you were free to date whoever you wanted.
response: I’m sorry, I can’t imagine any of that.

speaker: Alright, back to the game.
response: I believe it’s my turn, you may begin your questions whenever you’re ready.

speaker: Are you Spock?
response: I don’t like this game.

speaker: She dumped me!
response: I bet he’s someone from Babylon 5, we’re never going to guess.

speaker: I don’t know. She just said Howard, momma’s a rolling stone. And then her call waiting beeped and she was gone.
response: I don’t understand. If you were in a non-emotional relationship then why are you having what appears be an emotional response?

speaker: I don’t want to go anywhere.
response: You know, I’m given to understand that there is an entire city in Nevada designed specifically to help people like Howard forget their problems. Where you can replace them with

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, are you coming?
response: I’d rather have a blowfly lay eggs and hatch larvae in my auditory canal.

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: And how are you doing this fine evening?

speaker: Great.
response: Good. I’m glad.

speaker: Really? Are you drunk?
response: I’m just in a good mood. While my compatriots are in Las Vegas, I will be enjoying a blissful evening in my personal Fortress of Solitude.

speaker: That’s Superman’s big ice thing, right?
response: Do you know, I’m such a good mood, I’m actually finding your tenuous grasp of the English language folksy and charming today.

speaker: Mmm, what smells so good?
response: That is the intoxicating aroma of Kadhai Paneer, a perfect culinary representation of the freedom this evening holds. Not only is it Indian cuisine, which Koothrappali loathes, it contains a generous helping of peanuts, which would reduce Wolowitz to a wheezing 97 pound blister. And finally, it’s main ingredient is Paneer, a farmer’s cheese which would cause Leonard to render any room uninhabitable within minutes.

speaker: Yum. Well, enjoy your big evening.
response: Penny. I realize you are also on your own tonight, so if at some point you find yourself with nothing to do, please do not disturb me.

speaker: Have fun, Sheldon.
response: Oh, I shall. (Sings Superman theme while searching his pockets.) No!

speaker: Hang on, I think the emergency key is around here somewhere.
response: We have a bowl. Our keys go in a bowl. You should get a bowl.

speaker: So, how did the beautiful mind of Sheldon Cooper forget his key in the first place.
response: I left them in the bowl.

speaker: Oh-oh. I just remembered where the emergency key is.
response: Where?

speaker: In your apartment.
response: What’s it doing in my apartment?

speaker: Well, I went in there a few weeks ago when you guys weren’t home, and I forgot it there.
response: You were in my… why would you… what are you saying?

speaker: It’s not a big deal, I was making coffee and I ran out of milk.
response: You’re the milk thief! Leonard said I was crazy but I knew that carton felt lighter.

speaker: Alright, Sheldon, let’s just calm down and we’ll call the building manager, he’ll come open your door, you just eat your dinner here while you’re waiting.
response: Eat? My dinner? In your apartment?

speaker: Yeah, why not?
response: Sure, why not? And after the sun’s down we can all pile in my pick-up and go skinny-dipping down at the creek. ‘Cause today’s the day to stop making sense.

speaker: Are you trying to make small talk? Oh, sweetie, you really don’t have to.
response: No, it’s the accepted convention. How was your day?

speaker: Well, uh, they shifted my schedule around at the restaurant so my hours are going to be a little different…
response: I’m sorry, that’s not going to interest me at all, just eat.

speaker: Oh, God, I don’t know Sheldon, are you Star Wars?
response: How can one person be a whole movie?

speaker: Okay, I give up, can we just do something else?
response: Fine. I was Spock. Are you and Leonard friends with benefits.

speaker: What?
response: Are you and Leonard friends with benefits?

speaker: Where did that even come from, did he say we were?
response: No, Leonard said nothing, but who knows what goes on over here when he pretends your mail was misdelivered.

speaker: No, just mail, no benefits.
response: Hmm, I see.

speaker: Why are you asking?
response: I’m curious about the whole social construct. On its face, the idea of satisfying ones sexual appetite, assuming one is afflicted with such, without emotional entanglement, that seems eminently practical. What I’ve observed, however, is Howard Wolowitz crying like a little girl.

speaker: Well, some people just can’t handle that kind of relationship.
response: Can you?

speaker: Excuse me?
response: Are you able to have sex with men without developing an emotional attachment?

speaker: Sheldon, I really don’t want to talk about this with you.
response: Is this conversation making you uncomfortable?

speaker: Of course it’s making me uncomfortable, can’t you tell?
response: I really have no idea. I don’t particularly excel at reading facial expressions, body language…

speaker: I’m uncomfortable, Sheldon!
response: Thank you, that’s very helpful.

speaker: I don’t think the manager’s coming tonight so, here.
response: Are you suggesting I sleep on the couch.

speaker: Well, it wasn’t the first suggestion that came to mind, but it’s the one I’m going with.
response: I can’t sleep on your couch. I sleep in a bed. And given it’s dimensions I have no intention of living out E.M. Snickering’s beloved children’s book , The Tall Man From Cornwall.

speaker: What?
response: There was a tall man from Cornwall whose length exceeded his bed. My body fits on it, but barely upon it, there’s no room for my big Cornish head.

speaker: Oh, alright. I will give you my bed on one condition. That you promise to zip your hole for the next eight hours.
response: May I say one last thing.

speaker: Only if it doesn’t rhyme.
response: Alright. Goodnight.

speaker: What?
response: I can’t sleep. how are you going?

speaker: Maybe that’s because your hole is still open.
response: I’m homesick.

speaker: Your home is twenty feet from here.
response: Twenty feet, twenty light years, it doesn’t matter. It’s in a galaxy far, far away.

speaker: Damn it. What do you want me to do
response: Sing soft kitty.

speaker: That’s only for when you’re sick.
response: Homesick is a type of being sick.

speaker: Come on, do I really have to?
response: I suppose we can stay up and talk.

speaker: Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur. Happy kitty, um…
response: Sleepy kitty.

speaker: Sleepy ki…
response: No. Start over.

speaker: Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur. Happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr, purr, purr.
response: Penny.

speaker: Yeah.
response: Thank you for letting me stay here.

speaker: Oh, you’re welcome sweetie.
response: Okay, I’m sleepy now, get out.

speaker: What were you doing at Penny’s?
response: Well, we had dinner, uh, played some games, and then I spent the night. Oh, you’ll be happy to know that I now have a much better understanding of friends with benefits.

speaker: Uh, I was hoping you wouldn’t notice. Irene was always a slave to a good bargain when it came to clothes, and sadly as it turned out, space heaters.
response: Ladies, please. These four walls once housed an intellectual salon where the mind received nourishment as well as the stomach. But through no one’s fault, Penny, the quality of dinner conversation in this apartment has declined. And again, I’m looking at no one in particular, Penny.

speaker: What would you like to talk about, Sheldon? Why do you hate us?
response: I’ve prepared a number of topics that should appeal to both the advanced and novice conversationalists.

speaker: Who didn’t? Your skin is like alabaster. Do you even have pores?
response: Topic one. Faster-than-light particles at CERN, paradigm-shifting discovery or another Swiss export as full of holes as their cheese? And converse.

speaker: Wait for moi.
response: You’re leaving?

speaker: Sheldon, sometimes you forget, I’m a lady. And with that comes an oestrogen fuelled need to page through thick glossy magazines that make me hate my body.
response: Ah. New topic. Women, delightfully mysterious or bat-crap crazy?

speaker: Your neurology department loaned me a culture of prions for my research on bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
response: She popped by to borrow a cup of mad cow disease.

speaker: Please, we’re eating. Can we get that off the table and change the subject?
response: Can we? Stand back while I turn this conversation into a conver-sensation.

speaker: This time, it’s your fault.
response: I have 100 alphabetized topics from artichoke, come on, people, it’s just a giant thistle, to zzz, the onamona-poetry of sleep.

speaker: Leonard’s coming down the home stretch! Come on, horsey, you can do this! Damn. Come on, thigh muscles, you can do this! Yes! First place. I would have been a great jockey if I weren’t too tall. And scared of horses. Sheldon, you’re up.
response: What?

speaker: Come on, it’s your turn. We said we’d get more fresh air.
response: Sorry. I’m a little distracted. I can’t seem to get in touch with Amy. I tried e-mail, video chat, tweeting her, posting on her Facebook wall, texting her, nothing.

speaker: Did you try calling her on the telephone?
response: The telephone. You know, Leonard, in your own simple way, you may be the wisest of us all. Voice mail. Curiouser and curiouser.

speaker: If you’re worried, we can go over there and see if she’s all right.
response: Okay. You know, I heard in the news a bobcat has been spotted in her neighbourhood.

speaker: I don’t think Amy was eaten by a bobcat.
response: Who thinks Amy was eaten by a bobcat?

speaker: You do?
response: Leonard, I was just mentioning an interesting local news item. Now, thanks to you, I’m worried Amy’s been eaten by a bobcat.

speaker: Forget about the bobcat.
response: How can I? You won’t stop talking about it.

speaker: Everybody hurts, sometimes everybody cries. Everybody hurts, sometimes.
response: She sounds weepy. I don’t like weepy. Let’s go.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Bye.
response: Where are you going?

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: You didn’t respond to any of my electronic communications.

speaker: I wanted to be alone.
response: Would you like to talk about it? And keep in mind that no is a perfectly viable answer.

speaker: Sheldon, my world is crumbling around me.
response: Point of order. As you’re in distress, it would be customary for me to offer you a hot beverage. But I’m a guest in your home, so it would be customary for you to offer me a beverage. How do you want to proceed vis-a-vis beverages?

speaker: It doesn’t matter. Nothing matters.
response: If you’d like to take your mind off what’s troubling you, uh, word on the street is a bobcat has been spotted.

speaker: Penny and Bernadette went shopping for bridesmaids dresses without me.
response: And that made you feel sad?

speaker: Yes.
response: I knew it. Just keep going, I guess I’m good at this.

speaker: It’s just, I thought they liked hanging out with me, but I guess I was fooling myself.
response: When they were over here, did you fail to offer them a beverage? ‘Cause I can see how that could stick in someone’s craw.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m going to ask you something, and I’d like you to keep an open mind.
response: Always.

speaker: At this moment, I find myself craving human intimacy and physical contact.
response: Oh, boy. You know ours is a relationship of the mind.

speaker: Proposal. One wild night of torrid lovemaking that soothes my soul and inflames my loins.
response: Counterproposal. I will gently stroke your head and repeat, aw, who’s a good Amy.

speaker: How about this? French kissing, seven minutes in heaven culminating in second base.
response: Neck massage, then you get me that beverage.

speaker: We cuddle. Final offer.
response: Very well. Oh, boy. (They cuddle, awkwardly.)

speaker: This is not a safe place. You can’t share anything here.
response: The two of you need to get your women in line!

speaker: What?
response: Last night I was strong-armed into an evening of harp music and spooning with an emotional Amy Farrah Fowler. This on a night that I had originally designated for solving the space-time geometry in higher-spin gravity and building my Lego Death Star. And why? Your gal pals, Penny and Bernadette, went out shopping for some wedding nonsense without Amy, an action they took with no thought or regard as to how it would affect me, the future of string theory or my Lego fun time.

speaker: What do you want us to do about it?
response: You clearly weren’t listening to my topic sentence, get your women in line! You make them apologize to Amy and set things right. I am a man of science, not someone’s snuggle bunny!

speaker: Why do I have to talk to Penny? She’s not my girlfriend.
response: You invited her to lunch four years ago. Everything about her is on you, you make it so!

speaker: What’s going on?
response: It would seem Amy is drunk in a liquor store parking lot.

speaker: Really? Amy?
response: Leonard, be glad you can’t keep a woman. They are a handful.

speaker: Cuddles?
response: Yes, Cuddles. We cuddled. Grow up, Leonard.

speaker: Yeah, Sheldon, what would it take?
response: I’m begging both of you, please, let’s go.

speaker: All I’m saying is, if they took all the money they spent trying to make a decent Hulk movie, they could probably just make an actual Hulk.
response: That is apt and amusing. I think I shall share that with Amy Farrah Fowler. She’ll appreciate the witticism.

speaker: Thank you.
response: It’ll also help improve her initial impression of you.

speaker: So what’s going on with you two?
response: Well, the status is as it always was. She’s a girl. She’s a friend. She is not my, please forgive me for doing this, girlfriend.

speaker: Right, right. So you’re still just texting and emailing? You don’t feel any need to hang out with her, you know, be in the same room?
response: Leonard, you are my best friend. I’ve known you for seven years, and I can barely tolerate sitting on the couch with you. Imagine my attitude regarding prolonged physical proximity to Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: Got it.
response: I sense judgment on your part.

speaker: No, no. Maybe a little.
response: May I suggest that your criticism is based on jealousy.

speaker: Jealousy? What do I have to be jealous of?
response: I have a functioning and satisfying relationship with a female. You have none.

speaker: Oh, right. That.
response: Jealousy is an ugly green-eyed monster, not unlike the Hulk, who, by the way, also has a girlfriend. In this iteration, Jennifer Connelly, whom you may recall as the girlfriend of Russell Crowe in A Beautiful Mind, a feel-good romp if there ever was one.

speaker: I’m not jealous.
response: Hu-u-urgh! Leonard not jealous.

speaker: Probably. What’s your point?
response: No point. It’s just one of the things that makes one of the mes chuckle. What makes you chuckle, Leonard?

speaker: Hmm, recently? Not much.
response: Is it because of the conflict that arises from your desperate need to pair-bond with a woman, and the apparent collective decision of all womankind to deny you that opportunity?

speaker: Um, shut up.
response: You know, when my grandfather died, and Meemaw was alone, my mom arranged for her to visit a centre three times a week where she could socialize with other lonely people. It’s very nice. They discuss current events, play bridge, get a hot meal.

speaker: That sounds lovely.
response: It is if you like bridge. Do you like bridge, Leonard?

speaker: Sheldon, I’m just not dating someone right now. I don’t need to go to a senior centre.
response: Meemaw resisted at first, but now she loves it.

speaker: Fine. If I don’t meet someone soon, you can put me in a home.
response: It’s not a home. It’s a senior centre. We’d never put Meemaw in a home!

speaker: Hey.
response: All right, I’ll bow to social pressure. Hey!

speaker: Great. You have a girlfriend, Howard’s got a girlfriend, Sheldon’s got a girl…
response: No, no, no, no!

speaker: …who’s a friend.
response: Thank you.

speaker: No.
response: Are you ill?

speaker: No.
response: Are you still depressed because you’re alone, and no one loves you?

speaker: I don’t know. Maybe.
response: I want you to know that I’m genuinely concerned about your well-being.

speaker: Thank you.
response: You’re welcome. But it’s still no reason to have your feet in my spot.

speaker: What the hell? How long has she been here?
response: Since we got home from the comic bookstore.

speaker: That was two hours ago.
response: As per your suggestion, we’re hanging out. Quite frankly, I don’t see what all the hoopla’s about. Go on, Amy.

speaker: From a neurobiological standpoint, Leonard, you may be alone because your psychological state is causing an actual pheromone-based stink of desperation.
response: Did you know that, Leonard?

speaker: No.
response: I did.

speaker: No, I’m not gonna try to pick up a woman in a bar.
response: Wise decision. You see, Amy, success at a bar is based on classic male attributes such as height, strength, attractiveness, the ability to hold one’s liquor and throw darts, separately or together. Leonard has none of these attributes, right, Leonard?

speaker: That’s not true of all bars. Juice bars, for example.
response: Oh! Good point, Amy. Yeah, building on your premise, Leonard could frequent sushi bars, salad bars, oyster bars, the Apple Genius Bar, what are you doing?

speaker: That was rude.
response: He does it all the time. He’s a cornucopia of social awkwardness.

speaker: Cornucopia. What a mellifluous word.
response: Let’s make that our word of the day.

speaker: Agreed. And we’ll use mellifluous tomorrow.
response: Well, I have to void my bladder. It was nice spending this time with you.

speaker: Wait. I have a request.
response: Yes?

speaker: I’d like you to meet my mother.
response: I see. Can I get back to you on that?

speaker: Certainly. Good night.
response: Good night. (Closing laptop, and running down stairs in panic) Leonard, Leonard, Leonard,

speaker: Yeah, what?
response: Amy Farrah Fowler has asked me to meet her mother.

speaker: Yeah. So?
response: What does that mean?

speaker: Well, you know how you’re always saying that Amy is a girl who’s your friend, and not your girlfriend?
response: Uh-huh.

speaker: You can’t say that anymore.
response: Wait. What?

speaker: Look, she obviously wants to take your relationship to the next level.
response: I don’t want the next level. I like this level. Fix it for me!

speaker: Me? Well, how am I supposed to fix it?
response: Simple! You want a girlfriend, Amy wants to be someone’s girlfriend. Take her off my hands. I give you my blessing.

speaker: That is insane.
response: You’re right. It would never work. Amy finds you tedious.

speaker: Okay, good luck.
response: Wait! What am I supposed to do?

speaker: Well, have you considered telling her how you feel?
response: Leonard, I’m a physicist, not a hippie.

speaker: All right, well, let me see if I can explain your situation using physics. What would you be if you were attached to another object by an inclined plane wrapped helically around an axis?
response: Screwed.

speaker: There you go.
response: Amy’s right. He is tedious.

speaker: Well, I’m off to meet Bernadette’s friend. How do I look?
response: As if one of the plants from Invasion of the Body Snatchers duplicated you in every way, only with an absurd amount of hair gel.

speaker: What are you working on?
response: I’m removing my digital footprint from the Internet so Amy Farrah Fowler can’t find me and compel me to meet her mother.

speaker: Ah, you’re going off the grid.
response: Exactly.

speaker: The old b*mb approach. Kudos.
response: Thank you. I’ve also sent Amy a relationship termination notice and changed my cell phone number and e-mail address.

speaker: What if she just comes over?
response: She’ll get lost. We no longer live at 2311 Los Robles. We now live at 311 Los Robles.

speaker: You changed the address on the building? What about mail?
response: Oh, no worries, I explained my predicament to our letter carrier. He was sympathetic. His exact words were, Got your back, Jack. Bitches be crazy.

speaker: Amy Farrah Fowler.
response: Darn! She found me!

speaker: She’s been here before.
response: The only flaw in an otherwise perfect plan. Now, get my back, Jack.

speaker: What do you want to do?
response: Tell her I’m not here.

speaker: Okay, where are you?
response: I don’t know. You’ll have to devise a scenario that plausibly explains my absence, keeping in mind that the key to a good lie lies in the details.

speaker: All right. (Leaves)
response: Way to go on the details.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Rats!

speaker: I believe a misunderstanding may have occurred when I asked you to meet my mother.
response: No misunderstanding. I’ve learned what that request actually means, and I don’t want to be joined to another object by an inclined plane wrapped helically around an axis.

speaker: In what way are you screwed? All I want to do is present you as my boyfriend to my mother so she’ll be satisfied that I’m in a relationship.
response: So we’d be perpetrating a ruse?

speaker: Precisely.
response: And you haven’t fallen hopelessly in love with me?

speaker: Don’t be absurd. I find the notion of romantic love to be an unnecessary cultural construct that adds no value to human relationships.
response: Amy Farrah Fowler, that’s the most pragmatic thing anyone has ever said to me.

speaker: I trust this clarification allows us to return to boy-slash-friend-slash-girl-slash-friend status.
response: Of course. Would you like to join me for Chinese food?

speaker: Sheldon, please, you’re suffocating me.
response: My apologies. Good night, Amy.

speaker: It’s nice to meet you, too, Sheldon. I honestly didn’t believe Amy when she told me she had a boyfriend.
response: I assure you I am quite real and I’m having regular intercourse with your daughter.

speaker: What?
response: Oh, yes. We’re like wild animals in heat. It’s a wonder neither of us has been hurt.

speaker: You wanted me to have a boyfriend, Mother. Well, here he is. Have to sign off now. My hunger for Sheldon is stirring in my loins.
response: Oh, yes, it’s time for me to make love to your daughter’s vagina.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon, that went very well.
response: Agreed. Amy, I find myself wondering if we should actually engage in coitus at least one time in our relationship. Bazinga. Bedtime. Please show yourself out.

speaker: Wow, Sheldon, I cannot believe you made up your own game.
response: Oh, Research Lab is more than a game. It’s like the slogan says, the physics is theoretical, but the fun is real.

speaker: All right, five. One, two, three, four, five. Oh, wow, look at that, my Department of Defence research grant is renewed.
response: Oh! Great roll! Now you can demolish your Soviet-style cyclotron and build the large Hadron Collider.

speaker: Yay.
response: You’re a natural at this, Penny. And as the first beta testers, you two’ll have quite the edge when we play with Wolowitz and Koothrappali on Sunday.

speaker: Oh, gee, Sheldon, I don’t think we can play on Sunday.
response: Why not?

speaker: My friend, Justin.
response: Pay attention, Leonard. That’s why she can’t play on Sunday.

speaker: Who is this Justin?
response: Your turn, Leonard.

speaker: No, you didn’t.
response: Roll the dice, Leonard.

speaker: Yeah, my friend from Omaha, plays the guitar. Anyway, he’s coming to L.A. looking for some session work, so I told him he could just crash on my couch for a few weeks.
response: Come on, Leonard, if you roll a six, Penny dies horribly in a nuclear meltdown. See what I mean when I say the fun is real?

speaker: Okay, not to be pedantic, but the last I checked went out was in fact the past tense of going out, which I think we all know is a popular euphemism for saw each other naked.
response: I’ll just roll for you.

speaker: What was your first clue?
response: Uh-oh! Industrial accident.

speaker: I’m not talking to you like you’re an idiot! I’m saying the whole idea is idiotic!
response: You accidentally stare at a helium-argon laser. Lose one turn and a retina.

speaker: How is that not talking to me like I’m an idiot? It’s my friend, it’s my couch, and it’s my freakin’ life!
response: It’s also your roll.

speaker: I heard of ‘em. Didn’t know they were a band. Sheldon, she’s gone. You can turn off the blender.
response: Has your relationship reached its inevitable ugly end?

speaker: No, we just had a little spat.
response: Look on the bright side. As the result of Penny’s forfeit, you have become the world’s first winner of Research Lab. Would you like a commemorative snow cone?

speaker: I don’t get how she can just announce that an old boyfriend is going to be sleeping on her couch.
response: Hey, I thought of a game we can play in the car.

speaker: I don’t want to play a game, Sheldon.
response: It’s called Scientists. Now, I will name three scientists, then you will put them in order of the size of their contribution to their respective fields. To make this game even more compelling, you must consider only the contribution of the man to the field, not the validity of the field itself. For example, Abu Musa Jabir ibn Hayn made a greater contribution to the discredited field of alchemy than Halbert Vanderplatt made to neurobiology. Okay, ready to have some fun?

speaker: An old boyfriend who’s definitely not gay. That’s what a guy likes to hear, definitely.
response: All right, I’ll start with an easy one, um, Isaac Newton, Madame Curie and Niels Bohr.

speaker: And then I say one little thing and I end up being the bad guy!
response: Hint, Madame Curie had her husband to help her.

speaker: What am I supposed to say? Sure, Penny, I’m cool with your old boyfriend sleeping in your apartment. Well, Leonard, it doesn’t matter if you’re cool or not because I’m Penny and I’m pretty and I can do whatever the hell I want! Oh, I get it! You think you’re doing me a favour just by being in a relationship with me! No, no, Leonard! I’m doing you a favour just by being in the same room as you!
response: Leonard! Stop the car!

speaker: What?
response: I can’t listen to the two of you fight anymore.

speaker: Calm down, we’ll make the movie.
response: I believe my alarm is appropriate, given the situation. The movie starts in 17 minutes, which means we’ll need to make all the lights on Colorado Boulevard, plus skip the concession stand, and preshow urination.

speaker: Oh, dude, I wish you had said something before I pounded that last Red Bull.
response: Go, go, Power Rangers, go!

speaker: Hey. We’re, uh, going to the movies.
response: No, we’re not. We’re standing in the hallway, suffering through an awkward encounter.

speaker: Not really, no.
response: All right, invitation pointlessly offered, invitation declined as expected, everyone’s civil, nobody’s fighting. Have a nice evening.

speaker: Yeah, I don’t think I need my preshow urination anymore.
response: Leonard, when that woman moved in three years ago I told you not to talk to her, and now look, we’re going to be late for the movies.

speaker: Hey! Look! Amazing Spider-Man 183.
response: Got it.

speaker: You brought your mother into this!
response: Stop it, both of you. All this fighting, I might as well be back with my parents! Damn it, George, I told you if you didn’t quit drinkin’ I’d leave you! Well, I guess that makes you a liar, ’cause I’m drunk as hell and you’re still here! Stop yelling! You’re making Sheldon cry! I’ll tell you what’s making Sheldon cry! That I let you name him Sheldon.

speaker: Oh, thank you very much. Come back soon. With the other half of my tip. Hey, Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: This is a restaurant. It’s lunchtime. I would think, as a waitress, you’d be familiar with the paradigm.

speaker: Is Leonard coming?
response: No, I believe Leonard is waiting for you to come crawling back to him and apologize.

speaker: Well, that’s not gonna happen.
response: I assumed that would be your attitude. Hence, my true purpose in coming here.

speaker: Which is?
response: I want you to crawl back to him and apologize.

speaker: I’m busy.
response: Excuse me, miss. I’d like to order lunch.

speaker: Fine. What do you want?
response: I have a few questions. First, I notice that you offer soup and a half-sandwich?

speaker: Yes.
response: Where exactly does the half-sandwich come from? Are you giving me half of someone else’s sandwich, or do I have to wait for someone else in the restaurant to order the other half?

speaker: No, no, Sheldon, they just make a half-sandwich.
response: You can’t make a half-sandwich. If it’s not half of a whole sandwich, it’s just a small sandwich.

speaker: Okay, fine, it’s soup and a small sandwich. Is that what you want?
response: Of course not. I’ll have my usual.

speaker: Great.
response: Aren’t you going to ask me if I want a beverage?

speaker: Don’t you usually get lemonade?
response: Yes.

speaker: Do you want lemonade?
response: Yes.

speaker: Anything else?
response: Yes, I want you to apologize to Leonard.

speaker: I am not going to apologize. I’ve done nothing wrong. He is completely overreacting.
response: Irrelevant. The disruption in your relationship is making my life intolerable.

speaker: Well, I’m sorry, Sheldon, but this really isn’t about you.
response: I don’t follow.

speaker: Yeah, yeah, I’ll be right there. Look, Sheldon, I have to go.
response: All right, let’s assume, ad argumentum, that in this case, Leonard is wrong.

speaker: Leonard is wrong.
response: Considering the number of transgressions you’ve committed that he’s overlooked, don’t you think that, just this once, you could return the favour?

speaker: I’m coming. Goodbye, Sheldon. What do you mean, transgressions I’ve committed?
response: Were you under the impression that Leonard has no complaints about you?

speaker: Like what? Yeah, yeah, I see you, you’re making a little cheque sign in the air, I got it, just hold your horses. What does Leonard complain about?
response: Your driving, the plethora of stuffed animals on your bed that stare at him during your amorous activities, your constant tardiness, your singing.

speaker: My singing?
response: That’s actually from my list, but Leonard would be a fool if he didn’t agree with it.

speaker: Okay, if Leonard has so many problems with me, why hasn’t he just said so?
response: Because, according to him, you’re oversensitive and have a temper.

speaker: Oh, really? Well, then, do me a favour and tell Leonard that he can drop dead!
response: And she wonders why she’s constantly undertipped.

speaker: Hey.
response: Oh, good, you’re home. I need you to do me a favour.

speaker: Sure.
response: Go apologize to Penny.

speaker: What?
response: Right now would be good.

speaker: Leonard!
response: Although, a few minutes ago would have been better.

speaker: It’s a little hard to explain. He does this thing where he pretends he’s in an alternate dimension that occupies the same physical space we’re in, but he can’t perceive us.
response: Don’t flatter yourself. I’m just ignoring you.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, let’s go home. Look, we’re done fighting.
response: I’ve heard that before, but then, the next thing you know I’m hiding in my bedroom, blaring a Richard Feinman lecture while my mom is shouting that Jesus would forgive her if she put ground glass in my dad’s meatloaf, and my dad’s on the roof sh**t her Franklin Mint collectible plates.

speaker: Okay, there’s going to no more shouting and no sh**t.
response: Really? Where’s your friend Justin going to sleep?

speaker: You know, how about we buy you this robot, and then we all go home?
response: I want that one.

speaker: Buy him the robot, Leonard.
response: Can I get this comic book, too?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: What is shaking?

speaker: I’m sorry?
response: It’s colloquial, a conversation opener. So, do you find the weather satisfying? Are you currently sharing in the triumph of some local sports team?

speaker: What’s wrong with you? you’re freaking me out.
response: I’m striking up a casual conversation with you. S’u’up?

speaker: Please don’t do that.
response: All right, But I’m given to understand that when you have something awkward to discuss with someone, it’s more palatable to preface it with banal chit chat.

speaker: So, this wasn’t the awkward part?
response: No.

speaker: Oh, all right. S’u’up?
response: Oh, good, I used that right. Anyway, you’re aware that Leonard has entered into a new romantic relationship which includes a sexual component?

speaker: Okay, feeling the awkward now.
response: Her name is Dr. Stephanie Barnett and she is a highly distinguished surgical resident at Freemont Memorial.

speaker: Yeah, Leonard told me.
response: Good. What he may have left out is how important this relationship is to me.

speaker: To you?
response: Yes, see, of the handful of women Leonard’s been involved with, she’s the only one I have ever found tolerable.

speaker: Well, what about me?
response: The statement stands for itself.

speaker: Well, aren’t you sweet?
response: Anyway, should you have any interaction with her, it would be most helpful that she not see you as a sexual rival.

speaker: Yeah, I think she’s pretty safe.
response: You say that now, but consider the following scenario, you’re sitting in your apartment, it’s late, you’re alone, your hypothalamus is swimming in a soup of estrogen and progesterone and suddenly even Leonard seems like a viable sexual candidate, or a, uh, hookup as it’s referred to by today’s urban youth.

speaker: Really?
response: Yes. Now, should that happen, I would ask you to find some way to suppress your libido.

speaker: I could think about you.
response: Fine, whatever works.

speaker: Always nice talking to you, Sheldon.
response: Uh, peace out!

speaker: I’m glad you’re enjoying yourself.
response: And you said there’d never be enough pasta for the three of us.

speaker: I stand corrected.
response: You know, Italian housewives have a rule of thumb. A handful of dry pasta about an inch in diameter is sufficient for each person as it doubles in volume when cooked.

speaker: That’s very interesting.
response: Thank you.

speaker: She doesn’t mean it. She’s just being nice.
response: Well, Stephanie, since Leonard seems to be dropping the conversational ball, I guess I’ll just have to pick it up. Have you ever witnessed a violent crime?

speaker: No.
response: Good. What’s your favourite fruit?

speaker: Ih-uh, strawberries.
response: Hmm, technically not a fruit, but all right. Where did you do your medical internship?

speaker: Uh, Lawrence Memorial in Galveston, Texas.
response: Really? That’s where I was born!

speaker: You’re kidding!
response: I spent so much of my childhood at that hospital. When I was 12, I got to ride there in a helicopter.

speaker: Why, what-what-what happened?
response: Radiation burns. A little mishap while I was building my own cat scanner.

speaker: I’m sorry, you tried to build your own cat scanner?
response: No, I didn’t try, I succeeded. In fact, I was briefly able to see the inside of my sister’s guinea pig, Snowball, before he caught fire. It led to an interesting expression in our house, not a snowball’s chance in a cat scanner.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon?
response: Excuse me. When I come back, just for fun, the subject will be alternative history. Specifically, how would the civil w*r have gone differently if Lincoln had been a robot sent from the future? (To Leonard) Look at that, there’s even pasta left over.

speaker: Do you understand that this was supposed to be a date?
response: I do. Do you? Because frankly, you’ve been in a foul mood since I sat down.

speaker: Okay, here’s my question, why did you sit down?
response: To help. Look, if you fail at this relationship, and history suggests you will, then we risk losing the medical officer that our landing party has always needed.

speaker: What landing party?
response: You’re Kirk, I’m Spock, Wolowitz is Scotty, Koothrappali is the guy who always gets k*ll, and now we’ve got McCoy.

speaker: What do you think I did? I discreetly slipped off the other earring, put it in my pocket and then got the hell out of there!
response: I have a bone to pick with you, sir.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon.
response: Hi, Stephanie. I’m sorry I’m late, but your companion left the most indecipherable invitation.

speaker: What invitation?
response: We’re going to the movies. What movie? What theatre? What time? If you were trying to make it impossible to locate you, you couldn’t have done a better job.

speaker: Oh, clearly I could have.
response: It took me nearly 20 minutes to go through the browser history on your computer to see what movie times you looked up. Wait here, I’ll find us seats.

speaker: No, it’s fine. you know, he’s sweet.
response: My apologies, you’ve been sitting in it all along. Leonard, you want to slide over one?

speaker: No, just sit here.
response: Oh, yeah, this is it.

speaker: What, Sheldon? What, Sheldon? What, Sheldon?
response: Tell me what you see here.

speaker: The blunt instrument that will be the focus of my m*rder trial?
response: This is Stephanie’s facebook page. Now, where it should say in a relationship, what does it say?

speaker: Stephanie Barnett is single.
response: Yeah, furthermore, earlier this evening, she threw a digital sheep at some guy named Mike. Who’s Mike? Why does he get a digital sheep and not you?

speaker: It’s just her facebook page and we’ve only been going out a couple of weeks.
response: You don’t see it, do you? We’re losing her.

speaker: Okay, I’m going to make this very simple for you. You are not in this relationship, I am. Ergo, you have no say in anything that happens between me and Stephanie.
response: I’m afraid I can’t allow that. Pursuant to Starfleet General Order 104 Section A, you are deemed unfit and I hereby relieve you of your command.

speaker: General Order 104, Section A does not apply in this situation.
response: Give me one good reason why not.

speaker: What?
response: This is banana bread.

speaker: This is a door knob.
response: It’s my understanding that an unsolicited gift of food can be a precursor to an impromptu invitation to come in and chat.

speaker: Sheldon, would you like to come in?
response: I suppose I could spare a few minutes. Were you robbed?

speaker: No.
response: How can you be sure?

speaker: Sheldon, what do you want?
response: I’m certain this will come as no surprise to you, but Leonard is failing in yet another relationship.

speaker: He’s having problems with Stephanie?
response: She’s sending virtual livestock to random men on the internet. If I have any hope of keeping them together, I need data. Specifically, I need to know exactly what Leonard did that caused you to pop an emotional cap in his buttocks.

speaker: What?
response: Again, urban slang. In which, I believe I’m gaining remarkable fluency. So, what is the down and the low? And don’t worry, this is all entirely confidential, so, you feel free to include any and all shortcomings in the bedroom.

speaker: We never got to the bedroom.
response: Because?

speaker: Oh, okay, all right, you know what? I’ll tell you what happened. We were young, we were very much in love, but we could only communicate through a time-traveling mailbox at my lake house.
response: It’s not enough that you made me watch that movie, but now you mock me with it?

speaker: I’ve been waiting for someone to have the talk with me.
response: More to the point, it’s about finding a way to keep Leonard and Stephanie together.

speaker: Oh, I don’t think you can.
response: Well, why not?

speaker: Based on the geometric progression, his relationship with Stephanie should have ended after 20 minutes.
response: Yes, I’m aware of the math, Y equals 27 days over 12 to the nth, the issue remains, how do we circumvent his inevitable rejection?

speaker: I’ll tell you what you shouldn’t do. Don’t spritz him with that body spray from the commercial where the women undress when they smell it, that doesn’t work at all, no matter how much you put on.
response: So, that’s all you’ve got? Apocalyptic genocide and go easy on the cologne?

speaker: What?
response: Penny. Zucchini bread.

speaker: Oh, thank you.
response: May I come in?

speaker: No.
response: I see. Apparently my earlier inquiry regarding you and Leonard crossed some sort of line. I apologize.

speaker: Well, thank you.
response: So, have you and I returned to a social equilibrium?

speaker: Yes.
response: Great. New topic. Where are you in your menstrual cycle?

speaker: What?
response: I’ve been doing some research online, and apparently female primates, you know, uh, apes, chimpanzees, you, they find their mate more desirable when he’s being courted by another female. Now, this effect is intensified when the rival female is secreting the pheromones associated with ovulation. Which brings me back to my question, where are you in (Penny slams door). Clearly, I’m 14 days too early.

speaker: Leonard, you’re going to have to let this go. You had a little cheese dip, you farted, I thought it was cute.
response: Oh, hi Stephanie.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I have a craving for white asparagus that apparently is destined to go unsatisfied.

speaker: Excuse me. What the hell is wrong with you?
response: I’m helping you with Stephanie.

speaker: By making constipated moose sounds?
response: When I fail to open this jar and you succeed it will establish you as the alpha male. You see, when a female witnesses an exhibition of physical domination she produces the hormone oxytocin. If the two of you then engage in intercourse this will create the biochemical reaction in the brain which lay people naively interpret as falling in love.

speaker: Huh? Would it work if I just punched you in the face?
response: Yes, actually it would, but let’s see how the lid goes. I’m not strong enough, Leonard, you’ll have to do it.

speaker: Oh, for god’s sakes.
response: Go ahead, it’s pre-loosened.

speaker: No, no, no, I got it.
response: No, yeah, yeah, he’s got it, and that’s not surprising. This is something I long ago came to peace with in my role as the beta male. Open it. (Leonard tries again. Then taps jar on counter. Jar breaks.)

speaker: No, I’m not. I’m bleeding.
response: Like a gladiator!

speaker: Oh, okay, yeah, hang on a sec. (Throws up in sink)
response: FYI, I was defrosting a steak in there.

speaker: I can’t remember a time when you weren’t talking.
response: Just for the record, my efforts to establish you as the alpha male were not aided by you bursting into tears.

speaker: I did not burst into tears, my eyes just got a little watery.
response: Watery?

speaker: Uh, no, I think that you probably need to rest.
response: She’s right, as long as you’re vomiting, coitus is contra-indicated.

speaker: Thank you, Dr. Cooper.
response: You’re welcome, Dr. Hofstadter.

speaker: What?
response: Well, you seem like a perfectly pleasant person. I just can’t understand why women have such a hard time loving you.

speaker: Well, then who did?
response: I had no choice, he cried in front of her.

speaker: You hacked my facebook account?
response: Oh, it’s hardly hacking when you use the same password for everything, Kal-el.

speaker: Are you insane? Now she’s going to think I’m desperate. You’ve destroyed this relationship! And you want to know what the worst part is? You don’t even understand what you did wrong because you can’t conceive of something that you are not an expert in!
response: In which I am not an expert.

speaker: Really? Oh, look at that, I have a girlfriend.
response: If I am permitted to speak again, Dr. Sheldon Cooper for the win.

speaker: Speaking of new careers, how are things going with dark matter, Sheldon?
response: Oh, yeah, I'd have to say it's the most exiting time in the history of the field.

speaker: Oh. What's going on?
response: I started doing it.

speaker: Wait, hang on, you guys are gonna work in a mine?
response: Why not?

speaker: You had a panic attack when we went through the car wash.
response: Perhaps the emotion you're referring to was shock at you having something cleaned.

speaker: Yeah, it'll help them get away when they see a g-g-ghost.
response: Are they making fun of us?

speaker: Yup.
response: I miss the old days when I couldn't tell.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, you busy?
response: I'm always busy. This mind is capable of advanced multitasking. You know, currently, I'm attempting to solve the Penrose conjecture, I'm composing my Nobel acceptance speech for when I've solved the Penrose conjecture, and I'm wondering how mermaids have babies.

speaker: Don't they lay eggs on a rock?
response: Now I've got room for another thing. What do you want?

speaker: So, I did a little research on what the conditions are like in the mines, and the guys might be right, sounds pretty rough down there. For starters, it's very humid, and about a hundred degrees.
response: Well, I'm from Texas and you're from India, we're no strangers to the fragrant armpit. Next.

speaker: It's also a live mine, so there'll be dynamite explosions going off in the distance.
response: Yeah, I have a lactose intolerant roommate with a taste for ice cream. Next.

speaker: Oh, you have to be down there for 12 hours at a time.
response: Yeah? We have to be somewhere.

speaker: Well, there's no toilets, we'll have to do our business in a bucket.
response: So it's settled, we're not doing it.

speaker: Look, I get it, but before we pass up on an incredible opportunity, I was thinking about when Howard was training to go to space, they put him in a simulated environment.
response: Interesting. You're suggesting that we recreate the conditions of the mine to see if we can handle it.

speaker: Exactly.
response: Very well.

speaker: So where should we do it?
response: Well, I'll just Google hot, dark and moist, see what comes up.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon…
response: Oh, there, well, look, there's all kinds of videos.

speaker: No. They forgot I was there. But it really opened up my pores.
response: Well, according to my research, the steam tunnels below this access point should be the closest analog to the mines.

speaker: This is gonna be so much more accurate than the steam room at the gym.
response: Plus, there's almost no chance we'll see any of our coworkers half naked.

speaker: Or totally naked. I love Howard, but the dude needs a little shame.
response: All right, Amy, this walkie-talkie is yours. If we run into any problems, I'll contact you. And if anything bad happens, what's the rule?

speaker: Sheldon, I'm really impressed you're willing to try this.
response: Well, admittedly, this brushes up against my well-known aversions to heat, small places, going below floor-level, dampness, hatches, ladders, darkness, echoes, and eliminating in Home Depot buckets. That last one is quite new, but I have a feeling that's gonna rocket to the top of the list.

speaker: I'm sweating already.
response: Yeah, as the person beneath you, allow me to say, I know.

speaker: How hot is it?
response: Uh, let's see. 704? No, wait, it's on clock. Uh, the real answer isn't much better. 102 degrees.

speaker: Well, that's what we wanted. This is as hot as the mines will be.
response: True. Sheldon's Mine Simulation Log, entry one. Koothrappali's restating of the obvious is already getting on my nerves.

speaker: How you feeling?
response: Good. Little claustrophobic.

speaker: Let's set up the equipment. It'll help take your mind off of it.
response: Miners often sang mining songs to keep their spirits up.

speaker: Do you know any mining songs?
response: Just the hits. (Singing) ♪ Where it's dark as a dungeon, and it's damp as the dew. ♪

speaker: That's pretty.
response: ♪ Where the dangers are double, and the pleasures are few. Where the rain never falls and the sun never shines, yes, it's dark as a dungeon way down in the mine. ♪

speaker: It's a little more bleak than I thought.
response: ♪ Well, I pray when I'm dead and the ages shall roll, that my body will blacken and turn into coal. ♪

speaker: Getting kind of grim.
response: ♪ Then I'll look from the door of my heavenly home, and pity the miner that mines my poor bones. ♪

speaker: Okay. How 'bout a little Miley Cyrus next?
response: Who's he?

speaker: So, as Hannah Montana, Miley was a world-famous pop star. But then she would take off her wig and go to school like a normal girl. Which, I don't have to tell you, at that age, is its own headache.
response: That's preposterous. How would she go unrecognized just by wearing a wig?

speaker: But you're okay with Superman concealing his identity with a pair of glasses?
response: He doesn't just put on a pair of glasses. He combs back his curlicue and affects a mild-mannered personality.

speaker: You guys doing okay down there?
response: I told you to use the walkie-talkie!

speaker: You guys doing okay down there?
response: Please keep this channel clear for emergencies. Thank you.

speaker: I'm going to the vending machine. Do you want anything?
response: This is a simulation. We have to survive on the supplies we brought.

speaker: We should have asked her to get some Funyuns.
response: You're not going to have Funyuns when we're a mile below the surface of the Earth.

speaker: What if we brought them down with us?
response: We'll take some Funyuns.

speaker: Anything else?
response: Some York Peppermint Patties, a couple of Dr. Peppers, and run to Best Buy and see if they have a portable DVD player and season one of a show called Hannah Montana.

speaker: Oh, this heat is brutal.
response: As someone from the tropical subcontinent of India, you should know that fanning yourself in a humid environment only raises your body temperature.

speaker: Huh. That does explain why the servants used to look so hot while they were fanning me. Let's get our minds off how uncomfortable we are. We could take some more simulated instrument readings.
response: My major focus at the moment is keeping my claustrophobia at bay.

speaker: How's that going?
response: You tell me. I feel like I can't breathe, and I am tempted to crack you open and suck the air right out of your lungs.

speaker: Sheldon, if this is too much, we can stop.
response: We're not stopping.

speaker: You don't have to bite my head off.
response: I apologize. I just, I'm plagued by an internal struggle.

speaker: If you would just use the bucket, you'd be so much more comfortable.
response: My struggle is emotional.

speaker: Oh. Is it Amy?
response: It's dark matter. When I entered the field of string theory, I was a prodigy. I rose to a position of respect, and I assumed my career would continue on that upward trajectory. Now here I am in my 30s, I'm back at square one. And, frankly, it's frightening.

speaker: Sheldon, you know what I think of when I'm scared? Voyager.
response: Voyager the space probe or Voyager the Star Trek TV show?

speaker: The space probe.
response: Good. Because I am too hot and tired to go on about how much I hate Voyager the TV show.

speaker: Sheldon, is everything okay?
response: It's too late for Koothrappali. Let's go.

speaker: Do you really need me to transcribe this?
response: You're not doing it for me. You're doing it for future generations who will benefit from my struggle. (Voice on recorder) Sheldon's Mine Simulation Log, entry four. My Kit Kat has melted. All is lost.

speaker: You call yourself a friend? I was trying to help you, and at the first sign of trouble you ran away, leaving me to fend off a family of rats. You're a completely selfish human being and a, and a physical and a moral coward.
response: His statements of the obvious continue to annoy.

speaker: He’s not braver than whoever uses the bathroom after The Thing?
response: As usual, you’re all wrong. The bravest person in the Marvel Universe is the doctor who gives Wolverine his prostate exam.

speaker: How about the guy who gets a prostate exam from Wolverine?
response: Now you just being silly. Wolverine’s never displayed the slightest interest in helping others prevent prostate cancer. (Answering phone) Hello. Yes, the elevator’s out of order you’ll have to use the stairs. Of course you can. Pizza dates back to the 16th century, while the first elevator was not installed until 1852. That means that for over 300 years, people carried pizzas up stairs. Be part of that proud tradition.

speaker: Oh, okay. Good. I don’t need more comics. Howard’s gonna stop by, we’re gonna play intergalactic battleship and Indian Monopoly.
response: I don’t care for novelty editions of Monopoly. I prefer the classics, regular and Klingon.

speaker: You’ll never guess what just happened.
response: You went out in the hallway, stumbled into an interdimensional portal which brought you 5,000 years into the future, where you took advantage of the advanced technology to build a time machine, and now you’re back to bring us all with you to the year 7010 where we are transported to work at the thinkatorium by telepathically controlled flying dolphins?

speaker: No.
response: Aw.

speaker: Penny kissed me.
response: Well, who would ever guess that?

speaker: Penny kissing me is not insane. She used to kiss me all the time.
response: Einstein defined insanity as doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results. By that standard, Penny is cuckoo for cocoa puffs.

speaker: Why do I bother talking to you people?
response: If it’ll make you feel better, we rarely listen.

speaker: Yeah, sure.
response: I’m starting to think we’re never going to see that pizza.

speaker: Love you, too.
response: Oh, friggety-frak. Not this again.

speaker: Maybe.
response: Leonard, Penny, excellent. I’d like to say I’m very happy that you’re back together, and if I can figure out a way to do so and sound sincere, I will. In the meantime, I’d like to go over some proposed changes to the roommate agreement specifically to address Penny’s annoying personal habits.

speaker: Ba-ba-ba-ba. Are you sure you want to include him in this?
response: Include me in what? Is there a plot afoot? I’ll have no truck with plots.

speaker: No, you’re right. No, there’s, there’s no plots, no trucks, no feet. So what other annoying habits shall we discuss?
response: Uh, we don’t discuss anything. Leonard is the signatory to the Roommate Agreement. As such, he bears responsibility for all your infractions and must pay all fines.

speaker: Fines?
response: Yes. If Penny’s going to be spending nights here again, you’ll need to set up an escrow account. Sign here.

speaker: Yeah, well, not necessary. We broke up again.
response: Do you even think about other people, Leonard? Do you?

speaker: Why? You writing a book?
response: I’m going to propose a hypothesis. Last night, Raj accidentally made contact with an alien civilization and has been ordered by the United States government to keep it a secret.

speaker: Nothing happened. Can we please just change the subject?
response: That sounds rehearsed. We are not alone.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Fine, it bothers me. You happy?
response: You think you've got problems. The gibbon is the only member of the ape family not classified as a great ape.

speaker: How is this helpful?
response: All the non-human apes are classified as great apes except one. That means taxonomists created the entire category of lesser ape just to single out the poor gibbon as the weird kid on the playground. Now there's a hairy little fellow with a genuine beef.

speaker: But the gibbon doesn't know what it's categorized as. It doesn't even know it's called a gibbon.
response: True. Sorry, kid, you've got it worse than a gibbon.

speaker: Did you go to your prom?
response: No. I had a date with a proper education. Instead of a tuxedo, I dressed myself in good habits. Instead of spiked punch, I enjoyed the intoxicating flavour of knowledge. Instead of dancing in a gym, I shook my bootyto the seductive rhythms…

speaker: I got to go, bye.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny?

speaker: You knocked more than usual.
response: Next time I might be in a rush, it's good to have a few in the bank.

speaker: Okay, what's up?
response: I'd like to discuss this party that Amy and Bernadette are throwing. Since you and I are both reluctant to go, I think I've come up with a perfect way for us to enjoy it.

speaker: Great, how?
response: We pretend we're aliens. I'm not the best at reading facial cues, but I'm gonna say that you love it and want to hear more. Now, in the beloved novel Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, an alien named Ford Prefect pretended to be human in order to blend in so that he could write an entry about Earth for The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, which is a travel book within the actual book, which is also called The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.

speaker: Okay, just one question. What?
response: My point is, pretending to be an alien is a valuable coping mechanism I've used many times. I did it the first time I went to see you in a play. You had no idea Commander Umfrumf of Ceti Alpha Three was in the audience. Oh, don't worry, he gave you seven thumbs up.

speaker: Here's a question, as an alien pretending to be human, are you planning to engage in any post-prom mating rituals with Amy?
response: There are post-prom mating rituals?

speaker: Not always. Unless your date drives a van with an air mattress, then always.
response: Well, if it's part of the prom experience, then I'm open to it.

speaker: You're kidding.
response: I may be an alien, but I have urges. If Amy wants to copulate by firing her eggs into space, well, then, I will happily catch them with the reproductive sac on my upper flermin. I'm not the best at reading facial cues, but I can see that you're a little turned on.

speaker: You know, if you're not gonna learn how to do this, they make some pretty good clip-ons.
response: Bruce Wayne doesn't wear a clip-on.

speaker: Bruce Wayne doesn't make his roommate tie it for him.
response: His name is Alfred, and, yes, he does.

speaker: There, perfect.
response: What, are you sure? It's my first prom, I want to do it correctly.

speaker: I thought you were gonna pretend to be an alien.
response: I was, but Penny didn't want to. You didn't want to. Bernadette, Amy, Koothrappali and Wolowitz didn't want to. And even I knew it was weird to hire somebody.

speaker: Was that a flask?
response: Yes. I've decided to embrace all of the traditions associated with prom, including spiking the punch.

speaker: You're gonna put alcohol in the punch?
response: Oh, no, this is pomegranate juice. It's all the fun of high school high jinks with the cell-protecting zip of antioxidants.

speaker: If you had ripped jeans and a leather jacket, you'd be like the toughest kid on the Disney Channel. So, anything else planned for tonight?
response: Oh, everything. Getting our picture taken, slow-dancing, being elected prom king. Pointing out that kings aren't elected. It's gonna be off the hook.

speaker: And while you're at it, I know that at this age your hormones are raging, but just because all your friends are having sex doesn't mean you have to.
response: Why would you say that?

speaker: You know, 'cause, 'cause a lot of people lose their virginity on prom night.
response: Penny implied the same thing. Is this true?

speaker: Sheldon, you look so handsome.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Oh, it's a scaly genital organ that grows between his shoulder blades. Try not to touch it when you're dancing.
response: Excuse me.

speaker: Where are you going?
response: I can't do this. And for your information, Leonard, the upper flermin doesn't grow between my shoulder blades, it grows out of the belly button on my neck.

speaker: Sheldon, can I come in?
response: I don't think that's a good idea.

speaker: Why not?
response: According to an online message board, I may be having a panic attack. SoccerMom09 had similar symptoms. But to be fair, the twins were a real handful that day.

speaker: You're making me worry. What's going on?
response: What's going on is we're about to go to a prom. And there's a great deal of pressure on young couples like us to engage in what Mr. Bob Eubanks called making whoopee.

speaker: What pressure? All I said was you look handsome. Can you please open the door?
response: It's not just that. Leonard and Penny also made comments about it. And I'm not blind. Even I looked twice when I saw my posterior in these tuxedo pants.

speaker: Sheldon, this is silly. I'm not missing another prom. I'm going upstairs now. Good-bye.
response: I really did think you looked pretty.

speaker: You did?
response: Yes. So much so that I started to panic.

speaker: Well, you can relax. Just because you think I look pretty doesn't mean we have to spend the night together.
response: Were you hoping we would because it's prom?

speaker: I'm always hoping. But tonight I just wanted to have a nice time with you. And maybe dance with someone who has arms.
response: Thank you for understanding.

speaker: Of course I understand. Sheldon, there's something else I've been wanting to say, but before I do, I just, I want you to know that you don't have to say it back. I know you're not ready, and I don't want you to say it just because social convention dictates…
response: I love you, too.

speaker: You said it.
response: There's no denying I have feelings for you that can't be explained in any other way. I briefly considered that I had a brain parasite. But that seems even more farfetched. The only conclusion was love. I know what's happening. This is a panic attack. SoccerMom09 says to lie down with your feet elevated.

speaker: Okay.
response: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. Just because I love you doesn't mean girls are allowed in my room.

speaker: Got it.
response: Leonard, you’ll never guess who I just found online. Hey!

speaker: Eh, his giant head did most of the work.
response: Very mature. You’re lucky I’m out of silly string. As I was saying, Leonard, you’ll never guess who I just found online. Professor Proton.

speaker: You’re kidding. He’s still alive?
response: Yes.

speaker: Yes! Sorry, tell me about Professor Proton.
response: Professor Proton hosted my favourite science show when I was a child. I never missed an episode. He demonstrated scientific principles using everyday objects.

speaker: Aw, so cute when you use the word cool wrong. Like when kids say pasghetti.
response: Oh, dear lord, Leonard, look. He’s still available for parties and events. We should hire him.

speaker: Hire him to do what?
response: Well, whatever we want. Hang out, do experiments, make him take 12 pictures with us so we can make a calendar.

speaker: It would be pretty awesome to hang out with him. I just used awesome wrong, didn’t I?
response: Well, I’m e-mailing him right now.

speaker: Do you remember his old theme song?
response: Of course I do.

speaker: Thank you.
response: It’s happening. Leonard, it’s happening. Professor Proton is coming to our house.

speaker: You mean the guy who used to host that lame kids show?
response: And you just got yourself uninvited. See? I told you I’d find a tactful way to do that.

speaker: How’d you get him to come to your house?
response: As Professor Proton always says, there is no problem you can’t solve if you use your noggin.

speaker: And he wrote him a cheque.
response: Yeah, that, too. Big cheque.

speaker: Yes.
response: Me, too.

speaker: Great.
response: I can’t sleep.

speaker: Well, I can, so shut up.
response: Do you realize that in less than nine hours, Arthur Jeffries, aka Professor Proton, will be in our apartment?

speaker: Sheldon, you know that if you stay up all night, you’re gonna be sleepy tomorrow. And a sleepy Sheldon is a cranky Sheldon. And a cranky Sheldon is actually no different than a regular Sheldon. Good night.
response: I’m thinking of wearing a tuxedo.

speaker: That’s not ridiculous. Good night.
response: Do you have cufflinks?

speaker: No.
response: Ah, just as well. Where can you rent a tuxedo at three o’clock in the morning?

speaker: Okay, good night.
response: Nice to meet you, Professor Proton. Nice to meet you, Professor Proton. Nice to meet you, Professor Proton. Nice to meet you, Prof… Ow! Leonard?

speaker: What?
response: I still can’t sleep.

speaker: Relax, Sheldon, he’s only a few minutes late.
response: Professor Proton was never late when he was on TV. You know, every day, four o’clock, he was there. Unless tornadoes were ripping apart East Texas, in which case we’d join him in progress. (Phone rings) It’s him. Hello. Well, I see. Yes. All right, we can come get you. Yeah, well, see you soon. Bye.

speaker: Where is he?
response: The third floor landing. The poor old guy’s been walking up the stairs for half an hour. It’s really you.

speaker: I agree.
response: Professor Proton, it’s an honour to meet you.

speaker: Just, just call me Arthur.
response: Leonard, you hear that? Professor Proton said I should call him Arthur. That means we’re friends.

speaker: No. A friend would’ve, would’ve told me about the elevator.
response: Look at me. I can get as close to you as I want without my mom saying it’s going to ruin my eyes.

speaker: Actually, he’s a genius.
response: I am.

speaker: Well, I hope I haven’t, uh, kept the kids waiting too long for, for the show.
response: Oh, no, there are no kids. No, the, the show’s for me. Come on. I’ll race ya, Arthur.

speaker: You, you get bit a lot. Let me see if, if I have this straight. You, you two are, are physicists, and you, and you want me to do a children’s science show?
response: Yes. And if there’s time, take 12 pictures with us in seasonal clothing.

speaker: You know, I’m a real scientist. I, I have a PhD from Cornell University.
response: Yeah, that’s great. Did you bring your puppet?

speaker: No, no. I, I hate that puppet.
response: Oh, no. How could anybody hate Gino the Neutrino? It’s nice, huh? I got him for 20 bucks on eBay. Including the shipping!

speaker: I think I know.
response: It’s gonna get sucked in. It’s going to get sucked in.

speaker: Okay, I didn’t know.
response: Yes.

speaker: I, I figured that out.
response: Potato clock. Do potato clock.

speaker: No. Look, guys, keep your money. I, I think, uh, I, I think I’m done.
response: What, well what’s wrong? Is she upsetting you? Because I can make her go away.

speaker: I don’t know. I think I’m just, I, I just, I just don’t want to be Professor Proton any more.
response: Well, how can you say that? Professor Proton’s the best.

speaker: What, what has it ever gotten me? I mean, I’m, I’m an 83-year-old man who has potatoes in, in his suitcase. Other scientists think, think I’m a joke. And the, the puppeteer who did, who did Gino, well, he also did my wife.
response: Mr. Jeffries, I need to show you something.

speaker: What do you two talk about?
response: I wrote a fan letter to you when I was a child in Texas, and you sent this autographed picture back to me. Do you remember that?

speaker: I’ll, I’ll give you a hint. I have a bracelet with my own address on it.
response: Well, anyway, um, you may find this hard to believe, but I didn’t have any friends growing up.

speaker: No, I, I get that.
response: But, um, I did have you. And every day at four o’clock, you’d come to my house on Channel 68, and we’d do science together. If it hadn’t been for you, well, who knows what would’ve become of me? You know? Instead of a world-class physicist, I could’ve wound up as a hobo. Or a surgeon.

speaker: I bet there are important discoveries being made every day because you inspired millions of kids to pursue science. In a way, their discoveries are your discoveries.
response: Yeah, it’s true. A generation of young scientists are standing on your shoulders.

speaker: You want one of us to go with you in the ambulance?
response: I’ll do it.

speaker: No, that’s not a rule. He can go.
response: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Well, at, at this point, I’m just glad someone’s carrying me down the stairs.
response: Met my childhood hero, now I get to ride in an ambulance. Boy, if we can get him to do that calendar, this’ll be the best day ever.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon. That, that was very nice.
response: Want me to sing it again?

speaker: No. The fourth, the fourth time was, was the charm.
response: There anything I can get for you? Some apple juice? Uh, some Jell-O?

speaker: No. No, thank you. But I, I do, I do have a favour to, to ask.
response: Name it.

speaker: Well, I’m, I’m booked to do a children’s party tomorrow, and, um, frankly I, you know, I, I don’t feel up to it.
response: Oh, you’re not. You look awful.

speaker: Thank you. Anyway, uh, I mean, you know my act better than anybody. I was, I was hoping that maybe, you know, maybe you’d fill in for me.
response: Are you saying that you want me to be Professor Proton?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Oh, my. What an honour. Oh, this is like being asked to ascend Mount Olympus and dine with the gods.

speaker: Or a Korean family in Alhambra.
response: But they’ll know I’m not you. Should I call myself Professor Proton, Jr.?

speaker: Sounds great.
response: So, in a way it’s like I’m your son.

speaker: What, Whatever.
response: Father.

speaker: Probably because we left the diagram of it in the restaurant, and none of us wanted to walk back.
response: I know the real reason you never made progress with that idea. You thought of it September 22nd, 2007. Two days later, Penny moved in, and so much blood rushed to your genitals, your brain became a ghost town.

speaker: That's not what happened.
response: I remember it distinctly because I had just composed my annual poem commemorating the anniversary of Dr. Seuss's death.

speaker: No one wants to hear it.
response: Why, die. Why did he die? Old, told. I was told he was old.

speaker: Penny is not the reason I didn't pursue that idea.
response: Oh, really? Since meeting her, what have been your greatest accomplishments?

speaker: I think someone owes me an apology.
response: Well, don't feel bad. I think we've all been distracted since the girls entered our lives.

speaker: You admit Amy's a distraction?
response: Oh, very much so. Listen to this. This is from two days ago. Hi. Hope you're having a good day. Who has time for this constant sexting?

speaker: My cousin has a cabin out in the woods.
response: I'm not going to a cabin in the woods. Did you see the movie Cabin in the Woods?

speaker: Then we'll go to a hotel.
response: A hotel? Did you see The Shining?

speaker: We could go up to Big Bear and get a house on the lake.
response: Did you see The Lake House?

speaker: Nothing bad happens in The Lake House.
response: Yeah, well, no, not to them. To me. Time traveling mailbox. The only time that traveled was an hour and half of my life down the toilet.

speaker: Fine. Then we'll just stay here and do it.
response: Well, you didn't suggest a beach house.

speaker: You would go to a beach house?
response: Well, good Lord, no, have you seen Jaws?

speaker: For your information, Emily is working tonight.
response: Yeah, one would assume, on getting out of the pit.

speaker: Okay, let's focus. The girls are gone, we have 48 hours. There are no distractions. Let's change the world.
response: Thinking caps on.

speaker: Oh. I never saw that.
response: Really?

speaker: Oh. It's wonderful, and I swear I'm not saying that because Justin Timberlake is in it.
response: Yeah, I have it on Blu-ray. We should watch it.

speaker: Guys, in 30 seconds, we went from let's change the world to let's watch TV.
response: I'm sorry. Is that a no?

speaker: I, I think I still have it.
response: I did not get a clear answer. I'm gonna set this down now.

speaker: Also mine.
response: Wait. I'm confused. Why would you need both a robot girlfriend and a robot prostitute?

speaker: You know, let's just come up with something new.
response: You know, a number of significant innovations have been inspired by science fiction. The, the geosynchronous satellite from Arthur C. Clarke. The Motorola flip phone, that came from Star Trek. And I've long suspected that the idea of an African-American president was stolen from the movie Deep Impact.

speaker: How cool would that be if we could make one of those a reality?
response: If we could figure out the scientific basis for Marty's hover board, that would have universal application.

speaker: Oh, I have an idea.
response: I think I have the same one.

speaker: This is Hot Tub Time Machine all over again. If future Biff goes back to 2015 right after he gives young Biff the almanac, he could get back to the 2015 with Marty and Doc in it. Because it wasn't until his 21st birthday that 1955 Biff placed his first bet.
response: Wait. Whoa, whoa. Is placed right?

speaker: What do you mean?
response: Is placed the right tense for something that would have happened in the future of a past that was affected by something from the future?

speaker: Had will have placed?
response: That's my boy.

speaker: Okay, so, it wasn't until his 21st birthday that Biff had will have placed his first bet and made his millions. That's when he altered the timeline.
response: Yeah, but he had will haven't placed it!

speaker: What?
response: Unlike Hot Tub Time Machine, this couldn't be more simple. When Biff gets the almanac in 1955, the alternate future he creates isn't the one in which Marty and Doc Brown ever use the time machine to travel to 2015. Therefore, in the new timeline, Marty and Doc never brought the time machine…

speaker: Wait. Is brought right?
response: Marty and Doc never had have had brought?

speaker: I don't know. You did it to me.
response: Oh, I'm going with it. Marty and Doc never had have had brought the time machine to 2015. That means 2015 Biff could also not had have had brought the almanac to 1955 Biff.
