Therefore, the timeline in which 1955 Biff gets the almanac is also the timeline in which 1955 Biff never gets the almanac. And not just never gets. Never have, never hasn't, never had have hasn't.

speaker: Guys.
response: Do you know that the word wiener comes from the German name of the Austrian capital Vienna, or Wien?

speaker: Guys, what are we doing? We sent the girls away so we could focus.
response: I don't think it worked.

speaker: All right.
response: Oh, this is already better. There are far fewer distractions in here.

speaker: Or if we could figure out a way to supercool the materials, we could utilize quantum coupling.
response: Well, I wonder if anyone's tried that.

speaker: I'm sure Mrs. Florida's walking funny. Can we get back to work?
response: Yeah, he's right. Oh, here's a thought. What if we use some form of operant conditioning techniques to keep us from getting off topic?

speaker: Like behavior modification?
response: Yeah, exactly. Did you know those techniques were used to actually teach pigeons to play ping-pong?

speaker: We could snap a rubber band on our wrists every time we get sidetracked.
response: Mmm, not bad. You know, in medieval times, idle chatter was punished with a device called the scold's bridle. It's an iron cage that's locked around the head and pierces the tongue.

speaker: If only we had one.
response: Oh, I'll check Amazon.

speaker: All right, now, one benefit of quantum coupling…
response: Wait, a question, who decides if someone's gone off topic?

speaker: I think it'll be pretty clear. If not, we'll take a vote. Oh, and also…
response: Ow. We didn't vote!

speaker: We didn't have to, that was clearly a tangent. Now come on. Back to work. If we're leaning towards quantum coupling… Aah! Why?
response: You said quantum coupling. That made me think of the show Quantum Leap. That's a tangent and it's your fault.

speaker: Thank you. And now I owe you one.
response: Ow. That was your fault.

speaker: Everyone stop. This was a stupid idea. Negative reinforcement isn't working.
response: I think you mean positive punishment. Negative reinforcement is the removal of a positive stimulus. It's a common mistake.

speaker: Negative reinforcement is really wrong?
response: Oh, it's used incorrectly all the time. Even Bill Murray makes that mistake in the first scene of Ghostbusters.

speaker: No.
response: Leonard's right. We can't just jump ahead. We have to watch the whole movie.

speaker: It's late. We've wasted hours. Can we please find it in ourselves to do any amount of work tonight?
response: But we didn't see them bust one ghost.

speaker: So you're, you're saying we should stand here in my lab on a Saturday night and watch the rest of Ghostbusters on a crappy laptop?
response: No.

speaker: To Stuart, your comic book store is out of this world. Just like the guy in this picture was.”
response: For the record, he also thinks the Walgreens and the dry cleaners are out of this world.

speaker: Have you noticed that Howard can take any topic and use it to remind you that he went to space?
response: Interesting hypothesis. Let’s apply the scientific method, perform an experiment.

speaker: Anywhere but the Space Station. On a good day, dinner was a bag full of meat loaf. But, hey, you don’t go there for the food, you go there for the view.
response: It’s fascinating. Let me see if I can duplicate the result. Howard, I’ve always thought the lemon was an underrated fruit. Care to weigh in?

speaker: Not really.
response: Oh, well.

speaker: I think I’m gonna try green tea mixed with lemon zinger.
response: Two tea bags in one cup? You’re not at a rave.

speaker: So, listen, Sheldon, I was thinking, since this is gonna be our first Halloween party as boyfriend and girlfriend, I thought it might be fun for us to go in a couples costume.
response: I couldn’t agree more.

speaker: Really? I find that inconsistent with everything I know about you.
response: Oh, oh, on the contrary. Couples costumes are one of the few benefits of being in a relationship. Now imagine this, you and I entering Stuart’s party and all eyes turn to see America’s most beloved and glamorous couple.

speaker: Yeah?
response: R2-D2 and C-3PO. Dibs on Threepio.

speaker: Sheldon, when I said couples costume, I meant like Romeo and Juliet or Cinderella and Prince Charming, not two robots from some silly movie I don’t even like.
response: Okay, I’m gonna let that slide because I know you’re hopped up on tea bags.

speaker: I make compromises for you all the time. Just this once, can’t we find something that we’re both happy with?
response: Fine. How about one of the most beguiling and influential couples of the 20th century? Hewlett and Packard. Dibs on Hewlett. What? You want to be Hewlett?

speaker: On Sesame seed Bunzillas.
response: Night of the Living Garlic Bread?

speaker: It’s funny because bread sounds like dead.
response: I’m sorry, but these are just ordinary foods with the names bent into tortured puns. The dishes themselves are in no way Halloweenie.

speaker: Hello, boys.
response: What are you smiling at?

speaker: So, I thought the photo booth for the party could either be creepy like a mummy’s tomb, or they also have the Tardis from Doctor Who.
response: A Tardis makes no sense. It’s a time machine from a science-fiction show. It has nothing to do with Halloween. That being said, if you don’t get a Tardis, you stink and your party stinks.

speaker: I don’t care. Get the Tardis.
response: Yes! This party just became a major rager.

speaker: Okay, here it is. Bernadette said you guys are all sick of me talking about my trip to space. Is that true?
response: Yes.

speaker: No.
response: We seem to have different approaches here. I was going for helpful honesty. I have no idea what you’re doing.

speaker: It’s called being nice.
response: Okay. If you think being nice will get him to shut up, I’ll try it.

speaker: You know what, guys? Never mind. I just won’t talk about the greatest achievement of my life ever again.
response: Look at that, the problem solved itself.

speaker: You know salt makes me retain water and my cousin William was ground to death in a pepper factory accident. How about Raggedy Ann and Andy? I loved them growing up.
response: No, I don’t think so. Those dolls represent three things I do not care for, clowns, children and raggediness. I think it’s a lost cause.

speaker: No. There are certain things that say to the world, I have a boyfriend, and he’s not made up. Matching costumes, hickeys and sex tapes. Pick one.
response: What’s a hickey?

speaker: Sheldon, get in here.
response: I should’ve picked hickey.

speaker: I’m Raggedy Ann, and he’s Raggedy C-3PO.
response: It was a compromise. I lost.

speaker: Thank you.
response: No, thank you. Delivery men are the unsung foot soldiers of our nation's commerce. It's because of people like you, people like me can limit our human contact. I'd shake your hand, but, well, you know.

speaker: I'm not a delivery man, I'm a doctor. Although I do often deliver alarming biopsy results to my patients.
response: That's humorous.

speaker: All right.
response: Yeah, I bet you leave your patients in stitches. That was also humorous.

speaker: All right.
response: Are you bringing flowers to a patient to cushion the blow of a terminal diagnosis? That wasn't a joke.

speaker: All right. These are actually for a nice woman who makes sales calls to my office.
response: Hmm. You know, they have delivery people that will do that for you.

speaker: I was hoping to impress her by tracking her down on the Internet and then showing up unannounced at her door.
response: Making the extra effort. Good for you.

speaker: Great timing, food just got here.
response: Ooh, Siam Palace?

speaker: Yes.
response: Uh, mee krob and chicken satay?

speaker: Yes.
response: Uh, extra peanut sauce?

speaker: No, but you can have mine.
response: Eh, well, very well. Oh, and on the topic of sharing things that are yours, there is a gentleman caller bringing flowers to your fiancée as we speak.

speaker: What? Why didn't you say that first?
response: Why didn't you get extra peanut sauce? We can both play this game.

speaker: Oh, uh, you probably don't want her to see this. It's unnecessarily graphic.
response: Hold on, Doctor. Leonard, where are your social k*ll? This man is clearly upset. We should invite him in for a hot beverage.

speaker: He tried to score with Penny.
response: So have these two, and they're having dinner with us.

speaker: Please don't go. Up until my vicious attack, you were the one in the wrong.
response: Here you go, Doctor. Red Zinger with one teaspoon of honey.

speaker: Ever since I was a kid, but, uh, I didn't really get serious until William Shatner's bladder infection.
response: What'd you get? What'd you get?

speaker: Oh. Well, you know, just being myself, really.
response: Oh, please, you know, I'll tell you how he did it. Implacable, relentless badgering. In urology terms, he was a drug-resistant staph infection. And she was a urethra that could not shake him.

speaker: Ah, that's a good question. Apparently someone was being awfully flirty while not wearing their engagement ring, causing another someone to show up here thinking the first someone might be available.
response: Oh, God. Don't make it so hard on her. Look, the first someone is the deceitful you. The second someone is the delightful Dr. Lorvis.

speaker: I'll be right back.
response: So what other celebrity genitalia have you handled?

speaker: Oh, my God.
response: Leonard, I was wrong. Heaven does exist. And it's in the basement of a urologist's house in Sherman Oaks.

speaker: Wow, Donkey Kong. This, this was my game when I was a kid.
response: Because it's a story of a pretty blonde girl tirelessly pursued by a small, oddly-shaped man?

speaker: No, because I liked it.
response: Well, now, don't get defensive. You're oddly-shaped, but you got the girl.

speaker: So, I've noticed Leonard gets teased a lot 0about his relationship with Penny.
response: Yes. If you'd like to join in, the premise is their love seems unlikely and doomed to failure.

speaker: So, you think she'll be single soon?
response: Oh, if you want to get in on the pool, you're too late. All the squares have been purchased.

speaker: Interesting. Excuse me, I have to take care of something.
response: Leonard, as your friend I feel I should tell you something.

speaker: What?
response: I'm still upset about that peanut sauce.

speaker: Next game, let's switch helmets.
response: No, I'd look silly in that helmet.

speaker: Uh, guys, we're locked in here.
response: Oh, this day just keeps getting better.

speaker: Just walk.
response: You can do this.

speaker: Thank you for not making fun of me during my speech.
response: It wasn’t easy. Was it Buzz?

speaker: We can’t show up to your mom’s empty-handed. We should bring something.
response: I already am. I’m bringing the gift of knowledge.

speaker: Oh, boy.
response: Despite what her Bible says, recent archaeological studies indicate that although camels are referenced in the Old Testament, they didn’t exist in the Middle East until hundreds of years later.

speaker: Okay, give me the flowers and pie.
response: But if we show up and you’re holding them, she’ll think they’re only from you.

speaker: They are only from me. You said the gift of you was enough.
response: Yes, but now that I’ve seen what the gift of me with flowers and pie looks like, there’s no going back. Boy, I can’t wait to see the look on her face. We’re leaving right now.

speaker: What’s wrong?
response: Nothing.

speaker: What? Sheldon, tell me what’s going on.
response: I saw my mommy with a naked man and she was trying to be a mommy again.

speaker: You ready to talk about it?
response: I’m not nearly drunk enough. Okay. Do you have any idea what it’s like to see your mother ravaging someone?

speaker: Does a brisket count? I’m sorry, buddy, that’s rough. But didn’t she know we were coming?
response: No. I wanted to surprise her. What am I supposed to say to her after something like this?

speaker: Well, did she see you in the window?
response: No.

speaker: Then don’t say anything.
response: I have to. How can we ever hope to have a healthy relationship if I don’t tell her how disappointed I am, and that I’ll never forgive her?

speaker: Well, don’t do it on the phone.
response: No, I’m just going to tell her I’m coming so she can give that good time Charlie the heave-ho.

speaker: That’s some tough talk, I may need to cut you off.
response: Yeah, maybe you better, I took a pretty big sip.

speaker: Look, she’s a grown woman. And, and your dad’s been gone a long time. Maybe this is none of your business.
response: I beg to differ. I used to live in those genitals. And if someone wants to move into my old room, I should at least get a vote.

speaker: Good luck.
response: You, aren’t you gonna come with me?

speaker: While you confront your mother about her sex life? I’d rather go back to that bar in ass-less chaps.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Mother? (Knock, knock, knock) Mother? (Knock, knock, knock) Mother?

speaker: Shelly, I’m so glad you’re here.
response: I saw you having naked sex.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: Earlier, I came here to surprise you. I looked in the window and I saw you with a man.

speaker: Oh, Shelly, I’m so sorry. Come in. Um, maybe we should sit down and talk about this.
response: Can you recommend a surface you haven’t had coitus on?

speaker: That’s not funny. Maybe we should sit at the table. Well, I’m sure that, uh, you have a lot of questions.
response: Who was he?

speaker: His name is Ron. I met him at my prayer group.
response: How long have you been involved with him?

speaker: A few months.
response: And of those few months, how long have you been a demented sex pervert?

speaker: That is no way to speak to your mother.
response: Perhaps not. But it is a way to speak to a woman who quoted the Bible to me my whole life, and then desecrates one of Ethan Allen’s finest sofas.

speaker: I will give you one opportunity, young man, to apologize.
response: Or what?

speaker: Or I will send you to your room.
response: That’s ridiculous. I am a grown man. I am a professional scientist. And I currently occupy the moral high ground.

speaker: Go to your room.
response: But I occupy the moral high ground.

speaker: Go to your room.
response: But I’m a professional scientist.

speaker: Go to your room!
response: I’m a grown man.

speaker: Hey, can I come in?
response: Apparently any man is welcome in this house. Why not you? I thought you were waiting in the car.

speaker: That was an hour ago, Sheldon. A Jew sits in front of a house in Texas that long, For Sale signs start to go up. I take it things didn’t go smoothly with your mom.
response: No. I’m not sure how we’re going to get past this.

speaker: You know, I, I sort of went through something like this myself.
response: Howard, we’ve all seen your mother naked. That woman needs to learn how to tie a robe.

speaker: I’m talking about when my mom started seeing someone a couple of years after my dad left.
response: I didn’t know she did.

speaker: Yeah, she was dating this guy, and I was kind of a jerk to her about it.
response: What did you do?

speaker: Well, let’s just say it was the most vicious bar mitzvah speech in the history of Temple Beth El. Anyway, she broke up with him. And she’s basically been alone ever since. She never said it, but I always felt I was the reason why.
response: I’m sorry. Although, based on your story, you absolutely were the reason why.

speaker: All I’m saying is you might not want to get in the way of your mom’s happiness.
response: You may have a point. I love my mother. Even if she fornicates like a demonic weasel.

speaker: Hello. Are you ready to discuss this calmly, like adults?
response: I am.

speaker: Shelly, I’m sorry that you saw what you saw. I know that this is hard for you.
response: I think what most upsets me about it, Mother, is the hypocrisy. Doesn’t this contradict all the religious rules you’ve been espousing your whole life?

speaker: You’re right, it does, and it’s something that I’m struggling with these days.
response: Then why are you doing it?

speaker: Because I’m not perfect, Shelly. And that man’s booty is.
response: Well, this is confusing for me. But I don’t want to stand in the way of your happiness. So, I’ll condemn you internally while maintaining an outward appearance of acceptance.

speaker: That is very Christian of you.
response: Mother, if you’re going to conduct your life in this fashion, then I should let you know that the world has changed since you were a young woman. You know, it’s not all sock hops, soda jerks and segregation anymore.

speaker: How old do you think I am?
response: My point is that you’re going to need to be careful. You used to be protected by your pre-Enlightenment mythology, but now you’re going to need a stronger friend named latex.

speaker: Are you having the sex talk with me?
response: Well, someone has to.

speaker: Oh, dear Lord.
response: No, don’t look to Him. He’s mad at you right now.

speaker: Not great. They hired divorce attorneys.
response: You know, speaking of attorneys, if I ever needed a lawyer, I would not hire She-Hulk.

speaker: Yeah, she works at a law firm in New York.
response: Yes, but she's the only monster at the firm. Between you, me and the wall, I think she's an affirmative action hire.

speaker: I've always wanted to do a traditional Victorian Christmas. Parlour games, goose and figgy pudding.
response: Ugh. English pudding. You get yourself all excited for pudding, and here comes a cake with raisins in it. I'm not going.

speaker: You're going.
response: Why do you hate me?

speaker: I don't hate you. I love you.
response: Well, you call it love, but it has a lot of raisins in it.

speaker: Here comes Santa Claus, here comes Santa Claus, right down Santa Claus Lane. Vixen and Blitzen and all his reindeer pulling on the reins.
response: Yeah, I appreciate the ride.

speaker: Bells are ringing, children singing, all is merry and bright. So hang your stockings and say your prayers 'cause Santa Claus is coming tonight. Why'd you turn it off?
response: Because in the last ten minutes, Santa came to town, kissed Mommy and ran Grandma over with a reindeer. I had a drunk uncle who did all those things. Nobody sings songs about him.

speaker: Maybe you'd like it more if you thought of Santa as a superhero and his power is bringing joy to children.
response: My uncle was accused of that, too. It turned out to be legal in Oklahoma.

speaker: Okay, new subject. Let's talk about presents. What did you get Amy?
response: Oh, we're not exchanging gifts.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, you have to get her something.
response: Why should I? She knows that I don't like Christmas, and yet, every year, she forces me to celebrate it. Not only am I going to this foolish dinner against my will, at the Christmas tree lot, there was mistletoe, and she kissed me under it in public. Like we were the stars of a Tijuana sex show.

speaker: She's just excited about the holidays.
response: Yes, and she's not taking my feelings into account at all. Maybe it's time I teach her a lesson.

speaker: How?
response: Hmm. It'd have to be something heinous, something that makes her as miserable as she's making me. Oh, I've got it. This is good.

speaker: What?
response: I'm going to buy her a present.

speaker: Yeah, you're gonna have to walk me through that.
response: With gift-giving, there's an implied social contract. If I show up tonight with a present, and she doesn't have one for me, she'll feel terrible.

speaker: Then you're both sad?
response: Yes. Maybe she'll feel so guilty, she'll never make me celebrate the holidays again.

speaker: So your evil plot here is to buy your girlfriend a present?
response: That's right. So stay on my good side, or I'll get you a little something, too.

speaker: What about that sweater?
response: No, it's not good enough. It has to be perfect.

speaker: I think the nicest gifts I've got from Howie show how well he knows me.
response: Hmm. Let's see, what do I know about Amy? She loves medieval literature, Chaucer's her favourite. And her eyes sparkle when she watches old French movies. I enjoy how harp music causes her fingers to dance as if she's playing along.

speaker: Wow, you really do love her.
response: I do. Now, let's find the kind of gift that makes her feel small and worthless.

speaker: All right, let me see if I've got this straight. A picture of you on my lap is a way to punish your girlfriend for making you celebrate Christmas?
response: Correct.

speaker: Santa thinks dating you may be punishment enough.
response: There's an argument for that. But I want to make sure.

speaker: Mmm. Amy, that pudding was delicious.
response: If you like raisins.

speaker: Thank you. And it's figs.
response: Oh. Oh, in that case, it was pretty good.

speaker: Oh, you Heimliched a ball of wool out of me; you're good.
response: Uh, what do you say we exchange gifts?

speaker: I thought you hate giving gifts.
response: Yeah, I do. Which is why I got Amy this.

speaker: You got me something?
response: Oh, not just something, no. It's from the heart, it's holiday-themed, and I swallowed the gift receipt so you cannot return it.

speaker: Look at you on Santa's lap. That's so sweet.
response: Of course it is. It's the perfect gift. How are you feeling right now? Guilty? Sad? Wishing you were Jewish?

speaker: No, I love it.
response: Oh, really? Well, how about now? (On recording) Happy holidays to my dear Amy. I hope you treasure this as much as I treasure you. (Not on recording) And you got me nothing. Christmas is ruined. Let's never speak of it again. Well, this was fun.

speaker: Actually, I did get you something.
response: But what about our agreement?

speaker: Well, you got me something. Here.
response: Cookies?

speaker: They're your Meemaw's Christmas cookies. I called and got the recipe.
response: They're perfect. It tastes like her hugs.

speaker: Merry Christmas, Sheldon.
response: I can't believe this. You're happy, I'm happy. Well, maybe a holiday that's all about giving isn't so… Get your hand out of that box.

speaker: What are you drawing over there?
response: It’s a hypothetical containment field for a Frisbee-sized wormhole that could serve as a portal to a parallel universe.

speaker: You know, a lot of scientists believe that making contact with other life-forms would probably not end well for us.
response: It’s a Frisbee-sized wormhole, Leonard. You can block it with a Frisbee. Calm down. (Hands Howard the napkin)

speaker: Do you expect me to build this?
response: I expect you to wipe the pudding off your chin. Gentlemen.

speaker: Two forty-four, Right on schedule. Hey, Sheldon.
response: Oh, hello.

speaker: Raj and I are heading over to the genetics lab to pet the glow-in-the-dark bunny. Want to come with us?
response: No, thank you.

speaker: Are you sure? They turn off the lights, and it’s like a cute little laser show that poops all over the place.
response: I’m quite sure. Good day.

speaker: Well, where are you going?
response: Where are you going?

speaker: We just told you.
response: I just told you.

speaker: No, you didn’t.
response: Well, it’s your word against mine; see you in court.

speaker: If you’re wondering why I’ve been staring through the peephole, I’m trying to get a look at this guy who’s coming over to Penny’s.
response: To be honest, I didn’t know you were here.

speaker: It’s not a big deal. He’s just in her history class. They’re working on a project together. I don’t even know why I care. You know what, I don’t care.
response: You think you don’t care?

speaker: This is silly. I have nothing to worry about.
response: Oh, I don’t know. I mean, statistically speaking, I’m sure you have something to worry about.

speaker: What do you mean?
response: Well, if we assume your looks are average, yeah, right off the bat, fifty percent of men on Earth are more attractive than you. That’s one point five billion handsome lads standing by, waiting to rain on your parade.

speaker: Well, yeah, but this isn’t just about looks. I’m, I’m way above average in a lot of other things.
response: Not height, vision, athleticism, or ability to digest dairy products.

speaker: I’m talking about important things like emotional maturity.
response: You were just spying on your girlfriend through a peephole.

speaker: I liked it better when you thought I wasn’t here.
response: I’m not saying you don’t have attractive qualities. Your choice of friends is impeccable, you’re a good sleeper, and last but not least, you buy the grapes I like. You’re a real catch compared to some snoring guy with a fridge full of lousy grapes.

speaker: None of this matters. I trust that Penny cares about me, and nothing’s gonna happen with this guy.
response: Well, unless of course he’s a k*ll hypnotist.

speaker: What?
response: While unlikely, it’s still a statistical possibility. She might be performing sexual acts with him and not even know it.

speaker: Now you’re just being ridiculous.
response: Am I? The mind’s a mysterious thing, Leonard. He could be having the time of his life while she thinks she’s a chicken pecking for corn.

speaker: I’ll be right back.
response: I thought you left a long time ago.

speaker: I don’t know.
response: This is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Experimental log. Wormhole generator test forty-four.

speaker: Wormhole generator test? (On screen a wormhole appears)
response: The first forty-three parallel universes I’ve checked proved to be empty. I see no reason to suspect universe number forty-four will be any different. (Puts his head in the wormhole)

speaker: Holy crap!
response: Oh! It’s eating my face!

speaker: Aah! It’s eating his face!
response: I found your webcam and replaced the video feed. You two should be ashamed of yourselves.

speaker: Yeah, really sorry.
response: Sorry? You may not realize it, but I have difficulty navigating certain aspects of daily life. You know, understanding sarcasm, feigning interest in others, not talking about trains as much as I want to. It’s exhausting. Which is why, for twenty minutes a day, I like to go down to that room, turn my mind off and do what I need to do to recharge.

speaker: And what does forty-three mean?
response: You don’t need to know, you don’t deserve to know, and you will never know.

speaker: It was good.
response: That’s it? Good”

speaker: I enjoyed it. When you told me I was going to be losing my virginity, I didn’t think you meant showing me Raiders of the Lost Ark for the first time.
response: My apologies. I chose my words poorly. I should have said you were about to have your world rocked on my couch. Anyway, thank you for watching it. It’s one of my all-time favourites.

speaker: It was very entertaining despite the glaring story problem.
response: Story problem? You, oh, Amy, what a dewy-eyed moon-calf you are. Raiders of the Lost Ark is the love child of Steven Spielberg and George Lucas, two of the most gifted filmmakers of our generation. I’ve watched it 36 times, except for the snake scene and the face-melting scene, which I can only watch when it’s still light out, but, I defy you to find a story problem. Here’s my jaw, drop it.

speaker: All right. Indiana Jones plays no role in the outcome of the story. If he weren’t in the film, it would turn out exactly the same.
response: Oh, I see your confusion. You don’t understand. Indiana Jones was the one in the hat with the whip.

speaker: Why are you reading Pride and Prejudice?
response: I’ll tell you why. Amy ruined Raiders of the Lost Ark for me, so now I’m trying to find something beloved to her and ruin that.

speaker: Wait, how can, how can anyone ruin Raiders? It’s perfect.
response: Yeah, except for the fact that Indiana Jones is completely irrelevant to the story. With or without him, the n*zi find the ark, open it and die.

speaker: Whatcha doin’?
response: Oh, it turns out Amy’s beloved Pride and Prejudice is a flawless masterpiece. He’s got too much pride, she’s got too much prejudice, it just works.

speaker: So you’re looking to ruin something for her in the funny pages?
response: Amy has a fondness for the comic strip Marmaduke.

speaker: Mm-hmm. And?
response: And I think I’ve got it. Consider, a family possesses a dog that is so large and poorly disciplined, he causes nothing but problems. Why do they keep him?

speaker: Maybe they fell in love with him as a puppy and didn’t know how big he was gonna be.
response: Of course. You know, why couldn’t she just like Ziggy? Yeah? That thing’s riddled with plot holes.

speaker: Sorry, buddy.
response: Ooh, I think she’s a fan of Garfield as well. Oh, darn it, now so am I.

speaker: I’ll see you later. I gotta go watch a stupid football game with Penny.
response: Wait, hang on. You’ve spent time with Amy. Can you think of anything she’s fond of that has a bunch of flaws she hasn’t noticed?

speaker: Hello, Sheldon. Is everything okay?
response: Yes. Why?

speaker: Well, the last time you made an unscheduled video-chat, there was a curly fry in your regular fries and you thought someone might be trying to slip you a mickey.
response: April 13, a dark night, indeed.

speaker: So what can I do for you?
response: I’m calling to invite you to a spontaneous date night tomorrow evening.

speaker: Really?
response: Yes. You were kind enough to watch Raiders of the Lost Ark with me. So I’d like to return the favour by inviting you to watch an episode of your favourite childhood television series, Little House on the Prairie.

speaker: That sounds lovely. Why are you rubbing your hands together?
response: Um, I’m putting on lotion. Are you in or not?

speaker: Of course I’m in.
response: Excellent. Then I shall see you tomorrow. Good night, Dr. Fowler.

speaker: Good night, Dr. Cooper.
response: Good night, indeed. What a rube. Why would I put on lotion when I have such soft hands?

speaker: I love Little House. It made me want to live on a farm so much I tried to milk my cat. That tangy bowl of Cheerios was not worth the stitches.
response: Well, you sit back, relax and enjoy a beloved childhood memory. You see that cabin there? I read they were illegally squatting on Indian land. Yeah. Personally, I think what we did to the Native Americans was wrong, but this is your favourite show, not mine. Oh, look at little Laura Ingalls, eating that peanut butter sandwich. Peanut butter? Huh? That’s strange, since peanut butter wasn’t introduced until the early 1900s. If I knew this show was about time travel, I would have watched it much sooner.

speaker: You’re trying to get back at me for what I said about Raiders of the Lost Ark.
response: That’s silly. Almost as silly as Dr. Baker having a telephone, since telephones only existed in large cities at that time. This is more like Little House on the Preposterous.

speaker: Sheldon, we’re in a relationship. When you get angry, just tell me. You don’t need to seek revenge.
response: Are you sure? Every time my dad stayed out all night, my mom would put hamster poop in his chewing tobacco.

speaker: Well, that’s not how we’re going to do it.
response: Fine. I’m mad at you. Not only did you ruin Raiders for me, you may have ruined the whole franchise. Except for the fourth one, which was bad before you got your mitts on it.

speaker: I shouldn’t have said it. I’m sorry.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Do you feel better?
response: Yes. But not as good as I’m going to when I tell you that your precious Garfield has no reason to hate Mondays. He’s a cat. He doesn’t have a job.

speaker: Wait, wait, if it wasn’t for Indiana Jones, the ark would never have ended up at the warehouse.
response: That’s true. He collected and delivered the ark to the proper authorities for filing.

speaker: Please let it go, Sheldon.
response: It was rife with historical inaccuracies. For example, the tavern girl serving flagons of mead, now her costume was obviously Germanic, but in 1487 the Bavarian purity laws or Rhineheitsgebot severely limited the availability of mead. At best they would have had some sort of spiced wine.

speaker: You’re nitpicking.
response: Oh-ho! Really? Well here’s another nit for you. The flagons would not have been made of polypropylene.

speaker: Renaissance fairs aren’t about historical accuracy. They’re about taking chubby girls who work at Kinko’s and lacing them up in corsets so tight their bosom jumps out and says howdy.
response: Bosoms would not have said howdy in the fifteenth century. If anything they would have said “huzzah!”

speaker: Hi guys. Looks like you’ve been to the Renaissance fair. I’m hoping.
response: Renaissance fair? More of a medieval slash age of enlightenment slash any excuse to wear a codpiece fair.

speaker: By moving on, do you mean, she’s going out with other men and you spent the afternoon making fifteenth century soap with Wolowitz?
response: That was not fifteenth century soap, my God those people need to learn you can’t just put “ye olde” in front of anything and expect to get away with it.

speaker: Can we please just go in, my chain mail is stuck in my underwear.
response: You’re wearing modern underwear?

speaker: Relatively modern. Why, what are you wearing?
response: I fashioned historically accurate undergarments out of linen.

speaker: You went out and bought linen?
response: Don’t be silly, I borrowed one of your pillow cases.

speaker: What? I’ve dated plenty of women. There was Joyce Kim, Leslie Winkle.
response: Notify the editors of the Oxford English Dictionary, the word plenty has been redefined to mean two.

speaker: What about Leslie Winkle.
response: Oh no.

speaker: Why?
response: Her research methodology is sloppy, she’s unjustifiably arrogant about loop quantum gravity, and to make matters worse she’s often mean to me.

speaker: I’d hit that.
response: You’d hit particulate soil on a colloidal suspension. Mud.

speaker: How?
response: If we were, the food would be better.

speaker: Hey, dummy.
response: Hello to you, insufficiently intelligent person.

speaker: Uh, sure.
response: Well, if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to go do work that promises significant results, as opposed to what you do, which does not. Yeah, you heard me.

speaker: Terrific.
response: You know what this means, don’t you? Break out the Red Bull, it’s time to rock Mario old school.

speaker: I kind of have other plans tonight.
response: But it’s Friday. Friday’s always vintage game night. Look, mom included the memory card, we can pick up where I left off in 1999 when I had pernicious anaemia.

speaker: Well, the thing is, someone’s coming over.
response: Well then, no problem, I have three controllers, the more the merrier.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s a date, I have a date coming over.
response: Oh, well you can’t blame me for not jumping to that conclusion.

speaker: Why, what’s so unusual about me having a date?
response: Well, statistically speaking…

speaker: Alright, alright. Well, uh, nevertheless, I have one now and I would appreciate it if you would, you know, make yourself scarce.
response: Leonard, I am a published theoretical physicist with two doctorates and an IQ which can’t be accurately measured by normal tests, how much scarcer could I be?

speaker: You know what I mean, could you just give us a little privacy?
response: You want me to leave the apartment?

speaker: Yes.
response: You mean just go someplace else and be… someplace else?

speaker: Yes.
response: Well, why should I leave, this is my apartment too.

speaker: I know it is, and if science ever discovers a second member of your species and you two would like some privacy I would be more than happy to get out of your way.
response: Well alright then.

speaker: Sheldon? What are you doing?
response: Playing Super Mario on a poorly coded Nintendo 64 emulator.

speaker: Yeah, but why are you doing it on the stairs?
response: I’m a modern day Napoleon exiled to the Elba of the staircase because Leonard, get this, has a date.

speaker: Oh. Oh, well, good for him. Yeah but, why are you sitting here, why don’t you just go to a movie or something?
response: Alone?

speaker: Yeah, why not?
response: What if I choke on my popcorn, who will administer the Heimlich manoeuvre.

speaker: Well then don’t order popcorn.
response: No popcorn at the mo… listen to yourself.

speaker: Well why don’t you go to a coffee shop.
response: I don’t drink coffee.

speaker: They have other things.
response: What do they have?

speaker: I don’t know, you know, cookies, pastries…
response: Pastries such as bearclaws?

speaker: Yeah, sure.
response: I don’t like bearclaws.

speaker: Heya Penny. Dumbass.
response: Leslie Winkle. Of all the overrated physicists in all the labs in all the world, why does it have to be Leslie Winkle?

speaker: Well, they have a lot in common. I mean they’re both scientists.
response: Oh please. The only way she could make a contribution to science would be if they resume sending chimps into space.

speaker: Okay, well I have a date too, so see ya.
response: Everybody has a date. Even you, Mario, going after Princess Peach. And what am I doing, I’m just enabling you.

speaker: Besides shortness, what genetic weaknesses run in your family?
response: I’m sorry to interrupt, batteries dying continue.

speaker: Uh, genetic weaknesses, right, um, there’s the lactose intolerance.
response: Don’t forget the male pattern baldness. When his uncles sit around the dinner table they look like a half carton of eggs. (Exits. Extension cord trails after him. Eventually goes tight a couple of times then falls loose.)

speaker: Okay, now my uncles are bald, but my Aunt Edna is one of the hairiest women you will ever meet. So… Sweet lady. It always tickles when she hugs me. (Sheldon knocks and enters again.) What now?
response: I have to make pee-pee.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, there’s so few places I can wear my jester costume.
response: I don’t care. There are far too many historical anomalies for my comfort.

speaker: Oh, okay, how about this. You can go dressed as a Star Trek science officer exploring a planet similar to Earth in the 1500s.
response: You mean like Spock?

speaker: Sure.
response: Fascinating.

speaker: Hmm, let’s do it. (Sheldon does not move. Leonard looks confused.)
response: If you’re having trouble deciding where to sit may I suggest one potato two potato, or as I call it the Leslie Winkle experimental methodology.

speaker: Don’t make this hard for me.
response: It’s not hard. It’s simple. You can either sit with me, your friend, colleague and roommate, or you can sit with an overrated scientist you might have sex with.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Penny.

speaker: Third floor tonight. Mixing it up? (Sheldon indicates extension cord.) Oh. You know, I still don’t understand why you just don’t go to dinner or something.
response: Alright, let’s say I go to dinner alone. And during the meal I have to use the rest room. How do I know someone’s not touching my food?

speaker: Goodnight Sheldon.
response: Penny, hold on. Are you sure things can’t work out with you and Leonard?

speaker: Excuse me?
response: I’m just wondering if you really gave it the old college try? Or in your case the old community college try?

speaker: Okay, where is this coming from?
response: Leonard is upstairs right now with my arch enemy.

speaker: Your arch enemy?
response: Yes, the Doctor Doom to my Mr Fantastic. The Doctor Octopus to my Spiderman. The Doctor Sivana to my Captain Marvel.

speaker: Okay, I get it, I get it, I get it.
response: Do you know, it’s amazing how many supervillains have advanced degrees. Graduate school should probably do a better job of screening those people out.

speaker: Sheldon, come back, you’re losing me.
response: Leslie Winkle, Penny. She belittles my research.

speaker: Oh, sweetie, I’m sorry.
response: She called me dumbass.

speaker: I know. I heard.
response: Given this situation, I have no choice but to withdraw my previous objections to your ill considered relationship with Leonard.

speaker: Oh, gee, well, thankyou for that. But, um, I think for now Leonard and I are just going to stay friends.
response: No, that response is unacceptable to me.

speaker: Sheldon, you are a smart guy, you must know…
response: Smart? I’d have to lose 60 IQ points to be classified as smart.

speaker: Are you going to let me talk?
response: I’m sorry.

speaker: You must know that if Leonard and Leslie want to be together, nothing you can do is going to stop it.
response: You continue to underestimate my abilities madam.

speaker: Okay, let me put it this way, if you’re really Leonard’s friend you will support him no matter who he wants to be with.
response: Wait a minute, why am I doing all the giving here? If Leonard’s really my friend, why doesn’t he have to support me in my hatred of Leslie Winkle?

speaker: Because love trumps hate.
response: Oh now you’re just making stuff up.

speaker: Okay. Goodnight Sheldon.
response: Oh Mario. If only I could control everyone the way I control you. Hop, you little plumber, hop, hop, hop.

speaker: If the word is pee-pee, just do it.
response: Leonard, you are my friend. And friends support their friends, apparently. So I am withdrawing my objection to your desire to have a relationship with Leslie.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I will graciously overlook the fact that she is an arrogant sub-par scientist, who actually believes loop quantum gravity better unites quantum mechanics with general relativity than does string theory. You kids have fun.

speaker: Hang on a second. Loop quantum gravity clearly offers more testable predictions than string theory.
response: I’m listening, amuse me.

speaker: Okay, well, for one thing we expect quantii space-time to manifest itself as minute differences in the speed of light for different colours.
response: Balderdash. Matter clearly consists of tiny strings.

speaker: Sheldon, don’t make that noise, it’s disrespectful.
response: I hope so, it was a snort of derision.

speaker: I’m sorry, I could have accepted our kids being genetically unable to eat ice-cream or ever get a good view of a parade, but this? This is a deal breaker. (Leaves.)
response: Look on the bright side.

speaker: What’s the bright side?
response: Only nine more months to comic-con.

speaker: Yeah.
response: That’s a temporal anomaly. Corn dogs didn’t come into existence until the first half of the twentieth century.

speaker: I know.
response: The university, they think they can do whatever they want. We just have to sit there and take it.

speaker: You need to let it go, Sheldon.
response: You work tirelessly for someone, and this is what you get.

speaker: Oh, my God, they’re just making you use your vacation days.
response: But I don’t want a vacation.

speaker: Okay, listen, I don’t mean to diminish what you’re going through, but I’m a little distracted right now.
response: Oh, this again? So, Penny proposed, you didn’t say yes, and now you think you may have lost her love forever. How does this compare to me being forced to relax for a few days?

speaker: It doesn’t.
response: Thank you.

speaker: I’m gonna go talk to Penny.
response: I’m going to go inside, put on my coziest pajamas, curl up with a good book and wait for this nightmare to be over. (Leonard knocks three times) Penny. Sorry.

speaker: No. You’re on vacation.
response: Please. What if there’s a big breakthrough in science today and I’m not there to see it?

speaker: Do you really think there’s gonna be a breakthrough without you there to do it?
response: No. I was just tricking you.

speaker: Bye.
response: Leonard, wait. Take me with you.

speaker: No.
response: Please.

speaker: No.
response: Too bad. I’m coming with you.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, stay.
response: But.

speaker: Oh. Hey, Sheldon.
response: Hello.

speaker: You okay?
response: I’m on vacation. What do you think?

speaker: Why are you sitting in the stairwell?
response: Leonard told me to stay.

speaker: Oh. Well, good boy.
response: Where are you going?

speaker: Oh, I have a ton of errands to run. I need to make copies of my headshot, send them off to agents and sign up for a new acting class.
response: Well, have fun.

speaker: Okay. You want to come with me?
response: Really?

speaker: Before we begin your guided meditation, close your eyes and picture yourself in a peaceful environment.
response: Okay. I’m inside the CERN super collider.

speaker: Now, take a deep, relaxing breath in through your nose. And let it out.
response: Wow. Didn’t see that coming.

speaker: In.
response: Let me guess.

speaker: And out.
response: What was I gonna do? Two ins in a row? Where’s my lemonade?

speaker: I didn’t get it.
response: A fitting swan song to your career as a waitress, to forget my order one last time.

speaker: Do you think quitting my job was a mistake?
response: Do you see me drinking lemonade?

speaker: No. I’m serious.
response: Why do you ask?

speaker: Because Leonard just pissed me off. Am I being an idiot or not?
response: No, I don’t think you are.

speaker: Really?
response: The best way to achieve a goal is to devote 100% of your time and energy to it. When I decided I was going to be a physicist, I didn’t take some other job in case it didn’t work out. Which wasn’t easy because there was a lot of pressure from Ms. Pearson for me to be chalk monitor that year.

speaker: Thank you. I needed to hear that. Why can’t Leonard understand it?
response: Because he’s not like us, Penny. We’re dreamers.

speaker: And hold three, two, one. Very good. Now let’s try Warrior 2. And hold.
response: I’ve read that there are great yogis who have such mastery over their bodies they can draw water in through their genitals.

speaker: Yeah, well, I don’t think we’re gonna get to do that today.
response: Too bad. It seems like a good way to drink a milk shake without getting brain freeze.

speaker: How did she get you to do yoga?
response: Well, to be honest, I thought she said Yoda.

speaker: Sheldon, take a break.
response: Namaste.

speaker: Yeah, well, maybe we do.
response: I’m willing to if you guys are.

speaker: Can we please have some privacy?
response: Y, No. I’m as much a part of this relationship as you two, and I think it’s high time we put all our cards on the table. For example, where is this going? Are you two ever getting married? And, if so, where will we all live? Have you thought about that?

speaker: No.
response: Penny?

speaker: For some reason, we’re planning a future where we both live with Sheldon forever.
response: Good. Now we’re getting somewhere.

speaker: Look, I know you think I’m being reckless, and you might be right, but I need to take this sh*t.
response: Yeah, no kidding. Despite what it says on her résumé, she is no longer 22.

speaker: You keep saying you’re on my side, but you don’t act like it.
response: He does that to me, too. Why do we put up with it?

speaker: Well, it’s scary for me, too.
response: I’m fine with it.

speaker: Okay. Thank you.
response: Well, to celebrate this reconciliation, let’s all share a milk shake. Uh, Penny, you’ll need a straw.

speaker: Yeah.
response: Good evening, Leonard, Howard, Raj, freeloader.

speaker: Really? Triumphant?
response: Oh, yes, you should have seen those young people. Thirsty for knowledge, drinking in my wisdom. I may have changed a few lives today.

speaker: I don’t know, I kind of promised Howard.
response: Tell me what?

speaker: Actually, we should all share the moment. Raj, if you would.
response: Oh, tweets about my lecture. Hmm. That’s rather unfair. That’s downright cruel. Plus, insects have six legs. Yeah, I’m not familiar with the acronym KMN.

speaker: Oh, uh, from the context, we think it means k*ll me now.
response: Well, I suppose everyone’s entitled to their own opinion. I think I’ll turn in. I didn’t want to teach those poopy heads, anyway.

speaker: So, what do you think?
response: It’s a charming illusion, but it does not cheer me up.

speaker: Not even when I do this? (Pretends to be a fish)
response: No.

speaker: Well, that was the last arrow in my quiver of whimsy.
response: Do you realize that teaching is the first thing I’ve failed at since my ill-fated attempt to complete a chin-up in March of 1989?

speaker: If this humiliating experience is really troubling you, there are things we could do about it.
response: For instance?

speaker: Well, the first thing that comes to mind is isolating the part of your brain where the memory is stored and destroying it with a laser.
response: Hmm, no. One slip of the hand, and suddenly I’m sitting in the Engineering Department, building doodads with Wolowitz.

speaker: All right. Have you considered improving your socialization k*ll, thus allowing you to communicate more effectively with other people?
response: Isn’t that their burden? I’m the one with something interesting to say.

speaker: Fair enough, but in its essence, teaching is a performance art. In the classroom paradigm, the teacher has the responsibility to communicate, as well as entertain and engage.
response: I sense that you’re trying to slow-walk me to an epiphany. Would you mind very much jumping to it?

speaker: Perhaps you should consider taking acting lessons.
response: Acting lessons. Interesting. It might help if I could act as though I care about my students and whether or not they learn.

speaker: What?
response: You’re an (finger quotes) actress, correct?

speaker: I’m not an (finger quotes)actress. I’m an actress.
response: All right. You’re an actress. I need you to teach me.

speaker: You want an acting lesson?
response: Perhaps two. I’d like to master the craft.

speaker: Okay, where is this coming from?
response: It has been suggested to me that acting techniques could improve my lecturing, at which, if certain tweets and blogs are to be believed, I suck the big one.

speaker: Yeah, I saw those. They were funny. I printed a few out and put ‘em on my fridge.
response: So, when could we start?

speaker: Okay, just to be clear. You are asking me for help because I know something that the brilliant Dr. Sheldon Cooper doesn’t.
response: I suppose that’s one way to look at it.

speaker: I think it’s the only way to look at it.
response: Are you going to help me or not?

speaker: Probably. I’m just enjoying the foreplay. Does this mean you are done mocking my acting career?
response: Oh, I’m sorry, I thought making the transition from actor to acting teacher was the signal that one’s career had reached the end of the road.

speaker: Forget it.
response: I’ll pay you 40 dollars.

speaker: What’s wrong?
response: Nothing. I was acting.

speaker: You were acting?
response: Yes. In preparation for today’s studies, I read Stanislavski’s An Actor Prepares, Stella Adler’s

speaker: Well, good for you. Come on in.
response: How shall we begin?

speaker: Well, I thought we’d start with some basic movement exercises. You know, get our bodies warmed up a little.
response: All right.

speaker: So I just want you to relax and kind of move around in the space. You know, just do whatever feels natural. Sheldon?
response: You said to do whatever feels natural. This feels natural. Certainly more natural than what you’re doing.

speaker: Come on, you got to work with me. We need to get connected with our bodies.
response: Penny, my body and I have a relationship that works best when we maintain a cool, wary distance from each other.

speaker: All right, let’s just say we’ve warmed up.
response: You’re the teacher.

speaker: Okay. One of the things that might help you in connecting with your students is being a little more spontaneous. So why don’t we try some improvisation?
response: Why not? It seems like you’re improvising your entire curriculum.

speaker: This is all about listening and responding.
response: Gotcha.

speaker: I’m going to create a character and a situation, and you just jump in when you feel it.
response: All right.

speaker: All right.
response: Action.

speaker: Okay, it’s not a movie. It’s improv. So no one calls action.
response: Hey, you taught me something. Who would have thought it?

speaker: Okay. Uh, no, the shipment has not arrived, and I really need those shoes. They are my biggest seller. Yes, ladies sizes six through ten. Thank you. Oh, sorry, I have to go, I have a customer. Bye-bye. Hi. Can I help you?
response: I’d like a frozen yogurt, please.

speaker: Yogurt?
response: Yeah.

speaker: Um, okay, sure. Luckily, we sell both shoes and yogurt here.
response: You do?

speaker: Yes. Look up at the sign, and remember, improv is always about saying yes.
response: All right. Yes. I see a sign. It says Camarillo State Mental Hospital.

speaker: What?
response: It’s the only explanation I can come up with for why you think you sell shoes and yogurt.

speaker: Okay, you know what? Let’s just try a different improv. Uh, oh, this time we will be two winos living under a freeway overpass.
response: Oh, and we’re going to use props?

speaker: You bet. I had dreams, you know. I was gonna be famous. Show everybody back home I could be someone. Now look at me. Want some?
response: You have any frozen yogurt?

speaker: So, did you get a chance to go over the scene I gave you?
response: Yes. I didn’t care for it.

speaker: Okay, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is an American classic.
response: So is the McRib sandwich. I don’t care for that, either.

speaker: Fine. What would you rather do as a scene study?
response: I’m glad you asked. I took the liberty of adapting a Star Trek fan fiction novella I wrote when I was ten into a one-act play.

speaker: And you think it’s better than Tennessee Williams?
response: Why don’t we leave that for future generations to decide?

speaker: Where No Sheldon Has Gone Before.
response: It’s the story of a young boy who is transported from the ignorant backwoods of East Texas to the 23rd Century, where his genius is not only appreciated, but celebrated.

speaker: KMN.
response: Now, in this pivotal scene, Sheldon’s mother, played by you, argues with an emissary of the United Federation of Planets, Mr. Spock, the role I will bring to life.

speaker: Okay, that’s fine, but let’s try and get you out of your comfort zone.
response: Why would we want to do that? It’s called the comfort zone for a reason.

speaker: Okay, the whole point of this is to loosen you up a little, so I’m thinking you’ll play the role of your mother, and I will bring life to Mr. Spock.
response: I’m sorry. You’ll be Spock?

speaker: It’s only logical.
response: Very well. I’ll set the scene.

speaker: All right.
response: East Texas. A warm summer night. A woman, Mary, stands on a porch. In the distance, we hear a lonesome train whistle. Woo-woo. The droning buzz of cicadas. Zzzzzzzzz. A coyote howls at the moon, frightening sensitive young boys everywhere. Aw-aw-aw! Out in the woods, an owl screeches.

speaker: Okay, okay. We get it. You set the scene.
response: Hoo!

speaker: Now just read your mother’s line.
response: Shelly! Shelly, how many times have I told you not to leave your sciencey stuff out on the porch? Goodness, I’ll never understand that boy. But then again, I’m a religious nut, and my mind is closed to so many things.

speaker: Woo-woo-woo-woo-woo-woo. Spock to Enterprise. Transport successful.
response: Glory be to Heaven, some sort of creature just manifested out of thin air. George, put down that Pepsi can full of bourbon that ain’t foolin’ no one, and get your g*n!

speaker: Greetings, Mary Cooper. I am Spock.
response: I’m sorry. I just don’t buy it.

speaker: Just keep going!
response: Oh, my, your sudden appearance startles me.

speaker: We have been monitoring your son Sheldon from the 23rd Century, and we have determined that he is now ready to join us. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy.
response: I understand. Oh, Shelly? A man’s here to take you away to the future! Be sure to pack clean underwear.”

speaker: Okay, okay, let’s try that last line again, and this time, maybe try choking up a little.
response: Why?

speaker: Well, you’re losing your son.
response: Yes, but he’s going to a better place where he won’t get b*at up. So much.

speaker: All right, come on, just try it my way. Pretend you’re sad to see him go. I’m gonna lead you in. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy. That’s your cue.
response: I’m sorry. I just love that line. Even the way you do it.

speaker: All right, come on, come on. Put some real emotion into it. Blah-blah, blah, blah, vast and troubled galaxy. Go.
response: Oh, Shelly? A man’s here to take you away to the future. Be sure to pack clean underwear.

speaker: That’s good. That’s good. That’s good.
response: Mommy, why are you crying? ‘Cause I’m gonna miss you, Shelly-bean, even though you creep the bejeezus out of me.

speaker: Okay, I guess we’re improvising now.
response: Well I’m sorry. It’s not my fault. I’m just incredibly smart, and everyone around here is dumber than a bag of rocks. Oh, now, don’t you start crying. You get in that spaceship. Mommy’s late for Indian bingo.

speaker: Mrs. Cooper, hey, it’s Penny. Yeah, I think I broke your son. Hey, hold on. Talk to your mother.
response: Mommy, I love you. Don’t let Spock take me to the future!

speaker: No, you weren’t because it was a week ago and nobody came. So, if you want to solve the mystery of who stabbed Koothrappali in the back with the w*apon of indifference, it was all of you.
response: I don’t think thatqualifies as a mystery, we all knew what we were doing.

speaker: Great.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Why?
response: Come on.

response: That’s amusing, I was going to say that about M.I.T., but it works for Princeton, too.

speaker: I’m in, let’s do it.
response: I’m sorry. Are we really doing this or are we tricking Koothrappali again like with the dinner party?

speaker: What’s all this?
response: Oh, everything I could possibly need to win the scavenger hunt.

speaker: You really think he’s gonna send us to a bowling alley?
response: Well, if he does, do you know how filthy those rental balls are? They might as well stand on the corner and give away free rectal exams.

speaker: Okay, everybody. Who’s ready for a scavenger hunt? (Pumping disco music) Somewhere in the city of Pasadena, I’ve hidden a golden coin. You will be faced with a total of ten puzzles. Each p… (cough) each, each puzzle will lead you to the location of the next, the last of which will lead you to the coin. The first team that finds it wins.
response: He is a born showman.

speaker: It’s not funny.
response: No, Oh, it actually is if you get the joke. It’s based on the premise that Princeton isn’t a very good school.

speaker: Ha-ha.
response: Oh, see? Now he gets it.

speaker: No, no. Let’s mix things up. I choose Sheldon, and we’re gonna kick your ass!
response: Really? The only time I’m ever picked first for a team and I’m stuck with the liability?

speaker: All right, hurry up and close the door so they can’t hear us. Would you stop pouting? So, you picked my name. Get over it.
response: Yes, and do you know what the odds are I’d pick your name?

speaker: No.
response: It’s not hard, one in five. Now you know why I’m pouting.

speaker: All right, teams. Get ready to open your first puzzle. Go. Do you see what I did? The first puzzle is a puzzle. Oh, my God, how adorable is that? I wish I had a friend like me.
response: What are you doing? You have to start with the edges.

speaker: Well, there’s no right way, Sheldon. I already found a few pieces that fit.
response: Yeah, well, take them apart and start with the edges. And stop wasting time.

speaker: Ooh, ooh, it’s the comic book store. All right, come on, that’s where we have to go.
response: But we haven’t finished the puzzle.

speaker: But, it, it doesn’t matter. We know the answer, come on.
response: You think you know the answer. But it could be a trick. What if when the puzzle’s complete, there’s a sign in the window that says go to the train store?

speaker: Okay, it’s not gonna say that.
response: Well, I hope you’re wrong. I really want to go to the train store.

speaker: It’s the comic book store, it’s the comic book store, it’s the comic book store.
response: It’s the comic book store.

speaker: Ugh, we’re the last ones here, hurry up.
response: It is a marathon, not a sprint.

speaker: People run in a marathon.
response: Not with a bowling ball on their back.

speaker: Riddle me this…
response: Got it.

speaker: Hey, Princeton, look at that, Team Community College Night School is in the lead.
response: I thought we were the Lightning Sharks.

speaker: Aha. Okay, let’s see. To continue on your quest, leave no stone unturned. Ooh.
response: The next clue must be hidden under one of these rocks.

speaker: Oh. Okay. Sheldon, I, I’ve got to ask, how did you figure out that it was the geology lab?
response: Oh, simple, the ‘arrah, ‘arrah in the riddle mean Jan Arrah, a member of the Legion of Superheroes, known as Element Lad. And then the word He, it wasn’t the masculine pronoun, but rather H e, the abbreviation for helium. See where I’m going with this?

speaker: Yes.
response: Nice try. Now, Element Lad’s ability is the power to transmute chemical elements. Helium has an atomic number of two. If you multiply that by the atomic number of N, nitrogen, you get 14, which is the atomic number of? I’m just funnin’ you, silicon. And that is the most common element in the Earth’s surface. So that narrowed it down to the geology lab or the chemistry lab.

speaker: Wow. I can drink a beer underwater.
response: And I’m sure your parents are proud. Now, finally, the line in this room the thing you’ll see was an obvious reference to Fantastic Four member The Thing, who’s made entirely of…

response: Those are map coordinates. Got ‘em. Let’s go.

speaker: Well, wait. Don’t you want to know how I figured it out?
response: No one likes a know-it-all, Penny.

speaker: Okay. Oh, it’s a bowling alley.
response: Yes. Yes. My brain is better than everybody’s.

speaker: Three bags, no one’s opened ‘em. we’re the first ones here.
response: It’s dirty laundry. You’re up.

speaker: What? Why me?
response: Because you’ve been training for this your whole life. You live in a pile of dirty laundry.

speaker: Because you were about to quit like a big, Sheldon, cover your ears.
response: I’m not a child. I know the word ninny.

speaker: Hey, I am every bit as much of a man as Penny. Now, let’s do this.
response: Wait, it’s not all pants, there’s one shirt.

speaker: Oh.
response: Hey, that’s my shirt.

speaker: This one is, too.
response: No, no, that’s not mine. It has a big spot on it.

speaker: Sheldon’s spot. The coin is in your spot.
response: Oh, that’s clever.

speaker: Hurry.
response: Be there in a minute. I just have to pre-soak these.

speaker: I just wanted to do something beautiful.
response: Hey, look. I won.

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Yeah, we’re going to have to stop by Pottery Barn on the way to work, I bought these Star Wars sheets but they turned out to be much too stimulating to be compatible with a good night’s sleep. I don’t like the way Darth Vader stares at me.

speaker: I’m not going to work.
response: Oh, just because your career’s been stagnant for a few years, that’s no reason to give up.

speaker: Sheldon, I was up all night using the new free-electron laser for my X-ray diffraction experiment.
response: Did the laser accidentally burn out your retinas?

speaker: No.
response: Then you can drive. Let’s go.

speaker: Didn’t I tell you I’d be working nights, and that you’d have to make other arrangements.
response: You did.

speaker: And?
response: I didn’t. Let’s go.

speaker: Goodnight, Sheldon.
response: But how am I going to get to work?

speaker: Take the bus.
response: I can’t take the bus any more. They don’t have seatbelts. And they won’t let you lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords.

speaker: You tried to lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords?
response: I didn’t try, I succeeded. For some reason it alarmed the other passengers and I was asked to de-bus.

speaker: Oh, you’re a big boy, you’ll figure it out.
response: Don’t talk to me like I’m a child. Now, take me to return my star wars sheets!

speaker: Sheldon, what is it?
response: Leonard’s asleep.

speaker: Thanks for the update (begins to close door.)
response: No, wait. You have to drive me to work.

speaker: Yeah, uh, I really don’t think I do.
response: But I don’t drive, and I can’t take the bus.

speaker: Yeah, honey, you’ll be fine as long as you don’t do that bungee cord thing, okay?
response: Penny. Didn’t you recently state that you and I are friends?

speaker: Yes, Sheldon, we are friends.
response: Then I hereby invoke what I’m given to understand is an integral part of the implied covenant of friendship. The favour.

speaker: Oh, dear God.
response: I’m sorry, I didn’t realize I was interrupting your morning prayers. When you’re done, we’ll go.

speaker: You know this is my day off, Sheldon.
response: Oh, good. I’m not keeping you from anything. Your check engine light is on.

speaker: Mm-hmm.
response: Typically that’s an indicator. To, you know, check your engine.

speaker: It’s fine, it’s been on for, like, a month.
response: Well, actually, that would be all the more reason to, you know, check your engine.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s fine.
response: If it were fine, the light wouldn’t be on. That’s why the manufacturer installed that light, to let you know it’s not fine.

speaker: Uh, maybe the light’s broken.
response: Is there a “check the check engine light light”? (Penny takes a drink of coffee) O-o-o-oh!

speaker: What?
response: Studies have shown that performing tasks such as eating, talking on a cell phone or drinking coffee while driving reduces one’s reaction time by the same factor as an ounce of alcohol.

speaker: Do you have any alcohol?
response: Of course not.

speaker: Too bad.
response: You’re going up Euclid Avenue?

speaker: Mm-hmm.
response: Leonard takes Los Robles Avenue.

speaker: Well, good for Leonard.
response: Euclid Avenue is shorter as the crow flies, but it has speed bumps, which appreciably increase point-to-point drive time, making it the less efficient choice. But you have the conn. Of course, if you’re not going to slow down for the speed bumps, I withdraw my previous objection. Here’s a fun question. Do you know what the most common street name is?

speaker: No.
response: The answer’s tricky. It’s Second Street. You see, you’d think it would be First Street, but in most towns, First Street eventually gets renamed to something else, you know, like Main Street, Broad Street, Michigan Avenue. Leonard and I often use our commute time to exercise our minds with brain-teasers like that. We also play games. Would you like to play one?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, come on, it’s fun. Ooh! Another bump. Okay. I’ll say an element, and uh, you say an element whose name starts with the last letter of the one I said, okay? I’ll start. Helium. Now, you could say Mercury. That would give me a Y. Ooh. Very clever, that’s a tough one. So I go Ytterbium, which gets you back to M. So you go Molybdenum, and I say Magnesium, you say Manganese, and I say Europium, and, and you’re left with Mendelevium, and there are no more M’s because I believe that Meitnerium should still be called Ekairidium, so congratulations, you win. Do you wanna go again?

speaker: How about we just have a little quiet time now?
response: All right. Hmm, huh, I’m sorry, I’m finding your reckless nonchalance regarding the check-engine light to be very troubling.

speaker: Get out.
response: Well, I have to tell you that while I do have a theoretical understanding of the workings of an internal combustion engine, I’m not sure I’m capable of performing diagnostics.

speaker: I said, get out.
response: Okay. I’ll give it a sh*t. (Gets out. Penny drives away.)

speaker: I just got here.
response: Good, perfect timing.

speaker: Sheldon, I told you, I only have access to the free-electron laser at night. I can’t drive you for the next few weeks.
response: No, you said you couldn’t drive me to work, this is from work.

speaker: No, just for the fun of it, I’m gonna take his side.
response: Now, how do you propose I get home?

speaker: How did you get here in the first place?
response: Penny. But I sense that’s no longer an option.

speaker: Why did Howard leave you in the middle of the road anyway?
response: We had a difference of opinion.

speaker: Over what?
response: Whether or not he was trying to k*ll me. For the record, I maintain he was. Where are you going?

speaker: I’m taking you home.
response: Oh, but I’m not going home. It’s Wednesday, Wednesday is new comic book day, we have to go to the comic book store. And then we have to stop at Soup Plantation, it’s creamy tomato soup day, and Radio Shack, there’s a sale on triple-a batteries. Plus, we have to go to Pottery Barn and return my Star Wars sheets.

speaker: I have a better idea.
response: You want to go to pottery barn first?

speaker: Sheldon, sit down.
response: She’s in my spot. Don’t look at me like that, everybody knows that my spot.

speaker: So we made you an appointment, and we want you to keep it.
response: Department of motor vehicles new driver handbook? But I don’t have a problem.

speaker: Penny’s taking you to the DMV, I’m going to bed.
response: Why Penny?

speaker: All right, come on Sheldon.
response: Hold on, I have one condition.

speaker: What?
response: We have to stop at Pottery Barn.

speaker: Okay.
response: And Radio Shack.

speaker: Fine.
response: And the comic book store.

speaker: Yeah, and I never wanted to kick Albert Einstein in the nuts. You know, I gotta ask, why didn’t you just get a license at 16 like everybody else?
response: I was otherwise engaged.

speaker: Doing what?
response: Examining perturbative amplitudes in n=4 supersymmetric theories leading to a re-examination of the ultraviolet properties of multi-loop n=8 supergravity using modern twistor theory.

speaker: Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next! (Sheldon moves forward) Application?
response: I’m actually more of a theorist.

speaker: The application in your hand, give it to her.
response: Oh.

speaker: Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next!
response: Excuse me, but I have some concerns about these questions.

speaker: Look at that sign up there.
response: Yes?

speaker: Does it say I give a damn?
response: No.

speaker: That’s because I don’t.
response: Just, look, see, this first question makes no sense, how many car lengths should you leave in front of you when driving? There’s no possible way to answer that, a car length is not a standardized unit of measure.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s C, just put down C.
response: I don’t need your help, Penny.

speaker: Listen to that little girl, honey, put C. Next!
response: No, no, wait, no, hang on, look at this next question.

speaker: Sheldon, why are you arguing with the DMV?
response: How else are they going to learn? Look, question 2, when are roadways most slippery? Now, okay, there are three answers, none of which are correct. The correct answer is, when covered by a film of liquid sufficient to reduce the coefficient of static friction between the tire and the road to essentially zero, but not so deep as to introduce a new source of friction.

speaker: Here’s your learner’s permit. Go away.
response: But I’m not done. I have many additional concerns about these questions.

speaker: Next!
response: Aced it.

speaker: This is a state-of-the-art simulator. I adapted it from something a friend of mine designed for the army.
response: Is that why I appear to be in downtown Fallujah, behind the wheel of an up-armored Humvee?

speaker: I haven’t configured it yet. Let’s see… Bradley t*nk… transport truck… Batmobile…
response: Ooh!

speaker: Here we go, red 2006 Ford Taurus on the streets of Pasadena.
response: Hmmmm?

speaker: What?
response: Statistically, red cars are stopped by police far more often than any other colour. I don’t want any hassles with the fuzz.

speaker: Fine, what colour do you want?
response: You know the pale blue of Luke Skywalker’s lightsaber, before it was digitally remastered?

speaker: Okay, now, what you want to do first is turn on the ignition and shift into drive.
response: I haven’t fastened my seat belt yet.

speaker: Okay, fasten your seat belt.
response: Click. Now, are there air bags?

speaker: You don’t need air bags.
response: What if a simulated van rear-ends me?

speaker: Oh God, wait, slow, hit the brakes, hit the brakes!
response: Thank you.

speaker: How did you manage to get on the second floor of the Glendale galleria?
response: I don’t know. I was on the Pasadena freeway, I missed my exit, flew off the overpass, and one thing led to another.

speaker: Maybe you want to give it a rest and try again tomorrow.
response: No. I quit. (Stands up. There is more sound of crashing and panic, then animal noises.)

speaker: Aw, the pet store?
response: Remind me to compliment Wolowitz on the software, it’s amazingly detailed.

speaker: So wait,you’re just gonna give up?
response: No, I’m not giving up, I never give up.

speaker: So what is it you’re doing?
response: I’m transcending the situation. I’m clearly too evolved for driving.

speaker: What does that mean?
response: Leonard, have you ever wondered why my little toes and lateral incisors are significantly smaller than the average for someone of my size?

speaker: I wonder a lot of things about you, Sheldon, but not… not that.
response: Well, those are indicators that I’m farther along the evolutionary scale than the average human.

speaker: No kidding.
response: Well, no, no, I’m not going to go so far as to say that I represent a distinct new stage in humankind, you know, a h*m* Novus, if you will, no, that’s for anthropologists to decide. But I am convinced that the reason I cannot master the plebeian task of driving is because I’m not meant to.

speaker: Yes, you are, you’re meant to learn how to drive. Please learn how to drive!
response: No, no. Leonard, I’m meant for greater things, like unraveling the mysteries of the universe, not determining when it’s safe to pass a stopped school bus on a country road.

speaker: It’s never safe.
response: Yeah, well, I know that now.

speaker: Fine. Assuming that everything you say is true, how does the biologically superior h*m* Novus get to work tomorrow morning?
response: h*m* Novus doesn’t know.

speaker: Rats don’t make toast and cut off the crust.
response: You saw nothing! (Sweeps hood around himself and vanishes through cafeteria door.)

speaker: The apartment.
response: Oh look, Saturn 3 is on.

speaker: I don’t want to watch Saturn 3. Deep Space Nine is better.
response: How is Deep Space Nine better than Saturn 3?

speaker: Compromise. Watch Babylon 5.
response: In what sense is that a compromise?

speaker: I’ll tell you what, how about we go rock-paper-scissors?
response: Ooh, I don’t think so. No, anecdotal evidence suggests that in the game of rock-paper-scissors, players familiar with each other will tie 75 to 80% of the time due to the limited number of outcomes. I suggest rock-paper-scissors- lizard-Spock.

speaker: What?
response: It’s very simple. Look, scissors cuts paper. Paper covers rock. Rock crushes lizard. Lizard poisons Spock. Spock smashes scissors. Scissors decapitates lizard. Lizard eats paper. Paper disproves Spock. Spock vaporizes rock. And as it always has, rock crushes scissors.

speaker: Noticed the eye patch, did you? It’s all part of a technique I’ve been studying for picking up women. You employ a visual display designed to make yourself distinctive and memorable.
response: Oh yes, like the male peacock with brilliant plumage or the rutting baboon with engorged hindquarters.

speaker: Well, I want to watch it now.
response: Then I believe we’ve arrived at another quintessential rock-paper-scissors- lizard-Spock moment.

speaker: I saw what you did there.
response: What did I do?

speaker: Hello. Hey, Howard. What’s wrong? Okay. Okay, we’ll be right there.
response: What happened?

speaker: Howard’s at the Mars Rover lab. He says he’s in trouble. Defcon 5.
response: Defcon 5? Well, there’s no need to rush.

speaker: What?
response: Defcon 5 means no danger. Defcon 1 is a crisis.

speaker: Yeah, Star Trek V, worse than I.
response: Okay, first of all, that’s a comparison of quality, not intensity. Secondly, Star Trek I is orders-of-magnitude worse than Star Trek V.

speaker: Are you joking? Star Trek V is the standard against which all badness is measured.
response: No, no, no. Star Trek V has specific failures in writing and direction, while Star Trek I fails across the board, art direction, costuming, music, sound editing.

speaker: I got the Mars Rover stuck in a ditch.
response: Where?

speaker: Yeah, baby, I’ll be right in.
response: You brought a girl to the Mars Rover control room?

speaker: No, there were three other guys with eye patches, iIt was a fiasco. What did work was, “How’d you like to visit a secret government facility?”
response: So what exactly do you want us to do?

speaker: I need you and Raj to help me get the Rover out of the ditch, and I need you to get Stephanie out before somebody notices she’s here. She doesn’t exactly have clearance.
response: Really? They don’t let strange women from honky-tonks come in and play with $200million government projects on distant planets?

speaker: My mother is so gonna love her.
response: Oh, how nice. Maybe they can carpool when they visit you in federal prison.

speaker: Actually, I was just checking my e-mail. But, uh, no, the Rover is not responding.
response: I believe the appropriate metaphor here involves a river of excrement and a Native American water vessel without any means of propulsion.

speaker: You could try calling Triple-A, but based on NASA’s latest timetable, they won’t get there for 35 years.
response: Plus I understand you have to be standing next to the vehicle with your card when they arrive.

speaker: Oh, snap.
response: Snap what?

speaker: Erase all the hard drives, scrap the surveillance tapes, wipe our fingerprints off every surface and run.
response: Why wasn’t that Plan A?

speaker: Psst! Psst!
response: Will you all excuse me? Leonard is subtly signalling that he’d like to talk to me in private.

speaker: Well, that does sound like me, but no.
response: Is there some problem?

speaker: Yeah. Listen, I have to kinda sneak out for a while.
response: All right, goodbye.

speaker: No, wait! If anyone asks you where I went, you don’t know.
response: Where are you going?

speaker: I can’t tell you that.
response: Who would ask me?

speaker: I can’t tell you that, either.
response: So you brought me in here to inform me that you can’t tell me where you’re going and you can’t tell me who might ask?

speaker: Yeah, I really didn’t think this through.
response: Leonard, a moment.

speaker: What?
response: If someone, and of course, we don’t know who this would be, does ask where you’ve gone, what should I say?

speaker: I don’t know. Just tell them I went to the office.
response: Are you going to the office?

speaker: No.
response: Then how can I say it convincingly?

speaker: Just say, Leonard went to the office.
