response: All right. Leonard went to (exaggerated) the office.

speaker: What is? No, not like that! Just, Leonard went to the office.
response: This would have worked out a lot better if you’d just told me you were going the office.

speaker: I’m going to the office.
response: See? Why don’t I believe you?

speaker: Okay.
response: Doesn’t anyone want to know where he’s going?

speaker: Okay, where is he going?
response: Leonard is going to (exaggerated) the office.

speaker: Rock-paper-scissors- lizard-Spock.
response: Okay, one of us is going to have to stop putting up Spock.

speaker: Oh, hey, guys.
response: Hello.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Howard is employing a schoolyard paradigm in which you are, for all intents and purposes, deceased. He intends to act on this by not speaking to you, feigning an inability to hear you when you speak and otherwise refusing to acknowledge your existence.

speaker: That’s just ridiculous. Why are you cooperating with him?
response: I don’t make the rules, Leonard.

speaker: Did someone just feel a cold breeze?
response: I believe this is an extension of the death metaphor. The cold breeze is the so-called ectoplasmic issue of a disembodied soul passing by.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Look I’m sorry, you violated the terms of your metaphor by acknowledging her existence. I’m out.

speaker: Ugh. Hey, Sheldon? Hi. This came for you today. It’s from your mom.
response: Oh, thank you, Penny.

speaker: M-hmm.
response: Yeah, wait, here. For your troubles.

speaker: Mmm, doesn’t matter. Half the time, he just ends up playing with the box.
response: Yeah, it’s journals and research papers I wrote as a child.

speaker: Aw, how cute. Is this like a diary?
response: No, that’s my potty training journal.

speaker: Really, your potty training journal?
response: Yeah. And forgive my crude penmanship. I didn’t start typing until I was six.

speaker: August 7, 8
response: There are some charts in the back where I kept track of shape, colour and consistency.

speaker: Sorry!
response: I am glad you asked. Are you familiar with the Higgs boson?

speaker: Of course, it is, it’s been in the news. And it’s a very famous boson.
response: Nice try. Now, in 1964, Dr. Peter Higgs, accomplished self-promoter and physicist, he wrote a paper postulating the existence of a subatomic particle called the Higgs boson. Now, initially the paper was rejected, but recently, he was proven right, and now he’s on the fast track to win a Nobel prize.

speaker: Yeah, that’s basically what I said.
response: Yeah, the point is Higgs is being celebrated for work he did 50 years ago, so that got me thinking, perhaps I’ve already hit upon the idea that will win me my Nobel prize.

speaker: You really think there’s some kind of scientific discovery in here?
response: Well, this box only covers my work through nursery school. There’s a good deal more to come. I didn’t really hit my academic stride until I cut out that time-suck known as playing outdoors.

speaker: So, you’re going to spend hours and hours combing through all this stuff?
response: That’s a good point. My time is much too valuable. You know, perhaps I should find someone to do it for me. You know, someone with a rudimentary understanding of science, but whose real talents lie in menial labour.

speaker: Not gonna happen.
response: Well, if I didn’t think you could handle it, I wouldn’t be asking.

speaker: Maybe I could do it.
response: You, really? You can assess the quality of my work? Okay, um, here. I wrote this when I was five years old.

speaker: A proof that algebraic topology can never have a non self-contradictory set of abelion groups. I’m just a blonde monkey to you, aren’t I?
response: You said it, not me.

speaker: No, thanks. I’m fine.
response: Now, are you sure? Everyone’s smoking them. I think they’re the best.

speaker: I don’t do drugs.
response: Excellent, yeah. That was a ruse. They’re not the best. Physics is the best. And by the way, coffee was also an unacceptable choice. All right, so I see here you’re from Des Moines, Iowa. Uh, you’re summa cum laude in theoretical physics from Stanford University. Oh, and two years ago, you had a persistent ear infection. I hope that didn’t cause any hearing loss.

speaker: No, of course not. How did you know about that?
response: I did a comprehensive background check. Medical records, credit reports, criminal history. (Hiding mouth behind book) I trust you paid off those parking tickets.

speaker: Yes, I did.
response: Hearing unimpaired, good.

speaker: Look, Dr. Cooper, I really want this position. It would be an incredible honour to work for a man of your brilliance.
response: Flattery will not get you this job, Ms. Jenson.

speaker: It’s not flattery if it’s the truth.
response: Oh, well, thank you. Welcome aboard.

speaker: Sheldon, aren’t you going to introduce us?
response: No. I have people for that now. You’re up.

speaker: It’s nice to meet you. I’m so excited to be working with Dr…
response: Yeah, please reserve chitchat for your breaks, Ms. Jenson. FYI, there will be no breaks.

speaker: Has your, uh, assistant said anything about me?
response: Oh, in fact, she has. Uh, her exact words were, what is that guy’s problem?

speaker: This should be fun.
response: Half chocolate, half vanilla, side by side, not swirled?

speaker: Yes.
response: Half a teaspoon of sprinkles?

speaker: Rainbow, not chocolate.
response: Two cherries?

speaker: One on top, one on the bottom.
response: Stems removed?

speaker: I’m so sorry, Dr. Cooper.
response: It’s all right, Alex. I’m not mad at you, I’m just disappointed.

speaker: Um…
response: Uh, Alex, a moment. I need a word with Dr. Hofstadter. Do you think it’s appropriate for her to sit with us, given her station?

speaker: Given her what?
response: If I’ve learned anything from British television shows on PBS, it’s that servants dine downstairs with their own kind.

speaker: What?
response: It’s a kindness, Leonard. Otherwise, you’re cruelly tempting them with a glimpse of a world that’s just beyond their soot-stained fingertips.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Cherry stem! Cherry stem!

speaker: Isn’t that enough? It had the w*apon fruit and a puppet. What more do you want?
response: Oh, good, Leonard, you’re here. Science news. This will interest you. And, Penny, feel free to paint your nails.

speaker: What do you got?
response: I believe Alex may have unearthed the grade school science project that could be my ticket to the Nobel Prize. Behold.

speaker: Magnets
response: The original title was “A Rederivation of Maxwell’s Equations Regarding Electromagnetism”" I dumbed it down because some of the more religious people in town were starting to say I was a witch.

speaker: She seems nice.
response: Notice people on your own time. We’re working.

speaker: What are you working on?
response: Can’t talk. In the zone.

speaker: Guys, listen up.
response: Can’t listen, zone. Also don’t care.

speaker: Next week is the anniversary of my first date with Bernadette.
response: Really don’t care.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: When did we get to the Cheesecake Factory?

speaker: Well, for starters, you’ve broken up with me so many times, which first date are we talking about?
response: Ooh, somebody call the burn ward. And back to the zone.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Zone.

speaker: Sheldon, I know you’re in the zone, but do you want some tea? All right, I can’t believe I’m gonna say this, but you haven’t spoken in hours and I’m starting to get worried. Please say something.
response: Leonard, prepare to be humbled and weep at the glory of my genius.

speaker: Nope, it was better before.
response: Look at it. I feel like my mind just made a baby. And it’s beautiful. It’s not like human babies, which are loud and covered in goop.

speaker: Holy crap, Sheldon, did you just figure out a method for synthesizing a new stable super-heavy element?
response: Did I? Well, that can’t be right. No one’s ever done that before. Except me, because I just did it. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain, yeah. Sheldon and his brain…

speaker: Fine. I will melt her heart. And her face.
response: Gentlemen. Uh, no doubt you heard about my little breakthrough. Now, if your plan is to hoist me on your shoulders and carry me around the cafeteria, please refrain. I don’t care for heights, motion sickness or the thought of your necks touching my buttocks.

speaker: Yeah, I read your paper online. That technique for creating a new heavy element is inspired.
response: Oh, well, thank you. Believe it or not, I just learned a Chinese research team at the Hubei Institute for Nuclear Physics ran a test on a cyclotron, and the results were extremely promising.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s incredible.
response: Yeah, I know. They called it the greatest thing since the Communist party. Although I’m pretty sure that the Communist party made them say that. I like China. See, they know how to keep people in line.

speaker: So, what happens next?
response: Oh, more testing, more success, more fame. Yeah, but don’t worry, I will remain the same down-to-earth humble Joe I’ve always been.

speaker: Good to know.
response: Now give me that cookie, I discovered an element.

speaker: I don’t think the Smithsonian’s gonna want your marker.
response: And that’s why you’re not on a list for my tree fort. Ooh, guess who’s getting an article written about him in Physics Today? I’ll give you a hint. You measured the diameter of his suspicious mole yesterday.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m so proud of you.
response: Well, you should be. My discovery is spreading like wildfire. Unlike my mole, which is holding steady at the size of a navy bean.

speaker: What’s next?
response: This is the very copy of The Handbook of Chemistry and Physics in which I looked up the reaction rates of mendelevium and…

speaker: And what?
response: No. No, no, no, no.

speaker: What’s wrong?
response: I’ve made a horrible mistake.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: This table, it’s in square centimetres. I read it as square metres. You know what that means?

speaker: That Americans can’t handle the metric system?
response: Amy, I was off by a factor of 10,000.

speaker: But the Chinese team found the element.
response: Yeah, well, they shouldn’t have. My calculations were wrong. There must be some resonance between the elements I didn’t know about.

speaker: So you just got lucky?
response: Sheldon Cooper does not get lucky.

speaker: You and me both, brother. It doesn’t matter. The element was found because of you, and that’s groundbreaking.
response: What matters is the greatest scientific achievement of my life is based on a blunder. I’m not a genius, I’m a fraud.

speaker: You know, Sheldon, in neuroscience, we’re forever finding something in one part of the brain that we thought was someplace else.
response: Oh, great. Now I’m worse than a fraud. I’m practically a biologist.
There’s nothing happy about it. I’m being given credit that I don’t deserve.

speaker: Oh, people get things they don’t deserve all the time. Look at me with you.
response: No, Leonard, this is going to haunt me for the rest of my life. Every science classroom, every periodic table, every textbook, this mistake will be staring back at me. Like that time you let Koothrappali wax your eyebrows. I’ve got to find a way to stop this thing.

speaker: Buddy, I don’t think you can. I mean, once it’s out there, it’s out there. This thing is like the science equivalent of a sex tape.
response: You know, frankly, I’d prefer a sex tape.

speaker: You don’t know what a sex tape is, do you?
response: No.

speaker: There he is. (General applause)
response: Stop it. Stop celebrating me.

speaker: Woo!
response: And no woos. Oh, not you, Dr. Woo. You’re fine. I want you all to know that you have no reason to applaud me. My so-called breakthrough wasn’t the result of my genius. It was nothing more than a boneheaded mistake. So please refrain from praising me for it in the future.

speaker: Wait, I don’t understand. They didn’t find the element?
response: Oh, no, they found the element. (More applause) No, no, stop it. I don’t need to take this admiration from the likes of you people. How do I make them stop loving me?

speaker: I’m getting worried about Bernadette. I’m gonna call and check on her.
response: The National Science Foundation wants to give me a substantial grant.

speaker: Oh, that’s a big deal.
response: I know. When will this nightmare end?

speaker: I’m not.
response: You’re not?

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve been thinking about it, and you’re right. You don’t deserve any credit. All you did was misread some numbers on a table. A very easy table, too. Honestly, I’m embarrassed for you.
response: That’s the most romantic thing I’ve ever heard.

speaker: Damn it, everyone’s better at this than me.
response: Congratulations, Dr. Fowler. You just made the fort.

speaker: Oh, no.
response: I hate to pile on the bad news, but I just got a raise.

speaker: Sheldon, get over here.
response: She might be contagious. Don’t you think I’m having a rough enough day?

speaker: If I didn’t have you, life would be blue, I’d be Dr. Who without the TARDIS.
response: Is it me, or does she not look so good?

speaker: Howie, that was amazing. Look, I’m shaking.
response: She’s sick, I knew it. Bye.

speaker: Me? What did I do?
response: You distract me. I’ve been distracted since the moment I met you.

speaker: Sorry.
response: Well, you should be. Because all I can think about is how much I want to kiss you. And not just on the cheek, but on the mouth. Like mommies and daddies do.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon.
response: Amy? Amy? Did you hear what I said?

speaker: Uh, that’s my water.
response: What?

speaker: My water. You’re drinking it.
response: Dear Lord! Have you been drinking it?

speaker: Yes. It’s my water.
response: Well, that’s it then. I’m dead.

speaker: Here we go.
response: I’m sorry, do I really need to connect the dots for you? The backwash into this glass is every pathogen that calls your mouth home, sweet home. Not to mention the visitors who arrive on the dancing tongue of your subtropical girlfriend.

speaker: You guys ready to order?
response: Yes, I’d like a seven-day course of penicillin, some, uh, syrup of ipecac, to induce vomiting, and a mint.

speaker: He drank from Leonard’s glass.
response: He drank from Leonard’s glass. Words they’ll be carving into my tombstone.

speaker: That’s actually my napkin.
response: Oh, this is a nightmare!

speaker: Where are you going?
response: To the bar, to sterilize my mouth with alcohol. Gang way! Dead man walking!

speaker: Right, right, whereas Jewish mothers take a casual, la-di-da approach to their sons.
response: I gargled with tequila and may have swallowed a teeny bit.

speaker: You all right?
response: Fine. Thank you for asking. I love you so much.

speaker: Oh, yeah, she’s got puddles in all the right places.
response: Could you please play the game without commenting on every card?

speaker: Sorry. Walking tree.
response: Last one.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s my water.
response: Oh, dear Lord!

speaker: I know.
response: Where’s the mouthwash?

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Haven’t seen you in a while. How’s it going?
response: Oh, other than waiting out the exponential growth period of the virulent organisms trooping through my microvilli into my circulatory system, hunky-dory. (Penny laughs) Did I say something amusing?

speaker: I don’t know, maybe, I have no idea what you said.
response: So your mirth is merely a discharge of nervous energy with no semantic content at all?

speaker: My mirth. Classic.
response: Is there a station coming up where I can board your giggling train of thought?

speaker: It’s not a big deal, Sheldon. It’s just, ever since Leonard’s been dating Raj’s sister, I’ve had to keep my distance. I don’t get to hear all your jibber-jabber.
response: Jibber-jabber? I don’t jibber-jabber.

speaker: What are you doing at work these days?
response: Oh, I’m working on time-dependent backgrounds in string theory, specifically quantum field theory in D-dimensional de Sitter space.

speaker: Alright, come on, even you have to admit that’s jibber-jabber.
response: Interesting, do you know where the phrase jibber-jabber comes from?

speaker: Sheldon, let’s go!
response: To a hospital? Full of sick people? Oh, I don’t think so.

speaker: Okay, well, your friend and his mother are there, we’re going.
response: I can’t.

speaker: Oh, don’t tell me you’re afraid of germs.
response: Not all germs. Just the ones that will k*ll me. It’s the same way I’m not afraid of all steak knives, just the ones that might be plunged in my thorax.

speaker: Right, fine. I’ll tell Howard you didn’t come because you’re more concerned about your own well-being than his.
response: I would think he would know that.

speaker: Okay, you know what? You are unbelievable. You buy all these superhero T-shirts, but when it’s time for you to step up and do the right thing, you just hide in the laundry room.
response: Fine, I’ll go. Just for the record, my Aunt Ruth died in a hospital. She went in to visit my Uncle Roger, caught something and bit the dust a week later. The two of them now share a coffee can on my mother’s mantel.

speaker: What’s the difference?
response: A heart-attack-like event is an event that’s like a heart attack.

speaker: Thanks for clearing that up.
response: Regardless, coronary problems are eminently treatable. What’s more likely going to k*ll Howard’s mother are the antibiotic-resistant super-bugs festering in every nook and cranny of this hospital.

speaker: Okay, you’re not helping.
response: Disagree.

speaker: Go sit over there.
response: I’ll sit over there, it looks cleaner.

speaker: Bernie, wait!
response: I’ll give you $1,000 if you’ll drive me home.

speaker: Hey, Raj, wanna see a new magic trick I’ve been working on?
response: Howard, if I may interject here with a piece of friendly advice. Is working on magic tricks really how you want to spend your time? Granted, you’re just an engineer, but that doesn’t mean you might not someday build a geegaw or a thingamabob that may get you a thank you in someone else’s Nobel prize acceptance speech.

speaker: Now remember your card, put it back in the deck.
response: Is it any wonder he doesn’t have a doctorate?

speaker: Yes, it is. Very cool!
response: It’s not cool. It’s a childish trick designed to confuse and intrigue simpletons. How’d you do it?

speaker: A magician never reveals his secrets. But surely a future Nobel prize winner can figure it out.
response: Fine. Give me a second.

speaker: Seven of clubs! That is amazing!
response: It’s not amazing. All magic tricks are merely a combination of manipulation and misdirection with the occasional dwarf in a box wiggling his feet.

speaker: Oh, really? So how did I do it?
response: Well, I don’t care how you did it. I have more important things to think about. Clearly, the cards are marked.

speaker: I thought you had more important things to think about.
response: I do. You just happen to have caught me on a break. Oh, let me see those cards.

speaker: Oh, big deal. Not knowing is part of the fun.
response: Not knowing is part of the fun. Was that the motto of your community college?

speaker: Oopsy.
response: This deck is rigged in some fashion.

speaker: Fine. Get another deck and I’ll do the trick with that.
response: So you’re saying this is a regulation deck?

speaker: Oh, unbelievable! Know how he did it yet?
response: Um…

speaker: Hey, I think I know how you did the card trick.
response: Oh, oh, please, if I don’t know, you don’t know. That’s axiomatic.

speaker: Is the autumn cruel for letting the flowers die, or is that just nature’s way?
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard?

speaker: What?
response: I think I figured out Wolowitz’s magic trick, and I need you to pick a card.

speaker: I am not opening that door, Sheldon.
response: As you wish. (Cards slide under door) Pick a card, put it back, and prepare to be amazed. (Leonard does not) Did you pick one?

speaker: Yep.
response: (Sliding card under door) Is this your card?

speaker: (Not looking) Nope.
response: Drat. Is this your card?

speaker: No.
response: I’ll be right back.

speaker: Whatcha doin’?
response: I’m reverse engineering Wolowitz’s magic trick.

speaker: What’s up with the infrared cameras?
response: I’m measuring residual heat levels on the playing cards to determine which one’s been touched. By the way, if you hope to have children, I suggest you switch from briefs to boxers. Your testicles look a tad warm.

speaker: Holy crap, are you connected to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory?
response: Yes. I’m using their Cray Supercomputer to analyze shuffling patterns.

speaker: Sheldon, that computer is used for National defence. Hacking into it is a Federal crime.
response: Relax, we’re not under attack right now.

speaker: Okay, I’m leaving before the black helicopters get here.
response: And is this my card? Rats! I wonder if Howard used a radioactive tracer. Where am I going to find Uranium-235 this time of night? Come on, Craigslist.

speaker: Really?
response: Oh, yes. In fact, I improved upon it.

speaker: Beefaroni and a show? How do you turn that down?
response: All right. Pick a card.

speaker: Okay.
response: Bippity-boppity-boo.

speaker: What’s with the wand and the beep?
response: The wand is called showmanship, and the beep is none of your business. Oh! Excuse me, I’m getting a text message completely unrelated to this magic trick. Oh, look, my dry cleaning’s ready. And your card was the five of spades. Ta-da.

speaker: These cards have barcodes on them. The wand is a reader. It’s transmitting to your phone.
response: I said, ta-da. Show’s over.

speaker: Bippity-boppity-boo-yah!
response: That does it. I’m getting uranium.

speaker: Hey!
response: Hello.

speaker: Why so glum, chum?
response: Apparently, you can’t hack into a government supercomputer and then try to buy uranium without the Department of Homeland Security tattling to your mother.

speaker: Oh, that’s too bad. Figure out the magic trick yet?
response: Figure out the magic trick yet?

speaker: Want me to tell you how to do it?
response: No.

speaker: I’ll show you one more time. Raj?
response: Hang on. This time do it with me, so I can make sure there’s no monkey business.

speaker: All right. (Raj looks over Sheldon’s shoulder. Holds two fingers over his heart). Two of hearts.
response: I hate you.

speaker: Yeah, he’s gonna win the Nobel prize.
response: Hey, would you like to hear some songs I've rewritten to get children interested in the hard sciences?

speaker: Yeah. Well, I like music, I like science, I like making fun of Sheldon. Hit it.
response:
♪ There was a scientist who had a theory ♪
♪ And James Clerk Maxwell was his name-o ♪
♪ J-A-M-E-S ♪
♪ C-L-E-R-K ♪
♪ Space M-A-X-W-E-L-L ♪
♪ And James Clerk Maxwell was his name-o ♪
♪ There was a scientist who had a theory ♪
♪ And James Clerk Maxwell was his name-o ♪
♪ A-M-E-S ♪

speaker: Uh, okay, okay. Uh, we, we get it.
response:
Perhaps you'd prefer this one. (clears throat)
♪ The itsy bitsy spider is not an insect at all ♪
♪ Because it has eight legs ♪
♪ And two body parts ♪

speaker: That's pretty cool, Sheldon.
response: Thank you. Do either of you know Beyoncé? I'd love her to get behind it.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Oh. When I encountered alien life, I discovered that the key thing was not to sit in its spot.
response: All right, you can't breathe our air without an inhaler, he's allergic to Earth nuts, but I'm the alien.

speaker: Anyway, I'm among a handful of scientists that have been asked to submit a design proposal for the message and its delivery system.
response: Excellent.

speaker: Are you kidding? Yes. What did you have in mind?
response: I'll tell you exactly what you should do, avoid the presumption of the Terran sensory input paradigm.

speaker: Yeah, absolutely. You need a device capable of delivering information across a wide range of perceptual modalities.
response: Any intelligent organism would at the very least need the ability to locate the position of objects in space. So the ideal interstellar lingua franca would be haptic.

speaker: (Knocks) Sheldon. (Knocks) Sheldon. (Knocks) Sheldon.
response: I bet that started off as a joke, but by the third one you realized there was something strangely enjoyable about it.

speaker: Yeah, I kind of want to do it again.
response: I don't recommend it. You'll be doing it the rest of your life. Anyway, if you're looking for Leonard, he's with Koothrappali.

speaker: Uh, no, I actually came to talk to you.
response: How nice. Here are some topics that interest me, quantum mechanics, trains, flags.

speaker: No, no. It's about my acting career.
response: Oh, sorry. That's not on the list.

speaker: Well.
response: Oh, wait. No. How about we split the difference and discuss why Austria was an archduchy and not just a regular duchy.

speaker: Okay, look, here's the thing. I like pharmaceutical sales, it's going great, but I have an audition for a movie, and if I get it, it could screw everything up.
response: Hmm. I know exactly what you should do. Unfortunately, I cannot tell you.

speaker: Well, why? (sighs)
response: I'm attempting to turn over a new leaf. Earlier today, it was pointed out to me that I tend to force my ideas on people.

speaker: You're really not gonna tell me?
response: No, that train has left the station. Now, we can play this one of two ways. You can say, "trains, tell me more," or you can just look at me like that and I'll start.

speaker: There's my big boss man.
response: So, often on the front of the locomotive is a large iron wedge for clearing objects off the tracks. Now, while commonly known as a cowcatcher, I prefer the more accurate cow exploder.

speaker: Okay. Sheldon, let me ask you a question.
response: Mmm.

speaker: If I was at a train station and one train could take me to my current job and the other train could take me to an audition for a movie, which train should I get on?
response: Are you using trains to trick me into giving you advice?

speaker: No.
response: All right, then. You should take a third train where you audition for the movie but hold off on making a career decision until you have more information.

speaker: Oh. You're right. I'm worried about something that hasn't even happened yet. Huh. You are a wise man.
response: Well, Penny, who's smarter, the wise man or the person who comes to him for advice?

speaker: Oh, I guess you're right. Maybe it is the person who asks.
response: No, it's the wise man. That's why he's called the wise man. You know how I know that? I'm the wise man.

speaker: I'm sorry. What was I thinking?
response: Uh, just out of curiosity, why didn't you ask Leonard for advice about this?

speaker: 'Cause I already know what he'll say. (whining voice) "Wah, wah, wah, you shouldn't do it."
response: Ah, it's just like he's here.

speaker: Well, thank you for peeing in my slippers.
response:
♪ It's the eye of the tiger ♪
♪ It's the ear of the bat ♪
♪ It's the whiskers of the catfish ♪
♪ And the walrus... ♪

speaker: Hang on. Not that your song isn't terrible, it is... but how do you mention bats and leave out sonar?
response:
You didn't let me finish.
♪ And also regarding the bat ♪
♪ It has sonar. ♪

speaker: Well, well, well, did you hear that, Sheldon?
response: I'm sorry. I was trying to think of what rhymes with nose of the aardvark.

speaker: We want you back on the project with us.
response: Well, well, well, did you hear that, Howard?

speaker: It wasn't, so are you in?
response: Certainly.

speaker: Great. Now that we're all on the same page, let's get together tonight and work on it.
response: "Get together tonight"? Leonard, stop trying to control everything, and give poor Raj a chance to come up with what we should do. Go ahead, Raj.

speaker: Okay, I think we should do it right now.
response: Tonight works better for me.

speaker: So, I'd like to try a technique where no one gets steamrolled. When you talk, instead of bringing up a new idea, respect what was just said by building on it.
response: Uh, building on that, we should order dinner.

speaker: Hang on. Building on what Leonard said, no one built on what I said.
response: Building on building on that, there's a new build-your-own pizza place on Colorado.

speaker: I saw the menu. They have soy cheese.
response: Bah, you didn't say building on. You're out.

speaker: Yeah, you're missing the point, Sheldon.
response: You're out, and you're out. I win. Who wants pizza?

speaker: The plaque they sent up on the Pioneer probe had a drawing of a naked man and woman on it.
response: Yeah, I never cared for that. It's advertising to predator races just how soft and squishy we are.

speaker: Squeeze yourself.
response: Oh, don't be offended. You know, of the four of us, you have the most veal-like consistency.

speaker: Oh, you mean passive-aggressive like posting pictures of you and your wife eating cosmopolitan balls that you know belong in my mouth?
response: Perhaps Howard meant passive-aggressive like asking our group to help on your project, and then only choosing Leonard.

speaker: What about when we went to Comic-Con and dressed like Jabba the Hutt? You got to be Jabba's head, and I got to be his fat slug butt.
response: We looked great.

speaker: You know what? You're right. I should have asked you.
response: Yeah, and if he does ask you, go. It's amazing.

speaker: Okay, and if we're talking about being left out of things, you guys went to Skywalker Ranch without us.
response: Oh, I recommend that, too. That was a magical experience.

speaker: Wait a minute. Sheldon spent a whole day with James Earl Jones and never told any of us.
response: I sure did. Oh, my goodness. Well, from Jabba's head to ice cream with Darth Vader, I'm having a heck of a ride. Yeah, look, clearly, good things happen when I'm in charge. Now, why don't you boys step aside, let me knock this project out?

speaker: Sheldon, you're not in charge. Raj is in charge.
response: Leonard, who's really in charge? The person in charge, or those who put him in charge?

speaker: He's right. If you think about it, we're all in charge.
response: No, the guy in charge is in ch... why is everyone so bad at these?

speaker: I, uh, huh. (groans)
response: Greetings from planet Earth. Just turn left at Alpha Centauri. You can't miss it.

speaker: She’s just so impossible, they keep quitting.
response: So, who’s watching her now?

speaker: Hey, buddy.
response: Hello.

speaker: You okay?
response: I just got called into President Siebert’s office. The university won’t let me switch my field of study to inflationary cosmology. They’re forcing me to continue with string theory.

speaker: Why?
response: He said it’s why they hired me, it’s, it’s what my grant was designated for, and that everybody has to do things they don’t want to do. He then gave an example of something he had to do, even though he didn’t want to, which was look at my stupid face.

speaker: That’s a rude thing to say, out loud.
response: It’s an outrage. Honestly, I’m tempted to leave the university.

speaker: Whatever you do, just don’t make any rash decisions.
response: I don’t know. I am really aggravated.

speaker: What you working on?
response: I’m writing an appeal to the Faculty Senate, so that I can move on from string theory.

speaker: Oh. How’s it going?
response: You tell me. Dear Esteemed Colleagues, as you may know, I have requested to change my field of study. My decision to do so is, I believe, in the best interest of science. At your convenience, I’d be happy to explain it to you in words you’ll understand.

speaker: It’s nice that you called them esteemed.
response: You’re right. I’ll take that out.

speaker: So, listen, there was something I was hoping to float past you.
response: Mm.

speaker: Now that Penny and I are engaged, I thought we might want to talk about our living arrangements.
response: Of course. She’s spent many nights here, and you’re worried about preserving the myth of her virginity before the wedding.

speaker: I’m not.
response: Good, because not only has that ship sailed, if it hit an iceberg, countless men would perish.

speaker: Actually, this is about where she and I are going to live.
response: What do you mean?

speaker: Well, well, we might want to live together.
response: Oh, yeah, well, I’ve already given this some thought, and I’m willing to let Penny live with us one day a week for a trial period. Now, obviously, not when she’s made cranky by the shedding of her uterine lining.

speaker: That’s very sweet. But we were thinking more of us maybe living together with… not you.
response: I don’t understand. How could we all live together if I’m not there?

speaker: Look, I, I know this is, this is change, and that sounds scary.
response: Where are you going to go?

speaker: I don’t know. We just started to think about this. Maybe I’ll move in with Penny, or maybe she and I’ll take this place, and you can move across the hall.
response: Move across the hall? Did you take a marijuana?

speaker: No, I did not.
response: Did you get hit on the head with a coconut?

speaker: No.
response: Well, then, I’m all out of guesses. What? Me move across the hall. Why would you even suggest such a thing?

speaker: Because I love Penny, and want to give her the life she deserves.
response: I see. You’re putting your future bride’s happiness above mine.

speaker: Well, yeah.
response: Wow.

speaker: They just don’t appreciate you.
response: Yeah, and on top of that, Leonard has the audacity to suggest that now that he and Penny are engaged, he may not want to live with me any more.

speaker: Here, I made you some Strawberry Quik.
response: I have real problems here, Amy. I can’t be mollified with a beverage designed for children. Mmm, yummy.

speaker: You know, this might work out for the best. I mean, you’re always complaining about what a terrible roommate Leonard is. Like how he turns up the thermostat when you’re not there.
response: Ugh, it’s like walking into the Amazon. And not the good Amazon with one-day shipping. The awful one with birds and snakes.

speaker: You hate the sound of all those keys on his key chain.
response: Four keys! Who does he think he is, a warden?

speaker: See? Maybe you’ll love living alone.
response: I don’t know. Perhaps.

speaker: And if it turns out you don’t, you and I could live together.
response: You and… oh, sure, and while we’re at it, why don’t we get engaged, too? Why don’t we get a little house, start a family? Enjoy our sunset years together? Do you hear yourself, woman?

speaker: Sheldon, it was just a thought.
response: No. Here’s a thought. You’re not moving in, Leonard’s not moving out, everything stays exactly the way it is. And by the way, I saw you make this Strawberry Quik with syrup, you’re supposed to use the powder.

speaker: It tastes the same.
response: No. The syrup tastes better and I don’t like it.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: What happened?

speaker: I was cooking in the back room last night and the hot plate caught on fire.
response: And you couldn’t put it out?

speaker: I was across the street at the do-it-yourself car wash, taking a shower.
response: So when will you reopen?

speaker: Um, I don’t know. I’m waiting to hear back from the insurance company.
response: So, tomorrow?

speaker: I don’t mean to be rude, Sheldon, but, uh, my life is kind of falling apart right now.
response: Your life? The university is making me do string theory and my girlfriend loves me so much she wants to live with me. And now, the place I need to go when I’m sad is damp and smells funny.

speaker: Well, sorry I let you down.
response: No. I do not accept this. Everything is changing and I hate it. It stops now. I’m helping you get back on your feet. I would like to purchase this comic book, please.

speaker: That’ll be $2.99.
response: Really? It’s soaking wet.

speaker: Fine, a dollar.
response: Can you break a twenty?

speaker: No, I only have hundreds.
response: You know what? I don’t always recognize sarcasm, but I do right now, and I don’t appreciate it. I’m sorry for your loss. But you’re not the only one whose day has been a disaster.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: You tracked my phone?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Boy, you chase one balloon for three miles.

speaker: We were worried about you.
response: Don’t be melodramatic. I’m just getting on a train and leaving forever.

speaker: Seriously? You don’t even have a change of clothes or a toothbrush.
response: My plan is to stop at malls and buy what I need. It’s called living off the land.

speaker: Okay, I know you’re upset and there’s a lot of stuff going on, but it’s nothing we can’t work out. Come on, let’s get you home.
response: No. I’ve reached my breaking point. I need to leave. Now.

speaker: And go where?
response: It doesn’t matter.

speaker: So a few things don’t go your way and your best decision is to ride the rails like a hobo?
response: I suppose it is. Except I have a credit card. And I refuse to carry my laptop at the end of a stick. And I’d sooner die than eat beans out of a can.

speaker: Come on, come home with us and tomorrow I’ll, I’ll take you to Legoland.
response: Legoland is not the solution to everything. And it’s too much of a scene since that movie came out.

speaker: Then what can I do?
response: Leonard, I am overwhelmed. Everything is changing and it’s simply too much. I need to get away and think.

speaker: He’ll be okay. You taught him well, Padawan.
response: Good Lord. Padawan’s the student, not the teacher.

speaker: Sheldon, if you really need to do this, I’m not gonna stand in your way.
response: I do.

speaker: Be safe and call us.
response: I will.

speaker: Bye, buddy. Sheldon?
response: Yes?

speaker: I’m gonna miss you.
response: Of course you are.

speaker: Oh my God, I love this chicken.
response: Oh, you know what they say, the best things in life are free.

speaker: Okay, youâ€™re right, I eat your food a lot. How about this, you can raid my fridge any time you want.
response: Oh, thatâ€™s very kind of you. Next time I have a hankering to wash down a D cell battery with a jar of old pickle juice, Iâ€™ll come a-knocking.

speaker: Well, can you make it soon. Thereâ€™s a battle royale going on over the seating charts. In one corner, Bernadetteâ€™s mom, and the other three, mine.
response: Yeah, I hate wedding receptions. I wish the bride and groom would take a cue from Bilbo Baggins, slip on the ring, disappear and everyone goes home.

speaker: Mmm, you liked Professor Guysterâ€™s wedding.
response: They had a make your own sundae bar. Ooh, that was a night to remember. Do you know, on the one trip, I just had a bowl of nuts.

speaker: Iâ€™m not telling. Iâ€™m from Asia. Iâ€™m mysterious. Deal with it.
response: Howard, are you having a make your own sundae bar?

speaker: No, uh, I donâ€™t think so.
response: Well you should. 50% of marriages end in divorce, but 100% of make your own sundae bars end in happiness.

speaker: Yeah, Iâ€™m glad.
response: Itâ€™s like looking at the universe naked. (Shivers)

speaker: Well, I was thinking about Sheldonâ€™s little joke the other night about me eating all your food.
response: Oh, that was no joke. But I understand your confusion as I am our groupâ€™s resident cut-up.

speaker: Iâ€™m sorry, you are our resident cut-up?
response: Yes.

speaker: Prove it.
response: Knock, knock.

speaker: Whoâ€™s there?
response: Interrupting physicist.

speaker: Interrupting physiâ€¦
response: MUON!

speaker: Anyway, I got a little residual cheque from my commercial and I thought, hey, how about I get the guys a little thankyou to pay them back. So, Sheldon, ta-da!
response: Ah! A vintage, mint in box, 1975 Mego Star Trek transporter with real transporter action. Hot-darn!

speaker: Yeah, it was fun, I walked in and two different guys got asthma attacks. Felt pretty good.
response: Well this calls for an expression of gratitude.

speaker: Ooh, am I about to get a rare Sheldon Cooper hug?
response: Not this time. Then they wouldnâ€™t be special. Thanks Penny.

speaker: Awesome!
response: Look, it was actually designed for my vintage Mr Spock action figure.

speaker: Ah!
response: Oh dear Lord. No!

speaker: Why, theyâ€™re just toys?
response: Theyâ€™re mint in box.

speaker: Dr Cooper. Dr Cooper?
response: Is someone there?

speaker: Down here, on your desk.
response: Spock?

speaker: I need to speak with you.
response: Fascinating. The only logical explanation is that this is a dream.

speaker: It is not the only logical explanation. For example, you could be hallucinating after being hit on the head by, say, a coconut.
response: Was I hit on the head by a coconut.

speaker: Iâ€™m not going to dignify that with a response. Now, to the matter at hand. You need to play with the transporter toy.
response: But itâ€™s mint in box.

speaker: Yes, and to open it would destroy itâ€™s value. But remember, like me, you also have a human half.
response: Well, Iâ€™m not going to dignify that with a response.

speaker: Consider this. What is the purpose of a toy?
response: To be played with.

speaker: Therefore? To not play with it would be?
response: Illogical. Oh, damn it Spock, youâ€™re right. Iâ€™ll do it.

speaker: Sheldon, wait. You have to wake up first.
response: Oh, of course. Set phasers to dumb, right? (Wakes up in bed) Goody, goody, goody. This is wrong. This is wrong. Iâ€™m so excited, but this is wrong. Iâ€™m gonna do it. Iâ€™m doing it. I did it. Oh, thatâ€™s what I always thought 1975 smelled like. One to beam down Mr Scott. Aye, aye, Mr Spock. Energise. (Spins toy). Energise. (Tries to spin toy. It sticks. Tries to get Spock out and toy falls apart.) Donâ€™t be broken. Please donâ€™t be broken. (To Spock toy) What did you make me do? Okay, okay, think. (Sees Leonardâ€™s toy) Itâ€™s only logical.

speaker: Hello again, Sheldon.
response: What is it now, tiny Spock?

speaker: I am very disappointed in you. You broke your toy and switched it with Leonardâ€™s. You should be ashamed of yourself.
response: Youâ€™re the one who told me to play with it.

speaker: If I told you to jump off the bridge of the Enterprise, would you do it?
response: No. If I got on the bridge of the Enterprise, I would never, ever leave.

speaker: Trust me, it gets old after a while. You must right your wrong, Sheldon.
response: Why? I got away with it. Leonard has his toy, and heâ€™s never going to open it, so he wonâ€™t know itâ€™s broken. And I have a toy that isnâ€™t broken. Everybodyâ€™s happy.

speaker: Well I am unhappy.
response: I thought where you come from they donâ€™t have emotions.

speaker: I come from a factory in Taiwan. Now do the right thing.
response: You know what you are? Well, youâ€™re a green blooded k*ll. Perhaps itâ€™s time you beam on out of here.

speaker: Fine. I will just use the transporter. Oh, right. You broke it.
response: Very well. Cooper to Enterprise, one to beam up. Energise. (Throws Spock away. Getâ€™s attacked by a Gorn. Wakes up.) Ah. Tiny Spock. Help.

speaker: What?
response: Nothing. I said nothing.

speaker: I dunno. I just think itâ€™s a waste. (Picks up box. Sheldon screams.) Relax. Iâ€™m just looking at the box.
response: Perhaps you should look with your eyes, and not your muscular Nebraska man-hands.

speaker: What is your problem?
response: My problem is that I donâ€™t want you to break Leonardâ€™s toy, which you probably did by shaking it. She shook it. We all saw her.

speaker: Yes.
response: Mmmmm!

speaker: What?
response: Oh, nice job, man-hands.

speaker: I didnâ€™t break it. I, I guess Stuart sold it to me like this.
response: Yes. Yes, he did, that is a perfectly satisfying and plausible explanation. Yeah, letâ€™s all be mad at Stuart.

speaker: Absolutely.
response: Wait. It was me. I opened your toy, discovered it was broken and didnâ€™t tell you.

speaker: Why would you open mine?
response: I didnâ€™t. That was a lie. I opened my own toy. And it was already broken so I switched them.

speaker: Well, you should talk to Stuart.
response: I canâ€™t because that was a lie. Yours was broken in an earthquake. And thatâ€™s a lie.

speaker: What is the truth?
response: My Mr Spock doll came to me in a dream and forced me to open it. And when the toy broke I switched it for yours. Later he encouraged me to do the right thing and I defied him. And then I was attacked by a Gorn.

speaker: Mmm.
response: Leonard, Penny, I just, I want you both to know that I regret my actions toward the two of you. Thatâ€™s a lie.

speaker: So, is that one mine.
response: Yes.

speaker: Well, hand it over so I can open it.
response: Okay. Leonard, even though I donâ€™t have one any more, I hope you have fun playing with it.

speaker: And thatâ€™s a lie, right?
response: Big fat whopper. I hope it breaks.

speaker: I can’t blame you. Tiny Twister was a complete bust.
response: No, I was wrong. The looming threat of being crushed under a pile of lumber does add a certain spice. I’ve never felt so alive. (Answers door) Oh, hello, Alex. Uh, let me go get you last night’s recordings.

speaker: What recordings?
response: Well, you remember when you told me I talk in my sleep? Well, it occurred to me that, like most things I say, it’s probably pure gold. So I started recording it all, and now Alex gets to comb through eight hours of what I like to call Sheldon After Dark.

speaker: What?
response: Jenga, I win!

speaker: I both hate you and want to be you. This is Ryan Gosling all over again.
response: Ah, gentlemen, what is on the conversational menu this morning?

speaker: Your assistant is totally hitting on this jerk and he loves it.
response: Well, that’s not acceptable. I mean, I’m her boss. She needs to be solely focused on my needs, not distracted by your pasty, androgynous brand of sexuality.

speaker: I’m androgynous?
response: Oh, please. Look at you with your pouty bee-stung lips.

speaker: What is happening?
response: I need your advice about a delicate workplace situation. Uh, to protect those involved, I’ll be changing their names.

speaker: Who’s involved?
response: Well, a short, bespectacled colleague of mine who lives in the shadow of his brilliant roommate. Let’s call this colleague Ricardo Shilly-Shally.

speaker: You’re talking about Leonard.
response: No, no, Shilly-Shally has red hair and, uh, he briefly served in the Mexican Navy. Anyway, despite the fact that he has a girlfriend, Shilly-Shally has been the recipient of inappropriate workplace flirtations from a young lady.

speaker: It’s your assistant Alex, isn’t it?
response: No. No. No. This is Tondelaya della Ventimiglia.

speaker: Wait, what the hell’s going on with Leonard and Alex?
response: No, uh, no, I’m sorry. Who’s talking about Leonard and Alex?

speaker: Fine. Ricardo and Tondelaya.
response: Okay, look, it’s not really about Ricardo and Tondelaya. It is really about her boss, who doesn’t quite know how to handle this situation and could use your advice, which is surprising because Dr. Einstein Von Brainstorm, he’s usually pretty smart about these things.

speaker: She’s right. But say the word, I got a lab full of cocaine-addicted monkeys with nothing to lose. One of them could end up in the backseat of her car. Or her shower.
response: Ladies, ladies, please. We’re not here to talk about Penny, okay? We’re here to talk about me. Uh, I mean Einstein Von Brainstorm. Oh, darn it! All right, I guess the cat’s out of the bag. Let me explain what’s going on. Ricardo is really Leonard.

speaker: We know what’s going on, Sheldon!
response: Well, what should I do?

speaker: Well, Alex is your employee. If she’s doing something that’s making Leonard uncomfortable, you should talk to her.
response: Oh, no, he’s not uncomfortable at all. No, he’s loving it. Yeah, he’s strutting around like he’s five-foot-six.

speaker: Sheldon, you need to talk to Alex right away.
response: Talk to her? That’s all you’ve got? With a cool name like Sheldon Cooper’s Council of Ladies, I really expected more. Give me back the T-shirts.

speaker: I think it’s pretty wide open. Oh, wait. Here’s something at four o’clock. Give Alex a talking to?
response: Well, that snuck up on us, didn’t it?

speaker: Is there a problem?
response: Let’s not call it a problem. Let’s call it an opportunity. To solve a serious problem.

speaker: What did I do?
response: You don’t know? Oh, you poor dear. Your ovaries are squirting so much goofy juice into your brains you don’t even know which way is up. You made an inappropriate sexual advance towards Dr. Hofstadter.

speaker: What? I didn’t make a sexual advance on anybody.
response: Now, there’s no need to get defensive. I’m not unsympathetic to your plight. My father used to say that a woman is like an egg salad sandwich on a warm Texas day.

speaker: What?
response: Full of eggs and only appealing for a short time.

speaker: This conversation is making me uncomfortable.
response: Yeah, you and me both, sister. Now, please understand, I don’t hold you responsible for your behaviour because, see, from an evolutionary standpoint, you’re a slave to your desire to reproduce. But during the work day, when you feel possessed by amorous intent, may I suggest that you suppress it by leafing through this illustrated book of sexually transmitted diseases? Let’s see here. Oh, yes. Check out this oozy doozy.

speaker: I have to go.
response: So does this fellow, but he can’t without it burning like hot soup.

speaker: I’m missing something. (Enters apartment. To Sheldon) Did you say something to Penny about Alex?
response: Oh, yes. Yeah, and a fat lot of good it did me. All she did was get mad at you.

speaker: Why would you do that?
response: I needed advice about a woman. I would have asked you, but if the last few years have proven anything, it’s that you can’t tell a uterus from a unicycle.

speaker: At least I know not to blab to a girl about somebody flirting with her boyfriend.
response: Good to know. Yeah, a few more helpful hints like that, you may find yourself on the Council of Ladies. (Answering phone) Hello. I see. Uh, what time? Very well, then. Huh. That was the Human Resources Department at the university. Apparently, my assistant Alex has filed a complaint accusing me of inappropriate behaviour in the workplace.

speaker: Oh, my God, what did you do?
response: Hmm, let me think. Nothing. I’m a delight.

speaker: Come in.
response: Hello.

speaker: Ah, Dr. Cooper, have a seat.
response: Thank you.

speaker: I called you in today because your assistant Alex Jensen has lodged a complaint against you.
response: So I’ve been told. But I can’t understand what she has to complain about. I mean, she has a front-row seat as I make scientific history. There’s string cheese in my mini-fridge, and that’s for anyone. Yeah, and just yesterday I led her away from a life of sexual promiscuity by making her look at pictures of disease-ridden genitalia.

speaker: Cancel my next appointment. This is gonna take a while. Dr. Cooper, you said things to your employee that you just cannot say in the workplace.
response: Like what?

speaker: Well, according to Ms. Jensen, you said that she was a slave to her biological urges and called her an egg salad sandwich. I don’t even know what that means, but I’m gonna go ahead and tell you you can’t say it.
response: Oh! I see the confusion here. No, no, Alex thought I was singling her out. No. I meant that all women are slaves to their biological urges, you know? Even you. You’re a slave.

speaker: I’m a what?
response: Well, y-you, I-I’m just saying, you know, at a certain point in a woman’s menstrual cycle…

speaker: Whuh-ah! Woah! You can’t talk about that, either, Dr. Cooper. Your language is entirely inappropriate, and I’m gonna advise that you shut your mouth right now.
response: I don’t see why I’m the one being persecuted here. Dr. Hofstadter, he was bragging about his sexual desirability to anyone who would listen. You know, and Howard Wolowitz, he spent two years using university resources building a six-breasted sex robot. Oh, and at the office Christmas party, I heard Rajesh Koothrappali refer to you several times as Brown Sugar.

speaker: Hofstadter… Wolowitz… and the last one was Rajesh Koothrappali?
response: Yes. No, yeah, but in his defense, that wasn’t r*cist. He’s also brown.

speaker: I’m sorry, I’m a feminist, I don’t notice things like how many breasts a robot has.
response: Well, hello.

speaker: What are you doing here?
response: Actually, I came to speak to Mrs. Davis.

speaker: And I’m a little busy right now.
response: But I came to file a complaint. Somebody has made me feel uncomfortable in the workplace by using language of an inappropriate and sexual nature.

speaker: And who was that?
response: You, you dirty birdie. I-I thought about the things you said to me yesterday, and I realized I’m deeply offended. Now, be a dear and get me one of those complaint forms.

speaker: That’s it. All of you, in my office now!
response: And thanks to you, I know better than to ask if you’re menstruating. And based on your behaviour, I don’t have to.

speaker: Thank you, Dr. Cooper.
response: Yeah, additionally, you should know that the university has mandated that I take an online sexual harassment seminar so this sort of thing doesn’t happen in the future.

speaker: Okay.
response: Yeah. Now, unfortunately, uh, my time is much too valuable to waste on nonsense like this, so, um, I’m gonna need you to take it for me. Oh, and, uh, you’d better ace it, they’re pretty mad.

speaker: You take this one. I spent an hour last night on how do vampires shave when they can’t see themselves in the mirror?
response: Well-groomed vampires meet in pairs and shave each other. Case closed.

speaker: Why’s the president of the university slumming in the cafeteria?
response: Perhaps he’s emulating Shakespeare’s Henry V, who dressed as a commoner and mingled among them, to find out how he was being perceived by his subjects. Course, if he’d have read any of the thirteen hundred e-mails I’ve sent him on the subject of his administration, he could have saved himself the trouble.

speaker: Hey, there’s my favorite geniuses! How are we doing today?
response: That depends, how much longer do you plan on fondling my shoulder?

speaker: Sorry, Dr. Cooper, I forgot you have a touch phobia.
response: It’s not a touch phobia, it’s a germ phobia. If you’d like to go put on a pair of latex gloves,

speaker: I’m in!
response: Hold on. Just because the nice man is offering you candy, doesn’t mean you should jump into his windowless van. What’s the occasion?

speaker: Just a little fund-raiser for the university.
response: Aha! The tear-stained air mattress in the back of the van.

speaker: I understand your reticence, Dr. Cooper, and I sympathize, but the hard facts are, occasionally, we have to shake a few hands and kiss a few butts to raise money for our research.
response: I don’t care, it’s demeaning. And I refuse to be trotted out and shown off like a prize hog at the Texas State Fair. Which, by the way, is something you don’t want to attend wearing a Star Trek ensign’s uniform.

speaker: So, Saturday night! It’s gonna be off the hook.
response: Ugh!

speaker: What about Sheldon?
response: Sheldon is not going.

speaker: Really? What do we tell Siebert?
response: Tell him Dr. Cooper feels that the best use of his time is to employ his rare and precious mental faculties to tear the mask off nature and stare at the face of God.

speaker: Sheldon, it’s Saturday night, you’ll be doing laundry.
response: Don’t tell him that, tell him the mask thing.

speaker: Well, normally I respect your macho rebellious attitude toward The Man, but, in this case, I think you’ve made a foolish mistake.
response: Unlikely. But make your case. Keeping in mind that your critical attitude is ruining our Saturday night together, and I’m not above minimizing your window.

speaker: Sheldon, like it or not, until you manage to upload your intelligence into a self-sustaining orbiting satellite, equipped with high-speed Internet and a cloaking device, you will be dependent on other members of the human race.
response: That’s it. Prepare to be minimized.

speaker: I’m not finished. All scientists have to fund-raise, Sheldon. How do you think I paid for my lab?
response: Your lab is funded by some Middle-Eastern dilettante?

speaker: Technically, Faisal is my fiance. But I do have a state-of-the-art two-photon microscope and a place to stay in Riyadh for the winter.
response: Well, that explains those puzzling camel race photos on your Facebook page.

speaker: And consider this, without you to make the case for the physics department, the task will fall to people like Leonard and Rajesh.
response: Are you trying to scare me? ‘Cause you’re succeeding.

speaker: Well, then prepare to be terrified. If your friends are unconvincing, this year’s donations might go to, say, the geology department.
response: Oh, dear,not, not the dirt people!

speaker: Or worse, it could go to the liberal arts.
response: No!

speaker: Millions of dollars being showered on poets, literary theorists and students of gender studies.
response: Oh, the humanities!

speaker: Oh, I don’t know, it’s one of the fun things you get to do when you have lots of money. Watch. Hey! Who said you could eat that shrimp? See? Fun.
response: No, no, no, I’m just here for your money. I don’t want to shake anyone’s germy hands. Explain it to them, Siebert.

speaker: Hello, Mrs. Latham. Yes, I live with him. I don’t, I, I really don’t know why. Tonight? Sure, that’d be great. Okay, I’ll, I’ll see you then. Bye. She wants to have dinner and talk about my research.
response: An entire dinner to talk about your research? Where you going, the drive-thru at Jack in the Box?

speaker: Well, wherever we’re going, she’s sending a car to pick me up.
response: Okay, I see what’s happening.

speaker: What?
response: My stature intimidates her, so she’s using you to get to me. Crafty old gal.

speaker: Excuse me, but you are not the only distinguished scientist in this apartment. I’ve been published in peer-reviewed journals, I received a Dissertation of the Year award for experimental particle physics.
response: No, that can’t be it. And since you seem to have forgotten, the reason we live together is we’re best friends. And I got your back, Jack.

speaker: Yes, Sheldon. Keep watching.
response: You know, it’s a shame, all that work she’s doing to get sober, only to be torn apart and eaten alive.

speaker: Swell. I need a drink. Do we have any alcohol?
response: No. But we have potatoes, I could make you vodka. It’ll take two weeks.

speaker: Well, Mrs. Latham said she was seriously considering donating money so we could get a cryogenic centrifugal pump.
response: Oh, wow!

speaker: Then she stuck her tongue down my throat.
response: Why?

speaker: I was able to get out of there before anything else happened, but she wants to see me again tomorrow night.
response: Excellent! What are you planning to wear?

speaker: What?
response: Penny, you’re an expert on trading sexual favours for material gain, walk him through this.

speaker: Well, n-no, hold on a second, I’m not going to sleep with her.
response: But we need a cryogenic centrifugal pump.

speaker: Well, forget it! It’s not gonna happen.
response: Well, come now, Leonard, this may be your only chance to make a real contribution to science!

speaker: What was all that about me trading sexual favours for material gain?
response: It was a compliment. I believe in giving credit where credit is due.

speaker: I won’t be too late. I’m just gonna make a final pitch for the funding and then say good night.
response: Hold on, I have something for you.

speaker: What’s this?
response: Just a few things you may need tonight. There’s, uh, baby oil, condoms and, uh, a little something I procured from the school of pharmacology. They say it is to Viagra as Viagra is to a green M&M.

speaker: I am not going to have sex with her.
response: Maybe this will overcome your reluctance. I went on the Internet and found a photograph of a 25-year-old Mrs. Latham to get your libido humming. Check out those saddle shoes. Rar!

speaker: Are you insane? I’m not going to prostitute myself just so we can get some new equipment.
response: Oh, come on! Why not?

speaker: Good night, Sheldon.
response: Given how much time you spend engaging in pointless self-abuse, you might consider, just this once, using your genitalia to actually accomplish something!

speaker: He still won’t shag the old lady, huh?
response: No. But thank you for asking.

speaker: Oh, please, I recognize the walk of shame when I see it. All you’re missing is a little smeared mascara and a purse with panties wadded up in it.
response: What’s going on?

speaker: Oh, nothing’s going on. Excuse me.
response: Are you just getting home?

speaker: Yeah.
response: That’s a good sign, right?

speaker: Oh, yeah.
response: I’m so proud of you! You sold yourself out like a common streetwalker!

speaker: No, I didn’t do it for the money.
response: She stiffed you?

speaker: I believe that’s what your roommate did to her.
response: What?

speaker: No, I mean, I, I, I got the money first.
response: Smart. Get paid up front. Yeah, I think you have a real knack for gigolo work, Leonard.

speaker: Uh, I’m gonna go lie down.
response: That’s a good idea, get your rest. There are a lot more rich old ladies out there, and Daddy needs a new linear accelerator. And I thought he didn’t learn anything from his relationship with you.

speaker: Hey!
response: Another compliment! Learn to recognize them.

speaker: Speaking of new careers, how are things going with dark matter, Sheldon?
response: Oh, yeah, I'd have to say it's the most exiting time in the history of the field.

speaker: Oh. What's going on?
response: I started doing it.

speaker: Wait, hang on, you guys are gonna work in a mine?
response: Why not?

speaker: You had a panic attack when we went through the car wash.
response: Perhaps the emotion you're referring to was shock at you having something cleaned.

speaker: Yeah, it'll help them get away when they see a g-g-ghost.
response: Are they making fun of us?

speaker: Yup.
response: I miss the old days when I couldn't tell.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, you busy?
response: I'm always busy. This mind is capable of advanced multitasking. You know, currently, I'm attempting to solve the Penrose conjecture, I'm composing my Nobel acceptance speech for when I've solved the Penrose conjecture, and I'm wondering how mermaids have babies.

speaker: Don't they lay eggs on a rock?
response: Now I've got room for another thing. What do you want?

speaker: So, I did a little research on what the conditions are like in the mines, and the guys might be right, sounds pretty rough down there. For starters, it's very humid, and about a hundred degrees.
response: Well, I'm from Texas and you're from India, we're no strangers to the fragrant armpit. Next.

speaker: It's also a live mine, so there'll be dynamite explosions going off in the distance.
response: Yeah, I have a lactose intolerant roommate with a taste for ice cream. Next.

speaker: Oh, you have to be down there for 12 hours at a time.
response: Yeah? We have to be somewhere.

speaker: Well, there's no toilets, we'll have to do our business in a bucket.
response: So it's settled, we're not doing it.

speaker: Look, I get it, but before we pass up on an incredible opportunity, I was thinking about when Howard was training to go to space, they put him in a simulated environment.
response: Interesting. You're suggesting that we recreate the conditions of the mine to see if we can handle it.

speaker: Exactly.
response: Very well.

speaker: So where should we do it?
response: Well, I'll just Google hot, dark and moist, see what comes up.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon…
response: Oh, there, well, look, there's all kinds of videos.

speaker: No. They forgot I was there. But it really opened up my pores.
response: Well, according to my research, the steam tunnels below this access point should be the closest analog to the mines.

speaker: This is gonna be so much more accurate than the steam room at the gym.
response: Plus, there's almost no chance we'll see any of our coworkers half naked.

speaker: Or totally naked. I love Howard, but the dude needs a little shame.
response: All right, Amy, this walkie-talkie is yours. If we run into any problems, I'll contact you. And if anything bad happens, what's the rule?

speaker: Sheldon, I'm really impressed you're willing to try this.
response: Well, admittedly, this brushes up against my well-known aversions to heat, small places, going below floor-level, dampness, hatches, ladders, darkness, echoes, and eliminating in Home Depot buckets. That last one is quite new, but I have a feeling that's gonna rocket to the top of the list.

speaker: I'm sweating already.
response: Yeah, as the person beneath you, allow me to say, I know.

speaker: How hot is it?
response: Uh, let's see. 704? No, wait, it's on clock. Uh, the real answer isn't much better. 102 degrees.

speaker: Well, that's what we wanted. This is as hot as the mines will be.
response: True. Sheldon's Mine Simulation Log, entry one. Koothrappali's restating of the obvious is already getting on my nerves.

speaker: How you feeling?
response: Good. Little claustrophobic.

speaker: Let's set up the equipment. It'll help take your mind off of it.
response: Miners often sang mining songs to keep their spirits up.

speaker: Do you know any mining songs?
response: Just the hits. (Singing) ♪ Where it's dark as a dungeon, and it's damp as the dew. ♪

speaker: That's pretty.
response: ♪ Where the dangers are double, and the pleasures are few. Where the rain never falls and the sun never shines, yes, it's dark as a dungeon way down in the mine. ♪

speaker: It's a little more bleak than I thought.
response: ♪ Well, I pray when I'm dead and the ages shall roll, that my body will blacken and turn into coal. ♪

speaker: Getting kind of grim.
response: ♪ Then I'll look from the door of my heavenly home, and pity the miner that mines my poor bones. ♪

speaker: Okay. How 'bout a little Miley Cyrus next?
response: Who's he?

speaker: So, as Hannah Montana, Miley was a world-famous pop star. But then she would take off her wig and go to school like a normal girl. Which, I don't have to tell you, at that age, is its own headache.
response: That's preposterous. How would she go unrecognized just by wearing a wig?

speaker: But you're okay with Superman concealing his identity with a pair of glasses?
response: He doesn't just put on a pair of glasses. He combs back his curlicue and affects a mild-mannered personality.

speaker: You guys doing okay down there?
response: I told you to use the walkie-talkie!

speaker: You guys doing okay down there?
response: Please keep this channel clear for emergencies. Thank you.

speaker: I'm going to the vending machine. Do you want anything?
response: This is a simulation. We have to survive on the supplies we brought.

speaker: We should have asked her to get some Funyuns.
response: You're not going to have Funyuns when we're a mile below the surface of the Earth.

speaker: What if we brought them down with us?
response: We'll take some Funyuns.

speaker: Anything else?
response: Some York Peppermint Patties, a couple of Dr. Peppers, and run to Best Buy and see if they have a portable DVD player and season one of a show called Hannah Montana.

speaker: Oh, this heat is brutal.
response: As someone from the tropical subcontinent of India, you should know that fanning yourself in a humid environment only raises your body temperature.

speaker: Huh. That does explain why the servants used to look so hot while they were fanning me. Let's get our minds off how uncomfortable we are. We could take some more simulated instrument readings.
response: My major focus at the moment is keeping my claustrophobia at bay.

speaker: How's that going?
response: You tell me. I feel like I can't breathe, and I am tempted to crack you open and suck the air right out of your lungs.

speaker: Sheldon, if this is too much, we can stop.
response: We're not stopping.

speaker: You don't have to bite my head off.
response: I apologize. I just, I'm plagued by an internal struggle.

speaker: If you would just use the bucket, you'd be so much more comfortable.
response: My struggle is emotional.

speaker: Oh. Is it Amy?
response: It's dark matter. When I entered the field of string theory, I was a prodigy. I rose to a position of respect, and I assumed my career would continue on that upward trajectory. Now here I am in my 30s, I'm back at square one. And, frankly, it's frightening.

speaker: Sheldon, you know what I think of when I'm scared? Voyager.
response: Voyager the space probe or Voyager the Star Trek TV show?

speaker: The space probe.
response: Good. Because I am too hot and tired to go on about how much I hate Voyager the TV show.

speaker: Sheldon, is everything okay?
response: It's too late for Koothrappali. Let's go.

speaker: Do you really need me to transcribe this?
response: You're not doing it for me. You're doing it for future generations who will benefit from my struggle. (Voice on recorder) Sheldon's Mine Simulation Log, entry four. My Kit Kat has melted. All is lost.

speaker: You call yourself a friend? I was trying to help you, and at the first sign of trouble you ran away, leaving me to fend off a family of rats. You're a completely selfish human being and a, and a physical and a moral coward.
response: His statements of the obvious continue to annoy.

speaker: But what about the creek bed?
response: The Pharmacology Department controls that, and they’re all hopped up on experimental steroids.

speaker: Well, that’s it then, we’re doomed.
response: I think the time has come to acknowledge that we are paying the price for some of us failing to attend my Physics Department paintball strategy meeting.

speaker: I told you my mom has spider veins, I had to take her to the laser clinic.
response: And I told you I wanted to see a doctor’s note.

speaker: No, that shouldn’t be a problem, Venus is up during the day. They’re probably just all staring at the sky.
response: All right, what we need now is a tactical retreat. Did you see the episode of Stargate where they found themselves on a planet with a culture based loosely on Earth’s Athens and Sparta? Not important. Leonard, Raj and I are going to burst out the door and run away, Howard will cover us.

speaker: Why don’t I run away and you cover me?
response: Because you chose your mother’s veins over victory. On three. One, two, three, go!

speaker: Yeah, more cutbacks.
response: Unacceptable. It baffles me why they don’t simply let some of you go so that there’s money available for my research.

speaker: You know what baffles me, Sheldon?
response: Based on your academic record, any number of things, I would imagine.

speaker: Yeah, okay, but what’s with the back-scratching and the meow!
response: I believe the back-scratching metaphor generally describes a quid pro quo situation where one party provides goods or services to the second party in compensation for a similar action.

speaker: Thank you.
response: The mrow, that sounded to me like an African civet cat.

speaker: Are you done?
response: No. Despite what the name suggests, the civet cat is not a true cat. Now I’m done.

speaker: In the paintball shed! Twice!
response: Is that why you didn’t cover our escape and let us get cut down like animals?

speaker: Oh, yeah, sorry about that.
response: My good man, dereliction of duty in the face of the enemy is a court-martial offense.

speaker: How can I calm down? I’m gonna lose my whole shopping cart. That’s three hours of picking out shoes just sh*t to hell.
response: Hello, Penny.

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: You’re in my spot.

speaker: Are you planning on sitting here?
response: No, I’m going to the comic book store.

speaker: Then what difference does it make?
response: What difference does it make?

speaker: Here we go.
response: That is my spot. In an ever-changing world, it is a single point of consistency. If my life were expressed as a function on a four-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system, that spot at the moment I first sat on it would be zero-zero-zero-zero.

speaker: Fine. (Moves) Happy?
response: I’m not unhappy.

speaker: Sheldon! How was the comic book store?
response: Fine. The new issue of Flash is out.

speaker: Great, great. Did you walk the whole way? It’s a little chilly.
response: Koothrappali picked me up.

speaker: Isn’t that terrific? He is such a good friend. You know what the best thing about friends is?
response: They don’t talk incessantly for no particular reason.

speaker: Don’t you dare, missy.
response: Hello, fastest man alive. Want to see me read your entire comic book? Want to see it again? Something’s wrong.

speaker: What do you mean?
response: I’m not sure. It doesn’t feel right.

speaker: Why don’t you just eat in your desk chair?
response: Why don’t I just eat in my desk chair?

speaker: Here we go.
response: That is my desk chair, that is where I work. I don’t eat in my desk chair and I don’t work in my spot. I work in my desk chair and eat in my spot.

speaker: You know, there’s kind of an obvious solution here. (To Raj) Get up. (Raj does. Howard moves his cushion across to Sheldon’s spot) There. Problem solved. (Raj whispers to him) Nobody cares where you’re going to sit. You’re not crazy.
response: Excuse me, but the problem is not solved. If your head had been accidentally amputated, and we transplanted a dog’s head in its place, would that be “problem solved”?

speaker: Sheldon, I am really, really sorry, but it’s only for a week. Can’t you be a little bit flexible? Yeah, sorry. I didn’t really think that through.
response: You claim it’s going to be a week, but I have no faith in your dry cleaner.

speaker: Why not?
response: Did you notice the sign on his counter? He’s not a full-time dry cleaner. He also makes keys.

speaker: Oh, for God’s sake, Sheldon.
response: Focus is important. Was Michael DeBakey a wedding planner in between heart transplants? Did Alexander Fleming moonlight as a hairdresser? “Thanks for discovering penicillin, now how about we try a bouffant?”

speaker: Why are you crouching there?
response: This is my spot. Where else am I supposed to crouch?

speaker: Really? Great. Sheldon, look. Good as new.
response: From that key maker, I highly doubt it.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. Just give it a try.
response: All right.

speaker: There, nice and comfy cosy. Zero, zero, zero.
response: There’s one more zero. You forgot the time parameter.

speaker: Sit on the damn couch.
response: Nope.

speaker: Penny, Penny, I think I know what to do. Sheldon, I have some bad news.
response: More?

speaker: I’m afraid so. You know the cashew chicken I get you Monday nights?
response: Yes. From Szechuan Palace.

speaker: Szechuan Palace closed two years ago.
response: What? Wh-Where did my cashew chicken come from?

speaker: Golden Dragon.
response: No. No, this isn’t right. Our food always comes in Szechuan Palace containers.

speaker: Yeah, well, before they went out of business, I bought 4,000 containers. I keep them in the trunk of my car.
response: But. Oh, this changes everything.

speaker: I thought that might take his mind off the cushion.
response: What’s real? What isn’t? How can I know?

speaker: Oh, God, I wish I had.
response: Leonard?

speaker: Yeah, buddy?
response: I still don’t like this cushion.

speaker: Okay. Now, we all run out. Sheldon and I will cut to the left behind these trees. Raj, Howard and Leslie flank to the right behind the rocks. Then we’ll all have a great view as Penny runs out and k*ll everyone else in sight.
response: Right, just one thing before we start.

speaker: What the hell?
response: That was for my cushion.

speaker: Sheldon, Penny was our only hope.
response: I’m sorry, Leonard. But revenge is a dish best served cold.

speaker: Screw that. (sh**t Sheldon)
response: She can’t sh**t me. She’s dead.

speaker: He’s right. You can’t. (sh**t Sheldon)
response: Well, if we’re going to descend into anarchy (sh**t Leonard)

speaker: Surrender, then Denny’s.
response: Hello. I'm Doctor Sheldon Cooper, and welcome to Sheldon Cooper presents Fun with Flags, the final episode flagtacular. (gasps) I knew it was coming. Still scary. Now, I'm sure you're thinking, the final episode? Who will stand between us and flag ignorance?

speaker: I know I was thinking that. Is this a show on flags or mind reading?
response: But the truth is I can no longer balance a full-time career, a popular Internet show, and a girlfriend.

speaker: And he really does have one, you jerks on the comment board.
response: So as they say, all good things must come to an end.

speaker: After only 232 episodes.
response: 233 if we include the one somebody forgot to press record on.

speaker: You said you weren't gonna bring that up.
response: And you said you pressed record. Anyway, please sit back, relax, and join us as we take our final lap, as indicated by the waving of this racing flag. And, of course, white flags can also represent surrender, the Stewards of Gondor, and the Japanese Minamoto clan, but I'm sure you remember that from episode sixty-two, White Flags, Who's Wavin' ‘Em and Why?

speaker: That was a good one.
response: It was so good.

speaker: Oh. We were just talking about how much we love working with you. Isn't that right? Dan?
response: Over the years here at Fun With Flags, we've had an opportunity to learn, laugh, wonder.

speaker: And, yes, even shed a tear or two.
response: Like when you do a two-hour Fourth of July spectacular and it doesn't get recorded.

speaker: How many times do I have to say I'm sorry?
response: How about four thousand. One for every domino I set up to make that American flag. Please enjoy these highlights.

speaker: Australia, mate.
response: And now it's time for the speed round of Flag or Not a Flag.

speaker: Say, Betsy Ross, what you working on?
response: I have no idea. Because the story of me sewing the first American flag is unsupported poppycock.

speaker: Then who did sew it, hmm?
response: Don't ask me. I'm just a simple seamstress whose descendants are out to make a quick buck.

speaker: I do.
response: Wait, that purple flag indicates that marine pests, such as jellyfish, are present.

speaker: Wow, that flag is a lifesaver.
response: No. This is. Stop looking at my legs.

speaker: Action.
response: Welcome back. Our guest today is a returning fan favourite. He puts the reading in your rainbow, the Geordi in your La Forge, and the Kunta in your Kinte, Mr. LeVar Burton.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon. Now, remember our deal.
response: You do this, I delete your contact information.

speaker: While?
response: While you watch me do it.

speaker: Great. Happy to be back.
response: Well, since you're here, I'd like to get your opinion on something. In honour of Black History Month, I portrayed George Washington Carver in a loving tribute that my roommate called wildly r*cist. What do you think? (On recording) Hi. My name is George.

speaker: Oh, hell, no.
response: You heard him, Leonard. No, it's not r*cist.
