speaker: Even though your dress is ugly.
response: Well, my little flag-keteers, it looks like the last episode of Fun with Flags is at an end. If I could, I would run each and every one of you viewers up a flagpole and salute you. And if you touched the ground, burn you. I'd like to take a moment to personally thank Dr. Amy Farrah Fowler, who you may or may not know is the first woman to co-host a flag or banner-related Internet info-tainment show.

speaker: Take that, glass ceiling.
response: And if I may get serious for a moment, hosting this show has been one crazy ride. But with all its ups and downs, I wouldn't give it up for the world. Except for now, when I'm giving it up. Before I sign off, I'd, uh, I'd like to share with you all one last use for a white flag. It's good for times like this. Good night.

speaker: Cut. Sheldon, that was beautiful.
response: If you didn't press record…

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: How come you're up so late?
response: I posted the last episode of Fun with Flags hours ago, and not a single person cared enough to comment. All that effort for nothing.

speaker: Mm. I know how you feel. I spent the day throwing out a man's entire career, and all that's left is an old bottle of champagne and a naked lady pen that Raj took when he thought no one was looking.
response: It's not the same thing. I don't think you know how I feel at all.

speaker: Sad?
response: Hmm. You do get me. Someone left a comment.

speaker: Yeah. What did they say?
response: Too bad your show is done. I kind of liked it. Leonard, did you hear that? Oh, the people are heartbroken. I can't take this away from the world. Fun with Flags is back.

speaker: Congratulations.
response: Let's celebrate.

speaker: Sheldon, that wasn't for you.
response: Oh, no, I'm not going to drink it. I just wanted to hear the pop. Yeah, I knew it was coming. Still scary.

speaker: Ugh. What are you doing here?
response: You told me not to call, and I didn't know how else to give you the good news. Fun with Flags is back, and you can be in the next episode.

speaker: Wil Wheaton said, get a gate. I don't know why I didn't get a gate.
response: You, at least listen to the premise. Since you were born in Germany, I thought we could talk about German flags. How do you feel about dressing up like a swastika?

speaker: Judge’s ruling?
response: Bilurrrbe.

speaker: Hey, guys, I need to use your TV.
response: What’s wrong with your TV?

speaker: You sound just like the cable company. All right, so, shh, Tyra Banks is about to kick someone off America’s Next Top Model.
response: Excuse me, Penny, but we’re…

speaker: No, no, don’t tell her.
response: …playing Klingon Boggle.

speaker: What do you mean, aw? Like she didn’t know we were nerds?
response: All right, if you must watch, then mute it with closed captions, please.

speaker: Fine.
response: All right, Boggle warriors, kapla’!

speaker: They’re gorgeous.
response: Oh! Worf, nice! Too bad that’s a proper noun.

speaker: Yeah, and they can all move in with you and your mother, the current Mrs. Wolowitz.
response: Is qochbe’ spelled with a (gargling) or a (guttural grunt)?

speaker: Yes.
response: Seems unlikely. Did you bring your asthma inhaler?

speaker: Uh, uh, uh, yes, I did.
response: Well, then, I guess it’s plausible. Hang on a second, mister.

speaker: What?
response: After you used the facilities at the gas station, did you make a purchase?

speaker: What?
response: It’s customary, when using the rest room at a retail establishment, to make a small purchase. Did you?

speaker: No.
response: Here’s two dollars. Go buy some beef jerky.

speaker: I don’t want beef jerky.
response: It’s not about you. It’s about a poor immigrant from Pakistan trying to make his way in America by working the graveyard shift at the Colorado Boulevard Chevron.

speaker: Fine.
response: Needy Baby, Greedy Baby indeed.

speaker: Why?
response: We were next to a car with an ask me about my grandchildren bumper sticker, and I was afraid if we ran into them on the way out, I’d be obligated to do so.

speaker: Me, too. Out of deference to them, let’s not flaunt our happy relationship.
response: You have a keen insight into the human heart, Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: We are next to a Suburu with a Gore/Lieberman bumper sticker.
response: Well, I doubt they’d want to talk about that, so we’re fine.

speaker: Is the point that you don’t know when to let something go?
response: People, people, please, before you say something you both regret, I’d like to place my order.

speaker: Oh, that is not true.
response: I’ve got to go with Leonard on this. He is wrong more than anyone I know.

speaker: Well…
response: Leonard, promise me that when our new waitress comes over, you will not start a complicated on-again, off-again relationship with her, because I am very, very hungry.

speaker: What? Yeah.
response: This is a disaster. I distinctly ordered the Leonard Nimoy Mr. Spock cardboard standee. Why would I feel safer with Zachary Quinto at the foot of my bed?

speaker: I don’t know, he was pretty badass on Heroes.
response: You’re right, I’ll give him a sh*t.

speaker: Yes, and I think we should go anyway.
response: No, can’t do it. Sorry, Quinto, you’re going back.

speaker: Okay, we're headed out, see you later.
response: Before you leave, could you test these noise-cancelling headphones?

speaker: Yeah, sure.
response: Okay. Go ahead.

speaker: Ooh, and one time when you were asleep, Amy totally took off her... and that's why you're the best roommate ever.
response: Aw, now I'm sad I didn't hear it.

speaker: So what do you need the headphones for?
response: Well, I've been struggling for months to come up with a theory of dark matter that doesn't make protons decay. I'm hoping to finally tackle it by optimising my work environment. See, I've got, uh, my tea is at the perfect sipping temperature. Uh, I have fleece-lined boxer shorts to keep my tushie toasty. And then, oh, last but not least, this inspirational cat poster improved with the reassuring face of physics renegade Richard Feynman.

speaker: Yeah, have fun.
response: Oh, I will, nothing more fun than a paradigm-shifting evening of science.

speaker: Bye.
response: Okay. Here we go. Proton decay. Proton decay. (Time shift) Proton decay. Proton decay. (Time shift) Proton decay. Proton decay.

speaker: Hey, we're home. Any progress?
response: How could there be, with these constant interruptions?

speaker: What are you doing? It's time to go.
response: I'm not going to work today. And would you like to know why?

speaker: Ah, you're upset because you spent the whole night working on dark matter and didn't make a breakthrough, and now you're worried you made a huge mistake switching fields, and you're gonna sit around and sulk all day?
response: Like a big old baby.

speaker: Call me if you need anything.
response: I've been cooped up in here too long. Maybe I need some fresh air. (inhales, exhales)

speaker: Ugh! Ugh! Ugh! Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh, what?
response: You sounded in distress. I was worried something unpleasant was happening to you. Like a m*rder. Or spontaneous coitus with Leonard.

speaker: Oh, I'm just doing this awful workout. I hate it.
response: Well, if you hate it, then why are you doing it? Although I could ask the same question about coitus with Leonard.

speaker: I don't know, I guess I like that I hate it. It makes me work harder.
response: And to clarify?

speaker: The exercise, Sheldon. Shouldn't you be getting ready for work?
response: I'm not going. Would you like to know why?

speaker: Uh, you're sad about not getting anything done last night, so you're gonna sit around and pout about it?
response: Boy, I'm not nearly as mysterious as I think I am.

speaker: Ooh, Emily. I heard him say that to Emily. Hey, I thought you were staying home.
response: Yeah, I was, but after talking to Penny, I realised something. I, first, she's trying much harder to stay attractive in this relationship than you are. And second, the reason I may not be progressing in my research is I've created too pleasant of an environment for myself.

speaker: What do you mean?
response: According to a classic psychological experiment by Yerkes and Dodson, in order to maximize performance, one must create a state of productive anxiety. So I'd like to ask you all to do something for me. Keep me on my toes. (stammers) Just throw me off my game. Essentially, go out of your way to make my life miserable.

speaker: Hold on. What's in it for us?
response: Well, I suppose...

speaker: Okay, we'll do it.
response: Done.

speaker: 33 seconds. Okay, that'll be our baseline.
response: You know, I don't want to tell you how to do your job, but when a mouse completes a maze, it gets a food pellet.

speaker: It also gets its brain plucked out with tweezers.
response: And his last meal was a food pellet? You're a monster.

speaker: All right, next, we're gonna introduce an anxiety-inducing stimulus, measure your stress levels and see how it affects your problem-solving rate.
response: Very well. And good luck, I'm a pretty laid-back guy.

speaker: Ready? Begin. (squeezes balloon) Why'd you pop it?
response: I'm sorry, I was aiming for your heart.

speaker: Look, I know you don't like it, but that's the point of the experiment. I need to irritate you to find your optimal anxiety zone. And you said no to tickling, polka music or watching me eat a banana.
response: Who eats them horizontally?

speaker: My mother said that's how good girls do it.
response: Perhaps this was a waste of time.

speaker: Sheldon, you're a remarkable scientist. Just be patient, I'm sure you'll find the breakthrough you've been looking for.
response: Thank you.

speaker: And if you only do solid research instead of making a groundbreaking discovery, what does it matter?
response: "Only do solid research"? I come to you for help, and you insult me? I thought the least that you would do would be...

speaker: Look, your anxiety levels are right in the zone.
response: Really? Oh, that's fantastic. Now, wait, they're dropping. Why are they dropping?

speaker: Because you're happy they're elevated.
response: Oh, that is infuriating. Ooh, look, they went back up again. Terrific. Oh, no, they went back down.

speaker: That is a tough one. Uh, I know he brushes both of them.
response: Gentlemen, I have figured out the perfect way for you to irritate me. I'd like you to be my intellectual sparring partners. From now on, when I make an assertion, I need you to challenge it.

speaker: So you just want us to disagree with whatever you say?
response: Yes.

speaker: And you think that's going to help?
response: Yes.

speaker: Well, I don't think that's gonna help at all.
response: Oh, no, it will. See, by keeping my mind engaged, I'll become more focused.

speaker: Howard's right, that'll never work.
response: Stop fighting me on the premise. It's scientifically valid. I'm going to advance propositions, I just want you to challenge me.

speaker: I don't think that's what you want at all.
response: Why, of course it's what I want. Why would I say it's what I want if it's not what I want?

speaker: Because it is what you want, and it's not what you said.
response: I ask you for one simple thing, and you can't even do it.

speaker: Yes, we can.
response: Yeah, well, then do it.

speaker: Nah.
response: You guys are the worst. Thank you, I think that was helpful.

speaker: Really? Want to go to Hawaii?
response: (knocking on door) Ladies? (Knocks) Ladies? (Knocks) Ladies?

speaker: Come in.
response: Ladies.

speaker: What's up?
response: Well, as you may know, I've been experimenting with elevated anxiety levels, and I thought, what better way to increase my discomfort than to subject myself to an evening of tasteless uncensored crotch talk?

speaker: What exactly do you think goes on here?
response: Well, conversations that you wouldn't be comfortable having in front of the opposite sex. You know, who has the best cervix. Which sanitary napkin is all the rage right now. Men's buttocks, and how you want to pat and squeeze them.

speaker: We were talking about Penny's job.
response: And how difficult it is to do when she's bloated, cranky and crampy? Continue.

speaker: Sheldon, we are just people. We talk about the same things you guys talk about.
response: You talk about if werewolves can swim? See, Leonard says yes, but I say it depends on if the human could swim before he was bitten. What do you think?

speaker: Well, they're not a hundred percent wolf. They're a werewolf, that's only part wolf. It's like comparing apples to oranges.
response: Thank you. Oh, and technically, it's apples that turn into were-oranges when the moon is full. Hey, this is fun. We should do it sometime when you aren't all PMS'ing. Bye.

speaker: What is going on?
response: Oh. Uh, I need to keep my anxiety at the right level, so I'm using Darth Vader, the Joker, and Godzilla's roar to keep me in that sweet spot. Uh, I tried including Taylor Swift in the mix, but turns out I love her.

speaker: Well, at least listen to it through headphones. I'm trying to sleep. Good night.
response: Boy, Taylor was right, haters gonna hate, hate, hate, hate, hate.

speaker: You've been working so much lately, I'm glad you didn't forget about date night.
response: Of course.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Yeah.

speaker: Maybe you want to put the notebook away and talk to me.
response: (stammers) I can do both. My brain is working at optimal capacity. I can have a conversation with you and solve the dark matter proton decay problem at the same time.

speaker: Fine. How was your day?
response: Oh, you said it.

speaker: Sheldon. Sheldon, I'm worried about you. You're not eating, you haven't slept in days, and, to be honest, that cap is starting to smell.
response: I know. It's replaced Godzilla as my principle source of anxiety.

speaker: You didn't have to scoop vomit out of your glove compartment.
response: He is getting a lot of work done. He had a pretty interesting take on proton decay.

speaker: Sheldon, I want you to take that cap off.
response: That nagging tone is helping my anxiety, yeah. But if you could maybe just go ten percent less shrill, that'd really put the zip-a-dee in my doo-dah.

speaker: I'm sorry, but you know we agreed not to bring work to date night.
response: There you go, perfect.

speaker: Sheldon, stop it, I'm not kidding. Take the cap off, and put the notebook away.
response: But after months of struggling, I'm finally making progress.

speaker: You don't need to drive yourself crazy in order to be productive.
response: Or do I, hmm? Sir Isaac Newton wrote his Principia while convinced he was an armadillo.

speaker: That's not true.
response: Yeah, well, maybe it is, maybe it isn't. I have been hallucinating lately.

speaker: Sheldon, this has to stop. You need to get some sleep and take care of yourself.
response: Amy, I have gotten more done in the last few days than I have since I made the switch to dark matter. What if I stop doing this, and it all goes away?

speaker: Your thoughts and ideas come from you, not from your anxiety.
response: Hmm, perhaps. But I'm not taking the cap off.

speaker: It's one thing to make yourself miserable, but you're making everyone around you miserable, too. Now, I'm telling you for the last time, take the cap off.
response: Oh, really? What if I don't? And before you answer that, can I have my dessert?

speaker: Yeah, well, women, what are you gonna do?
response: I knew you'd understand, Armadillo Isaac Newton.

speaker: Here we are.
response: Hey. What are you trying to pull? The president of science isn't in here.

speaker: You lie down, he'll be here in a minute.
response: Okay. Hey, I thought you were trying to trick me.

speaker: Now, you just get comfortable.
response: No, no, comfort is the enemy. You know what's comfortable? Slippers and blankets and panda bears. Imagine a panda bear with Richard Feynman's face on it. Warm up the car, Leonard, it's poster time.

speaker: Yeah, you get some sleep.
response: No, I don't want to go to sleep, you can't make me.

speaker: You're right, we can't.
response: Yeah, darn straight, you can't. Try to tell a grown man to go to sleep.

speaker: ♪ Little ball of fur... ♪
response: That's not gonna work.

speaker: You look like you got some rest.
response: Oh, I'm feeling much better. And I've also been continuing to make progress without artificially raising my anxiety levels.

speaker: Yeah, no problem.
response: Of course not.

speaker: Whatcha doing?
response: I’m attempting to view my work as a fleeting peripheral image so as to engage the superior colliculus of my brain.

speaker: Interesting. I usually just have coffee. You’ve been up all night?
response: Is it morning?

speaker: Yes.
response: Then I’ve been up all night.

speaker: And you’re stuck?
response: Why else would a person try to engage their superior colliculus?

speaker: Mmm, he’s either isolating the terms of his formula and examining them individually, or looking for the alligator that swallowed his hand after Peter Pan cut it off.
response: Captain Hook’s hand was eaten by a crocodile, not an alligator. If you’re going to mock me, at least get your facts straight.

speaker: Aye, aye, Captain.
response: I can’t see it! It just won’t coalesce.

speaker: Maybe you need a fresh start.
response: You’re right. (Takes whiteboard to window and throws it out. Picks up a new one) It’s a great idea, Leonard. Thank you.

speaker: Intellectually about 30 hours. Emotionally about 29 years.
response: Unit cell contains two carbon atoms. Interior angle of a hexagon is 120 degrees.

speaker: No, it’s okay. I don’t have to go. I’m happy just to guide you and your ladies to suitable entertainment choices. I’m a walking brown Yelp.com.
response: Structure, constant structure. One atom…

speaker: I thought I smelled popcorn.
response: Pattern is the same as fermions, travels on the pathways, hexagonal, it’s always hexagonal…

speaker: Hey, those are my lima beans!
response: Not lima beans, carbon atoms.

speaker: Here, you want my peas?
response: Peas! Perfect, they can be electrons.

speaker: Want my corn?
response: Don’t be ridiculous. What would I do with corn?

speaker: Okay, just to be clear, roller skating was my idea, and I’m very unhappy that you turned it into a double date, and I hope you both fall on your asses and break your coccyxes.
response: The plural of coccyx is coccyges.

speaker: Oh, my God! Are you… (falls as well)
response: Good Lord! You’re ruining everything!

speaker: Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
response: The same thing I’ve been doing for three days. Trying to figure out why electrons behave as if they have no mass when travelling through a graphene sheet.

speaker: With marbles?
response: Well, I needed something bigger than peas, now, didn’t I?

speaker: Sheldon, when was the last time you got any sleep?
response: I don’t know, two, three days. Not important. I don’t need sleep, I need answers. I need to determine where in this swamp of unbalanced formulas squatteth the toad of truth.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon. What happens to our neuroreceptors when we don’t get enough REM sleep?
response: They lose their sensitivity to serotonin and norepinephrine.

speaker: Which leads to…?
response: Impaired cognitive function.

speaker: Right, so march in there, brush your teeth and go to bed.
response: But I don’t want to go to bed.

speaker: I’m going to count to three. One…
response: Oh, all right.

speaker: Yeah, well, he’s extra special. Hey, Shelly. What you doing?
response: Size ratio was all wrong. Couldn’t visualize it. Needed bigger carbon atoms.

speaker: Sure, sure. How did you get into this place?
response: Back door has a five-pin tumbler system, single-circuit alarm. Child’s play. You can start sorting protons and neutrons while I build carbon atoms.

speaker: No, I don’t think so. We need to go home now.
response: But I’m still working.

speaker: If you don’t come out of there, I’m going to have to drag you out.
response: You can try, but you’ll never catch me. (He disappears under the balls)

speaker: For God’s sakes. Sheldon, come here!
response: Bazinga. (Disappears, pops up in another place) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga. (And again) Bazinga.

speaker: What! What, what, what?
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard and Penny.

speaker: What?
response: I have good news.

speaker: And you had to barge in here and wake us up in the middle of the night?
response: Your cell phone was off.

speaker: Because we didn’t want to be disturbed.
response: And that didn’t work out, did it?

speaker: Sheldon, what do you want?
response: I came to tell you I’ve got the answer.

speaker: Really? You figured out the graphene problem?
response: No, no, I’m still hopelessly stuck on that, but I figured out how to figure it out.

speaker: Oh.
response: Einstein.

speaker: Yeah, I’m going to need a little more.
response: Albert Einstein.

speaker: Keep going.
response: When Albert Einstein came up with special relativity, he was working at the patent office.

speaker: So, you’re going to go work at the patent office?
response: Don’t be absurd. That’s in Washington. You know I could never live in a city whose streets are laid out in a wheel-and-spoke pattern. No. I’m going to find a similarly menial job where my basal ganglia are occupied with a routine task, freeing my prefrontal cortex to work quietly in the background on my problem.

speaker: Sounds like a great plan.
response: Of course it is. Even talking to you is sufficiently menial that I can feel the proverbial juices starting to flow.

speaker: Okay, well, thanks for sharing with us. Good night.
response: You’re welcome. Good night to you, too. Oh, by the way, I was watching you sleep for a moment, and I noticed that your snoring seems to be worse when you’re on your back.

speaker: Leonard doesn’t snore.
response: No, I wasn’t talking to Leonard.

speaker: So, Mr. Cooper, you’re looking for a job.
response: A menial job. Like yours.

speaker: Why, thank you for noticing. I’m Menial Employee of the Month. Do you have a particular field in mind?
response: I do. For thousands of years, the lowest classes of the human race have spent their lives labouring to erect monuments under the lash of their betters, until finally they dropped down and became one with the dust through which they trudged. Do you have anything like that?

speaker: No.
response: Shouldn’t you check your database?

speaker: No.
response: You didn’t really type.

speaker: I didn’t really have to. So, how about construction?
response: Oh, that would be good! Sawing, hammering, eating out of a lunch pail as my working-class fellows and I sit perched precariously on a girder high above the metropolis.

speaker: No, no. This is putting up sheetrock at a housing project in Rosemead.
response: I could do that.

speaker: Good.
response: One question.

speaker: Yes?
response: What’s sheetrock?

speaker: Moving on. How about doing deliveries for a florist?
response: That seems acceptable.

speaker: Do you have your own car?
response: I don’t drive.

speaker: Of course you don’t. Mr. Cooper, let me just ask you a question. What was your last job?
response: Senior theoretical particle physicist at CalTech, focusing on M theory, or, in layman’s terms, string theory.

speaker: Okay, I’ll get those drinks started for you.
response: Behind you.

speaker: Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?
response: I’m trying to get these tables cleared. We’re slammed.

speaker: No, wait, wait, no, wait. Wh.. what are you doing here?
response: A reasonable question. I asked myself, what is the most mind-numbing, pedestrian job conceivable, and three answers came to mind, uh, toll booth attendant, an Apple Store genius, and what Penny does. Now, since I don’t like touching other people’s coins, and I refuse to contribute to the devaluation of the word genius, here I am.

speaker: You just, you just walked in and they hired you, just like that?
response: Oh, heavens, no. Since I don’t need to be paid, I didn’t need to be hired. I simply came in, picked up a tray, and started working for the man. Let me get that plate out of your way.

speaker: Sheldon, this is ridiculous.
response: Is it? Just a moment ago I had a minor epiphany regarding the polymer degradation phenomenon while scraping congealed nachos off a plate. Bernadette, table 10 wants their check.

speaker: Sheldon, wait, this isn’t even what I do. I’m a waitress, not a busboy.
response: You’re right. That is more menial. Hello, I’m Sheldon. I’ll be your server today. I don’t recommend the salmon. I saw it in the kitchen.

speaker: Hang on. Black beans, not pinto beans?
response: Yes.

speaker: Double guacamole?
response: Of course.

speaker: No cilantro?
response: Nope.

speaker: Lettuce shredded, not chopped?
response: Yep.

speaker: You understand why I’m doing this to you?
response: I do.

speaker: Well, honey, not to complain, but we were starting to think you didn’t either.
response: Is that really necessary? Good Lord. The interference pattern in the fracture. The motion of the wave through the molecular structure. I’ve been looking at it all wrong. I can’t consider the electrons as particles. They move through the graphene as a wave. It’s a wave! The moment to applaud would be now. Troglodytes.

speaker: Sheldon, where are you going? Aren’t you going to clean this up?
response: I’m sorry. I don’t work here.

speaker: No, she was pretty clear about wanting to keep her options open.
response: I have something to announce, but out of respect for convention, I will wait for you to finish your current conversation. What are you talking about?

speaker: The cultural paradigm in which people have sex after three dates.
response: I see. Now, are we talking date, the social interaction, or date, the dried fruit?

speaker: Never mind, what’s your announcement?
response: Oh, good, my turn. Well, this is very exciting and I wanted you to be among the first to know…

speaker: Hey, Cooper, I hear you’re going to be on the wadio with Ira Fwatow from Science Fwiday next week.
response: Thank you, Kripke, for depriving me of the opportunity to share my news with my friends.

speaker: My pweasure.
response: My thank you was not sincere.

speaker: But my pweasure is. Let me ask you a question, at what point did National Public Wadio have to start scwaping the bottom of the bawwel for its guests? Eh, don’t answer, it’s wetowical.
response: Why are you such a stupid head? That is also rhetorical. I’m sorry you had to hear that.

speaker: Are you really going to be on NPR?
response: Yes, they’re interviewing me by phone from my office, regarding the recent so-called discovery of magnetic monopoles in spin-ices. It’s pledge week and they’re trying to goose the ratings with a little controversy.

speaker: Very cool, congratulations.
response: Thank you. My mother is very excited. She’s convening her Bible study group to listen in, and then pray for my soul.

speaker: Excuse me, I have a master’s degree in engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It required the completion of 144 units of grad work and an original thesis.
response: Yes. Look this over and tell me what’s unclear to you.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: All right, you know what, I will tell you why it’s wrong…
response: Excuse me, may I interject?

speaker: What?
response: Biologically speaking, Howard is perfectly justified in seeking out the optimum mate for the propagation of his genetic line.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: Now, whether that propagation is in the interest of humanity is, of course, an entirely different question.

speaker: Thanks for being with us today, Dr. Cooper.
response: My pleasure, Ira.

speaker: Now, let’s talk about magnetic monopoles. Can you explain to our audience just what a monopole is?
response: Of course. First, consider an ordinary magnet which has, (the pitch of his voice begins to rise) as even the most uneducated in your audience must know, two poles, (pitch rises further) a north and south pole. If you cut that in half, you have two smaller magnets, each with its own north and south pole.

speaker: Uh, Dr. Cooper, I think there might be something wrong with our connection.
response: No, I hear you fine. As I was saying, an ordinary magnet has two poles. The primary characteristic of a monopole is that it has only one pole, hence, monopole.

speaker: How ya doin’, buddy?
response: I was humiliated on national radio. How do you think I’m doing?

speaker: Come on, it wasn’t that bad.
response: What do you want?

speaker: Okay, so Kripke played a joke on you.
response: It wasn’t funny.

speaker: You laughed.
response: Did you laugh?

speaker: I fell on the floor. All right, he got you, you can get him back.
response: I refuse to sink to his level.

speaker: Are you really admitting defeat?
response: I never admit defeat.

speaker: Good.
response: However, on an unrelated topic, I am never getting out of this bed again.

speaker: That’s true. He didn’t just stay there and talk about his feelings with the other psychotic villains. He, he broke out and poisoned Gotham’s water supply.
response: Well, I suppose I could poison Kripke.

speaker: No, no.
response: It’s a simple matter. There are several toxic chemicals that’d be untraceable in an autopsy.

speaker: Okay, uh, that’s the spirit, but, um, let’s dial it back to a non-lethal form of vengeance.
response: Oh! How about we put awhoopee cushion on his office chair? He’ll sit down, it’ll sound like he’s flatulent, even though he’s not.

speaker: What’s this?
response: Mountain Dew. Ah, refreshing. Now, we’re going to combine these chemicals with ordinary dish soap, creating a little exothermic release of oxygen.

speaker: Foamy vengeance.
response: Yes, exactly.

speaker: This is brilliant, Sheldon. How are we going to deploy it in Kripke’s office?
response: Already taken care of. Observe. This is a live sh*t of Kripke’s lab via a mini webcam I was able to install, thanks to a dollar bill discreetly placed in the night janitor’s shirt pocket. At the same time, I also secured large quantities of these chemicals above the tiles in the drop ceiling.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, you remind me of a young Lex Luthor.
response: You flatter me, sir.

speaker: Let me guess, motion sensors?
response: The reaction will be triggered when Kripke reaches the center of the room. Mwah, ha, ha.

speaker: I gotta say, I am really impressed. This is truly the Sheldon Cooper way to get even. (Sits down. There is a flatulent noise)
response: It may be low-tech, but I still maintain the whoopee cushion has comic validity.

speaker: And the board of directors. Abort! Abort!
response: There is no abort.

speaker: Well, how could you not put in an abort?
response: I made a boo-boo, all right?

speaker: At least they don’t know it was you.
response: Hello, Kripke. This classic prank comes to you from the malevolent mind of Sheldon Cooper. If you’d like to see the look on your stupid face, this video is being instantly uploaded to YouTube. Oh, and a hat tip to Leonard Hofstadter and Raj Koothrappali for their support and encouragement in this enterprise.

speaker: This is an easy one. You love this guy.
response: Me.

speaker: Come on, he's an under-appreciated genius.
response: Still think it's me.

speaker: It's not you. Now think, there's a car named after him.
response: Of course there is. The Mini Cooper, 'cause it's me.

speaker: How about this, he's a poor man's Sheldon Cooper.
response: Oh, Tesla.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hey, how did it go?

speaker: Yeah. It's a deviated septum. The surgery to correct it is simple. He's gonna do it next week.
response: Why would you have surgery?

speaker: Yeah, back off, he's all mine.
response: But you don't have a life-threatening condition. Why would you take the risk of surgery?

speaker: Sheldon, it's a routine procedure, I've heard you complain about his snoring.
response: Yes, for the first five or six years, but I've gotten used to it. It helps me sleep. He's like my mucus-powered white noise machine.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm gonna get the surgery, it's no big deal. End of story.
response: Very well. I'm done talking about it.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I believe it was your turn in the game.

speaker: Okay.
response: Let's see. Oh, this person is most famous for never having gotten his nose mutilated with elective surgery and never living the rest of his life in the shadows as a hideous, disfigured freak.

speaker: I think you could give a better clue.
response: I don't. I'm not even sure if that's a person or a typo.

speaker: Okay, why?
response: I'm listening to you snore. I'm wondering how I'll ever sleep without it.

speaker: If it helps you sleep, then why are you sitting here staring at me like the albino boogeyman?
response: Really Leonard. Insults? After I spent two hours in your closet, waiting for you to fall asleep?

speaker: What's your problem?
response: If the surgery is successful, the snoring is gone. And if you die during surgery, the snoring is gone.

speaker: It sounds like either way, I finally get some rest.
response: I have to be honest with you Leonard, I'm truly worried.

speaker: I told you, there's nothing to worry about.
response: Well, I've been doing some research and I've learned that one in 700,000 people die from general anaesthesia.

speaker: Buddy, wh, do you realize that that also means 699,999 people don't die?
response: I suppose that's true. You're such a glass half-full kind of guy. I'm going to miss that.

speaker: Hey. What're you working on?
response: Remember when I said if you went through with your surgery, there was a one-in-700,000 chance of dying?

speaker: Yeah?
response: Well, I've been crunching the numbers, and so far, I've gotten your probability of death all the way to a sphincter-tightening one in 300.

speaker: Great timing. My check sphincter light just went on.
response: Leonard, what if you have an allergic reaction to the surgeon's latex gloves?

speaker: I'm not allergic to latex.
response: Well, then why don't you wear the rubber gloves I bought for you to do the dishes?

speaker: For the same reason I don't wear the apron or the hair net.
response: Fine. What about epilepsy?

speaker: I don't have epilepsy, either.
response: You don't, but the surgeon might, hmm? And your carotid artery is just one shaky scalpel away from becoming the dancing fountain at Disneyland.

speaker: Sheldon, do you realize that driving is riskier than surgery?
response: I do. I have the drive to the hospital right here. That is if you make it to the car without falling down the stairs. And don't expect me to carry you, I do that enough in life.

speaker: Buddy, I, I get that you're worried about me and I, I appreciate that, but I'm not going to die.
response: You don't know that.

speaker: Well, I do know that it won't be from an asteroid strike.
response: You know who else said that? Every cocky T. Rex currently swimming around in the gas t*nk of your car.

speaker: If there was an asteroid strike, wouldn't you die, too?
response: I don't know, I'm smart and scrappy, I think I'd find a way.

speaker: Tell you what, the surgery's not for a week, I'll think about it.
response: Thank you. And while you're thinking about it, if you have the surgery in Nicaragua during monsoon season, I can practically guarantee your death.

speaker: He was so busy figuring out how many parts per million of urine we'd be floating around in, he didn't even question it.
response: 18 parts per million. And he's still doing it.

speaker: Don't worry about that. I'm happy to take you to work.
response: Well, thank you. And Leonard never lets me have French toast sticks in the car. I can't have syrupy fingers, but he can do the backstroke in a toilet bowl.

speaker: It's nice they're getting exercise.
response: Although now that I think about it, Leonard would never go swimming in public without his swim shirt.

speaker: I'm sure he brought it.
response: No, but last year, at Magic Mountain, he got such a bad sunburn, we had to cut him out of it.

speaker: He probably got a new one. Finish your breakfast. Look, there's an entire section of my dashboard that doesn't have any syrup on it.
response: You're acting odd. Why?

speaker: I'm odd all the time, everyone knows that. Just last night I tried to see how many fava beans I could fit in my mouth.
response: Tell me the truth.

speaker: Twenty eight.
response: Come on.

speaker: Fifty six.
response: Amy. What's going on?

speaker: All right. Don't get upset, but, an earlier appointment opened up for Leonard and he's getting the surgery right now.
response: I see. Take me to Leonard.

speaker: Just go to work, he'll be fine.
response: Amy, he's my best friend, and if you don't take me, I'm going there anyway.

speaker: Fine. It's sweet that you care about him so much.
response: I do. And I wouldn't be able to forgive myself if something happened to him and I wasn't at his bedside to say I told you so.

speaker: We had a really nice swim.
response: Oh, stop it. I assume this medical centre's already treated the burns on your bottom from the recent pants fire.

speaker: ‘Cause I'm a liar, liar?
response: That's for the fire marshal to determine.

speaker: He wore me down. And I was distracted, he has on extra baby powder today.
response: Is he okay?

speaker: He's still in surgery.
response: Very well.

speaker: Come on, let's talk about something other than the surgery.
response: That's a good idea. Penny, did you and Leonard ever discuss funeral arrangements?

speaker: I think she meant something a little happier.
response: I suppose we could try to make it a celebration, but he died so young.

speaker: Oh, it's nice you got him that.
response: Oh, this isn't for Leonard, no. Amy bought it for me.

speaker: Stubbed his toe on the revolving door on the way in.
response: You know those confounded things make me dizzy.

speaker: Who told you to keep going around?
response: There was a large plant in the lobby. It kept looking like the outside.

speaker: Penny has a good point. This is like the man in the supermarket with the goiter on his neck. Whatever you're thinking, just keep it to yourself.
response: It was like a grapefruit.

speaker: And I'm sure he knew that before you held a grapefruit up next to it.
response: Well, I'm not making any promises. Not only did Leonard take what I feel is an unnecessary risk, he deceived me.

speaker: Okay, the reason he deceived you is you were being a pain in the ass.
response: The reason I was being a pain in the B is because I was worried about him, and no one else was.

speaker: Really? You won't even say A?
response: You bet your sweet B I won't.

speaker: Obviously, I care about Leonard. I'm gonna spend the rest of my life with him.
response: And I'm not? It's an earthquake. I knew it.

speaker: Sheldon, it was just a little tremor.
response: A little tremor that turns routine sinus surgery into a frontal lobotomy. Oh, I don't care for this at all. Oh, I need to see he's okay.

speaker: Sheldon, you can't go back there.
response: Try and stop me.

speaker: Are you okay?
response: Why didn't you stop me?

speaker: Come on, smile. This is gonna be my Christmas card.
response: You know this is all your fault.

speaker: How is it my fault?
response: I told you not to get the surgery.

speaker: Okay, first of all, the surgery was a success, and secondly, I didn't even want you there.
response: Wow. I don't know which hurts worse, my nose or my heart. Well, I'm done speaking to you.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm sorry I didn't tell you about the surgery, but you were worried about nothing.
response: Oh, you're hardly out of the woods, no. You still run the risk of infection, a blood clot, the possibility that an inattentive surgeon let a barn spider lay eggs in your nose. The minute you sneeze web, I'm moving out.

speaker: Yeah, once he figures out how to work a door.
response: I was not panicked, and I am not overly attached to Leonard.

speaker: You were so worried that you smashed your face trying to check on me. You love me.
response: Yeah. Tell me those aren't the words of a man with a spider eating its way through his brain. Amy, you're a neuroscientist. Crack his skull open, spray some Raid in there.

speaker: Oh, what'd you get?
response: Oh, I ordered it before your surgery. It's the urn I was going to put you in.

speaker: Okay, that's morbid. Send it back.
response: I can't send it back, I had it engraved. Here lie the ashes of Leonard Hofstadter. He thought he was right, but his room mate knew better.”

speaker: Hey, why did you get two? I'm with stupid.
response: Oh, that one's mine.

speaker: Okay, we're headed out, see you later.
response: Before you leave, could you test these noise-cancelling headphones?

speaker: Yeah, sure.
response: Okay. Go ahead.

speaker: Ooh, and one time when you were asleep, Amy totally took off her... and that's why you're the best roommate ever.
response: Aw, now I'm sad I didn't hear it.

speaker: So what do you need the headphones for?
response: Well, I've been struggling for months to come up with a theory of dark matter that doesn't make protons decay. I'm hoping to finally tackle it by optimising my work environment. See, I've got, uh, my tea is at the perfect sipping temperature. Uh, I have fleece-lined boxer shorts to keep my tushie toasty. And then, oh, last but not least, this inspirational cat poster improved with the reassuring face of physics renegade Richard Feynman.

speaker: Yeah, have fun.
response: Oh, I will, nothing more fun than a paradigm-shifting evening of science.

speaker: Bye.
response: Okay. Here we go. Proton decay. Proton decay. (Time shift) Proton decay. Proton decay. (Time shift) Proton decay. Proton decay.

speaker: Hey, we're home. Any progress?
response: How could there be, with these constant interruptions?

speaker: What are you doing? It's time to go.
response: I'm not going to work today. And would you like to know why?

speaker: Ah, you're upset because you spent the whole night working on dark matter and didn't make a breakthrough, and now you're worried you made a huge mistake switching fields, and you're gonna sit around and sulk all day?
response: Like a big old baby.

speaker: Call me if you need anything.
response: I've been cooped up in here too long. Maybe I need some fresh air. (inhales, exhales)

speaker: Ugh! Ugh! Ugh! Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh!
response: (Knocks) Penny?

speaker: Ugh, what?
response: You sounded in distress. I was worried something unpleasant was happening to you. Like a m*rder. Or spontaneous coitus with Leonard.

speaker: Oh, I'm just doing this awful workout. I hate it.
response: Well, if you hate it, then why are you doing it? Although I could ask the same question about coitus with Leonard.

speaker: I don't know, I guess I like that I hate it. It makes me work harder.
response: And to clarify?

speaker: The exercise, Sheldon. Shouldn't you be getting ready for work?
response: I'm not going. Would you like to know why?

speaker: Uh, you're sad about not getting anything done last night, so you're gonna sit around and pout about it?
response: Boy, I'm not nearly as mysterious as I think I am.

speaker: Ooh, Emily. I heard him say that to Emily. Hey, I thought you were staying home.
response: Yeah, I was, but after talking to Penny, I realised something. I, first, she's trying much harder to stay attractive in this relationship than you are. And second, the reason I may not be progressing in my research is I've created too pleasant of an environment for myself.

speaker: What do you mean?
response: According to a classic psychological experiment by Yerkes and Dodson, in order to maximize performance, one must create a state of productive anxiety. So I'd like to ask you all to do something for me. Keep me on my toes. (stammers) Just throw me off my game. Essentially, go out of your way to make my life miserable.

speaker: Hold on. What's in it for us?
response: Well, I suppose...

speaker: Okay, we'll do it.
response: Done.

speaker: 33 seconds. Okay, that'll be our baseline.
response: You know, I don't want to tell you how to do your job, but when a mouse completes a maze, it gets a food pellet.

speaker: It also gets its brain plucked out with tweezers.
response: And his last meal was a food pellet? You're a monster.

speaker: All right, next, we're gonna introduce an anxiety-inducing stimulus, measure your stress levels and see how it affects your problem-solving rate.
response: Very well. And good luck, I'm a pretty laid-back guy.

speaker: Ready? Begin. (squeezes balloon) Why'd you pop it?
response: I'm sorry, I was aiming for your heart.

speaker: Look, I know you don't like it, but that's the point of the experiment. I need to irritate you to find your optimal anxiety zone. And you said no to tickling, polka music or watching me eat a banana.
response: Who eats them horizontally?

speaker: My mother said that's how good girls do it.
response: Perhaps this was a waste of time.

speaker: Sheldon, you're a remarkable scientist. Just be patient, I'm sure you'll find the breakthrough you've been looking for.
response: Thank you.

speaker: And if you only do solid research instead of making a groundbreaking discovery, what does it matter?
response: "Only do solid research"? I come to you for help, and you insult me? I thought the least that you would do would be...

speaker: Look, your anxiety levels are right in the zone.
response: Really? Oh, that's fantastic. Now, wait, they're dropping. Why are they dropping?

speaker: Because you're happy they're elevated.
response: Oh, that is infuriating. Ooh, look, they went back up again. Terrific. Oh, no, they went back down.

speaker: That is a tough one. Uh, I know he brushes both of them.
response: Gentlemen, I have figured out the perfect way for you to irritate me. I'd like you to be my intellectual sparring partners. From now on, when I make an assertion, I need you to challenge it.

speaker: So you just want us to disagree with whatever you say?
response: Yes.

speaker: And you think that's going to help?
response: Yes.

speaker: Well, I don't think that's gonna help at all.
response: Oh, no, it will. See, by keeping my mind engaged, I'll become more focused.

speaker: Howard's right, that'll never work.
response: Stop fighting me on the premise. It's scientifically valid. I'm going to advance propositions, I just want you to challenge me.

speaker: I don't think that's what you want at all.
response: Why, of course it's what I want. Why would I say it's what I want if it's not what I want?

speaker: Because it is what you want, and it's not what you said.
response: I ask you for one simple thing, and you can't even do it.

speaker: Yes, we can.
response: Yeah, well, then do it.

speaker: Nah.
response: You guys are the worst. Thank you, I think that was helpful.

speaker: Really? Want to go to Hawaii?
response: (knocking on door) Ladies? (Knocks) Ladies? (Knocks) Ladies?

speaker: Come in.
response: Ladies.

speaker: What's up?
response: Well, as you may know, I've been experimenting with elevated anxiety levels, and I thought, what better way to increase my discomfort than to subject myself to an evening of tasteless uncensored crotch talk?

speaker: What exactly do you think goes on here?
response: Well, conversations that you wouldn't be comfortable having in front of the opposite sex. You know, who has the best cervix. Which sanitary napkin is all the rage right now. Men's buttocks, and how you want to pat and squeeze them.

speaker: We were talking about Penny's job.
response: And how difficult it is to do when she's bloated, cranky and crampy? Continue.

speaker: Sheldon, we are just people. We talk about the same things you guys talk about.
response: You talk about if werewolves can swim? See, Leonard says yes, but I say it depends on if the human could swim before he was bitten. What do you think?

speaker: Well, they're not a hundred percent wolf. They're a werewolf, that's only part wolf. It's like comparing apples to oranges.
response: Thank you. Oh, and technically, it's apples that turn into were-oranges when the moon is full. Hey, this is fun. We should do it sometime when you aren't all PMS'ing. Bye.

speaker: What is going on?
response: Oh. Uh, I need to keep my anxiety at the right level, so I'm using Darth Vader, the Joker, and Godzilla's roar to keep me in that sweet spot. Uh, I tried including Taylor Swift in the mix, but turns out I love her.

speaker: Well, at least listen to it through headphones. I'm trying to sleep. Good night.
response: Boy, Taylor was right, haters gonna hate, hate, hate, hate, hate.

speaker: You've been working so much lately, I'm glad you didn't forget about date night.
response: Of course.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Yeah.

speaker: Maybe you want to put the notebook away and talk to me.
response: (stammers) I can do both. My brain is working at optimal capacity. I can have a conversation with you and solve the dark matter proton decay problem at the same time.

speaker: Fine. How was your day?
response: Oh, you said it.

speaker: Sheldon. Sheldon, I'm worried about you. You're not eating, you haven't slept in days, and, to be honest, that cap is starting to smell.
response: I know. It's replaced Godzilla as my principle source of anxiety.

speaker: You didn't have to scoop vomit out of your glove compartment.
response: He is getting a lot of work done. He had a pretty interesting take on proton decay.

speaker: Sheldon, I want you to take that cap off.
response: That nagging tone is helping my anxiety, yeah. But if you could maybe just go ten percent less shrill, that'd really put the zip-a-dee in my doo-dah.

speaker: I'm sorry, but you know we agreed not to bring work to date night.
response: There you go, perfect.

speaker: Sheldon, stop it, I'm not kidding. Take the cap off, and put the notebook away.
response: But after months of struggling, I'm finally making progress.

speaker: You don't need to drive yourself crazy in order to be productive.
response: Or do I, hmm? Sir Isaac Newton wrote his Principia while convinced he was an armadillo.

speaker: That's not true.
response: Yeah, well, maybe it is, maybe it isn't. I have been hallucinating lately.

speaker: Sheldon, this has to stop. You need to get some sleep and take care of yourself.
response: Amy, I have gotten more done in the last few days than I have since I made the switch to dark matter. What if I stop doing this, and it all goes away?

speaker: Your thoughts and ideas come from you, not from your anxiety.
response: Hmm, perhaps. But I'm not taking the cap off.

speaker: It's one thing to make yourself miserable, but you're making everyone around you miserable, too. Now, I'm telling you for the last time, take the cap off.
response: Oh, really? What if I don't? And before you answer that, can I have my dessert?

speaker: Yeah, well, women, what are you gonna do?
response: I knew you'd understand, Armadillo Isaac Newton.

speaker: Here we are.
response: Hey. What are you trying to pull? The president of science isn't in here.

speaker: You lie down, he'll be here in a minute.
response: Okay. Hey, I thought you were trying to trick me.

speaker: Now, you just get comfortable.
response: No, no, comfort is the enemy. You know what's comfortable? Slippers and blankets and panda bears. Imagine a panda bear with Richard Feynman's face on it. Warm up the car, Leonard, it's poster time.

speaker: Yeah, you get some sleep.
response: No, I don't want to go to sleep, you can't make me.

speaker: You're right, we can't.
response: Yeah, darn straight, you can't. Try to tell a grown man to go to sleep.

speaker: ♪ Little ball of fur... ♪
response: That's not gonna work.

speaker: You look like you got some rest.
response: Oh, I'm feeling much better. And I've also been continuing to make progress without artificially raising my anxiety levels.

speaker: Yeah, no problem.
response: Of course not.

speaker: Can’t we just postpone it till the spring? Maybe next summer?
response: This should be fairly easy to deduce. He’s holding the phone to his left ear. Ears do not cross hemispheres, so he’s using the analytical rather than the emotional side of the brain, suggesting that he has no personal relationship with the caller.

speaker: No, I didn’t realize it had been so long. Sure, I guess there’s no other choice but to just go ahead and do it.
response: He’s referring to an activity he has done before. It’s unpleasant and needs to be repeated. This suggests some sort of invasive medical test, like perhaps a colonoscopy.

speaker: Aren’t there any other options? There’s not a lot of room, it’s gonna be uncomfortable.
response: Yes, yes. Yeah, I’m definitely going with colonoscopy.

speaker: I’ll start again.
response: I have the same problem with him. My theory is that his lack of focus stems from an over-developed sex drive.

speaker: Oh, I don’t know where he would’ve gotten that. Aside from a pro forma consummation of our marriage, his father and I only had intercourse for the purposes of reproduction.
response: That seems a fairly efficient arrangement.

speaker: Yes, we think so. We’ve both done papers on it. Mine from the neuroscientific point of view and his from an anthropological. Mine, of course, was the only one worth reading.
response: Of course. I would very much like to read about your sex life.

speaker: Here’s your tea, Mother. So, what are you guys talking about?
response: The frequency with which your parents had intercourse.

speaker: I’m sorry, it’s on my other laptop.
response: Aw…

speaker: His heart stopped b*at. I have to urinate.
response: What a remarkable woman.

speaker: Yeah I, I thought you guys might hit it off.
response: I envy you your childhood.

speaker: I hate to tell you, but the only warm memories I have of my childhood are of my Uncle Floyd.
response: You’re clearly misremembering. Your mother is brilliant, analytical, insightful, and I’m betting she never hit you with a Bible because you wouldn’t eat your Brussels sprouts.

speaker: Sheldon, you don’t give your mother enough credit. She’s warm, she’s loving, she doesn’t glue electrodes to your head to measure your brain waves while potty training.
response: You were lucky. When I was a kid, if I wanted an EEG, I had to attach my own electrodes.

speaker: You know the rules. You brought your mom to work, you must suffer.
response: Leonard, I had no idea your siblings were so much more successful than you.

speaker: Oh, the middle stall was occupied. I’ll have to try again later.
response: It’s totally understandable. In bladder voiding, as in real estate, it’s location, location, location.

speaker: But it’s one o’clock, you were going to show me your laboratory at one o’clock.
response: Her reasoning is unassailable. It is one o’clock.

speaker: You always say that, but we never do.
response: You went to the comic book store without me.

speaker: Your scan data will be very elpful to my research. You have a remarkable brain.
response: I know. Although I’ve always hated how my right frontal lobe looks in pictures.

speaker: Common complaint among men. Nothing’s ever big enough, except when they get a tumour. Then you never hear the end of it.
response: I’d love to see a scan of your brain sometime.

speaker: Oh, I’ll send you a link, but its physiology is fairly unimpressive.
response: Oh, I can’t believe that.

speaker: Your unwillingness to accept empirical evidence suggests an attempt at flattery.
response: My apologies. I’ve been living with your son too long. Gotten into some bad habits.

speaker: Understandable.
response: Can I make you a cup of tea?

speaker: I doubt it, but if anyone has a chance, it’s probably you.
response: I feel very comfortable around you.

speaker: I feel very comfortable around you, too.
response: It’s surprising because I generally don’t feel comfortable around, well, anyone.

speaker: Nor I.
response: What are the odds that two individuals as unique as ourselves would be connected by someone as comparatively workaday as your son?

speaker: Is that a rhetorical point or would you like to do the math?
response: I’d like to do the math.

speaker: I’m very tempted. I’m just not sure it’s appropriate with my son’s roommate.
response: Normally, I’d feel the same way. But based on everything I’ve observed about us, I can’t help but speculate we’d be very good together.

speaker: True. I’ve had a similar observation. It’s certainly something I could never do with my husband.
response: I was hesitant the first time I tried it, but I experienced an unanticipated and remarkable release of endorphins. It’s quite satisfying.

speaker: I see what you’re doing. You’re appealing to the neuroscientific researcher in me.
response: You see right through me, don’t you?

speaker: This is the worst cobbler I’ve ever eaten. I mean it tastes like it was made of actual ground-up shoemaker.
response: Amusing. A play on the two meanings of cobbler.

speaker: Hey guys, guess who I found at LAX. My baby sister Priya.
response: Excuse me. I object. You propose a guessing game, yet you don’t give me enough time to guess. For the record, I was going to say your sister Priya.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon. You haven’t changed a bit, have you?
response: Why would I change?

speaker: Can you believe it? Little Priya’s one of the lead attorneys for the biggest car company in India.
response: Given that when we met her she was finishing law school and planning an internship at a large Indian car company, it’s actually extremely plausible.

speaker: Alright, this goes without saying, but I’m just going to say it anyway. Hands off my sister.
response: Why would I touch her, she’s covered with airplane germs.

speaker: Okay then.
response: Cobbler. I’m still laughing.

speaker: Oh, not really, just hang out.
response: I always tell people, if you have only one day in Los Angeles, make it a train day.

speaker: Train day?
response: The fun starts with brunch at Carney’s in Studio City, a hot dog stand in a converted railroad dining car. Next stop, Travel Town, an outdoor museum featuring 43 railroad engines, cars and other rolling stock from the 1880s to the 1930s. Finally, we’re off to the glitz and glamour of Hollywood for dinner at, that’s right, the Hollywood Carney’s, a hot dog stand in a different converted railroad dining car.

speaker: I don’t think we’re going to do that.
response: Well then apparently, you hate fun.

speaker: Uh, my plans with Priya.
response: He rejected train day.

speaker: Did you make it clear that it’s two different train cars turned into hot dog stands?
response: Abundantly.

speaker: I guess he just hates fun.
response: That’s what I said.

speaker: I don’t know, I just have the one day.
response: Do you like trains?

speaker: Not particularly.
response: You might as well just wait at the airport for your flight.

speaker: It’s getting pretty late, how come you’re still up?
response: I’ve found an emulator online that lets you play classic text based computer games from the 1980s.

speaker: That’s pretty cool.
response: Oh yes. It runs on the world’s most powerful graphics chip, imagination.

speaker: You’ve really got to get out more.
response: Go north. You can’t go that way. Go west. A troll blocks your passage. Okay, fasten your seatbelts, k*ll troll. With what? With sword. (There is a knock on the door.) You don’t have the sword. Good golly, it’s as if it’s actually happening to me.

speaker: Yeah, he does but he got caught up in a computer game and…
response: Hit troll with axe. Hit troll with axe. Hit troll with axe. Oh my, this is one tough troll.

speaker: If the past is any indication, no.
response: Leonard, I’m trapped in quicksand, the axe is dragging me down.

speaker: Drop axe.
response: Drop axe. Brilliant.

speaker: Give me a minute. Sheldon,
response: Hold on. I have to figure out how to get the bucket, so I can carry the mud past the dragon.

speaker: Sheldon, you need to work in the morning.
response: I know.

speaker: Well then, bed mister.
response: Five more minutes.

speaker: Really? You’re going to risk getting sleepy in the middle of your thermodynamic fluctuations seminar? You know what happens when you yawn in public.
response: Everyone will see my oddly shaped uvula.

speaker: You don’t want that, do you?
response: No. But it’s a shame our society mocks the differently uvulated. Who was at the door?

speaker: Oh, uh, building manager. They have to fix a pipe so the water will be off tomorrow from noon to two.
response: That’s unacceptable. We’re supposed to be given written notice.

speaker: No, no, it doesn’t matter, we’ll be at work.
response: Well, what if I spill tomato soup on my shirt and have to come home to change, only to find there’s no water for an enzyme soak.

speaker: Bifurcated uvula, Sheldon!
response: I’ll have the chicken noodle. Goodnight.

speaker: We’re going to have to be very quiet.
response: I know how to get the bucket! I can turn the axe around and use the handle to reach it. Let’s see. Go north. You are in a forest. Go north. You are in a forest. Go north. You are in a forest. Oh dear, I believe I’m lost. Well, I’ll just have to get a fresh start tomorrow.

speaker: No, no, no, no, no. You just need, you just need, you just need to map it out. Come on, I’ll help you. So, uh, you stopped at the stream and you turned north three times?
response: Yes.

speaker: Aha, you’re funny.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard.

speaker: What?
response: I heard a woman laughing.

speaker: Oh, uh, yeah, I was trying to see if I could laugh as a woman.
response: Oh. Well, good job, quite convincing. I smell perfume.

speaker: Air freshener.
response: And is that lipstick on your cheek and neck.

speaker: Uh, rash, that’s a bad rash.
response: My sympathies. I am no stranger to the crimson scourge that is dermatitis. Can I interest you in a topical steroid from my lotion and unguent collection?

speaker: Uh, yeah, yeah, that sounds great.
response: Very well, I’m sure I can find something that will help you ditch that itch.

speaker: Okay, he’s in the bathroom, let’s go.
response: Do you prefer ointment or cream?

speaker: Uh, cream.
response: With or without a numbing agent?

speaker: Without.
response: Really? Leonard, there are no heroes when it comes to dermatitis.

speaker: Fine. With.
response: Prescription or non-prescription strength.

speaker: Use your best judgement.
response: Well, I think I have a nice 2009 AnaMantle HC. It’s usually indicated for acutely inflamed haemorrhoids, but it also goes nicely with non mucosal body parts.

speaker: Sounds great.
response: Excellent choice.

speaker: Right, right, alright. (They creep almost to the apartment door.)
response: Priya?

speaker: Good morning, Sheldon.
response: For shame, Leonard. For shame. And to think I was ready to waste the last of my good haemorrhoid cream on you.

speaker: Making pretty good time, huh?
response: Is that really what you want to talk about, Leonard?

speaker: No.
response: What do you want to talk about?

speaker: Please don’t tell anyone I spent the night with Raj’s sister.
response: There it is. What if someone asks?

speaker: No-one’s going to ask if I spent the night with Raj’s sister.
response: Perhaps. But they might ask me something else.

speaker: Like what?
response: Like, has Leonard betrayed any of his friends recently?

speaker: Priya and I are both adults. We didn’t betray Raj.
response: In fact, you did, but I was referring to Howard.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: April 12th, 2005, Bob’s Big Boy, Toluca Lake. Raj had just introduced us to Priya for the first time, and she was enjoying the sweet taste of Hindu rebellion in the form of a Bob’s Super Big Boy hamburger. In order to preserve your friendship, you and Howard made a pinky swear that neither of you would attempt to woo her. I had a patty melt.

speaker: Okay, fine, I betrayed Howard.
response: And Raj.

speaker: Alright, and Raj.
response: And me.

speaker: You?
response: Violation of the roommate agreement, overnight guest notification clause.

speaker: Okay fine, I’m, I’m a horrible human being, I’m the Darth Vader of Pasadena.
response: You’re far too short to be Darth Vader. At best you might be a turncoat Ewok.

speaker: My point is, Priya’s gone. And it would be much better if no-one else found out about this.
response: You mean, you want me to keep a secret.

speaker: Yes.
response: You know I can’t keep a secret.

speaker: You can if you try. Think about it this way, if I were Batman and you were Alfred, you’d keep that secret. Right?
response: Why do you get to be Batman?

speaker: Because, well, Batman has the secret.
response: Well Alfred has secrets too.

speaker: Like what?
response: Alfred knows that Barbara Gordon is Batgirl. Which I’ve now just told to Batman. See, I can’t keep a secret.

speaker: What.
response: Ta-da. It’s short for da-da-da-da!

speaker: Kind of busy here, Sheldon.
response: I know, that’s why I shortened it.

speaker: What do you want.
response: I came to go over your alibi for last night.

speaker: What alibi?
response: You’ve asked me to lie on your behalf, and as you know, I am deeply uncomfortable with impromptu dishonest, so I’ve provided you with an iron clad alibi. You couldn’t have spent last night with Priya, because you were with another woman.

speaker: Oh, I’m so sure I’m going to regret this, but, who was I with?
response: The fun loving, and morally loose, Miss Maggie McGeary.

speaker: Oh, God.
response: You met her at Pasadena’s most popular Irish watering hole, Lucky Baldwin’s, where Maggie spends her nights tending bar, with a head full of curls and a heart full of dreams.

speaker: Leonard, call me if you’re interested in coitus. Sincerely, Maggie McGeary.
response: And if anyone were to actually call that number they will hear this.

speaker: Top of the morning to you. You’ve reached Maggie McGeary. Leave a message after the wee little beep.
response: It’s pretty convincing, huh? And it wasn’t even a real person. And here is the clincher. A lock of Maggie’s flaming auburn hair.

speaker: Where did you get that?
response: From an orang-u-tan in the primate lab.

speaker: An orang-u-tan?
response: Well, no-one’s going to run a DNA test on it, Leonard, honestly you over-think everything.

speaker: C’mon Raj, how am I supposed to know who she’s attracted to. Or was attracted to. Or who she might be attracted to. In the future.
response: And I have nothing to contribute to this conversation. Because I too know absolutely nothing about Priya’s preferences in male companionship. And with that, I will re-zip my lip.

speaker: To, uh, Lucky Baldwin’s.
response: Oh, I’ve heard of that place, isn’t that Pasadena’s favourite Irish watering hole.

speaker: Yes.
response: Did you meet anyone interesting there, perhaps a promiscuous redheaded barmaid?

speaker: As a matter of fact I.. I… I can’t… I can’t… I can’t do it.
response: Sure you can, you’re doing fine, it’s very believable.

speaker: Look, I’m sorry Raj, but the truth is I was with Priya last night.
response: Don’t listen to him, he’s still light headed from all the Irish whiskey and pickled eggs in his system.

speaker: What were you doing with Priya?
response: I believe they engaged in coitus but, more importantly, if Leonard had not abandoned his story, would you have found it plausible?

speaker: Excuse me, I think how could you she’s my sister takes precedence over a five year old pinky swear!
response: May I point out, in a parallel universe, your friends are saying Maggie McGeary, she sounds lovely.

speaker: Dude! I put that thing on my face!
response: I think a more amusing violation of Raj’s trust is when Howard convinced him that foreigners give presents to Americans on Thanksgiving.

speaker: And as long as we’re talking about betraying our friends, how about the month Sheldon spent grinding up insects and mixing them into Leonard’s food.
response: Well, excuse me. That was not a betrayal, that was an experiment to determine at what concentration food starts tasting mothy.

speaker: You put moths in my food?
response: For science.

speaker: Well, uh, I can’t believe you used Sheldon’s toothbrush.
response: You used my toothbrush?

speaker: As long as we’re apologising, Sheldon, I, I’m sorry I used your toothbrush.
response: And I’m sorry. But that behaviour is beyond the pale and cannot be tolerated. We are no longer friends.

speaker: I got you a talking Thomas the t*nk Engine for Thanksgiving.
response: With real puffing smoke?

speaker: Yes.
response: Alright. But I’m watching you.

speaker: Hey, you got Snoopy out. Can I have a snowcone?
response: Well, sure.

speaker: These are pretty god, what flavour is this?
response: Guess.

speaker: Papaya?
response: No.

speaker: Guava?
response: You’re so close.

speaker: I give up.
response: Mango, caterpillar. What are you doing? You said you liked it!

speaker: My point is, if I were a horse or a bird, I’d be very nervous around James Cameron.
response: It amazes me how you constantly obsess over fictional details when there are more important things in the real world to worry about. For example, why wasn’t William Shatner in the new Star Trek movie?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I was up in the administration office, and I happened to overhear the name of the winner of this year’s Chancellor’s Award for Science.
response: And you want to rub my nose in the fact that my contributions are being overlooked again? I am the William Shatner of theoretical physics. All right, I’ll play. What self-important, preening fraud are they honouring this year?

speaker: Oh, I’m so glad you asked it like that. You.
response: I won?

speaker: You won.
response: I won! This is astonishing. Not that I won the award, no one deserves it more. Actually, I guess I misspoke. It’s not astonishing, more like inevitable. I’m not sure what to do first. Maybe I should call my mother. Wait! I know, I’m going to conduct an interview with myself and post it online.

speaker: Hey, you didn’t want a Slurpee at 7-Eleven, you don’t get glasses.
response: Oh, that will be another congratulatory call for me. Uh, mute, please.

speaker: Uh, hang on, flaming arrow.
response: Hello? Oh, Chancellor Morton, how are you, sir? Yes, I was expecting your call (aside) three years ago. I see. Wait. What happens if I choose not to give a speech? Uh-huh. And if I don’t want to forfeit the award? Well, you’ve got that tied up in a neat little bow. All right. Thank you. (Hangs up) Problem.

speaker: What?
response: They expect me to give a speech at the banquet. I can’t give a speech.

speaker: Yeah, before the movie, you did 20 minutes on why guacamole turns brown. It turned brown while you were talking.
response: I am perfectly comfortable speaking to small groups. I cannot speak to large crowds.

speaker: What, to you, is a large crowd?
response: Any group big enough to trample me to death. General rule of thumb is 36 adults or 70 children.

speaker: Sheldon, congratulations. Brought you cheesecake from work. You know, ’cause of your award, not because a busboy sneezed on it.
response: I’m not accepting the award.

speaker: That’s no reason to back out. You know, I once got a pretty big honour in high school, and I was terrified about appearing in front of a big crowd, but I went through with it, and you know what? The world looked pretty darn good sitting on a haystack in the back of a Ford F-150 as a member of the Corn Queen’s court.
response: Thank you. Yeah, I’ll bear that in mind if I’m ever nominated for the Hillbilly Peace Prize.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re being ridiculous.
response: Am I? Let me tell you a story.

speaker: Where’s 70 children when you need ‘em?
response: I was 14 and graduating summa cum laude from college. Summa cum laude is Latin for with highest honours.

speaker: I just love how you always skip over the part where no one asks.
response: I was valedictorian and expected to give an address. Even now, I can remember that moment when I walked up to the podium and looked out at the crowd. There must have been thousands of people. My heart started pounding in my chest. I began to hyperventilate. My vision became blurry, and before I knew it… oh, dear. (He faints.)

speaker: Sheldon? Sheldon, are you okay?
response: Don’t trample me.

speaker: Sit down, we want to talk to you.
response: Am I in trouble? Did my mother call you?

speaker: We think we can help you with your stage fright.
response: Oh, I doubt that. I haven’t figured out a way, and I’m much smarter than all of you.

speaker: Yes, but you’re not smarter than all of us put together.
response: Oh, I’m sorry, that is what I meant.

speaker: We can help you. We can be your team. Like, uh, Professor Xavier and his X-Men.
response: I do like the X-Men.

speaker: Oh. I say a lot of things, sweetie. So, how about it, Sheldon?
response: I don’t know. If you’re my X-Men, what are your powers?

speaker: Okay. Well, I am going to take you shopping, get you a nice suit. Might give you more confidence.
response: That’s not exactly a mutation that would get you into Xavier’s School for Gifted Youngsters, but go on. Leonard?

speaker: I thought I could try to analyze you and get to the root of your anxiety.
response: What qualifies you to attempt to understand my mind?

speaker: Raj says he can teach you, what did you call it? I don’t know, some Indian meditation crap.
response: I see. Well, I assume, since the rest of you have set the bar so low, you’re saving the most impressive contribution for last. Go ahead, Howard. Dazzle me.

speaker: My power is the ability to pretend like I give a damn about your piddly-ass problems. And that’s 24-7, buddy.
response: And I appreciate the pretence.

speaker: So, what do you say, Sheldon? Are we your X-Men?
response: No. The X-Men were named for the X in Charles Xavier. Since I am Sheldon Cooper, you will be my C-Men.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon. I’m going to be leading you through a series of meditation exercises. These methods come from the ancient gurus of India and have helped me overcome my own fears.
response: And yet, you can’t speak to women.

speaker: True, but thanks to meditation, I am able to stay in the same room with them without urinating. Now, close your eyes.
response: Okay, but don’t punch me.

speaker: What?
response: When I was little, my sister would say to me, close your eyes, you’ll get a surprise, and then she’d punch me.

speaker: I’m not going to punch you.
response: That’s what my sister used to say.

speaker: Do you want to do this or not?
response: I’m sorry. Proceed.

speaker: All right. Imagine yourself in the one place you feel most at home. Where is that?
response: Sim City. More specifically, the Sim City I designed, Sheldonopolis.

speaker: Okay, you’re in Sheldonopolis.
response: Where exactly? Sheldon Square? Sheldon Towers? Sheldon Stadium, home of the Fighting Sheldons?

speaker: Whatever you like.
response: I thought this was supposed to be a guided meditation.

speaker: Fine. You’re in Sheldon Square.
response: Really? This time of year? It’s a bit nippy.

speaker: Then, put on a sweater.
response: Suppose I could run downtown and pick up something at Shel-Mart.

speaker: Yeah, whatever. Just go buy a sweater.
response: You know, the nice thing about Shel-Mart is I own it, so I get a 15% discount.

speaker: You own the damn thing. Just take a freaking sweater!
response: Look, I didn’t turn a profit last quarter by taking product off the shelves willy-nilly.

speaker: All right. You’ve paid for a sweater, and you’re in Sheldon Square.
response: Hang on. It’s a cardigan. I have to button it. Oh, no.

speaker: What now?
response: A Godzilla-like monster is approaching the city. I have to get my people to safety. People of Sheldonopolis, this is your mayor. Follow me. If the children can’t run, leave them behind. Oh, the simulated horror! (Sound of door slamming) Raj? Just as I suspected. Meditation is nothing but hokum.

speaker: It’ll give you confidence. You know, sometimes when I’m feeling all stressed out about something, I go out and buy a cute top or a fun skirt and I have a whole new outlook on life.
response: Don’t you eventually realize you’re just the same stressed out person in a cute top or a fun skirt?

speaker: Yeah, that’s when I buy shoes. Now, let’s see what we’ve got. Ooh! This is nice.
response: It’s only one colour.

speaker: Yeah, so?
response: That’s a lot of money for only one colour.

speaker: Fine. Why don’t you pick out what you like.
response: Hmm. (Cut to Sheldon exiting changing room in a loud check suit). This is pretty sharp.

speaker: No, you’re wrong.
response: This is great. I had a suit like this when I was six. (Cut to Sheldon exiting in a white dinner suit with tails) Okay, I think we have a winner.

speaker: Where the hell d’you find that?
response: In the prom department.

speaker: It’s ridiculous.
response: Says the former member of the Corn Queen’s Court.

speaker: Please just try this one on.
response: Okay. But anything I put on now is only going to suffer in comparison. (Goes into changing room. Comes out in black suit looking terrific.) This is absurd. I look like a clown.

speaker: So, Sheldon, how you doing?
response: That’s how you start a psychotherapy session? How am I doing? I was promised a riverboat journey into the jungles of my subconscious. Instead, I get the same question I hear from the lady who slices my bologna at Ralph’s.

speaker: I’m sorry, I’ll start again.
response: Would it be helpful to you if I told you about my dreams?

speaker: Um, I don’t know, maybe.
response: I recently had a dream that I was a giant. But everything around me was to scale, so it all looked normal.

speaker: How did you know you were a giant if everything was to scale?
response: I was wearing size a million pants.

speaker: Why don’t we just talk?
response: Ah, the talking cure. Classical Freudian, good choice. If it will help speed things along, uh, my answers to the standard Rorschach ink blot test are A, a bat, B, a bat, C, a bat, and D, my father k*ll my mother with a hypodermic needle.

speaker: Why don’t I just start? Sometimes people have trouble accepting accolades if, on a subconscious level, they don’t feel they deserve them. Do you think maybe that’s what’s happening here?
response: Really, Leonard? You’re just going to try to recycle Adler’s doctrine of the inferiority complex? I could probably get that from the woman at Ralph’s. And she’d let me taste some pieces of cheese for free.

speaker: But it could be part of your problem. Let me give you an example. When I was eight, I won a ribbon at the science fair for my project, “Do Lima Beans Grow Better to Classical Music.” But my mother pointed out that it was just a rehash of my brother’s earlier “Do Lima Beans Grow Worse to Rock ‘n’ Roll.” I felt so guilty, I gave the ribbon back.
response: And how did that make you feel?

speaker: Terrible. I worked really hard on that project. I stayed up all night singing the clown’s aria from Pagliacci to a lima bean sprout.
response: Go on.
