speaker: It wasn’t my fault. I had never seen my brother’s project. And my mother could’ve told me before instead of at the ceremony in front of everyone.
response: So, I hear you saying you’re angry with your mother.

speaker: Damn right, I’m angry with my mother. For God’s sake, I was eight years old. She humiliated me. That’s when the bed-wetting started again.
response: Thank you, Leonard.

speaker: For what?
response: If someone as damaged as you can find his way to crawl out of bed each morning, I think I can face a simple award ceremony.

speaker: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Dr. Leonard Hofstadter, and it is my very great honour to introduce the winner of this year’s Chancellor’s award for Science and my good friend, Dr. Sheldon Cooper. But before I do, I’d like to share with you a letter from Sheldon’s mother, who couldn’t be here tonight. Isn’t that nice? His mother sent him a letter. She’s proud of him. I wonder what that feels like. Dear Shelly. That’s what she calls him. Shelly, it’s a pet name. You know what my mother’s pet name for me is? Leonard. But I digress. Dear Shelly. I am so proud of… (continues as background noise)
response: Oh, dear.

speaker: What’s the matter?
response: I’m getting dizzy.

speaker: Don’t worry. You’re surrounded by your C-Men.
response: I can’t do this. I’m going to faint.

speaker: Here, drink this. It’ll relax you.
response: Alcohol? I don’t drink alcohol.

speaker: Fine, faint.
response: I don’t feel different, this alcohol’s defective.

speaker: First of all, the projects were totally different. I was showing that classical music nurtures lima beans and makes them grow, but my mother didn’t hear me. If you’d like to look at the relationship between nurturing and growth, I’d like to point out that my brother is eight inches taller than me.
response: I’m ready.

speaker: Oh, right. Ladies and gentlemen, our guest of honour, Dr. Sheldon Cooper.
response: Thanks, shorty,I’ll take it from here. All right, you people ready to have some fun? You have a basic understanding of differential calculus and at least one year of algebraic topology? Well, then here come the jokes. Why did the chicken cross the Mobius strip? To get to the same side, bazinga! All right, a neutron walks into a bar and asks, how much for a drink? The bartender says, for you, no charge. Hello? I know you’re out there. I can hear you metabolizing oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide. Looks like we have some academic dignitaries in the audience. Dr. Randall from the geology department, only man who’s happy when they take his work for granite. Ba-da cha! I kid the geologists, of course, but it’s only ’cause I have no respect for the field. Let’s get serious for a moment. Why are we all here? ‘Cause we’re scientists. And what do scientists study? The universe. And what’s the universe made of? I am so glad you asked. (Singing) There’s antimony, arsenic, aluminium, selenium, and hydrogen and oxygen and nitrogen and rhenium, and nickel, neodymium,

speaker: Sure.
response: Question one, where are my pants?

speaker: You might want to check YouTube.
response: What do I search?

speaker: All right, people, let’s get down to the math. It is only three dimensional thinking that limits our imagination. Can I take my pants off over my head? Of course not. My body’s in the way. But if we had access to higher dimensions, we could move our pants around our bodies through the fourth dimension and our days of dropping trousers would be over.
response: Oh, Lord, this couldn’t be any more humiliating.

speaker: It’s from Game of Thrones. What do you think?
response: I don’t know. If we’re going to start a fantasy sword collection, and I’ve long thought we should, is this really the sword to start with?

speaker: What did you have in mind?
response: Well, off the top of my head, I’d have to go with Excalibur. It gives you the right to rule England.

speaker: It would be a replica of a movie prop.
response: Fair enough. It’d give you the right to rule a replica of England.

speaker: Well, they don’t have an Excalibur here, so what do you want to do?
response: Mm. Tough decision. There’s no w*apon from Lord of the Rings, forged in a Chinese sweatshop?

speaker: Just Bilbo Baggins’ sword over there.
response: Two grown men with a hobbit’s dagger; wouldn’t we look silly? Okay, let’s go for it.

speaker: Yeah. It’s okay, I guess.
response: Okay? It’s magnificent.

speaker: Well, it’s a limited edition. They only made 8,000 of these bad boys.
response: Only 8,000? We’re wasting precious time. Buy it.

speaker: Are you kidding? I’m already giving you the friends and family discount.
response: Oh, did you hear that? We’re getting the friends and family discount. We are honoured and we will take it.

speaker: Slow down. Two hundred.
response: What are you doing? Two fifty is already the discounted price.

speaker: Okay, two twenty five, my final offer.
response: Take it, take it.

speaker: Man, you’re k*ll me!
response: k*ll you? I can’t breathe.

speaker: Two ten, and I’m losing money.
response: Oh, now, we can’t let him lose money, Leonard. I’m so sorry.

speaker: See that? I just saved us forty bucks.
response: I’ve long said, what you lack in academic knowledge you make up for in street smarts.

speaker: Ah, hey, Wil.
response: Hello, Wil Wheaton.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon. Nice sword.
response: It’s part of my sword collection. Do you have a sword collection?

speaker: No.
response: I’m not surprised.

speaker: Good deal.
response: Sucker. Didn’t even ask for the friends and family discount.

speaker: All right, great. Later.
response: I see what you’re doing. You accept an invitation to a party at the home of my sworn enemy, he tells everyone we’re going to be there, and when we don’t show, he looks the fool. Fiendishly clever.

speaker: I was actually thinking about going.
response: And then declaring the party a fiasco and storming out, leaving him humiliated in front of his guests. Love it.

speaker: Sheldon, can you grab me a water?
response: Possibly.

speaker: Can you or can’t you?
response: It’s not that simple, Leonard.

speaker: It never is, is it?
response: At this moment, our relationship exists in two mutually contradictory states. Until you either do not go or go to Wil Wheaton’s party, you are simultaneously my friend and not my friend. I’m characterizing this phenomenon as Schrodinger’s Friendship.

speaker: Got it. Can I have my water?
response: Of course. Now get it yourself, you traitor.

speaker: Wait, what is going on?
response: In case you have forgotten, Schrodinger’s cat is a thought experiment…

speaker: It gets better. Someone has to go up with the telescope as a payload specialist, and guess who that someone is.
response: Mohammed Lee.

speaker: Who’s Mohammed Lee?
response: Mohammed is the most common first name in the world, Lee, the most common surname. As I didn’t know the answer, I thought that gave me a mathematical edge.

speaker: Cheers.
response: That was a lovely toast. Kudos.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Simultaneously, a festival of cloying clichés. You sicken me.

speaker: Pretty cool about Howard, huh?
response: Don’t talk to me as if nothing’s happened between us. And yes, it sure is, buddy.

speaker: For God’s sake, will you stop with the Schrodinger stuff.
response: Would you prefer a simpler application of Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, in which I could either know where you are or whether I like you, but not both?

speaker: Sheldon, I know you’re a bit of a left-handed monkey wrench, but, you really have a mortal enemy?
response: In fact, I have 61 of them. Would you like to see the list?

speaker: Oh, say no, say no, say no, say no.
response: You just got off the list. Would you like back on it? This’ll just take a moment. It’s on a five and a quarter inch floppy.

speaker: A floppy disk?
response: Well, I started the list when I was nine.

speaker: Oh! Oh, God!
response: As a child, I loved Wesley Crusher, Wil Wheaton’s character on Star Trek. So, I drove for hours by bus to a Star Trek convention at which Wil Wheaton was scheduled to appear, so that I could get my Wesley Crusher action figure signed. But he never showed, because apparently, it was cooler for him to be the lower-left corner on Hollywood Squares. Oh, damn! The floppy failed. Well, whoever was in charge of quality control at the Verbatim Corporation in 1989, congratulations, you just made the list.

speaker: I hate to say it, but she did kind of betray you.
response: Interesting. You see betrayal in others, but not yourself.

speaker: Going to Wheaton’s party is not betraying you.
response: Oh, of course you would have to believe that. Evil always thinks it’s doing right. Excuse me, Stormtrooper. These are the droids you’re looking for.

speaker: I’m going to a party. I’m not turning R2-D2 and C-3PO over to the empire!
response: Not yet.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, we’re going to Wil’s. This is your last chance.
response: No, Leonard, this is your last chance. One day, a historian is going to come to you and say, is it true you were friends with Dr. Sheldon Cooper? And you’re going to have to choke back a hot sob of regret and humiliation as you mumble, I was, but I chose to go to a party thrown by the one kid from Stand By Me that no one remembers.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon?
response: Oh, good. You picked me, you picked me.

speaker: No, I just got a text from Stuart. Brent Spiner is at the party.
response: Brent Spiner?

speaker: Yes.
response: I don’t care.

speaker: Really? Brent Spiner, Mr. Data himself. You love him.
response: I did, but I think I’ve kind of outgrown Star Trek. You know, stock characters, ludicrous plots, beam me up. What a load of hooey.

speaker: I’m going. Live long and prosper, Sheldon.
response: Yeah, even that. You look like a dork.

speaker: What are you doing here?
response: Fighting for our friendship. As peculiar and annoying as you can be, you’re still my little buddy. I’m not going to let that end here tonight. Now put down that drink, let’s meet Brent Spiner and go home.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, I’m so glad you made it. I found something I think you might like.
response: What I’d like is for him to have a more depressing home. This is quite lovely.

speaker: This is for you.
response: An original mint-in-package Wesley Crusher action figure.

speaker: Look at what I wrote.
response: To Sheldon, sorry this took so long. Your friend, Wil Wheaton.

speaker: It’s my last one. I want you to have it.
response: Look, everyone. Wil Wheaton is my friend!

speaker: Oh, wow. I haven’t seen one of these in years. (Rips open action figure packaging) Remember how we used to make these things look like they were masturbating?
response: Brent Spiner, what have you done? That was an original mint-in-package Wesley Crusher action figure signed by my close personal friend, Wil Wheaton.

speaker: Sorry, Slim. I’ve got some Mr. Data dolls in the trunk of my car. You want me to sign one for you?
response: You’ve already signed something, Brent Spiner. Your name on my list. From this moment on, you are my mortal enemy.

speaker: Don’t worry. It doesn’t take up a whole lot of your time.
response: Come on, buddy. Let’s not waste another second on this loser. Love your house.

speaker: In a world where rhinoceroses are domesticated pets, who wins the Second World w*r?
response: Uganda.

speaker: Defend.
response: Kenya rises to power on the export of rhinoceroses. A Central African power block is formed, colonizing North Africa and Europe. When w*r breaks out, no one can afford the luxury of a rhino. Kenya withers, Uganda triumphs.

speaker: Correct. My turn.
response: In a world where a piano is a w*apon, not a musical instrument, on what does Scott Joplin play The Maple Leaf Rag?

speaker: Tuned bayonets.
response: Defend.

speaker: Isn’t it obvious?
response: You’re right. My apologies.

speaker: What the hell are you guys playing?
response: It’s a game we invented. It’s called Counterfactuals.

speaker: We postulate an alternate world that differs from ours in one key aspect and then pose questions to each other.
response: It’s fun for ages eight to eighty. Join us.

speaker: All right. I like a good brainteaser. Give it a whirl.
response: You’re in luck, this is an easy one. In a world where mankind is ruled by a giant intelligent beaver, what food is no longer consumed?

speaker: Uh, a BLT where the B stands for beaver? I don’t know.
response: Leonard, be serious. We’re playing a game here.

speaker: I can figure this out, let’s see. Um, well, beavers eat tree bark. The only tree bark I know that humans consume is cinnamon. So, I’ll say cinnamon.
response: Incorrect. Obviously, the answer is cheese Danish.

speaker: Is he always like this when he loses?
response: Oh, yes. You should’ve been here for the great Jenga tantrum of 2008.

speaker: If I don’t have to boom-boom.
response: Greetings. You all remember Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: Hello.
response: Sorry we’re late.

speaker: Okay.
response: I believe she’s experiencing her menses.

speaker: Shamy?
response: A juvenile amalgamation of our names. Sheldon and Amy, Shamy.

speaker: Like everybody else’s. Subject to entropy, decay and eventual death. Thank you for asking. Why is she not taking our order?
response: I should’ve warned you, one has to navigate a labyrinth of social nonsense before one can be fed here.

speaker: Really? I assumed an establishment called the Cheesecake Factory would function more efficiently.
response: It’s how they lure you in. I believe it’s called bait and switch.

speaker: I’m curious as to why we’re not eating alone.
response: They can’t function without me. I’m the social glue that holds this little group together. You’re welcome.

speaker: Listen, can I talk to you about your girlfriend?
response: She’s not my girlfriend. She’s a girl and she’s my friend, but there’s no touching or unsanitary exchange of saliva.

speaker: Got it.
response: Although, for the record, on one occasion, she licked her thumb to remove raspberry jelly from the corner of my mouth. It’s an action we both regret to this day.

speaker: Uh-huh. Anyway, I’m not sure she’s the best fit for our little, how should we call it, rebel alliance.
response: Oh, I never identified with the rebel alliance. Despite their tendency to build Death Stars, I’ve always been more of an empire man.

speaker: Yeah, not my point.
response: I know what your point is. You’re intimidated by Amy’s intellect. To that I say, buck up.

speaker: Okay, let me just get right to it. Amy is judgmental, sanctimonious and frankly just obnoxious.
response: So?

speaker: So we already have you for all that.
response: Are you suggesting I terminate my relationship with Amy?

speaker: No, no, of course not. Just have your relationship someplace else.
response: May I point out that for eight long months, I suffered in silence as your female companion filled our apartment with her off-key country music caterwauling, the unappetizing spectacle of her grinding a pumice stone against her calloused feet in our living room, and night after night of uninformative TV documentaries about the Jersey Shore.

speaker: Suffered in silence?
response: Yes. And I’d thank you to do the same.

speaker: More like Yoko and Yoko.
response: Greetings.

speaker: Hey.
response: I brought Amy here to show her some of the work I’m doing.

speaker: It’s very impressive, for theoretical work.
response: Do I detect a hint of condescension?

speaker: Oooh!
response: Are you suggesting the work of a neurobiologist like Babinski could ever rise to the significance of a physicist like Clarke-Maxwell or Dirac?

speaker: I’m stating it outright. Babinski eats Dirac for breakfast and defecates Clarke-Maxwell.
response: You take that back.

speaker: I’m sorry, I’m-I’m still trying to work on the defecating Clark Maxwell, so…
response: Excuse me, but a grand unified theory, insofar as it explains everything, will ipso facto explain neurobiology.

speaker: Yes, but if I’m successful, I will be able to map and reproduce your thought processes in deriving a grand unified theory, and therefore, subsume your conclusions under my paradigm.
response: That’s the rankest psychologism, and was conclusively revealed as hogwash by Gottlob Frege in the 1890s!

speaker: We appear to have reached an impasse.
response: I agree. I move our relationship terminate immediately.

speaker: Seconded.
response: There being no objections…

speaker: No, uh-uh.
response: The motion carries. Good day, Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: Women, huh? Can’t live with them, can’t successfully refute their hypotheses.
response: Amen to that.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Hello.

speaker: I hear you broke up with Amy.
response: A breakup would imply she was my girlfriend. She was a girl who was my friend who is now a girl who is not my friend.

speaker: Wow. That’s like the worst country song ever. So, how are you doing?
response: Regarding what?

speaker: Amy.
response: I don’t follow.

speaker: Well, breakups, or whatever the hell this is, can be tough.
response: Penny, I assure you, I’m fine. My relationship with Amy was purely intellectual. There were no emotional bonds, the severing of which would cause me any discomfort. The relationship simply outlived its utility, and I’m continuing on with my life as before.

speaker: Okay. Good.
response: Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m off to buy a pussycat.

speaker: Don’t try to change me, dude. I am what I am.
response: Oh, gentlemen.

speaker: Hey. Aren’t you going to introduce us to your little friend?
response: My apologies. Raj, Howard, I’d like you to meet Dr. Robert Oppenheimer.

speaker: Hi.
response: Now, if you’ll excuse me, the father of the atomic b*mb wants a saucer of milk.

speaker: Hey. (Turns to see Sheldon now has five cats) Oh, no.
response: Robert Oppenheimer was lonely.

speaker: So you decided to get the whole Manhattan Project?
response: Yes. This is Enrico Fermi, Richard Feynman, Edward Teller, Otto Frisch, and Zazzles.

speaker: Zazzles?
response: I was going to name him Herman von Helmholtz, but he’s so zazzy.

speaker: Okay, we need to talk.
response: About what?

speaker: Cats, Sheldon. You’re clearly upset about Amy being gone, and you’re trying to replace her with a bunch of cats.
response: Clowder.

speaker: What?
response: A group of cats is a clowder. Or a glaring.

speaker: Okay, yeah, fine.
response: It’s the kind of thing you ought to know now that we have one.

speaker: Terrific. My-my point is you need to face up to what you’re feeling with this breakup.
response: It wasn’t a breakup. A breakup would imply that Amy was my girlfriend.

speaker: Okay, I got it, I got it, she’s not your girlfriend. Now listen to me. I know about loneliness. I know about trying to replace someone with other stuff. When I broke up with Penny, I got back into my cello, I built a bunch of model rockets, I got those weightlifting gloves and that five-pound dumbbell.
response: You didn’t break up, she dumped you.

speaker: She didn’t dump me. It was mutual!
response: I was there. She dumped you.

speaker: Okay, fine. Live with cats. Be like my Aunt Nancy. She had dozens of them. And do you know what happened after she died? They ate her.
response: You don’t have to sell me on cats, Leonard. I’m already a fan. All right, fellas, who’s in the mood for Fancy Feast? Well, that’s not fancy at all.

speaker: Hold on to that thought. (Knocks on Sheldon’s bedroom door)
response: Come in. (They enter. The room is full of cats.)

speaker: Surprise.
response: Mom, what an unexpected pleasure.

speaker: My, my, that’s a powerful smell.
response: I’d like you to meet Oppenheimer, Frisch, Panofsky, Feynman, Weisskopf…

speaker: Yeah, I get it. You got a lot of cats and you gave ‘em cute Jewish names.
response: What are you doing here?

speaker: Leonard called, and he said that you were pining for a young lady.
response: Oh, that’s preposterous. I’m not pining over anyone.

speaker: Oh, lambchop, we can quibble what to call it, but I think we can both agree it’s creepy.
response: I do not agree. Cats make wonderful companions. They don’t argue or question my intellectual authority, and this little guy here, I think you’ll find to be quite zazzy.

speaker: Shelly! Dinner’s ready!
response: Coming!

speaker: No cats!
response: Aw.(Enters to find Amy) What is she doing here?

speaker: Your mother thinks you might be losing your mind over me. As a neurobiologist, I was curious.
response: Well, rest assured, I am in full possession of my faculties.

speaker: Oh, God bless you, dear. Sheldon, sit down. Let’s talk.
response: All right, but you’re not fooling me. Whenever you say we have to talk, it means you want me to listen.

speaker: Then stop talking.
response: Yes, ma’am.

speaker: Now, the reason I called Amy over was to find out what type of person she is. And after chatting a bit, I have to say that while she is a perfectly unique young woman, you two are definitely not suited for each other.
response: That’s a peculiar conclusion. By any standard, Amy is more similar to me than anyone I’ve ever met.

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, Shelly, I can’t see it.
response: Well, whether you see it or not is irrelevant. I can’t see subatomic particles, but nevertheless, they’re there.

speaker: Excellent point.
response: A physics point.

speaker: Well, putting aside the pig Latin, it’s a good thing that you two decided to end the relationship so I didn’t have to end it for you.
response: Amy, after consideration, I believe we may have acted rashly. I propose we resume our relationship and attempt to resolve our differences.

speaker: I’ll agree to that only if you’ll stipulate that 80% of our difficulties were caused by you.
response: I’ll go as high as 40.

speaker: Sixty-five.
response: Done. You understand that moving forward, we deal with the fact that my mother does not approve of you?

speaker: I do. I find being cast in the role of bad girl oddly titillating.
response: Would you like to see my cats?

speaker: I would. I love cats. They’re the epitome of indifference.
response: Ah, then you may find Zazzles a little cloying.

speaker: Next!
response: Thank you, Amy. Here’s your cat. And here’s your $20.

speaker: What?
response: Explain your sneeze.

speaker: I’m sorry?
response: Do you have allergies?

speaker: No.
response: Is there too much pepper on your salad?

speaker: I don’t put pepper on salads.
response: I’ve heard enough. Sit over there.

speaker: Oh, come on. I don’t want to sit by myself.
response: That’s what Typhoid Mary said, and clearly, her friends buckled.

speaker: See you, buddy.
response: Oh, Leonard, I have something for you. Per our roommate agreement, this is your 24-hour notice that I will be having a non-related female spending two nights in our apartment.

speaker: When you say non-related female, you still mean human, right?
response: Of course. Pets are banned under the roommate agreement, with the exception of service animals, such as seeing eye dogs and, one day, cybernetically-enhanced helper monkeys.

speaker: Are you planning on kidnapping a woman?
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: Yes, but mixed with genuine concern.
response: For your information, I’ll be playing host to Dr. Elizabeth Plimpton.

speaker: The cosmological physicist from Princeton?
response: Yes. And until you acquire a surgical mask, please address your comments to me through a napkin. We’ve been corresponding for years about our mutual interest in gravitational wave signatures of inflatons in the early universe. And now she’s under consideration for a position at our university.

speaker: Why didn’t you tell me you knew Elizabeth Plimpton? I am a huge fan of hers!
response: I didn’t realize I was obligated to share my connection with things you’re a fan of, but very well. You enjoy Canadian bacon. I’ve been to Toronto.

speaker: Okay, fine. Where is she going to sleep?
response: My room, of course.

speaker: Yeah, um, I have a two-part question.
response: Go ahead.

speaker: A, are you kidding me? And B, seriously, are you freaking kidding me?
response: A, I rarely kid. And B, when I do kid, you will know it by my use of the word bazinga.

speaker: So you’re saying the two of you are going to be sleeping in the same bed?
response: Yes. Bazinga. Leonard?

speaker: Thank you. Why is a world-renowned scientist staying in our apartment instead of a hotel?
response: Well, she doesn’t care for hotels. And who can blame her? Windows that don’t open, multi-user linens, keys shaped like credit cards, as if one walks around with unassigned slots in one’s wallet. All right, I believe I have time for one more question. Yes, Raj?

speaker: When can I sit with you again?
response: When I’ve seen two consecutive negative throat cultures spaced 12 hours apart. You know the drill. All right, if you’ll excuse me, I am off to start a prophylactic course of antibiotics.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon.
response: Oh, Penny, excellent. I have a question about these maxi pads. Are the wings truly functional or have I fallen victim to marketing hype?

speaker: What? What are you doing with, what?
response: The stock boy at Walgreens was frustratingly uninformed on the subject.

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing with maxi pads?
response: I have a lady friend who will be staying with me for a few days.

speaker: Oh. What?
response: I want her to feel at home. I also bought scented soaps, pantyhose, Midol, calcium chews and what is apparently a yogurt specifically designed to regulate the female bowel.

speaker: Wait, wait, hold on, back up. You’re having a woman stay with you?
response: Yes. Why does that seem to flabbergast everybody?

speaker: Oh, no, no, no, no. I’m not flabbergasted. I’m puzzled. Yeah, let’s go with puzzled.
response: A word of warning. My guest is a noted physicist and the leading expert on quantum cosmology, so please try to avoid wasting her time with female jibber jabber.

speaker: Female jibber jabber?
response: Shoe sales, hair styles, mud masks, gossip about your friends Brad and Angelina.

speaker: Oh, they’re not my friends.
response: I’m not surprised, considering the way you talk about them behind their backs.

speaker: She’s here, she’s here. How do I look? Do I look smart?
response: Oh, good grief. This isn’t about you. Coming! Now listen, one of the great minds of the 21st century is about to play host to one of the other great minds of the 21st century. So pay attention. Years from now, my biographer might ask you about this event.

speaker: Ah, Dr. Cooper, thank goodness. I completely forgot your address. But then I remembered that I’d written it on my hand. Lucky for me, I didn’t confuse it with what I’d written on my other hand, which are the coordinates for a newly discovered neutron star. ‘Cause if I tried to go there, I’d be crushed by hypergravity. Anyway, hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: Nice to finally meet you in person.
response: I would imagine it is. This is my friend and roommate, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.

speaker: Hi-lo. Oops. I started to say hi, and then I switched to hello in the middle. It came out hi-lo. Duh. Uh, it’s nice to meet you. I’ve read both your books and most of your papers. I’m Leonard, I live
response: I apologize. He’s only an experimental physicist.

speaker: Are you hungry, thirsty? Can I offer you anything?
response: No, she’s my guest. If anyone should offer her anything, it should be me. Elizabeth, can I get you something? Perhaps a feminine hygiene product or a bowel-regulating yogurt?

speaker: Interesting choices. Based on my current needs, I guess I’d pick the yogurt.
response: Excellent. If the yogurt works, I bought some delightful scented candles.

speaker: I’m so glad you understand.
response: No, he doesn’t understand. I understand.

speaker: Well, I understand, too.
response: You’re just misappropriating my understanding.

speaker: Oh, (blows a raspberry). I think any university would want you. Except, of course, any university that had already had you. Because they would’ve already wanted you before they, you know, got you.
response: From the mind that brought you hi-lo. Let me show you to your room.

speaker: Uh, sleep night. I mean, obviously, good night. I started to say sleep tight, then I changed my mind in the middle. I swear to God, I’m smart.
response: Get it together, man.

speaker: Good to know.
response: In here, you’ll find emergency provisions. An eight-day supply of food and water, a crossbow, season two of Star Trek

speaker: What if there’s a disaster that destroys all the USB ports?
response: Then there’s really no reason to live, is there?

speaker: Can I ask a question about your roommate?
response: He’s an odd duck, isn’t he?

speaker: What’s his relationship status?
response: Well, there was a misbegotten adventure with a waitress who lives across the hall. It ended as inexplicably as it began. They had very little in common, except for carnal activity. That’s why I acquired these noise-cancelling headphones. If you decide to use them, please clean the ear pieces afterwards with the Wet Wipes you’ll find in the bathroom. They’re in the drawer labelled Wet Wipes.

speaker: Okay.
response: Good. I’ll leave you to your night time ablutions. I’ve e-mailed you the morning bathroom schedule. You’ll also find a laminated copy in your welcome packet. It’s on the back of the emergency escape route diagram.

speaker: How thoughtful.
response: Sleep well, my friend.

speaker: You, too.
response: Oh, let me just get one thing. It’s my backup emergency supply kit. The living room escape route doesn’t pass through here. Now, good night. And if there’s an apocalypse, good luck.

speaker: Morning, Sheldon.
response: Morning.

speaker: Morning, Sheldon.
response: Morning. I trust you had a pleasant night.

speaker: More than pleasant.
response: Excuse me, I’m going to relieve myself.

speaker: Okeydoke.
response: Pee for Houston, pee for Austin, pee for the state my heart got lost in. And shake twice for Texas.

speaker: Something his mother taught him.
response: All right, Elizabeth, the bathroom is yours. The seat is down, and has been sanitized for your protection.

speaker: That’s very thoughtful, but I think I’ll finish my coffee first.
response: Ah, so the yogurt didn’t work. I’ll fire off a critical e-mail to the manufacturer.

speaker: Oh, good, you’re up. Look, my car won’t start. I need a ride to work.
response: Did you once again ignore your check engine light?

speaker: No, Mr. smarty-pants. I ignored the fill gas t*nk light.
response: Leonard, Penny wants to exploit any residual feelings you have for her in order to get a ride to work.

speaker: Good.
response: Wonderful. Meaningless pleasantries accomplished. Elizabeth, Leonard’s bathroom time is coming up, and believe me, you do not want to follow him.

speaker: Well, now…
response: Excuse me. I’m uncomfortable with you recommending that Leonard pursue having intercourse with Dr. Plimpton, who I assure you has better things to do.

speaker: I’m not recommending it. I’m saying it already happened.
response: That’s preposterous. Tell her, Leonard.

speaker: Well…
response: No.

speaker: Come on. It wasn’t my fault.
response: The implication being that you somehow tripped and fell into her lady parts?

speaker: Oh, no, no, it’s okay. You might slip on a banana peel and get me pregnant.
response: I must say, I’m shocked by this betrayal.

speaker: I didn’t betray Penny.
response: Not Penny, me!

speaker: How am I betraying you?
response: Elizabeth’s my friend, and you’re playing with her!

speaker: It is if you love her and give her a name.
response: Dr. Plimpton, I’d like you to meet my colleagues, Dr. Rajesh Koothrappali

speaker: Hi.
response: And not-a-doctor Howard Wolowitz.

speaker: Thank you.
response: And of course, you’ve already introduced yourself to Dr. Hofstadter.

speaker: What if he gets something Kryptonian on it?
response: Like what?

speaker: I don’t know. Kryptonian mustard.
response: I think we can safely assume that all Kryptonian condiments were destroyed when the planet Krypton exploded.

speaker: Yeah, what about Kryptonian pit stains?
response: Superman doesn’t sweat on Earth.

speaker: Booya.
response: Superman would have taken his uniform to a Kandorian dry cleaner before he left the Bottle.

speaker: It’s David Underhill. So what?
response: So what? His observation of high-energy positrons has provided the first conclusive evidence for the existence of galactic dark matter.

speaker: I have two words for you. The first is big, the other’s whoop.
response: It is a big whoop. It made almost all the work you’ve done since you’ve been here completely useless.

speaker: That doesn’t count. Do over! Do over!
response: There are no do-overs in Wii bowling.

speaker: There are always do-overs when my people play sports.
response: Where were you that’s more important than Wii bowling night?

speaker: Actually, I was…
response: It’s a rhetorical question. There is nothing more important than Wii bowling night.

speaker: Come on, it’s just a video game. And we suck at it.
response: Nice motivational speech from the team captain.

speaker: No, we play Rock Band on our X-Box.
response: Nice motivational speech from our lead guitarist.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, are you and Leonard putting up a Christmas tree?
response: No, because we don’t celebrate the ancient pagan festival of Saturnalia.

speaker: Gather round, kids, it’s time for Sheldon’s beloved Christmas special.
response: In the pre-Christian era, as the winter solstice approached and the plants died, pagans brought evergreen boughs into their homes as an act of sympathetic magic, intended to guard the life essences of the plants until spring. This custom was later appropriated by Northern Europeans and eventually it becomes the so-called Christmas tree.

speaker: Okay, well, thank you for that, but I got you and Leonard a few silly neighbour gifts, so I’ll just put them under my tree.
response: Wait! You bought me a present?

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Why would you do such a thing?

speaker: I don’t know. ‘Cause it’s Christmas?
response: Oh, Penny. I know you think you’re being generous, but the foundation of gift-giving is reciprocity. You haven’t given me a gift, you’ve given me an obligation.

speaker: Now, honey, it’s okay.You don’t have to get me anything in return.
response: Of course I do. The essence of the custom is that I now have to go out and purchase for you a gift of commensurate value and representing the same perceived level of friendship as that represented by the gift you’ve given me. It’s no wonder su1c1de rates skyrocket this time of year.

speaker: Okay, you know what? Forget it. I’m not giving you a present.
response: No, it’s too late. I see it. That elf sticker says to Sheldon. The die has been cast, the moving finger has writ, Hannibal has crossed the Alps.

speaker: Sheldon, I am very, very sorry.
response: No. No, I brought this on myself by being such an endearing and important part of your life. I’m going to need a ride to the mall.

speaker: See ya. ‘Bye, Penny. Have fun. (Bangs head on door. Sheldon opens it.)
response: Yes? (Leonard falls through) Did you forget your key?

speaker: Sheldon, if you don’t like this stuff, let’s just go next door and build her a bear.
response: I told you before, bears are terrifying.

speaker: Come on, bath stuff, it’s perfect! You got a scented candle, a cleansing buff, spearmint and green tea scented bath oil, promotes relaxation.
response: That presupposes Penny is tense.

speaker: Excuse me, we’re ready.
response: No, we’re not. Let’s say for a moment that I accept the bath item gift hypothesis, I now lay the following conundrum at your feet, which size?

speaker: This one. Let’s go.
response: You put no thought into that.

speaker: I’m sorry. Uh, this one. Let’s go!
response: I have insufficient data to proceed. Excuse me, miss?

speaker: Yes?
response: If I were to give you this gift basket, based on that action alone and no other data, infer and describe the hypothetical relationship that exists between us.

speaker: Excuse me?
response: Here. Now, are we friends? Colleagues? Lovers? Are you my grandmother?

speaker: Yippee.
response: You see, the danger was that I might under or over-reciprocate, but I have devised a foolproof plan. See, I will open her gift to me first and then excuse myself, feigning digestive distress.

speaker: Brilliant.
response: It is, isn’t it? Is it okay if I hide them in your room? The smell makes me nauseated.

speaker: Do whatever you want.
response: Thank you, that’s very gracious. Gentlemen.

speaker: Very good, thanks for asking. Come on in.
response: Ah, good, Penny, you’re here to exchange gifts. You’ll be pleased to know I’m prepared for whatever you have to offer.

speaker: Okay, here.
response: I should note I’m having some digestive distress, so, if I excuse myself abruptly, don’t be alarmed. Oh, a napkin.

speaker: Turn it over.
response: To Sheldon, live long and prosper. Leonard Nimoy.

speaker: Yeah, he came into the restaurant. Sorry the napkin’s dirty. He wiped his mouth with it.
response: I possess the DNA of Leonard Nimoy?!

speaker: Well, yeah, yeah, I guess. But look, he signed it.
response: Do you realize what this means? All I need is a healthy ovum and I can grow my own Leonard Nimoy!

speaker: Okay, all I’m giving you is the napkin, Sheldon.
response: Be right back.

speaker: Sheldon! What did you do?!
response: I know! It’s not enough, is it? Here.

speaker: No, we agreed they all have their merits. This was about Bernadette.
response: What’s going on?

speaker: Howard’s gonna sleep here tonight. He had a fight with his mother.
response: Did you offer him a hot beverage?

speaker: No.
response: Leonard, social protocol states when a friend is upset, you offer them a hot beverage, such as tea.

speaker: Tea does sound nice.
response: You heard the man, Leonard. And while you’re at it, I’m upset that we have an unannounced houseguest, so make me cocoa. Point of inquiry, given that Leonard is your secondary friend and Koothrappali is your primary friend, why didn’t you seek refuge under his roof?

speaker: Wait, wait. What?
response: Cocoa, Leonard. Focus. I’m down in the dumps here.

speaker: Yeah, that’s a real pickle. Bye.
response: Don’t worry. As your tertiary friend, I am prepared to step in and comfort you.

speaker: That’s not really necessary.
response: No, no. I’ll finish making the tea, while you narcissistically ramble on about whatever’s troubling you.

speaker: Thanks.
response: That’s what tertiary friends are for.

speaker: That’s very nice of you, but I made other plans.
response: Well, just keep in mind that should you ever need a slightly apathetic tertiary friend, I stand at the ready.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Listen, Rajesh, Leonard and I have decided to see each other again, and you don’t get to tell me who I can and can’t have a relationship with.
response: Actually, he can. The Hindu Code of Manu is very clear in these matters. If a woman’s father is not around, the duty of controlling her base desires falls to the closest male member of her family, in this case, Raj. The code also states that if she disobeys, she will be reborn in the womb of a jackal and tormented by diseases. If true, that seems like an awfully large gamble given that the prize is Leonard.

speaker: Oh, yeah, you, too.
response: Priya, if you’re experiencing any tension or awkwardness, it may stem from the fact that Leonard and Penny used to, if I may quote Howard, do the dance with no pants.

speaker: Ooh, I thought I smelled pizza.
response: That’s remarkable. If pepperoni were an expl*sive substance, you could replace German shepherds at our nation’s airports.

speaker: Oh, yes. Hi, hi. I’m sorry. I didn’t know you had company. I don’t want to impose.
response: No, no. It’s not an imposition. At this point, in our ecosystem, you are akin to the plover, a small scavenging bird that eats extra food from between the teeth of crocodiles. Please, fly into our open maw, and have at it.

speaker: Oh, yeah, yeah. It’s real great. Today I drove to Van Nuys for an audition I thought was going to be for a cat food commercial. Turned out to be p*rn.
response: Did you get the part?

speaker: I didn’t do the audition.
response: Given the state of your career, can you really afford to be picky?

speaker: I smell Chinese food.
response: It’s actually Thai. You’re slipping.

speaker: Are Leonard and Priya here?
response: They went to Catalina for the weekend.

speaker: Oh. Where’s Raj?
response: At home, forbidding it.

speaker: How about Howard?
response: I’m given to understand his mother grounded him for running away.

speaker: Oh, okay. Well, I guess it’s just the two of us, huh?
response: Actually, it’s the three of us.

speaker: Sheldon, you have a guest who’s upset.
response: Right. I’ll make tea.

speaker: Oh, sweetie, it’s okay. I don’t want tea.
response: I’m sorry. It’s not optional.

speaker: No, seriously, I think I’ve finally figured out my problem with women.
response: The capybara is the largest member of the rodent family.

speaker: What does that have to do with me and women?
response: Nothing. It was a desperate attempt to introduce an alternate topic of conversation.

speaker: Good news. I made it onto the team for the new Defence Department laser-equipped surveillance satellite.
response: Excuse me. If we’re changing topics, I believe I have first dibs with capybara, a rodent the size of a baby hippo.

speaker: Nobody cares. Do you know how long it’s been since I got through airport security without being given a colonoscopy?
response: You know, I try very hard to make our lunch hours educational and informative, but your insistence on talking about your own lives stymies me at every turn.

speaker: Fine, Sheldon, tell us about your giant rodents.
response: No, you squandered your time with me, and the moment has now passed. Feast on your disappointment, much as the capybara feasts on its own waste.

speaker: Want to get that?
response: Not particularly.

speaker: Could you get that?
response: I suppose I could if I were asked.

speaker: Would you please get that?
response: Of course. Why do you have to make things so complicated?

speaker: Dr. Cooper?
response: Yes.

speaker: I’m Special Agent Page, FBI.
response: You say you’re Special Agent Page, FBI.

speaker: Here’s my I.D.
response: And here is my Justice League membership card. But that doesn’t prove I know Batman.

speaker: I just want to ask you a few questions about Howard Wolowitz.
response: Oh. All right. I doubt anyone would risk the stiff penalties for impersonating a federal officer just to ask questions about a minor league engineer with an unresolved Oedipal complex.

speaker: Thank you.
response: For the record, I truly support the FBI in the mission which is expressed through their motto?

speaker: Fidelity, bravery, integrity?
response: Correct. Now to business. 18 years ago, I sent the FBI Crime Lab samples from a bag of excrement that had been lit on fire on my front porch for fingerprinting and DNA analysis. Why haven’t I heard back yet?

speaker: Well, the FBI Crime Lab does have a lot on its plate.
response: That’s of little comfort to a nation attempting to scrape burning feces off its shoes.

speaker: Would you mind if we talked about Mr. Wolowitz now?
response: A little, but go on.

speaker: Thank you. Would you characterize him as responsible?
response: I’m going to answer that with a visual aid. This is my nine-disc complete Lord of the Rings trilogy blu-ray set. Mr. Wolowitz borrowed it, damaged plastic retention hub number three, and then returned it to me, hoping I wouldn’t notice. Would you characterize that as responsible?

speaker: That’s really not the sort of thing we’re interested in.
response: You heard me say blu-ray, right?

speaker: I did.
response: Very well. Would you be interested in knowing that Mr. Wolowitz once snuck onto my World of Warcraft account and changed the name of a certain level-80 warlock from Sheldor to Smeldor?

speaker: I’m afraid not. Is there anything else?
response: Is there anything else? Where would you like to start? He refuses to pay fines when he’s overdue with books I lend him. He crashed the Mars Rover while attempting to impress a woman. He recommended that I go see the third Matrix movie because it was, and I quote, just as good as the first one. If that’s not irresponsible, I don’t know what is.

speaker: The Mars Rover?
response: Did I say Mars Rover?

speaker: You did.
response: That was actually a poorly chosen example, as it had nothing to do with me.

speaker: Yes, well, let’s talk about it anyway.
response: I don’t want to. Not that my disinclination to discuss the topic should be interpreted as evidence of Howard Wolowitz’s culpability in the destruction of government property worth millions of dollars.

speaker: Thank you, Dr. Cooper. I think I have all I need.
response: Oh, good. I was afraid you were going to fixate on that Mars Rover incident.

speaker: To tell you the truth, I thought if anyone was going to screw things up for Howard, it’d be Sheldon.
response: Well, your expectations have been subverted. Aha.

speaker: What are you doing up?
response: Sleep eludes me, Leonard.

speaker: Really? Maybe sleep has met you before.
response: Mockery? That’s all you have to offer?

speaker: I’m sorry. Why can’t you sleep?
response: Who knows? I haven’t watched any scary movies recently. I’m no longer obsessing over why the predicted mass of the quantum vacuum has little effect on the expansion of the universe. And it’s been weeks since I took that accidental sip of Red Bull.

speaker: Did something happen today that’s bothering you?
response: Well, I did mention the Mars Rover incident to that FBI agent and probably cost Howard his security clearance.

speaker: What?
response: But why should that keep me up?

speaker: Because you feel guilty?
response: Interesting. So you’re saying my insomnia is caused by a guilty conscience.

speaker: Actually, you don’t have insomnia. You’re sleeping now.
response: Excuse me?

speaker: You’re having a guilt-ridden dream.
response: Do you have any evidence to support that hypothesis?

speaker: How about that Gorn sitting on the couch?
response: That seems fairly conclusive. (In his bed) No, Gorn, no. That’s where I sit.

speaker: Thank you for filing a complaint with my superior, Dr. Cooper. I understand you want to recant your statement about Howard Wolowitz.
response: Yes.

speaker: Was your statement untrue?
response: No.

speaker: Then I’m afraid you can’t withdraw it.
response: I’m sorry. I don’t recall you saying no backsies.

speaker: Is there anything else?
response: Yes. I’d like to offer a laudatory statement about Howard’s many excellent qualities that I believe will tip the scales back in his favour. Howard Joel Wolowitz. H is for honesty, of which he has much. O’s for outstanding, which he is such. W’s for witty, he’s quick with a joke. A’s for artistic, his ability…

speaker: I’m sorry, Dr. Cooper, this matter is already closed.
response: But I still have rd Joel Wolowitz left to go.

speaker: It’s closed.
response: I don’t understand why you people are picking on my friend, Howard, when there are much more serious security threats to pursue. For instance, when I first met Leonard, he was on the verge of giving away rocket secrets to a North Korean spy, and not one agent ever investigated that.

speaker: This is Leonard Hofstadter?
response: No, it’s a different Leonard. He’s Chinese, red hair, six fingers. Good-bye.

speaker: I think he’s eating lunch. Uh, Sheldon, I want you to meet Neil deGrasse Tyson from the Hayden Planetarium in New York.
response: I’m quite familiar with Dr. Tyson. He’s responsible for the demotion of Pluto from planetary status. I liked Pluto. Ergo I do not like you.

speaker: But I actually didn’t demote Pluto. That was a vote of the International Astronomical Union.
response: If ifs and buts were candy and nuts, we’d all have a merry Christmas. Think about that, Dr. Tyson.

speaker: You?
response: Yes, but before you get upset, I want you to know I went to the FBI and retracted my statement.

speaker: And they were okay with that?
response: No. If anything, I made it worse. In any case, I have been riddled with guilt, which is causing Gorn-infested REM sleep. So, I’m here now to say I’m sorry.

speaker: Are you kidding me? You’ve set my career back at least two years, and you think you can make it right with I’m sorry?
response: Yes. I followed the social protocol. I attempted to right the wrong, and when I failed to do so I delivered a heartfelt apology. Now you say apology accepted, and I will offer you a one-time-only high five.

speaker: Your apology is not accepted.
response: You’re tricking me. It really is, isn’t it?

speaker: Dr. Cooper, I just wanted you to know I’m sorry for the role I played in the Pluto matter.
response: Oh, shut up.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Hello.

speaker: What are you doing here?
response: I have troubles, Penny. I’ve come to pour them out to the sympathetic ear of the local barkeep.

speaker: You know, they have a really nice bar over at the Olive Garden.
response: I don’t like the Olive Garden. They treat me like family.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon. What can I get you?
response: Alcohol.

speaker: Could you be a little more specific?
response: Ethyl alcohol. 40 millilitres.

speaker: I’m sorry, honey, I don’t know millilitres.
response: Ah. Blame President James “Jimmy” Carter. He started America on a path to the metric system but then just gave up. He wonders why he was a one-term president.

speaker: Would you say that’s about 40 milliliters?
response: More or less.

speaker: Great. (Drinks the tequila) Now, where were we?
response: I believe you were about to ask me to choose a cocktail. Fortunately, thanks to computer-savvy alcoholics, there’s an app for that. Let’s see. Harvey Wallbanger. Eh. Sex on the Beach. I hardly think so. Rob Roy, Silk Slipper, Mad Hatter. Ooh! I’ll have a Rosewater Ricky.

speaker: A what?
response: You’ll need pitted, brandied cherries, gin, rosewater, angostura bitters and overproofed rum. Now, first, dust the cherries with sugar, then spray them with a mixture of rum and bitters. Then ignite the rum, caramel…

speaker: Here you go, one Rosewater Ricky.
response: That’s not how it looks in the picture.

speaker: Oh, yeah, you know, every bartender makes it differently. Why don’t you give it a try.
response: All right. To the metric system. (Knocks back drink. Spits it all back into glass.) I can’t taste the cherries.

speaker: All right. Sheldon, what’s on your mind?
response: I wronged Howard, and he won’t accept my apology.

speaker: Oh, right, that. Yes, Leonard told me. Sorry, honey.
response: Penny, you face failure on a daily basis. How do you cope?

speaker: I drink.
response: To drinking. (Knocks back drink and spits it out again.) Nope. Oh, if only there were some way to force Howard to accept my apology so I could escape this miasma of guilt.

speaker: You know, sometimes stuff just happens, and there’s nothing you can do about it. For example, Lisa Peterson hasn’t talked to me since the 11th grade, because no matter how much you apologize, you can’t go back and un-dry-hump someone’s boyfriend.
response: I see. You’re saying I’m facing Starfleet Academy’s unwinnable command scenario, the Kobayashi Maru.

speaker: Exactly. Sometimes you can’t win.
response: Captain Kirk won.

speaker: Kirk cheated.
response: Impressive that you know that. It’s hard to believe I’m actually having this conversation with you.

speaker: Right there with you.
response: Kirk b*at the Kobayashi Maru by reprogramming the simulator. That’s it.

speaker: What?
response: I’ll reprogram Howard.

speaker: What? Sheldon, you can’t reprogram people.
response: No, you can’t reprogram people. To James Tiberius Kirk. (Drinks. Leaves. Comes back and spits it out again.)

speaker: Hey.
response: Howard, you’re feeling better about me today, aren’t you?

speaker: Not really.
response: Yes, you are. I’m using neurolinguistic programming to modify your thought patterns.

speaker: Oh. Go away, Sheldon.
response: There’s a nine ninety five e-book down the drain.

speaker: What’s in the bag?
response: It’s for Howard.

speaker: Oh. Sheldon, you can’t fix this with gifts.
response: Nevertheless, I’ve hurt you, and whether you forgive me or not, I want you to have this.

speaker: You’re giving me a couch cushion?
response: No. The cushion is merely symbolic. I’m giving you my spot on the couch.

speaker: But you love that spot.
response: No. I love my mother. My feelings for my spot are much greater. It is the singular location in space around which revolves my entire universe. And now it’s yours.

speaker: All right. Apology accepted.
response: High five. Not too hard. Thank you.

speaker: I got to tell you, Sheldon, I understand why you chose this spot. I mean, the temperature is good, but there’s no draft. I can see the television, but I can still talk to…
response: I changed my mind. Get out of my spot.

speaker: What’s going on?
response: They stole everything, Leonard, everything.

speaker: Oh, my God, what did they get?
response: What didn’t they get? They got my enchanted w*apon, my vicious gladiator armour, my wand of untainted power, and all my gold.

speaker: You called the police because someone hacked your World of Warcraft account?
response: What choice did I have? The mighty Sheldor, level 85 blood elf, hero of the Eastern kingdoms, has been picked clean, like a carcass in the desert sun. Plus, the FBI hung up on me.

speaker: Into the bag.
response: They took my battle ostrich.

speaker: Oh, no, not Glenn?
response: Yes, Glenn! The only bird I ever loved.

speaker: Thank you, officer.
response: Wait a minute! You’re not going to do anything?

speaker: Mr. Cooper, there’s nothing…
response: Doctor Cooper.

speaker: Fine. Dr. Cooper. I’m sorry for your loss, but the Pasadena Police Department doesn’t have jurisdiction in Pandora.
response: That’s from Avatar, World of Warcraft takes place in Azeroth. Goodness gracious, how are you allowed to carry a g*n? Can you at least refer me to a rogue ex-cop?

speaker: What?
response: You know, one who was drummed off the force because he refused to play by the rules, and now he hires himself out to impose his own brand of rough justice?

speaker: Thank you, officer.
response: It’s all gone. All gone.

speaker: I’m really sorry, Sheldon.
response: What kind of world do we live in, where a man would take another man’s battle ostrich?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: This act of aggression must be met with swift and cruel ferocity. It is time to cry havoc, and let slip the dogs of w*r.

speaker: I’m on it. (On phone) Hi, Mrs. Wolowitz. Is, is Howard there? Okay, thanks. That particular dog of w*r will have to call you back after his bath.
response: See if Raj is done with Pilates.

speaker: Whoever did this knew what they were doing. He got in and out of your account in under 15 minutes, transferred all your stuff, and didn’t leave a digital fingerprint.
response: Oh! There isn’t enough camomile tea in the world to quell the rage in my heart.

speaker: Hold on. I’m talking to an orc under the bridge in Thunder Bluff who says if we pay him, he’ll help us track down your things.
response: Can we trust him?

speaker: Whoa! Somebody’s auctioning off a jewelled ostrich bridle!
response: No. Glenn’s was leather. He was a simple ostrich. Is! Is, I haven’t given up hope.

speaker: Oh, I know. Bernadette told me. Sorry, Sheldon. I know that game meant a lot to you.
response: That game? Excuse me, Penny, but Doodle Jump is a game. Angry Birds is a game. World of Warcraft is a massively multi-player online role-playing… all right, technically it’s a game.

speaker: Okay, well, anyways, I brought you a day-old cheesecake to cheer you up!
response: Stale pastry is hollow succour to a man who is bereft of ostrich.

speaker: Just say thank you.
response: I thought I just did.

speaker: So, how do you guys want to play this?
response: Be ruthless. You tell him if he doesn’t start talking, we’ll register a complaint with his Internet service provider.

speaker: Sheldon, what if he gets his Internet from his cable company? He could lose his HBO and all their delightful original programming.
response: I don’t care! I’m losin’ it, man!

speaker: Good, good. I’ll tell you what happens.
response: And people think I don’t get sarcasm.

speaker: Good news, gentlemen, I found our hacker.
response: What?

speaker: Yeah. No one can hide from me, not Waldo, not Carmen San Diego, not even topless Natalie Portman.
response: I’ve never said these words before, but good job, Howard!

speaker: Thanks. Our culprit is one Mr. Todd Zarnecki, 2711 Ocean View Road, Carlsbad, California.
response: The name and the address drip with evil.

speaker: Yes, he does live with his parents. Here’s a Google Earth sh*t of their house.
response: Excellent! It’s in a cul-de-sac. We can box him in.

speaker: Hold on, you’re thinking of going there?
response: Carlsbad is only a couple of hours away.

speaker: Fine. You walk up to the house, knock on the door and demand your stuff back. What if he says no?
response: I don’t know if you’ve been following the news, Leonard, but there have been some terrific advancements in the field of torture.

speaker: No one’s getting tortured.
response: Fine, we’ll abide by the Geneva Convention. But ask yourself this, in the course of our lives, how much lunch money has been taken from us? How many kites? How many Scooby-Doo Trapper Keepers?

speaker: I totally had one of those.
response: Of course you did. It was a fun and practical way of organizing your school work. But the bullies took it from us. Well, no more. Tonight, we take back our dignity, our birthright and our pride. What do you say? Who’s with me?

speaker: I have a hip-hop aerobics class at five, could we go after?
response: Sure.

speaker: Also, tonight’s the Sabbath and my mother and I have a tradition of lighting the candles and
response: Fine. Leonard?

speaker: And me.
response: One moment. (Places a tissue on their hands before adding his own) I’m hell-bent on catching a cyber criminal, not the common cold.

speaker: Whoopi and Rube Goldberg!
response: That’s uncanny.

speaker: Hey, how about we stay the night and hit Legoland in the morning?
response: Sea World is better. It has Shamu, who is literally tons of fun. But for the moment, let’s stay focused on Todd Zarnecki.

speaker: Yeah, we’re coming for you, Todd Zarnecki. And for the record, Legoland is more interactive.
response: I almost feel sorry for the poor fool, sitting in his split-level suburban ranch, unaware that a vengeful horde is barrelling down the San Diego Freeway at 71 miles an hour. Ease up there, lead foot. You trying to get us k*ll?

speaker: I took the liberty of burning us a mix of heroic questing music.
response: This says Beyonce Bootylicious Dance Mix.

speaker: Oh, yeah, I’m feeling it.
response: We are winged fury! Which is still no excuse for going over the posted speed limit.

speaker: Next time we go to kick someone’s ass, we take the train.
response: I always prefer the train.

speaker: Sheldon, let’s go.
response: Coming.

speaker: Why did you bring that?
response: No w*apon strikes more fear into a man’s heart than a Klingon bat’leth.

speaker: Okay, let’s get clear on something. We’re just going to tell this guy to transfer all of your stuff back into your account and then be on our way. No one’s bat’lething anybody.
response: So my blade shall not taste blood tonight?

speaker: No.
response: Well, now I just feel silly holding it.

speaker: Come on.
response: Can I at least kick down the door?

speaker: Who is it?
response: Your doom!

speaker: Don’t say your doom. Who opens the door for their doom?
response: Good point. Basket of puppies.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon?
response: Are you Todd Zarnecki?

speaker: Yeah. Who are you?
response: I am Sheldor of Azeroth. I want my things back.

speaker: I don’t think so. Let me see that.
response: Careful. That’s a collectible.

speaker: I know. I’ve always wanted one. (Closes door)
response: Well, he’s even more cunning than we thought.

speaker: Something’s wrong, I’m not getting any gas. Anybody know anything about internal combustion engines?
response: Of course.

speaker: Does anybody know how to fix an internal combustion engine?
response: No.

speaker: Well, we’d better call somebody to come pick us up.
response: It’d be swell if they had a train.

speaker: So did you at least get Sheldon’s fake stuff back?
response: No. We failed in our noble quest.

speaker: How come?
response: Todd Zarnecki was mean.

speaker: Okay.
response: We did it! I said, we.

speaker: Ordinary, yet I sense it is dripping with magical potential.
response: Oh, dear Lord. A man pops out for a moment to evacuate his bowels and catch up on the adventures of the Caped Crusader, only to emerge and discover his apartment has been transformed into a cabaret.

speaker: I’m telling you, dude, there’s a seat on the Hogwarts Express with your name on it.
response: This is how you’re going to entertain your little cousin and his friends? By lying to them?

speaker: How is this lying?
response: A magic show is an inherently deceitful proposition. This is an ordinary top hat. You’ve chosen that card freely. I do not have a set of lock picks lodged in my keister.

speaker: Can’t you just enjoy the wonder, Sheldon? Why must you peek behind the curtain? Or up the butt?
response: If we poison the critical thinking faculties of children by telling them that rabbits come out of hats, then we create adults who believe in astrology and homeopathy and that Ryan Reynolds was a better choice for Green Lantern than lovable rogue Nathan Fillion.

speaker: Don’t be so hard on him. It’s natural to be a little cranky when you have a quarter in your ear!
response: Coins lodged in body parts is not a source of amusement. When I was five, Billy Sparks put a Mexican peso up my nose.

speaker: How is that not amusing?
response: It’s still there. Takes me 45 minutes to get through airport security. (Storms out)

speaker: Ooh, look who’s out on a date. Pasadena’s favourite power couple, Shamy.
response: And that is the answer to the question, what is wrong with eating at The Cheesecake Factory?

speaker: That is so hot.
response: All right, without objection, the minutes of the previous date are considered read and agreed to. Any new business?

speaker: How was your day?
response: Superb. This morning I made a palindrome with my Alpha-Bits. Nice hat, Bob Tahecin.

speaker: Sounds like you hit the ground running. I have a bit of good news myself. My most recent paper on how a cooperative long-term potentiation can map memory sequences in dendritic branches made the cover of Neuron.
response: Ooh! Speaking of good news, somebody just hit 100 Twitter followers.

speaker: That’s nice. Anyway, I’ve been dreaming of this day for a long time.
response: Yeah, me, too. Triple digits, I’m not gonna lie, feels pretty good.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m the sole author on a paper being published in a distinguished journal that may change the course of my field.
response: Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Ooh, 101! Air’s getting a bit thin up here.

speaker: Give me a minute. I’m gonna go wash up.
response: Well, that’s odd. We both washed up when we came in. It’s probably a euphemism for urination.

speaker: Sheldon, what is wrong with you?
response: Not much. Although, I can be faulted for being overly fond of koala bears. I don’t know what it is, when they smart munching on eucalyptus, I just melt inside.

speaker: Okay, Amy just told you some exciting news, and you acted like it was no big deal.
response: Oh, I see why you’re confused. No, her news sounded important, but what you’re forgetting is, it was an achievement in the field of biology. That’s all about yucky, squishy things.

speaker: Honey, she’s upset. You’re her boyfriend. You have to at least try to be excited by the things she’s excited by.
response: What if they simply don’t excite me?

speaker: Well, just smile and think about koalas.
response: She’d see right through that. We go to the zoo all the time. She knows my koala face. And for future reference, it’s this.

speaker: Oh, a little Red Dead Redemption, huh?
response: Yes.

speaker: How come you’re not doing a mission? You’re just wandering around.
response: Had a rough night. I thought I’d go for a walk and clear my head.

speaker: Some people go outside and do that.
response: It’s after nine o’clock, at this hour the streets of Pasadena are teeming with drunken sailors and alley cats.

speaker: You want to talk about it?
response: No. I think I’ll just go in this saloon and drink my troubles away.

speaker: You know digital alcohol is never a solution. What’s going on?
response: Hard as this may be to believe, it’s possible that I’m not boyfriend material.

speaker: Glad I was sitting down for that. Did you and Amy get in a fight?
response: Amy had a fight. I was being perfectly reasonable. I’m gonna have a whiskey. Do you want anything?

speaker: No, I can’t. I’m playing Grand Theft Auto later. Look, I’m no expert in women.
response: I’ll say.

speaker: That’s not necessary when someone’s trying to help you.
response: I’m sorry. It’s the alcohol talking. Go on.

speaker: Sometimes with women you want to listen to what upsets them and then show them that you can grow and change.
response: Nuts to that. What else you got?

speaker: I don’t know what to tell you. Buy her something.
response: How does that work?

speaker: Well, you skip over any attempt to repair your emotional connection and you win back her affection with an empty financial gesture.
response: Well, that approach has Sheldon Cooper written all over it.

speaker: Glad I could help.
response: It’s appreciated. And if you ever manage to find a woman again, I’ll be glad to return the favour.

speaker: Oh, my God, now I know what I sound like to you when I say stupid stuff.
response: Ooh, a pocket watch.

speaker: Okay, I don’t think Amy wants a pocket watch.
response: No, but maybe she wants a man with a pocket watch.

speaker: Still saying stupid stuff. Ooh, does she like bracelets?
response: Well, she’s very fond of her silver one that says allergic to penicillin. Maybe they have a dressier version of that?

speaker: (Snorts) Trust me, we are not a couple.
response: Excuse me. I don’t see why you get to snort derisively and point that out. You’d be lucky to land a fella like me.

speaker: Fine, go ahead.
response: (Snorts) Trust me, we are not a couple.

speaker: Yes. Channel set baguettes, 20 points total weight.
response: Remarkable. Diamonds, crystallized carbon. Every day, people go to the grocery store and come home with sacks full of carbon in the form of charcoal briquettes that they toss in their barbeques and set on fire. But just because you’ve got some carbon with the atoms stacked neatly, you expect me to plunk down thousands of dollars.

speaker: Actually, that’s only 750. Everything’s on sale.
response: Really. Talk to me about that pocket watch.

speaker: Eight o’clock. (Sheldon checks pocket watch) Sheldon, that pocket watch is ridiculous.
response: Nonsense. I look like a train conductor. Under what pretext did you lure her here?

speaker: I said, hey, want to come over and hang out?
response: Good, good, if you had said something clever, she might’ve gotten suspicious.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re up.
response: Thank you. Amy, I’d like to apologize. Your accomplishment was impressive. And I’m proud of you.

speaker: We both know that’s your koala face.
response: I told you.

speaker: Of course I do, I’m a princess, and this is my tiara!
response: You’re right, the tiara was too much.

speaker: Okay, see you later.
response: Good news. I finally have a handle on my idea for three-person chess.

speaker: That is good news. Bye.
response: Uh, do you know how I solved the balanced centre combat-area problem? Five words, transitional quadrilateral to triangular tessellation.

speaker: That, that’s brilliant.
response: It’s what I do. But wait, there’s more. I also invented two new chess pieces. The serpent, and the old woman.

speaker: Okay, now I have to ask. What do they do?
response: When the serpent slithers to an opposing player’s piece, that piece is considered poisoned and will die after two more moves. Ugh.

speaker: All right.
response: Unless, it gets to the old woman in time, in which case she sucks out the poison, turning her into the Grand Empress, a piece combining the power of the knight, queen and serpent.

speaker: Elegant.
response: That’s because it’s simple.

speaker: Okay, well, I look forward to playing with you.
response: And…

speaker: And what?
response: And a third person. It’s three-person chess. I must say, ever since you started having regular intercourse, your mind has lost its keen edge. You should reflect on that.

speaker: Excuse me, but Einstein had a pretty busy sex life.
response: Yes, and he never unified gravity with the other forces. If he hadn’t been such a hound dog, we’d all have time machines.

speaker: Got it. Bye.
response: You know I’m right.

speaker: I need a hug.
response: Sorry, I have company.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, open the door.
response: I don’t want to hug you.

speaker: I don’t want to hug you, either. I was just feeling blue.
response: Blue, as in depressed.

speaker: Well, not so much depressed as lonely.
response: I don’t know what colour lonely is.

speaker: What?
response: Red is angry, yellow is frightened, green is jealous and blue is depressed. Perhaps we can assign a colour to lonely.

speaker: Nothing rhymes with orange. It’s probably lonely.
response: All right. Come in. You look positively orange with loneliness. No, I don’t see that catching on at all.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: I’m working on my three-person chess game.

speaker: Oh, cool. Can I play?
response: It’s three-person chess. Did you bring a friend?

speaker: No.
response: Then as a mental exercise I invite you to figure out why the two of us can’t play three-person chess. Can you believe this guy? Social protocol does, however, require me to bring you a hot beverage in your time of need.

speaker: No, thank you. I’m fine.
response: It’s not optional. We’re out of tea. I hope you like bouillon.

speaker: I, uh, I guess you’re probably wondering what’s got me down.
response: Actually, I was wondering if I could add a third new chess piece. How do you think people would feel about Prince Joey, the king’s feeble-minded but well-meaning cousin?

speaker: I’m going to be 30 years old, and I have no one in my life to love me. I’m such a basket case, I can’t even talk to a woman without having alcohol in my body.
response: The fun thing about Prince Joey is every time he moves, there’s a one-in-five chance he’ll k*ll himself.

speaker: Sheldon, listen to me. I have a big decision to make, and I’m scared.
response: Yellow. Go ahead.

speaker: A friend at the School of Pharmacology gave me these new pills they’re testing. He says it’s the next big thing for social anxiety disorder.
response: Fascinating. What’s in it?

speaker: I’m not sure. Some sort of beta-blocker attached to a molecule extracted from the urine of cows.
response: I like cows.

speaker: That’s not the point.
response: It was its own point. Go on.

speaker: I’m a scientist. My ability to think is my bread and butter. I’m afraid if I take this, I might lose that special, unique something that makes me so successful in my field.
response: Rajesh, I’ve had the privilege of working alongside you for many years. My recommendation is that you gobble these up like Tic Tacs.

speaker: Thank you for coming with me, Sheldon. You’re a good friend.
response: I’m glad you think so. That’s what I strive to emulate.

speaker: Hi.
response: Oh, there’s no need to interact with me. I’m just here to observe.

speaker: We’re scientists. We observe everything. Here, go buy yourself a scone.
response: All right.

speaker: You’re cute.
response: I’d like to buy a scone.

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, we’re out. We have muffins.
response: They sound delicious, but this money is earmarked for scones.

speaker: I…
response: They were out of scones.

speaker: Hang on. When is my pawn allowed to use the golf cart?
response: When it’s done charging. Or you land on the time machine. Obviously.

speaker: Oh, oh, Beekeeper to King 12. I capture your Pope and release the swarm. Checkmate on Sheldon.
response: I knew I should have given my Pope the jet pack.

speaker: Oh, and there’s not even a bathroom on set. I have to go to the gas station across the street. I mean, I was dressed like half an ape and still not even close to the most disgusting person in there.
response: Leonard, I could use your assistance.

speaker: Sure. What’s up?
response: Well, now that I’ve given up string theory, I’m struggling to find my next area of focus. So, in your professional opinion, which of these areas do you think is the most promising?

speaker: Huh, well, I think there’s some really innovative stuff going on in dark matter.
response: That’s helpful. Okay. Of these four areas…

speaker: Leonard, what did we say about being a gullible weenie?
response: It is just so frustrating.

speaker: Yeah. Sounds like me. Come on, Sheldon. What do you say?
response: All right. I officially reinstate Anything Can Happen Thursday.

speaker: Great, what do you want to do?
response: I don’t know. What do you want to do?

speaker: What can we do that’s free?
response: Oh, got it. We order a pizza.

speaker: Are you kidding? That’s what you always do. Think harder.
response: You’re right. You’re right. Got it. We order calzones, cut them open, eat them like pizza. All right, all right, I’ll shake the brain bush one more time, see what falls out. Got it. There’s a live-action role-playing group that meets every Thursday night in Griffith Park and re-enacts battles from Lord of the Rings.

speaker: You know what? Why don’t we just ease into this. Let, let’s go for a walk and, and, and see if we find a new restaurant.
response: Any chance that restaurant is near Griffith Park?

speaker: No.
response: All right.

speaker: No. Bernadette’s working late.
response: Amy’s sick.

speaker: Aw. What’s wrong with her?
response: Well, she talks a lot. She always wants to hold hands.

speaker: That’s not what I meant.
response: Well, if you were referring to her illness your question should have been, what ails her?

speaker: What ails her?
response: Oh. Who knows?

speaker: Yep.
response: Great. You know, this is how Anything Can Happen Thursday turns into It Won’t Stop Coming Up Friday.

speaker: Hey, how about that Asian fusion place?
response: Fusion and Asians? I’m trying not to think about science.

speaker: What the hell? What? She’s not working late.
response: And Amy doesn’t look sick.

speaker: Why would they lie to us?
response: That’s a good question. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy and Bernadette. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy and Bernadette. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy and Bernadette. Why did you lie to us?

speaker: You’re not working late. Why did you lie to me?
response: And Amy, you told me you were sick, but you look just as pale and tired as always.

speaker: Well you know what? Maybe I need a break from all of you. Come on, Sheldon.
response: Where are we going?

speaker: We’re gonna have Anything Can Happen Thursday, you’re gonna tell me all about your science stuff and I’m gonna complain about my movie, and we’re gonna support each other because that’s what friends do.
response: Okay. ‘Cause if I had to pick now, I’d probably go with dark matter because…

speaker: What’s wrong?
response: I don’t understand my food. Chinese noodles with Korean barbecue in a taco.

speaker: It’s fusion.
response: My mother would lock her car doors if she had to drive through this hodgepodge of ethnicity.

speaker: Think I’ve been complaining too much about the movie?
response: Not at all.

speaker: Thank you.
response: But to be fair, when you talk, most of what you say sounds like, wah, wah, wah, clothes, wah, wah, wah.

speaker: Hey, I don’t understand why you’re not upset with Amy.
response: I am. So much so that I’m gonna bring her here for dinner on our next date night.

speaker: Thank you. Hey, maybe the answer to your career question is in one of these.
response: Penny, there’s only one cookie with something in the middle that solves life’s problems, and that’s an Oreo. Or a Nutter Butter, if you’re in a pinch.

speaker: Come on, open it. I bet it says something great.
response: This is Asian fusion. For all you know, there’s a tiny Chihuahua in here.

speaker: Fine, I’ll go. Hmm. People turn to you for guidance and wisdom. Yeah, that’s a good one.
response: No, it’s not.

speaker: How is that not good?
response: Turn to you for wisdom? Clearly, that cookie is mocking you. You’d never hear that kind of sass from a Nutter Butter.

speaker: Uh, since you’re paying for dinner, I’ll let that slide. Open yours.
response: Have you ever paid for a meal?

speaker: Not with money. Read.
response: Your warm and fun-loving nature delights those around you.

speaker: Oh, I think I see our next stop.
response: You can’t be serious. If I wanted to waste my time on nonsense, I’d follow Leonard on Instagram.

speaker: No, come on, tonight we are trying new things.
response: Oh. That’s a lot of incense. Or someone set a hippie on fire.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, just ask your question.
response: Okay, I just did. What was it?

speaker: Oh, for God’s sake. Look, he’s a physicist who’s trying to figure out what his next field of study should be.
response: For your information, I was asking her about the next Star Trek movie.

speaker: All right, why don’t we begin? Your spirit guides are telling me that there’s a woman in your life you’re having problems with.
response: That’s an easy guess. I’m clearly an annoying person and have problems with both genders.

speaker: Yes, yes, your spirit guides are on fire.
response: The majority of people have dark hair. Even you, at one time.

speaker: Does she work in a similar field to you?
response: Ha. The opposite. She’s a neurobiologist, and I’m a theoretical physicist. My spirit guides can go suck an egg.

speaker: Exactly. Personally and professionally. Everything will fall into place once you commit to her.
response: You know what this is? Yeah, and I reserve this word for those rare instances when it’s truly deserved. This is malarkey.

speaker: Well, I was just feeling so bad about lying to you the other night, I wanted to make it up to you.
response: And how do you propose to do that? (Amy takes off coat and is dressed as a Catholic schoolgirl) Unless you have Gravity on Blu-ray under that skirt, I don’t know where you’re going with this.

speaker: I'm heckling you. It's a beloved part of baseball.
response: He's right. And given that you're probably still waiting to be picked for a game that was played in fifth grade, I'm sure you do suck.

speaker: That's so cool. Congratulations. I guess that makes you the athlete of the group.
response: Well, not just him. May I remind you that you're talking to the seeker, b*at, chaser and water boy of the third place Griffith Park Quidditch team.

speaker: Now you know why we're not outside.
response: Did you enjoy my lecture?

speaker: No, and neither did our waiter.
