response: Well, if you're going to serve Cornish game hen, you should either be familiar with the history of Cornwall or be prepared to learn it.

speaker: Hey, how was dinner?
response: Good, I had Cornish game hen.

speaker: You guys are going out two nights in a row?
response: I missed a number of date nights while I was on my train trip, and I'm contractually obligated to make them up under the terms of the Relationship Agreement.

speaker: It's better than hot, it's binding.
response: If you're free tomorrow night, I'd love to have you join us on a double date.

speaker: You are aware that a double date doesn't count as two dates.
response: Oh. Well, then come or don't. I don't care.

speaker: Sheldon, I'm surprised you'd choose to go to a pub.
response: At our committee meeting, Amy made a motion for a picnic in a park, but I tacked so many amendments on that thing it sank like a lead balloon.

speaker: I then suggested a pub.
response: Yeah, which I was initially sceptical of until I saw online that they serve Yorkshire pudding.

speaker: You don't even like Yorkshire pudding.
response: No, it's yucky, but informing people about the history of Yorkshire is yummy, yum-yum.

speaker: Nice to see a busy couple keep the spark of bureaucracy alive.
response: Ignore them, Amy. They're just jealous because they'll never have a relationship as good as ours.

speaker: Isn't this when he says bazooka or something?
response: I wasn't making a joke, I was merely stating fact. Amy and I have a superior relationship to yours.

speaker: You don't honestly think that, do you?
response: Leonard, I assumed you knew. The ranking of relationships in our circle by quality is me and Amy, Howard and Bernadette, Raj and his girlfriend, Penny and Chardonnay, Penny and you.

speaker: Okay, I got to, I, I, I, I got to ask. What makes you think that your relationship is so wonderful and ours isn't?
response: For starters, we enjoy spending time together.

speaker: So do we. And I've seen you guys ignore each other for hours doing totally different things.
response: It's called parallel play.

speaker: Yeah, toddlers do that.
response: Not as well as we do.

speaker: So what? Why do you even care?
response: Oh, listen to them. Not even married and the honeymoon's over.

speaker: Whatever. You can't even go on a date without checking your relationship agreement.
response: If you've got a problem basing a relationship on a contract, I'd like to tell you about 13 plucky colonies that entered a relationship agreement called the U.S. Constitution. And it may not be cool to say so, but I think that love affair is still pretty hot today.

speaker: Uh, we're not sure. But I want to wait long enough to prove to my mother I'm not pregnant.
response: May I have one of your fries?

speaker: Of course. Can I have a bite of your burger?
response: Absolutely not.

speaker: Some perfect couple. He won't even share his food with her.
response: It has avocado on it. She's allergic to avocado. Are you so jealous of our relationship you want Amy to die?

speaker: I'm not jealous. I just think it's silly for you to compare relationships like they're something that can be quantified.
response: Everything is quantifiable. That French fry? A seven. Spider-Man? A nine. The number nine? Oddly, only a four.

speaker: Sheldon, you're just assigning random numbers to things based on your opinion.
response: No, I'm not. French fries have three variables, crispiness, saltiness and shape. Which is why a curly fry only gets a two. If I wanted curls for dinner, I'd order a clown wig.

speaker: Well, a relationship is more complicated than a French fry.
response: Not according to the work of Berscheid, Snyder and Omoto.

speaker: They developed the Relationship Closeness Inventory, which predicts the stability of a couple based on behaviour.
response: Yeah, not to be confused with the French Fry Goodness Inventory. That's pure Cooper.

speaker: So, this is accurate?
response: It's been around for 25 years, and has been extensively corroborated by other researchers.

speaker: Well, kind of takes the romance out of relationships.
response: Kind of? It does it perfectly.

speaker: No, we're sorry. We never should have been comparing relationships in the first place.
response: Why? We won. You know, I say, next, we take on Koothrappali and his dog. Really give ourselves a challenge.

speaker: I just want to say one more thing about this. Just because Penny and I are very different people does not mean that we're a bad couple.
response: The answer is one simple test away. Hmm? You know, it's like when I thought there was a possum in my closet. Did I sit around wondering? No, I sent Leonard in with a pointy stick and a bag.

speaker: Because it doesn't matter. I don't care if we're a ten or a two.
response: Or a one. A one is possible.

speaker: It would make me so happy if you said things like that.
response: We got an eight-point-two. Trust me, you're happy.

speaker: This is fun, huh? We get to see our friend throw out the first pitch, have a hot dog, watch the game.
response: Whoa. Nobody said anything about watching the game.

speaker: Sheldon, what did you expect?
response: I expected to see Howard throw the baseball, finish my hot dog, and hightail it across the street to Disneyland just in time for Mickey's Soundsational Parade.

speaker: I'll tell you what. If we stay, I'll buy you cotton candy and a bobblehead.
response: Who's the bobblehead of?

speaker: Does it matter?
response: No, as long as it bobbles.

speaker: 'Cause I'm an idiot who didn't think this through.
response: Okay, new plan. We go to Disneyland, play hide and seek on Tom Sawyer's Island, and then come back and see the end of the pitch.

speaker: You suck, Wolowitz!
response: He makes a valid point.

speaker: Boy, a restraining order from Stephen Hawking. It’ll look so nice next to the ones he’s already got from Leonard Nimoy, Carl Sagan and Stan Lee.
response: Leonard, do you recall when I said that I was going to revolutionize humanity’s understanding of the Higgs boson particle, and you said, Sheldon, it’s two a.m., get out of my bedroom?

speaker: Like it was ten hours ago. What about it?
response: Well, I believe I’ve done it. And I’m only saying believe to sound modest, because, sweet Sam Houston, I did it.

speaker: That’s incredible. Oh, here, break out the math.
response: Oh, okay, let me see this. All right, so this particle here is the boson moving forward in time. Now, I was thinking… Howard, you go ahead and eat. This isn’t going to make any sense to you.

speaker: Sheldon, I have a working understanding of physics.
response: Yeah, good for you, and don’t stop working on it.

speaker: I told you, no.
response: But I said I’m sorry.

speaker: No, you said, would it help if I said I’m sorry?
response: And you never answered me. So who owes whom an apology now?

speaker: Sheldon, you’re a condescending jerk. Why on earth would I want to do something nice for you?
response: Um, to go to Jewish heaven?

speaker: Jews don’t have heaven.
response: Then to avoid Jewish hell?

speaker: Have you met my mother? I live in Jewish hell.
response: Howard, please. This is Stephen Hawking. Perhaps my only intellectual equal.

speaker: Oh, you can’t be serious.
response: Try to put yourself in my place. Imagine you’re the sole human being living on a planet populated with nothing but dogs. And then it turns out there’s another human being.

speaker: Hang on. Are you saying the rest of us are dogs?
response: Yeah, okay, I can see you’re going to take this the wrong way. Let me try again. Imagine you’re the sole human being living on a planet populated with nothing but chimps.

speaker: Get out of my lab.
response: Oh, now they’re so much smarter than dogs. Have you seen them on those little bicycles?

speaker: Get out.
response: How about dolphins?

speaker: It was great. We talked about movies.
response: Oh!

speaker: I showed him some card tricks.
response: Oh!

speaker: He even let me read a couple pages from his new book.
response: Oh!

speaker: Something got you down there, bunky?
response: Howard, please, I’m begging you.

speaker: Three times. He begged the Fox network not to cancel Firefly. He begged the TNT network to cancel Babylon 5. And when he got food poisoning at the Rose Bowl Parade, he begged a deity he doesn’t believe in to end his life quickly.
response: Do you understand how important Hawking is to me? When I was six years old, I dressed up as him for Halloween.

speaker: You’re kidding.
response: No, sir, no, I took my dad’s desk chair, attached a Speak & Spell to it and made my sister push me up and down the block to trick or treat. Granted most people thought I was R2-D2, but still, I got a lot of candy.

speaker: You don’t seem to be understanding the English word no. Maybe a different language will help. Russian, nyet. Chinese, bu. Japanese, iie. Klingon, qo. Binary coded Ascii, 0110111001101111.
response: It’s actually 01100111.

speaker: No!
response: I’m not asking for me, I’m asking for Hawking.

speaker: Let me try gansta, hells no.
response: Okay, look, how about this? Just give him my paper on the Higgs boson. If he sees the incredible breakthrough I’ve made, he’ll reach out to me.

speaker: What if he doesn’t?
response: He will, he’s really smart.

speaker: That’s an interesting idea. Why don’t you give me a minute to talk it over with my friends?
response: How do I do that?

speaker: You walk away.
response: Walking away.

speaker: Well, don’t be too mean.
response: Hey, fellas, I’m thinking about making some freshly brewed iced tea if anyone would like some.

speaker: I wouldn’t mind a glass.
response: I wasn’t talking to you.

speaker: Sheldon, come on back.
response: Yes, yes. What did you decide?

speaker: I’ll give your paper to Professor Hawking.
response: Great, thank you. Oh, that’s terrific.

speaker: But in exchange, I’d like you to do a few things for me.
response: What kinds of things?

speaker: Are you familiar with the 12 labours of Hercules?
response: Of course.

speaker: Well, I thought I’d start you off by polishing my belt buckles.
response: Oh. By all means. When I was a boy, I would polish my Mee-Maw’s silver. And she would entertain me with stories about growing up in Oklahoma. Interesting woman. You know, she once k*ll a prairie dog with a gravy boat.

speaker: That’s nice.
response: That’s a lot of belt buckles.

speaker: Funny thing is, I only have one belt. Anyway, I’ll let you get started. Oh, by the way, the little marks, uh, that look like water spots, I tend to stand too close to the urinal, so what you’re seeing there is splash back.
response: You make sissy on your belt buckles? Mee-Maw’s forks never had that.

speaker: Sheldon, these look great. They’re like magnificent little crowns to hang over my magnificent little jewels. How’d you get them so shiny?
response: Oh, I-I buffed them with Turtle Wax. The man down at Pep Boys says from now on, the urine should just bead up and roll right off.

speaker: Way to go the extra mile. Your Mee-Maw would be proud.
response: My Mee-Maw must never know of this. Now will you give Professor Hawking my paper?

speaker: Oh, my dear boy, no. Okay. Next, this is a sexy French maid costume I bought for Bernadette. I thought it might spice things up and get her to dust my room at the same time, but I was wrong and really wrong.
response: And you want me to return it for you?

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: It’s not Saturday night. Why are you doing your laundry?
response: This is not my laundry.

speaker: Wow, are these Amy’s? Kind of trashy, good for her.
response: Those are Howard’s.

speaker: Ugh. Why are you washing Howard’s man panties?
response: Because if I don’t, he won’t give my paper to Stephen Hawking. He’s a famous physicist.

speaker: Yeah, yeah, I know, he’s the wheelchair dude who invented time.
response: That’s close enough.

speaker: I don’t understand, why doesn’t Howard just introduce you to the guy?
response: Because he’s punishing me for being a, quote, condescending jerk. You don’t think I’m condescending, do you?

speaker: Well…
response: Oh, I’m sorry, condescending means…

speaker: I know what it means. And yes, you love correcting people and putting them down.
response: Au contraire. When I correct people I am raising them up. You should know, I do it for you more than anyone.

speaker: Come on, you do it to feel superior. I see that twinkle in your eye when someone says who instead of whom or thinks the moon is a planet.
response: Or Don Quixote is a book about a donkey named Hotay.

speaker: See, there it is, there’s that twinkle.
response: Well, I can’t help it. That’s an involuntary twinkle.

speaker: What do you want me to tell you, Sheldon?
response: I want you to tell me that Howard is being mean to me for no reason.

speaker: Fine, Howard is being mean to you for no reason.
response: I knew it.

speaker: Sheldon! I need your help!
response: What is it now, Mrs. Wolowitz?

speaker: It’s this dress. When I put my front in, my back pops out. When I put my back in, my front pops out. It’s like trying to keep two dogs in a bathtub!
response: What do you want me to do?

speaker: We’re gonna have to work as a team. Get in here, grab a handful, and start stuffing.
response: I’m not sure how to do this.

speaker: It’s easy, just pretend you’re putting away a sleeping bag.
response: Sleeping bags don’t usually sweat this much, but okay.

speaker: Now zip me up.
response: Oh, if we squeeze you any tighter, you may turn into a diamond.

speaker: You’re right, who am I kidding? You should have seen me when I was young, Sheldon. The fellas used to line up and bring me boxes of candy. Why did I eat it all? Would you hold me?
response: Oh, no, you know, I’m not really the holding kind of… Oh!

speaker: Yeah, I made an adjustment on the motor drive and when I was putting it back together I could not for the life of me figure out where they went.
response: I did it. Had to go to three clothing stores, but we finally found a dress that could envelop your mother.

speaker: I should have sent you to the custom car cover place in Altadena. They have her pattern on file.
response: Humorous. Now will you please present my paper to Professor Hawking?

speaker: I don’t know.
response: Oh, for heaven’s sake. I did your laundry, I pee-pee-proofed your belt buckles, I, I even sprained my wrist helping your mother lift her bosom.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, there’s only one thing left I want you to do. Don’t worry, it’s an easy one.
response: Okay.

speaker: Give me a compliment.
response: Fine. You have very tiny hands.

speaker: No, about my job. I want you to tell me I’m good at what I do.
response: You’re obviously good at what you do.

speaker: Well, then why are you always ripping on me?
response: Oh, I understand the confusion. I have never said that you are not good at what you do. It’s just that what you do is not worth doing.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: Now will you give my paper to Hawking?

speaker: Sorry, I can’t.
response: What, why not?

speaker: I gave it to him three days ago. He was really impressed. He wants to meet you.
response: All right, then. Thank you, Howard. Please let Professor Hawking know that I’m available at his earliest convenience.

speaker: I know.
response: I want to thank you for taking time to see me.

speaker: My pleasure. I enjoyed reading your paper very much. You clearly have a brilliant mind.
response: I know.

speaker: Your thesis that the Higgs boson is a black hole accelerating backwards through time is fascinating.
response: Thank you. It just, it came to me one morning in the shower.

speaker: That’s nice. Too bad it’s wrong.
response: What do you mean wrong?

speaker: You made an arithmetic mistake on page two. It was quite the boner.
response: No, no, th-th-th-that can’t be right. I-I don’t make arithmetic mistakes.

speaker: Are you saying I do?
response: Oh, no, no, no, of course not. It’s just, I was thinking… Oh, gosh, golly, I made a boo-boo, and I gave it to Stephen Hawking.

speaker: Yes, actual women are the best.
response: I don’t understand. What other kind of women are there?

speaker: Seen it.
response: Detailed analysis posted online.

speaker: Great. They get girlfriends, and they just abandon us?
response: It is great, isn’t it? We have a wonderful evening ahead of us.

speaker: We do?
response: Oh, yes. I just discovered I don’t have enough room on my hard drive for a Linux partition, so you and I are going to perform a full backup, reinitialize and then reinstall all my operating systems.

speaker: I don’t want to do that.
response: All right. Well, I’m going to perform full backup, reinitialize and then reinstall all my operating systems.

speaker: What about me?
response: Well, I understand there are several types of artificial women. Maybe you should look into that.

speaker: Dude, there’s so many cool things we could be doing tonight. Look. At the Glendale Galleria, put on your best zoot suit, it’s a salute to Swing music in the center court near Macy’s. 5pm to 9pm, huh, huh? A salute to zoot. Sounds like a hoot.
response: I’m sorry, Raj, I have no desire to salute any article of clothing tonight. Much less one that’s linked to race riots in the 1940s.

speaker: Race riots?
response: The zoot suit riots.

speaker: Oh. I always thought that was some sort of after-Christmas sale. Well, then why don’t we just go to the galleria and walk around?
response: I don’t need anything at the Galleria. Do you need anything at the Galleria?

speaker: No. We would just walk around and see what’s what.
response: That’s a semantically null sentence.

speaker: Okay, well, how about this? From the university Web site, 7pm to 10pm, Norton Hall Multipurpose Room, mixer for grad students and faculty of the science and humanities departments. Whether you split atoms or infinitives, this is the place to be.
response: Well, that’s certainly amusing, but I have no interest.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, the world is filled with people doing things outside. Let’s go outside. Outside is good.
response: If outside is so good, why has mankind spent thousands of years trying to perfect inside?

speaker: I don’t know, it’s a marketing scheme. Please, Sheldon, I’m a young, virile visitor from a foreign land and I need to strut my stuff.
response: Let me offer you a compromise. Sometimes when I feel stifled and want a change of scenery, I use my imagination.

speaker: Oh, boy.
response: One of my favourite places to visit is the two-dimensional world described in Edwin Abbott’s mathematical fantasy, Flatland.

speaker: I don’t want to go to Flatland.
response: You’re only saying that because you haven’t been there. I am now a hexagon in two-dimensional space and can only perceive the edges of other objects.

speaker: Oy.
response: Is that you, Raj? I don’t recognize your edge.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m begging you. I want to go to this mixer, and I don’t want to go alone.
response: Well, you’re in luck, there’s a mixer here in Flatland. Oh, look, there’s a sexually attractive line segment, you should chat her up.

speaker: What?
response: Tell her you’re a circle, Flatland gals are all hot for circles.

speaker: Thanks for coming with me.
response: Thanks for giving me your limited edition Green Lantern lantern.

speaker: Did you really have to bring it in with you?
response: What if evil strikes and my power ring runs low?

speaker: Come on, let’s get a drink.
response: I don’t drink.

speaker: Yeah, well I do. And when my wingman is carrying a Green Lantern lantern, I drink a lot. I’ll have a screwdriver, please. Don’t be chintzy with the screw.
response: I would like a root beer float.

speaker: Sheldon, they don’t have ice cream.
response: They don’t? Well, apparently, these people and I differ greatly on the definition of party.

speaker: He’ll have a Shirley Temple.
response: And don’t be chintzy with the Shirley.

speaker: Okay, let’s check out the females.
response: All right. There’s a female.

speaker: That’s Professor Wilkinson’s wife, she’s like 80 years old.
response: But she’s female. Isn’t that the game?

speaker: No. I’m looking for a hookup.
response: Oh, yes. So, the point of this exercise is for you to find someone to copulate with?

speaker: Not so loud, but ideally, yes. Thanks.
response: Thank you. And what is my function as wingman?

speaker: You help me run my game.
response: Okay. What is your game?

speaker: Hey, that’s pretty cool. What is it?
response: It’s a limited edition Green Lantern lantern. My friend is looking for someone to copulate with.

speaker: You’re very funny. I’m Abby.
response: I’m Sheldon. How do you do?

speaker: Well, I’m a slumdog astrophysicist.
response: I thought your father was a gynaecologist. I’m sorry. (Smiles and nods)

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: Is that the limited edition Green Lantern lantern?
response: In brightest day, in darkest night, no evil shall escape my sight.

speaker: Oh, that is so awesome.
response: Thank you. Have you chosen one to copulate with?

speaker: What’s going on?
response: We scored. I’m the wingman.

speaker: What was that?
response: It means come in. It’s taking forever to load the new operating system on my computer. I disinfected the kitchen and the bathroom, and now I thought I’d learn Finnish.

speaker: जो भी तुम्हारे नाव मंगाई. That’s Hindi for whatever floats your boat. Uh, listen, I got a text from that girl Abby, and she and her friend Martha want to hang out with us again. What do you say?
response: I don’t say anything. I merely offer you a facial expression that suggests you’ve gone insane.

speaker: I don’t get it. You had a great time.
response: Yes, exactly, I had a great time. That’s done, I’ve moved on to other things. For example, after I learn Finnish, I’m not going to learn Finnish again.

speaker: Please, Sheldon, I’m a lost Indian boy far from home, and I want a girlfriend and I want her to be Abby, and she’ll only come over if she can bring Martha.
response: Raj, I highly doubt there is any argument you can make, threat you might levy, rhetorical strategy, plea, invocation, supplication, or… vetoomus that you can employ that would convince me to reconsider.

speaker: My Incredible Hulk hands signed by Stan Lee.
response: Oh, my. I’ve admired these for years.

speaker: So does that mean we can go with the girls again?
response: Hulk agree to second date with puny humans!

speaker: You can’t wear the hands on the date.
response: Hulk sad.

speaker: Flatland is more than just a mathematical essay. It is also a treatise on Victorian social mores.
response: You know, I had never considered that. Wow, that’s going to completely change my visits there. Well, it’s late.

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Time for bed.

speaker: Okay.
response: Good night, puny human! (He gets up and leaves).

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Yes?

speaker: Listen, they’re kind of getting busy in the living room, and I was wondering if I could hang out in here for a while.
response: Well, I suppose. Come in. I’ll sleep in Leonard’s room. Good night.

speaker: Fine, it bothers me. You happy?
response: You think you've got problems. The gibbon is the only member of the ape family not classified as a great ape.

speaker: How is this helpful?
response: All the non-human apes are classified as great apes except one. That means taxonomists created the entire category of lesser ape just to single out the poor gibbon as the weird kid on the playground. Now there's a hairy little fellow with a genuine beef.

speaker: But the gibbon doesn't know what it's categorized as. It doesn't even know it's called a gibbon.
response: True. Sorry, kid, you've got it worse than a gibbon.

speaker: Did you go to your prom?
response: No. I had a date with a proper education. Instead of a tuxedo, I dressed myself in good habits. Instead of spiked punch, I enjoyed the intoxicating flavour of knowledge. Instead of dancing in a gym, I shook my bootyto the seductive rhythms…

speaker: I got to go, bye.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny?

speaker: You knocked more than usual.
response: Next time I might be in a rush, it's good to have a few in the bank.

speaker: Okay, what's up?
response: I'd like to discuss this party that Amy and Bernadette are throwing. Since you and I are both reluctant to go, I think I've come up with a perfect way for us to enjoy it.

speaker: Great, how?
response: We pretend we're aliens. I'm not the best at reading facial cues, but I'm gonna say that you love it and want to hear more. Now, in the beloved novel Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, an alien named Ford Prefect pretended to be human in order to blend in so that he could write an entry about Earth for The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, which is a travel book within the actual book, which is also called The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.

speaker: Okay, just one question. What?
response: My point is, pretending to be an alien is a valuable coping mechanism I've used many times. I did it the first time I went to see you in a play. You had no idea Commander Umfrumf of Ceti Alpha Three was in the audience. Oh, don't worry, he gave you seven thumbs up.

speaker: Here's a question, as an alien pretending to be human, are you planning to engage in any post-prom mating rituals with Amy?
response: There are post-prom mating rituals?

speaker: Not always. Unless your date drives a van with an air mattress, then always.
response: Well, if it's part of the prom experience, then I'm open to it.

speaker: You're kidding.
response: I may be an alien, but I have urges. If Amy wants to copulate by firing her eggs into space, well, then, I will happily catch them with the reproductive sac on my upper flermin. I'm not the best at reading facial cues, but I can see that you're a little turned on.

speaker: You know, if you're not gonna learn how to do this, they make some pretty good clip-ons.
response: Bruce Wayne doesn't wear a clip-on.

speaker: Bruce Wayne doesn't make his roommate tie it for him.
response: His name is Alfred, and, yes, he does.

speaker: There, perfect.
response: What, are you sure? It's my first prom, I want to do it correctly.

speaker: I thought you were gonna pretend to be an alien.
response: I was, but Penny didn't want to. You didn't want to. Bernadette, Amy, Koothrappali and Wolowitz didn't want to. And even I knew it was weird to hire somebody.

speaker: Was that a flask?
response: Yes. I've decided to embrace all of the traditions associated with prom, including spiking the punch.

speaker: You're gonna put alcohol in the punch?
response: Oh, no, this is pomegranate juice. It's all the fun of high school high jinks with the cell-protecting zip of antioxidants.

speaker: If you had ripped jeans and a leather jacket, you'd be like the toughest kid on the Disney Channel. So, anything else planned for tonight?
response: Oh, everything. Getting our picture taken, slow-dancing, being elected prom king. Pointing out that kings aren't elected. It's gonna be off the hook.

speaker: And while you're at it, I know that at this age your hormones are raging, but just because all your friends are having sex doesn't mean you have to.
response: Why would you say that?

speaker: You know, 'cause, 'cause a lot of people lose their virginity on prom night.
response: Penny implied the same thing. Is this true?

speaker: Sheldon, you look so handsome.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Oh, it's a scaly genital organ that grows between his shoulder blades. Try not to touch it when you're dancing.
response: Excuse me.

speaker: Where are you going?
response: I can't do this. And for your information, Leonard, the upper flermin doesn't grow between my shoulder blades, it grows out of the belly button on my neck.

speaker: Sheldon, can I come in?
response: I don't think that's a good idea.

speaker: Why not?
response: According to an online message board, I may be having a panic attack. SoccerMom09 had similar symptoms. But to be fair, the twins were a real handful that day.

speaker: You're making me worry. What's going on?
response: What's going on is we're about to go to a prom. And there's a great deal of pressure on young couples like us to engage in what Mr. Bob Eubanks called making whoopee.

speaker: What pressure? All I said was you look handsome. Can you please open the door?
response: It's not just that. Leonard and Penny also made comments about it. And I'm not blind. Even I looked twice when I saw my posterior in these tuxedo pants.

speaker: Sheldon, this is silly. I'm not missing another prom. I'm going upstairs now. Good-bye.
response: I really did think you looked pretty.

speaker: You did?
response: Yes. So much so that I started to panic.

speaker: Well, you can relax. Just because you think I look pretty doesn't mean we have to spend the night together.
response: Were you hoping we would because it's prom?

speaker: I'm always hoping. But tonight I just wanted to have a nice time with you. And maybe dance with someone who has arms.
response: Thank you for understanding.

speaker: Of course I understand. Sheldon, there's something else I've been wanting to say, but before I do, I just, I want you to know that you don't have to say it back. I know you're not ready, and I don't want you to say it just because social convention dictates…
response: I love you, too.

speaker: You said it.
response: There's no denying I have feelings for you that can't be explained in any other way. I briefly considered that I had a brain parasite. But that seems even more farfetched. The only conclusion was love. I know what's happening. This is a panic attack. SoccerMom09 says to lie down with your feet elevated.

speaker: Okay.
response: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. Just because I love you doesn't mean girls are allowed in my room.

speaker: All right, you brought this on yourself. Sheldon, get him.
response: If a zombie bites you, you turn into a zombie. However, if a mummy bites you, all you turn into is some schmo with a mummy bite. So, like a zombie, that’s been eaten from the waist down, you, sir, have no leg to stand on.

speaker: Good boy. Here’s a cookie.
response: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Yep. For as long as I can keep my mother out of it. If you want to check it out later, it’s parked right out front, space 294.
response: I’m sorry, 294?

speaker: Yeah.
response: That’s my parking spot.

speaker: Why do you have a parking spot? You don’t have a car. You don’t even drive.
response: It doesn’t matter. That’s my spot.

speaker: Maybe they reassigned it because you never use it.
response: Well, I’m not using my nipples, either. Maybe they should reassign those.

speaker: Sheldon, someday, if you get a car, I’m sure they’ll give you another parking space.
response: I don’t want another parking space. I want my parking space. It’s perfect. It’s a corner spot, cutting the risk of door-dings in half. It’s a mere 28 steps from the building entrance. The nearby tree provides shade on hot days and is also home to a delightful squirrel. Which is fortuitous because most squirrels are real jerks.

speaker: Fun story. Meanwhile, you still don’t have a car.
response: Don’t try to change the subject. This is about a parking space. It has nothing to do with cars.

speaker: Are you listening to yourself?
response: I always listen to myself. It’s one of the great joys of my life. Now, get your car out of my spot.

speaker: Nope.
response: Very well. You leave me no choice.

speaker: Well, he’s not wrong. Howard did go to the International Space Station.
response: Yeah, that was five weeks ago. How much longer is he gonna milk that cow?

speaker: Sheldon, let it go. It’s not a big deal.
response: No, no, this is a slippery slope, Leonard. It starts with a parking space, where does it end? It’s like my dad always said, first they say you can’t drink and drive, next thing you know, you can’t let your 10-year-old take the wheel while you sleep one off in the backseat.

speaker: All that story does is make me feel bad for your mother.
response: Leonard, you’re my best friend. Why don’t you ever take my side?

speaker: Give it back.
response: I’m sorry, but could you be more specific?

speaker: My Iron Man helmet. Koothrappali saw you take it. Give it back.
response: Oh, that. Well, see, I wanted it, and you weren’t using it. Apparently, those are the rules we live by now. Payback, it truly is the B word, isn’t it?

speaker: Sheldon, that is a five hundred dollar limited edition collectible, and I want it back.
response: I’d love to help you out, but unfortunately (puts helmet on), I’m using it.

speaker: Fine. I’m taking your diploma.
response: Go ahead. That’s the only doctorate you’ll ever get. It smells funny in here.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: Cookie.

speaker: I don’t have any.
response: Well, I’m not giving it away. (Enters apartment. Howard is sitting naked in his spot with a laptop on his lap)

speaker: Hi Sheldon.
response: He’s in my spot. Leonard, make him stop being naked in my spot.

speaker: He wasn’t using it. And I needed a nice cool piece of leather to wiggle my naked ass on.
response: Get off there.

speaker: Give me back my Iron Man helmet.
response: Give me back my parking space.

speaker: You don’t need a parking space. You don’t have a car.
response: You don’t need an Iron Man helmet. You’re not Iron Man.

speaker: This is so exciting. I’m feeling all tingly. Although that could just be my newly defoliated bikini zone.
response: Keep a lookout. This place is swarming with campus security. They will not hesitate to scold us.

speaker: Freaking pigs.
response: Oh, yeah. Okay, now, pull your car into the spot and let’s get out of here.

speaker: Wait, I’m leaving my car here?
response: Yes, and be sure and put on the emergency brake. Really makes these things tough to budge.

speaker: Before I park, come in the back seat. I want to show you something I had done today.
response: All right, colour me intrigued.

speaker: What do you think?
response: I think you’re high on paint fumes. And boy, that’s a lot of Band-Aids.

speaker: What the hell are you doing?
response: Oh. You said I’m not using my space, so I’m using it.

speaker: Okay, you need to move now.
response: No, I don’t.

speaker: You can’t stay there forever.
response: Actually, I have a plastic baggy strapped to my leg that says I can. Give up, Wolowitz. You’ve chosen to tangle with a superior intellect you can’t defeat. There is nothing you could possibly do to… (Howard starts sounding his horn. Sheldon puts on earphones)

speaker: Those aren’t gonna help you, Sheldon,
response: Oh, yes, they are. I mean, what?

speaker: I’m warning you, Sheldon!
response: Your threats are empty, nothing can move me. (Howard starts pushing his chair with the front of the car) Stop that.

speaker: Get out of my spot.
response: No. That’s it. I am calling campus security. You prepare for the scolding of your life.

speaker: What are you idiots doing?
response: He’s trying to k*ll me, Leonard. Video games and rock music have desensitized him to violence.

speaker: It’s not just a parking spot. He can’t handle the fact that I’m a bigger deal than he is now.
response: Oh, preposterous. I have been solely responsible for this university’s six loop quantum gravity calculations, I have changed the way we think about Bose-Einstein condensates, and I am also the one who got Nutter Butters in the cafeteria vending machine. Maybe you missed that news while you were floating around like a goof in outer space. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have work to do.

speaker: Oh, like you’ve never thought of doing that. Don’t hate me just because I lived the dream. (Horn beeps. Sheldon is sitting naked in Howard’s car.)
response: Hey, sweet ride.

speaker: What are you doing in there?
response: Just breaking in your new car.

speaker: Stop that. You stop that.
response: You know what they say? Revenge is a dish best served nude.

speaker: Hey, got a minute?
response: Oh, of course, come in. (Raj opens door to reveal Howard) This is an authentic Chinese throwing star, and I must warn you, I have seen many people throw them in movies.

speaker: I had no idea how much that spot meant to you. Anyway, I called President Siebert and told him it’s not worth fighting over the spot, so you keep it, and I’ll park in the structure across the street.
response: Well, Howard, thank you. It’s quite a gesture on your part. You’ve shown yourself to be the bigger man.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Which I find totally unacceptable. I must be the bigger man. Therefore, you may use my spot until such time as I learn to drive or get a Batmobile.

speaker: Wow, okay. Well, thanks. I don’t know what to say.
response: There is nothing to say. Except I’m the bigger man. I’m not kidding. Say it.

speaker: You’re the bigger man, Sheldon.
response: Oh, stop. And I believe this is yours. FYI, if you wear that into a bank, they will tackle you to the ground.

speaker: I’d like to propose a toast, to burying the hatchet.
response: To burying the hatchet.

speaker: Can I help you?
response: Yes. According to information I gleaned from Yelp, you had great success when a santeriasuzy37 brought you a pair of leather slacks stained with chicken blood. I believe I may have a similar problem. This cushion experienced a nude revenge wiggle.

speaker: A what?
response: A naked man sat on it. Now, here’s my concern, his diet is rich in fatty deli meats. What test do you have to detect lipid residue?

speaker: Lipid what?
response: Lipid residue. An a**l autograph. A colon calling card, if you will.

speaker: Tuesday okay?
response: Don’t rush it. We may be dealing with befoulment on a molecular level.

speaker: Let me write you a ticket.
response: Is that your son?

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Looks like that laptop’s seen better days. If you’re interested, I’m selling this. It’s only two years old, 16 gigabytes of RAM, Intel core i7 processor, and I can personally guarantee it has spent less than 20 minutes resting on an astronaut’s penis.

speaker: I'm sorry, do you mean the guy or the juy?
response: Well, I'll give you three guesses why I'm so irritated.

speaker: Something happened different from the way you wanted it.
response: I guess news travels fast. It's true, a select group of scientists was invited to a weekend symposium at a former home of Richard Feynman, and I wasn't included.

speaker: Yeah, I bet you anything it's just 'cause you're a pain in the ass.
response: You're just saying that to make me feel better.

speaker: Look, you can spend the rest of the day being bitter about this.
response: Agreed.

speaker: Can you please pass the salt?
response: Sure. It's not like I was invited to Richard Feynman's house and have anything better to do.

speaker: Is this how the rest of the night's going to be?
response: I don't know the future. Do you think there's a chance that an asteroid could hit the Earth, destroying Feynman's house and everyone in it?

speaker: No, Sheldon.
response: Then buckle up, you're in for a cranky night.

speaker: According to the codicil of the Relationship Agreement which you insisted upon, we're not allowed to pout or be moody on date night.
response: You know I just put that in because of uterus stuff.

speaker: Well, it applies to you, too.
response: I was afraid you might bring this up, so I have a work-around. There you go. As far as you're concerned, I'm smiling. Although, I must admit, I'm smiling a little bit at the moment because this loophole is so brilliant.

speaker: Stay out of it, Kevin Smith.
response: Do you think there comes a point in life when it stops feeling bad to be left out of things?

speaker: Probably not. It's an evolutionary advantage to be included in group activities.
response: You know what? I used to be a fan of evolution, but I've since evolved, and now I think it's dumb.

speaker: Being left out is a terrible feeling. No one understands that better than I do.
response: Hey, look at that. Even in your example, you're all by yourself.

speaker: When there was a lice epidemic at my school, everybody got it except me. I tried to fool everyone by sprinkling sugar in my hair, but I just got attacked by bees.
response: I can just picture them all right now at Feynman's house, probably discussing Schrodinger and at the same time, not discussing Schrodinger. See? They're missing out on hilarious jokes like that.

speaker: And at the same time, not.
response: It reminds me of when my stupid brother and sister would build forts in the living room and wouldn't let me in. I hated that so much.

speaker: You know, there's nothing I can do about getting you invited to the symposium, but if you wanted, we could build a fort.
response: Isn't that a little juvenile?

speaker: More juvenile than this?
response: I'll get the blankets. You Google how to have childlike fun.

speaker: How's it going, Sheldon?
response: Wonderful. I just finished hanging the lights.

speaker: Can I come in?
response: Yes, oh, but enter through the side. Batman is a load-bearing blanket.

speaker: Amazing.
response: I know. This isn't the printout. This is my real face.

speaker: What are we doing? This is a fort. Let's sit on the floor.
response: Roughing it? Okay. Everything looks so big from down here. This must be how Leonard feels.

speaker: You are my brother.
response: Okay, so the final four forts in the first annual best fort ever contest, or "fort off", are, Fort Knox, Fort Ticonderoga, Fort Sumter and Fort Cozy McBlanket.

speaker: I'd say, Knox over Ticonderoga, 'cause it's got the gold.
response: Mm-hmm.

speaker: And McBlanket over Sumter 'cause it has a higher thread count. (phone rings) Oh. Ten o'clock. Date night's over.
response: Wait, no. We haven't picked a winner.

speaker: We both know this one's gonna win.
response: Well, of course we do. Fort Knox doesn't have a secret physics lending library.

speaker: Come on, I'll help you take this down.
response: Well, wait. What if, just this once, we suspend the date night parameters and you stay later?

speaker: Well, as long as we're suspending the parameters, I could stay really late and we could have our first sleepover.
response: That's a big step.

speaker: It's a big fort.
response: Very well. I will agree to a family-friendly, G-rated, boy-girl sleepover.

speaker: PG. Some scenes may be too intense for younger viewers.
response: G-rated, with a warning for families with babies and toddlers.

speaker: You got yourself a sleepover.
response: Do you need to borrow a toothbrush or pajamas?

speaker: Would it alarm you to know that I hid those things here two years ago just in case this ever came up?
response: It would, but you know how much I admire preparedness. How did you know we'd be in the living room?

speaker: Hello? What is this?
response: We built a fort.

speaker: Okay. Well, you kids have fun. I'm gonna go to sleep.
response: Well, Leonard, don't you want to see the inside of the fort?

speaker: Yeah, I'm good.
response: Oh, come on. I really wanted to tell someone they can't come in.

speaker: Okay, fine. Sheldon, may I please visit your fort?
response: I want to say no, but it's too glorious. Get in here.

speaker: Okay, have a seat on the floor.
response: Not there. That's my spot.

speaker: Have you guys heard about this research team that's trying to transgenically manipulate chicken DNA to create some sort of chicken dinosaur?
response: Oh, I think that sounds wonderful.

speaker: What? You're afraid of both dinosaurs and chickens.
response: Yes, but tell me a dinosaur chicken salad sandwich wouldn't hit the Mesozoic spot.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Yeah. I'm excited to finally meet your girlfriend.
response: Speaking of which, according to a recent study out of Oxford University, when someone takes on a new romantic partner, that person loses one or two close friends.

speaker: Since when do you read social science?
response: I go to the bathroom like everybody else.

speaker: Hey, guys.
response: Hello.

speaker: Uh, yeah, I'm a resident at Huntington Hospital.
response: Oh, I like their emergency room. Yeah, even if it turns out you don't have Dengue fever, they still let you take a lollipop.

speaker: Yeah. I'm sure that'd be fine.
response: I have some odd freckles on my buttocks. Can I make an appointment for you to look at them?

speaker: I'd say it now, but look at those cheekbones.
response: I miss Stuart's place. All this loud music and exposed brick. What, is this a comic book store, or a rave at the third little pig's house?

speaker: You know, he might not reopen. He didn't get a lot of money from the insurance company.
response: Oh, boy, if there is one thing that gets my goat, it's those dad-gum insurance companies.

speaker: All I know is, he's got my mother buying four-ply toilet paper. I mean, four-ply. If his butt is so delicate, why doesn't he just use an angora rabbit?
response: For starters, they shed and bite.

speaker: Ooh, maybe we could come up with a business plan to compete with this place.
response: I'll give you a plan right now. Step one, open comic book store. Step two, start rumour this comic book store gives you genital warts. Step three, buy a big bag to put the money in.

speaker: No. Yeah.
response: So, what are some ways we could set our comic book store apart from the competition?

speaker: Ooh, what if we got a van and drove around and picked kids up?
response: Nice. You mean, like at parks and schools?

speaker: Hold on. So, your idea is to get a van and cruise the streets looking for kids to pick up?
response: Yes.

speaker: Great.
response: On the bright side, that Oxford study was right. One friend down. I wonder who you're going to lose next.

speaker: You, okay? It's you. You're, you're next.
response: No. You're crazy about me.

speaker: Shh. Amy's here now.
response: You know, the more I think about it, the more intrigued I am about having our own store.

speaker: We'll get to see all the new stuff before it hits the shelves.
response: And we'll get to have fun interactions with our customers. Like, this isn't a library, buy it or get out.

speaker: You say things like that all the time.
response: Yes, but as a store owner, I'll finally have a good comeback to, You don't work here, shut up.

speaker: Well, do you think when she and I had that conversation, she left people off her list?
response: I'm sure she did.

speaker: Why?
response: Because if she hadn't, she'd still be wading through the list.

speaker: Will you stay out of this?
response: If only Penny had said that once in a while.

speaker: Yeah, and I'm not sure that complete honesty is always the best thing for a relationship.
response: Yeah, he's right. Once, in a moment of candour, I told Amy that her hair reminded me of a duck caught in an oil spill. She stormed out. Which was sad, because we were playing Scrabble, and I had all the letters to spell persimmon.

speaker: Why are you even part of this conversation? You don't know anything about women.
response: I know that if I had a wife or a fiancée, I'd ask her first before I invested money in a comic book store.

speaker: He's right.
response: Yeah, well, of course I am. I was also right about her hair. It did everything but quack.

speaker: That's how much buying a comic book store means to me.
response: I'd like your honest opinion on something.

speaker: Of course.
response: Now, before I start, I need you to know that I'm very excited about this, and anything you say that isn't enthusiastically supportive will throw our entire relationship into question. So, keep an open mind.

speaker: I'm feeling a little backed into a corner, Sheldon.
response: Perfect. Now, I'm considering investing in Stuart's comic book store.

speaker: Interesting. Can you see how a grown man, an accomplished scientist, who invests in a store that sells picture books about flying men in colourful underwear might be wasting both his financial and intellectual resources?
response: No.

speaker: Then I think it's a terrific idea.
response: Great. Wait till you hear about our van.

speaker: I know. I was looking forward to it.
response: It would've been so nice to have a place that was ours, where we could just sit and read comics in peace.

speaker: And snacks.
response: Well, I guess it was too good to be true.

speaker: Yeah.
response: I've invented a science joke, would you like to hear it?

speaker: Sure.
response: How many Edisons does it take to screw in a light bulb?

speaker: How many?
response: Who cares? He stole the idea and doesn't deserve his own joke.

speaker: Is that really true?
response: Of course, that's how you know it's a good joke. It not only entertains, it informs.

speaker: Hey, sowwy to intewupt.
response: Uh, Barry, uh, how many Edisons does it take to screw in a light bulb?

speaker: Did you know Edison didn't actuawy invent the wight bulb?
response: What do you want, Barry?

speaker: Well, that's fascinating. I can't wait to read it.
response: Oh, no, me as well. Uh, please e-mail it to Sheldon at bazinga dot biz. Why dot biz? Because I just gave you the business. And also bazinga dot com was taken.

speaker: Anyway, thanks again. Cooper, suck eggs.
response: Since when do you help out Barry Kripke?

speaker: Well, I'd been thinking about a cellular automata approach to neuronal connectivity, and I thought it might have some interesting applications to string theory, it's not a big deal.
response: Oh, really? When I was doing string theory and hit a dead end, why didn't you try to help me?

speaker: I did. You said the only math biologists know is if you have three frogs and one hops away, that leaves two frogs.
response: That's pretty funny, that does sound like me. But that doesn't mean that you should be standing on street corners handing out your math to whatever guy comes along.

speaker: Sheldon, we're all scientists. I helped out a fellow colleague. You're being petty.
response: I'm being petty? You know Barry and I have a professional rivalry. You heard him, he told me to suck eggs. If we were friends, he would have suggested I suck something more pleasant. Why are you laughing? Did you learn something?

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: You okay?
response: If I was okay, I would've said hello, and not the much more ominous hello.

speaker: What's going on?
response: I'm mad at Amy.

speaker: Did she leave pit stains in your favourite crop top, too?
response: No. She helped Barry Kripke make an advancement in string theory.

speaker: Oh, that sounds like a good thing.
response: Well, it would be, except that I left string theory because I decided it was a dead end. Yeah, and then she went behind my back to help someone else prove me wrong. My rival, no less. I'm sorry you had to see that.

speaker: I'm sorry I didn't have a camera.
response: Why would she do this to me?

speaker: Well, I'm sure she didn't upset you on purpose. Besides, aren't you the one who says there's nothing more important than the advancement of science?
response: No, I said there's nothing more important than me advancing science.

speaker: All right, well, if I'm understanding this right, and all she did was help out another scientist, I'm thinking you might have to let this one go.
response: Ugh, let it go. I have heard that my whole life. Every time something upsets me somebody says, let it go, you know, like it's my fault, and it's not okay to feel the way I feel.

speaker: I don't know what to tell you. I mean, why don't you talk to her?
response: Is that all you have? Shopworn tidbits like talk to her and let it go? Gee, Penny, life's giving me lemons. What should I do?

speaker: Well, you could shove them somewhere.
response: Okay, now you're getting creative.

speaker: Mmm, when really we're just exiting an uncomfortable situation.
response: Kripke, you know, of all the people, Barry Kripke. I'm so... Are you folding that like a crazy person to get me to do it for you?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, give me that. Just out of curiosity, if I were to let something go, how would I do that?

speaker: I don't know, just think about something else.
response: Can I think about the spiny anteater?

speaker: Sure.
response: The spiny anteater never went behind my back and worked with Barry Kripke. That didn't help at all.

speaker: You know, some people try visualization.
response: How does that work?

speaker: Okay, imagine your problems are a pen.
response: Okay.

speaker: Now imagine you're holding that pen.
response: Okay.

speaker: Now open your hand and let it go.
response: But I just got this pen. It's got my initials on it and everything. Look.

speaker: Sheldon, this isn't that hard.
response: I may have a better way that you can teach me.

speaker: How?
response: What if I told you that over the past few months Amy has secretly been giving you little puzzles to test your intelligence against chimpanzees in her lab?

speaker: What? She didn't give me any puzzles.
response: Are you sure?

speaker: Son of a bitch.
response: Okay, that's great. Now, let it go.

speaker: I can't believe you were testing me against a chimp.
response: Well, excuse me, Amy was testing you. I was rooting for you. Good job on that banana box, by the way.

speaker: Why would she even do this?
response: She's been conducting an experiment on apes where they're given various puzzles to solve. I was surprised at the complexity of the puzzles and thought some humans wouldn't be able to solve them. That's when Amy said, want to make this interesting?

speaker: Make this interesting? You bet money on me?
response: No, no. We designed an experiment involving you. See? Now, isn't that interesting?

speaker: It's not interesting. It's incredibly insulting.
response: Okay, maybe this will help. Imagine you're holding a pen. Before you go too far, not a special pen with your initials engraved on it, that'll make the next part really hard.

speaker: Oh, my, that's it. Get out.
response: I don't understand why you're mad at me. You should be mad at Amy. Like I was this afternoon. Hey, look at that, I let it go.

speaker: Get out.
response: Penny?

speaker: What?
response: I think I left my pen in there.

speaker: Sheldon, open the door.
response: I can't. I'm naked.

speaker: I just saw you.
response: Hang on.

speaker: Really? You couldn't get it out?
response: Thank you.

speaker: That's not true.
response: That sounds like us. I still don't understand why you're upset. You solved every puzzle faster than all of the chimps.

speaker: Can you please just let it go?
response: Oh, I can help you with that. Imagine you're holding an ordinary pen. While your favourite pen is safe and secure in your pocket.

speaker: I don't know.
response: May I say something?

speaker: Not right now, Sheldon.
response: But I think it would be comforting.

speaker: No, it's okay. What?
response: When I lost my own father, I didn't have any friends to help me through it. You do.

speaker: Don't take this away from me.
response: I didn't care for her yelling. But now that I'm not going to hear it again, I'm sad.

speaker: If you want, I can yell at you later.
response: It won't be as good.

speaker: Sheldon, what channel is NASA TV?
response: 289, right between the Game Show Network at 288 and the East coast feed of the Disney Channel on 290.

speaker: I love his eidetic memory, it’s so sexy. Sheldon, what are the ingredients in Pringles?
response: Dried potatoes, vegetable oil, corn flower, wheat starch, maltodextrin, salt, and my favourite ingredient of all, uniformity.

speaker: You’re nervous? I’ve been stress-eating for four days. Look at me. I’m wearing my fat pants.
response: Remarkable. In just under a half hour, 200 metric tons of fuel will ignite in a controlled expl*si*n right beneath Howard’s keister. And all from a country whose entire contribution to the global economy, has been Tetris and mail-order brides.

speaker: Well, it was going to be mine.
response: Thank you for the invitation, but I have to decline because it doesn’t sound like something I’ll enjoy.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, it’ll be fun.
response: That’s what you said about The Green Lantern movie. You were 114 minutes of wrong.

speaker: Look at all these people in love. It kind of gets you thinking, doesn’t it?
response: It does, indeed. Leonard, is it awkward being here with Penny given that you recently proposed to her?

speaker: Why wasn’t it a real proposal?
response: He asked her during coitus.

speaker: There’s got to be some place special we could do it.
response: Leonard, where did you envision marrying Penny?

speaker: Great, well, who’s it going to be?
response: I’ll do it, provided I can perform the ceremony in Klingon.

speaker: No.
response: What do you see in her?

speaker: Oh, thanks, man.
response: You didn’t have to do that.

speaker: Oh, wow.
response: Oh, dear. I was afraid of this.

speaker: What?
response: While a thoughtful gift, this comic book in this condition is worth at least a hundred dollars.

speaker: Yeah, so?
response: I bought you and Bernadette a gravy boat worth eighty-eight dollars. Which places me in your debt and I can’t be in your debt because someday you might ask me to help you move, or to k*ll a man.

speaker: I doubt he’ll ask you to k*ll a man.
response: Well, what if it’s his only way out? I can’t risk it. Here is twelve dollars. Now, we’re even. Wait, wait, wait, I bought a card. Give me two dollars. And for the record, this is why I hate gift-giving.

speaker: No.
response: I think the Reverend Hofstadter is making an ironic connection between your statement about love and your rejection of his proposal in the bedroom.

speaker: Thank you, Amy. Very touching. Howard and Bernadette, you are lucky enough to be best friends who love each other. And that’s the strongest kind of love because at its core, it has kindness, patience, and respect. Qualities that are hard to find in people these days.
response: Would you like some aloe vera? You just got b*rned. All right, my turn. Howard, Bernadette. (Begins speaking in Klingon)

speaker: Sheldon! I told you no Klingon.
response: Fine, I’ll do it in English, but it loses something. The need to find another human being to share one’s life with has always puzzled me. Maybe because I’m so interesting all by myself. With that being said, may you find as much happiness with each other as I find on my own. The Klingon would have made you cry.

speaker: By the power vested in us, by the state of California…
response: And the Klingon High Council…

speaker: This is it.
response: Boldly go, Howard Wolowitz.

speaker: Oy vay!
response: I've invented a science joke, would you like to hear it?

response: How many Edisons does it take to screw in a light bulb?
