speaker: If you want, I can yell at you later.
response: It won't be as good.

speaker: That’s a Hanukkah present you’re regretting, huh?
response: I won’t say that all senior citizens who can’t master technology should be publicly flogged, but if we made an example of one or two, it might give the others incentive to try harder.

speaker: I had a great idea. You know how we’re always having to stop and solve differential equations, like when you’re doing Fourier analysis, or using the Schrodinger equation?
response: Howard doesn’t. He’s only an engineer.

speaker: You know what’s a great app? The one that makes fart noises.
response: You know, Leonard, that’s actually a valid idea. Very good.

speaker: Can you say that and not make it sound like I’m a cat who learned how to use the toilet?
response: No. The two achievements are equally surprising and equally admirable, though if pressed, I’d have to give a slight edge to the cat. I’ll save you the pain and nervousness of waiting for the answer. I agree to be part of your project. Congratulations.

speaker: Yeah.
response: Oh!

speaker: I checked the App Store. No one is doing handwriting-recognition differential equation solving.
response: Oh, dear Lord, shush.

speaker: What?
response: You have so few good ideas, Leonard. And you’re just going to spill the beans in front of an outsider?

speaker: Sheldon, I don’t think Penny cares about handwriting-recognition based differential…
response: The stars at night are big and bright, deep in the heart of Texas.

speaker: We’re gonna write an application…
response: The prairie sky is wide and high, deep in the heart…

speaker: Okay, stop, stop!
response: Of Texas.

speaker: Satisfied?
response: Hardly. Consider this unlikely but very plausible scenario. A young woman alone in the big city. Her ridiculous dream of becoming an actress lies shattered about her.

speaker: Well, hang on. Let’s see where he’s going.
response: Then it hits her. How is she going to survive? I mean, she has no prospects, no marketable k*ll. And then one day, she meets a group of geniuses and their friend Howard.

speaker: Hang on. Let’s see where he’s going.
response: She befriends them, and then lies in wait until they reveal a marketable idea, which she steals and sells to the highest bidder.

speaker: That is ridiculous.
response: Oh, is it? Well let’s see you come up with an explanation as to why this woman hangs out with us all the time.

speaker: There’s your answer, free food.
response: All right, I’ve taken the liberty of drafting these workflow charts which outline our various duties and the path we will follow as we develop our ground-breaking new app.

speaker: Hey, why am I in charge of phone support? Seems a bit r*cist.
response: A customer service representative with an Indian accent will create the impression we’re a vast enterprise that uses overseas call centres.

speaker: Oh. Very clever. But still r*cist.
response: Duly noted, Steve from Wichita.

speaker: Why am I listed as your executive assistant?
response: Because the word secretary has fallen into disrepute. FYI, my mother’s birthday is coming up. I’m going to need you to pick up a present.

speaker: Okay, we need to stop for a minute.
response: Leonard, please, we can talk during our break. We have one coming up at midnight. We’ll need snacks.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re not in charge. It’s my idea. I’m in charge.
response: Oh, of course you are. Look at the organizational chart. You’re clearly listed as founder.

speaker: Well, yes, and you’re listed as Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer.
response: You missed Chief Science Officer, Chairman of the Board, and Head of the Secret Santa Committee.

speaker: Ooh. Leonard’s going all alpha nerd on Sheldon’s ass.
response: All right. All right, I’m not going to argue with you. Sheldon Cooper is nothing if not a team player. Dr. Hofstadter, you have the conn.

speaker: Thank you. I thought we might start by talking about the user interface.
response: Oh, dear Lord, we’re doomed.

speaker: So this button here will allow you to scan a new equation, but over here, you can press this, and just substitute new values for the coefficients.
response: Good one, boss.

speaker: What?
response: This diagram. I assume you were opening with a joke. It certainly buoyed up this employee’s esprit de corps.

speaker: It’s not a joke. It’s the real design.
response: In that case, may I offer 27 little tweaks to make it slightly less embarrassing?

speaker: Sheldon, I think this will work. Let’s just try it my way.
response: Oh, I’m, I’m sorry. I assumed that you wanted candid truth-telling from your employees, but I realize now, you want the mindless nattering of complacent yes-men.

speaker: Are you done?
response: If you say so, boss.

speaker: So right now, this button-press event is just triggering a dummy procedure call…
response: How about this for the app name? The Surprisingly Helpful Equation-Linked Differential Optimized Numerator.

speaker: So it spells Sheldon?
response: Does it? A happy accident.

speaker: Like I was saying, right now it’s just a dummy procedure, but eventually, it will drop us into…
response: All right, fine. If we’re not going to give it a name, can we at least give it a secret code designation?

speaker: No.
response: Well, but hear me out. The atomic b*mb was The Manhattan Project. Windows 95 was originally Project Chicago. For our app, I would humbly suggest Project Nodlehs.

speaker: That’s just Sheldon backwards.
response: Another happy accident.

speaker: We’re not wasting time with names right now.
response: I see. Is that decision open for discussion?

speaker: No.
response: Is the decision to not discuss it open for discussion?

speaker: Again, right now it’s just a dummy procedure, but eventually, it will drop us into…
response: I call for a vote of no confidence and an immediate change in leadership.

speaker: Oh Sheldon, stop it.
response: When in the course of human events, it becomes necessary to dissolve the bonds that tie three competent scientists together…

speaker: That’s enough, Sheldon.
response: All right, let’s get right to the vote. Show of hands all those opposed to Leonard and his reign of tyranny.

speaker: Okay, that’s it, you’re fired.
response: Really? Why?

speaker: Because you’re impossible to work with.
response: I see. And is that open for discussion?

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Oh. Good morning, shoemaker. I think you’ll be pleased with what the elves were up to last night.

speaker: But I fired you.
response: Oh, I know. I’m now an independent contractor.

speaker: No, you are now nothing. You have no connection to this project whatsoever.
response: But I made it better.

speaker: I don’t want it better. I want it my way.
response: Well, that speaks volumes, doesn’t it? All right, I suppose I’ll go put on my bus pants.

speaker: What the hell are bus pants?
response: They are pants one wears over one’s regular pants when one sits on bus seats that other people have previously sat on. But perhaps from your lofty heights atop the corporate ladder, you’ve lost touch with the struggles of the common man.

speaker: Look, I’m still happy to drive you to work. Nothing’s changed in that regard. We’re still roommates, we’re still friends.
response: Except you identified me, your best friend, as a gangrenous limb that needed to be severed from the organism and tossed away. The desperate act of a little man with a big Napoleon complex.

speaker: It means after we play handball, I’m showering at home.
response: Good morning, Friend Howard. Friend Raj. I see you gentlemen are enjoying beverages. Perhaps they would taste better out of these.

speaker: World’s Greatest Astrophysicist?
response: Don’t thank me. You earned it.

speaker: Howard Wolowitz. Why not World’s Greatest Engineer?
response: I’m sorry. I typed that into the label maker, but I just couldn’t press enter. Now down to business. What would it take for you to abandon Leonard and join me in a rival company? Unless, of course, the mugs are sufficient, in which case, welcome aboard.

speaker: We’re not quitting on Leonard.
response: I understand. And your loyalty is admirable. But what if I were to up the ante?

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: Monogrammed key chains with a built-in laser pointer. No? How about can cosies emblazoned with our university mascot? Go, Beavers. I’ll be back.

speaker: No. The moment has passed.
response: Greetings, gentlemen. How goes your little project?

speaker: You mean, Project Lenwoloppali?
response: Ah, a combination of all your names. Very clever. I assume Koothranardowitz was taken?

speaker: We’re actually scanning equations and getting good results.
response: Oh, well then, by all means, carry on. I wouldn’t want to impede your progress.

speaker: What are you doing?!
response: Playing the theremin.

speaker: No. I mean, what are you doing with a theremin?
response: Playing it. I’ve loved the theremin from the first moment I heard the original Star Trek theme. And it’s been k*ll me that it just sits in my closet, gathering dust.

speaker: Sheldon! We’re working here!
response: That’s all right. I can barely hear you over my theremin. (Leonard pulls out plug) Well, that was a little uncalled for.

speaker: No, that was completely called for. We need quiet.
response: So, your project is more important than mine?

speaker: Well, seeing as your project is to sabotage my project, yes.
response: Don’t b*at around the bush, Leonard. If you don’t want me here, just say the word, and I’ll leave.

speaker: What you doing? Trying to contact your home planet?
response: I’m practicing my theremin.

speaker: Oh.
response: Nobody knows the trouble I’ve seen. Glory, hallelujah.

speaker: Something got you down, there, Sheldon?
response: Leonard kicked me out of my own apartment. And his app team.

speaker: Oh, honey, I’m sorry.
response: He wouldn’t drive me to work today. I had to wear my bus pants.

speaker: Is that so?
response: Yes. And they’re still sticky.

speaker: Aw.
response: Probably going to have to throw them away.

speaker: Hey, you don’t need Leonard and his app. You can make one with me.
response: With you?

speaker: Seriously, I have a great idea for one.
response: Is it better than your idea to move to Los Angeles and become a famous actress?

speaker: Okay, look, when you see someone wearing shoes you like, you just snap a picture of them, and the app goes on the Internet to find out where you can buy them.
response: That’s your app idea?

speaker: Well, you don’t like it?
response: I didn’t say that. But no, I don’t.

speaker: Why not?
response: Oh, Penny, where do I begin? The simple-mindedness of your idea is exceeded only by its crass consumerism and banality.

speaker: And Leonard didn’t want to work with you? Imagine that.
response: I know, it’s baffling. (Singing) Nobody knows the trouble I’ve seen.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m gonna make some cocoa. Do you want some?
response: Do you make it with milk or water?

speaker: Milk.
response: Real cocoa?

speaker: That’s what it says on the packet.
response: Do you have those little marshmallows?

speaker: No, sorry.
response: Well, I suppose it’s appropriate.

speaker: What does that mean?
response: A disappointing drink for a disappointing day.

speaker: Oh, yes. He says they are lost without you.
response: Well, we sure saw that coming.

speaker: That’s right.
response: You know what I’m going to do? I am going to sit here and just let them stew.

speaker: No, no, no. You know, they have suffered enough. Everybody’s suffered enough. The thing is, you’re going to have to offer him a face-saving way out of this.
response: How?

speaker: Say you’re sorry.
response: Oh, no. Mrs. Mary Cooper didn’t raise her no liars.

speaker: Okay. Um, how about this? You know how you’re always trying to learn about sarcasm?
response: No.

speaker: No?
response: I was being sarcastic.

speaker: Oh. Good for you. So all you have to do here is say you’re sorry to Leonard, but say it sarcastically.
response: Of course. He will hear it as an attempt to mend fences, as opposed to the withering condemnation you and I will know it to be.

speaker: Yeah. Yeah, that was my plan. All right. Come on. Let’s go.
response: Oh, by the way, thank you for the delicious cocoa.

speaker: Oh, you’re welcome.
response: Boy, I’m getting good at this.

speaker: Okay, now that you’re back on the team, let’s get you caught up.
response: Before you begin, let me say again how deeply sorry I am for my earlier behaviour and how much I respect and admire your leadership.

speaker: Thank you. So as you can see, not only can you store your favourite equations, but you can forward them to your friends or post them on Facebook right from the app.
response: Well, I must say, I am impressed.

speaker: Thanks.
response: You all have clearly put in a lot of hard work.

speaker: We have.
response: As a result, you have taken the most important step on the road to success, learning what not to do. Now, let’s start fresh. Howard, we’re going to need some tea.

speaker: Okay, these are Uggs. These are Crocs. These are knockoff Manolo Blahniks.
response: Bored.

speaker: Look, you said it yourself, we have to create a database before you can write an alga-thingy.
response: Algorithm. You see, Penny, Alan Turing defined an algorithm…

speaker: Bored. Okay. These are Steve Maddens. These are Nine West. These are Target. Oh, but don’t they look like Chanel? These are Michael Kors. These are Roxy. These are Sachel’s. Oh, these are Betsy Johnson, they’re so cute…
response: Nobody knows the trouble I’ve seen, nobody knows my sorrow…

speaker: Oh, great! I’ve always wanted to play Dungeons and Dragons.
response: Yeah, oh, I’m sorry. I should’ve mentioned this earlier. You’re not invited.

speaker: Why not?
response: Amy, from time to time, we men need to break free from the shackles of civility and get in touch with our primal animalistic selves.

speaker: By rolling dice and playing make-believe with little figurines?
response: Yeah, like a bunch of savages.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, to start our quest you need to open this little Christmas gift I got you.
response: A Christmas gift? You know I don’t enjoy Christmas.

speaker: What’s wrong with Christmas?
response: Oh, where to begin? Trees indoors. Overuse of the words ’tis and ’twas. And the absurd custom of one stocking. Everyone knows socks belong in pairs. Who uses one sock?

speaker: Pirate with a peg leg?
response: Actually that helps, thank you.

speaker: Would you just look inside?
response: Oh, a scroll. I like scrolls. They’re my third favourite system of transmitting the written word. After stone tablets and skywriting. You have all been summoned to join a thrilling Dungeons and Dragons adventure. Your quest begins in a secret northern village of elves who have all been massacred. I like where this is heading. Your task is to rescue their leader from a dungeon of ogres. Oh, that’s a saucy twist. That leader’s name, Santa Claus. No, no, no.

speaker: It’s actually ho, ho, ho, but you’ll get the hang of it. Thought it’d be fun to make a quest with a holiday theme.
response: Fun? Mixing Dungeons and Dragons with Christmas is like making a sandwich of grape jelly, the best-tasting jelly, and petroleum jelly, the worst-tasting jelly.

speaker: Okay, there are ogre tracks and a trail of broken candy canes in the snow. Sheldon, what do you do?
response: I signal my contempt for your cruel plan to shove Christmas joy down my throat by making a gesture that says get a load of this guy.

speaker: But, a cannon? Am I really out of the game?
response: Lucky.

speaker: Hey, guys. I don’t mean to interrupt your little game, but I thought you’d like to see what you’re missing out on. So, Bernadette? Bernadette’s wearing leopard-print pumps and a rack-tastic red dress from Forever 21. And there’s Amy, showing all kinds of ankle. In an outfit I’m assuming is from Forever 63. And I, myself am wearing a little number that got me out of two speeding tickets and jury duty.
response: I know they’re making a rhetorical point, I just don’t know what it is.

speaker: I walk up to the large chest, bury my face in it and go “blublublublublublublublu”
response: I open the chest.

speaker: Oh, boy, happy place, happy place.
response: Wait, Svaty Vaclav was the Duke of Bohemia.

speaker: Seven, six.
response: Wait, wait. Svaty Vaclav is better known as Good King Wenceslas from the beloved Victorian Christmas carol.

speaker: Somebody sing the damn song.
response: Good King Wenceslas looked out, on the feast of Stephen. When the snow lay ’round about, deep and crisp and even

speaker: The walls are getting slower.
response: Brightly shone the moon that night, though the frost was cruel. When a poor man came in sight gathering winter fuel.

speaker: How did you know that?
response: It was simple. I combined a well-known historical fact about Bohemia with the memory of my grandparents, Mee-Maw and Pop-Pop, singing Christmas carols while I sat in front of the fire and tried to build a high-energy particle accelerator out of Legos.

speaker: Okay, continuing our quest.
response: W-W-Wait. There’s still four more verses. You don’t sing a song and not finish it. Hither, page, and stand by me, if thou know’st it, telling. Yonder peasant, who is he? Where and what his dwelling? Brightly shone the moon that night, though the frost…

speaker: Done?
response: I think the word you’re looking for is bravo.

speaker: Okay, you leave the room and find yourself standing before a pool of melted snowmen.
response: Melted snowmen? Are there carrots and lumps of coal in the water?

speaker: I don’t know. What’s the difference?
response: Well it’s a game of the imagination, Leonard. Paint a picture.

speaker: Fine. You leave the room and find yourself standing before a pool of melted snowmen. There are carrots and lumps of coal in the water.
response: What happened to the top hats and the corncob pipes?

speaker: You see those, too.
response: Oh, it’s like I’m really there.

speaker: What are you drinking there? A little eggnog?
response: Yes. What, is there a problem?

speaker: No, it’s nice to see you enjoying a holiday beverage. Pretty Christmassy.
response: Since when is eggnog a Christmas drink? Eggs are available all year ’round. I’ve been known to enjoy this poolside.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. You know all the Christmas stories, and the carols, you’ve got an eggnog moustache going on there. Just admit it. You’re getting a little Yuletide spirit.
response: Oh, don’t be silly. Christmas is a bunch of baloney created by the tinsel industry. Why is this so important to you?

speaker: I grew up in a house full of crazy academics. Instead of leaving Santa milk and cookies, we had to leave him a research paper. And in the morning, you could tell he’d been there because the paper would be graded.
response: No wonder you love Christmas. That sounds amazing.

speaker: It wasn’t amazing. I got a C-minus four years in a row.
response: Yeah, I’m familiar with your work. C-minus was your gift.

speaker: My carpal tunnel’s acting up.
response: Play through the pain.

speaker: I take out my skeleton key and run to Santa to unchain him.
response: But first, I cast a spell of paralysis on Stuart and Howard.

speaker: Wait, what are you doing?
response: You can’t talk, you’re paralyzed. I get right up in Santa’s big, fat face and say, well, well, well, jolly old Saint Nick, we meet again. Yeah, I believe the last time we spoke was in the Baybrook Mall in Galveston, Texas, when I was five years old, isn’t that right?

speaker: Uh, okay.
response: My mother dragged me there and she plopped me down on your lap and you asked me what I wanted for Christmas. And I told you, my Pop-Pop, because that was the year my grandfather died. I missed him and I wanted him back.

speaker: This is weird, right?
response: Pop-Pop was the only one in my family who encouraged me to pursue science. But you didn’t bring him back, did you? No, instead, I got Lincoln Logs. Well, you can build a lot of neat things out of Lincoln Logs, but Pop-Pop ain’t one of ‘em. And now you’re here asking me for something, to save you. Well, sorry, Mr. Kringle, but today’s not your day. I’m leaving you here to rot, and I hope the ogres feast on your bones. I take the skeleton key, and I toss it into the chasm, and on the way out, I give Santa a swift kick in his bowl full of jelly!

speaker: Oh, hello, Sheldon. You should be asleep.
response: Well, then, you shouldn’t have jingle bells on your boots.

speaker: Oh. I’ve been wanting to talk to you. I’m sorry I disappointed you when you were a little boy. I can do a lot of magical things, but unfortunately bringing your Pop-Pop back isn’t one of them.
response: I understand.

speaker: But I do have something special for you. Close your eyes.
response: Oh, I hope it’s a train.

speaker: Oh, it’s better than a train.
response: Two trains?

speaker: Better.
response: I’m getting three trains.

speaker: Okay, open ‘em. (It’s a cannon, pointed at Sheldon) This is for leaving me in the dungeon to be eaten alive by ogres!
response: Wait, uh, uh, hang on. In my defense…

speaker: I’m telling you, if xenon emits ultraviolet light, then those dark matter discoveries must be wrong.
response: Yes, well, if we lived in a world where slow-moving xenon produced light, then you’d be correct. Also, pigs would fly, my derriere would produce cotton candy, and The Phantom Menace would be a timeless classic.

speaker: Oh, you’re so arrogant. If you were a superhero, your name would be Captain Arrogant. And you know what your superpower would be? Arrogance.
response: You’re wrong again. If my superpower were arrogance, my name would be Dr. Arroganto.

speaker: Has it occurred to you you’re missing the big picture? If you look at neutron scattering data…
response: Oh, Penny? Penny?

speaker: What’s up?
response: Nothing. I just wanted to make Raj stop talking.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello. I see you decided to go with pathetic and frightened.

speaker: You’re being unreasonable. Why can’t I have a desk?
response: Our collaboration is a work of the mind. We don’t need desks.

speaker: You have a desk.
response: Correct.

speaker: But I can’t have one.
response: You’re two for two.

speaker: Why can’t he have a desk, Sheldon?
response: Oh, Lord, will this day never end? As I’ve explained repeatedly to Dr. Koothrappali, whose ability to comprehend the American idiom fails him when it’s convenient, there’s absolutely no money in my budget for additional office furniture.

speaker: Oh, but there’s money for a drawer full of Red Vines, a marshmallow sh**ting r*fle, and a super executive ant farm with glow-in-the-dark sand?
response: Yes.

speaker: Yeah, what if I buy my own desk?
response: That’s ridiculous.

speaker: Why?
response: Because…

speaker: Yes?
response: It’s my office.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: All right, all right. He can buy his own desk.

speaker: And I can put it in your office?
response: Well, you really want to dot the I’s and cross the T’s, don’t you?

speaker: Why would you want a glow-in-the-dark ant farm?
response: They do some of their best work at night.

speaker: Ah, it’s okay.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Knock, knock, knock) Penny? (Penny opens door. Howard is stood outside with a hand-held voice recorder.) Penny?

speaker: So anyway, Howard asked Penny to talk to Bernadette, and she did, and Bernadette agreed to meet him for a cup of coffee.
response: One question.

speaker: Yeah?
response: Why on earth are you telling me all this?

speaker: You said I could buy a desk.
response: This isn’t a desk. This is a Brobdingnagian monstrosity.

speaker: Is that the American idiom for giant, big-ass desk?
response: It’s actually British.

speaker: Can you say it again for me?
response: Brobdingnagian.

speaker: One more time?
response: Brobdingnagian.

speaker: Now three times fast?
response: Brobdingnagian, Brobdingna… How did you even get it in here?

speaker: That’s for me, Ramon, Julio, Jesus and Rodrigo to know and you to find out.
response: All right, you’ve made your point. A fine prank, very amusing. Now get it out.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: I have three brothers and two sisters, Sheldon, I can do this all day.
response: All right, if you’re not going to remove it, I’ll remove it for you.

speaker: Knock yourself out.
response: Help me move my desk.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: No.
response: Yes.

speaker: No. It’s too Brobdingnagian.
response: Why do you even want this here? Its size is completely disproportionate to its purpose.

speaker: Well, seeing as its purpose was to piss you off, I’d say it’s spot-on.
response: All right, I see what’s going on. This is the opening salvo in what will be an escalating series of juvenile tit-for-tat exchanges. Well titted.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Stand by for my upcoming tat.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon?
response: Yes?

speaker: Sorry, dude, the thermostat’s on my side of the room, so it stays Mumbai hot in here until you turn off that stupid Indian music!
response: I’ll turn off the music when you get rid of that salmonella-ridden parakeet!

speaker: Oh, too bad! Sheldon’s pathologically afraid of birds! Hey, look, Sheldon! Birdie, birdie, birdie!
response: That’s it! Prepare for marshmallow death!

speaker: Oh, God, what’s that smell? (Knocks on Sheldon’s door. Sheldon answers in a gas mask). Oh-ho-hoo!
response: Yes?

speaker: What are you doing in there?
response: I’m making hydrogen sulphide and ammonia gas. Just a little experiment in pest control.

speaker: It’s not gonna work, dude, I grew up in India, an entire subcontinent where cows walk in the street, and nobody has ever had a solid bowel movement.
response: Well, we’ll just see how long you can hold out.

speaker: Didn’t you say you’re making hydrogen sulphide gas?
response: Yes.

speaker: Isn’t that flammable?
response: Highly. Oh, dear. (expl*si*n)

speaker: Hello.
response: So, Penny, I understand you would like to learn more about flags.

speaker: Yeah, I can’t tell you how many times I’ve been at a party where everyone’s talking about flags and I just couldn’t join in.
response: Yeah. Well, you came to the right place.

speaker: Uh, I’m sorry, can we just pause for a minute?
response: What’s wrong?

speaker: I just think it might look more natural if you talked to me instead of the camera, you know, like, like a real conversation. It’s something we work on in my acting class.
response: Interesting. A few people in the comments section have said that my delivery is robotic. Perhaps that isn’t the compliment it sounds like.

speaker: Yeah, let’s try it again, and maybe, this time, you could work on your body language a bit. You know, when you’re all hunched like that, you’re shutting the audience out, but when you’re relaxed and open, you’re inviting them in.
response: Right. And which one do I want?

speaker: Let’s try open.
response: If our friend, the flag, has taught me anything, it’s to go where the wind takes you. As long as you remain firmly attached to a rigid pole. And, action. So, Penny, what sort of flag questions keep you awake at night?

speaker: Um, well, I’m from Nebraska. So what can you tell me about the state flag?
response: Gosh, Penny, what’d you have for breakfast? A big glass of good question juice? The Nebraska state flag is simply the state seal on a field of blue. Spread your legs, invite them in.

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: Hello. How’s the final stage of your nicotine addiction study going?

speaker: Fine. Just hold on. Mommy’s on the phone! Sorry. We’ve cut the monkeys down to one cigarette a day, so things are a little intense. Makes me miss my marijuana-abusing flatworms. Those guys were mellow.
response: Good news. Uh, the latest episode of Fun with Flags is online.

speaker: Oh, that’s right. How’d it go with Penny?
response: Much better than I expected. She even gave me some helpful tips about acting and body language. Watch. Welcome to my world. Not welcome to my world. Welcome. Not welcome.

speaker: Subtle, but powerful.
response: I know. I’m still learning to control it.

speaker: Did you tell Penny how helpful she was?
response: Why would I do that?

speaker: Because she’s your friend, and she did a nice job. I’m sure she’d like to hear it.
response: All right.

speaker: Oh, hi. What’s up?
response: Um…

speaker: You need me to shut the door so you can do your knocking thing?
response: No. I didn’t start yet, it’s fine.

speaker: Okay. So, what do you need?
response: Well, I was thinking about you helping me out last night (knock, knock, knock)Penny. And I just wanted to tell you (knock, knock, knock) Penny, that the answer to the question, who did a great job? is you, (knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: Really?
response: Yes, you were very natural in front of the camera, and I found your suggestions extremely helpful.

speaker: Aw, sweetie, you just made my day.
response: Okay.

speaker: Hey, my acting class is putting on a play Friday night. I could put you and Amy on the guest list.
response: Oh, that sounds terrible. Why would I want to do that?

speaker: That’s right. They’re no good without the lighter.
response: Well, so much for your advice on complimenting Penny.

speaker: Why? What happened?
response: She tried to rope us into going to her acting class to see a play. Don’t worry. Luckily, I had the good sense to drown that kitten in the river.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s very rude. She helped you with your show. The right thing to do is reciprocate by going to see her play.
response: Oh, so many crazy rules.

speaker: What?
response: Amy pointed out to me that since you did something nice for me, I’m obligated to do something nice for you. So, yes, I’ll go to your dopey play.

speaker: Hey, I don’t want you to go any more.
response: Why not?

speaker: You should go ’cause you want to go, not because you have to.
response: Oh, Dear Lord, more rules? Where does it stop? Can I want to go because I have to want to go?

speaker: Okay. Do whatever you want.
response: Yeah, but now, wait. Do whatever I want? Or whatever I have to want?

speaker: Oh, for God’s sake, just come to the play.
response: All right. I don’t want to, but at least that makes sense.

speaker: He’s just decided he’s never leaving his apartment again.
response: Oh, brilliant. I’ve been itching to pull that trigger.

speaker: He’s upset because he can’t get anywhere with women.
response: Would it help if I gave him some pointers? I’m just funnin’ ya.

speaker: I’m sorry. That I asked.
response: All right, let’s get this stupid play over with.

speaker: Uh, hang on. Empty your pockets.
response: Why?

speaker: You know why. The Nintendo DS. And the PSP. Now the Gameboy.
response: Aw, for Pete’s sake. Can we go now?

speaker: Just so you know, this is not a stupid play. A Streetcar Named Desire is an American classic.
response: It’s about streetcars? Oh, great. I won’t need this. (Pulls out an etch-a-sketch.)

speaker: She’s pretty good, huh?
response: She is. But when do they get to the part about streetcars?

speaker: …when I was a very young girl. When I was 16 years old, I made the discovery, love. All at once, and much, much too completely. It was like you suddenly turned a blinding light on something that had always been half a shadow. That’s how it struck the world for me. But I was unlucky. Deluded.
response: She’s remarkable.

speaker: Our Penny’s a star.
response: How can she remember all those lines, but as a waitress, she can’t remember no tomato on my hamburger?

speaker: Can we please talk about something other than my depressing love life?
response: How about Penny’s depressing acting career?

speaker: Serial Ape-ist? I thought you died in that.
response: She does. 42 minutes in.

speaker: While showering topless, 16 minutes after brief side butt during a pillow fight with her sorority sisters.
response: I have an eidetic memory. I don’t know what his problem is.

speaker: Okay, well, there are no shower scenes in this one. They just try to clone me from my corpse, but my DNA gets mixed with the ape’s DNA and I end up running around with giant gorilla hands and feet.
response: Am I missing something, or isn’t that the part she was born to play?

speaker: I think we’re gonna go.
response: Are you sure? We were making fun of failed careers. We didn’t get to tap the juicy vein that is Howard’s.

speaker: Hey, I work at the same university you do.
response: Yes, and Hawkeye’s in the Avengers, but no one ever says help, Hawkeye.

speaker: No, no, no. This is not a fight. I was just excited that someone offered you a part and a little surprised that you’d rather sit at home and do nothing than take it. Now it’s a fight.
response: Well, with that sorted out, I’m happy to answer your question, Bernadette. Howard started it.

speaker: I didn’t do anything. I was just sitting here.
response: I wasn’t referring to this evening. Ten years ago, upon first seeing me, your husband claimed that I looked like C-3PO and Pee-wee Herman. And he called me C-3P-wee Herman.

speaker: That was ten years ago.
response: Nine years, 11 months and three weeks ago, he followed that up by replacing the slides for my lecture with photographs of nude fat women bending over.

speaker: I was there. It was funny.
response: In any event, that began a decade-long progression of insults, pranks and unwanted magazine subscriptions. To this day, I still get a monthly copy of Granny on Granny. Which, other than its surprisingly fun puzzle page, is complete filth.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: Listen, I was thinking you and I could probably try to be better friends.
response: Really? I was thinking what we have now is a bit much.

speaker: Seriously, I was talking to Bernadette last night and she made some great points. You and I have known each other a long time, and I didn’t hear the rest ’cause she took her bra off.
response: Very well. How do you propose we move forward?

speaker: Uh, for starters, we could stop insulting each other.
response: That’s a great idea. And in the spirit of our new arrangement, I will mask my surprise that you came up with it.

speaker: Anyway, I got invited to do a little talk at NASA in Houston this weekend. They gave me two tickets. Bernadette can’t go. You want to come with me? You can visit your mom, and I’ll show you around the space centre.
response: I have one question. Is this a prank where we land in Houston and you’ve made up wanted posters that have my face with a moustache and a Spanish name and then I get arrested and deported to South America?

speaker: No.
response: I’m glad because I would not have seen that coming.

speaker: Oh, it’s no problem. Is everything okay?
response: Oh, I’m fine. It’s just some, uh, stomach medication for my trip. There’s the remote yet distinct possibility that I may end up in South America.

speaker: Remember the old days when I would’ve said something dumb like why? Uh, that doesn’t sound good.
response: Remember the old days when I used to point out that your check engine light was on?

speaker: Yes.
response: Well, get ready to stroll down memory lane. Penny, your check engine…

speaker: Yeah, I know it’s on, Sheldon. Oh, no, no, no, no, no. I cannot afford this right now.
response: Maybe it’s just something minor. Ooh, good news, the light just went out.

speaker: Teams are fun.
response: Oh, in that case, I’d like to be partnered with my good friend Howard.

speaker: How? Unlike me, you have a job. I’m just gonna have to go back to being a waitress, like I will be for the rest of my life.
response: Leonard, would you wrap it up? We’re waiting on you.

speaker: I’m sorry, is the fact that my life’s falling apart interfering with your board game?
response: It is. You were wrong, friend Howard. She completely understood.

speaker: How do I know what you said? Damn you and your noise-cancelling breasts.
response: Hello.

speaker: You excited for Texas?
response: Oh, very much so.

speaker: It’s not every day you get to tour NASA with a real astronaut.
response: Oh, who’s the real astronaut?

speaker: Buzz Aldrin.
response: Oh. Yay.

speaker: What now?
response: I have to go to the bathroom.

speaker: You just went to the bathroom.
response: But I didn’t use it because it didn’t seem safe. Despite all my e-mails, the toilet didn’t have a seatbelt.

speaker: Well, it still doesn’t.
response: I realize that, but safety concerns went out the window two apple juices ago.

speaker: Fine.
response: Why are you getting annoyed?

speaker: I’m trying to be a better friend, but you constantly say and do irritating things.
response: Like when?

speaker: When? How about in the car? I’m an astronaut, and you know it. You just don’t like admitting it, because you’re jealous.
response: Well, truth be told, as a child, I did dream of going to space. Those astronauts were my heroes. And when you got to go, it was hard for me.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Because it made me realize they’ll just send anyone up there. Aren’t you going to let me out?

speaker: No.
response: But I still need to use the bathroom.

speaker: Here you go. Be creative. What’s the matter? Scared of a little turbulence?
response: No, turbulence is just the equalization of diurnal temperature variations in the atmosphere. I’m not scared at all. Oh, apple juice, stay where you are.

speaker: Oh, this is nothing. I experienced way worse when I was plummeting back to Earth, apparently not being a real astronaut. Okay, that was a big one.
response: I take it back. I’m scared of turbulence!

speaker: I’m sorry, too. It’s all my fault.
response: If you weren’t my friend, there’d be a hole in my life.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: Kind of like when Firefly was cancelled. But not as big.

speaker: It’s over.
response: Yeah.

speaker: Should we stop holding hands now?
response: In a minute.

speaker: Morning, Sheldon. Come dance with me.
response: No.

speaker: Why not?
response: Penny, while I subscribe to the many worlds theory which posits the existence of an infinite number of Sheldons in an infinite number of universes, I assure you that in none of them am I dancing.

speaker: Are you fun in any of them?
response: The math would suggest that in a few I’m a clown made of candy. But I don’t dance.

speaker: All right, want some French toast?
response: It’s Oatmeal Day.

speaker: Tell you what, next French Toast Day, I will make you oatmeal.
response: Dear Lord, are you still going to be here on French Toast Day?

speaker: Morning.
response: Look, Leonard, Penny made French toast.

speaker: Sorry. I haven’t given her your schedule yet.
response: It’s an iCal download, she can put it right in her phone. And I thought we agreed that you’d have your conjugal visits in her apartment.

speaker: We did, but there were extenuating circumstances.
response: I see. Did her abysmal housekeeping k*ll finally trump her perkiness?

speaker: No, her bed kind of… broke.
response: That doesn’t seem likely. Her bed’s of sturdy construction. Even the addition

speaker: Sorry. Okay, who wants syrup and who wants cinnamon sugar?
response: I want oatmeal.

speaker: Yes, well, I want a boyfriend whose roommate isn’t a giant pain in the ass.
response: I’m sure that will happen soon enough. But in the meantime, I still want oatmeal.

speaker: You know what, I give up. He’s impossible.
response: I can’t be impossible. I exist. I believe what you meant to say is, “I give up, he’s improbable.”

speaker: Sheldon, you really need to find a better way of dealing with Penny.
response: What am I supposed to do, eat French toast on a Monday? Now, that would be impossible.

speaker: I’m just saying, you can catch more flies with honey than with vinegar.
response: You can catch even more flies with manure. What’s your point?

speaker: It’s a… (gives up)
response: Boy, that does smell good. Too bad it’s Monday.

speaker: I know. What are the odds?
response: Easily calculable, we begin by identifying the set of married couples with unisex names. We then eliminate those unqualified for restaurant work, the aged, the imprisoned and the limbless, for example. Next we look at…

speaker: Sheldon! it’s an amazing coincidence, can we leave it at that?
response: I’m sorry. Ooh, Penny, it’s as if the Cheesecake Factory is run by witches.

speaker: Fine, whatever. Are you finished?
response: Well, thank you. How thoughtful. Would you like a chocolate

speaker: What was that?
response: You said be nice to Penny. I believe offering chocolate to someone falls within the definition of nice.

speaker: It does. But in my experience, you don’t.
response: There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy.

speaker: They’re called tattoo sleeves. Look. I bought them online, Raj got a set, too. Fantastic, right? Put them on, have hot sex with some freaky girl with her business pierced, take them off, and I can still be buried in a Jewish cemetery.
response: You know, I’ve always wanted to go to a goth nighclub.

speaker: Really?
response: Bazinga! None of you ever see my practical jokes coming, do you?

speaker: They’re gonna get b*at up at Walgreens. Oh, sorry, Sheldon, I almost sat in your spot.
response: Did you? I didn’t notice. Have a chocolate.

speaker: Oshikuru
response: And it’s not a cartoon, it’s anime.

speaker: Anime. You know, I knew a girl in high school named Anna May. Anna May Fletcher. She was born with one nostril. Then she had this bad nose job and basically wound up with three.
response: You’re here a lot now.

speaker: Oh, am I talking too much? I’m sorry. Zip.
response: Thank you. Chocolate?

speaker: Okay, I know what you’re doing.
response: Really?

speaker: Yes, you’re using chocolates as positive reinforcement for what you consider correct behaviour.
response: Very good. Chocolate?

speaker: No, I don’t want any chocolate! Sheldon, you can’t train my girlfriend like a lab rat.
response: Actually, it turns out I can.

speaker: Well, you shouldn’t.
response: There’s just no pleasing you, is there, Leonard? You weren’t happy with my previous approach to dealing with her, so I decided to employ operant conditioning techniques, building on the work of Thorndike and B.F. Skinner. By this time next week, I believe I can have her jumping out of a pool, balancing a beach ball on her nose.

speaker: No, this has to stop now.
response: I’m not suggesting we really make her jump out of a pool. I thought the “bazinga” was implied. I’m just tweaking her personality, sanding off the rough edges if you will.

speaker: No, you’re not sanding Penny.
response: Are you saying that I’m forbidden from applying a harmless, scientifically valid protocol that will make our lives better?

speaker: Yes, you’re forbidden.
response: Bad Leonard.

speaker: What could she possibly be talking about for so long?
response: Obviously, waitressing at the Cheesecake Factory is a complex socioeconomic activity, that requires a great deal of analysis and planning. Bazinga! You know, using positive reinforcement techniques, I could train that behaviour out of her in a week.

speaker: No.
response: If you let me use negative reinforcement, I can get it done before we go to bed.

speaker: You’re not squirting her in the face with water.
response: No, of course not. We’re talking very mild electric shocks. No tissue damage whatsoever.

speaker: Forget it.
response: Oh, come on, you can’t tell me that you’re not intrigued about the possibility of building a better girlfriend.

speaker: I’m not. And Penny’s qualities, both good and bad, are what make her who she is.
response: You mean, like that high-pitched, irritating laugh?

speaker: You’re not changing how Penny laughs.
response: No, that would be incongruous, I was going to lower the whole voice to a more pleasing register.

speaker: Uh, sorry guys, that girl is (high pitched) freaky!
response: Come again?

speaker: Freaky.
response: Freaky?

speaker: Yeah, freaky.
response: Have a chocolate.

speaker: Of course.
response: Thank you. (Throws a chocolate. Penny catches it in her mouth)

speaker: Let’s go.
response: Interesting. Sex works even better than chocolate to modify behaviour. I wonder if anyone else has stumbled on to that.

speaker: Morning, Sheldon. Come dance with me.
response: No.

speaker: Why not?
response: Penny, while I subscribe to the many worlds theory which posits the existence of an infinite number of Sheldons in an infinite number of universes, I assure you that in none of them am I dancing.

speaker: Are you fun in any of them?
response: The math would suggest that in a few I’m a clown made of candy. But I don’t dance.

speaker: All right, want some French toast?
response: It’s Oatmeal Day.

speaker: Tell you what, next French Toast Day, I will make you oatmeal.
response: Dear Lord, are you still going to be here on French Toast Day?

response: Look, Leonard, Penny made French toast.

response: It’s an iCal download, she can put it right in her phone. And I thought we agreed that you’d have your conjugal visits in her apartment.

speaker: We did, but there were extenuating circumstances.
response: I see. Did her abysmal housekeeping k*ll finally trump her perkiness?

response: Come again?

speaker: Freaky.
response: Freaky?

speaker: Yeah, freaky.
response: Have a chocolate.

speaker: Of course.
response: Thank you. (Throws a chocolate. Penny catches it in her mouth)

speaker: Let’s go.
response: Interesting. Sex works even better than chocolate to modify behaviour. I wonder if anyone else has stumbled on to that.

speaker: Whatcha doin’ there? Working on a new plan to catch the roadrunner?
response: The humorous implication being that I am Wile E. Coyote?

speaker: Yes.
response: And this is a schematic for a bird-trapping device that will ultimately backfire and cause me physical injury?

speaker: Yes.
response: What I’m doing here is trying to determine when I’m going to die.

speaker: A lot of people are working on that research. So what is all this?
response: My family history factoring in longevity, propensity for disease, et cetera.

speaker: Interesting. Cause of death for Uncle Carl was KBB. What’s KBB?
response: k*ll by badger.

speaker: How’s that?
response: It was Thanksgiving. Uncle Carl said, I think there’s a badger living in our chimney. Hand me that flashlight. Those were the last words he ever spoke to us.

speaker: I don’t think you need to worry about death by badgers being hereditary.
response: Not true. The fight or flight instinct is coded genetically. Instead of fleeing, he chose to fight barehanded against a brawny member of the weasel family. Who’s to say that I don’t share that flawed DNA?

speaker: You can always get a badger and find out.
response: But seriously, even if I disregard the Uncle Carl factor, at best I have 60 years left.

speaker: That long, huh?
response: 60 only takes me to here. I need to get to here.

speaker: What’s there?
response: The earliest estimate of the singularity, when man will be able to transfer his consciousness into machines and achieve immortality.

speaker: So, you’re upset about missing out on becoming some sort of freakish self-aware robot?
response: By this much.

speaker: Tough break. You want eggs?
response: You don’t get it, Leonard. I’m going to miss so much, the unified field theory, cold fusion, the dogapus.

speaker: What’s a dogapus?
response: A hybrid dog and octopus. Man’s underwater best friend.

speaker: Is somebody working on that?
response: I was going to. I planned on giving it to myself on my 300th birthday.

speaker: Wait a minute. You hate dogs.
response: A dogapus can play fetch with eight balls. No one can hate that.

speaker: Sheldon, six bucks.
response: No, thank you. I’m not eating pizza tonight.

speaker: But it’s Thursday. Thursday’s pizza night.
response: Not for me. Thursday is now Cruciferous Vegetable Night. Tonight’s selection, brussels sprouts.

speaker: Really? You’re changing the Sheldonian calendar?
response: It’s a small price to pay.

speaker: Sorry, sorry, sorry, sorry, sorry.
response: In order to live long enough to fuse my consciousness with cybernetics, I need to change my diet.

speaker: Wait. Cybernetics is robot stuff, right?
response: Correct.

speaker: So you want to turn yourself into some sort of robot?
response: Essentially, yes.

speaker: Okay, here’s my question. Didn’t you already do that?
response: Flattering, but sadly, no. I’m also planning to begin an exercise regimen designed to strengthen my cardiovascular system. AKA jogging.

speaker: Wait. Honey,have you ever run before?
response: Certainly. I’ve run from bullies, dogs, angry chickens, and one particularly persistent P.E. teacher determined to bend me over and give me a scoliosis test.

speaker: You’re right, Penny jogs. Maybe you guys can run together.
response: That’s an excellent idea. Yeah, if we chat, it will create the illusion of time going faster.

speaker: What the hell? What’s the matter?
response: I have pain radiating from my navel to my lower right abdomen. I’m nauseated and feverish. I believe I may have cholera.

speaker: There’s no cholera in Pasadena. Just like last summer, when there was no malaria in Pasadena.
response: Well, if it’s not cholera, then based on a quick Internet search, the other explanations in decreasing order of likelihood are Hirschsprung’s Disease, botulism, a 30-foot tapeworm or accidental ingestion of chrysanthemum blossoms.

speaker: When would you have accidentally eaten chrysanthemum blossoms?
response: It’s part of an unlikely scenario that involves sleepwalking and a 24-hour flower mart with a less-than-vigilant proprietor. Oh, Lord, my belly!

speaker: Have you had your appendix out?
response: I haven’t. I’ve been meaning to, but who has the time?

speaker: Let’s get you to the hospital.
response: So this is how it ends, with cruel irony. Just as I make the commitment to preserving my body, I am betrayed by my appendix, a vestigial organ. Do you know the original purpose of the appendix, Leonard?

speaker: No.
response: I do. And yet I’m doomed while you live on.

speaker: Funny how things work out, isn’t it?
response: Oh, Lord, I think it’s about to burst! (Loud sound of farting) On the other hand, it might have been the Brussels sprouts.

speaker: Good night.
response: Good night. Appendicitis. What a nervous Nelly.

speaker: Coming, coming. Hey, nice knees.
response: Thank you. They’re my mother’s.

speaker: Oh. And the Flash shirt is what? Because you’re gonna run really fast?
response: No, the Flash shirt is because it’s Friday, but it’s nice when things work out. Where’s your heart rate monitor?

speaker: I don’t have one.
response: What about your pedometer?

speaker: Don’t have one.
response: Do you have telematics in your shoes connected to an iPod?

speaker: Uh, no.
response: What do you do, you just go out there and gambol about like a bunny?

speaker: No. I just run till I’m hungry, then I stop for a bear claw.
response: Why are you doing that?

speaker: It’s good to stretch your muscles before you run.
response: All right.

speaker: All right, let’s start with a toe touch. Okay, you do it.
response: I am doing it.

speaker: Oh. Wow. Good job. Okay, um, can you do this?
response: We’ll never know.

speaker: Okay, let’s just warm up on the run.
response: Okay.

speaker: Okay, let’s go.
response: Yeah, I’ve been reading up on biomechanics. I think you’ll be surprised at my… Wah! Oh!

speaker: Oh, my God, are you okay?
response: I think so.

speaker: Oh, let me help you up.
response: Thank you. (Loud sound of farting)

speaker: Oh, Sheldon!
response: If it makes you feel any better, Thursday is no longer Cruciferous Vegetable Night.

speaker: Sheldon, are you gonna join us?
response: Coming! (From the bedroom area, a wheeled device consisting of a base, a tee-shirt on a coat hanger, and a computer monitor with Sheldon’s face, appears). Greetings, friends.

speaker: Sheldon, this is ridiculous.
response: I’m behind you. Please look at me when you’re talking to me.

speaker: I am looking at you.
response: No, you’re not. Pay no attention to that man in the bed.

speaker: You cannot exist as a virtual presence. Not here and certainly not at work. Oh, good God.
response: At my age, do you know how I’m statistically most likely to die?

speaker: At the hands of your roommate?
response: An accident.

speaker: That’s how I’m going to make it look.
response: Until I can transfer my intellect to a more durable container, my body will remain safely ensconced in my bed.

speaker: Fine, but don’t expect my help.
response: You have to help, it’s in the roommate agreement.

speaker: No, it’s not.
response: Section 74.C. The various obligations and duties of the parties in the event one of them becomes a robot.

speaker: I can’t hear you, I’m in the shower.
response: I asked if you were in the shower, but that’s moot now.

speaker: What?
response: Moot. Rendered unimportant by recent events.

speaker: I can’t hear you, I’m in the shower.
response: I have to skip the chitchat. Emergency.

speaker: What kind of emergency?
response: Mathematical. 32-ounce banana smoothie, 16-ounce bladder.

speaker: You might not want to do that.
response: I assure you I do.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m not alone in here.
response: What?

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: What are you doing in there? She can’t be in here.

speaker: We were in here first, you can’t be in here.
response: According to the roommate agreement, paragraph nine, subsection B, the right to bathroom privacy is suspended in the event of force majeure. And believe me, I am experiencing a very majeure force.

speaker: What?
response: Move. Move. Move!

speaker: Proceed.
response: Very well. Count the first, on or about the 28th day of April, the accused did knowingly and with malice aforethought deny access to the shared bathroom in a time of emergency, to wit, my back teeth were floating. Count the second, the accused exceeded the agreed upon occupancy of the shower, to wit, one, unless we are under attack by water-soluble aliens.

speaker: Can I see the roommate agreement?
response: Um, it’s fairly technical.

speaker: All right, based on a cursory reading, it doesn’t look like you have much of a case, Sheldon.
response: Do so, do so.

speaker: Oh, I’m afraid not. Section seven here, on the right to enter the bathroom in emergency situations, is not specific as to what constitutes an emergency.
response: Oh, that’s ridiculous. A bathroom emergency is self-explanatory.

speaker: Is it? If Leonard forgot to trim his nose hair, could he barge in while you were showering?
response: Irrelevant. Leonard doesn’t trim his nose hair. He thinks because he’s short nobody can see up there.

speaker: My point is, Sheldon, the legal principle is ambiguity in a contract benefits the party that did not draft it, in this case, Leonard. So much for count one.
response: But…

speaker: Superceded!
response: This isn’t over.

speaker: I wish to discuss your theories of black holes. Meet me at the Randy’s Donut by the airport at 2
response: What is that you’re eating? Tonight is pizza night.

speaker: According to what I see here, Thursday nights are Franconi’s pizza night.
response: Yes, and when Franconi’s went out of business, we switched to Graziano’s.

speaker: A good question, Howard. Turns out you can’t. According to the document you drew up, Sheldon, the selection of a new takeout restaurant requires public hearings and a 60-day comment period. Were those criteria met?
response: No.

speaker: Opa!
response: This is Greek food? Leonard, you hate Greek food.

speaker: Not as much as you.
response: Fine. I’m nothing if not adaptable.

speaker: I got you the lamb kabob.
response: Thank you. If you think about it, Greek food isn’t that far from italian food. They share a spice palette. And what a civilization is the Greeks. They gave us science, democracy, and little cubes of charred meat that taste like sweat.

speaker: Hey. What’s up?
response: The mean Indian lady tried to make me eat lamb. Congratulations. Pizza night will now be at your apartment. Order one.

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, honey, I’m meeting Amy and Bernadette for dinner. But you’re welcome to tag along.
response: A girls night? Oh, I don’t know if I’m up for an evening talking about rainbows, unicorns and menstrual cramps.

speaker: Okay, suit yourself. We’ll probably be trashing Priya a little.
response: g*n.

speaker: Yeah. Last week we smoked cigars and pretended to be dragons.
response: Really, Amy? Tobacco and alcohol? Need I remind you not a lot of scientific discoveries were made by people having a good time?

speaker: You smell like baby powder.
response: It’s talc. But as that’s a primary ingredient of baby powder, I understand your confusion.

speaker: Oh, I’m not confused at all. You’re like a sexy toddler.
response: I don’t know how to process that.

speaker: Sheldon, have you ever kissed a girl?
response: Other than my mother, my sister and my mee-maw, no. But in the interest of full disclosure, I was once on a bus and had to give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to an elderly nun who passed out from heat exhaustion. Every year I get a Christmas card from her, signed with far too many X’s and O’s.

speaker: I’m available for experimentation.
response: Thank you. Not necessary. We know everything there is to know about kissing. It requires 34 facial muscles and 112 postural muscles.

speaker: Oh, blah, blah, blah. Give me some sugar, bestie (kisses Penny).
response: I’m certainly glad no one said they were curious about Aztec human sacrifice.

speaker: Oh, I totally want to see Sheldon dance. I bet he looks like a spider on a hot plate.
response: No, thank you, but for the record, I’m an excellent dancer. Proficient in the rumba, waltz and cha-cha.

speaker: Really?
response: I don’t see why that’s surprising. I excel at so many things. You’ve had my sourdough bread.

speaker: Did you take dance lessons?
response: Against my will. In the South, pre-adolescent children are forced through a process called cotillion, which indoctrinates them with all the social graces and dance k*ll needed to function in 18th century Vienna.

speaker: Oh, we are so taking you dancing.
response: No, you most certainly are not.

speaker: Well, what does your cotillion training say is expected of a gentleman when three ladies ask him to escort them to a dance soiree?
response: I saved a nun’s life. Why am I being punished?

speaker: Where you can what?
response: Waltz. It’s a social dance from Austria, choreographed to a three-four time signature. (Sings Blue Danube. The taxi driver says something into radio in Korean. The word “waltz” is included. Dispatcher replies also in Korean. Taxi driver sings Blue Danube. Dispatcher says “oh, waltz!” They speak Korean some more. )

speaker: I kissed a girl and I liked it, I hope my boyfriend don’t mind it.
response: What happened to you?

speaker: How come if we’re the smart people, we don’t do this every night?
response: What’s 16 times 14?

speaker: My burps taste like cranberry juice.
response: And there’s your answer.

speaker: Would you like to come in for a nightcap?
response: If you’re referring to the beverage, you know I don’t drink. If you’re referring to the hat you don while wearing a nightshirt and holding a candle, I have one.

speaker: I have yoo-hoo.
response: It’s hard to say no to yoo-hoo. The name literally beckons.

speaker: Make yourself comfortable.
response: Thank you. Is someone smoking?

speaker: Oh, that’s just Ricky.
response: You own a smoking monkey?

speaker: Don’t be silly. He’s one of the animals in my department’s nicotine addiction study.
response: What’s he doing here?

speaker: I’m giving him emphysema. The least I can do is let him hang out and watch cable.
response: Remarkable. Aren’t you worried about secondhand smoke?

speaker: A little. The real danger is him biting my face off while I’m sleeping.
response: is he deliberately blowing smoke at me?

speaker: Yeah. He’s kind of an ass.
response: Thank you. May I share something with you that’s troubling me?

speaker: Of course. What’s rattling around that big bulbous brain of yours?
response: Priya has essentially nullified my roommate agreement with Leonard, making life in the apartment very uncomfortable for me.

speaker: And you want me to k*ll her? Done.
response: No, of course not.

speaker: I trained Ricky how to smoke. I can train him to sh**t a poison dart. No jury would convict us ’cause people love monkeys.
response: I understand the alcohol has stirred up whatever it is that makes girls go wild, but I really need to talk to smart Amy now.

speaker: Excuse me. Have you considered that your intelligence might be the very thing causing your dilemma?
response: No.

speaker: What do you think Ricky over here would do if an interloper encroached on his territory?
response: Well, when challenged, monkeys generally assert their dominance through chasing, as*ault and a stylized penile display. That’s a little outside my comfort zone.

speaker: You’re being too literal. My point is, he would not meekly surrender to the rules, and neither should you.
response: Are you suggesting I play dirty?

speaker: Yes, dirty. Dirty, dirty, dirty. Which brings me to our next order of business. (Kisses him)
response: Fascinating.

speaker: I hope you don’t take what I’m about to do as a comment on what we just did. (Runs to bathroom and vomits)
response: Who’s to say you shouldn’t be dissecting our brains? You really are an ass.

speaker: Morning, Sheldon.
response: Oh, good, you’re up. I’ve written a new and improved roommate agreement that benefits me greatly. I’d like you to sign it.

speaker: Why would I want to do that?
response: Excellent question. Do you remember what happened to the alien, played by talented character actor Frank Gorshin, in the Star Trek episode Let That Be Your Last Battlefield?

speaker: Uh, Captain Kirk activated the self-destruct sequence and threatened to blow up the Enterpriseand k*ll them both unless he gave in?
response: Affirmative. Computer, this is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Activate self-destruct sequence. Code 1-1-A-2-B.

speaker: What are you gonna do, Sheldon, blow up the apartment?
response: That was my first thought, but all my cool stuff is here.

speaker: So what happens when it counts down?
response: Unless Leonard signs the new agreement in the next 41 seconds, this computer will send an e-mail to your parents in India saying that you’re in a secret relationship with the whiter-than-marshmallow-fluff Leonard Hofstadter.

speaker: Yeah, of course, just not today.
response: 20 seconds.

speaker: Please, don’t push this.
response: He does that all the time, doesn’t he? 15.

speaker: No, he’s bluffing.
response: I never bluff. Ten.

speaker: It’s blackmail!
response: Nine.

speaker: We give up.
response: Eight.

speaker: This is ridiculous. (Pulls out plug)
response: It’s a laptop with a full charge. Honestly, what do you see in him?

speaker: Give him what he wants or we’re done.
response: Three.

speaker: Really?
response: Two.

speaker: Self-destruct sequence aborted.
response: You may have gone to Cambridge, but I’m an honorary graduate of Starfleet academy.

speaker: It most assuredly is not.
response: Are you experiencing dehydration, headache, nausea and shame?

speaker: Yes. I also found a Korean man’s business card tucked into my cleavage. What happened last night?
response: Ah, memory impairment, the free prize at the bottom of every vodka bottle.

speaker: Sheldon?
response: All right. Last night you gave me some excellent advice regarding my problem here at home, you kissed me and then vomited on and off for 40 minutes, following which you passed out on your bathroom floor. I then folded a towel under your head as a pillow, set your oven clock to the correct time because it was driving me crazy, and I left.

speaker: Okay. Don’t really know where we go from here.
response: I suggest we treat our relationship as if it were a crashed computer and restore it to the last point we both agree it worked.

speaker: Come on, Priya, just admit I embarrass you!
response: You’re preaching to the choir, sister.

speaker: Do you think maybe it’s tight because you’re wearing long underwear?
response: Yes, of course that’s why it’s tight.

speaker: All right, let me rephrase the question. Why are you wearing long underwear?
response: You’re kidding. Shouldn’t the question be why aren’t you?

speaker: No, it should be
response: Leonard, these rental tuxedos have been worn by hundreds of sweaty strangers. I don’t like my own sweat touching my skin, how do you think I feel about theirs?

speaker: Why don’t you slip this on?
response: Said the hangman offering a noose.

speaker: Make all the jokes you want, but there’s only one of us here brave enough to almost do what I almost did.
response: Ah, much better.

speaker: You must be burning up.
response: A little. But not more than your urethras will be after whatever’s in those pants swims up them. Well, I cut quite the dashing, yet hygienic figure, don’t I? I look like the Flash about to get married. Oh! A tissue! A tissue! Oh, good Lord!

speaker: He keeps emergency Purell in the car.
response: Keys! Keys! Keys!

speaker: Seven o’clock, right on time.
response: It’s not an accident. I waited outside your door for twenty minutes.

speaker: Well, dinner’s almost ready.
response: I must say, I was surprised you chose to spend our date night in your apartment. As I mentioned, the Pasadena City Council is debating longer crosswalk times, and later, the LEGO store is having a midnight madness sale. You ask anyone, that’s a hot date.

speaker: Tempting choices, but I have something special planned for tonight.
response: What can be more special than having an adequate amount of time to cross the street on your way to buy a tiny LEGO Indiana Jones?

speaker: With our friends moving forward in their relationships, I’ve decided that we should make progress in ours as well.
response: Oh, dear Lord. Two years ago, we didn’t even know each other, and now I’m in your apartment after dark. How much faster can this thing go?

speaker: I had a feeling you’d be reluctant, which is why I’m going to dip into my neurobiological bag of tricks.
response: Oh, you brain monkeys k*ll me. Dip away.

speaker: I have devised an experiment that I believe will increase your feelings for me in an accelerated time frame.
response: And how do you propose to do that? Uh, hope you’re not thinking about some sort of LSD thought control. Because there’s only one mind-expanding drug that this man enjoys, and that’s called school.

speaker: Human beings form emotional attachments as they grow up. In your case, to your mother, superheroes, et cetera. I’m going to attempt an experiment that will get you to transfer those feelings to me.
response: Well, seems what’s on the menu tonight is malarkey with a big side of poppycock.

speaker: We’ll see. Let’s start with a little romantic dinner music, shall we?
response: Super Mario Bros. theme?

speaker: Yes.
response: I see what you’re doing. You’re attempting to build on the work of Ebbinghaus by triggering an involuntary memory of me playing that game, admittedly the happiest 600 hours of my childhood, but it won’t work.

speaker: Fine. There’s no reason we still can’t have a lovely dinner. Why don’t you have a seat.
response: Da-da-da da-da dum, boink, boink.

speaker: May I offer you something to drink?
response: You know I don’t drink.

speaker: Not even strawberry Quik?
response: I love strawberry Quik. It’s my favourite pink fluid, narrowly b*at out Pepto-Bismol.

speaker: Oh, I know. I think it will go nicely with what I have prepared for dinner.
response: Spaghetti with little pieces of hot dog cut up in it!

speaker: Just like your mommy used to make.
response: Oh yummy, yummy! We should do this more often. Uh-oh.

speaker: Sheldon, knight takes bishop. You all right?
response: I’m fine.

speaker: Are you? You left your queen exposed from above, you trapped your knight in the corner, and you keep sighing and saying, why me?
response: Very well. Can I ask you a question about women?

speaker: We got you that book last year. Wasn’t everything in there?
response: No, I’m having a relationship problem with Amy. And by the way, that book gave me nightmares.

speaker: Well, if it makes you feel any better, I screwed things up pretty good with Penny.
response: Look at us, Leonard, engaging in the social convention of men bellyaching about their ol’ ladies.

speaker: I guess we are. So, what’s going on?
response: Believe it or not, Amy has embarked on a campaign to increase my feelings for her by making me happy.

speaker: I’m sorry, that must be very difficult for you.
response: It’s awful. This morning, she arranged for me to be an Amtrak junior conductor for the day. It, it’s usually only open to children. She got them to make an exception.

speaker: Shame on her.
response: They let me blow the whistle, Leonard.

speaker: She’s good.
response: I know. And it gets worse. Her efforts are causing me to have affectionate feelings for her at inappropriate times.

speaker: You mean, like in bed or in the shower?
response: No! Would you please stop referencing that infernal book? For example, this morning, I was calculating the random motion of virtual particles in a vacuum, when suddenly the particles morphed into an image of Amy’s dandruff gently cascading down onto her pale, slightly hunched shoulders. Oh, what has that vixen done to me, Leonard? And how do I make it stop?

speaker: Well, if you had a physical relationship, I’d say propose during sex. Turns out that’s a real mood k*ll.
response: I assume we’re talking about you now?

speaker: Yeah.
response: So, that’s how this works? I complain, and then you complain, and no one offers any solutions?

speaker: Pretty much.
response: Well, no wonder the women are winning.

speaker: We’re playing doctor. Star Trek style.
response: I’m in hell, Leonard. Don’t stop.

speaker: Oh, that’s very impressive. And a little r*cist.
response: If we’re all through playing mock the flawed technology, can we get on with Halo night, we were supposed to start at eight, it is now 8

speaker: So? We’ll start now.
response: Yes, first we have to decide if those lost six minutes will be coming out of game time, bathroom time or the pizza break.

speaker: If we’re having anchovies on the pizza we can’t take it out of bathroom time. (There is a knock on the door.)
response: Oh, what fresh hell is this?

speaker: Well, there’s this girl I know from back in Nebraska, Christie, well anyway she called me up and she’s like “Hey, how’s California,” and I’m like “Awesome” ‘cos, you know, it’s not Nebraska, and the next thing I know she’s invited herself out here to stay with me.
Well, she was engaged to my cousin while she was sleeping with my brother, so she’s kind of family.
response: You know, I apologise for my earlier outburst, who needs Halo when we can be regaled with the delightfully folksy tale of the whore of Omaha?

speaker: Bonjour mademoiselle, I understand you’re new in town.
response: Oh good grief.

speaker: Ugh, I cannot believe Christie let Howard into my apartment.
response: And I cannot believe people pay for horoscopes, but on a more serious note it’s 8

speaker: Okay, fine, we’ll just play one on one until he gets back.
response: One on one? We don’t play one on one, we play teams, not one on one. One on one!

speaker: Great idea.
response: Uh, no. The wheel was a great idea. Relativity was a great idea. This is a notion, and a rather sucky one at that.

speaker: Why?
response: Why? Oh, Penny, Penny, Penny.

speaker: Oh, what, what, what?
response: This is a complex battle simulation with a steep learning curve, there are myriad w*apon, vehicles and strategies to master, not to mention an extremely intricate back-story.

speaker: Oh cool, whose head did I just blow off?
response: Mine.

speaker: It’s the only way we can play teams.
response: Yes, but whoever’s her partner will be hamstrung by her lack of experience and not to mention that fact that sh…. (another expl*si*n)

speaker: Ha-ha, there goes your head again.
response: Okay, this isn’t at all good sportsmanship to sh**t somebody who’s just respawned, you need to give them a chance to (expl*si*n) now come on!

speaker: Yeah, so is Sheldon.
response: Okay, that’s it, I don’t know how, but she is cheating. No-one can be that attractive and be this k*ll at a video game.

speaker: Wait, wait, Sheldon, come back, you forgot something.
response: What?

speaker: This plasma grenade. (expl*si*n.) Ha! Look, it’s raining you!
response: You laugh now, you just wait until you need tech support.

speaker: She’s an enigma, Raj.
response: And another thing, there’s a certain ethic to the game, Penny, a well estab…

speaker: She’s gone, Sheldon.
response: Well she could have said goodbye.

speaker: Okay, I have a problem.
response: It’s called carpal tunnel syndrome, and quite frankly you deserve it.

speaker: Uh, the couch is good.
response: Hold that thought, Leonard, a moment.

speaker: Let me guess, you have a problem with this.
response: Where do I begin?

speaker: It’s up to you, crazy person’s choice.
response: Well first, we don’t have house guests, frankly if I could afford the rent I’d ask you to leave.

speaker: Your friendship means a lot to me as well, what else?
response: Well, our earthquake supplies, we have a two day, two man kit.

speaker: So?
response: So, if there is an earthquake and the three of us are trapped here, we could be out of food by tomorrow afternoon.

speaker: I’m sorry, are you suggesting that if we let Penny stay we might succumb to cannibalism?
response: No-one ever thinks it will happen until it does.

speaker: Hu.. what?
response: He’s engaging in reductio-ad-absurdum. It’s the logical fallacy of extending someone’s argument to ridiculous proportions and then criticising the result, and I do not appreciate it.

speaker: I’ll get you a blanket and a pillow.
response: Okay, well since I’m obviously being ignored here, let’s go over the morning schedule, I use the bathroom from 7 to 7

speaker: How am I supposed to plan my bodily functions?
response: I suggest no liquids after 11pm.

speaker: Thanks Leonard. (Arranges pillows on left of couch.)
response: Hmmph, wrong.

speaker: I’m listening.
response: Your head goes on the other end.

speaker: Why?
response: It’s culturally universal, a bed, even a temporary bed, is always oriented with the headboard away from the door. It serves the ancient imperative of protecting oneself against marauders.

speaker: I’ll risk it.
response: Hm!

speaker: Anything else I should know.
response: Yes. If you use my toothbrush I’ll jump out that window. Please don’t come to my funeral. Have a good night.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Every Saturday since we have lived in this apartment, I have awakened at 6

speaker: Penny’s still sleeping.
response: Every Saturday since we have lived in this apartment, I have awakened at 6

speaker: I know, I know, look, you have a TV in your room, why don’t you just have breakfast in bed?
response: Because I am neither an invalid nor a woman celebrating Mother’s Day.

speaker: What the hell is your problem?
response: Okay, this cereal has lost all its molecular integrity, I now have a bowl of shredded wheat paste.

speaker: chka-chka-chka-chka-chka-chka-chka (they kiss).
response: Well there’s one beloved children’s book I’ll never read again.

speaker: Leonard.
response: I’m Sheldon.

speaker: Penny, you’re always welcome to stay with us.
response: Oh, terrific, now we’re running a cute little B&B.

speaker: I do not, my mother lives with me.
response: Well then, it’s all settled, Christie will stay with Howard, Penny can go back to her apartment, and I’ll watch the last 24 minutes of Doctor Who, although at this point it’s more like Doctor Why Bother.

speaker: Sheldon you just can’t dictate…
response: No more talking, everybody go.

speaker: Oh, that’s so cool. My first Jew!
response: I imagine there aren’t many kosher corn-huskers.

speaker: We can’t order Chinese food without Wolowitz?
response: Let me walk you through it, our standard is, the steamed dumpling appetizer, General So’s chicken, beef with broccoli, shrimp with lobster sauce and vegetable lo-main. Do you see the problem?

speaker: I see a problem.
response: Our entire order is predicated on four dumplings and four entrees divided among four people.

speaker: So, we’ll just order three entrees.
response: Fine, what do you want to eliminate, and who gets the extra dumpling.

speaker: We could cut it into thirds.
response: Then it is no longer a dumpling, once you cut it open it is at best a very small open faced sandwich.

speaker: Hi fellas. Oh, where’s your annoying little friend who thinks he speaks Mandarin?
response: He’s putting his needs ahead of the collective good. (Pointing at waiter) Where he comes from, that’s punishable by death.

speaker: That works.
response: No, if we fill up on dumplings we’ll need to eliminate another entree.

speaker: If we have extra, we’ll just take the leftovers home.
response: And divide it how, I’m telling you we cannot do this without Wolowitz.

speaker: Wolowitz is with his new girlfriend, if you had let me invite Penny then you would have had your fourth.
response: Have you seen Penny eat Chinese food, she uses a fork, and she double dips her egg rolls.

speaker: We don’t order egg rolls.
response: Exactly, but we’d have to if she was here.

speaker: Here’s an idea, why don’t we just go out for Indian food.
response: No.

speaker: You are nice boys. Tell you what I’m going to do. I’m going to bring you the four dumplings. When I’m walking over to the table, maybe I get bumped, one of the dumplings falls to the floor, no-one has to know.
response: I’ll know.

speaker: Yeah, we can always divide soup.
response: What about the won-tons?

speaker: Oh, hey guys, what’s up?
response: It’s Halo night.

speaker: Right, anyway, uh, with Wolowitz occupied elsewhere, we had something we wanted to ask you. Sheldon?
response: Yes. Penny, we would very much appreciate it if you would be the fourth member of our Halo team. I don’t think I need to tell you what an honour this is.

speaker: Oh, that’s so sweet. But I’m going out dancing with a girlfriend.
response: You can’t go out, it’s Halo night.

speaker: Well, for Penny it’s dancing night.
response: You go dancing every Wednesday.

speaker: No.
response: Then it’s not dancing night.

speaker: Look, why don’t I play with you guys tomorrow?
response: Tonight is Halo night, it’s like talking to a wall.

speaker: Sheldon, remember, we role-played this.
response: Yes, but you didn’t portray her as completely irrational.

speaker: Maybe we should have asked if we could go dancing with her and her girlfriend.
response: Okay, assuming we could dance, which we can’t, there are three of us and two of them.

speaker: So?
response: It’s the Chinese restaurant all over again. I assure you that cutting a dumpling in thirds is child’s play compared with three men, each attempting to dance with 67% of a woman.

speaker: Aaah, for God’s sake, Sheldon, you are driving me crazy.
response: Your anger’s not with me, sir, but with basic mathematics.

speaker: Who are you calling?
