response: The only man who can restore any semblance of balance to our universe.

speaker: Sheldon, think this through, you’re going to ask Howard to choose between sex and Halo.
response: No, I’m going to ask him to choose between sex and Halo 3. As far as I know, sex has not been upgraded to include high-def graphics and enhanced w*apon systems.

speaker: You’re right, all sex has is nudity, orgasms and human contact.
response: My point.

speaker: What are you guys doing here?
response: It’s Halo night.

speaker: I thought she was the whore of Omaha?
response: Shhh!

speaker: Sheldon, you got him in your sights, fire, he’s charging his plasma r*fle.
response: I can’t sh**t now, I’m cloaking.

speaker: I can’t see him.
response: That’s why the call it cloaking, dead man.

speaker: That will do, Raj, straight for the t*nk.
response: We said no t*nk.

speaker: All I’ve got is a needler, and I’m all out of a*mo.
response: And now you’re out of life. Why did you hit pause?

speaker: Lesser Warlord of Ka’a.
response: Not so fast. Infinite Sheldon.

speaker: Infinite Sheldon?
response: Yes, Infinite Sheldon defeats all other cards and does not violate the rule against homemade cards because I made it at work.

speaker: Do you understand why people don’t want to play with you?
response: No, although it’s a question I’ve been pondering since preschool.

speaker: You know, I saw this great thing on the Discovery Channel. Turns out that if you k*ll a starfish, it’ll just come back to life.
response: Was the starfish wearing boxer shorts? Because you might have been watching Nickelodeon.

speaker: Well, maybe we can do an experiment to find out.
response: Oh, that’s easy enough. We’d need a large t*nk of water, a hoop to jump through, and a bucket of whatever bite-sized treats you find tasty.

speaker: Oh, I see. You guys are inferring that I’m stupid.
response: That’s not correct. We were implying it. You then inferred it.

speaker: What would I even say?
response: Zack, I’m sorry you’re stupid. Have a Milk Dud.

speaker: A Milk Dud?
response: Yeah, Milk Duds, with their self-deprecating name and remarkably mild flavour, are the most apologetic of the boxed candies.

speaker: Junior Mints are pretty apologetic.
response: You’re embarrassing yourself.

speaker: Come on, that’s what we do. We give each other a hard time. Hey, Sheldon, you look like a praying mantis.
response: That’s very hurtful.

speaker: I don’t know, it still wasn’t very nice.
response: Milk Dud?

speaker: Oh, I love Milk Duds. Okay, we’re cool.
response: Junior Mints.

speaker: Really? I haven’t been to a comic book store in literally a million years.
response: Literally? Literally a million years?

speaker: Wow, this place is awesome. Where do they keep the Archies?
response: In the bedrooms of ten-year-old girls, where they belong.

speaker: So are you guys coming to my New Year’s Eve costume party?
response: Of course. We’re coming as the Justice League of America.

speaker: Switching it up from last year when we came as the Justice League of America.
response: To that point, it occurs to me that we might have an opportunity to finally snare Best Group Costume if we shore up our weak link, which is clearly Leonard as Superman.

speaker: Hey, I got new boots this year. Guaranteed to add three inches.
response: That’s sad. Let’s ask ourselves, is there anyone we know who would make a more manly and convincing son of Krypton?

speaker: Than than Leonard in high-heeled boots? Howard’s mother in high-heeled boots?
response: I was thinking specifically of the gentleman over there moving his lips as he enjoys the latest exploits of Betty and Veronica.

speaker: You can’t replace me with Zack.
response: Why not? Penny did it.

speaker: Score. I got an Archie, Betty and Veronica, and a Jughead. All set for my weekend number twos.
response: Congratulations. Zack, how would you like to be Superman?

speaker: I don’t want to be Aquaman. He sucks. He sucks underwater. He sucks fish pee.
response: Excuse me, I believe Aquaman uses his telepathic powers to request the fish do their business elsewhere.

speaker: We’re going to a costume party at the comic book store on New Year’s Eve, and you get to be Wonder Woman.
response: Complete with bulletproof bracelets and lasso of truth. Invisible plane sold separately.

speaker: Okay, what about your friend Amy?
response: Amy Farrah Fowler doesn’t believe in wearing costumes. She isn’t the free spirit I am.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: We’re going to be late. I’m pacing nervously.

speaker: You’re jogging.
response: This is how the Flash paces.

speaker: I’m Batman.
response: Oh, I hardly think so. The real caped crusader calls his crime-fighting cohorts when he’s running late.

speaker: All right. Let’s get this thing over with.
response: I’m sorry. But in what universe is Wonder Woman blonde?

speaker: Well, actually.
response: Don’t. He’s making our case.

speaker: Then who are you talking to? Babe?
response: (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny, (Knock) Penny.

speaker: What the hell is wrong with you?
response: I’m the Flash. I just knocked 30,000 times.

speaker: Okay. What do you want, Sheldon?
response: I understand why you’re upset.

speaker: Really?
response: Yes. You’re afraid that costume makes you look fat.

speaker: No. Wait, wait, does it?
response: Don’t worry. Wonder Woman was an Amazon. And Amazons tend to be very beefy gals.

speaker: Good-bye, Sheldon.
response: But they’re not blonde, so put on your wig. Hello?

speaker: I don’t know. Somebody bigger and, yeah, sure. Why not you?
response: I may have failed.

speaker: Oh, great. No Superman, no Wonder Woman? All we’ve got is a skinny Flash, an Indian Aquaman, a nearsighted Green Lantern, and a teeny, tiny Dark Knight.
response: Obviously, we’re no longer a Justice League. We have no choice but to switch to our Muppet Baby costumes.

speaker: Ooh, I call Kermit.
response: I’m Kermit. You’re Scooter.

speaker: Okay, let me see if I understand this. You want me to convince my ex-girlfriend to go to a costume party with her new boyfriend just so we can win a stupid prize?
response: Yes. And make her wear the black wig. Good luck.

speaker: Okay, the good news is, we have a Wonder Woman.
response: Oh.

speaker: Yes.
response: What’s the bad news?

speaker: And the award for best group costume goes to Justice League of America number three!
response: Thank you! Thank you so much!

speaker: Ten, nine, eight…
response: No, wait! I have a speech.

speaker: Seven, six…
response: Stop counting!

speaker: Five, four, three…
response: This is my moment, dag nab it!

speaker: Two, one! Happy New Year!
response: I’m not going to say another word until you people settle down. I’m waiting.

speaker: What should we do?
response: We’re the Justice League of America. There’s only one thing we can do. Turn around and slowly walk away.

speaker: Look, I know our winter thermostat setting is 72 degrees, but I’m a little warm, so I’m going to turn it down.
response: Good Lord, how you frustrate me, Leonard Hofstadter! (Runs back) Fine.

speaker: I think we have to acknowledge, those were some fairly savage pre-adolescent Jews.
response: You know, we were annihilated by our own incompetence and the inability of some people to follow the chain of command.

speaker: Sheldon, let it go.
response: No, I want to talk about the fact that Wolowitz sh*t me in the back.

speaker: I sh*t you for good reason, you were leading us into disaster.
response: I was giving clear, concise orders.

speaker: So, how was paintball, did you have fun?
response: Sure, if you consider being fragged by your own troops fun. (To Howard) You clear space on your calendar, there will be an enquiry.

speaker: Well, there will be boys, and there will be girls, and it is a party. So, it’ll just be a bunch of my friends, we’ll have some beer, do a little dancing…
response: Dancing?

speaker: Yeah, I don’t know, Penny…
response: The thing is, we’re not….

speaker: We’re really more….
response: No.

speaker: Are you sure? Come on, it’s Halloween.
response: A Halloween party?

speaker: Um, yeah, Halloween.
response: Yes, but are the costumes random, or genre specific?

speaker: Sure.
response: What about comic-books?

speaker: Fine.
response: Anime?

speaker: Of course.
response: TV , film, D&D, Manga, Greek Gods, Roman Gods, Norse Gods…

speaker: Oh, no.
response: Oh no! (He is also wearing a Flash costume.)

speaker: Make way for the fastest man alive. (Enters, also in a Flash costume.) Oh no!
response: See, this is why I wanted to have a costume meeting.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, there’s something I want to talk to you about before we go to the party.
response: I don’t care if anybody gets it, I’m going as the Doppler Effect.

speaker: No, it’s not…
response: If I have to, I can demonstrate. Neeeeoooowwwww!

speaker: Terrific. Um, this party is my first chance for Penny to see me in the context of her social group, and I need you not to embarrass me tonight.
response: Well, what exactly do you mean by embarrass you?

speaker: For example, tonight no-one needs to know that my middle name is Leakey.
response: Well, there’s nothing embarrassing about that, your father worked with Lewis Leakey, a great anthropologist. It had nothing to do with your bed-wetting.

speaker: Late? It’s 7
response: And you said the party starts at seven.

speaker: Well, yeah, when you start a party at seven, no-one shows up at, you know, seven.
response: It’s 7

speaker: Probably, but in their own homes.
response: So what time does the costume parade start?

speaker: The parade?
response: Yeah, so the judges can give out the prizes for best costume, you know, most frightening, most authentic, most accurate visual representation of a scientific principle.

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, I’m sorry but there aren’t going to be any parades or judges or prizes.
response: This party is just going to suck.

speaker: Oh, he’s the Doppler Effect.
response: Yes. It’s the apparent change in the frequency of a wave caused by relative motion between the source of the wave and the observer.

speaker: Okay.
response: See, people get it.

speaker: No thanks, peanuts, I can’t afford to swell up in these tights.
response: I’m confused. If there’s no costume parade, what are we doing here?

speaker: We’re socialising. Meeting new people.
response: Telepathically?

speaker: She’s not Catwoman, she’s just a generic cat.
response: And that’s the kind of sloppy costuming which results from a lack of rules and competition.

speaker: I want to get to know Penny’s friends, I just, I don’t know how to talk to these people.
response: Well, I actually might be able to help.

speaker: How so?
response: Like Jane Goodall observing the apes, I initially saw their interactions as confusing and unstructured, but patterns emerge, they have their own language if you will.

speaker: Go on.
response: Well, it seems that the newcomer approaches the existing group with the greeting “How wasted am I?” which is met with an approving chorus of “Dude.”

speaker: Then what happens?
response: That’s as far as I’ve gotten.

speaker: This is ridiculous, I’m jumping in.
response: Good luck.

speaker: No, you’re coming with me.
response: Oh, I hardly think so.

speaker: Come on.
response: Aren’t you afraid I’ll embarrass you?

speaker: Yes. But I need a wing-man.
response: Alright, but if we’re going to use flight metaphors I’m much more suited to being the guy from the FAA, analysing wreckage.

speaker: Hi.
response: Hello.

speaker: So, what are you supposed to be?
response: Me? I’ll give you a hint. Neeeeooooowwwww!

speaker: Uh, a choo-choo train?
response: Close! Neeeeeoooooowwwww!

speaker: How wasted am I? (Raj shrugs.)
response: Neeeeeooooowwwwww!

speaker: I still don’t get it.
response: I’m the Doppler Effect.

speaker: Why don’t you just tell people you’re a zebra?
response: Well, why don’t you just tell people you’re one of the seven dwarves.

speaker: Because I’m Frodo.
response: Yes, well, I’m the Doppler Effect.

speaker: Oh no.
response: What?

speaker: That’s Penny’s ex-boyfriend.
response: What do you suppose he’s doing here? Besides disrupting the local gravity field.

speaker: If he were any bigger, he’d have moons orbiting him.
response: Oh, snap. So I guess we’ll be leaving now.

speaker: Why should we leave? For all we know, he crashed the party and Penny doesn’t even want him here. (Penny and Kurt hug).
response: You have a back-up hypothesis.

speaker: Maybe they just want to be friends.
response: Or maybe she wants to be friends, and he wants something more.

speaker: Then he and I are on equal ground.
response: Yes, but you’re much closer to it than he is.

speaker: Look, if this was 15,000 years ago, by virtue of his size and strength, Kurt would be entitled to his choice of female partners.
response: And male partners. Animal partners. Large primordial eggplants, pretty much whatever tickled his fancy.

speaker: Yes, but our society has undergone a paradigm shift, in the information age, Sheldon, you and I are the alpha males. We shouldn’t have to back down.
response: True. Why don’t you text him that and see if he backs down?

speaker: No. I’m going to assert my dominance face to face.
response: Face to face? Are you going to wait for him to sit down, or are you going to stand on a coffee table?

speaker: Oh, hey guys. You having a good time?
response: Given the reaction to my costume, this party is a scathing indictment of the American education system.

speaker: What, you’re a zebra, right?
response: Yet another child left behind.

speaker: So why the hell would you want to be a Hobbit?
response: Because he is neither tall nor immortal, and none of us could be The Flash.

speaker: I think we’re all talking to Penny here.
response: I’m not. No offence.

speaker: No, I said animalistic. Of course we’re all animals, but some of us have climbed a little higher on the evolutionary tree.
response: If he understands that, you’re in trouble.

speaker: So what, I’m unevolved?
response: You’re in trouble.

speaker: Yeah, how about I make a point out of your pointy little head.
response: Let me remind you, while my moral support is absolute, in a physical confrontation I will be less than useless.

speaker: Fine. You’re one lucky little leprechaun.
response: He’s a Hobbit! I’ve got your back.

speaker: Oh, okay, alright, well thank you for coming.
response: Happy Halloween. (They leave) If it’s any consolation, I thought that homo-habilus line really put him in his place.

speaker: What’s that?
response: Tea. When people are upset the cultural convention is to bring them hot beverages. There there. You want to talk about it?

speaker: No.
response: Good. There there was really all I had.

speaker: Good night Sheldon.
response: Good night Leonard.

speaker: Hey, have you seen Koothrapali?
response: He’s not here. Maybe the Avenger summoned him.

speaker: He’s not the Marvel comic story, he’s the original Norse God.
response: Thank you for the clarification.

speaker: I’m supposed to give him a ride home.
response: Well I’m sure he’ll be fine. He has his hammer.

speaker: Wow, I have to say, you are an amazing man. You’re gentle and passionate, and my God, you are such a good listener!
response: Leonard, I've been working on an opening joke for our lecture at Berkeley.

speaker: Oh, I like to laugh. But say it anyway.
response: Okay, um, what do you say to a graduate of the UC Berkeley physics department? I'll have fries with that. Because his education hasn't prepared him for a career in the sciences.

speaker: Are you all set for your trip?
response: Yeah, I think so. I just restocked the old PRK.

speaker: Public restroom kit. Everything a boy needs for making pee pee in new and strange places.
response: I don't see what's crazy about bringing a backpack with your own toilet paper and Purell.

speaker: Keep going.
response: And rubber gloves, uh, air freshener. Um, noise-cancelling headphones. Oh, danger whistle. Um, pepper spray. Ooh, a multi-language occupied sign. Uh, let's see, we have seat protectors, uh, booties for my shoes, a clothespin for my nose. Oh, and a mirror on a stick, so I can make sure the person in the stall next to me isn't some kind of weirdo.

speaker: Yes, who do you think gave him the danger whistle?
response: Would you like to play a physics car game I invented called "I Can't Spy"? It's all the nail-biting tension of I Spy but the added fun of subatomic particles and waves outside the visible spectrum.

speaker: If it's half as much fun as "One Times Ten to the Fourth Bottles of Beer on the Wall," I'm in.
response: I'll begin. Uh, I can't spy with my little eye something passing right through us.

speaker: That soy Frappuccino I had.
response: Will you please play the game? I can't spy with my little eye something passing right through us.

speaker: I don't know, um, if 65 billion solar neutrinos pass through a square centimetre every second, given the surface area of this car is about 60,000 square centimetres, that means 3.9 times ten to the 15th solar neutrinos?
response: I don't want to play anymore.

speaker: We haven't been on a road trip in a while. This is fun.
response: We get it, you won the game. Stop bragging.

speaker: No, listen, we wrote a paper together. Now we get to go to a university and talk about it? That's pretty cool.
response: I suppose it is. In fact, if you'd like to celebrate with a little music, I'd be okay with that.

speaker: What? This road trip just got crazy.
response: Play that funky music, white boy.

speaker: I'm surprised you know that reference.
response: What reference?

speaker: Of course.
response: So they're requesting that the white boy play the funky music, yes?

speaker: Yes.
response: And this music we're listening to right now is funky as well?

speaker: Sure.
response: Let me ask you this. Do you think this song is the music the white boy ultimately plays?

speaker: It could be.
response: So it's like the musical equivalent of Russell's Paradox, the question of whether the set of all sets that don't contain themselves as members contains itself?

speaker: Exactly.
response: Well then I hate it. Music should just be fun.

speaker: Making great time. Gonna be there pretty early.
response: Will our hotel room be ready?

speaker: I doubt it.
response: Aren't you worried that sitting in the lobby for a long period of time might attract the attention of the hotel detective?

speaker: If we do, we'll just tell him to hit the bricks, see?
response: Seems a little confrontational, but all right. You know, we won't be very far from Skywalker Ranch.

speaker: Oh, that's true. It's not like we can get in there.
response: Why not?

speaker: I-I don't think George Lucas put his headquarters in the middle of nowhere because he wanted people dropping in.
response: Yoda's swamp was in the middle of nowhere. Tatooine was in the middle of nowhere. Hoth was in the middle of nowhere. That's code, Leonard. He wants us to drop in.

speaker: We do have time. I mean, we could drive by and just look at it.
response: Yes. Oh, I'm so excited. And I just can't hide it.

speaker: "I'm about to lose control, and I think I like it."
response: What are you talking about?

speaker: If you still have that bra, I'll give you a nickel for it.
response: There it is. It's just a gate. On a road.

speaker: Wasn't even that hard to find.
response: This is so amazing.

speaker: I know. You want to get a picture?
response: I want more than a picture. I want to go in.

speaker: Well, so do I, but they'll never let us.
response: Is that the attitude that helped you get Penny?

speaker: No, but I don't have three years to make that gate feel sorry for me.
response: There's a speaker box. Drive up, push the button, and let's see what happens.

speaker: Okay, yeah. What do we have to lose? I'm a little nervous.
response: Well, get over it. Confidence is key in these situations.

speaker: Right.
response: (gasps) You pushed it, are you out of your mind?

speaker: Um, uh, uh, uh, we don't have an appointment, and, and we don't belong here, but we, we're, like, crazy-big fans. I mean... (stammers) uh, buh, buh, "crazy for Star Wars" crazy, not crazy like we have a backpack full of duct tape, although we do have a backpack that you really don't want to look in.
response: You're blowing it. We want to meet George Lucas and become his friends and play with him.

speaker: And that's how it's done.
response: All right, we've defeated the first challenge. Now we must steel ourselves to face the monster who defends the gate.

speaker: We're trying to get past a security guard, not rescue Zelda.
response: I think what really needs to be rescued is your sense of whimsy, but one quest at a time. So what's the plan?

speaker: Uh, I'm just gonna be honest with the guy.
response: Honesty will never get us in.

speaker: Well, what's your plan?
response: All right, my plan is predicated on the assumption that they have a nurse's office and your willingness to be lightly stabbed.

speaker: Uh, I'm just gonna tell you the truth.
response: Oh, you are k*ll me.

speaker: Sorry, guys, we get this a lot. Can't let you in.
response: What if I told you that I was the voice of Yoda? (imitating Yoda) A recording session I must attend.

speaker: Thank you so much. See? Maybe honesty is the best... (door opens) What are you doing?
response: Shedding the yoke of my oppressors, you blind, sad little man.

speaker: Copy.
response: I can see the ranch, Leonard. Oh, it's rustic, it's lovely. I'd take a picture, but people are chasing me. I'm gonna make it. I'm gonna make it. They have Tasers, but they wouldn't dare use... Aaaaaaagh!

speaker: So did I.
response: Do you think they're gonna call the police?

speaker: I don't know. Maybe they'll call Imperial Officers to take us to a holding cell on the Death Star.
response: Oh, I think that's below the pay grade of an Imperial Officer. Stormtroopers are really the ones who...

speaker: Uh-huh, I'm normally very nice, but you shut up, too.
response: So, what are you in for?

speaker: Honestly, I just wanted to meet Mr. Lucas and say thank you. You know, growing up, the movies had such an impact on my life. I never really fit in anywhere. Till I discovered the worlds he created and finally found a place where I belong.
response: But why are you here?

speaker: Oh, I, uh, I hopped a fence, and they caught me in the sculpture gallery making out with a Chewbacca statue.
response: Excuse me. Leonard, they have a sculpture gallery.

speaker: No, you're not going anywhere, kissy face. Let's go. I have to take your picture to post at the guard gate.
response: Uh, one question about that picture. Can it be with George Lucas? (imitating Yoda) Ooh, grumpy you are.

speaker: If this doesn't get him into your bedroom, nothing will.
response: Are you still mad at me?

speaker: Yes, we missed our lecture, we were almost arrested, and you got me locked in a room with a man who forced his tongue down the throat of a stuffed Wookiee.
response: Boy, some people are just glass-half-empty.

speaker: The glass is empty, Sheldon. It's completely empty. If you gave that glass to a man who was dying of thirst, he would be dead, do you know why?
response: Before I answer, was he a smoker? I think you're looking at this all wrong.

speaker: Fine, then tell me how I should be looking at it.
response: Well, not only did we go to Skywalker Ranch, we got in. And no one we know can say that. And for all the times you find me irritating, today you got to watch someone sh**t me with a Taser.

speaker: That part was pretty good.
response: See?

speaker: You did flop around a lot.
response: I'll take your word for it. I was too busy trying not to defecate.

speaker: You know, when they were escorting us to the detaining room, I looked through a door, and I'm pretty sure I saw a display case with the Ark of the Covenant.
response: That's amazing.

speaker: I know.
response: And I saw Jabba the Hutt riding by on a motorcycle. Although that was right after the Tasing, so who can say for sure?

speaker: I guess this could count as an adventure.
response: It was. And even though we're not allowed back there, they can never take today away from us. Unlike my sense of smell, which hasn't returned since the Tasing. No, I got nothing.

speaker: That’s because you’ve never seen him on restock the medicine cabinet day.
response: Look. A new topical antihistamine with lidocaine. Wow. I can’t wait until I get a rash.

speaker: Oh, Gas-X has a new ultra strength. I guess they really do read their mail.
response: Hey, isn’t that Professor Proton?

speaker: Oh, yeah.
response: Look at him, just standing in line like he wasn’t moderately famous 30 years ago. Let’s go say hello.

speaker: Oh, maybe we shouldn’t bother him.
response: I’m not going to bother him, I’m going to talk to him.

speaker: He thinks there’s a difference.
response: Arthur? Arthur, it’s me, Sheldon Cooper. You may not remember because of your advanced age.

speaker: Trust me, I, I remember.
response: This is my girlfriend, Amy. Amy, this is television legend Arthur Jeffries. His science show inspired millions of children.

speaker: No, she’s not.
response: So, what prescription are you getting filled?

speaker: Sheldon.
response: No. Wait, I want to guess. Don’t tell me.

speaker: Sheldon, come on.
response: No, no, no. I’m really good at this. All right, give me a hint. Does it involve difficulty initiating a stream of anything?

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, let’s go mock the people buying homeopathic medicine, you love that.
response: But I’m hanging out with my friend, and we’re having fun. Look how happy he is.

speaker: Hey, I got an email from Professor Proton.
response: Goody. What’s it say?

speaker: He’s working on a paper about nano vacuum tubes, and wants to know if I’d take a look at it.
response: That’s strange. That he would come to you for that and not me. Oh, I got two emails from him. Do you have Leonard’s email address? And. Never mind, I found it. I can’t believe he picked you over me.

speaker: Yeah, it’s nothing to cry about.
response: Sheldon Cooper does not cry.

speaker: Is it really worth getting upset about?
response: Yeah, they say don’t meet your heroes. Don’t peek behind that curtain of fame and celebrity, because if you do, you’ll see them as they really are, degenerate carnival folk.

speaker: Come on, he’s a retired kids show host.
response: That’s even worse. Using the sweet candy of science to trick children into loving him. Pervert.

speaker: Have you ever thought about why Arthur didn’t want you to read his paper?
response: Yes, I have. And my only conclusion is the prescription he was picking up the other day was for cuckoo pills.

speaker: Maybe he found you, um, a bit much.
response: That’s kind of a stretch. Look, when it comes to social k*ll, I’ve mastered the big three. There’s the coy smile. There’s the friendly chuckle. There’s the vocalization of sympathy. Aw. That last one’s tricky, I’m still working on it.

speaker: From what I saw the other day, I could understand why he and some people might find you…
response: What?

speaker: Doesn’t matter.
response: No, go ahead, say it. I know what it is. I’ve heard it my whole life. The word’s annoying. Go ahead, say it. Say it. Say I’m annoying.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Oh, it won’t hurt my feelings. Go ahead, Amy, say I’m annoying. I’m annoying. I’m annoying. I’m annoying. Yeah, now, uh, now where are you going? Look, you know you want to say it, say it. Say I’m annoying. Go ahead, say it. Say it. Say it. Amy, say it. Well, she can’t stand it when I’m right.

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: I’m sorry, did I wake you?

speaker: Of course you woke me, it’s seven thirty.
response: Well, I would have been here sooner, but for some reason your home isn’t on this map of Hollywood stars.

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: It’s been pointed out by my girlfriend that I may have been annoying to you.

speaker: She sounds like a keeper.
response: Anyway, I wanted to apologize. I am truly sorry.

speaker: All right, apology accepted. Have a nice night.
response: No, no, now that we’ve cleared the air, I wanted to discuss another matter with you.

speaker: Sheldon, in a couple hours I have to get up, pee and then wander around the house.
response: Well, then, I’ll make this quick. Um, I want to talk about the paper you sent Leonard. Now, I know he said it’s promising and he’s going to collaborate on it, but now that you and I are friends again, I am at your disposal. And, um, frankly, lending my name and reputation to it will help, because a lot of people think that you’re a washed-up has-been. Or dead.

speaker: I should be so lucky.
response: So, uh, what do you say?

speaker: You know, if it’s all the same with you, I, I think I’ll, I’ll stick with Leonard.
response: It’s because I’m annoying, right? I know it is. Say it. Say it. Say I’m annoying.

speaker: Good night.
response: Say it. Arthur, say it. Say I’m annoying. Say it. Say it. I’m annoying. Say it.

speaker: You’re annoying.
response: Well, that really hurt.

speaker: I’m sorry, Dr. Jeffries, I’m just excited. This nano vacuum tube idea of yours is, it’s really interesting.
response: Hello, Leonard. Oh, hello, Arthur. What an odd coincidence that you’re both here.

speaker: Why is it odd?
response: Because as it just so happens, I’m also spending the day with a beloved children’s television science personality. Isn’t that right, new friend and colleague Bill Nye the Science Guy. Sorry, I replaced you with a newer model.

speaker: He said I’d be speaking to a class.
response: No, I said you were teaching someone a lesson. Now let’s go.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon.
response: I’m surprised to see you here.

speaker: Yeah, me, too. Somewhere around the third floor I began to see a, a white light.
response: I’ll get Leonard.

speaker: No, no, no, I’m, I’m here, I’m here to see you.
response: If you’re hoping to get in touch with Bill Nye, I can’t help you. I’ve been informed that he’s now Bill Nye the Restraining Order Guy.

speaker: No, I, I, I was thinking, if it isn’t too much trouble, I’d like to get your opinion about my, my paper.
response: Thank you. It would be an honour.

speaker: Oh. Uh, great.
response: Actually, I don’t need that. I hacked into your e-mail account and read it.

speaker: And, what did you think?
response: Well, first, I think the fact that you use your birthday as a password is embarrassing.

speaker: Mmm. Thank you.
response: Second, um, I thought your paper was inspired.

speaker: Oh, well, that, that means a lot to me.
response: Can I invite you in for tea?

speaker: He can’t help it. He can’t. He really can’t.
response: Oh, wait here. I’ll get some Alka-Seltzer, we can build that rocket, and we can sh**t it at Bill Nye’s house. As long as I’m not within 500 feet of it.

speaker: Okay, I’m out of here.
response: Un momento. Oh, for heaven’s sake, now you’re being deliberately stupid. (to Leonard) Where are you going?

speaker: I’m having dinner with Priya at Raj’s. I think Howard’s going to be there. You want to join us?
response: But tonight’s Thursday. On Thursdays, everybody comes over here and has pizza. Or a reasonable facsimile prepared by someone claiming to be Luigi, but who sounds suspiciously like Jackie Chan.

speaker: Can’t we make a one-time exception for tonight?
response: We could. We could also stop using the letter M, but I think that idea is isguided and oronic.

speaker: Just come with me to Raj’s.
response: Well, I don’t want to go to a party.

speaker: It’s not a party. It’s the same group of people who hang out here, hanging out over there.
response: I’m sorry, but five people eating and chatting is a party.

speaker: How come it’s not a party when we do it here?
response: Because we don’t throw parties.

speaker: I don’t know what to tell you, Sheldon. I’m going to see Priya. Everyone’s over there. You coming or not?
response: Well, no, sir, and do you know why? In a word, tradition. Every Thursday night for the last eight years, you and I and our friends have gathered here in this very spot to break bread covered with cheese and sauce, discuss the issues of the day, and yes, share a laugh or two. But I guess our rich heritage means nothing to you.

speaker: I guess you’re right. See you later.
response: Wait! Leonard! Wait! What am I going to do for dinner?

speaker: Come with me to Raj’s and eat there.
response: I can’t do that. What if he serves haggis and blood pudding?

speaker: I really doubt that’s what he’ll serve.
response: But what if he does? I’ll be obliged to dine on liver and lungs stuffed in a sheep’s stomach. And frankly, blood pudding is essentially the same thing. I don’t know why he’s serving both.

speaker: What do you want to do? You want to come with me, or do you want to sit here alone?
response: No, I’ll go to your haggis party. But I’m telling you, this is adness. This is utter and coplete adness.

speaker: What?
response: Raj’s television. I just realized we’re about to spend an evening watching a plasma screen with a cluster of dead pixels in the upper left-hand corner.

speaker: So don’t watch TV. Read a book.
response: And be a social pariah? Oh, you know that’s not my style.

speaker: Ugh!
response: The audible sigh is a show of exasperation, right?

speaker: Right.
response: Is it about me or the dead pixels?

speaker: Oh, sounds great.
response: Oh, Indians making Tex-Mex. Might as well have had the Chinese pizza.

speaker: That’s got to be fun for you, huh? Watching Hofstadter suck the saliva out of your sister’s mouth?
response: Excuse me. Before this evening goes any further, we need to decide where everyone is going to sit.

speaker: There is no assigned seats, Sheldon. Just sit anywhere. Make yourself comfortable.
response: Oh, what fun. We’re like hippies at a love-in.

speaker: Just sit here.
response: Yeah, right on, man. Right on. Oh, look, it’s Harry Potter and 98% of The Sorcerer’s Stone.

speaker: Okay, we’ve got fajitas with all the fixins, so you make your own.
response: Wonderful. Dinner, some assembly required.

speaker: Do you want a margarita, Sheldon?
response: A margarita? Where are we? What is happening?

speaker: Oh. Hey, Sheldon. What can I get ya?
response: Water. Neat. With a little umbrella.

speaker: Where are all your friends?
response: Sadly, Penny, this evening, I am the Dark Knight, roaming these mean streets alone. A windbreaker for my cape, and a stern expression for my cowl.

speaker: Okay.
response: Excuse me? Isn’t this the point where the world-weary barkeep absentmindedly wipes down the bar and coaxes the woes out of the troubled patron?

speaker: Well, I was getting your stupid umbrella, but all right. What’s troubling you, buddy?
response: I don’t think your heart’s in it, but since you asked. Apparently, because Leonard is dating Raj’s sister, we’re all forced to hang out at his apartment.

speaker: Oh, the horror.
response: Indeed. Yeah, at one point, Raj put on reggae music, and his sister took off her shoes. It was like the last days of Caligula. (Phone rings) Oh, I have to get this. Umbrella?

speaker: Ugh!
response: Wonder what she’s exasperated about. Hello?

speaker: Sheldon, are you all right? When last we spoke, you were going to take a taxi home from Raj’s, but according to Facebook, you just checked in at the Cheesecake Factory.
response: Yes, I was in a taxi, but the driver didn’t look at all like the photograph on his license, so I leapt out and ran for it.

speaker: Yeah, it’s a great time to be alive, isn’t it?
response: Don’t worry. My problems can wait while you two hens finish your clucking.

speaker: Your flaring nostrils indicate otherwise.
response: Cluck-cluck-cluck.

speaker: Sheldon, look at me. I think it’s time to face the fact that Leonard is the nucleus of your social group. Where he goes, the group goes.
response: Leonard the nucleus? That makes no sense. I’m the whimsical elf that everyone looks to for a good time.

speaker: What you doing?
response: I’m setting out snacks.

speaker: You do realize everyone’s eating at Raj’s again tonight?
response: I didn’t say the snacks were for you now, did I, Nosy Rosie?

speaker: You’re having people over?
response: Yes. Must be k*ll you wondering who. Fine, I’ll tell you. Stuart from the comic bookstore, Barry Kripke from the university, Penny’s ex-boyfriend Zack and TV’s LeVar Burton.

speaker: Really? LeVar Burton’s coming here?
response: Possibly. I Tweeted him.

speaker: Okay, well, tell him I loved him on Star Trek.
response: Please, Leonard, stop trying to horn in on my new friends.

speaker: Of course. Good night.
response: Leonard.

speaker: Yeah?
response: We had a good run, you and I.

speaker: Okay.
response: But change is a part of life.

speaker: It certainly is.
response: Okay. I have guests coming. I’m afraid I’m going to have to ask you to leave now.

speaker: I am leaving.
response: Don’t make this harder than it is, Leonard.

speaker: Good-bye, Sheldon.
response: And good-bye to you, sir. He’ll be back.

speaker: Um. Hi. I’m Stuart. I run a comic bookstore, which for financial reasons, I’m currently living in. And I guess what I’m hoping for most out of tonight is a hot shower.
response: That’s very nice, Stuart. Zack?

speaker: I’m Zack, and I’m, uh… uh… could you come back to me?
response: Of course. Barry?

speaker: I’m Barry Kwipke, and I’m here because you told me there was going to be a whaffle. When is the whaffle?
response: Patience, patience, Barry. The whaffle… the raffle is the grand finale to an evening-long festival of fun and folly.

speaker: One more question…
response: Yes, you must be present to win.

speaker: Anyway, after we get done snowboarding, I go back to the lodge and get in the Jacuzzi. There’s no one around, so naturally, I’m free-balling it. Next thing I know, this beautiful chick shows up, drunk out of her skull, wants to get in with me.
response: Question. Was it a Jacuzzi or a hot tub?

speaker: What’s the difference?
response: Jacuzzi is a commercial brand. Hot tub is the generic term, i.e., all Jacuzzis are hot tubs, but not all hot tubs are Jacuzzis.

speaker: Is that like all thumbs are fingers, but not all fingers are thumbs?
response: Surprisingly, yes.

speaker: Oh, yeah. Right. Anyway, she takes off all of her clothes, climbs into the hot tub, and the first thing I notice…
response: The water level rose.

speaker: No.
response: Of course it did. It’s said that Archimedes, the ancient Greek mathematician, discovered the principle of displacement while taking a bath.

speaker: Tewwific. Go ahead, Zack. Naked dwunk girl, fwee-balling, continue.
response: Forgive me, but I think you’ll find my story is more interesting.

speaker: Does yours have wet bweasts in it?
response: Better. It has a gold crown. You see, the king wondered how much gold was in it and charged Archimedes with coming up with the solution. Because the crown was irregularly shaped, there was no way to mathematically determine its volume. But, while bathing, Archimedes realized he could immerse the crown and measure the amount the water rose.

speaker: So, long story short, I nailed her.
response: When he finished, he shouted Eureka!

speaker: No, I always shout, Holy Moly! Don’t know why. Just do.
response: All right, that concludes the getting to know you portion of the evening. Who’s ready to play some vintage video games? And tonight’s selections include ColecoVision’s Smurf Rescue in Gargamel’s Castle, Atari’s Cookie Monster Munch, and for you text adventure aficionados, Zork. Pick me, pick me. I’m fun.

speaker: Check.
response: I’m unhappy.

speaker: Anybody do Walking on Sunshine yet?
response: No.

speaker: Long before the cats. I think it was around the time he tried to declare our apartment a sovereign nation. I still have some of the currency.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) All my friends. (Knock, knock, knock) All my friends. (Knock, knock, knock) All my friends.

speaker: Come on in.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Hey. I thought you were with your new buddies.
response: I had to leave. They were having fun wrong.

speaker: Come here, Sheldon. Sit here with me.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Would you like some homemade chili?
response: Are there beans in it?

speaker: Yes.
response: Then it’s not chili. Real chili has no beans in it, but you’re from a foreign land, so your ignorance is forgiven.

speaker: Sheldon, do you want some or not?
response: Yes, please. Your girlfriend’s a little short-tempered.

speaker: Cheers.
response: Priya, do you know why this is called a toast?

speaker: Actually, I do. I believe the Romans used to put spiced toast in their punch bowls.
response: She’s also a bit of a know-it-all. Mmm. This is good. Whatever it is.

speaker: Why would it trouble you? It’s, like, your third favourite cartoon theme song.
response: It is, right behind do-do-do-do-do Inspector Gadget., and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, heroes in a half-shell.

speaker: Turtle power!
response: However, the Spider-Man lyrics posit that Spider-Man, Spider-Man does whatever a spider can.

speaker: Yeah, so?
response: I can think of many things Spider-Man can’t do that a spider can. One, crawl in your ear and die. Two, legally leave Guatemala without a passport. Three, have sex with a spider.

speaker: It’s torture. Especially with her dad. We have nothing in common.
response: You know what I like to do when I’m forced to speak with those beneath my intellectual station? I bring up an interesting topic, like the difference between Spider-Man and spiders.

speaker: Thanks, Sheldon. I’ll try that with my father-in-law.
response: No, you can’t use that one. That’s mine. Uh, try this one for an ice-breaker. Uh, despite popular lore, there is no place in the continental United States, Alaska or Hawaii from which one can dig straight through the centre of the earth and come up in China.

speaker: Great, thank you.
response: Actually, you can’t have that one either. It’s too good. Sorry.

speaker: What about you, Sheldon? Do you have any plans tonight?
response: Sadly, yes. Amy’s taking me to a memorial service. It’s for one of her colleagues who is of Asian descent, so my planned conversational gambit is to casually remark that no matter how deep they dig his grave, he’ll never make his way back to China.

speaker: That should lighten the mood.
response: What can I say? I put the fun in funeral.

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: I’m not allowed to wear my Silver Surfer neck tie, but you can wear a bathrobe?

speaker: I think I’m too sick to go to the funeral.
response: You’re sick? You poor kid. Well, see ya.

speaker: Sheldon, aren’t you gonna take care of me?
response: Me? No. No, I’m not that kind of doctor.

speaker: But our relationship agreement clearly states that when one of us is sick, the other must take care of them.
response: Oh, no, I see the confusion. No, the intent behind that clause was to force you to take care of me when I’m ill. When you’re feeling better, you’ll think that’s funny.

speaker: Never mind. Good night, Sheldon.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. I made a commitment in writing to comfort you in times like this. Additionally, you are my girlfriend, and I care about your well-being.

speaker: Thank you, Sheldon.
response: You’re welcome. Now let’s get this over with.

speaker: Sheldon, you don’t get over the flu in half an hour.
response: Well, not with that attitude.

speaker: I have to say, I’m finding your bedside manner a little lacking.
response: I’m sorry. I just want you to get better as soon as possible. And with that goal in mind, let me ask you a question. Do you believe in the placebo effect?

speaker: Of course I do. There have been many studies proving its validity.
response: Great. Now, this may look like a Tic Tac, but it is really a powerful medication specifically designed to cure your illness as well as freshen your breath.

speaker: Sheldon, this isn’t helping. Why don’t you just let me get some rest.
response: How can you sleep? I’m not done making you feel better. I still have to put a cold rag on your head, sing to you and apply VapoRub to your chest.

speaker: You, you want to rub something on my chest?
response: Yes. All over it.

speaker: Maybe we should start with that.
response: Now you’re being a responsible patient. Now, you may notice some tingling.

speaker: That was great. Rub my chest again. (Knock at door)
response: No. I need to get you down for a nap. And for some reason, that VapoRub gets you all fired up. (Opens door)

speaker: How’s the poor thing?
response: Oh, I’m hanging in there. Thanks for asking.

speaker: Okay, Amy, I brought you some drugs we were working on in the lab. This is proving really good for congestion, but there’s a slight chance it can make your tears burn like acid, so if you take it, happy thoughts.
response: Uh, I’m going to draw you a soothing bath. Where’s your bath thermometer?

speaker: I don’t have a bath thermometer.
response: Fine. Then I’m going to draw you a nerve-wracking bath of indeterminate temperature.

speaker: All right. I’ll tell him.
response: Amy, would you be strong enough to bathe yourself, or do you need my help?

speaker: Oh, Sheldon, am I glad you’re back. Taking a turn for the worst. I think I’m going to need another bath.
response: I’m surprised to hear that. See, the other day, I was concerned that you weren’t recovering, so while you were sleeping, I took a cheek swab and had it cultured in the lab.

speaker: Oh?
response: I got the results back. Have you developed any of the following symptoms? A growing nose, or perhaps a warm sensation in the trouser region? Also known as full-blown liar, liar, pants on fire.

speaker: All right, all right. But I really was sick at the beginning. It’s just been so nice having you take care of me.
response: It hurts that you would lie to me, Amy. I thought our relationship was based on trust and a mutual admiration that skews in my favour.

speaker: I feel terrible I did this.
response: It pains me to say it, but I think some form of penalty is in order, so as to discourage this type of behaviour in the future.

speaker: I suppose that’s fair. What do you suggest?
response: In a perfect world, I’d lock you in a stockade in the public square. That probably requires a permit.

speaker: I could not be allowed to go to the opening of the next Star Trek movie.
response: Oh, that seems overly harsh. I mean, you gave in to a human weakness, you didn’t k*ll a man. You know, it’s a tad old-school, but my father was not one to spare the rod when my brother would sneak into his truck and drink his driving whiskey.

speaker: Are you saying you want to spank me?
response: I don’t want to. But it looks like you left me no choice.

speaker: One second. I want to put on some music.
response: Why?

speaker: I don’t want to disturb the people next door while you discipline me.
response: Very well, then. Get over my knee. Let’s begin.

speaker: Oh, my.
response: Excuse me. You’re not supposed to be enjoying this.

speaker: Then maybe you should spank me harder.
response: Maybe I will.

speaker: Ooh, me.
response: Penny, a moment. We just had Thai food. In that culture, the last morsel is called the krengjai piece, and it is reserved for the most important and valued member of the group.

speaker: Thank you all for this high honour.
response: I’ve seen pictures of your mother, keep eating.

speaker: All right, I got to go to work. I’ll walk down with you.
response: Wait. Uh, which is closer to the new train store in Monrovia, the movie theatre or the Cheesecake Factory?

speaker: Neither of them are close.
response: Oh, well, then I guess it doesn’t matter which one of you drives me. Let’s play a fun guessing game to see who gets to take me. All right, this four-letter word describes either a printer’s type size or a compulsion to eat dirt.

speaker: Okay, I’m not driving him.
response: No, Penny, don’t give up, you can get this.

speaker: What are you going to get at the train store, Sheldon?
response: Oh, I’m not buying anything. They’re having a lecture. H-O gauge railroading. Half the size of O-gauge, but twice the fun. Very controversial topic.

speaker: Which side do you come down on?
response: I’ll let you know after tonight. Unlike some people, I’m going in with an open mind. Who am I kidding? Of course we all know it’s O-gauge or no gauge.

speaker: Hang on. You seriously think I’m going to live with your mother?
response: Howard, I think I can help here. Yes, Bernadette, that’s exactly what he thinks.

speaker: Mmmmmm.
response: Okay, everybody calm down. There is a simple solution here. Raj, take me to the train store, and then I don’t care what you people do.

speaker: Dear Amy, self-respect and a hymen are better than friends and fun. Love, Mom.
response: Well, you can add Jerry’s Junction to the list of train stores Sheldon Cooper will never set foot in again.

speaker: Rough night, Casey Jones?
response: You don’t know the half of it. It was billed as a lively give-and-take on the merits of model train sizes. But it was actually a set-up to intimidate weak-minded spineless rubes into buying H-O starter sets.

speaker: What’s in the bag?
response: I don’t want to talk about it. But it’s not a spine,I’ll tell you that.

speaker: I would, but the last wedding we went to was a disaster. He behaved like a child the entire time.
response: Not my fault. You said there’d be other scientists there my age.

speaker: Doesn’t matter. You’re out, he’s in. No date to the prom, two dates to a wedding. Hmm, how times change.
response: Ha-ha, you have to go to a wedding.

speaker: Aw. So handsome. Like James Bond.
response: Better than James Bond, because he’s tinier.

speaker: When you’re done copping a feel, that goes on my wrist.
response: All aboard! Woo-woo! It’s official. I’m an H-O trainiac.

speaker: Sounds like you had a great night.
response: I did. How was yours?

speaker: Not bad. I had a lot more fun with Amy than I thought I would.
response: What exactly do you mean by that?

speaker: Well, it turns out she really knows how to help a guy loosen up and have a good time. Although, truth be told, my groin’s a little worse for wear. (Sheldon hits him) Ow! Why did you do that?
response: To send a message. She is not for you.

speaker: What?
response: Not for you!

speaker: Which means a spherical multidimensional superfluid shows the same negative-energy density as space-time. So what do you think? What do you think? So what do you think?
response: Hmm.

speaker: What? Is it wrong? Have you seen it somewhere else?
response: Hmm.

speaker: I know this isn't my area, and I could never do the math like you can, but could this be something?
response: Well, (sighs) (stammers) you could have set Newton's gravitational constant to one. And, ugh, the whole thing reeks of blueberry. You know I can't stand these scented markers.

speaker: No one told you to taste them. Come on, is, is this good or not?
response: It's good.

speaker: Really?
response: I like it. I think you're on to something.

speaker: You do? You're not messing with me?
response: Not at all. In fact, I have got something for just such an occasion. I was starting to think I might never get a chance to give it to you. Good job.

speaker: You're giving me a sticker?
response: Not just a sticker. That is a sticker of a kitty saying me-wow.

speaker: I'm not a preschooler.
response: (stammers) Fine, I'll take it back.

speaker: You're still awake?
response: For a man whose last observation was our universe may be the surface of a multidimensional supercooled liquid, "you're still awake" seems like quite the sophomore slump.

speaker: You worked out all the math.
response: Oh, I did more than work out all the math. I wrote a paper.

speaker: You wrote a paper on my idea?
response: I wrote a paper on our idea.

speaker: When did my idea become our idea?
response: When I mixed it with Sheldony goodness and cooked it in the Easy-Bake oven of my mind.

speaker: This is good. Our idea is really good.
response: Well, the lightbulb in this oven is ridiculously bright.

speaker: You know, if no one's thought of this, yet, this could be a big deal.
response: Only way we'll know for sure is if we post it online to the pre-print server. I have it ready to go, but I wasn't gonna do it without you.

speaker: Wow, it's all happening so fast. Should we just sleep on it?
response: We could, but we always run the risk of someone else b*at us to the punch.

speaker: You're sure it's good?
response: My name is right on there with yours. That is a surefire mark of quality. That might as well say "directed by Joss Whedon".

speaker: Okay, partner, let's do it.
response: Come on. Click the mouse with me.

speaker: Well, we did it.
response: Yes, we did, my friend.

speaker: Is your tongue blue?
response: I don't want to talk about it.

speaker: Sheldon, this is superfluid helium. Put this in your mouth, your tongue will freeze and break off.
response: Does it smell like blueberries?

speaker: No.
response: Then we're probably okay.

speaker: Let me see, let me see. One calls it insightful and innovative. We're insightful and innovative.
response: Oh, nice to meet you, Mr. Insightful.

speaker: Oh, the pleasure is mine, Mr. Innovative. Uh, another one says, "The concept shows some real out-of-the-box thinking". Do you hear that, Mr. Out-Of-The?
response: I do, indeed, Mr. Box-Thinking.

speaker: Just dandy, Mr I-Wish-I-Was-Better-At-Improv.
response: Read another one.

speaker: Okay, okay. Uh, "The analogy between space-time and a supercooled fluid is either meaningless or false. I wish this blog would devote itself to real science instead of wasting our time with crackpot wannabe theoreticians in a rush to publish."
response: Who wrote that?

speaker: It's anonymous, and user name "General Relativity".
response: Well, I'm responding to it.

speaker: Uh, don't lower yourself to their level.
response: Look, I am simply going to defend our work, scientist to scientist. And failing that, suggest that his mother enjoys a string of both human and non-human lovers.

speaker: Sheldon, my name's on that paper, too. There's no upside to doing this.
response: He just left another comment.

speaker: "Upon review, I've changed my mind about the Cooper-Hofstadter hypothesis that space-time is like a superfluid. In fact, it's inspired me to come up with my own theory. Maybe space-time is like two clowns with their heads in a bucket, much like Cooper and Hofstadter."
response: Can I respond now?

speaker: Do it.
response: You mess with the bull, you get the horns. I'm about to show this guy just how horny I can be.

speaker: Did he respond yet?
response: Hmm. No, not yet.

speaker: Read it back one more time.
response: (clears throat) "My good sir, we are neither crackpots nor wannabes. In fact, we are experts in our fields. And while you hide behind your anonymity, we stand behind our paper. And later tonight, your mother."

speaker: And you don't think that's too rough?
response: We're just standing behind her. It's not like we're gonna say boo and scare her.

speaker: You know, there was a time when I was alone and had no friends. I'm starting to miss that.
response: He still hasn't responded. What's taking him so long?

speaker: Do you really want him to write back?
response: Yeah, I do. Then no matter how he responds, I am going to destroy him with a picture of a bored cat saying, "Oh, really?"

speaker: No. You have to read it how Dr. Angus McDougal of the University of Edinburgh would. (Scottish accent) "This wee li'l bairn of a theory nearly blew me kilt off."
response: (gasps) He wrote back. "Cooper and Hofstadter resorting to juvenile attempts at humour is proof they have nothing to back up their ridiculous paper. It should come as no surprise given they work at Cal Tech, essentially a technical school, where even the physicists are basically engineers." (gasps) "Engineers"? Do you know how insulting that is?

speaker: Guys, this person's just going out of their way to get a rise out of you.
response: Yeah, but it's still so aggravating.

speaker: See? Better with the accent.
response: And send.

speaker: What did you write?
response: I'm done hiding from bullies. I'm taking this into the real world.

speaker: What does that mean?
response: I told him we'll meet him face-to-face anytime, anywhere.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon!
response: Oh, okay, okay, calm down. (electronic tones play) (gasps) It's him. He's trying to video chat. Perhaps I shouldn't have taken this into the real world.

speaker: Well, I think the anonymity makes everyone feel like they can say things they'd never say to your face.
response: Interesting. I can't think of a single thing I wouldn't say to someone's face.

speaker: You know what? At least you guys did something. You know, you, you had a theory, you wrote a paper, you made an actual contribution. All guys like this do is just stand on other people's work.
response: He's right. I say we call this person back. We've got no reason to hide.

speaker: All right, do it. Call him. Let's find out what this loser's ever accomplished.
response: Click it with me. One, two, three, click.

speaker: Well, hello there.
response: Professor Hawking?

speaker: I like your paper very much. The premise is intriguing.
response: Then why are you attacking us?

speaker: Stephen Hawking liked our paper. (chuckles softly) Said the premise is intriguing.
response: Good to see you again, Mr. Stephen-Hawking Liked-Our-Paper.

speaker: Well, you might want to mark your Google calendars. Stan Lee is coming to do a signing on Thursday.
response: Did he finally write a sequel to his autobiography? I’m sure ages 79 through 87 were just action-packed.

speaker: No, just a regular comic signing. My uncle is his dermatologist and Stan’s doing him a favour.
response: Oh, I don’t want to know that! How can I possibly discuss with Stan Lee the scientific foundations for interstellar flight on a silver surfboard when part of my brain will be scanning his face for signs of contagious skin disease?

speaker: Stan Lee does not have a contagious skin disease.
response: Well, look who thinks he’s Stuart’s uncle now.

speaker: I can’t decide whether I want Stan Lee to autograph my Journey into Mystery 83, first appearance of Thor or my Fantastic Four number five, first appearance of Dr. Doom. (Raj presses his iPod. The theme from Jeopardy plays.) Alex, I’m going to go with what is… you’re a dumbass? (Presses again, his shirt blows a raspberry.)
response: I’ve decided I’m going to have Mr. Lee sign my copy of this month’s Batman.

speaker: That’s crazy. Stan Lee had nothing to do with Batman.
response: Yes, which is why no one else will ask him to sign one, and I will be the possessor of a unique, albeit confusing, artifact, which will set me apart from the hoi polloi of comic book fandom.

speaker: That’s a great idea, I’m going to get him to sign a Batman as well.
response: What is it about the word unique you don’t understand?

speaker: Well, obviously you don’t remember your circumcision.
response: There’s Neosporin and Band-Aids in my top desk drawer.

speaker: He does. And in the kitchen. And in the car. And in his pocket.
response: Yeah, but the ones in my pocket are mine.

speaker: Sheldon, why do you have all these unopened paychecks in your desk?
response: Because most of the things I’m planning to buy haven’t been invented yet.

speaker: But there must be thousands of dollars here. Why don’t you put it in the bank?
response: I don’t trust banks. I believe that when the robots rise up, ATMs will lead the charge.

speaker: You’ve also got something from the Pasadena Municipal Court.
response: Undoubtedly yet another snide response to my repeated letters complaining that the flags in front of the courthouse are flying in the wrong order. From left to right, it’s supposed to be federal, state, and then city of Pasadena.

speaker: I’m sorry. You sent more than one letter about that?
response: It bothers me.

speaker: Sheldon, this is a summons.
response: A summons for what?

speaker: Looks like you ran a red light on Marengo Avenue at 9
response: November 16? Penny, that’s the evening you fell in your bathtub and I had to drive you to the emergency room.

speaker: No, it isn’t.
response: Yes, it is.

speaker: No, it isn’t.
response: Penny, I have an eidetic memory. Also, that’s a picture of you in the passenger seat holding your dislocated shoulder.

speaker: Mmm, no, it isn’t.
response: Okay, then why is a summons for a traffic violation committed in your car, bearing your license plates, coming to me?

speaker: Okay, look, they sent me the ticket. I told them I wasn’t driving and they were all, if it wasn’t you, who was it?
response: So you betrayed me?

speaker: No! It wasn’t a betrayal. It was more of a can’t afford any more points on my license. I already have to buy my insurance from this place in the Cayman Islands.
response: But the only reason I was driving your car was because you were in distress and I was rescuing you.

speaker: It’s not that big a deal. You just go down to the court on Thursday and you pay the fine.
response: I’m not going to pay a fine. That would imply I’m guilty.

speaker: You are guilty. (Raj’s shirt plays the gavel sound from Law & Order) That one I liked.
response: I am not guilty. I only have a learner’s permit, Penny was the teacher. When the light turned yellow she said go, go, go, so I went, went, went.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m sorry. I’ll be happy to reimburse you for the fine. You know, as soon as I get a part in a movie or my own TV series.
response: You don’t need to reimburse me because I’m not paying. On Thursday, I will have my day in court and justice will be done. In fact, I’m going to begin preparing my defence right now.

speaker: Oh, that’s right. Thursday is Stan Lee Day.
response: Now you see what you’ve done? Because of you, we’re all going to miss Stan Lee.

speaker: Whoa! What do you mean all?
response: Well, you’re my friends. You’ll be standing by my side, supporting me, feeding me legal precedents, and if you had the upper body strength, carrying me out on your shoulders when I’m victorious.

speaker: Yeah, okay. No.
response: Are you saying that you will not stand beside me as I plead my case?

speaker: That’s what I’m saying.
response: Howard?

speaker: Wow. Uh, Stan Lee, or you in court? Uh, if this was Sophie’s Choice it would’ve been a much shorter movie. No.
response: Raj? You’ll be there, won’t you? (Shirt plays “incorrect” quiz sound) All right, then, my so-called friends have forsaken me. So, I guess it’ll just be me and my eyewitness.

speaker: Oh, balls.
response: Please try to wear something appropriate. It won’t help my case if the judge is busy trying to read the word Juicy scrawled across your buttocks.

speaker: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
response: That’s just wrong.

speaker: All right, let’s go.
response: Wait, hold on. Before we get to the courthouse, I’d like to call on your k*ll as an actress.

speaker: What is this?
response: I’ve taken the liberty of scripting your appearance on the witness stand because, let’s face it, you’re somewhat of a loose cannon. Now, don’t worry, it’s written in your vernacular. So shall we rehearse?

speaker: Do I have a choice?
response: Well, of course you have a choice. Although we live in a deterministic universe, each individual has free will. Now, sit down. I call your attention to the events of November 16. Do you remember that date?

speaker: Darn tootin’, I do, if the court will excuse my homespun, corn-fed Nebraskan turn of phrase.
response: Excellent. Go on.

speaker: The reason that date is, like, so totally fixed in my memory is that I had the privilege to be witness to one of the most heroic acts I’ve ever seen in, like, ever.
response: And who performed that heroic act?

speaker: Why, you did, sir. You. Dr. Sheldon Cooper, and may I add, it is a privilege to know you.
response: There’s no need for compliments, this court is only interested in the facts.

speaker: But it is a fact that it’s a privilege to know you. Totally. A teardrop rolls down my cheek?
response: Only a suggestion. A catch in your throat would work just as well.

speaker: But it is a fact that it’s a privilege to know you. Totally.
response: Maybe you should put on your Juicy pants again.

speaker: Pay the cashier. Sheldon Cooper?
response: Good morning, Your Honour. Dr. Sheldon Cooper appearing in pro se. That is to say, representing himself.

speaker: I know what it means. I went to law school.
response: And yet you wound up in traffic court. Anyway, if it would please the court, I’d like to begin with an opening statement.

speaker: The court would advise you to make it quick, as the court had a dicey-looking breakfast burrito this morning and just took an Imodium.
response: Very well, a quick opening statement. Like a milking stool, my case rests on three legs. I will demonstrate that I was improperly instructed in driving by a woman whose lack of respect for society borders on the sociopathic. I will argue that the emergency met the legal doctrine of quod est necessarium est licitum, that which is necessary is legal. But first, I will raise a Sixth Amendment issue. I’m unable to confront my accuser, a non-human entity, to wit, a camera. So, to sum up, improper instruction, quod est necessarium est licitum, Sixth Amendment. My milk stool is complete.

speaker: Impressive.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Guilty. Pay the cashier.
response: I object. You’re completely ignoring the law.

speaker: No, I’m following the law. I’m ignoring you.
response: Really? I would point out that I am at the top of my profession, while you preside over the kiddy table of yours.

speaker: Dr. Cooper, before I find you in contempt and throw you in jail, I’m going to give you a chance to apologize for that last remark.
response: I am a scientist. I never apologize for the truth.

speaker: What?
response: I need to use the restroom.

speaker: Knock yourself out. (Points to urinal in cell)
response: That’s the toilet?

speaker: Well, it ain’t a wishing well.
response: Please tell the judge I’m ready to apologize.

speaker: Oh, hey, buddy. How’d it go?
response: You know very well how it went.

speaker: Yeah, but we all want to hear it from you.
response: I was found guilty and fined $533.

speaker: I’m going to write you a cheque for that. As long as you promise to put it in your drawer and never cash it, like the others.
response: I also now have three points on a driver’s licence I do not yet possess, and I was forced to issue an undeserved apology, simply because I refuse to urinate in a stainless steel bowl in front of criminals.

speaker: You’re right, so it would be cruel to mention that after he finished signing autographs, Stan Lee took Stuart and us out for gelato.
response: You had gelato with Stan Lee?

speaker: Except for Raj.
response: Well, I hope you’re satisfied, Penny. You are responsible for all the evil that has befallen me today.

speaker: Okay, I realize that…
response: Not finished. It is because of you that I now have a criminal record, and it is because of you that I missed out on having gelato with Stan Lee.

speaker: Okay, maybe you’ll have another chance to have…
response: No, no. I will never have another chance to have gelato with Stan Lee because opportunities to have gelato with Stan Lee come but once in a lifetime. The moving finger writes, and having writ, moves on!

speaker: Yup.
response: Oh, Lord, you just rang Stan Lee’s doorbell. At Stan Lee’s house. We’re about to go in and have milk and cookies with Stan Lee.

speaker: Hi. I’m Penny. This is my friend, Sheldon.
response: We’re not friends at the moment. Depends on how this goes.

speaker: I see. And you thought you’d just come over to my house uninvited?
response: You said we were invited.

speaker: You know, you fan boys are unbelievable. Do you think you can just ring my doorbell any time you want? I mean, why don’t you just come on in and watch the Lakers game with me?
response: Well, I’m not much of a sports fan, but thank you.

speaker: Hey, where’ve you been?
response: I’ll tell you where I’ve been. You boys may have had gelato with Stan Lee and gotten autographed comics, but I saw the inside of his house and got an autographed application for a restraining order.

speaker: Sweet.
response: Plus, I get to hang out with him again at the hearing. This is going to look great hanging next to my restraining order from Leonard Nimoy.

speaker: The apartment.
response: The entrance to the dungeon is a moss covered door. You manage to open it only to find yourself face-to-face with a hideous, foul-smelling, moss-covered ogre. What do you do?

speaker: I say, hey Ma, what’s for dinner?”
response: Seventeen. The ogre is amused by your joke and allows you to pass. By the by, I liked it, too.

speaker: Maybe. We enter the dungeon.
response: You see a dragon.

speaker: Really? So we’re playing Dungeons and Dragons, and we walk into a dungeon and see a dragon? Isn’t that a little on the nose?
response: When you play Chutes and Ladders, do you complain about all the chutes and all the ladders?

speaker: That’s cruel. You know it goes straight to my hips.
response: Gentlemen, please focus. You’re facing a fire-breathing dragon.

speaker: I don’t know if I want to play anymore.
response: Because you don’t have a girlfriend? Well, good Lord, if that becomes a reason not to play Dungeons and Dragons, this game’s in serious trouble.

speaker: Are we ready to order?
response: One moment. I’m conducting an experiment.

speaker: With Dungeons and Dragons dice?
response: Yes. From here on in, I’ve decided to make all trivial decisions with a throw of the dice, thus freeing up my mind to do what it does best, enlighten and amaze. Page 14, item seven.

speaker: So, what’s for dinner?
response: A side of corn succotash. Hmm. Interesting.

speaker: Uh, no, that’s not it. Just come with me, please.
response: Let’s see what I’ll be washing that succotash down with. A pitcher of margaritas.

speaker: Do you really want that?
response: That’s the great thing. It doesn’t matter. My mind is freed up to think about more important things.

speaker: What’s it thinking about now?
response: Hamburgers and lemonade.

speaker: Ah, look at that. I have a date. I love America again.
response: And now for dessert, come on, hot fudge sundae, come on, hot fudge sundae. Bam! That’s what I’m talking about!

speaker: Mustache is looking good there, Sheldon.
response: Don’t thank me. Thank the dice. They told me what percentage of my face to shave.

speaker: Why are you still doing this?
response: Because it’s working. In the past few weeks, unburdened by trivial decisions, I’ve co-authored two papers in notable peer-reviewed journals, and I’m close to figuring out why the Large Hadron Collider has yet to isolate the Higgs boson particle.

speaker: You left out, got chafed testicles because you no longer wear underpants.
response: The dice giveth and the dice taketh away.

speaker: Wow, can’t believe he has a girlfriend.
response: Me neither.

speaker: Handicapped people are nice, Leonard. Everyone knows that.
response: Yeah, I actually have information about Raj that would be helpful with this discussion.

speaker: Could you tell us?
response: Let’s see. (Rolls dice) Snake eyes. Sorry, bud.

speaker: Wait, hang on. Doubles. Roll again.
response: Okay, get this. It doesn’t matter if he’s showering her with gifts, because the Koothrappalis are vastly wealthy.

speaker: What do you mean, vastly wealthy?
response: Well, wealthy means a lot of money, and vastly means even more. I’m not sure what’s tripping you up.

speaker: Look, I know they have money. I don’t think it’s that much.
response: No, you’re wrong. See, as you know, a few years ago, I achieved one of my lesser dreams and became a notary public. Well, from time to time, I notarize banking documents for Raj. The Koothrappalis aren’t just rich, they’re Richie Rich rich.

speaker: Well, so how much is that?
response: About halfway between Bruce Wayne and Scrooge McDuck.

speaker: He’s not going to listen, he’s in love.
response: Can’t figure out what to do? I remember those days. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have to… (rolls dice) stay right here.

speaker: Try throwing it in the microwave for a few seconds.
response: Should I use the rest room or wait until we get home? Come on, papa needs to void his bladder. Oh, that’s not what you want to see after three buttermilks.

speaker: Yeah, real big of you.
response: Hurry, hurry, hurry.

speaker: Bite me. Sheldon, how could you just sit there and let them spy on me?
response: They were clever, Leonard. They exploited my complete lack of interest in what you were doing.

speaker: Well, we sort of decided to wing it.
response: Oh, even I know that’s lame.

speaker: Nice close up, by the way.
response: Interesting, her jaws are clenched, no tongue access, clearly a bad sign amongst mating humans.

speaker: That’s not a bad sign.
response: Please, you might as well have been two iguana with no dewlap enlargement.

speaker: Hi.
response: Oh, hi Penny. FYI, the hot water is inadequate on machine 2 so colours only, and 4 is still releasing the fabric softener too early in the cycle so I’d avoid using that for your delicates.

speaker: Thanks.
response: Oh, good Lord. Why don’t you just take your clothes down to the river and b*at them with a rock?

speaker: Sheldon, may I ask you a question?
response: I would prefer that you not, but I won’t go so far as to forbid it.

speaker: Alright, I heard yes, so… okay, here’s my question, has Leonard ever dated, you know, a regular girl.
response: Well I assume you’re not referring to digestive regularity? Because I’ve come to learn that such inquiries are inappropriate.

speaker: No, I meant has he ever been involved with someone who wasn’t a braniac?
response: Oh. Well, a few years ago he did go out with a woman who had a PhD in French Literature.

speaker: How is that not a braniac?
response: Well, for one thing, she was French. For another, it was literature.

speaker: So, do you think that if Leonard and I keep dating he’ll eventually get bored with me.
response: That depends.

speaker: On what?
response: Do you have a working knowledge of quantum physics?

speaker: No.
response: Do you speak Klingon?

speaker: No.
response: Do you know any card tricks?

speaker: Okay, okay, you know, I get it, Leonard has no business being involved with a waitress slash actress who felt so insecure that she lied to him about finishing community college.
response: Why would you lie about that?

speaker: Well, he was going on and on about this college and that grad school and I didn’t want him to think I was some stupid loser.
response: You thought the opposite of stupid loser was community college graduate?

speaker: You know, there are a lot of successful people in this country who are community college graduates.
response: Yeah, but you were neither.

speaker: Right, okay look, this is between you and me, you cannot tell Leonard any of this.
response: You’re asking me to keep a secret?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Well I’m sorry, but you would have had to express that desire before revealing the secret, so that I could choose whether or not I wanted to accept the covenant of secret keeping. You can’t impose a secret on an ex post facto basis.

speaker: What?
response: Secret keeping is a complicated endeavour. One has to be concerned not only about what one says, but about facial expression, autonomic reflexes, when I try to deceive, I myself have more nervous tics than a lyme disease research facility. (Long pause.) It’s a joke. It relies on the hominymic relationship between tick the blood-sucking arachnid, and tic the involuntary muscular contraction. I made it up myself.

speaker: Okay, look, if Leonard finds out that I lied, I will absolutely die of embarrassment.
response: Physiologically impossible.

speaker: Oh Sheldon, please, look, I’m asking you as a friend.
response: So you’re saying that friendship contains within it an inherent obligation to maintain confidences?

speaker: Well, yeah.
response: Interesting. See, one more question, and perhaps I should have led with this, when did we become friends?

speaker: You could be Batman?
response: Sure. (In a gravelly voice) I’m Batman. See.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hi Penny.

speaker: Great. So you just let me know when you know. So… (she leaves) Oh God, I am the bad fish! What did I do wrong?
response: Why are you asking me, I have no information about your interactions with Penny other than what you provided me, nor do I have any method of learning such things. (Runs away.)

speaker: What does that mean?
response: Nothing. You seem to be implying an informational back channel between me and Penny where obviously none exists.

speaker: No I didn’t.
response: I just think you need to be careful how you phrase things, sir.

speaker: What’s going on with you?
response: Well I might ask you the same question. Why do you insist on attempting to drag me into matters which have nothing to do with me? But exist between you and Penny. A person to whom I barely speak. (His eye begins to twitch.)

speaker: What’s wrong with your face?
response: There’s no reason to bring my looks into this. Good day, Leonard.

speaker: What?
response: I said Good Day! (He leaves)

speaker: Also today we have a fresh caught Alaska salmon, and that’s served with a teriyaki glaze and sticky rice. Our soup of the day…
response: You must release me from my oath.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m working.
response: Why don’t you take a minute to decide (leads her away)I can’t keep your secret Penny. I’m going to fold like an energy based anobo protein in conformational space. Like a renaissance triptych. Like a cheap suit.

speaker: Oh, look, why is it so hard for you to keep one little secret?
response: I’m constitutionally incapable. That’s why I was refused clearance for a very prestigious government research fellowship at a secret military supercollider, located beneath a fake agricultural station 12.5 miles south east of Travers City, Michigan. Which you did not hear about from me.

speaker: Look, just forget I told you about me not graduating from community college. Okay?
response: Forget! You want me to forget? This mind does not forget. I haven’t forgotten a single thing since the day my mother stopped breast feeding me. It was a drizzly Tuesday.

speaker: What do you mean, you’re moving out? Why?
response: There doesn’t have to be a reason.

speaker: Yeah, there kind of does.
response: Not necessarily. This is a classic example of munchausen’s trilemma. Either the reason is predicated on a series of sub-reasons leading to an infinite regression, or it tracks back to arbitrary axiomatic statements, or it’s ultimately circular, i.e., I’m moving out because I’m moving out.

speaker: I’m still confused.
response: Leonard, I don’t see how I could have made it any simpler.

speaker: And some of those skinless chicks were hot.
response: If you’ll excuse me, I’m going to pack.

speaker: That was fast.
