response: It’s my pre-packed disaster evacuation bag. Recommended by the department of homeland security. And Sarah Connor.

speaker: Where are you gonna live?
response: Until I find a permanent place I will stay with friends.

speaker: Well you can’t stay with me, I have a teeny tiny apartment.
response: Excuse me, but isn’t hosting guests an aspect of Menushya Yajna, one of the five central religious duties or sacrifices of the Hindu householder?

speaker: I hate trains.
response: Don’t be ridiculous, you love trains.

speaker: Sixty years. Used to be a watch factory.
response: Uh-oh.

speaker: What?
response: Don’t you worry about the residual radium from the luminous dials?

speaker: Not until now.
response: I can’t believe I didn’t bring my gieger counter. You know, I had it on my bed and I didn’t pack it.

speaker: Well, if you’re not comfortable staying here, Sheldon…
response: I’m kidding, I packed it. It was a joke, I was subverting the conversational expectations. I believe they call that the, um, old switcheroo.

speaker: Terrific.
response: Is that woman Aishwarya Rai?

speaker: Yes, isn’t she an amazing actress.
response: Actually, I’d say she’s a poor man’s Madhuri Dixit.

speaker: How dare you. Aishwarya Rai is a Goddess. By comparison Madhuri Dixit is a leprous prostitute.
response: Sorry, I didn’t mean to offend you. Obviously you’re not that familiar with Indian cinema.

speaker: Maybe you’d be happier on a park bench?
response: I don’t see any way to get a park bench in here.

speaker: Do you want to switch?
response: No, that’s fine. I’m perfectly comfortable sleeping on a bouncy castle.

speaker: Get out of bed, we’re switching.
response: Now, only if you want to.

speaker: For God’s sake, ma, I’m 27 years old. It’s not even a school night! (To Sheldon) Comfy now?
response: Meh. That poster of Halle Berry’s a little unnerving.

speaker: So don’t look at it.
response: She’s like my fourth favourite catwoman.

speaker: No kidding?
response: Yeah, Julie Newmar, Michelle Pfieffer, Eartha Kitt and then her.

speaker: What about Lee Meriwether?
response: Oh, I forgot about Lee Meriwether.

speaker: Well I’m glad that’s settled.
response: That makes Halle Berry my fifth favourite catwoman. There’s Julie Newmar, Michelle Pfieffer, Eartha Kitt, Lee Meriwether…

speaker: Please, I’m begging you, go to sleep.
response: I’m trying, I’m counting catwomen. She did make a fine mutant in the X-Men movies though.

speaker: Oh for God’s sake.
response: But she’s not my favourite of the X-Men, in order that would be Wolverine, Cyclops, oh wait, I forgot Professor X. Professor X, Wolverine, Cyclops, Iceman, then Storm, Angel, the Beast, oh wait, Nightcrawler. Professor X, Nightcrawler, Wolverine, Cyclops, Iceman, then Storm, Angel….

speaker: I’m coming! (Opens the door. Sheldon falls inside, wearing his pyjamas. Howard is outside.)
response: Hey, there he is, there’s my old buddy-bud-bud.

speaker: Koothrappali dumped him on me, and he couldn’t get to sleep, so I gave him a glass of warm milk with a handful of my mom’s valium in it. But he still wouldn’t shut up, so, tag, you’re it.
response: I’m ba-ack!

speaker: I still don’t know why you left.
response: I can’t tell you.

speaker: Why not.
response: I promised Penny.

speaker: You promised Penny what?
response: That I wouldn’t tell you the secret. Shhhhh!

speaker: What secret. Tell me the secret.
response: Mom smokes in the car. Jesus is okay with it, but we can’t tell Dad.

speaker: Not that secret, the other secret.
response: I’m Batman. Shhhhh!

speaker: Dammit, Sheldon! You said Penny told you a secret, what was the secret.
response: Okay, I’ll tell you, but you can’t tell Leonard.

speaker: I promise.
response: Penny lied about graduating from community college because she is afraid she’s not smart enough for Leonard.

speaker: So it’s nothing I did? It’s her problem?
response: I drank milk that tasted funny.

speaker: Penny thinks I’m too smart for her, that’s ridiculous.
response: I know, most of your work is extremely derivative. Don’t worry, that’s not a secret. Everybody knows.

speaker: Can you believe it's been five years since our first date?
response: I know. Do you think I should start watching The Flash TV show?

speaker: That's what you're thinking about?
response: Well, one of the things.

speaker: Are any of them me?
response: Yes. I thought, "I can't decide if I should watch The Flash TV show. I know, I'll ask Amy." Anyway...

speaker: What are you doing?
response: You're right, you did kind of k*ll the mood.

speaker: I didn't k*ll anything. You did, talking about your stupid TV show.
response: Excuse me. Starting to watch a television show that might run for years isn't a decision to take lightly. I'm wrestling with a big commitment issue here.

speaker: Really? That's the commitment issue you're wrestling with? Sheldon, do you understand the irony of your fixation on a man with super speed, while after five years all I can get out of you is a distracted make-out session on a couch?
response: Irony's not really my strong suit. But I have been getting better with sarcasm, if you want to give that a try.

speaker: (sarcastically) Oh, sure, I'd love to.
response: Whenever you're ready.

speaker: Hey.
response: Oh, good. You're here. I need your assistance.

speaker: Can it wait until I put a Band-Aid on a goat bite?
response: What happened?

speaker: Oh, your buddy got mugged by some baby farm animals.
response: Been there.

speaker: Mmm. So what do you need help with?
response: Amy's mad at me, and I'm not clear why.

speaker: Okay. Were you talking before she got upset?
response: Yes.

speaker: That's probably it. What'd you say to her?
response: Well, I just asked her if I should start watching the new Flash TV series.

speaker: And that made her angry?
response: Baffling, right? We were necking like a couple of hooligans under the school bleachers. I stopped so I could ask the question. Next thing I know, good-bye, kissy face. Hello, yelly face.

speaker: Well, Sheldon, when you're kissing a girl, she expects the attention to be on her.
response: It was. I asked her if she thought I should watch The Flash.

speaker: I'm gonna guess that your main concern is the time commitment of watching an entire season of a new show.
response: Oh, no, not just a season. If I'm in, I'm in for the whole run, even if the quality declines.

speaker: I get it. Smallville almost wrecked you.
response: Yeah. Exactly. You know, I waited ten years to see a guy everyone knows can fly, fly.

speaker: Wait, what is wrong with you two? He was talking about television during their date night.
response: Oh, not just date night, our fifth anniversary.

speaker: Okay, see, that's even dumber than you wondering if being bitten by a goat would give you the powers of a goat.
response: If that happens, don't make me wait ten years to watch you eat a tin can.

speaker: Still haven't heard from her?
response: No, and I'm confused. It's been nearly 24 hours. Amy should have figured out she's wrong by now.

speaker: Hey, I don't think she's wrong about you going too slow in the relationship.
response: Too slow?

speaker: Yeah, you've been going out for years. You haven't even slept together.
response: That's right. It's called foreplay. And I could make the case that you two aren't moving forward in your relationship.

speaker: (scoffs) Uh, hello.
response: Hello.

speaker: No. Sheldon, we're getting married.
response: But you've been engaged for over a year now, and you don't even have a wedding date.

speaker: Well, we will. We're just not in a rush.
response: Okay.

speaker: We're gonna set a date.
response: Okay. If you say so.

speaker: Yeah.
response: Okay.

speaker: You know, I can see why Amy's mad at you.
response: Yeah, shut up, Sheldon.

speaker: Not in a rush, busy with work...
response: Things are good right now.

speaker: It's not just the date. We haven't talked about anything. Big wedding, small wedding, indoor, outdoor?
response: Outdoor? Oh. I can RSVP no right now.

speaker: Fine. I want to release butterflies.
response: Seriously? Airborne worms?

speaker: Great.
response: You still didn't pick a date.

speaker: Of ghosts, no. Of you, little bit.
response: I'm sorry I've upset you. I shouldn't have asked so many questions.

speaker: Yeah, maybe it's good you got us talking about this stuff.
response: Well, look at that, even when I'm causing problems, I make the world a better place. Hey, next, why don't we tackle your penchant for whining and Penny's love of the ol' glug-glug?

speaker: Uh, Sheldon, I think we're good for now.
response: Ah, well... very well. So does this mean you'll finally pick a wedding date?

speaker: (sighs) Here we go again. Why is everyone so concerned with us setting a date? We're committed to each other. We're happy. A ceremony isn't gonna change anything.
response: So you're never getting married? It's his whining, isn't it?

speaker: Sheldon, I'm not a whiner.
response: It's amusing that he doesn't hear it.

speaker: Yeah, but we'll be old and gross together.
response: My aunt and uncle were married 63 years. Towards the end, it was like watching cheese melt.

speaker: I'm in. Let's do it.
response: After all these years. I'm really happy for the two of you.

speaker: Thanks.
response: Now get out of my spot.

speaker: Hello.
response: Hello. Listen, I've been thinking a lot about relationships and how difficult they can be, and I think...

speaker: I've been thinking about them, too, Sheldon. Being your girlfriend is so challenging. Emotionally, physically. I've been incredibly patient for years.
response: Strongly disagree. Go on.

speaker: Okay, well, this isn't easy to say, because I love you, but I need some time to take a step back and re-evaluate our situation.
response: Oh.

speaker: I hope you understand.
response: Okay.

speaker: Bye, Sheldon.
response: Well, Gollum, you're an expert on rings. What do I do with this one?

speaker: It’s just two degrees, Sheldon. I just want to turn up the thermostat two degrees!
response: (voice off)

speaker: Yes, if we lived in a teakettle.
response: (voice off)

speaker: Aw, screw the roommate agreement!
response: (voice off)

One of the advantages of teaching history is that you donâ€™t have to create things, you know, you just have to remember stuff that happened and then parrot it back. You could have fun with that.

response: Oh, Leonard. Lots of people love you and want to help you, but they canâ€™t until you admit the problem.

response: Am I okay? Leonard, Iâ€™m on a lifelong trajectory that includes a Nobel Prize and cities named after me, all four wisdom teeth fit comfortably in my mouth without need of extraction, and my bowel movements run like a German train schedule. Am I okay?

speaker: A tribe of Abra-Comanches.
response: Flaming Spittoon. And for the record, Iâ€™m very disappointed in you cowpokes. Weâ€™re playing our inaugural round of Wild West and Witches, and Iâ€™m the only one who bothered to dress for the occasion. (Spits into a spittoon) Patooie.

response: All right, fine. Letâ€™s just play.

response: Cluck, cluck, cluck. What are we, ladies at a quilting bee? Or are we men playing a fantasy card game set in a magical frontier town?

speaker: Hocus Pocus Pocahontas.
response: And may I point out it is the three of you who are obsessed with Stuart and Amy, not me. I think you need to ask yourselves whoâ€™s really being ridiculous here. (Walks away with spurs jangling)

speaker: With a hologram? Nice. Hey, do you see this?
response: Iâ€™m in the matrix, Leonard, I see everything.

speaker: I thought you didnâ€™t like Facebook anymore.
response: Donâ€™t be silly. Iâ€™m a fan of anything that tries to replace actual human contact.

speaker: Please. Youâ€™re looking at Facebook to find out how their date went.

response: You are free to believe whatever you like. And unfriend Rajesh Koothrappali.

speaker: Sheldon, why donâ€™t you just acknowledge that you have feelings for Amy and you donâ€™t want her going out with other men?
response: And unfriend Leonard Hofstadter.

speaker: Hereâ€™s a radical thought. Go old-school, challenge Stuart to a fight. I mean, nothing makes the ladies hotter than two skinny white guys swatting at each other with their eyes closed.

speaker: Thatâ€™s all of us. Can I use the laptop?
response: Why?

speaker: Who do we love?
response: Penny. (Knock, knock, knock)

speaker: Who do we love?
response: Penny. (Knock, knock, knock)

speaker: Who do we love?
response: Penny.

speaker: Hello, Sheldon. Come on in.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Whatâ€™s up?
response: I came to ask if you would like to go on a date with me.

speaker: Iâ€™m sorry, what?
response: A date. You and me. Dining, dancing, perhaps youâ€™d like to take in a prizefight.

speaker: God, are you trying to make Amy jealous?
response: No. Why is everyone so obsessed with Amy and Stuart? And whether or not they may be having more pumpkin lattes or intercourse tonight.

speaker: Okay, listen to me. Playing games is not gonna help get Amy back.
response: I am not trying to get her back. But, out of curiosity, what is a way?

speaker: All right, honey, let me tell you a story. There was a guy I liked, and I never told him how I felt. Eventually, he started going out with someone else, and I always regretted it. Do you see where Iâ€™m going with this?
response: I believe I do.

speaker: Mm.
response: Iâ€™m the guy.

speaker: Youâ€™re not the guy.
response: Are you sure? That would explain so much. Your constant presence in my apartment, that baffling dalliance with Leonard just to be near me, the way you call me sweetie all the time.

speaker: I call everyone sweetie.
response: You tramp.

speaker: Look, Sheldon, all Iâ€™m saying is strap on a pair and go talk to Amy.
response: Strap on a pair? Of what, skates?

speaker: Donâ€™t patronize me.
response: Excuse me. Excuse me. Pardon me. Pardon me. Excuse me. Hi, Stuart.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon.
response: Pardon me. Excuse me.

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here?
response: The thought of you sitting in a darkened theatre with a character like Stuart is repellent. No offence, Stuart.

speaker: Um, againâ€¦
response: Stuart, please. Youâ€™re being rude.

speaker: Anything else?
response: I believe I would like to alter the paradigm of our relationship.

speaker: Iâ€™m listening.
response: With the understanding that nothing changes whatsoever, physical or otherwise, I would not object to us no longer characterizing you as not my girlfriend.

speaker: Interesting. Now try it without the quadruple negative.
response: Youâ€™re being impossible.

speaker: Hi, Stuart.
response: Fine. Amy, will you be my girlfriend?

speaker: Yes.
response: Well, thatâ€™s enough of that. Sorry to interrupt. You two enjoy your date. Hereâ€™s a dollar for your troubles. Get yourself some Sour Patch Kids.

speaker: Oh, youâ€™re welcome.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Letâ€™s wrap things up out there.

speaker: Good night.
response: Take the hint, Stuart. The lady said good night.

speaker: How did you get into my apartment?
response: Wow. Is that the kind of nagging I can expect now that youâ€™re my girlfriend? Good thing I drew this up.

speaker: Whatâ€™s that?
response: I present to you the relationship agreement. A binding covenant that, in its 31 pages, enumerates, iterates and codifies the rights and responsibilities of Sheldon Lee Cooper, here and after known as the boyfriend, and Amy Farrah Fowler, here and after known as the girlfriend.

speaker: Itâ€™s so romantic.
response: Mutual indemnification always is. Why donâ€™t you start perusing while I set up my notary stamp.

speaker: Section 5
response: Feel free to retain a lawyer.

speaker: We should play limbo next. No one b*at me at limbo.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Bernadette.

speaker: Thatâ€™s my boyfriend. Itâ€™s open!
response: I got a splinter.

speaker: What do you want me to do about it?
response: Relationship agreement Section 4, Boo-boos and Ouchies. You have to take care of it.

speaker: Yes, it is.
response: Yeah,uh, look, it is scientifically impossible for a person to tip a cow. Even you, with your stocky build and lumberjack shoulders, you couldn’t do it.

speaker: Mmm. I’m gonna say not. That’s just based on me trying to roll my mom over when she’s snoring. Speaking of that big side of beef, uh, she’s invited all of you to Thanksgiving at her house.
response: Mmm. You know, I’ve been told that a bald refusal of an invitation is rude and one must instead offer up a polite excuse, so I’d love to go, but, unfortunately, that sounds awful.

speaker: Please? Bernadette’s bringing her dad ’cause her mom’s out of town, and I never have anything to say to that guy.
response: Oh, since you put it that way, I’d love to go, but that sounds even more awful.

speaker: It’d actually be nice to not hear Sheldon complain about my cooking all day.
response: Uh, excuse me, but every year you prepare a terrible meal and every year I criticize it. Do our traditions mean nothing to you?

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Ugh, fine, I’ll go. But if her food is delicious, Thanksgiving is ruined, and it’s on you.

speaker: We do. And I expect you to be on your best behaviour.
response: Now I know how the African slaves felt. Being dragged from their homes to labour under the yoke of the white man.

speaker: Are you honestly comparing Thanksgiving dinner at Wolowitz’s mom’s with one of the greatest tragedies in the history of mankind?
response: Yes.

speaker: Yeah, they are.
response: He’s right.

speaker: But it didn’t seem real.
response: Let me ask you a question. At any point, was Las Vegas on its side?

speaker: No traffic, we’re sailing.
response: Yes. Like we’re on a ship. Coming from Africa to America.

speaker: Sheldon, that’s completely inappropriate. You can’t keep comparing yourself to a slave.
response: Yes, Miss Amy.

speaker: I will. Why are you making this such a big deal?
response: Oh, oh, oh, I have a reason. It could be because you said yes to marrying Zack, but every time Leonard’s proposed, he’s gotten a resounding no. Yeah, that’s just off the top of my head.

speaker: It says here you can get an annulment if any of the following conditions are met. Were you unable to consummate the marriage?
response: Hah!Penny? Next.

speaker: Happy Thanksgiving.
response: It smells wonderful. Is anyone slaving away in the kitchen? Because I, too, know…

speaker: Wuh, Penny.
response: I don’t know the first thing about women, but I would not follow her.

speaker: I’m trying to watch the game. Shut up. Oh, how do you not make a first down there?
response: They passed against a nickel defence. They should have run it off-tackle.

speaker: How the hell do you know that?
response: My father loved football. He always made me watch it before I was allowed to do my homework.

speaker: What do you think they ought to do now?
response: I would throw a quick slant to a wideout, given that the defence is showing blitz.

speaker: Yeah, that’s why. You remember the Thanksgiving game when it snowed in Dallas?
response: 1993. Leon Lett blew the game in the final seconds and the Dolphins emerged victorious. Then I finally got to do my calculus.

speaker: I was so pissed, I wanted to sh**t my TV.
response: So was my dad. And then he did.

speaker: So, does your dad still live in Texas?
response: No. He died when I was 14.

speaker: I’m sorry to hear that.
response: So was the man who owned the local liquor store. He cried and cried.

speaker: Oh, thanks. So, if your dad died when you were 14, you were never old enough to have a beer with the man.
response: No, sir. He did try to give me one for my high school graduation, but I was 11 and my mom said no.

speaker: Well, you’re having one with me.
response: All right.

speaker: I never had a beer with my dad, either.
response: Do you mind? We’re having a moment here.

speaker: I don’t know what’s scarier, the bathroom clowns or the woman that put them there.

speaker: Hey. Howie says you’ve been making fun of him all day. Now, both of you apologize right now.
response: She’s so tiny. It’s funny when she’s mad.

response: Perhaps you’re right. I’m sorry for my behaviour. I’ve had alcohol, and it’s caused me to be inappropriate.

speaker: Thank you.
response: Ain’t she great?

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Now, how’s about you get us a couple of beers?

response: This is a Jewish house. I don’t think they have pigskin.

speaker: Well, I’m drunk.
response: I just vomited on a lot of clowns.

speaker: Oh, I always tear up when the Grinch’s heart grows three sizes.
response: Tears seem appropriate. Enlargement of the heart muscle, or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, is a serious disease which could lead to congestive heart failure.

speaker: You really didn’t like it, Sheldon?
response: No, on the contrary. I found the Grinch to be a relatable, engaging character, and I was really with him right up to the point that he succumbed to social convention and returned the presents and saved Christmas. What a buzz k*ll that was.

speaker: When we watch Frosty the Snowman, he roots for the sun.
response: Excuse me, but the sun is essential for all life on Earth. Frosty is merely a bit of frozen supernatural ephemera in a stolen hat. A crime, by the way, for which he is never brought to account.

speaker: Sheldon, what about you? Did you have a Christmas tree?
response: Oh, yes. We had a tree, we had a manger, we had an inflatable Santa Claus with plastic reindeer on the front lawn. And to make things even more jolly, there were so many blinking lights on the house they induced neighbourhood-wide seizures.

speaker: So I take it you don’t want to help us trim the tree.

speaker: What is it?

speaker: Here we go.
response: December 25, 1642, Julian calendar, Sir Isaac Newton is born. Jesus, on the other hand, was actually born in the summer. His birthday was moved to coincide with a traditional pagan holiday that celebrated the winter solstice with lit fires and slaughtered goats. Which, frankly, sounds like more fun than 12 hours of church with my mother followed by a fruitcake.

speaker: Merry Newton-mas, everyone.
response: I sense that’s not sincere, although I have no idea why.

speaker: No, it’s fine. Look, Sir Isaac can go right next to this little candy cane.

speaker: No, he doesn’t.
response: I understand. You dispute Newton’s claim that he invented calculus and you want to put Gottfried Leibniz on the top.

speaker: Yeah, you got me. I’m a Leibniz man.

speaker: Well, I just, I thought…
response: If I can interject here, obviously Leonard is concerned that his mother won’t approve of you as his mate.

speaker: You are, it’s just…
response: If I can interject again. Leonard comes from a remarkably high-achieving family, who have all chosen high-achieving partners. He probably feels that it’s doubtful that his mother will be overly impressed with his dating a woman whose most significant achievement is memorizing the Cheesecake Factory menu.

response: Leonard, I’m no expert on meditation, but if you’re trying to calm yourself down, I believe the word is Om.

response: No trouble at all.

speaker: Yes, dear. Mommy’s proud. I’ve been meaning to thank you for your notes on my paper disproving quantum brain dynamic theory.

response: August 16th. Right after her carpal tunnel surgery.

response: You did.

speaker: I don’t really like flowers.
response: Neither do I, but it’s the social convention.

response: It’s what we think caused your narcissistic personality disorder. We discussed it at length during our last video chat. Although how we got onto the subject of you is baffling.

response: My bad. I did send a gift from both of us.

response: Well, I’m not sure about interesting, but…

speaker: It’s all right, Sheldon. I will just pretend that Leonard’s not withholding information. Although, I will point out, Leonard, that I am a trained psychiatrist and you are exhibiting the same secretive behavioural tics that accompanied your learning to masturbate.

speaker: Mmm, well, let’s see. Sheldon, when did I leave Leonard’s father?
response: September 22nd.

speaker: Mitzy’s dead?
response: She was old and blind, Leonard. What choice did we have?

speaker: What is it?
response: I made tea.

speaker: I don’t want tea.
response: I didn’t make tea for you. This is my tea.

speaker: Then why are you telling me?
response: It’s a conversation starter.

speaker: That’s a lousy conversation starter.
response: Oh, is it? We’re conversing. Checkmate.

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: What I want is to be departing the Starship Enterprise in a one-man shuttle craft headed to the planetoid I rule known as Sheldon Alpha Five.

speaker: I want that too. Why are you here?
response: To comfort you, of course. No, that’s not going to work at all, I’ll comfort you from over here. Leonard, what you’re experiencing is a classic Jungian crisis in which the aging individual mourns the loss of the never-to-be realized ideal family unit.

speaker: Thank you, that’s very comforting.
response: That’s not the comforting part.

speaker: It’s not?
response: No, no. The comforting part is that the Germans have a term for what you’re feeling. Weltschmerz. It means the depression that arises from comparing the world as it is to a hypothetical, idealized world.

speaker: You’re right, I do feel better.
response: Well, the Germans have always been a comforting people. Just remember, Leonard, where your biological family has failed you, you always have me, your surrogate family.

speaker: You’re my surrogate family?
response: If it’s any consolation, I’m not happy about it either. Good night.

speaker: That’s the Del Taco.
response: Why is Leonard softly banging his head against his bedroom door?

speaker: Thank you for taking me to the airport.
response: You’re very welcome.

speaker: Please, I am very hungover and in no mood to satisfy your need for approval. Sheldon, I do hope you’ll forgive me for my inappropriate behaviour last night.
response: I don’t blame you. You were intoxicated.

speaker: Thank you.
response: I blame Penny.

speaker: I think it’s best that you not know.
response: Agreed.

speaker: Oh, uh, Priya’s calling in a few minutes on Skype, and we are gonna have a dinner date.
response: It’s eight o’clock in the morning in Mumbai. How can she have dinner?

speaker: Fine, whatever. Priya will be having breakfast.
response: All right, so technically it’s not a dinner date. I suppose you could call it a, uh, dinfast date. But if you did, you’d open yourself to peer-based mocking, such as, Hey, Leonard, how was your dinfast with Priya last night?

speaker: That doesn’t sound like mocking.
response: You didn’t let me finish. Dinfast (rolls eyes). Are those soy-based candles?

speaker: I don’t know. Why?
response: Paraffin candles may contain carcinogens. Unless lung cancer is the ambiance you were going for at your dinfast. Dinfast (rolls eyes).

speaker: Listen, I don’t want to be rude, but Priya’s gonna be calling any minute, so…
response: Oh, yes, Priya. Leonard, you know I make a point of never interfering in your personal affairs.

speaker: Yes, I’ve always admired that about you.
response: As well you should. But I’m going to make an exception here.

speaker: Oh, good.
response: Priya has moved back to India to pursue her law career. Instead of desperately trying to keep this intercontinental relationship alive, you could use that time to take up a hobby.

speaker: A hobby?
response: Yes. I read recently about a fellow in Kansas with an enormous ball of twine. I bet you could give him a run for his money.

speaker: You know, some people might say that it’s great that we’re trying to make things work long distance. They’d say things like, love is stronger than the miles between you.
response: When I rise to power, those people will be sterilized.

speaker: You video-chat with Amy all the time. How is this different?
response: Don’t you like Amy?

speaker: Of course I like Amy.
response: Well, there’s the difference. (Skype tone rings)

speaker: Oh, I miss you, too.
response: I miss the old days when your romantic partners could be returned to the video store.

speaker: Oh, it’s no problem. It’s actually kind of nice. You reading, me reading. We’re like an old married couple.
response: If we were an old married couple, the wife would serve iced tea and snickerdoodles.

speaker: I don’t have iced tea and snickerdoodles.
response: A good wife would go to the store.

speaker: I want a divorce.
response: Good. On the way to see the lawyer, pick up some tea and cookies. I must say, I am enjoying your new chair.

speaker: It’s great, isn’t it?
response: It is. Aligns the lumbar, cradles the coccyx, balances the buttocks. This is a chair worthy of the name.

speaker: What name?
response: Chair.

speaker: Oh, all right, well, I’m glad you like it. I mean, I still can’t get over the fact someone just threw it away.
response: What?

speaker: Yeah, it was just sitting on the street. I paid a homeless guy ten bucks to help me get it up here.
response: Oh, dear. Oh, dear. Oh, dear. (Starts stripping off clothing)

speaker: What is wrong?
response: I’ve been sitting in garbage!

speaker: Sheldon, take it easy.
response: You take it easy! I need to use your shower.

speaker: I went into this marriage with so much hope.
response: There’s a wet Band-Aid on the shower floor. (Runs out of apartment).

speaker: Oh, come on, tell me I’m wrong.
response: Oh, Leonard, good. There you are. I need you to check my head for chair lice.

speaker: I don’t want to talk about it. You didn’t catch bugs from Penny’s chair.
response: Yes, I did. And now they’re cavorting at the base of my hair follicles like dancing hippies at the Redwood National Forest.

speaker: Sheldon, you do this all the time. You fixate on some crazy idea and then blow it way out of proportion.
response: Name one time I’ve ever done that.

speaker: How about when you put GPS trackers in your garbage because you were convinced North Korean spies were stealing your doodles? The chicken nuggets you were sure were human nuggets. The strangely-shaped cloud that was following you around town. The time you put on my shirt by mistake and were convinced you’d started growing again.
response: I said, name one. You really need to work on your listening k*ll.

speaker: Yello.
response: You need to remove that chair from the building. It’s a health hazard.

speaker: Okay, relax. I took off the slipcovers, had them dry-cleaned and then fumigated the cushions.
response: Really?

speaker: Yeah. It’s cleaner than my couch. Found half a Hot Pocket in there.
response: It certainly looks okay. Has a strong toxic chemical smell. That’s reassuring.

speaker: Why don’t you give it a try, Sheldon?
response: All right. It is a comfortable chair.

speaker: Why don’t you just admit you overreacted?
response: No, thank you. (Sees insect. More appear and swarm all over him. He jumps out of a daydream on his own couch. Jumps up and runs out to Penny’s apartment.

speaker: It’s like living with a Chihuahua.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: What’s up, buttercup?
response: You have to get rid of the chair.

speaker: Nope. (Closes door)
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: What’s the word, hummingbird?
response: For your safety, please wait in my apartment as I call the authorities so they may remove the chair of death.

speaker: No. (Closes door)
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: What’s the gist, physicist?
response: Under my authority as a self-appointed member of the Centres for Disease Control street team, these premises are condemned. (Penny tries to close door) As a man with a keen sense of style, I must tell you, that chair does not work with the room. (Penny closes door). (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Penny opens door and waves seat cushion at him. He screams and runs off. She closes door. He sneaks back) (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: Yeah. Sure, sure.
response: If your video’s frozen, try resetting the TCP/IP stack.

speaker: Oh! I didn’t even think of that. Thanks.
response: You’re welcome. Please let me know when you and your girlfriend are done hogging the bandwidth for your self-abuse. I’m trying to stream a movie on Netflix in here.

speaker: Five, six, seven, eight. Tall and tan and young and lovely, the girl from Ipanema goes walking, and when she passes, each one she passes goes…
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy.

speaker: Oh… You are aware that your ritualistic knocking behaviour is symptomatic of obsessive compulsive disorder?
response: Is not. Is not, is not.

speaker: Denial. Denial, denial. Come in.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Would you like to hear me play a bossa nova standard on the harp?
response: No.

speaker: How about the theme song to the classic television show Diff’rent Strokes? Now the world don’t move to the b*at…
response: No.

speaker: Well, that’s every song I know. What’s up?
response: You’re good friends with Penny, right?

speaker: Best friends, besties, BFFs, peas in a pod, sisters who would share travelling pants. Go on.
response: I was hoping she might listen to you about the dangers of owning unhygienic furniture.

speaker: For general educational purposes, or has she acquired a bar stool dipped in cholera?
response: Cholera is water-borne. You’re mocking me.

speaker: Yes, I am.
response: Penny has dragged a chair in off the street whose unknown provenance jeopardizes the health and welfare of every resident in our building.

speaker: Sheldon, just because you have a focus on cleanliness bordering on the psychotic doesn’t mean I have to participate.
response: All right, name your price.

speaker: Kiss me where I’ve never been kissed before.
response: You mean like Salt Lake City?

speaker: Never mind. I’ll talk to Penny.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Will you listen to me play my harp now?
response: No. I dislike the sound of the harp. Its overuse in classic television sitcoms always makes me think I’m going to experience an episode from my past. (Amy plays glissando) I’m sorry, Mommy. Don’t be mad at me. Don’t do that!

speaker: Well, that should do it.
response: Thank you for coming by. (He rises from his desk. Everyone rushes to look nonchalant.) Hello.

speaker: Oh, hey buddy.
response: Buddy.

speaker: Sorry I’m late, I’m working on a project that may take me up on the next space shuttle.
response: How can you be late, I wasn’t expecting you at all.

speaker: Sheldon, are you going to introduce us?
response: Oh, alright, this is Missy, Missy this is Leonard and Rajesh and you’ve already met Howard.

speaker: Excuse me?
response: She’s my twin sister, she thinks she’s funny but frankly I’ve never been able to see it.

speaker: It’s because you have no measurable sense of humour, Shelly.
response: How exactly would one measure a sense of humour? A humourmometer?

speaker: Okay, so let me see if I got this. Leonard, Howard and… I’m sorry what was your name again. (Raj looks uncomfortable, turns and walks away, disappears round corner. He then reappears, takes the orange paper from the noticeboard and leaves again.)
response: Rajesh.

speaker: And I had to drop off some papers for Shelly to sign for my dad’s estate.
response: The papers could have been mailed, Mom just sent you here to spy on me, didn’t she.

speaker: I guess that’s why they call you a genius.
response: They call me a genius because I’m a genius. Tell Mom that I currently weigh 165 pounds, and that I’m having regular bowel movements. Enjoy the wedding, goodbye.

speaker: Oh, I don’t think so. Shelly doesn’t like company. Even as a little boy he’d send his imaginary friends home at the end of the day.
response: They were not friends, they were imaginary colleagues.

speaker: Look, you’re here, we have plenty of room.
response: No we don’t.

speaker: Come on, Shelly, she’s family.
response: So what? I don’t issue invitations to your mother.

speaker: Well it would be nice not to have to drive out to Anaheim in rush hour.
response: And don’t ever call me Shelly.

speaker: I’ll walk you to your car. You’re in structure 3 level C, right?
response: What just happened?

speaker: Hee-hee, just classic.
response: I needed a place to fire ceramic semi-conductor substrates for home-made integrated circuits.

speaker: He was trying to build some kind of armed robot to keep me out of his room.
response: Made necessary by her insistence on going into my room.

speaker: Yep. I had to go through the entire second grade with crooked eyebrows my Mom drew on.
response: Is that what that was? I just assumed that the second grade curriculum had rendered you quizzical.

speaker: Can I get a hallelujah.
response: Fraternal twins come from two separate eggs, they are no more alike than any other siblings.

speaker: Sheldon, why are you ignoring your sister?
response: I’m not ignoring my sister. I’m ignoring all of you.

speaker: Hell, no!
response: Excuse me, can I interject something. I’m ordering pizza online, is everyone okay with pepperoni?

speaker: Sheldon, can I talk to you in private?
response: I guess. Don’t worry, I was going to order you cheeseless.

speaker: Thank you.
response: That’s okay. Lactose intolerance is nothing to be embarrassed about.

speaker: Sheldon, are you aware that your sister is an incredibly attractive woman?
response: Hmmm? She certainly has the symmetry and low body fat that western culture deems desirable. It’s noteworth that at other points in history, heavier women were the standard for beauty because their girth suggested affluence.

speaker: That’s fascinating, but I…
response: I didn’t say it was fascinating, I said it was noteworthy.

speaker: Alright, noted. But my point is that Koothrappali and Wolowitz… they’re hitting on your sister.
response: Oh. Okay. You know, I don’t want to criticise your rhetorical style but, we’d be a lot further along in this conversation if you’d g*n with that thought.

speaker: That’s great, but I….
response: What I’m saying is that we took quite an unnecessary detour from what I now understand to be your thesis.

speaker: Whatever. You have to do something about it.
response: Why?

speaker: Because she’s your sister.
response: I don’t understand. Yes, we shared a uterus for nine months, but since then we’ve pretty much gone our own separate ways.

speaker: Okay, uh…. oh, consider this. With your father gone, it is your responsibility to make sure that Missy chooses a suitable mate.
response: I hadn’t considered that. We do share DNA.

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: So there is the possibility, however remote, that resting in her loins is the potential for another individual as remarkable as myself.

speaker: Exactly. And, you owe it to yourself and to posterity to protect the genetic integrity of your sister’s future offspring.
response: You’re right. If someone wants to get at Missy’s fallopian tubes, they’ll have to go through me.

speaker: I’m warning you, I was judo champion at math camp.
response: Alright, that’s enough juvenile squabbling, stop it, stop it I say. I’m going to settle this right now. Neither of you are good enough for my sister.

speaker: He’s the man of his family, you have to respect his wishes.
response: You’re out too, by the way.

speaker: Say what?
response: It’s nothing personal, I’d just prefer if my future niece or nephew didn’t become flatulent every time they eat an Eskimo pie.

speaker: I’m not happy, it’s the medication, I can’t stop smiling. (Waves hand at mouth. It keeps waving.)
response: Now that Leonard’s made me aware of how high the genetic stakes are, we have to face the fact that none of you are suitable mates for my sister.

speaker: Excuse me, but I think you’re missing a big opportunity here.
response: How so?

speaker: Everybody knows genetic diversity produces the strongest offspring. Why not put a little mocha in the family latte.
response: In principle you have a point, but as a practical matter, need I remind you that it takes experimental pharmaceuticals to simply enable you to speak to the opposite sex.

speaker: Is it ‘cause I’m Jewish, ‘cause I’d k*ll my Rabbi with a porkchop to be with your sister.
response: This has nothing to do with religion. This has to do with the fact that you’re a tiny, tiny man who still lives with his mother.

speaker: Sheldon, you are really being unreasonable.
response: Am I? Here. Eat this cheese without farting and you can sleep with my sister.

speaker: Oh really?
response: Oops.

speaker: Shelly, can I speak to you for a minute? Alone?
response: Why does everyone suddenly want to talk to me alone? Usually nobody wants to be alone with me.

speaker: Okay. I’m not even going to ask why you’re pimping me out for cheese. But since when do you care at all about who I sleep with?
response: Truthfully, I’ve never given it any thought, but it has been pointed out to me that you carry DNA of great potential.

speaker: What on earth are you talking about?
response: Let me explain. You see, I’m a superior genetic mutation, an improvement on the existing mediocre stock.

speaker: And what do you mean, mediocre stock?
response: That would be you. But residing within you is the potential for another me. Perhaps even taller, smarter and less prone to freckling, a Sheldon 2.0 if you will.

speaker: Sheldon 2.0?
response: Exactly. Now, I am not saying that I should be the sole decider of who you mate with. If you’re not attracted to the suitor then the likelihood of conception would be reduced.

speaker: You have got to be kidding me!
response: Not at all. Frequent coitus dramatically increases the odds of fertiliziation.

speaker: Okay Shelly, sit down. Now I’ve lived my whole life dealing with the fact that my twin brother is, as Mom puts it, one of God’s special little people.
response: I always thought I was more like a cuckoo bird. You know, a superior creature whose egg is placed in the nest of ordinary birds. Of course the newly hatched cuckoo eats all the food, leaving the ordinary siblings to starve to death. Luckily for you, that’s where the metaphor ended.

speaker: I thought it ended at cuckoo. Now you listen to me, if you want to start acting like a brother who cares about me, then terrific. Bring it on. But you try one time to tell me who I should be sleeping with, and you and I are going to go round and round the way we did when we were little. Remember? (Sheldon hurriedly crosses his legs.)
response: I have an alternate proposal.

speaker: Go on.
response: You donate eggs. We will place them in cryogenic storage. I will find an appropriate sperm donor for your eggs, have them fertilized and implanted in you, that way everybody wins.

speaker: Stay down, bitch. Yeah, ha ha, natural selection at work.
response: I weep for humanity.

speaker: Any news you want me to pass along to Mom?
response: Well, she might be interested to know that I have refocused my research from bosonic string theory to heteronic string theory.

speaker: Yeah, I’ll just tell her you said hey.
response: Okay, well, it was pleasant seeing you, other than that business with my testicles. (Holds out hand to shake.)

speaker: Come on, Shelly. (Hugs him. He looks uncomfortable, then hugs back half heartedly.) I want you to know I’m very proud of you.
response: Really?

speaker: Yup, I’m always bragging to my friends about my brother the rocket scientist.
response: You tell people I’m a rocket scientist?

speaker: Well yeah.
response: I’m a theoretical physicist.

speaker: What’s the difference?
response: What’s the difference?

speaker: Goodbye Shelly.
response: My God! Why don’t you just tell them I’m a toll taker at the Golden Gate Bridge? Rocket scientist, how humiliating.

speaker: So, if any of you are considering going into experimental physics, my door is always open. Once again, I’m sorry that the demonstration didn’t quite work out, but now we know what happens when you accidentally spill peach Snapple into a helium neon laser. Short answer is… don’t. And now to tell you about the theoretical physics department is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Dr. Cooper?
response: Forget it.

speaker: Excuse me. Sheldon, we both agreed to do this.
response: It’s a waste of time. I might as well explain the laws of thermodynamics to a bunch of labradoodles.

speaker: If you don’t do this, I won’t take you to the comic book store.
response: Hello. Nice work with the laser, by the way. Looking out at your fresh young faces, I remember when I too was deciding my academic future as a lowly graduate student. Of course, I was 14, and I’d already achieved more than most of you could ever hope to, despite my 9 o’clock bedtime. Now, there may be one or two of you in this room who has what it takes to succeed in theoretical physics, although, it’s more likely that you’ll spend your scientific careers teaching fifth graders how to make paper mache volcanoes with baking soda lava.

speaker: Oh, good God.
response: In short, anyone who told you that you would someday be able to make any significant contribution to physics played a cruel trick on you, a cruel trick indeed. Any questions? Of course not. I weep for the future of science. Now if you’ll excuse me, the latest issue of Batman is out. Come, Leonard.

speaker: So, dumbass, I heard you made a grad student throw up last night.
response: The truth can indeed be a finger down the throat of those unprepared to hear it. But why should I cater to second-rate minds?

speaker: Because first-rate minds call you “dumbass”?
response: Oh, yeah? Well… you’re a mean person.

speaker: Excuse me, Dr. Cooper, I’m Ramona Nowitzki, I was at your talk last night. I think you’re just brilliant.
response: That is the prevailing opinion.

speaker: Ew. Dr. Cooper, I’ve read everything you’ve published. I especially liked your paper on grand unification using string-network condensates and was wondering how you determined that three-dimensional string-nets provided a unified picture of fermions and gauge bosons?
response: Amazing, an intelligent labradoodle.

speaker: Woof.
response: The fact is I’m quite close to a breakthrough in showing how neutrinos emerge from a string-net condensate.

speaker: Oh, my God, that would change the way we view the entire physical universe.
response: It’s what I do.

speaker: Again, ew. You know, I’d love to hear more about how you intend to add neutrinos. Could we get a cup of coffee sometime?
response: I don’t drink coffee.

speaker: Well, it doesn’t have to be coffee. How about dinner?
response: I do eat dinner.

speaker: Great. I know a terrific little Italian place.
response: I never eat in strange restaurants. One runs the risk of non-standard cutlery.

speaker: Sheldon lives in fear of the three-tined fork.
response: Three tines is not a fork, three tines is a trident. Forks are for eating, tridents are for ruling the seven seas.

speaker: What if I brought food to your place?
response: That would be acceptable. On Mondays, I eat Thai food. Mee krob and chicken sate with extra peanut sauce from Siam Palace.

speaker: You got it. I already have your address.
response: What a nice girl.

speaker: Sheldon, do you have any idea what just happened?
response: Yes. Apparently I’m getting a free dinner.

speaker: Uh-huh. The viewing area’s right over there. Sheldon, your girl… date… person… Ramona’s here.
response: Oh, hello.

speaker: Oh, sorry I’m late. I just got so caught up reading the draft of your latest paper.
response: Did you enjoy the humorous footnote where I illustrate mirror-symmetry by likening it to the Flash playing tennis with himself?

speaker: So funny. But the idea that you might be able to incorporate gravity, I have to tell you, I found it physically exhilarating.
response: My hypotheses tend to have that effect.

speaker: Hey, aren’t you having breakfast?
response: Yes.

speaker: Are you experimenting with nutritional suppositories again?
response: Not in these pants.

speaker: So, how’d it go with Ramona last night?
response: Oh, great. She’s smart, insightful and she has a very unique way of, you know, revering me.

speaker: Here’s your spinach mushroom omelette .
response: Thank you. Did anyone touch it?

speaker: Gloves were worn by everyone involved. I was vigilant.
response: Ramona pointed out that I’ve been wasting 20 minutes a day standing on cafeteria lines.

speaker: Time which would be better spent tackling the great physics problems of our day.
response: You don’t tackle the big issues, Ramona. You fence with them. En garde. Riposte.

speaker: There won’t be any room until they get rid of the permanent Leslie Winkle exhibit.
response: Oh, good one.

speaker: So have you worked out the neutrino issue?
response: Well, to paraphrase Mozart, all the subatomic particles are there, I just have to put them in the right order.

speaker: You’re so witty.
response: Aren’t I?

speaker: Dr. Cooper is working.
response: Yes, I’m close to a breakthrough. Ooh, it tickles

speaker: Yeah, I can see that. Sheldon, Halo night, Koothrappali’s. You coming?
response: Oh, yes, it’s Halo night. Let me just dry my tootsies.

speaker: You’re not going to Halo night.
response: Yes, I am. It’s Wednesday. Wednesday’s Halo night.

speaker: Didn’t a great man once say, “Science demands nothing less than the fervent and
response: He did.

speaker: And who was that great man?
response: Me. Sorry, Leonard.

speaker: Seriously? You’re not coming?
response: You heard her. How can I argue with me?

speaker: Dr. Cooper, I have to tell you, your friends are holding you back.
response: I prefer to think of it as I’m pulling them forward.

speaker: Halo night? A man with your intellectual gifts doesn’t waste an evening playing video games.
response: He does on Wednesdays.

speaker: Not if he wants a Nobel Prize.
response: He does want that. Does a man with my intellectual gifts play paintball on weekends?

speaker: What do you think?
response: Drat.

speaker: Now shall we get back to work?
response: I suppose. Battlestar Galactica comes on tonight. (Pause) I guess I can wait for the DVD. (Pause) And then never ever watch it.

speaker: Sheldon, honey, I’ve told you, it’s a small apartment, you only have to knock one time.
response: Please, please, I don’t have a lot of time. Look, Ramona finally dozed off, and I need you to help me get rid of her.

speaker: Get rid of her how?
response: I don’t know, but apparently I’m in some kind of relationship, and you seem to be an expert at ending them.

speaker: Excuse me?
response: I see man after man leaving this apartment never to return.

speaker: Dr. Cooper?!
response: Hide me.

speaker: Hide you?
response: I formally request sanctuary.

speaker: Why aren’t you working?
response: Um… she distracted me. I told you, Penny, I don’t have time for your nonsense, I have important things to do.

speaker: Sheldon? (Pause, then more tapping) What are you doing?!
response: It’s Morse code.

speaker: Why?
response: So we can communicate through the wall.

speaker: We are communicating through the wall.
response: Yes, but the communication is not encrypted.

speaker: I don’t know Morse code.
response: It’s very simple. This is A (knock knock) this is B (knock knock-knock-knock) this is C…

speaker: Sheldon, I’m not going to learn Morse code at three o’clock in the morning!
response: All right.

speaker: Don’t come in here, don’t come in here, don’t come in here, don’t (Sheldon enters) Aw! What’s going on?
response: Shh! Ramona’s sleeping on the couch.

speaker: I know. When is she going home?
response: Never, that’s the problem. I need your help.

speaker: What are you talking about?
response: I’m invoking the Skynet clause of our friendship agreement.

speaker: That only applies if you need me to help you destroy an artificial intelligence you created that’s taking over the Earth.
response: Come on! Don’t nitpick!

speaker: Good night.
response: Shh. All right, I’m invoking our bodysnatchers clause.

speaker: The bodysnatchers clause requires me to help you destroy someone we know who’s been replaced with an alien pod.
response: Yes. She’s in the living room. Go, I’ll wait here.

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing out of bed?
response: Now! Do it!

speaker: You know you need your sleep in order for your cognitive processing to perform at optimum levels. Now come on.
response: Godzilla clause?

speaker: Not unless she destroys Tokyo.
response: Rats.

speaker: It’s unbelievable! It’s paradigm-altering!
response: And I could not have done it without you.

speaker: Oh, please, I just offered a little encouragement.
response: It was a lot more than that. You helped me work out the masses of all the fermions, and you pumiced my hammer toe. How can I ever repay you?

speaker: Well, would you consider naming it the Cooper-Nowitzki Theorem?
response: Who’s Nowitzki?

speaker: I’m Nowitzki.
response: Oh, you want me to share credit?

speaker: Uh-huh.
response: Get out!

speaker: Excuse me, Dr. Cooper, I’m Kathy O’Brien. I just finished reading your paper reconciling the black hole information paradox with your theory of string-network condensates, and it just took my breath away.
response: Maybe when I publish it, I’ll include an inhaler.

speaker: Would you possibly have any time for me to pick your brain?
response: Let’s see, today’s Thursday. Thursday nights, I eat pizza from Giacomo’s. Sausage, mushrooms, light olives.

speaker: Great. I’ll bring it to your place. I have the address.
response: What a nice girl.

speaker: Sheldon, do you see what just happened here?
response: Yes, I’m getting a free pizza. I’m on a roll.

speaker: You might want to slow down a bit, buddy.
response: Just one more bite.

speaker: Sheldon? Sheldon, are you okay?
response: I’m just so… full.

speaker: And it only took 28 minutes.
response: Impressive, but we must be cautious.

speaker: Why?
response: Today, it’s a Chinese food retrieval robot. Tomorrow, it travels back in time and tries to k*ll Sarah Connor.

speaker: I don’t think that’s going to happen, Sheldon.
response: No one ever does. That’s why it happens.

speaker: Just wait.
response: You realize, Penny, that the technology that went into this arm will one day make k*ll food servers such as yourself obsolete.

speaker: Really? They’re going to make a robot that spits on your hamburger?
response: I thought you broke up with her. Why is she here?

speaker: Oh ha-ha, oh. That’s amazing.
response: I wouldn’t say amazing. At best, it’s a modest leap forward from the basic technology that gave us Country Bear Jamboree.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon?
response: Yes? (Howard types. The hand puts up two fingers to Sheldon.) Peace?

speaker: Borrowed. The trick is to carry it out to your car like you own it.
response: Excuse me. Oh. Amy’s at the dry cleaners, and she’s made a very amusing pun. “I don’t care for perchloroethylene, and I don’t like glycol ether.” Get it? She doesn’t like glycol ether. Sounds like either. (Taps in reply) L-O-L.

speaker: Sheldon has a girlfriend?
response: She’s not my girlfriend.

speaker: Four months.
response: She’s not my girlfriend.

speaker: Are you telling me, for the past four months I have been asking you what’s new and you never thought to go with Sheldon has a girlfriend?
response: She’s not my girlfriend.

speaker: Shamy. I am so digging the Shamy.
response: All right, everyone pay attention. Yes, I have a friend named Amy Farrah Fowler. Yes, she is female. Yes, we communicate on a daily basis, but no, she is not my girlfriend.

speaker: Okay, well, what do you communicate about?
response: Well, my work in physics, her work in neurobiology, and most recently, the possibility of our having a child together.

speaker: Wait a minute– a child? You never see this girl. You just e-mail and text and Twitter. Now you’re considering having a baby?
response: Amy pointed out that between the two of us, our genetic material has the potential of producing the first in a line of intellectually superior, benign overlords to guide humanity to a brighter tomorrow.

speaker: Okay, I have a question.
response: Yes, Penny.

speaker: You don’t even like people touching you. How are you going to have sex?
response: Why on Earth would we have sex?

speaker: Oh, honey, did your mom not have the talk with you? You know, when your private parts started growing?
response: I’m quite aware of the way humans usually reproduce, which is messy, unsanitary, and based on living next to you for three years, involves loud and unnecessary appeals to a deity.

speaker: Oh, God.
response: Yes, exactly. Consequently, if Amy and I choose to bring new life into this world, it will be accomplished clinically, with fertility experts in a lab with petri dishes. Which reminds me, you have broad hips and a certain corn-fed vigour. Is your womb available for rental?

speaker: Look, Sheldon, before you race off to the fertility clinic, you might want to think about, uh gee, I don’t know, maybe actually spending some time with her.
response: You mean dating?

speaker: Yeah.
response: I can’t date Amy.

speaker: Why not?
response: She’s not my girlfriend.

speaker: Okay, look, don’t think of it as dating a girlfriend. Think of it as, uh, getting to know the future mother of your child.
response: Oh. I hadn’t considered that. I suppose she will have to have access to our progeny. And you don’t think I can achieve the required intimacy via text messaging?

speaker: Probably not.
response: Huh. It would appear as if the phone companies have been lying to me.

speaker: You do realize I stand on the other side of the door waiting for you to finish knocking three times.
response: I know. I can see the shadow of your feet under the door.

speaker: Yeah, my point is it’s a waste of time.
response: If you’re looking for an example of a waste of time, I would refer you to the conversation we’re having right now.

speaker: What do you want?
response: I’ve decided to take your advice and have arranged to go on a date with Amy Farrah Fowler.

speaker: Oh, that’s great. Have fun.
response: Wait. You have to drive me.

speaker: What?
response: You know I don’t drive.

speaker: Well, go ask Leonard.
response: I did. He said, and I quote, ask Penny, it was her cockamamie idea.

speaker: Leonard said cockamamie?
response: Actually, I’m paraphrasing. Having been raised in a Christian household, I’m uncomfortable with the language he used. And to be honest, I’m not entirely comfortable with cockamamie.

speaker: Okay, fine. When’s the date?
response: Now.

speaker: Now?
response: Hurry. We’re going to be late.

speaker: Sheldon, did it ever occur to you that I might have other plans?
response: I’m sorry. Do you have other plans?

speaker: Well, no, not per se, but…
response: So this conversation is as pointless as your door-knocking soliloquy?

speaker: You’re welcome.
response: I wish you weren’t wearing flip-flops. It’s dangerous to drive in flip-flops.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Sorry. I just don’t want to be yet another flip-flop fatality.

speaker: Can I ask you a question?
response: Given your community college education, I encourage you to ask me as many as possible.

speaker: Yeah. Well, my question is, and I’m pretty sure I know the answer, is this your first date?
response: That depends. Does square-dancing with my sister at a Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown count as a date?

speaker: No.
response: Then, this is my first date.

speaker: Okay. Well, then, there’s a couple of things you should probably know.
response: I have a master’s degree and two doctorates. The things I should know, I do know.

speaker: My point is, I know more about dating than you, and if you were as smart as you think you are, you would listen to me.
response: If you know so much, how come I have a date tonight and you have nothing better to do than drive me to it?

speaker: But the light indicates…
response: Don’t bother. I’ve wasted many an hour tilting at that particular windmill.

speaker: Guys, how ’bout some music?
response: Oh, no, I wouldn’t care for that. Amy?

speaker: Okay. Uncomfortable silence it is. Hey, Sheldon, have you told Amy what it was like for you growing up in Texas?
response: No.

speaker: Well, why don’t you tell her?
response: All right. It was hell.

speaker: I myself grew up in Nebraska. Small town outside of Omaha. You know, nice place, mostly family farms, a few meth labs.
response: I’m sorry, how is this better than uncomfortable silence?

speaker: I don’t know. I was just trying something.
response: Muggles.

speaker: Hey, here’s another possible topic of conversation. This is a big night for Sheldon. Right, Sheldon?
response: Big night? The winter solstice is a big night. It’s over 14 hours in Southern California.

speaker: That’s an amusing factoid.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Is this true?
response: Apparently, a semi-incestuous Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown didn’t count.

speaker: Uh, yeah, I wouldn’t say many. A few. (Sheldon laugh’s strangely). What’s (imitates Sheldon’s laugh)
response: Your characterization of approximately 171 different men as a few.

speaker: What? Where did you get 171 men?
response: Simple extrapolation. In the three years that I’ve known you, you were single for two. During that time, I saw 17 different suitors. If we work backwards, correcting for observation bias and postulate an initial dating age of 15…

speaker: Whoa, wait, wait, wait. I did not start dating at 15.
response: I’m sorry. 16?
My mistake. Now, assuming the left side of a bell curve peaking around the present, that would bring the total up to 193 men. Plus or minus eight men.

speaker: No.
response: Although that number would be fairly easy to calculate.

speaker: Oh.
response: Based on the number of awkward encounters I’ve had with strange men leaving her apartment in the morning, plus the number of times she’s returned home wearing the same clothes she wore the night before…

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, I think you’ve made your point.
response: So we multiply 193, minus 21 men before the loss of virginity, so 172 times 0.18 gives us 30.96 sexual partners. Let’s round that up to 31.

speaker: No! No! No. Let’s just all finish our dinners, okay?
response: This is an interesting topic. How many sexual encounters have you had?

speaker: Does volunteering for a scientific experiment in which orgasm was achieved by electronically stimulating the pleasure centres of the brain count?
response: I should think so.

speaker: I did not have sex with 31 guys.
response: I’ll be happy to check the math, but numbers don’t lie, Penny. In any event, now that Amy and I have spent quality time together, I feel much more confident proceeding to the next stage of our relationship.

speaker: And that is?
response: Using in vitro fertilization and a surrogate uterus to gift humanity with our progeny.

speaker: You’re still on that?
response: In these uncertain times, doesn’t humanity deserve a gift?

speaker: Okay, you know what? I’m gonna come at this in a whole new way. Sheldon, if you try to make a baby with Amy in a petri dish, I’m gonna tell your mother on you.
response: That’s no threat. My mother’s always wanted a grandchild.

speaker: Really? Your deeply religious born-again Christian mother wants a test-tube grandbaby born out of wedlock?
response: Curses.

speaker: If I’d thought of that in the first place, I could’ve saved myself this whole night.
response: Well, it’s not that late. You could still go out and look for number 32. Good night.

speaker: Hey, Howard, what’s up?
response: I’ve decided not to procreate.

speaker: Sheldon, Sheldon.
response: Hmm. (Looks outside office door. Corridor lamp sparks and goes out. Corridor is bathed in an eerie glow) All right, all right. I see what’s going on. A little pre-Halloween hijinkery. A ghostly moan, a rattling of chains, a witch’s cackle. The trifecta of haunted house clichés. Instead of eek, I say yawn.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Oh, the walls are dripping blood, which looks nothing like a phenolphthalein indicator exposed to a sodium carbonate solution. (Reading message on wall) See you in hell Sheldon. The most frightening thing about that is the missing comma. (A luminous skeleton rushes towards him) Ah. Okay, all right. That one was clever. Skeleton with phosphorous on a zip line. Come on out, merry pranksters. Take a bow.

speaker: You should’ve seen your face.
response: Yes, there’s nothing quite like the slightly widened eyes of mildly startled.

speaker: Come on, admit it. We got you, Sheldon.
response: Please, fright depends on an element of surprise. The simple fact is, because I am much smarter than you, and able to anticipate your actions, it is highly unlikely that you two rubes could ever surprise me. (Leonard creeps out behind him wearing a Star Trek Balok mask)

speaker: We can’t b*at him. He’s just too smart.
response: Gentlemen. (Turns and sees Leonard. Screams and faints).

speaker: Oh. Watch out, Sheldon. This little boy Casper is a g-g-g-ghost!
response: Droll.

speaker: That was pretty droll. With a hint of ammonia.
response: Yes, enjoy your japes, gentlemen. You think you’ve poked fun at a milquetoast academic. Well, you’ve forgotten one thing. I am also a son of the Lone Star state. I’m Texas through and through. And we know how to settle scores down there. If you doubt me, ask Mexico.

speaker: How many times are you gonna tell me? What’s with you?
response: Nothing. It’s not suspicious that I’m fixating. It’s consistent with my personality.

speaker: Oh. Yeah. That’s gone. It’s a rough month when Halloween and PMS hit at the same time.
response: Leonard doesn’t have time to chat, he has to get the mail.

speaker: Will you relax? I’ll get it in a minute. Hey, how was work?
response: Open the mail!

speaker: Good morning, Sheldon.
response: It is, isn’t it? Oh, bother. Isn’t that just always the way? You go to staple something, and you’re out of staples. Gosh, I wish I’d known that earlier today when I was at Staples.

speaker: You have a thing of paper clips right there.
response: well, no, no, I need something more permanent to join these papers. Say, don’t you keep staples in your top desk drawer?

speaker: I don’t know. Maybe.
response: Be a lamb and check.

speaker: All right. (Opening drawer) Who do we have here?
response: It’s a snake. A terrifying snake.

speaker: Oh, did some bad man put us in a drawer?
response: Stop talking like that. You’ve been rendered speechless by fear.

speaker: Let’s go to the biology lab and find you some nice yummy mice.
response: I tried to scare an Indian with a snake. Come on, Cooper. You’re better than this.

speaker: What are you doing?
response: Science. You wouldn’t understand.

speaker: Hey, well, see you. I’m going out. (Starts to go out. Doesn’t.)
response: I thought you were leaving the apartment.

speaker: Yeah, me, too. I can’t make up my mind.
response: Are you concerned because the world is filled with big dogs and bullies?

speaker: No. I’m having a moral crisis.
response: Well, if it’s of any help, I’ve read all the great moral philosophers, including Dr. Seuss.

speaker: Oh, what the hell. I’m supposed to go see that girl from the comic book store, Alice, but I don’t know if I should, because I’m going out with Priya, but she’s in India.
response: All right. So the topic at hand is sexual fidelity. Probably won’t be relying on Seuss here. Although One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish might be surprisingly applicable. Go on.

speaker: Well, they say at the end of your life, you regret the stuff you didn’t do more than the stuff that you did, and I’m pretty sure Alice is the stuff I want to do.
response: You know, the German philosopher, Friedrich Nietzsche, believed that morality is just a fiction used by the herd of inferior human beings to hold back the few superior men.

speaker: That actually does help.
response: It’s worth noting that he died of syphilis.

speaker: Screw it, I’m going.
response: On your way home, will you pick up some orange juice?

speaker: Do you mind? I’m questioning a lot of things in my life right now.
response: Is one of those things your fondness for orange juice?

speaker: No.
response: Great. Tropicana, no pulp.

speaker: Who is it?
response: It’s me, Sheldon, Mrs. Wolowitz.

speaker: That’s not my mom, it’s Bernadette.
response: Really? That’s very unsettling.

speaker: Hi, Sheldon.
response: Hi.

speaker: What’s up?
response: It just occurred to me that I never formally congratulated you on your pending nuptials. So I hopped on the first bus and hightailed it down here to shake your hand. Put ‘er there, you old so-and-so.

speaker: Well, I, I’m gonna see you at work in 12 hours, don’t you think it could have waited until then?
response: Holy smoke, why didn’t I think of that? You’re a better man than I, Howard Wolowitz. You put ‘er there, you son of a g*n!

speaker: Oh, my God, Howard! What did you do?
response: It was a harmless Halloween prank. Look.

speaker: Howard has a heart condition! You know that!
response: Well, I thought he made that up. Isn’t hypochondria a common idiosyncrasy of Jewish people?

speaker: This is adrenaline, we’re gonna have to inject it into his heart.
response: We are?

speaker: You are. I’m not strong enough to get it through his chest plate, and we’ve only got one sh*t.
response: Oh, no! I can’t!

speaker: Hurry! We’re running out of time!
response: Okay.

speaker: Just do it!
response: Oh, God! One, two, three!

speaker: Trick or treat, bubbeleh.
response: What? No. You mean this was all a ruse? Oh, how could I be so stu… (puts hand to forehead. Electrocutes himself).

speaker: Oh yeah, it is, and you won. I, I, I’m, I’m sorry, I have to go. I don’t believe this.
response: Bazinga, punk. Now we’re even.

speaker: It's so nice both of your moms are coming in to see you guys get an award.
response: Well, my mother's been there for every honour I've won since I b*at out my twin sister for the did it on the potty trophy. How does this look?

speaker: Sure, his mom gets roses. When I want them, they're a bouquet of severed plant genitals.
response: You act like I didn't get you that mushroom log on Valentine's Day.

speaker: Uh, I don't know. They're pretty different.
response: Maybe they'll be best friends. One of them is brilliant, one is sweet and simple. Sound familiar?

speaker: Shelly, I'm so proud of you and Leonard for getting this award.
response: Oh, thank you, Mother.

speaker: I tried to read your paper, but it was very hard for me to understand.
response: Oh, it's quite straightforward, actually. It describes a new model of the universe that conceptualizes it as the surface of an n-dimensional superfluid.

speaker: Interesting. You can believe that, but God filling an ark with animals two-by-two is nonsense.
response: What did they feed the lions, Mother?

speaker: The floating bodies of drowned sinners, of course.
response: Listen, Leonard's mom is a renowned psychiatrist and woman of science. Can you please keep the Bible babble to yourself while she's here?

speaker: Are you ashamed of me?
response: Of course not. I love you. I'm just embarrassed by the things you believe, do and say.

speaker: Hey, look who's here.
response: Oh, Doctor Hofstadter, it's so good to see you again.

speaker: Likewise. I read your paper, it was very impressive.
response: Oh, thank you.

speaker: That's so sweet, you think I have self-esteem.
response: Doctor Hofstadter, I want you to meet my mother, Mary.

speaker: Oh, you mean this son. Uh, sure, he's terrific.
response: Beverly, would you like to see the math I worked out to support our hypothesis?

speaker: Calm down, dear. Mary, I'm curious. When did you first realize that your son had such a remarkable mind?
response: Ooh, good question. Everyone loves stories about Sheldon Cooper, boy genius.

speaker: Well, I would have to say when he was 13 and tried to build a nuclear reactor in the tool shed.
response: Ooh, this is a good one.

speaker: Now, the first thing you have to know about Shelly is ever since he was a little boy, he was always concerned with the well-being of others. And he didn't think that it was fair for people to pay for electricity, so he was gonna power the entire town for free.
response: (stammers) Tell her about the uranium. Tell her about the uranium.

speaker: Oh, well. Oh, this is adorable. When he arranged to get some yellowcake from Chad, I thought he was talking about Twinkies from one of his friends.
response: But I wasn't. 'Cause I didn't have any friends.

speaker: Oh, he was a handful.
response: I was a handful.

speaker: I do. And some of it's wool, so dry flat if possible.
response: Oh, and here's a picture of me receiving my bachelor of science degree.

speaker: You don't look very happy.
response: Well, I had just g*n puberty. It was figuratively and literally one of the hairiest moments of my life.

speaker: Shelly does not like change.
response: Oh, true. But all the clenching in the world will not keep testicles in your abdomen.

speaker: Sorry, I forgot.
response: You remember my mother.

speaker: Oh, lovely. Must have been very expensive.
response: Oh, no, not at all. No, we, uh, found a place online that, uh, repurposes diamond drill bits.

speaker: We did not. That's not true. Can I speak to you alone for a second?
response: Oh, sure.

speaker: It came from Tiffany's.
response: You mean the box, right?

speaker: Really doesn't matter to me how much he spent on the ring. I think.
response: Did I misspeak about the ring?

speaker: Yes, and we'll get back to that. But, uh, even with your mother here, you are deliberately hogging all the attention from my mom. You're like one of those elephant seal pups that steals the milk from two mothers.
response: Do you mean what marine biologists refer to as super weaning?

speaker: Yes, you are a super weaner.
response: Well, now I have to correct you. As a bit of an elephant seal buff, the more accurate comparison would be when two mother seals actively seek to nourish the same pup. So I believe the term you're looking for is a double mother suckler.

speaker: Yeah, you're right. That is the term I'm looking for. You are a dirty double mother suckler.
response: Okay, well, now that we have the terminology straightened out. How dare you.

speaker: Why don't we all stop hitting ourselves and talk about something safe, you know, like shoes or how cute little Chinese babies are.
response: It is not my fault that your mother likes me better than she likes you.

speaker: I'm terribly sorry that I upset your mother.
response: Oh, it's all right. She'll forgive you. She has to or she goes to hell.

speaker: I can't help but notice how her unconditional love for you is diametrically opposed to my own parenting strategies.
response: Well, you doled out affection as a reward for achievement, a proven way to raise a child. Or train a rat.

speaker: But look how well you turned out.
response: I'd feign modesty at this point, but who would believe me? Still, you need to consider how successful Leonard's brother and sister are.

speaker: I suppose.
response: While my brother and sister are mouth-breathing idiots.

speaker: Do you suppose you would've flourished more in a reward-based environment?
response: Perhaps. But my mom made me spaghetti with chopped-up hot dogs whenever I wanted, so who cares?

speaker: Leonard, I always made you earn my affection, but today I realize that there's more than one way to raise a child.
response: I taught her that.

speaker: And then they finish it off by staring into each other's eyes for four minutes.
response: Oh, that's nonsense. I proclaimed my love for you. And the last time I looked into your eyes was when you thought you had conjunctivitis.

speaker: Oh, careful. You're poking at the whole foundation of The Bachelor.
response: Yeah, but we don't have to debate this. We're scientists. We can conduct our own research. I propose that we imprison two street people and...

speaker: No.
response: You didn't even let me finish.

speaker: Forget it.
response: So, you can experiment on all the apes you want. But I want to manipulate the emotions of two captive human beings, suddenly I'm the monster.

speaker: Why don't you just do the test?
response: In the interest of science, I'd be willing to.

speaker: What? You're okay with an experiment where you have to answer awkward questions about your innermost feelings?
response: Yes.

speaker: That's what I said. Before I knew it, he pontificated his way right into my heart.
response: Uh, fun fact, pontificate comes from the Latin word pontifex, which means bridge builder or Pope.

speaker: In love yet?
response: Just out of curiosity, Penny, if this experiment does make us fall in love, would you drive me to Lake Geneva, Wisconsin for Gary Con? It's the only convention celebrating the life and work of Gary Gygax, the co-creator of Dungeons and Dragons.

speaker: You know what? I can honestly say if we fall in love, not only will I drive you there, I will buy you all the dragon T-shirts you want.
response: Okay, babe, let's do this.

speaker: The world's greatest mom is in the shoe compartment.
response: You ready to begin?

speaker: Yup. Be right there. I assume you don't want wine.
response: Correct. You're not supposed to drink alcohol when operating heavy machinery.

speaker: What heavy machinery? Let's just start.
response: Well, as a Texas gentleman, I'm inclined to say ladies first. Although, I'm concerned that level of politeness and charm might make you fall in love with me before the test even begins. Perhaps we should flip a coin. Or if you're familiar with the rules of Rock, Paper, Scissors...

speaker: Question one. "Given the choice of anyone in the world, whom would you want as a dinner guest?"
response: Hmm. Living or dead?

speaker: Just says "anyone in the world". I guess that means living.
response: Ah, that's just as well. As much as I'd love to meet Euclid, inventor of the geometric proof, he probably wore sandals and I cannot look at toes during dinner. Oh, I know, the person I'd most like to have dinner with is myself.

speaker: You sure that's your choice? 'Cause I've had that dinner.
response: Well, I haven't. And while they say never meet your heroes, I just don't see how I could disappoint. Who would you choose?

speaker: Robert Downey, Jr.
response: Oh, I didn't think of Iron Man. You know, maybe after myself and I have dinner, we can meet you two for dessert.

speaker: (short laugh) Oh, so kind of like what's happening with Penny right now.
response: "What would constitute a perfect day for you?"

speaker: Uh, well, I'd probably sleep in, do a little yoga, then lie on the beach while cute cabana boys brought me drinks and probably get a massage and then cap off the night with some dancing.
response: That's it?

speaker: Yeah, why?
response: You didn't mention Leonard.

speaker: He's there.
response: I don't think so. (stammers) Leonard can't stand yoga, the beach, massages or dancing.

speaker: Yeah, well, he brought a book, okay? What's yours?
response: Uh, I wake up. Uh, I enjoy some French toast with butter and syrup. Uh, then a wormhole opens, and whisks me millions of years into the future where my towering intellect is used to save the last remnants of mankind from a predatory alien race.
