speaker: Interesting, you didn't mention Amy.
response: Who do you think made the French toast with butter and syrup?

speaker: I'm sorry. W, would 500 frequent-flyer miles help? That could get you to Sacramento.
response: "If you could wake up tomorrow having gained any one quality or ability, what would it be?"

speaker: Well, not to steal from the Bible, but turning water into wine sounds pretty good.
response: I don't think you're taking this seriously.

speaker: Come on, I'm just having some fun with you.
response: I believe what you're doing is using humour to avoid vulnerability.

speaker: Fine. Honestly, if I could have one quality, I wish I could be as smart as you guys.
response: Ha. Keep dreaming.

speaker: Well, I can't read people's minds. Actually, that's not true, I can read men's minds, but only 'cause it's usually the one thing.
response: When are we going to get robot eyes?

speaker: You're all alike.
response: Well, what I meant was I often misinterpret how others are feeling. Like, I can't always tell if someone is only joking or laughing at me. You know, like, uh, if they're mad at something I've done or just in a bad mood. It, it's incredibly stressful.

speaker: Really? You always seem so confident.
response: Well, I'm not. And if I could read people's minds, life would be so much simpler.

speaker: Well, now I wish I had the ability to make that stuff easier for you.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Wow, I just felt this wave of affection for you.
response: You sure it's not too much Bible juice?

speaker: "If you were to die this evening with no opportunity to communicate with anyone, what would you most regret not having told someone?"
response: So, it would be today? Huh. Well, I suppose there's something satisfying about dying on my birthday.

speaker: Today's your birthday?
response: Yes.

speaker: Well, that's always been a secret. Not even Amy knows.
response: Well, I don't enjoy presents. And the thought of people jumping out and yelling "surprise" fills me with more dread than the words "George Lucas Director's Cut."

speaker: So, why did you finally tell me?
response: The point of the experiment is to be completely honest with each other.

speaker: Well, thank you for sharing it with me. I won't tell anyone.
response: Thank you.

speaker: That is so funny. I never would have pegged you for a Pisces.
response: You're making it difficult to love you right now.

speaker: Oh, no. That thing's gonna end up in my bedroom.
response: That's it. We're done with the questions.

speaker: All that's left to do is stare into each other's eyes for four minutes without talking.
response: Okay. Wait, hang on. Bladder check. We're good to go.

speaker: You ready?
response: Yes.

speaker: And begin. This is kind of creepy.
response: We're not supposed to talk during this part.

speaker: Sorry.
response: This is kind of creepy.

speaker: Do you want to stop? I know you have trouble with eye contact.
response: Well, you have a brown fleck in your right iris that looks like a Formula One race car. So I'm just concentrating on that. Plus, it's easier around people that I'm comfortable with.

speaker: Aw, sweetie, I'm comfortable around you, too.
response: Of course you are, I'm warm and soothing. I'm like a human bowl of tomato soup.

speaker: I meant more like a little brother.
response: Oh. Well, I suppose I do think of you as a sister. And sometimes, a mother.

speaker: It's getting creepy again.
response: What?

speaker: Just thinking about the day I met you and Leonard.
response: It was a Monday afternoon. You joined us for Indian food.

speaker: Can you believe it's been eight years?
response: Yeah, and you're still eating our food.

speaker: I can't remember a time you guys weren't in my life.
response: I remember it perfectly. But I have an eidetic memory. If you're interested, I also remember how much you owe us for the food.

speaker: That's it. That wasn't so bad.
response: No, it wasn't. Uh, now let's tabulate the results of the experiment. I think it's safe to say that you're not in love with me and I'm not in love with you. And psychology has once again proved itself the doofus of the sciences.

speaker: Well, maybe. But I'm still glad we did it. I do feel closer to you.
response: And I, you. And yes, that's how you say that. Yeah, so, given our newfound intimacy, I'd say we have some hard choices to make.

speaker: Like what?
response: Gary Con, do we fly or drive? Do we wear costumes? And if so, who gets to be Gary?

speaker: I just want to make sure you get there safe.
response: Well, this is me. It's been a very interesting evening.

speaker: Surprise!
response: Aah! And after I let you be Gary.

speaker: Yeah, that’s terrific, but what they wanted me to ask you was to cut it the hell out. (To someone off) Right come on guys, come on. (Singing while approaching another table) Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you…
response: We might as well stop, it’s a stalemate. You’re b*at me in tetris, but you’ve got the upper body strength of a Keebler Elf.

speaker: So Leonard, will we be seeing you on Saturday for your free birthday cheesecake?
response: He can’t eat cheesecake, he’s lactose intolerant.

speaker: Okay, he can have carrot cake.
response: What about the cream cheese frosting.

speaker: I did your horoscope, remember, I was going to do everybody’s until Sheldon went on one of his typical psychotic rants.
response: For the record, that psychotic rant was a concise summation of the research of Bertram Forer, who in 1948 proved conclusively through meticulously designed experiments, that astrology is nothing but pseudo scientific hokum.

speaker: Uh, that’s so silly.
response: It’s actually based on very sound theories, his mother published a paper on it.

speaker: What was it called, “I hate my son and that’s why he can’t have cake?”
response: It was obviously effective, Leonard grew up to be an experimental physicist. Perhaps if she’d also denied him Christmas he’d be a little better at it.

speaker: Howard, every Thai restaurant in town knows you can’t eat peanuts. They see me coming they go “ah, no peanut boy!”
response: Hello Penny. Leonard just left.

speaker: I know. I want to talk to you.
response: What would we talk about? We’ve no overlapping areas of interest I’m aware of, and you know I don’t care for chit-chat.

speaker: Okay, can you just let me in.
response: Well alright, but I don’t see this as a promising endeavour.

speaker: Okay, here’s the deal, we are going to throw Leonard a kick-ass surprise party for his birthday on Saturday.
response: I hardly think so, Leonard made it very clear he doesn’t want a party.

speaker: Fine. If I do have a threesome, you can’t be part of it. I’m just kidding, yes you can. Can you bring a friend?
response: I think a birthday party is a terrible idea. I envy Leonard for growing up without that anguish.

speaker: Anguish?
response: Year after year, I had to endure wearing conical hats while being forced into the crowded sweaty hell of bouncy castles, not to mention being blindfolded and spun towards a grotesque tailless donkey as the other children mocked my disorientation.

speaker: Okay, sweetie, I understand you have scars that no non-professional can heal, but nevertheless we are going to throw Leonard a birthday party.
response: Have I pointed out that I am extremely uncomfortable with dancing, loud music and most other forms of alcohol induced frivolity.

speaker: Nevertheless we are….
response: In addition I really don’t think that Leonard wants a…

speaker: Okay, here’s the deal, you either help me throw Leonard a birthday party or, so help me God, I will go into your bedroom and I will unbag all of your most valuable mint condition comic books. And on one of them, you won’t know which, I’ll draw a tiny happy face in ink.
response: You can’t do that, if you make a mark on a mint comic book it’s no longer mint.

speaker: Sheldon, do you understand the concept of blackmail?
response: Well of course I… oh! Yeah, I have an idea, let’s throw Leonard a kick ass birthday party.

speaker: What difference does it make?
response: The whole point of a secret knock is to establish a non-verbal signal to verify the identity of one’s co-conspirators.

speaker: Is that Raj and Howard?
response: Possibly, but unverified.

speaker: Can you just let us in.
response: Luckily for you this is not a nuclear reactor.

speaker: Uh, Sheldon, I didn’t see your present.
response: That’s because I didn’t bring one.

speaker: Don’t ask.
response: The entire institution of gift giving makes no sense.

speaker: Too late.
response: Let’s say that I go out and I spend fifty dollars on you, it’s a laborious activity, because I have to imagine what you need, whereas you know what you need. Now I can simplify things, just give you the fifty dollars directly and, you could give me fifty dollars on my birthday, and so on until one of us dies leaving the other one old and fifty dollars richer. And I ask you, is it worth it?

speaker: Well, Sheldon, you’re his friend. Friends give each other presents.
response: I accept your premise, I reject your conclusion.

speaker: It’s a non-optional social convention.
response: Oh. Fair enough.

speaker: He came with a manual.
response: Question, how am I going to get Leonard a present before the party? I don’t drive, and the only things available within walking distance are a Thai restaurant and a gas station. I suppose I could wrap up an order of mee krob and a couple of lottery scratchers.

speaker: Alright, you know they have DVDs over there.
response: Yes, but they have DVD burners over here. Leonard needs a DVD burner.

speaker: Sheldon, a gift shouldn’t be something someone needs, it should be something fun, you know, something they wouldn’t buy for themselves.
response: You mean, like a sweater?

speaker: Well, it’s a fun sweater, it’s got a bold geometric print.
response: Is it the geometry that makes it fun.

speaker: Okay, the point is, one of the ways we show we care about people is by putting thought and imagination into the gifts we give them.
response: Okay, I see, so not a DVD burner.

speaker: Exactly.
response: Something he wouldn’t buy for himself. Something fun. Something like… oh, an 802.11n wireless router.

speaker: Um, that one.
response: Because of the two additional Ethernet ports.

speaker: Sure.
response: He doesn’t need them, he’s already got a 640 connect switch

speaker: Oh, okay then this one.
response: Why?

speaker: I don’t know, the man on the box looks so happy.
response: Penny! If I’m going to buy Leonard a gift, I’m going to do it right. I refuse to let him experience the same childhood trauma I did.

speaker: Oh, I know I’m going to regret this but, what trauma?
response: On my twelfth birthday I really wanted a titanium centrifuge, so, you know, I could separate radioactive isotopes.

speaker: Of course.
response: Instead of a titanium centrifuge, my parents bought me… wow, this is hard. They got me… a motorised dirt bike.

speaker: No?
response: What twelve year old boy wants a motorised dirt bike?

speaker: All of them.
response: Really?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Huh?

speaker: Okay, so we’re getting this one?
response: Yeah, I suppose.

speaker: Excuse me, do you know anything about this stuff?
response: I know everything about this stuff.

speaker: Here, buy this one. Look, it’s the one we’re getting, see, happy guy available.
response: No, no, no, no, she doesn’t want that, she needs a point to point peer network with a range extender.

speaker: Which hard drive do I want, firewire or USB?
response: It depends on what Bus you have.

speaker: I drive a Chevy Cavalier.
response: Oh, dear lord.

speaker: Sheldon, we have to go.
response: Not now, Penny, this poor man needs me. (To woman approaching) You hold on, I’ll be right with you. What computer do you have, and please don’t say a white one?

speaker: Excuse me, sir, you don’t work here.
response: Yes, well, apparently neither does anyone else.

speaker: Sheldon, we have to go.
response: Why?

speaker: Well, for one thing, we’re late for Leonard’s birthday party. And for another, I told him to call security.
response: Good luck. (To assistant) By the way, a six year-old could hack your computer system.

speaker: Keep walking.
response: Yeah, 1-2-3-4 is not a secure password.

speaker: Why, did you hit a roadblock with invisibility?
response: Put it on the back burner. Anyway, it occurs to me, if I ever did perfect a time machine, I’d just go into the past and give it to myself, thus eliminating the need for me to invent it in the first place.

speaker: Interesting.
response: Yeah, it really takes the pressure off.

speaker: Sounds like a breakthrough, should I call the science magazines and tell them to hold the front cover? (Exiting the apartment.)
response: It’s time travel, Leonard, I will have already done that.

speaker: Then I guess congratulations are in order.
response: No, congratulations will have been in order. You know, I’m not going to enjoy this party.

speaker: I know, I’m familiar with you.
response: At the last department party, Dr Finkleday cornered me and talked about spelunking for 45 minutes.

speaker: Yes, I was there.
response: You know what’s interesting about caves, Leonard?

speaker: What?
response: Nothing.

speaker: Well then we’ll avoid Finkleday, we’ll meet the new department head, congratulate him, shake his hand and go.
response: How’s this? Pleased to meet you, Dr Gablehouser. How fortunate for you that the University has chosen to hire you, despite the fact that you’ve done no original research in 25 years, and instead have written a series of popular books that reduce the great concepts of science to a series of anecdotes, each one dumbed down to accommodate the duration of an average bowel movement. Mahalo.

speaker: Mahalo’s a nice touch.
response: Do you know there are only eight consonants in the Hawaiian language.

speaker: Of course, but it’s all Indian food. You can’t find a bagel in Mumbai to save your life. Schmear me.
response: Well here’s an interesting turn of events.

speaker: What. (Sees Howard entering with a statuesque blonde) Howard brought a date?
response: A more plausible explanation is that his work in robotics has made an amazing leap forward.

speaker: Howard, nice to meet you, and you are?
response: An actual real scientist. (To Leonard) How was that?

speaker: Well, you did call him a glorified high-school science teacher whose last successful experiment was lighting his own farts.
response: In my defence, I prefaced that by saying “with all due respect.”

speaker: Morning
response: Morning.

speaker: You’re making eggs for breakfast?
response: This isn’t breakfast, it’s an experiment.

speaker: Huh? Cos it looks a lot like breakfast.
response: I finally have the time to test my hypothesis, about the separation of the water molecules from the egg proteins, and its impact vis-a-vis taste.

speaker: Sounds yummy. I look forward to your work with bacon.
response: As do I.

speaker: You know, I’m sure if you just apologised to Gablehauser he would give you your job back.
response: I don’t want my job back. I’ve spent the last three and a half years staring at greaseboards full of equations. Before that I spent four years working on my thesis. Before that I was in college, and before that, I was in the fifth grade. This is my first day off in decades, and I’m going to savour it.

speaker: Okay. I’ll let you get back to fixing your eggs.
response: I’m not just fixing my eggs, I’m fixing everyone’s eggs.

speaker: And we all thank you.
response: Use new eggs. (There is a knock on the door).

speaker: Hi, hey. I’m running out to the market, do you guys need anything?
response: Oh, well this would be one of those circumstances that people unfamiliar with the law of large numbers would call a coincidence.

speaker: I’m sorry?
response: I need eggs. Four dozen should suffice.

speaker: Four dozen?
response: Yes, and evenly distributed amongst brown, white, free range, large, extra-large and jumbo.

speaker: Okay, one more time?
response: Never mind, you won’t get it right, I’d better come with you.

speaker: How come you didn’t go into work today.
response: I’m taking a sabbatical, because I won’t kow-tow to mediocre minds.

speaker: So you got canned, huh?
response: Theoretical physicists do not get canned. But yeah.

speaker: Well, maybe it’s all for the best, you know I always say, when one door closes, another one opens.
response: No it doesn’t. Not unless the two doors are connected by relays, or there are motion sensors involved.

speaker: No, no, I meant…
response: Or the first door closing causes a change of air pressure that acts upon the second door.

speaker: Never mind.
response: Slow down. Slow down, please slow down.

speaker: We’re fine.
response: Look, you’re not leaving yourself enough space between cars.

speaker: Oh, sure I am.
response: No, no. Let me do the math for you, this car weighs let’s say 4,000lb, now add say 140 for me, 120 for you.
Oh, I’m sorry, did I insult you? Is your body mass somehow tied into your self worth?

speaker: Well, yeah.
response: Interesting. Anyway, that gives us a total weight of, let’s say, 4,400lb.

speaker: Let’s say 4,390.
response: Fine. We’re travelling forward at, good Lord, 51 miles an hour. Now let’s assume that your brakes are new and the callipers are aligned, still, by the time we come to a stop, we’ll be occupying the same space as that Buick in front of us, an impossibility that nature will quickly resolve into death, mutilation and… oh look, they built a new put-put course.

speaker: Thank you.
response: No, thank you. And thank you, ordinary person. Hey, you want to hear an interesting thing about tomatoes.

speaker: Uh, no, no not really. Listen, didn’t you say you needed some eggs.
response: Uh, yes, but anyone who knows anything about the dynamics of bacterial growth knows to pick up their refrigerated foods on the way out of the supermarket.

speaker: Oh, okay, well maybe you should start heading on out then.
response: No, this is fun. Oh, the thing about tomatoes, and I think you’ll really enjoy this, is, they’re shelved with the vegetables, but they’re technically a fruit.

speaker: Interesting.
response: Isn’t it?

speaker: No, I mean what you find enjoyable.
response: Oh boy.

speaker: What now?
response: Well, there’s some value to taking a multivitamin, but the human body can only absorb so much, what you’re buying here are the ingredients for very expensive urine.

speaker: Well, maybe that’s what I was going for.
response: Well then you’ll want some manganese.

speaker: Oh, I don’t know Sheldon, it’s going to take me a while to recover from all the fun I had today.
response: Are you sure. There are a lot of advantages to buying in bulk. For example, I noticed that you purchase your tampons one month’s supply at a time.

speaker: What?
response: Well think about it, it’s a product that doesn’t spoil, and you’re going to be needing them for at least the next thirty years.

speaker: You want me to buy thirty years worth of tampons?
response: Well, thirty, thirty five, hey, when did your mother go into menopause?

speaker: Okay, I’m not talking about this with you.
response: Oh, Penny, this is a natural human process, and we’re talking about statistically significant savings. Now, if you assume 15 tampons per cycle and a 28 day cycle, are you fairly regular? (Penny shuts door in his face.) Okay, no warehouse store, but we’re still on for put-put golf, right?

speaker: Hey, I just ran into Penny, she seemed upset about something.
response: I think it’s her time of the month. I marked the calendar for future reference.

speaker: What’s with the fish?
response: It’s an experiment.

speaker: What happened to your scrambled egg research?
response: Oh, that was a dead end. Scrambled eggs are as good as they’re ever going to be.

speaker: So… fish.
response: I read an article about Japanese scientists, who inserted DNA from luminous jellyfish into other animals, and I thought hey, fish nightlights.

speaker: Fish nightlights.
response: It’s a billion dollar idea. Shhhhh!

speaker: Mum’s the word. Sheldon, are you sure you don’t want to just apologise to Gablehauser and get your job back.
response: Oh, no, no, no. No, I’ve too much to do.

speaker: Like luminous fish.
response: Shhhhh!

speaker: Right… I didn’t….
response: That’s just the beginning. I also have an idea for a bulk mail-order feminine hygiene company. Oh, glow in the dark tampons! Leonard, we’re going to be rich.

speaker: I didn’t know what else to do, he’s lost all focus, every day he’s got a new obsession. (They enter the apartment. Sheldon is weaving on a loom. He is wrapped in a poncho.) This is a particularly disturbing one.
response: Mommy.

speaker: Hi baby.
response: You called my mother?

speaker: Oh, you got yourself a loom, how nice.
response: Thank you.

speaker: Honey, why did you get a loom?
response: I was working with luminous fish, and I thought, hey, loom! Mom, what are you doing here?

speaker: Leonard called me.
response: I know, but why?

speaker: Because one of the great minds of the twenty-first century is raising glow-in-the-dark fish and weaving sarapes.
response: This is not a sarape. This is a poncho. A sarape is open at the sides, a poncho is closed, this is a poncho, and neither is a reason to call someone’s mother.

speaker: Really, when was the last time you left the house.
response: I went to the market with Penny.

speaker: That was three weeks ago.
response: Well then buckle up, in the next four to eight days she’s going to get very crabby.

speaker: Sweetheart, your little friend is concerned about you.
response: Yes, well I’m not a child, I’m a grown man capable of living my life as I see fit. And I certainly don’t need someone telling on me to my mother.

speaker: Where are you going?
response: To my room, and no-one’s allowed in.

speaker: Sheldon? Your mum made dinner.
response: I’m not hungry.

speaker: Good morning, snicker-doodle.
response: Morning.

speaker: Oh, well that looks awful fancy, what is that?
response: It’s my idea of what DNA would look like in a silicon based life form.

speaker: But intelligently designed by a creator, right?
response: What do you want, mom?

speaker: You know how your daddy used to say that you can only fish for so long before you got to throw a stick of dynamite in the water?
response: Yeah.

speaker: Well, I’m done fishing. (Throwing a pair of trousers on the bed) You put those on.
response: What for?

speaker: Because you’re going to go down to your office, you’re going to apologise to your boss, and get your job back.
response: No.

speaker: I’m sorry, did I start that sentence with the words “if it please your highness?”
response: I’m not going to apologise, I didn’t say anything that wasn’t true.

speaker: Now you listen here, I have been telling you since you were four years old, it’s okay to be smarter than everybody but you can’t go around pointing it out.
response: Why not?

speaker: Because people don’t like it. Remember all the ass-kickings you got from the neighbour kids? Now let’s get cracking. Shower, shirt, shoes, and let’s shove off. (Exits)
response: Wouldn’t have been any ass-kickings if that stupid death ray had worked.

speaker: Sheldon, he’s just doodling, get in here.
response: Dr Gablehouser.

speaker: Let’s go, baby, we’re losing daylight.
response: Um, as you know, several weeks ago in our first encounter we may have gotten off on the wrong foot, when I called you an idiot. And I just wanted to say that I was wrong. To point it out.

speaker: Please. Sheldon, shouldn’t you be working?
response: Okay.

speaker: Hey, how did it go?
response: I got my job back.

speaker: Really? What happened?
response: I’m not quite sure. It involves a part of the human experience that has always eluded me.

speaker: I’m very proud of you honey, you showed a lot of courage today.
response: Thanks, mom. Mom?

speaker: Mmm-hmm?
response: Is Dr Gablehouser going to be my new daddy?

speaker: Sit over there.
response: Sit over there. Baby wipe?

speaker: Don’t! Don’t! Don’t!
response: I’ll tell you why.

speaker: O-o-o-oh!
response: I had to sanitize my hands because the university replaced the paper towels in the rest rooms with hot air blowers.

speaker: Why? Don’t!
response: Hot air blowers are incubators and spewers of bacteria and pestilence. Frankly it would be more hygienic if they just had a plague infested gibbon sneeze my hands dry.

speaker: Well, wow, that’s incredible.
response: Excuse me. Thirty what, under thirty what, to watch what?

speaker: Thirty visionaries under thirty years of age to watch as they challenge the preconceptions of their fields.
response: If I had a million guesses I never would have gotten that.

speaker: It’s a lease.
response: I’m confused. Was there some sort of peer review committee to determine which scientists would be included?

speaker: Peer review? It’s People magazine. People picked me.
response: What people?

speaker: The people from People.
response: Yeah, but exactly who are these people? What are their credentials, how are they qualified, what makes accidentally noticing a hunk of rock that’s been traipsing around the solar system for billions of years more noteworthy than any other scientific accomplishment made by someone under thirty?

speaker: Are you proud of yourself?
response: In general, yes.

speaker: Hi Sheldon.
response: Here, look, look, I found my missing neutrino.

speaker: Well, we’re going to go apologise to Raj and invite him out to dinner.
response: Apologise, for what?

speaker: Well, he came over last night with some pretty good news, and we weren’t very supportive.
response: I sense you’re trying to tell me something.

speaker: You were a colossal ass-hat.
response: Oh! No, I beg to differ. Of the three of us, I was by far the most supportive.

speaker: Really, do tell.
response: How will Raj ever reach true greatness if his friends lower the bar for him? When I was eleven, my sister bought our father a “world’s greatest dad” coffee mug, and frankly the man coasted until the day he died.

speaker: Okay, let’s try it this way, what if the People magazine thing is the best Raj is ever going to achieve?
response: I had not considered that.

speaker: Come on.
response: I often forget other people have limitations. It’s so sad.

speaker: And when we go in there, let’s show Raj that we’re happy for him.
response: But I’m not.

speaker: Well then fake it. Look at me, I could be grinding on the fact that without my stabilizing telescope mount he never would have found that stupid little clump of cosmic schmutz, but I’m bigger than that.
response: Fine, what do you want me to do?

speaker: Dr Hoffstadter.
response: Dr Gablehauser.

speaker: I’m not talking about you, I’m talking about me. You, my exotic young friend are my star.
response: Well, you didn’t discover him, you merely noticed he was here, much like he did with 2008 NQ sub 17.

speaker: Sheldon!
response: Oh, sorry. (Smiles)

speaker: Wait a minute, I called dibs on Fishbine’s office the day he started showing up at work in his bathrobe.
response: He gets a new office, I can’t even get paper towels in the men’s room?

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Damn, this is hard. (Smiles)

speaker: You can stop smiling now.
response: Aaaah!

speaker: It’s fantastic, apparently the camera loves me and I it. They sh*t me in front of a starry background where I posed like this. (Stares into space.) They’re going to digitally add a supernova, they say it’s the perfect metaphor for my incandescent talent.
response: Right, a ball of hot flaming gas that collapses in on itself. (Leonard nudges him. He smiles. Phone rings.)

speaker: They gave him an assistant? If I want a new pen I have to go to the bank with wire cutters.
response: Have we at this point met our social obligations?

speaker: Oh, I’m sorry, is that politically incorrect? In India we just call them untouchables.
response: Now?

speaker: Oh, you’re welcome. Of course, I couldn’t get you into the VIP section, because, you know, that’s for VIPs, and you guys are just, you know, Ps.
response: There’s a tribe in Papua New Guinea where, when a hunter flaunts his success to the rest of the village they k*ll him, and drive away evil spirits with a drum made of his skin. Superstitious nonsense of course, but one can see their point. (Smiles)

speaker: Sheldon?
response: I can make it, but I won’t.

speaker: And you guys aren’t going? I can’t believe you, Raj is celebrating a tremendous accomplishment and you’re not even going to be there to support him?
response: A tremendous accomplishment would be if the planetary body he discovered were plummeting toward Earth and he exploded it with his mind.

speaker: Look at that. I got a date with Penny. I can’t believe it took you a whole year.
response: Now?

speaker: Let’s just eat so I can get to bed. With any luck tonight will be the night my sleep apnoea k*ll me.
response: Did you remember to ask for the chicken with broccoli to be diced not shredded?

speaker: Yes.
response: Even though the menu description specifies shredded?

speaker: Yes.
response: Brown rice, not white?

speaker: Yes.
response: Did you stop at the Korean grocery and get the good hot mustard.

speaker: Yes.
response: Did you pick up the low sodium soy sauce from the market?

speaker: Yes.
response: Thank you.

speaker: You’re welcome.
response: What took you so long?

speaker: Just sit down and eat.
response: Fine. (Opens carton. Shows it to Leonard in disgust.)

speaker: Alright, it’s shredded, what do you want me to do?
response: I want you to check before you accept the order.

speaker: Sorry.
response: Were you distracted by the possibility that Koothrappali might have intercourse with Penny tonight?

speaker: He’s not going to have intercourse with Penny.
response: Then there’s no excuse for this chicken. You know, this situation with Koothrapali brings to mind a story from my childhood.

speaker: Oh goody, more tales from the panhandle.
response: That’s Northwest Texas, I’m from East Texas, the Gulf region, home to many Vietnamese shrimpers.

speaker: Do the shrimpers feature in your story?
response: No. Anyway, when I was eight, a Montgomery-Ward delivery van ran over our cat, Lucky.

speaker: Lucky?
response: Yes, Lucky.

speaker: Okay, dead cat named Lucky, continue.
response: While others mourned Lucky, I realised his untimely demise provided me with the opportunity to replace him with something more suited to my pet needs. A faithful companion that I could snuggle with at night, and yet would be capable of k*ll upon telepathic command.

speaker: So, not a puppy?
response: Please, no, nothing so pedestrian. I wanted a griffin.

speaker: A griffin?
response: Yes, half eagle, half lion.

speaker: And mythological.
response: Irrelevant. See, I was studying recombinant DNA technology and I was confident I could create one, but my parents were unwilling to secure the necessary eagle eggs and lion semen. Course my sister got swimming lessons when she wanted them.

speaker: Sheldon, not that we don’t all enjoy a good lion semen story, what’s your point.
response: My point is, if Koothrappali is moving on to a new life of shallow, undeserved fame, perhaps this is an opportunity to create a better cohort.

speaker: You want to breed a new friend?
response: That’s one option, but who has the time? But consider this, the Japanese, they’re doing some wonderful work with artificial intelligence, now, you combine that with some animatronics from the imagineers over at Disney, next thing you know, we’re playing Halo with a multi-lingual Abraham Lincoln.

speaker: That may well be, but the fact is, it wouldn’t k*ll us to meet some new people.
response: Uh, for the record, it could k*ll us to meet new people. They could be m*rder, or the carriers of unusual pathogens, and I’m not insane, my mother had me tested.

speaker: And he should have a lot of money, and live in a cool place down by the beach where we could throw parties.
response: He should share our love of technology.

speaker: Well, you have milk in the taters, milk in the gravy, parmesan crust. Your lactose-intolerant boyfriend will turn into a gas-filled Macy’s Day balloon.
response: Not quite accurate. The Macy’s balloons are filled with helium, whereas Leonard produces copious amounts of methane.

speaker: k*ll me.
response: It wouldn’help. The human body is capable of being flatulent for hours after death.

speaker: Guys, sorry I’m late. I have amazing news.
response: Bernadette, before you change the subject, does anyone have any final comments on Leonard’s faulty digestive system?

speaker: Oh!
response: Oh, congratulations.

speaker: So, Howard, tell us, how’s it feel knowing that when you two get married, you’ll be referred to as Mr. and Dr. Wolowitz?
response: Unless he takes Bernadette’s last name. And considering her advanced status, that could open some doors for him.

speaker: It’s indeed admirable. Although, it is microbiology.
response: Your doctorate is in neurobiology. I fail to see the distinction.

speaker: I’ll make it simple for you. I study the brain, the organ responsible for Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony. Bernadette studies yeast, the organism responsible for Michelob Lite. Is there something wrong with your neck?
response: It’s a little stiff. What a remarkably fragile structure to support such a valuable payload. Not unlike balancing a Faberge egg on a Pixie Stick.

speaker: Have you considered massage?
response: I’d like to respond to that sarcastically. Yes, I relish the thought of a stranger covering my body with oil and rubbing it.

speaker: I was proposing you massage your muscles with your own hands.
response: Still sounds like a lot of unnecessary touching.

speaker: Trust me. With your right hand, locate the spot where the scapula meets the acromion process.
response: All right.

speaker: Now push your third finger along the ridge of the shoulder blade, making a small rotation as you do so.
response: Rotating.

speaker: You should feel a small node-like object rolling back and forth along the bone.
response: You mean the myofascial point?

speaker: Obviously. Now bear down on it like the seventh grade noogies we all know too well.
response: Oh, dear Lord, yes, yes, oh, yes! Amy, I’ve never been touched like this before! Oh! Oh, my hands are magic!

speaker: Don’t flatter yourself. Your hands are blunt tools guided by my knowledge of the nervous system. I could just as easily have paralyzed you.
response: There’s someone at my door.

speaker: Can I sleep here tonight?
response: Why?

speaker: Leonard’s having astronomically inaccurate Star Trek sex with my sister.
response: I can see how that would be upsetting. Come in. I’ll get the sheets and blankets for the couch.

speaker: Oh, don’t bother. I’ll just sleep in Leonard’s room.
response: No, I can’t authorize that.

speaker: Well, he’s in my bed. Why can’t I be in his?
response: The Hammurabic Code is an eye for an eye, not a bed for a bed.

speaker: Come on, dude, I’m exhausted, and Tyra Banks says the most important item in your makeup bag is a good night’s sleep.
response: All right. This is a form indemnifying me from your use of Leonard’s bedroom. Sign here, indicating that I tried to stop you and did so using a stern facial expression.

speaker: Good night, Sheldon.
response: Wait. Not yet. We still have to go over safety procedures. Now, the apartment has three emergency exits located here, here, and here. In the event of a power outage, luminous paint will guide you to the nearest exit.

speaker: You’re kidding.
response: I never kid about safety.

speaker: Until you have kids.
response: Good news, Raj. I got the blood work back from the lab. You’re okay to stay for a while.

speaker: When did you take my blood?
response: Not important. Your sugar was a little high. I’d follow up with your regular physician. In the meantime, I have some paperwork here for you to go over.

speaker: What the hell is this?
response: Boilerplate stuff. A modified roommate agreement for a temporary house guest. And a living will and durable power of attorney.

speaker: This says you can make end of life decisions for me.
response: As your friend, let’s hope it doesn’t come to that. Please sign.

speaker: Well, that seems fair.
response: Congratulations and welcome temporarily aboard. Here’s your I.D. Card, your key and your lapel pin. Which Leonard was too cool to wear. FYI, part of your responsibilities as roommate pro tem will be to drive me to and from work, the comic book store, the barbershop and the park for one hour every other Sunday for fresh air.

speaker: Bring a ball or a Frisbee, you know, something he can chase.
response: Also, you’re tasked with bringing home all takeout dinners. Tonight is Thai food. You’ll find the standard order in appendix B or downloadable from my FTP server. If you have any questions, here’s the FAQ sheet, or if you prefer the human touch, I do a live web chat called Apartment Talk on Tuesday nights.

speaker: Sheldon, dinner!
response: What is this?

speaker: This is the difference between eating and dining.
response: Remarkable. I’m just realizing how much Leonard’s been skating by all these years.

speaker: Hey, Sheldon, did you change your Wi-Fi password again?
response: Yes, it’s “Penny, get your own Wi-Fi.” No spaces.

speaker: Thanks. Wow! What’s with the fancy spread?
response: My new roommate is bending over backwards to ingratiate himself to me. (Pointing to lapel badge) Uh, nice touch, by the way.

speaker: What do you mean, new roommate? What happened to Leonard?
response: The same thing that happened to h*m* Erectus. He was replaced by a superior species.

speaker: He’s living at my place, so I’m living here.
response: You’re living here provisionally. But I must say it’s looking good.

speaker: Woah, Leonard and Priya are living together? That’s big.
response: No. Origami napkin swans, that’s the headline.

speaker: Oh, no, no, no. I’ve had way too much already.
response: Here’s an interesting fact about alcohol.

speaker: Hit me.
response: Man is not the only species that ferments fruit in order to become intoxicated. Can you guess what the other is? Hint, sometimes they pack the alcohol in their trunks.

speaker: Monkeys.
response: When does a monkey have a trunk?

speaker: When a suitcase just won’t do.
response: Mmm, all right. It would appear as if alcohol is playing keep-away with your intelligence. Good night. Please note, it is now past ten p.m. Per our roommate agreement, kindly refrain from raucous laughter, clinking of glasses, and celebratory g*n.

speaker: To friendship.
response: Would you booze hounds please stop that infernal clinking? And the answer was elephant!

speaker: What?
response: I said, what are you doing here?

speaker: I live here.
response: I have paperwork that says differently.

speaker: Priya’s going back to India.
response: Irrelevant. Rajesh and I have a good thing going and you’re not going to ruin it. (Knock on door) What are you doing here?

speaker: I’ve been up all night. I had a fight with Bernadette.
response: Why?

speaker: She gave me a beautiful watch.
response: Leonard, do you understand this?

speaker: Yes.
response: Talk to him.

speaker: Oh. It’s, it’s not what it looks like.
response: What does it look like?

speaker: Sheldon, your food’s getting cold.
response: I’ll eat later. Right now, I’m suckling at the informative bosom of mother physics.

speaker: What do you think, Sheldon? Want an action figure that looks just like you?
response: Would it come with Kung-Fu grip?

speaker: No.
response: Don’t waste my time.

speaker: Cooper?
response: Nobel. Kripke. Don’t look at my board.

speaker: What’s that?
response: That’s a drawing of a really cool train. Don’t look at that, either. What do you want?

speaker: I have some bad news. You’re working on a gwant pwoposal fow a new fusion weactow. I’m working on a gwant pwoposal fow a new fusion weactow. The university is only awowed to submit one pwoposal.
response: So they asked you to pack up your things and ship out. That’s hard cheese, Barry. You’re one of the good ones.

speaker: No, they’re making us work together.
response: That’s ridiculous. I am one of the great minds of our generation. I work on a level so rarified you couldn’t even imagine it. I said stop looking at my cool train!

speaker: You doing okay, sweetie?
response: There is ominous music playing, and there is an afghan over my head. I don’t know where you’re from, but where I’m from, that means I’m not doing okay.

speaker: Want me to make you some tea?
response: Tea is for when I’m upset. I’m not upset. The university’s forcing me to work with Kripke. I’m outraged.

speaker: So, cocoa?
response: Yes, cocoa. Do you have any idea what it’s like to be paired with someone who’s so incredibly annoying?

speaker: Oh, teacher! Me! Me!
response: See, I did all this great work, and now he’s just going to come along and ruin it. I am angrier than ever and filled with despair.

speaker: Oh, no, no, no, I know this. Uh, hot apple cider with cinnamon sticks?
response: Yes, hot apple cider with cinnamon sticks!

speaker: What the fwig, Cooper? We were supposed to meet in my office a half an hour ago.
response: And yet, now you’re in my office. Point, Cooper. Welcome to the Thunderdome, Kripke.

speaker: We agweed to exchange copies of our work. Let me see yours.
response: Why don’t you show me yours first.

speaker: You think I just few off the turnip twuck? We exchange at the same time.
response: How do I know you’re not going to take my ideas and publish them as your own?

speaker: How do I know you’re not going to do that with mine?
response: Because I’m not interested in getting published in Mad magazine. Zingers fly fast in the Thunderdome, Barry.

speaker: Are we going to do this or not? Thank you. So, we wead each other’s work, meet again tomowow?
response: Fine.

speaker: Nice twy. This is bwank paper.
response: And I am sure it’s still more valuable than whatever’s in here.

speaker: Cough it up, Cooper.
response: Very well.

speaker: If this one’s bwank, too, I’m going to be fuwious.
response: Fine.

speaker: The monkey in my tobacco study has taken to smoking a pipe. I’m supposed to remove his brain to examine, but it’s hard because now he reminds me of my uncle. You’ve been awfully quiet tonight. Is everything okay?
response: I’m fine.

speaker: All right, well, how was work today? Did you exchange your research with Kripke?
response: Yes.

speaker: Sheldon, what’s going on?
response: I read his research, and, it’s leaps and bounds ahead of mine. Which means the mommy of the smartest physicist at the university is not my mommy as I had thought. It’s his mommy.

speaker: Sheldon, I wish there was something I could do to make you feel better. May I offer you a consoling hug?
response: What do we have to lose?

speaker: How’s that?
response: I feel like I’m being strangled by a boa constrictor. Why’d you stop?

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, we’re going to be late.
response: I can’t go in today. I’m sick.

speaker: You’re not sick. You just don’t want to face Kripke.
response: No, look.
See?

speaker: What did you do, put this in your tea?
response: Oh, dear. Now I’m not even smarter than you.

speaker: Sheldon, Kripke’s not smarter than you. You just got stuck on a wrong path. Happened to Einstein. He got stuck on the unified field theory for decades.
response: Oh, don’t play the Einstein card. His great breakthroughs happened when no one knew anything. So everything was a great breakthrough.

speaker: Sheldon Lee Cooper, I do not have time for this nonsense. Now, go put your clothes on, get in the car, and lets go to work.
response: All right, geez. What a grouch.

speaker: Cooper, we have a pwobwem. Your work is weawy not at a wevew I expected it to be.
response: I know. Go ahead, mock me. Just use small words so I understand.

speaker: Don’t pway dumb with me. We both know what your pwobwem is.
response: We do?

speaker: You have a girlfwiend.
response: So?

speaker: So my work would suffew, too, if I was getting waid all the time.
response: Yes. That is the reason. My work is suffering because of all the laid I’m getting.

speaker: You wucky bastard.
response: What can I say, you know? She enjoys my genitals. I am giving them to her on a nightly basis.

speaker: Okay, stop bwagging. You had some bwiwiant insights in here, but if we’re gonna make this work, you need to buckew down and focus.
response: I’ll do what I can. But it’s not going to be easy, because when I’m with Amy and our bathing suit areas mush together, boy howdy, is it magic

speaker: All right, I don’t understand. Why didn’t you just tell Kripke the truth?
response: Because the truth made me look bad, whereas a ridiculous bald-faced lie makes me look good. Anyway, if Kripke asks, tell him my coitus with Amy is frequent, intense and whimsically inventive.

speaker: Yeah. Sheldon, can I ask you a question?
response: Of course.

speaker: You ever going to sleep with Amy?
response: That’s awfully personal.

speaker: Maybe you don’t, I do. What’s the deal?
response: Well, word around the university is I’m giving her sex organs a proper jostling.

speaker: All right, we’re down the rabbit hole. What are you doing?
response: Well, first of all, I’m quite fond of Amy.

speaker: Then what’s the problem?
response: Penny, all my life, I have been uncomfortable with the sort of physical contact that comes easily to others, hand-shaking, hugging, prostate exams. But I’m working on it, you know? Just recently, I had to put VapoRub on Amy’s chest. A year ago, that would have been unthinkable.

speaker: Okay. Hang on. Are you saying someday you and Amy might actually get physical?
response: It’s a possibility.

speaker: Oh, my God! (Out loud) Sheldon, I know this wasn’t easy for you, and I’m really glad we could have this conversation.
response: Fine.

speaker: Whatever. You get any wast night?
response: Yes.

speaker: Gave it to her good, huh?
response: No, I gave it to her well. Now, over here, I was thinking the turbulence could be reduced if we just put…

speaker: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Was she naked, or was she weawing wingewie?
response: I didn’t notice.

speaker: How could you not notice?
response: I was too busy squishing all the desirable parts of her body.

speaker: Ah, you’re kiwing me, Cooper!
response: Can we get back to work?

speaker: Sure, sure, sure. You guys ever use any toys?
response: Toys? I do have a model rocket next to my bed.

speaker: It’s actually steamier than it looks. Sheldon’s looking up the phallic symbolism of root vegetables in Renaissance paintings.
response: Oh, no, I got bored with that. I’m just browsing cuticle scissors on Amazon.

speaker: How do you not tear off his clothes and take him right here on this table?
response: If you do that, I’ll scream.

speaker: Sheldon, I have some exciting news to tell you.
response: That makes two of us. My new cuticle scissors will be here in one to two business days. Come on, one.

speaker: I’ve been invited to consult on an experiment at your university for a few months. Isn’t that great? We could have lunch together. We could carpool.
response: You know, riding with Leonard has gotten a little tedious lately. The only car game he ever wants to play is the Quiet Game. And he’s terrible at it, I always win.

speaker: So, you’re okay with this?
response: Well, why wouldn’t I be?

speaker: Well, this project would have us working in close proximity to one another. And there’s the vulgar adage that one should not defecate where one eats.
response: My father used to say that all the time. That and, um, who does one have to orally gratify to get a drink around here? But what does that have to do with you working at the university?

speaker: Sheldon, don’t defecate where you eat means don’t have a romantic relationship in the workplace.
response: Really?

speaker: Yes.
response: Huh. Yeah, I always took it literally. That’s why I have never once moved my bowels in this or any restaurant. Hmm.

speaker: I’m relieved that you don’t have a problem with us working together.
response: Not as relieved as I’m about to be. It’s a brave new world, little lady.

speaker: Are you crazy? You don’t want your girlfriend at work with you. Hell Clam.
response: Why not? Hairy Fairy.

speaker: No, no, I think it’ll be great. Maybe next time he gets conjunctivitis at work, she can hold his head and try to put the drops in his eyes. Giant baby.
response: That’s a Raging Ogre.

speaker: Yeah, I know, and it drove me into the arms of another woman. Bipolar Bear.
response: Well, I appreciate your concern, but I won’t be seeing any more of Amy than I already do. I assume we’ll deduct any extra time we spend together at work from our weekly quota.

speaker: Please let me be there when you tell her that.
response: Why? So you can see the look on Amy’s face when she hears my top-notch idea?

speaker: You know, not a lot of people know this, but the monoamine oxidase enzyme was discovered by a woman, Mary Bernheim. That’s right, my phone is just as smart as you guys.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy, Bernadette, Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy, Bernadette, Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy, Bernadette, Penny.

speaker: I don’t mind. I’m hoping to put his love of repetition to good use someday.
response: Hi. Um, I’ve reconsidered. Uh, you can’t work where I work. Enjoy the rest of your evening.

speaker: Sheldon. I already signed the contract. I cashed a cheque.
response: Mmm, you are not going to come out of this looking good.

speaker: Sheldon, I don’t understand. I thought you said you were fine with it.
response: Well, I was. But that was before Howard explained to me how awful it would be if he had to work with his significant other.

speaker: He said what?
response: Now, don’t be insulted. He just thinks too much of you would be mind-numbingly tedious.

speaker: Excuse me, I need to have a chat with my husband.
response: Yeah, well, now, well, keep it short. From what I gather, brevity is your friend. So, are we good here?

speaker: Yeah, and you can’t tell her what she can and cannot do.
response: Last week, you told Leonard he couldn’t wear his Wookie jacket out in public.

speaker: Sheldon, you don’t have to worry about me bothering you. I’ll be in a different building. And we don’t even have to have lunch together.
response: Really?

speaker: Yes. Before all things, I’m a scientist. I’m just there to do my work and, with a little luck, scare the living crap out of some monkeys.
response: Hmm. You sure your mothlike personality won’t be drawn to this blazing fire that is myself?

speaker: More and more sure.
response: Well, then, you have my permission.

speaker: I didn’t ask for your permission.
response: Too late. No backsies.

speaker: No, no, listen to me. Sheldon misunderstood. What I meant was, if we worked together, there’d be too much of me for you, not the other way around.
response: Howard, if you’re going to lie to your wife, don’t start the sentence with Sheldon misunderstood. That’s a dead giveaway.

speaker: Okay, fine. I did say that, and I think it’s true. I think if we worked together and lived together, we’d get sick of each other.
response: Yeah, but to be fair, he only said the part about him getting sick of you.

speaker: Bernie…
response: If it makes you feel any better, Amy and I are fine. I mean, really good.

speaker: I mean, you know, Sheldon, none of this would’ve happened if I hadn’t tried to help you.
response: Uh, it also wouldn’t have happened if, in the early universe, hydrogen was a little more common or a little less common. This is fun. Your turn.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: That was kind of icy. You two okay?
response: Oh, we’re fine. As Howard advised, she’s merely respecting our professional boundaries.

speaker: Smart. Take relationship advice from a man who spent last night braiding Raj’s hair.
response: Yeah, you make a good point. It would appear I was worried for nothing. Look at her, desperately wishing she was over here at the cool table. Don’t worry, little moth. The flame will come to you.

speaker: And this is Dr. g*n from Stockholm.
response: Ah, Sweden. Yeah, home of my favourite Muppet and, uh, second favourite meatball. Okay, the Nordic reputation for lack of humour is well-founded. Boy, is his name g*n or No-Funderson?

speaker: Where are we going with this, Dr. Cooper?
response: Oh, please, I’m your boyfriend. You call me Sheldon. That’s right, I am in a boy-girl relationship with this cute little lump of wool.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: It’s a physical relationship, too. Hand-holding, hugging, even on hot days. Ow. Okay, here’s a new one. Apparently now we kick each other in the shin under the table. How do you like it when I do it to you? Not so much, huh?

speaker: Test subject D7, aka Betsy, fear response study. Image number one, Frenchman on bicycle carrying baguettes. No visible reaction. Image number two, sousaphone. Still no reaction. Okay. Let’s kick things up a notch. Image number three, crocodile with a mouthful of monkeys. Okay, now we’re talking.
response: Dr. Fowler?

speaker: What do you want, Sheldon?
response: Well, I’m done with work, so… ugh!

speaker: Oh, sorry, sorry, sorry. Sorry, uh, better?
response: Oh, baguettes. Yes, I like baguettes. What exactly are you doing?

speaker: Determining baseline fear levels in capuchin monkeys by measuring their response to visual stimuli.
response: So, goofing off. As I was saying, I’m done with work and Leonard’s not. So good news, you get to take me home. Play your cards right, I’ll let you drive me past the lot where the buses park at night.

speaker: I can’t leave now, Sheldon. I’m very busy. Besides, why would I want to do you a favour after the way you treated me in the cafeteria? Image number four, boa constrictor.
response: What on earth are you talking about? My behaviour in the cafeteria was delightful. Maybe your friend g*n needs to head over to IKEA and assemble a sense of humour.

speaker: You embarrassed me in front of my colleagues on my first day here. Image number five, kitten in a teacup.
response: Aw. Embarrassed you?

speaker: You know what? I don’t have time for this. Find another way home.
response: I’m starting to get the sense that you’re angry with me.

speaker: Really? What tipped you off?
response: Couple things, actually. Your tone of voice, your body language…

speaker: Get out.
response: Well, now, that.

speaker: Image number six, woman giving birth.
response: Bleugh!

speaker: It’s nine o’clock, where you been?
response: Oh, I had to take the bus home. Fell asleep and missed my stop.

speaker: Oh, no.
response: Did you know that Los Angeles has a Little Sri Lanka?

speaker: I did not.
response: Well, I do now. They’re a lovely people. Although terrifying when you wake up face-to-face with them. If you’re hungry, I brought home some mutton and coconut milk.

speaker: Why’d you get that? You hate lamb.
response: I was asking for directions. Apparently, there was a communication problem.

speaker: I thought Amy was gonna drive you home.
response: Yeah, I thought so, too, but she’s acting very strangely. I was discussing it with a Sri Lankan fellow on the bus, and he hypothesized that a tiger may have recently run across her shadow. Although he may have just been trying to drum up business for his brother-in-law’s witch doctor practice.

speaker: Okay, Sheldon, what happened between you and Amy?
response: Well, can you believe she said I embarrassed her?

speaker: Yeah.
response: But you didn’t even hear the details.

speaker: Sheldon, I’ve known you a long time, and I’m going to tell you this with all the love I can possibly muster. Amy’s right. You’re wrong.
response: But you don’t even know…

speaker: Doesn’t matter.
response: But, now, but in my defence…

speaker: Doesn’t matter.
response: You’re not listening to my side of it.

speaker: Okay, fine, Sheldon. What is your side?
response: Well…

speaker: Sheldon, what are you doing here so late?
response: I couldn’t sleep because I kept thinking about what happened earlier between us. Also, I had one heck of a bus nap. Oh, speaking of which, do you want some mutton and coconut milk?

speaker: No.
response: Well, I cannot give this stuff away.

speaker: What do you want?
response: Amy, this isn’t easy to say. All relationships are difficult, but even more so when you’re in one with a person who struggles with everyday social interactions. And frankly, who can strike some people as being kind of a weirdo.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re not a weirdo.
response: I wasn’t speaking about me. I mean, honestly, there’s no telling what will set you off. You know, introducing myself as your boyfriend. Giving you the opportunity to drive me home. Breaking the ice with your colleagues using ethnic humour, the funniest kind of humour.

speaker: What’s your point?
response: My point is, we’re a couple, and I like you for who you are, quirks and all.

speaker: I like you, too.
response: Well, I should hope so. I don’t see anyone else banging on this door to put up with your nonsense. Not even a good-bye? You see, that’s the kind of thing that makes people think you’re weird. Poor kid. She just doesn’t see it.

speaker: Aaargh. What the hell?
response: Emergency preparedness drill.

speaker: Oh, no, come on!
response: Yeah, you know how it works. Once a quarter, keep our readiness up. Now, rise and shine, sleepy head. Half the town is probably dead.

speaker: I have to get a lock for my door.
response: I think you’ll like the drill tonight. I’ve tried to make it fun. Each of these cards contains a detailed scenario of a possible apocalyptic event. Everything from wild fires to a surprise invasion by Canada. Pick a catastrophe, any catastrophe.

speaker: Sheldon, Canada is not going to invade California.
response: Yeah, really? You think those hippies in Washington and Oregon can stop them?

speaker: Fine.
response: All righty! An 8.2 magnitude earthquake devastates Pasadena, reducing mighty edifices to dust, engulfing the city in flames. The streets flow with blood and echo with the cries of the wounded. Oh, excellent choice. Now, put on your hard hat and safety vest.

speaker: Oh, fun. I get to spend another night in front of our apartment dressed like one of the Village People.
response: You make that joke every three months. I still don’t get it. Leonard, wait. What are you doing?

speaker: I don’t know, what am I doing?
response: Look around you, there’s hypothetical broken glass everywhere. Really? You’re going to face Armageddon without your orthotics? All right, your choice. (Grabs him and pushes him over) Uh-oh, hypothetical aftershock!

speaker: Aah!
response: And that’s why we wear hard hats.

speaker: How’d you do?
response: I’ll tell you exactly how he did. Readiness

speaker: You know what, I’m so tired I can’t even think straight. I’m going home. Will one of you guys give this nutbag a ride back later?
response: You can’t go home. You have to take me to the dentist at four o’clock.

speaker: Oh, can’t you take the bus to the dentist?
response: Of course I can. It’s coming back under the residual effects of the anaesthesia, that’s the problem. Two years ago after a deep gum cleaning, I thought I got on a bus but somehow wound up on a booze cruise to Mexico.

speaker: They put you under for a cleaning?
response: Yeah, they have to, I’m a biter.

speaker: Whatever, Sheldon. I’m exhausted. I’m not taking you to the dentist.
response: Wrong, sir. Wrong. Under section 37B of the roommate agreement, miscellaneous duties, you are obligated to take me to the dentist. See? It’s right here after providing a confirmation sniff on questionable dairy products.”

speaker: You know what, I am sick of the roommate agreement. It’s ridiculous. I’m your roommate, not your chauffeur. You know, I had better things to do yesterday than drive you all the way to the good model train store in Garden Grove because the one in Pasadena has gotten too big for its britches.
response: Well, it has. Ask anybody.

speaker: I don’t care. I’m done.
response: Hold on. Are you saying that you want to invoke Clause 209?

speaker: I don’t know what that is, but if it means I can go home and sleep, then yes.
response: Think carefully here. Clause 209 suspends our friendship, and strips down the roommate agreement to its bare essentials. Our responsibilities toward each other would only be rent, utilities and a perfunctory chin jut of recognition as we pass in the hall. (Demonstrating) ‘Sup?

speaker: Where do I sign?
response: Right here. Use your finger.

speaker: There. Done.
response: All right. That’s it. We are now no longer companions, boon or otherwise. We are now merely acquaintances. To amend the words of Toy Story, you have not got a friend in me.

speaker: I’m gonna go home and take a nap.
response: Yeah, well, tell it to someone who cares.

speaker: Maybe your nickname should be Brown Dynamite.
response: Hello, dear friends. And Dr. Hofstadter.

speaker: ‘Sup?
response: ‘Sup? My apologies. I would’ve been here sooner, but the bus kept stopping for other people to get on it.

speaker: I saved you a dumpling.
response: Oh, your concern for me is touching. It will serve you well when you take me to the dentist tomorrow.

speaker: I’m sorry, Sheldon, I’m busy. I’m right in the middle of my addiction study. I’ve got a lab full of alcoholic monkeys, and tomorrow’s the day we switch them to O’Doul’s.
response: You’re my girlfriend and you’re not going to cater to my every need? Oh, where’d the magic go?

speaker: Absolutely. But when Ma’s hips give out, you’re up, kid.
response: Well, if Amy’s too busy, that gives the rest of you an opportunity to make my life easier, thus assuring yourselves a footnote in my memoirs, tentatively entitled You’re Welcome, Mankind. All right, then, just shout when you hear the task you want to undertake. Uh, dentist. Okay, we can circle back to that one. Um, well, who wants to take me Wednesday morning to get new heels put on my dress shoes? Anyone? Oh. That one had hoot written all over it. Um, all right, uh, dermatologist? Allergist? Podiatrist? Supercuts? Okay, okay, here’s a fun one. Um, I need a new picture frame and I have a hankering for Swedish meatballs. Who wants to spend the day with me at IKEA?

speaker: Their meatballs are pretty good.
response: What’s that?

speaker: Oh, hey, Sheldon. Can I help you find something today?
response: No, no. I was just sitting at home thinking about how it might be nice to catch up with my ninth favourite person.

speaker: Ninth?
response: You moved up one. My pen pal in Somalia was kidnapped by pirates. So, uh, how are you?

speaker: Uh, not so good. My shrink just k*ll himself and blamed me in the note.
response: Great. Great. So, what’s new with your family? How’s your mother? Is she alive?

speaker: Yeah.
response: And your father? Alive?

speaker: Yes.
response: How about your grandparents, they alive?

speaker: No.
response: Oh, I’m so sorry for your loss. On a cheerier note, I have a teeth-cleaning appointment this afternoon. What do you say you take me over there, buddy boy?

speaker: I’m sorry, you want me to take you to the dentist?
response: Yes. And now, I can’t make any promises, but that’s the sort of thing that gets a fella on the short list for the number eight friend slot.

speaker: Sheldon, I’m working. I can’t take you to the dentist. Also, and I can’t stress this enough, I don’t want to take you to the dentist.
response: Can’t help a friend out in a time of need, huh? I see where your therapist was coming from.

speaker: ‘Sup?
response: ‘Sup?

speaker: Hey, did you ever make it to the dentist?
response: Not necessary. No. I found a service that’ll send a van to your house for a teeth cleaning. Mostly they cater to dogs, but the fellow on the phone seemed to have an open mind.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, if you need me to take you to the dentist, I will take you to the dentist.
response: Are you suggesting that you’ve come to your senses and wish to re-establish the mutual benefits that stem from full participation in the roommate agreement?

speaker: Ooh, Sock Mouth’s got him on the ropes.
response: I will admit nothing of the sort. And now if you’ll excuse me, I have to call my dentist and see if I can also get my hair shampooed and my nails clipped.

speaker: Because last month, I sent the electric company a Starbucks gift card, an apology note, and a few snapshots of me in a bra.
response: Power failure. Implementing power-failure protocol.

speaker: What happened to all your glow-in-the-dark-emergency-exit stuff you had painted on the floor?
response: Oh, that was wildly carcinogenic. Anyway, it’s too bad you’re no longer entitled to the full benefits of my friendship, because I happen to be extremely prepared for such an emergency. Please try not to see anything by this light. It’s not for you.

speaker: It’s just a blackout, I’m sure the power will be back on soon.
response: And I’m sure some fool in the Donner party said the snow would stop any day now. I like to think they ate him first.

speaker: You know, I got some candles in my apartment.
response: But candles? During a blackout? Are you mad? That’s a fire hazard. No, Pasadena Water and Power recommends the far safer glow stick.

speaker: You call that a glow stick? That is a glow stick. Come on, let’s go.
response: Before you go, consider this. Not only do I have a deep-cycle marine battery power source which is more than capable of running our entertainment system, I also have all 61 episodes of the BBC series Red Dwarf and Fiddle-Faddle. All yours if you’re willing to reinstate the roommate agreement.

speaker: I’ve got wine at my place and some bubble wrap we could pop.
response: Oh, he’ll be back. Wine and a girl in the dark, he’s gonna be bored out of his mind.

speaker: Ugh. Well, lucky for you, there’s nothing else to do right now.
response: Excuse me, Leonard.

speaker: Since when don’t you knock? It’s like the only good thing about you.
response: Social niceties have been suspended, Leonard. We’re in a state of a emergency. The world has descended into darkened turmoil. Lawlessness and savagery are the order of the day.

speaker: Fine, what is it?
response: I’m making s’mores. I wanted to alert you in case you smelled caramelizing marshmallows and thought a nearby candy factory was on fire.

speaker: S’mores, huh? Good for you.
response: Yes, or good for us if you sign here and reinstate the full roommate agreement.

speaker: No, thanks. I’m good.
response: Really? Huh! Okay. In that case, I will have a s’more by myself. And then I’m gonna have s’more. By myself.

speaker: I thought you said candles were dangerous.
response: This is a Bunsen burner. I’m a scientist, I know what I’m doing. Oh, drat. (His s’more is on fire. He dunks it in a glass of water.) Aw. It took me a gallon of urine to make that water.

speaker: Listen, Sheldon, this is stupid. I don’t see why we can’t be friends. And I’m willing to drive you around and help you out with stuff. I just don’t want to do it because of some silly roommate agreement.
response: What are you proposing?

speaker: That we go back to the way things were. But when I do something for you, you show a little appreciation.
response: And how would I do that?

speaker: You say thank you.
response: Every time?

speaker: It’s not crazy.
response: Counter-proposal. We reinstate the full roommate agreement with the following addendum, in the spirit of Mother’s Day or Father’s Day, once a year, we set aside day to celebrate all your contributions to my life, both actual and imagined by you. We could call it Leonard’s Day.

speaker: I kind of like the sound of that.
response: Of course you do. It’s about you, like everything else. (Lights come back on) Oh, thank goodness. I don’t think I had it in me to make another glass of water.

speaker: So, do I get breakfast in bed on Leonard’s Day?
response: No.

speaker: Can I sit in your spot?
response: No.

speaker: Can I control the thermostat?
response: No.

speaker: Do I get a card?
response: Of course you get a card. It’s Leonard’s Day.

speaker: Really. Who do you think did that, Sheldon?
response: Oh, I don’t know. But whoever that mystery man was, you should be eternally grateful, for without him, there would be no Leonard’s Day.

speaker: Leonard’s Day?
response: Oh, no pressure. Just get him a crummy card, you’re good.

speaker: Hmmm.
response: The problem appears to be unsolvable.

speaker: We’ve got to be missing something. Let’s start again. The movie is playing here at 7
response: Right, these theatres have to be eliminated.

speaker: Why? They’re state-of-the-art digital projection, 20-channel surround sound.
response: Yes, but they have no Icee machines. Despite my aggressive letter-writing campaign, I might add.

speaker: What about the multiplex here? The seats are terrific.
response: They have Twizzlers instead of Red Vines. No amount of lumbar support can compensate for that.

speaker: We could eat after the movie.
response: Unacceptable, the delay would result in tomorrow morning’s bowel movement occurring at work.

speaker: Wow. I don’t see how we missed that.
response: Excuse me, in what universe are Slurpies Icees?

speaker: Sheldon, would you be prepared, on a non-precedential basis, to create an emergency ad-hoc Slurpie-Icee equivalency?
response: Oh, Leonard, you know I can’t do that.

speaker: Later, dude.
response: They’re right, it was the only option.

speaker: Ooh, ooh, shut the door, shut the door.
response: Why?

speaker: Just do it! (Penny runs in. Sheldon shuts door. Penny opens door again) Get inside and shut the door.
response: Well, you didn’t specify.

speaker: Is Leonard around?
response: He went to the movies without me. It was the only option. I’m sorry, I don’t understand which social situation this is. Could you give me some guidance as to how to proceed?

speaker: The building manager’s showing an apartment downstairs, and I haven’t paid my rent.
response: Oh, I see. Penny, I’m not sure I’m comfortable harbouring a fugitive from the 2311 North Los Robles Corporation.

speaker: It’s no big deal. I’m just a little behind on my bills because they cut back my hours at the restaurant and my car broke down.
response: If you recall, I pointed out the “check engine” light to you several months ago.

speaker: Well the “check engine” light is fine. It’s still blinking away. It’s the stupid engine that stopped working. It cost me like twelve hundred dollars to fix it.
response: You know, it occurs to me you could solve all your problems by obtaining more money.

speaker: Yes, it occurs to me, too.
response: Hang on a moment. (He opens a jar. Snakes jump out. He then pulls out a large wedge of money) Here. Take some. Pay me back when you can.

speaker: Wow, you got a lot of money in there.
response: That’s why it’s guarded by snakes. Take some.

speaker: Don’t be silly.
response: I’m never silly. Here.

speaker: No, I can’t.
response: Don’t you need money?

speaker: Well, yeah, but…
response: This is money I’m not using.

speaker: But what if you need it?
response: My expenses account for 46.9% of my after-tax income. The rest is divvied up between a small savings account, this deceptive container of peanut brittle and the hollowed-out buttocks of a superhero action figure who shall remain nameless for his own protection. Or her own protection. Take some.

speaker: Really? I mean, are you sure?
response: I see no large upcoming expenditures unless they develop an affordable technology to fuse my skeleton with adamantium like Wolverine.

speaker: Are they working on that?
response: I sincerely hope so.

speaker: Okay. Well, thank you. Oh, God, no, I can’t. Sheldon honey, I don’t want things to be weird between us.
response: Won’t it also be weird if I have to say hello to you every morning on my way to work and you’re living in a refrigerator box and washing your hair with rain water?

speaker: I’ll pay you back as soon as I can.
response: Of course you will. It’s impossible to pay me back sooner than you can. Assuming you subscribe to a linear understanding of time and causality.

speaker: Interesting.
response: Ask me why.

speaker: Do I have to?
response: Of course. That’s how you move a conversation forward.

speaker: Why?
response: The learning opportunities would be abundant. Additionally, I like having my belly scratched.

speaker: Great. I hope I’m a waitress at the Cheesecake Factory for my whole life.
response: Was that sarcasm?

speaker: No.
response: Was that sarcasm?

speaker: Yes.
response: Was that sarca..

speaker: Stop it!
response: Penny, you appear to have a package here.

speaker: Oh, thanks. This must be the beret I ordered. A couple of months ago. It was back-ordered.
response: Did you know the beret is an example of piece of women’s fashion adapted from male military uniforms? Another fascinating example is the epaulet.

speaker: Okay, whatever. It’s not like I’m running up and down the streets just buying myself berets. I bought one, like, a month ago, and it was back-ordered, look, it finally arrived, all right?
response: All right.

speaker: Weird.
response: Oh, good, that was an unusual interaction. I wasn’t sure.

speaker: Did you guys have an argument?
response: No.

speaker: Well, you clearly did something to aggravate her.
response: I’m at a loss. If you like, you can review my daily log of social interactions and see if there’s a blunder I overlooked.

speaker: It was fourteen fifty, but it’s okay.
response: Oh, good. Dinner’s here.

speaker: Yes, dinner’s here, and I’m having some. I’m having takeout food.
response: Okay.

speaker: You’re damn right it’s okay. I’ve been having leftovers at the restaurant for like four days, and I wanted something different. So sue me.
response: Forgive me, Penny, but that would be the very definition of a frivolous lawsuit.

speaker: Going home, where I won’t be interrogated like a criminal. I forgot my fortune cookie.
response: In case either of you have larceny in your heart, you should know that I’ve moved my money out of the snake can.

speaker: Hey, you guys want to go on a real live quest?
response: Outside? I just made cocoa.

speaker: You guys are unbelievable, you play a game to simulate adventure, but when there’s real adventure out there in the real world, you just wimp out.
response: Leonard, do you not recall the last time we visited this gentleman, we returned home without pants?

speaker: I do.
response: Are you sure? Because your proposal suggests that you don’t.

speaker: I’m not afraid of him.
response: All right. Leonard fairly calls the question, who is in favour of abandoning our game and confronting Penny’s steroid-infused ex-boyfriend in a suicidal mission to extract money from him? Say hi to Kurt for us.

speaker: Excuse me. When Frodo left the Shire to take the one ring to Mordor, didn’t Samwise, Pippin and Merry go with him?
response: They did.

speaker: Well?
response: They had a terrible time of it, Leonard.

speaker: Guys, there are four of us and one of him.
response: Which means his triumph will be even larger. Minstrels will write songs about him.

speaker: No. What do you want?
response: You don’t remember me? How could he not remember me?

speaker: Sheldon, not now.
response: I remember him.

speaker: No, the problem isn’t solved. He just blew us off.
response: I’ve got it. He didn’t remember me because the last time we met I was in a Halloween costume.

speaker: Maybe if you’re working on a tuna boat.
response: Hello, Penny.

speaker: Sheldon, here is your money. Thank you very much. It helped a lot.
response: Sarcasm?

speaker: No.
response: Darn. I can’t seem to get the hang of that.

speaker: Bye.
response: Well done, Leonard. The true hero doesn’t seek adulation, he fights for right and justice simply because it’s his nature.

speaker: Penny’s hooking up with her jerk of an ex-boyfriend and I have indelible ink on my forehead!
response: That’s your badge of honour, your warrior’s wound, if you will. I was wrong, minstrels will write songs about you.

speaker: Great.
response: There once was a brave lad named Leonard, with a fi-fi-fiddle-dee-dee. He faced a fearsome giant, while Raj just wanted to pee.

speaker: Kites, ho!
response: Excuse me. Youâ€™re misusing the word ho. Itâ€™s an interjection used to call attention to a destination, not an object, as in, uh, Land, ho! Or, uh, Westward, ho!

speaker: Oh, yeah. Itâ€™s an extremely competitive, cutthroat sport.
response: Well, actually, the risk of throat cutting is very low. On the other hand, severe string burn is a real and ever-Present danger.

speaker: Well, this sucks.
response: Iâ€™m sorry, I got bored and drifted off. Where exactly in the interaction did the sucking lie?

speaker: Leonard just realized that Pennyâ€™s been hiding him from her friends because heâ€™s a tiny, little man who flies kites.
response: Oh, that certainly would suck.

speaker: Why wouldnâ€™t Penny want her friends to meet me?
response: Focus, Leonard, focus! The heat of battle is upon us, the dogs of w*r are unleashed.

speaker: Maybe Koothrappaliâ€™s right, maybe I embarrass her.
response: Youâ€™re embarrassing me right now, a grown man worrying about such nonsense when in the middle of flying kites.

speaker: Sorry.
response: Sorry wonâ€™t bring their kites down. Ow! String burn! String burn!

speaker: Wait, what are you doing? I canâ€™t scissors by myself! Howard! Come back!
response: Victory!

speaker: So, Penny doesnâ€™t want me around her friends, I embarrass her. What else could it be?
response: Well, her actions could be out of concern for your feelings. Perhaps sheâ€™s excluded you from these gatherings because sheâ€™s scouting for a new mate and doesnâ€™t want to do it in front of you.

speaker: Oh, how kind of her.
response: Agreed. Most primates donâ€™t show that sort of discretion. A female bonobo will copulate with a new male in front of the old one without so much as a how do you do?

speaker: With a woman you were chasing through a park? Thatâ€™s not a sh*t, thatâ€™s a felony. Whatâ€™s worse, it cost me my prized Patang fighting kite. Sheldon, I donâ€™t suppose thereâ€™s any chance you could give me my kite back?
response: Iâ€™m sorry, Raj, but the rules of aerial warfare dictate at the fallen kite go to the victor. And without rules, the competition has no meaning. And without meaning, the following would be an empty gesture. (Sings) I have your kite. I have your kite.

speaker: Sacks, sacksâ€¦
response: Itâ€™s football nomenclature for when a quarterback is tackled behind the line of scrimmage.

speaker: Huhâ€¦ Scrimmageâ€¦
response: The line of scrimmage is the imaginary transverse line separating the offence from the defence.

speaker: Sheldon, how do you know this stuff?
response: I grew up in Texas. Football is ubiquitous in Texas. Pro football, college football, high school football, peewee football, in fact, every form of football except the original, European football, which most Texans believe to be a Commie plot.

speaker: Unbelievable.
response: If youâ€™re interested, I also know all about frying meat that isnâ€™t chicken as if it were chicken.

speaker: So you could teach me?
response: Football or chicken-fried meats?

speaker: Football. Iâ€™m going to Pennyâ€™s on Saturday to watch a game with her friends and I donâ€™t want to look like an idiot. I want to blend in.
