response: If you want to blend in with Pennyâ€™s friends, Iâ€™d think looking like an idiot would be the perfect camouflage.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon, please teach me about football. Itâ€™ll be fun.
response: Thatâ€™s exactly what my father said. Come to the games, watch the games, week in and week out from the time I was five until I went off to college. Longest seven years of my life.

speaker: Please, Iâ€™m asking you as a friend.
response: Are you making this a tier one friendship request?

speaker: Yes.
response: Fine.

speaker: I really appreciate this.
response: Yeah, yeah. All right, Poindexter, sit down, shut up and listen.

speaker: Iâ€™m sorry?
response: Thatâ€™s how my father always began our football conversations. And if youâ€™d like, after the game, Iâ€™ll take you outside and teach you how to sh**t close enough to a racoon that it craps itself.

speaker: When are you going to stop making Cylon toast?
response: When I have enough to destroy all the human toast on the battlestar known as Galactica. Is that what youâ€™re wearing to watch football at Pennyâ€™s?

speaker: Whatâ€™s wrong with a football jersey?
response: Nothing. That, however, appears to be a football cocktail dress.

speaker: Iâ€™s the smallest size they had, except the one for dogs. I canâ€™t believe they had one for dogs.
response: Oh, yes. Canine football fans are a common sight in Texas. Cats, however, refuse to wear sporting apparel. My sister found that out the hard way.

speaker: Anyway, wish me luck.
response: Leonard, wait. Am I correct in assuming that your attempt to be accepted by Pennyâ€™s peers is based on your desire to ensure your continuing mating privileges with her?

speaker: Well, I wouldnâ€™t put it exactly that way.
response: How would you put it?

speaker: Yeah, okay, like you said.
response: Huh. Seems like an awful lot of trouble to go through for intercourse. Donâ€™t you have access to women who will do it for money? By the way, another accepted usage for the term ho.

speaker: Good-Bye, Sheldon.
response: Hold on I believe that social convention dictate you not arrive empty-Handed. Would you like to bring some Cylon toast?

speaker: Yeah, no, Iâ€™m trying to fit in, not get laughed at.
response: Whatâ€™s funny about Cylon toast?

speaker: I know. I just need you stop talking.
response: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.

speaker: Sheldon, come in.
response: Thank you. Iâ€™d like to make a sandwich, but Iâ€™m out of bread.

speaker: Thereâ€™s some in the fridge.
response: You shouldnâ€™t keep your bread in the refrigerator. Staleness is caused by crystallization of the starch molecules, which occurs faster at cool temperatures.

speaker: On Earth, we say thank you.
response: So Leonard, how goes the mimesis?

speaker: Mimesis?
response: You know. Mimesis. An action in which the mimic takes on the properties of a specific object or organism. Mimesis.

speaker: What the hell are you talking about?
response: Iâ€™m attempting to communicate with you without my meaning becoming apparent to those around you. Let me try again. Have the indigenous fauna accepted you as one of their own? Nudge, nudge, wink, wink.

speaker: Oh, I guess so.
response: Good. Oh, FYI. After I eat my sandwich, Iâ€™m taking Koothrappaliâ€™s Patang kite out for a test run. Would you like to get your delta-wing raptor and join me?

speaker: I donâ€™t want to fly kites, Sheldon. Weâ€™re watching football here.
response: I can see that. I was providing you with an alternative. A courtesy I was never offered in similar circumstances.

speaker: I’d be more interested in a scene depicting Spock’s conception.
response: Oh, please. For Vulcans, mating, or, if you will, Pon Farr, it’s an extremely private matter.

speaker: Good story. (Clasps hands to mouth in shock.)
response: Well count me out.

speaker: What? Why?
response: You want me to use my intelligence in a tawdry competition? Would you ask Picasso to play Pictionary? Would you ask Noah Webster to play Boggle? Would you ask Jacques Cousteau to play Go Fish?

speaker: Come on, you need a four person team, we’re four people.
response: By that reasoning we should also play bridge, hold up a chuppah and enter the Olympic bobsled competition.

speaker: Sheldon, what, do I need to quote Spock’s dying words to you.
response: No, don’t.

speaker: Outweigh the needs of the few.
response: Or the one. Dammit, I’ll do it.

speaker: I like it.
response: I don’t. Teams are traditionally named after fierce creatures, thus intimidating ones opponent.

speaker: Then we can be the Bengal Tigers.
response: Poor choice. Gram for gram, no animal exceeds the relative fighting strength of the army ant.

speaker: Let’s put it to a vote. All those in favour….
response: Point of order. I move that any vote on team names should be unanimous. No man should be forced to emblazon his chest with the bengal tiger, when common sense dictates it should be an army ant.

speaker: Will the gentleman from the great state of denial yield for a question?
response: I will yield.

speaker: After we go through the exercise of an annoying series of votes, all of which the gentleman will lose, does he then intend to threaten to quit if he does not get his way?
response: He does.

speaker: Yes.
response: Of course.

speaker: Okay, the first question is on the topic of optics. What is the shortest light pulse ever produced? Dr Cooper.
response: And of course, the answer is 130 adoseconds.

speaker: Good for you, sweetie. Okay, next question. What is the quantum mechanical effect used to encode data on hard disk drives? Howard.
response: And of course, the answer is giant magneto resistance.

speaker: Hey, I buzzed in.
response: But I answered, it’s called teamwork.

speaker: Don’t you think I should answer the engineering questions? I am an engineer.
response: By that logic I should answer all the anthropology questions because I’m a mammal.

speaker: Okay. What artificial satellite has seen glimpses of Einsteins predicted frame dragging? (Raj buzzes.)
response: And of course it’s Gravity Probe B.

speaker: Sheldon, you have to let somebody else answer.
response: Why?

speaker: Because it’s polite.
response: What do manners have to do with it? This is w*r. Were the Romans polite when they salted the ground of Carthage to make sure nothing would ever grow again?

speaker: Leonard, you said I only had to ask questions.
response: The objective of the competition is to give correct answers, if I know them, why shouldn’t I give them?

speaker: Some of us might have the correct answers too.
response: Oh please, you don’t even have a PhD.

speaker: maybe we should take a little break.
response: Good idea, I need my wrist brace, all this button pushing is aggravating my old Nintendo injury.

speaker: Can it wait, I need to talk to you.
response: Just look. I’ve designed the perfect uniforms for our team. The colours are based on Star Trek, the original series. The three of you will wear support red, and I will wear command gold.

speaker: Why do they say AA?
response: Army Ants.

speaker: Isn’t that confusing? AA might mean something else to certain people.
response: Why would a physics bowl team be called anodised aluminium?

speaker: No, I meant…. never mind. Hey, check it out. I got you a Batman cookie jar!
response: Oh neat, what’s the occasion?

speaker: Well, you’re a friend, and you like Batman, and cookies, and you’re off the team.
response: What?

speaker: Howard, Raj and I just had a team meeting.
response: No you didn’t.

speaker: Yes we did, I just came from it.
response: Okay, I don’t know where you just came from, but it couldn’t have been a team meeting because I’m on the team and I wasn’t there, ergo the team did not meet.

speaker: Okay, let me try it this way, uh, I was at a coffee klatch with a couple of friends and one thing led to another and it turns out you’re off the team.
response: Why?

speaker: Because you’re taking all the fun out of it.
response: Well, I’m sorry, is the winner of the physics bowl the team that has the most fun?

speaker: Okay, let me try it this way, you’re annoying and no-one wants to play with you any more.
response: I see. Well. At this point I should inform you that I intend to form my own team and destroy the molecular bonds that bind your very matter together, and reduce the resulting particulate chaos to tears.

speaker: Thanks for the heads up.
response: You’re welcome. One more thing.

speaker: Yes.
response: It’s on, bitch.

speaker: So nothing, let’s destroy him.
response: Gentlemen.

speaker: Oh, no, no, I want to. It sounds really interesting.
response: Gentlemen.

speaker: So, is that your team.
response: Actually, I don’t need a team, I could easily defeat you single-handedly. But the rules require four, so may I introduce, the third floor janitor, he lady from the lunchroom, and, my Spanish is not good, either her son or her butcher. And what about your team? What rat have you recruited to the SS Sinking Ship?

speaker: Hello, Sheldon.
response: Leslie Winkle?

speaker: Yeah, Leslie Winkle. The answer to the question, who made Sheldon Cooper cry like a little girl?
response: Yes, well, I’m polymerised tree sap and you’re non-organic adhesive so, whatever verbal projectile you launch in my direction is reflected off of me, returns on its original trajectory, and adheres to you.

speaker: Correct.
response: Formal protest.

speaker: On what grounds?
response: The Velcro on my wrist brace caught on my shirt.

speaker: Denied. Alright, for ten points, what is the lightest element on earth with no stable isotope. (Buzz) AA?
response: And of course, the answer is Technetium.

speaker: Correct.
response: 4.1855 times ten to the seventh ergs per calorie.

speaker: Prevost’s theory of exchanges.
response: Lamda equals one over Pi R squared N

speaker: Mr Wolowitz, this is your second warning.
response: A sigma particle.

speaker: The answer is minus eight by alpha.
response: Hang on, hang on a second, that’s not our answer. What are you doing?

speaker: Answering question. Winning physics bowl.
response: How do you know anything about physics?

speaker: Here I am janitor, in former Soviet Union I am physicist. Leningrad Politechnica. Go Polar Bears.
response: Well that’s a delightful little story, but our arrangement was that you sit here and not say anything, I answer the questions.

speaker: You didn’t answer question.
response: Hey look, now maybe you have democracy now in your beloved Russia, but on this physics bowl team I rule with an iron fist. (Makes fist in the air). Ow!

speaker: AA, I need your official answer.
response: Well it’s not what he said.

speaker: Then what is it?
response: I want a different question.

speaker: You can’t have a different question.
response: Formal protest.

speaker: Denied.
response: Informal protest.

speaker: Denied. I need your official answer.
response: No. I decline to provide one.

speaker: Well, that’s too bad, because the answer your teammate gave was correct.
response: That’s your opinion.

speaker: Hang on. Sheldon, is proving that you are single-handedly smarter than everyone else so important that you would rather lose by yourself than win as part of a team.
response: I don’t understand the question.

speaker: Sorry, somebody’s sitting there.
response: Who?

speaker: My Physics Bowl Trophy!
response: That trophy is meaningless, I forfeited, therefore you did not win.

speaker: I know someone who would disagree.
response: Who?

speaker: My Physics Bowl Trophy! (In weird voice) “Leonard is so smart, Sheldon who?”
response: Alright that is very immature.

speaker: I’m settling once and for all who is the smartest around here. Okay, are you ready?
response: Absolutely.

speaker: Okay. Marsha, Jan and Cindy were the three daughters of what TV family? (They stare at her.) The Brady Bunch. Okay, Sammy Hagar replaced David Lee Roth as the lead singer in what group?
response: The Brady Bunch?

speaker: I go outside and I talk to people. Alright, here, what actor holds the record for being named people magazine’s sexiest man alive?
response: William Shatner.

speaker: Wait, I don’t think it’s Shatner.
response: Then it’s got to be Patrick Stewart.

speaker: No.
response: Formal protest.

speaker: Alright, singer who sang “Oops I Did It Again.” (Sheldon starts involuntarily twitching again.) Okay, Tweetie Bird, taught he taw a what?
response: Romulan.

speaker: Item 28, your pet name for me. Time’s running out on this. You need to make a decision.
response: I submitted you a notarised list.

speaker: I’m sorry, but Gollum and Flakey are not acceptable.
response: Well, you don’t like Princess Corncob, you don’t like Fester, you’re just impossible to please.

speaker: We’ll come back to that one. This brings us to the final item in our annual State of the Relationship Summit. Item 29, Valentine’s Day.
response: Ah, the worst for last. Hmm. Classic Flakey.

speaker: Before you get upset, I believe I’ve come up with a way for us to celebrate the occasion that we both can enjoy.
response: People usually start a meeting with a joke, but you go ahead, end with one.

speaker: I propose we spend a weekend at a bed-and-breakfast in Napa Valley.
response: I hate every word in that sentence. Including in, at, we and a.

speaker: Come on, Sheldon. Why not?
response: For starters, a bed-and-breakfast forces you to eat with strangers at your table.

speaker: One step ahead of you, Bernadette and Wolowitz are going with us.
response: Oh, very well. What are the sleeping arrangements? We’ve only been dating for three years. If we were to share a room, people might talk.

speaker: I got you your own room.
response: What if my room has a claw-foot bathtub?

speaker: It doesn’t. I know it makes you feel like you’re bathing inside a monster.
response: Look, I appreciate the effort, but I’m still unclear how this trip is supposed to be enjoyable for me.

speaker: We’re going to have Valentine’s Day dinner on a fully functioning vintage train.
response: Vintage? Be specific.

speaker: An Alcoa FA-4 diesel locomotive leading a train of meticulously restored 1915 Pullman first-class coaches.
response: Wow. I’m feeling the urge to hug you. And one, and two, all right, Gollum, we’re good.

speaker: That would really piss me off if I didn’t have a buzz going on.
response: Howard, which pocket watch will you be wearing for dinner on the train?

speaker: I’m sorry, what?
response: Oh, I’m afraid if we wear the same pocket watch, it will be embarrassing.

speaker: I don’t own a pocket watch.
response: Oh, my. Well, then my apologies for bringing up this sore spot.

speaker: What do you think, Sheldon?
response: It’s magnificent. This is going to be the best Valentine’s Day ever.

speaker: I’m so glad you like it.
response: I’m prepared to say I love it, as soon as I confirm there are no hobos aboard.

speaker: And for the entrée, tonight’s special is a seafood risotto. Do you have any questions?
response: Uh, I do. Uh, does this train car have the original link-and-pin coupler or the Miller Hook and Platform?

speaker: I’m sorry, I meant questions about the food.
response: Oh, of course. Um, is the seafood risotto being served on a train car with the original link-and-pin coupler or the Miller Hook and Platform?

speaker: Fun fact, it’s neither. They actually use the AAR type E coupler. If you listen carefully when the locomotive disconnects, you’ll hear the characteristic click-pshht-thunk of the knuckle.
response: Get out of town.

speaker: Okay. Here’s my impression of the Amtrak Acela barreling down the Eastern Corridor. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh. Wch-wch-wch-wch-shhhh.
response: It’s like there’s a train in your mouth. Howard

speaker: See if you guys can guess this one. Bang. Splat. Thud.
response: How many trains have you been on?

speaker: Tons. A box fell on my head at UPS six years ago. Now I just collect disability and ride trains.
response: Wow. Your life’s amazing.

speaker: Excuse me. You are at Valentine’s dinner with your girlfriend. Now get back over there and be with her.
response: You’re right. That was insensitive of me. I have to go back to my table now. You should join us.

speaker: Okay, what was the best four-ten-four U.S. Locomotive ever built?
response: Trick question. There never was one.

speaker: Or was there?
response: What?

speaker: In 1944, the Pacific Railroad built number 6131, which rearranged the drivers and cylinders, solving the problem of the Q-1, creating a duplex-drive four-four-six-four.
response: In what world is a four-four-six-four a four-ten-four?

speaker: Hold on to your conductor’s hat. You crank the second and third axles, creating a pair of internal connecting rods, and boom, four-ten-four. If you think about it, the Q-2 was like the four-ten-four America never made.
response: I may never stop thinking about it. Amy, what are the odds we run into this guy?

speaker: You know, if you ask nicely, they’ll let you visit the engine room.
response: I never want this day to end.

speaker: It’s feeling like it never will.
response: Come on.

speaker: You guys missed a pretty great time.
response: The conductor and I have the same pocket watch.

speaker: It was crazy.
response: Dare I say loco? Oh, and, Amy, guess what? The conductor said as soon as he gets off work, he can come back to the bed and breakfast and play his banjo for us.

speaker: Why are you still here?
response: Excuse me. I think you’re being a little rude.

speaker: I’m being rude? You’ve been rude to me this entire evening.
response: How is that possible? I’ve hardly spoken to you since we got on the train.

speaker: I’m detecting a little friction between you two, and I don’t want to be a third rail. Get it?
response: I get it.

speaker: Leave.
response: What is your problem?

speaker: It’s Valentine’s Day. We’re supposed to be having a romantic weekend.
response: Oh, really? Because I remember you saying that this trip was going to be something we could both enjoy. Did you mean that, or were you just trying to trick me?

speaker: Fine, it’s true. I deserve romance, and I didn’t know how else to make it happen.
response: Well, if you want romance, then let’s have romance. Oh, look, there’s wine. Mmm. Grape juice that burns. Uh, now let’s gaze into each other’s eyes, hmm? You blinked. I win.

speaker: Sheldon.
response: Let’s see. What’s next? Oh, kissing’s romantic.

speaker: That was nice.
response: Good. Um, the conductor said if I come back to the engine room, he’d show me how to bring the train through a crossing.

speaker: Okay, have fun.
response: Do you want to come with me?

speaker: Oh, hey. You’re back. How was your trip?
response: It was wonderful.

speaker: Great. What did you do?
response: I made a new friend who likes trains as much as I do, uh, I kissed Amy on the lips, and, uh, the conductor played his banjo for me. Good night.

speaker: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. I’m gonna need more details.
response: Oh, well, my new friend’s name was Eric. Um, Amy lips tasted like the brownie we had for dessert. Oh, and the banjo-playing conductor was missing a finger, but he made up for it with his can-do attitude.

speaker: No, hang on. Hang on. Are all those things equal to you?
response: Hmm. It never occurred to me to pick a favourite.

speaker: Well, give it a go.
response: I can’t answer that without collecting additional data.

speaker: Additional data. You dog.
response: I’m not sure how listening to other nine-fingered banjo players makes me dog, but all right.

speaker: What do you think about it, Sheldon?
response: Meh.

speaker: Are you kidding me? This may be the biggest scientific breakthrough of our lifetime. How can you, as a theoretical physicist, not care about this?
response: Maybe it’s because I’m not an elitist. What I’d like to know is, how does this gravity wave breakthrough help the man on the street? You know? Who’s looking out for Joe six-pack and all his quantum physics concerns?

speaker: Oh, my God, you’re jealous.
response: Why would I be jealous?

speaker: Oh, I don’t know. Maybe because the origin of the universe just got proven, the Higgs field just got proven, and you’ve been working on string theory for the last 20 years and you’re no closer to proving it than when you started.
response: Yeah, well, I’ve had a lot on my plate. We happen to live in a golden age of television.

speaker: Excuse me, fewwas. Sowwy for eavesdwopping, but there actually was some big stwing theowy news today out of the Hadwon Cowwider.
response: Really? Did they find evidence to support extra dimensions or supersymmetry?

speaker: No, but they did find evidence that you’ll bewieve anything.
response: Why would you do that? You’re a string theorist as well.

speaker: Incowwect. I am a stwing pwagmatist. I say I’m gonna pwove something that cannot be pwoved, I appwy for gwant money, and then I spend it on wiquor and bwoads. Water.
response: Do you think he’s right? Am I wasting my life on a theory that can never be proven?

speaker: Hey, you’re up early.
response: I couldn’t sleep.

speaker: I told you those Walking Dead pillowcases were a bad idea.
response: No, that’s not it.

speaker: Is something bothering you?
response: Yes, but you wouldn’t understand.

speaker: Oh, come on, try me.
response: All right. I’ve devoted the prime of my life to string theory and its quest for the compactification of extra dimensions. I’ve got nothing to show for it, and I feel like a fool.

speaker: Okay. I get it. I mean, not all the jibberjabber in the middle, but I know what it’s like to put your heart and soul into something and get nothing out of it.
response: You mean your acting career?

speaker: No.
response: Your relationship with Leonard?

speaker: No.
response: Your failed attempt to go back to college?

speaker: No. I’m saying you and string theory sound like a relationship, and I know what it’s like to be in one and realize it’s never gonna turn out the way you want.
response: I said Leonard, you said no.

speaker: I’m talking about other guys.
response: Okay. Well, what do you do?

speaker: You have to have the courage to end the relationship. You know? Break it off, shake hands, walk away.
response: I don’t know if I can do that.

speaker: Penny, have you seen my good inhaler?
response: Break it off, shake hands, walk away.

speaker: She is. But I like that attitude.
response: Gentlemen, is anybody interested in my old string theory books?

speaker: You’re really going to do this?
response: I am. Yeah, Penny pointed out that what I’m going through is essentially a breakup. And according to Cosmopolitan magazine, one of the most effective techniques for moving on is to get rid of all reminders of the relationship.

speaker: You’re reading Cosmo?
response: Yes. As it turns out, there’s an article on how to get over a breakup in literally every issue. Anyway, it suggests that I set these on fire, but the smell of burning books reminds me of church picnics in East Texas.

speaker: What’s this?
response: Oh, that’s just a doodle of a hyperelliptic Riemann surface.

speaker: Oh, yeah. Wasn’t that the basis of your postdoc fellowship?
response: It was. This seemed so elegant at the time, but now I realize I was just a simple country boy seduced by a big city theory with variables in all the right places.

speaker: It’s going to be okay.
response: I know. As hard as this is, I have to move on. I can’t keep postulating multidimensional entities and get nothing in return. I have needs, too.

speaker: Are you sure you want to do this?
response: The magazine articles suggest that one of the ways to get over a breakup is a new look.

speaker: Oh my God, I do look like that.
response: You stop it.

speaker: So, how do you want me to cut it?
response: Oh, how about Bill Gates meets Nikola Tesla?

speaker: Or I don’t cut it and maybe just style it a little.
response: Oh, I’m in your hands. Do a good job and I’ll tell you Cosmo’s ten dynamite tips to enjoy your PMS.

speaker: That doesn’t work any more. He just thinks I’m taking him to the doctor. So, now that you’re no longer invested in string theory, what are you gonna pursue?
response: Oh, there are so many exciting areas. Black holes, dark matter.

speaker: Oh, Leonard was telling me about dark matter, but I didn’t really understand it.
response: Don’t feel bad. Neither does he.

speaker: Okay, what do you think?
response: Have you ever even seen a picture of Tesla?

speaker: Yeah.
response: I suppose I could see myself in a scientific boy band. Of course, I’d be the dreamy one and the smart one.

speaker: Yeah, it’s cute. That’s the problem. I don’t need other girls to see him walking around like sex on a stick.
response: She’s right. I’m too hot.

speaker: Sheldon, your food’s getting cold. What are you doing?
response: Oh, looking through my textbooks for a new field of inquiry. Why do we have a geology book? Leonard, did you throw a children’s party while I was in Texas?

speaker: Wait. What’s wrong with geology?
response: Let me put this in a way you’ll understand, Penny. You remember how you explained to me that the Kardashians aren’t real celebrities? Well, geology is the Kardashians of science.

speaker: Maybe you could make your new field of study the calculation of nuclear matrix elements.
response: Oh, please. If I wanted to take up a fad, I’d get a tramp stamp.

speaker: What about loop quantum gravity?
response: Oh, Duchess, look at me. My quantum gravity’s positively loopy.

speaker: Sheldon, have you ever considered not rushing into something new? I mean, why don’t you take your time, enjoy your freedom? Maybe something new to study will find you.
response: That’s actually not bad advice. You know, I didn’t seek out string theory. It just hit me over the head one day.

speaker: How does that happen?
response: A bully chased me through the school library and hit me over the head with the biggest book he could find.

speaker: Okay, how about we toast your newfound freedom?
response: Ah, normally I refrain from alcohol, but since my cerebral cortex is twiddling its proverbial thumbs, why not soak it in grape juice that’s been predigested by a fungus?

speaker: Come on, let’s get you to bed. You’ve had a lot to drink.
response: No more than Penny.

speaker: That’s what I’m saying.
response: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. (Knock, knock, knock) Empty room. (Knock, knock, knock) Empty room. (Knock, knock, knock) Empty room. If somebody says come in, I’m gonna freak out.

speaker: How you feeling?
response: Not so good.

speaker: Are you gonna introduce me to your friend?
response: It’s not my friend. Nothing happened.

speaker: I don’t know. I heard you reading pretty loud last night.
response: Oh, dear Lord. Where’s Amy?

speaker: After she put you to bed, she went home.
response: Oh. I should call her and apologize. Oh, no.

speaker: What?
response: Apparently, I called Stephen Hawking last night.

speaker: First new message.
response: Hawkman. It’s your old buddy Sheldonoscopy. How come you didn’t pick up the phone? Oh, right. My bad.

speaker: You’re awful quiet. Everything okay?
response: Not really. I had a bit of an embarrassing evening.

speaker: Ugh. Me, too. What happened?
response: I drank alcohol and may have left an unfortunate voice mail for Stephen Hawking.

speaker: I wouldn’t worry about it. He’s got a pretty good sense of humour.
response: Oh, I hope so. What happened to you last night?

speaker: Oh, well, turns out I’d already met the girl Raj is seeing when I did a number on her bathroom. And that number was two.
response: Well, you know, I’ve always been a fan of a story told by Attar of Nishapur, about a king who assembled a group of wise men to create a ring that would make him happy when he was sad. And that ring was inscribed with the phrase, this too shall pass.

speaker: Whatever you say, Cwogziwwa.
response: Clogzilla. That’s pretty funny. I don’t think that’s gonna pass.

speaker: Next message.
response: It’s me again. I gave up string theory. You should give up black holes, and we can totally solve crimes together.

speaker: Next message.
response: Do you know what’s great? Geology. Oh. Look at this geode. That’s fun to say. Gee-ode. Gee-ode.

speaker: Next message.
response: Gee-ode. Gee-ode. I kiss girls now.

speaker: Next message.
response: Hey, guess who I am. Beep bop boop bop. I’m you. Get it?

speaker: Next message.
response: Are you mad at me? Oh, no, you’re mad at me. I’m so sorry. Beep bop boop bop.

speaker: Next message.
response: Thiospinel sulfide. Thiospinel sulfide. That’s even more fun than gee-ode. Hey, did you see The Lego Movie?

speaker: Uh, yeah, I just need to throw in a few last minute things, you know, makeup, underwear, clothes.
response: If your bathroom floor counts as a carry-on, you're packed.

speaker: Nope. It's pretty exciting.
response: Aren't you afraid of being blinded?

speaker: How would I be blinded?
response: At the end of the ceremony, all the students throw those pointy hats in the air. It's all pomp and circumstance until someone loses an eye.

speaker: I'll take my chances.
response: Fine. I wonder if they make I told you so cards in braille.

speaker: With a beautiful girl on your arm.
response: And a pointy hat sticking out of your eyeball.

speaker: Okay, the WiFi extender is on, the camera's on, they're both on the same network; we should be getting an image.
response: All I see is a black screen. And my own reflection. I look sad.

speaker: Maybe we should recalibrate it.
response: All right.

speaker: Step one, rapidly flip the calibration switch from the fully up to the fully down positions for at least ten times.
response: It actually says "at least"?

speaker: Yeah.
response: Why would they say "at least"? Is it ten toggles? Is it a hundred toggles? You know? Is it a thousand toggles? Ten thousand toggles? A hundred thousand toggles?

speaker: Sheldon.
response: You see where I'm going with this.

speaker: Just flip the switch until the lights on the drone change to solid yellow.
response: All right, that seems simple enough. Initiating calibration sequence. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten. Well, I suppose ten is technically "at least ten". But they're still getting at least one angry letter.

speaker: Now I rotate it horizontally on its centre axis until the lights turn green.
response: Initiating rotation sequence. Don't look at me, initiate. Oh... What does red and yellow mean?

speaker: It means the calibration failed. We have to start over.
response: Oh. Very well. Re-initiating calibration sequence. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten... eleven. It's a good thing I didn't send that letter.

speaker: No red and yellow, no red and yellow.
response: Yay.

speaker: It's green.
response: We did it. Oh, if it's this much fun to rotate, imagine when we fly it.

speaker: Okay, now all I have to do is rotate it vertically until the lights turn off.
response: Oh, no.

speaker: Oh. All right, playtime's over. Let's open this baby up.
response: Won't that void the warranty?

speaker: Boy, oh, boy, that's a lot of pieces.
response: You know what they all do, right?

speaker: Yes, of course.
response: What about this one?

speaker: Well, I, how familiar are you with miniaturized integrated logic circuits?
response: Not very.

speaker: That right there is a miniaturized integrated logic circuit.
response: So, can you get it working?

speaker: I'm an MIT-trained engineer. I've built components for the space station.
response: I thought the zero-gravity toilet didn't work.

speaker: Hey.
response: Hello.

speaker: I have to return the helicopter. My father... What did you do?
response: Well, don't worry. He went to MIT. He can solve any problem, as long as it doesn't originate in a Russian man's colon.

speaker: No, you have to put this back together right now, so I can return it.
response: You can't return it. Howard wiped his bottom with the warranty.

speaker: What?
response: I think metaphorically. But he was in the bathroom for a while.

speaker: Okay, I think I've narrowed it down to a faulty pin on the onboard communication chip.
response: Very impressive. You know, when you're done with that, can you look at this? It doesn't make smoke anymore.

speaker: One toy at a time.
response: Mm. Sorry. Ah, maybe it's for the best. I hear locomotive smoke is the second leading cause of death among train aficionados.

speaker: su1c1de.
response: Wrong. Obesity.

speaker: It's not about the money. It's about solving a problem. It's why I became an engineer. It's what I like to do, it's what I'm trained to do. It's who I am.
response: Oh, look at you, the little engineer that could.

speaker: Hey.
response: Whoa.

speaker: Ha-ha.
response: You call tech support.

speaker: All right, the power supply is reconnected. I think we're back in business. Let's just run a few tests before we take it outside. Sheldon, we got WiFi?
response: Check.

speaker: Battery charged?
response: Check.

speaker: Four, three, two, one.
response: That's what my train used to do.

speaker: What happened to me? When did I become an old man baffled by modern technology? Next thing you know, I'll be hitching my pants up to my armpits and complaining about the awful music the kids are listening to.
response: It is awful, isn't it? Listen to that noise.

speaker: Well, I'm not flying it.
response: Then who is?

speaker: I don't know. Must be getting a WiFi signal from somewhere else.
response: Initiate landing sequence. Initiate landing sequence. (screams) Hey, the camera's working. Oh, look, it's me. (screams)

speaker: Tech Support, can I help you?
response: Yes, it's a robot uprising. Call the police.

speaker: Oh, sweetie, it was the best speech I...
response: Don't worry, everyone in here is safe.

speaker: Sheldon, you’re wrong. Wolverine was not born with bone claws.
response: Howard, you know me to be a very smart man. Don’t you think if I were wrong, I’d know it?

speaker: Give it up, dude, you’re arguing with a crazy person.
response: I’m not crazy. My mother had me tested.

speaker: Okay, who had Leonard flames out with Penny in less than 24 hours”?
response: I did.

speaker: What’s there to learn? You get naked, do nasty things to each other, then somebody makes scrambled eggs and salami. Easy peasy.
response: Perhaps what Leonard is obliquely referring to is the occurrence of some sort of sexual dysfunction.

speaker: Okay, who had Leonard gets a floppy disk?
response: Oh, a clever, albeit obsolete, euphemism for insufficient blood flow to the male sex organ.

speaker: That’s because in your dreams you’re a horse from the waist down.
response: Excuse me, Wolverine

speaker: Sheldon, dinner’s here.
response: Tandoori Palace?

speaker: No, we went somewhere new.
response: You’re good-naturedly ribbing me, aren’t you?

speaker: No, look, Mumbai Palace.
response: Why? Why would we change? We had a perfectly good palace. Tandoori Palace is our palace.

speaker: I don’t know
response: I know. As I’m sure you’re aware…

speaker: Duh-duh-duh-duh-duh-duh.
response: If that’s Morse code, that’s terrible. As I was saying, you and Leonard had a disappointing sexual encounter. Earlier this evening, Leonard characterized it as just fine. So what you’re seeing here is a continuation of the mocking that followed.

speaker: Penny, wait. Aagh! What is wrong with you?
response: I sense I may have crossed some sort of line.

speaker: Whatever, dude. The point is, Leonard’s got one and you don’t.
response: Is this it? It was inappropriate to discuss Leonard and Penny’s sex life in front of Leonard and Penny. (Howard indicates that he has got it.) Oh, good! Now I can eat.

speaker: Sounds like a cricket.
response: Hang on. Based on the number of chirps per minute and the ambient temperature in this room, it is a snowy tree cricket.

speaker: Oh, give me a frickin’ break. How could you possibly know that?
response: In 1890, Emile Dolbear determined that there was a fixed relationship between the number of chirps per minute of the snowy tree cricket and the ambient temperature. A precise relationship that is not present with ordinary field crickets.

speaker: How do you know what the exact temperature of the room is?
response: Under the terms of my roommate agreement with Leonard, I’ve had unilateral control of the thermostat ever since the sweaty night of ‘06.

speaker: Okay, you were right about Wolverine and bone claws, but you’re wrong about the cricket.
response: Howard, don’t embarrass yourself, the science chirps for itself. Humorous word play.

speaker: Oh, dude, you are never getting a shiksa goddess.
response: That is a snowy tree cricket. Oecanthus fultoni. I was done with Latin by fifth grade.

speaker: Okay, okay, tell you what. I am willing to bet anything that’s an ordinary field cricket.
response: I can’t take your money.

speaker: What’s the matter, you chicken?
response: I’ve always found that an inappropriate slur. Chickens are not, by nature, at all timid. In fact, when I was young, my neighbour’s chicken got loose and chased me up the big elm tree in front of our house.

speaker: Chickens can’t climb trees
response: Thank God.

speaker: Okay, I believe a chicken made you his bitch. But the cricket thing, I don’t buy. Bet me.
response: Fair enough. What stake do you propose?

speaker: I will put up my Fantastic Four number 48, first appearance of Silver Surfer against your Flash 123, the classic Flash of two worlds issue.
response: All right, you have a wager.

speaker: Hallway. (All try to exit at once and get stuck in doorway.)
response: One at a time. (Same thing happens again. Eventually they leave the apartment. There is a growling noise.) What was that?

speaker: Shh! Elevator shaft.
response: Help me open it.

speaker: Are you crazy? We can’t go down an empty elevator shaft.
response: Fine, if you don’t want to proceed, then you forfeit the bet, and I’ll take possession of your Fantastic Four.

speaker: Let’s open her up.
response: Are you bothered that I can so easily manipulate you?

speaker: Don’t push me, Sheldon. I may be small, but I took kung fu when I was 13, and I remember a good deal of it.
response: Oh, really? Well, I grew up with an older brother and a very contentious twin sister and I believe I could easily best you in any physical confrontation, be it noogies, swirlies or the classic why are you hitting yourself?

speaker: Be careful.
response: If I were not being careful, your telling me to be careful would not make me careful.

speaker: Stairwell.
response: Uh-oh, flashlight went out. I need some batteries. Fellas? Hello? It’s really dark down here.

speaker: Ugh, Toby, what did you do in a past life to be so disgusting now?
response: His name isn’t Toby. Toby is an absurd name for a cricket.

speaker: What would you name him?
response: An appropriate cricket name. For example, Jiminy.

speaker: All right, Sheldon, here we go, Kleingast’s Field Guide to North American Insects. Hey, Toby. Right here, see it? The common field cricket, aka Gryllus assimilis, which is Latin for suck it, you lose.
response: Hang on. Voilà, the snowy tree cricket, aka Oecanthus fultoni, which is Latin for I’ll suck nothing. Of course I’m joking because the Latin for that is nihil exsorbibo.

speaker: What happened?
response: Obviously another carnal fiasco with the shiksi goddess.

speaker: Shiksa. Shik-sa.
response: Forgive me. Yiddish was not spoken in east Texas. And if it was, it wasn’t spoken for long.

speaker: Yeah, fine, whatever. The point is, you’re wrong again.
response: We haven’t established that I’m wrong once.

speaker: All right. Tell you what, let’s go down to the Entomology Department and let Professor
response: He’s a snowy tree cricket, and his name is Jiminy. (They leave)

speaker: Yeah, well, I don’t like bugs, okay? They freak me out.
response: Interesting. You’re afraid of insects and women. Ladybugs must render you catatonic. It was a joke. I made it to lessen your discomfort. You’re welcome

speaker: Don’t knock. Just walk in. Why be polite to the world’s leading expert on the dung beetle?
response: Excuse me, are you Professor Crawley?

speaker: Who wants to know?
response: I’m Dr. Cooper from the Physics Department.

speaker: Couldn’t wait, huh?
response: I’m sorry?

speaker: I’m from New Delhi. Maybe you should find another entomologist.
response: No, no. We’re here, let’s settle this. Professor, can you identify our cricket?

speaker: Toby? What a stupid name for a cricket.
response: Told you.

speaker: Yes!
response: No, no, wait. Dr. Crawley, are you sure?

speaker: Young man, I’ve been studying insects since I was eight years old. You know what they used to call me in school? Creepy Crawley.
response: Cruel as that may be, that is not in itself a credential.

speaker: Let me show you something. See that? That’s a Crawley’s dung beetle. I discovered it after spending six months slogging through a Bornean rain forest, while my wife was back home shacking up with a two-bit ornithologist who lives on a sailboat and likes to wear boot-cut jeans! So, when I tell you that that’s a common field cricket, you can take that to the damn bank! Cause God knows I can’t. That tramp took me for everything!
response: Well, apparently, I was wrong. Congratulations.

speaker: Oh, hey, Sheldon. What you got there? A new comic book?
response: Old comic book. I just retrieved it from my safe deposit box.

speaker: What do you have a safe deposit box for?
response: Old comic books. I lost this to Wolowitz in an ill-considered cricket wager.

speaker: What, do they have Wii cricket now? That can’t be very popular.
response: Penny, I’d rather not talk about it.

speaker: Well, if it makes you feel any better, I’m not feeling so hot either.
response: Why would that make me feel better?

speaker: I don’t know, empathy? Anyway, I’m just saying that you’re feeling upset about something with Howard, and I’m upset about something with Leonard.
response: Yes, yes, the disappointing sex. That’s an inexact parallel. You and Leonard can always return to being friends, whereas I can never return to a state in which Wolowitz has not bested me like Mrs. Riley’s chicken.

speaker: What’s Mrs. Riley’s chicken?
response: A chicken that was owned by Mrs. Riley.

speaker: Okay, forget the chicken.
response: Well, I wish I could.

speaker: No, no. You may be right about me and Leonard.
response: Of course I’m right What are the odds I’d be wrong twice in one week?

speaker: No, I mean, we can always go back to being friends.
response: I just said that. This conversation has started to circle. Meeting adjourned.

speaker: Hey. What’s going on?
response: Oh, you’d like to catch up on the events of the day. All right. Well, there was a half-hour wait at the bank to get into my safe deposit box, I was forced to talk to Penny about your sexual problems, and, oh, yes, in a moment filled with biblical resonance, pride wenteth before my fall, causing my Flash 123 to goeth to Wolowitz.

speaker: Wait a minute. You talked to Penny about our sex life?
response: Leonard, it astonishes me how you continually fixate on the trivial. I lost a bet to Wolowitz.

speaker: Right, right. You’re saying you talked to Penny?
response: Yes.

speaker: Interesting.
response: Hardly.

speaker: Excuse me.
response: Have I crossed some sort of line again?

speaker: Little bit. (Exits)
response: Hmm. Oh, who cares?
